name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, I propose that this House establish a special debate on the issue of Germany's debts to Greece, because a text has been circulated in which it appears that the representatives of the factions, without discussing with their groups, have decided that there is no issue. There is a question, both legally and ethically. I don't want to develop it now. I am simply proposing and asking for your approval for a special debate in plenary on the subject.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Thank you very much, Mr Glezos. Under our rules of procedure, I cannot now put this request up for discussion here. My recommendation would be that you should contact your group chairman, Mrs Zimmer, who may then be able to submit such a request on behalf of your group to the group conference, or you should collect 40 signatures from 40 Members. We will then be able to discuss whether to put this item on the agenda.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the council and Commission declarations on the preparation of the informal meeting of Heads of State or Government (12 February 2015) (2014/2940(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, today’s debate on the preparation of the informal meeting of Heads of States or Government comes at a time full of challenges. We have just marked the first month after the brutal terrorist attacks in Paris. These attacks targeted our common values – democracy, solidarity, basic freedoms, including freedom of expression, tolerance and human dignity. The shockwave has spread far beyond European borders and there has been a firm joint response – an unprecedented expression of unity and solidarity, and the firm conviction that terrorist attacks should not be tolerated. We have no time to waste. We must work on efficient measures to protect our societies and citizens from fear – from the fear of terrorist attacks, from the fear of radicalisation, and from the fear of intolerance. The informal meeting will discuss ways to strengthen further our fight against terrorism. While Member States have the primary responsibility for combating terrorism, measures taken at EU level will have added value in many ways. The EU has a long-standing counter-terrorism strategy, with measures in various areas supporting Member States’ counter-terrorism policies. However, recent events have shown that there is scope for stepping up our actions. In the past four weeks the Council has put a lot of effort into this. All relevant ministers – justice and home affairs, foreign affairs, finance, culture and others – have worked intensely to accelerate and improve our fight against terrorism. As a result of discussions among the Ministers for Home Affairs and Justice, the Riga Joint Statement was adopted. It outlines a further comprehensive set of measures to address the current threat: namely, prevention of radicalisation, information-sharing and cooperation between competent authorities, prevention of illegal trafficking in firearms, and the reinforcement of external borders. We expect the Commission to present its communication on the EU Internal Security Strategy by mid-April 2015 so that it can be reviewed and updated by mid-2015. Also, the Finance Ministers discussed further steps to be taken to combat the financing of terrorism and, together with the Commission, adopted a joint declaration with a view to more efficient application of the rules in the anti-money laundering package. With regard to further work on external aspects of counter-terrorism, the Foreign Affairs Ministers agreed on strengthening engagement with third countries, swift implementation of counter-terrorism measures, a strategy on foreign terrorist fighters, and addressing the unresolved crises and conflicts that foster terrorism. The January debate in the European Parliament on the fight against terrorism also contributed to the common pool of ideas. The informal meeting tomorrow will focus on three major areas: firstly, citizens’ security; secondly, preventing radicalisation and safeguarding values; and, thirdly, cooperation with international partners. The security of citizens is at the heart of our concerns. The informal meeting will discuss ways and means of implementing the existing tools more effectively or improving them. It will discuss a number of issues, ranging from information sharing, identification of terrorists and detection of their movements, to police and judicial cooperation. What is needed here is joint action by all Member States, supported by the EU institutions. In this context, let me mention a crucial issue on which all the EU institutions need to proceed swiftly: the proposal on a European Passenger Name Record (PNR) scheme. This is a complex issue and there are certain reservations, but we cannot afford to remain idle. Counter-terrorism experts have converging views that we need this measure. The Presidency is ready to engage in a constructive manner with the European Parliament as soon as it is ready to start the discussion. We believe that the outstanding concerns on fundamental rights, including solid data-protection safeguards, could be successfully addressed while negotiating the text of the present PNR proposal. Member States have a broad consensus on the need for a strong European PNR scheme: that was clearly evident during yesterday’s General Affairs Council meeting. In this regard, we appreciate the efforts made by Mr Kirkhope to revive the debate in Parliament, and Mr Kirkhope has recently also organised a series of discussions on the subject. In particular, we welcome his intention to present a modified report to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) by the end of this month. Secondly, preventing radicalisation is another key element of the fight against terrorism. We need to act jointly, not only at official level but also with civil society and the private sector. Our action must be twofold: monitoring, and removing from the internet, content that promotes terrorism or violence; and also engaging in positive communication. We need to develop a positive narrative to promote our values. Vocational training, job opportunities, social integration and rehabilitation can significantly contribute to the achievement of this goal. Lastly, cooperation with our international partners should be reinforced. The Foreign Affairs Council addressed this dimension on Monday, and the outcome of their deliberations will serve as an input to the leaders’ discussion tomorrow. Actions taken over recent weeks to fight terrorism, and further measures to be taken in the future, were discussed yesterday at the General Affairs Council, as I have mentioned, and delegations have concrete expectations from the informal meeting of Heads of State or Governments that will take place tomorrow. Tomorrow’s informal meeting will also address the Economic and Monetary Union. As you know, the President of the Commission, in close cooperation with the President of the Euro Summit, the President of the Eurogroup and the President of the European Central Bank, will report to the June 2015 European Council on their work regarding better economic governance in the euro area. The discussion scheduled for Thursday aims to feed the debate. We are looking forward to a communication from the four Presidents that will give a broader assessment of the functioning of the Economic and Monetary Union. Besides the above evaluation of the measures taken, the Presidency aims to foster a deeper reflection in the Council on the structural reforms that are key to sustainable economic growth in the Union. As the European Council has reiterated on a number of occasions, any strengthening of economic governance needs to be accompanied by further steps towards stronger legitimacy and accountability. Lastly, in the light of recent developments, the Heads of State or Government will also look at the situation on the ground at our eastern borders. Yesterday you heard an update from High Representative Mogherini on the situation on the ground and on ongoing diplomatic efforts. Later today, new talks should start in Minsk. Clearly we are at a crucial juncture. We expect a broad discussion at the summit on the latest developments. At this stage we need to maintain our unity, solidarity and consistency with regard to the full and comprehensive implementation of the Minsk Agreement by all parties. To conclude, as I have mentioned, the informal meeting of Heads of State or Government will address three major issues: the fight against terrorism, the Economic and Monetary Union and the situation in Ukraine. We expect the meeting will provide political impetus so that we can move forward swiftly. We expect clear orientation from the highest level. We are fully aware that tomorrow’s discussions will not be easy. However, we are hopeful that they will proceed and produce a positive and pragmatic result.

name: De Voorzitter. -
text: For the Commission's statement, I am now giving the floor to Mr Timmermans, Vice-President of the European Commission.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: Eerste vicevoorzitter van de Commissie. - Dank u, Voorzitter, en dank dat u de moeite heeft gedaan om de taal te spreken van het land dat vlak naast uw woonplaats ligt.  I had the honour of presenting to you, with President Juncker, the European Commission's work programme for 2015. As we agreed, it is a program that focuses on the essentials. It focuses on a limited number of concrete actions on real priorities. A total of 23 initiatives have been politically committed to implementing this year, including the European security agenda for the period 2015-2020. In the meantime, the terrorist attacks in Paris and those foiled in Belgium have placed this issue of security and, in particular, the terrorist threat, on the front page of all the media and the focus of attention.  The formal European Council on 12 February will be an opportunity for the Union to reaffirm its determination to combat all forms of terrorism and to have a broad exchange of views on both the actions taken by the Member States, given that they are the first responsible in this area, and on the support that the European Union can provide in terms of solidarity. added value and support for mutual trust. The attacks in France sent shockwaves through Europe. In the face of the terrorist threat, we must act decisively to bring structural solutions to this major challenge for European society, which touches on our fundamental values. Acting quickly is essential, but acting in haste would be a mistake: you have to keep your cool and give yourself time for a thorough reflection. This substantive reflection must focus on the multiple aspects of a difficult and complex issue to which we must give a balanced answer, which takes into account both the need to ensure the security of citizens and the need to defend fundamental rights and freedoms.  It cannot in any way call into question our common way of life, our freedom and our shared values, because that is what terrorists want. It is up to us to better understand that living together must be more than just cohabitation, more than just coexistence. It is a question of knowing each other and respecting the life chosen by each one. Personally, I cannot envisage a Europe where some communities - such as the Jewish community currently in Britain and France - feel that they have no future in Europe. If the Jews of Europe have this impression, Europe will have no future. We must defend our values and diversity, while defending our security and unity. Our long European history has taught us that there can be no security without freedom, no freedom without security: you cannot separate the two issues. The worst poison we know in European history is anguish, fear, fear. Fear creates a situation where one looks at the other with fear, where one believes that the other wants to undermine our position: in European history, this has always led to disasters.  While security is essentially the responsibility of the Member States, Europe has an obligation to develop an element of the overall solution. There is no doubt that the more coordination and coordination between Europeans on security, the better and the less terrorists will be able to slip into the loopholes that exist, particularly in the application and use of the current cooperation tools. The truth is that the Fight against European terrorism must start with the simple implementation of the decisions already endorsed. The European Union has an important arsenal in terms of European security legislation and tools. The weak point lies in a large part in their implementation on the ground, which is often still far from being up to what has already been decided. It should be remembered that since 1 December 2014 the Commission has only had the right to launch infringement proceedings against Member States which have not fully or correctly transposed our common rules in this area. There is a lot of talk, for example, about Schengen and often it is not spoken of, because Schengen, ladies and gentlemen, is not the problem - Schengen must be part of the solution. But before we think about the improvements we could make to the Schengen border code - the Commission is ready to take stock of it, when the time comes, the first step would be to make the most of the possibilities and flexibilities that exist under the current rules, for example the possibility of reintroducing in a framed and limited way controls at internal borders over time. We would rather act quickly on the basis of the existing rules, which allow it, than get lost in a legislative process that will last for years, with an uncertain outcome. Important work has already been started by the Commission in collaboration with the competent authorities of the Member States to facilitate the maximum exploitation of these possibilities. To conclude on this point, I do not think it is wise at this stage to concentrate our efforts on changing the current legal framework of the Schengen border code.  We will also have to finally move forward on the issue of the single European Passenger Record Registry (PNR). I believe that a motion of resolution will be put before Parliament after this debate, and I really want to stress that I welcome the work of Parliament, which is trying to play an important role as a facilitator, to find a solution to this problem; the Commission remains at the disposal of Parliament and the Council to participate in the search for a solution.  We need to strengthen the European Union's intelligence and analysis capabilities, including the creation within Europol of an integrated intelligence centre on threats related to terrorism and radicalisation, as well as making better use of existing structures and further improving exchanges between Member States, EU agencies and the intelligence analysis centre of the External Action Service. These are not new rules, new measures, but a certain level of trust between the Member States and the services concerned.  Of course, we must also focus our efforts on prevention, to counter the influence of radical movements on some of our citizens. It is nevertheless essential for European societies to understand why young people who were born here, who are part of our society, are tempted by a nihilistic ideology that incites them to arm themselves to attack in a murderous way the very society from which they come. It is still a very important issue for everyone here at European level. We have instruments to do this: we must have a network of alerts, establish a close dialogue with representatives of religions, make an effort to create a space of tolerance that Europe must give for a common European future. Once again, Europe, without tolerance, will not exist: it will be fragmented, it will be a Europe of confrontation.  I believe we are all in Minsk today. We all hope that it will be possible to find a solution or rather I feel that some, perhaps, are not there, but I believe that the vast majority of us want peace in Europe, we want a peaceful solution to the problems in Ukraine. Thursday's formal European Council will also be an opportunity to discuss Ukraine. The violence we witness on a daily basis condemns them in the strongest possible terms: we urge those responsible for the recent attacks to end hostilities, which have already claimed too many innocent victims. There can be no military solution to the situation in eastern Ukraine: the solution can only be political and is in accordance with international law, independence and sovereignty of Ukraine. It lies in the full implementation of the Minsk agreements. It is this crucial issue that the German Chancellor and the President of the French Republic are discussing today with Presidents Putin and I would also like to reiterate that the Commission is providing humanitarian support to Ukraine. My colleague Christos Styliamides was there recently to express the European Union's solidarity with the Ukrainian people. This year, the Commission will provide the country with an additional EUR 15 million, bringing the total humanitarian aid provided by the European Union and Member States since the beginning of the crisis to EUR 92 million.

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, representatives of the Council, Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. This week, before the discussions on the European Council, we feel that the challenges are major challenges. I believe that, above all, citizens expect clarity on the course that Europe is taking to respond to these challenges. The first major issue being discussed is the fight against terrorism. The terrorist attacks in Paris brutally pulled us out of the Christmas holidays and shocked us all. I would like to begin by expressing thanks and respect for the French on the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats; With what clarity and unity they oppose this struggle and say: "We will not let our values be destroyed by terrorists!", deserves all respect. We have to be self-critical. The terrorists are French, they also come from other nationalities. They are, by and large, European. That is why the question is how radicalisation comes about, an issue that must concern us. We need data to create the fight against terrorism. If data today means power and influence in the world, then the state must also be able to work with data. That is why we have always been in favour of the use of passenger data, of the use of PNR data sets, in order to make progress in the fight against terrorism – with a high European data protection standard, of course. We need data exchange. I would like to refer to what Mr Guy Verhofstadt said during the last debate. I hope that the Council will finally take action in the exchange of data between the authorities. It is easy to call for new data, but it is obviously extremely difficult between states to exchange the existing data properly. That is where the Member States have to deliver. The second major issue is Ukraine. The situation is serious. We now have thousands of dead, injured, enormous destruction – we have war in Europe. First of all, I would like to point out that the Russian propaganda we are seeing there is unbelievable – that we are being told that Russian soldiers are holidaying there, even though the OSCE makes it clear that it would not work without Russian supplies. Minsk was never respected. And the people who stand up for freedom and democracy in Ukraine are being called fascists. This is unacceptable. We must stand in the way of this. I would like to express my thanks to Francois Hollande and Angela Merkel, who are now giving diplomacy another chance. If the talks fail, Europe must also be able to impose tougher sanctions. The unity of Europe must not waver on this issue. I hope that the Heads of State or Government will do the same. The third major issue I would like to raise today is the issue of the bailout mechanism in Europe, in particular the handling of the election result in Greece. Everyone today underlines respect for the Greek electorate. On the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to say that respect for the electorate means that all the agreements that have been reached so far can simply be thrown over the top? In future, can a Slovak Government, perhaps newly elected, or a New-elected Finnish Government simply overturn any concessions on payments for Greece? I say: no! Existing agreements must be respected by all. Tsipras must also learn this. Tsipras has simply lied to his voters. He has made promises that he will not be able to deliver on. We want Tsipras to make that clear and clear. Even more scandalous is the coalition partner ANGL, a right-wing populist force. I was surprised that, among other things, the GUE was not prepared to discuss here in the European Parliament that politicians who openly appear anti-Jewish openly stir up resentment against Jews, that we are obviously not allowed to discuss it here, because the Communists in particular believe that a pact with these people is perfectly fine simply because they then come to power as communists. This is unacceptable. Then there is the question: has the course been voted out? Let me just point out that Antonis Samaras has remained almost stable in Greece with his Nea Dimokratia. Our political power has achieved almost the same result as in the last elections. 65% of Greeks did not vote for SYRIZA. If we did not have these electoral structures in Greece, we would have a different result today. These are just figures that I am presenting here. I would simply like to point out that in Greece, before the election, we had exports of plus 8%, a Employment growth of plus 2.6%; private consumption has increased; we had a primary surplus in the budget. Antonis Samaras has left behind a country that has returned to growth after the difficulties of suffering the greek people. And Tsipras is destroying the trust that Antonis Samaras has built up within weeks. We believe that our path as the EPP is the right way forward – because Ireland is currently a locomotive in Europe, because Spain is currently a growth engine and because Italy and France are unfortunately God's brakes on growth in the European Union. That's why the only way to grow ... (Calls)

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Ladies and gentlemen! Mr Coburn, I thought you were sick. Now you're finally back! Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Please let Mr Weber speak. I already have 20 Blue Cards. Mr Weber is now given speaking time, which is immense. You use your blue cards to extend his speech. Think about whether you really want that. Please, Mr Weber!

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, so I take all 20 blue cards that are invoked. I do not hope that answers will trigger any thought processes among colleagues, because ideologues unfortunately do not listen to God's arguments, but it is worth trying. I would like to conclude. Reforms, structural reforms and budgetary discipline are the right way to get states out of the crisis. This has been demonstrated by our states, the PPE-DE-governed states. I have only one expectation of Tsipras. When Mr Kenny took office in Ireland, the whole of Europe demanded that he accept the existing programme for Ireland as binding on its own. When Passos Coelho took office in Portugal, the whole EU demanded that he accept the existing programme for Portugal as the new Head of Government. Our simple demand, when Tsipras comes into office, is that the EU then demands that existing agreements be accepted as binding on him as well. No more and no less. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Weber, I would like to thank Mr Weber for his work Did I understand you correctly? Have you just offered to rewrite the Greek electoral law? And for which other countries do you offer this? (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Bütikofer, I would like to thank Mr Bütikofer for his excellent You have listened to what I said. Then you also heard that we have respect for the Greek electorate. We also respect the new Greek Prime Minister as his country's representative. I have just pointed out that, if you look at the election result, 65% of the voters who went to the polls did not vote for Syriza. I didn't say more. At the end of the day, this also means that many people in Greece are now worried, including whether this government, whether these extremists who have been held accountable there. You too, Mr Bütikofer, must be concerned about this. (Applause)

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to say straight away to Mr Weber that it is inadvisable to go into this war between them. Spain and Greece are the countries with the highest unemployment rates in the euro area: 25% unemployment, more than 50% youth unemployment. It is difficult to tell the people of Greece and Spain that they are doing well and drawing up the list of good countries against bad countries is no use other than dividing Europe. If there is one thing we must avoid, seventy years after the end of the Second World War and twenty years after the end of the conflict in Yugoslavia, it is the return of war to Europe. History has taught us that conflicts are the poison of our continent and everything must be done to prevent this evil. As long as there is a window of negotiation and negotiation, we must move forward. Today is an important day in Minsk and we hope that a ceasefire will be imposed and that an agreement will be seeking that is based on the principle of Ukrainian territorial integrity, but also recognises Russia's role. Recognising that Russia is a global player does not mean accepting that every rule of international law can be transgressed. We cannot allow peace to be sabotaged. If Russia does not show itself to be cooperative, it will have to take responsibility for it. We do not agree to spread weapons at our borders. We must go down the road of increasing sanctions and aim to strike at the heart of Russian interests. At this time when the risk of conflict is looming, Europe must remain united. That is why I hope, as Vice-President Timmermans said, that the informal Council will send a message of solidarity and unity to the Greek people. We are aware of the enormous suffering paid for by the Greeks. Greece's lesson is: never again austerity, never again troika, which has completely got the recipe wrong. New, more democratic and transparent forms of accompaniment to Greece must be introduced. We call on the Council on Thursday to create the conditions for a short-term loan to Athens. We are not interested in names, we are interested in the substance: ensuring the functioning of the government in the coming months and freeing up resources to repair austerity failures. This loan must be accompanied by reasonable conditions. In Athens, we must call for a sensible fiscal effort and structural reforms that will defeat corruption and finally combat tax evasion. In the medium term, our group supports a programme of reforms and reconstruction between the European institutions, including Parliament, and the Greek authorities, with an ambitious plan for positive reforms, capable of restarting growth and investment. In return, we must be willing to discuss a remodulation of interest rates and debt maturities. On one principle, however, we must be clear: the debts incurred must be repaid; then we can discuss how, but there is no solidarity without seriousness. We want to help Greece, but the Greek Government must also help itself. It's no longer time for forcing and sentences to effect. And beware of fellow road users: no one allows themselves to bloodbath the new executive, but frankly allying with the nationalist right was a very bad signal. I will conclude on terrorism. There was a risk that our societies would be overwhelmed by fear, whereas the reaction of our fellow citizens was wise. Europe does not want to be held hostage by a climate of tension, it does not give in to blackmail by those who trade freedom for a little apparent security. The fight against terrorism requires us not to let our guard down, to give convincing answers such as those made by Vice-President Timmermans and the Representative of the Council. We are in for greater European cooperation between the intelligence services. On PNR, we confirm that we are ready to play our part, provided that fundamental freedoms are not touched. The priority attention mentioned by the Council representative on deradicalisation, the fight against social exclusion and education is very important. Then there is the external dimension. I would not like the very right attention paid to Ukraine to obscure the urgency of European action in the world. We cannot outre up foreign policy to raids by fighters and drones. We must be very tough against ISIS, but we must also act on the political causes that led to its roots in Iraq and Syria, as Mrs Mogherini is trying to do. Then there is Libya, a cultural land of extremism 300 km from our coasts, a country completely in disarray. The other day, and I will end here, more than 200 people died in Lampedusa. You can't make people die during the rescue. All this happens before our eyes because Triton is a mission This mission must be strengthened by means and means. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Pittella, you said that the Troika has got the Greek case very wrong. The Troika merely set the fiscal target for the Greek economy; it was up to the Greek Government to adjust the economic policy. I would like to ask you if you propose that the fiscal target for Greece should be substantially relaxed and, if so, who will provide the necessary money for the Greek economy to service its debt.

name: Gianni Pittella (S&D)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. We have been saying for months that the troika is an inadequate and unse democratic instrument, and we are pleased that this same consideration was made by President Juncker when he declared the birth of the European Commission. The troika is not the right therapy. The interlocution must take place between the national authorities and the European democratic institutions.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Mr Niedermayer, I would like to thank Mr Niedermayer for his You can also get up if you want to speak, you don't have to sit. It would also have the advantage for viewers that they could more easily identify the Member who is speaking.

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, this is a summit to discuss threats – threats from radicals, threats to our economies, threats on our borders – and all these threats require strong leadership. On the terror threat, most of Thursday’s Council will, rightly, be devoted to the issue of law enforcement and aspects of our response, internal security and the Passenger Name Record (PNR) scheme. I would like to thank the Presidency for the kind comments on the Kirkhope report. However, I have to say that it is shameful that the other group leaders want to undermine the report, as Mr Kirkhope is seeking to get the right balance between our civil liberties and our security. Let us also make sure that we do not ignore the other strand of this problem, namely – as, Mr Timmermans said – the drivers of radicalisation. Why are people from all types of background, some of them highly educated, killing other, innocent, people and falsely invoking the name of God? Why? It is a question I have been asked a lot recently, but there is no one path to radicalisation. There are various drivers, such as a search for identity among some second-generation and third-generation Muslims, the radicalisation of violent criminals in prison, giving them another violent cause to fight for, or the fact of radicals from other countries being given a platform for their extreme views in some of our communities. There are many paths. There is no easy answer. There is no silver bullet, metaphorically or literally, and most of the answers are actually to be found at local rather than EU level. However, at EU level we should not be afraid to discuss these issues in an open and frank manner, exchanging best practice and seeing what works best and what does not work in our countries. If terrorism is a threat in our midst, there is also a serious threat on our doorstep. On Ukraine, the ECR Group shares the concerns about the humanitarian catastrophe unfolding right under our noses but, frankly, only Vladimir Putin can put an end to this crisis. He must literally get his tanks off Ukraine’s lawn. Today’s meeting in Minsk is perhaps the last chance for a deal. However, we must be clear. We must seek a peaceful and political solution, but if Putin’s aggression continues then we must deploy every economic weapon available to us. In 21st century Russia, money talks. That is why it is unfortunate that in the EU we are not in a stronger position. There are no shortcuts to economic growth, no easy fixes for the eurozone and no alternatives to much-needed reform. Anyone who tells you there is a simple solution is simply not telling the truth. Frankly, the European Council needs to be honest about what economic and monetary union entails. If you want to keep the weaker economies in the eurozone, taxpayers in richer eurozone countries – Germany, the Netherlands, Finland – will have to pay for fiscal transfers to poorer eurozone countries, maybe forever. But those countries benefiting from the transfers must also understand the old saying that ‘he who pays the piper gets to call the tune’. As politicians, we should be straight about this, and let people make up their own minds. The voters made up their minds in Greece and they chose Syriza. You will not be surprised to hear that I disagree with their platform, but the people of Greece voted for it and we have to recognise that. However, the time for grandstanding on both sides is over. If Greece wants to discuss its sovereign debt with creditors in a mild-mannered way, it should get a fair hearing, but if Greece wants to splash the cash, it must understand that voters in the richer eurozone countries may want to show it the exit door. So this might be an informal Council but the subjects being discussed could not be more serious – tackling terrorism, tackling Putin and tackling the eurozone crisis. Let us all hope that the leaders at the European Council will make some headway and lead us to calmer waters. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul Nuttall (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Kamall, you spoke about the drivers of terrorism and radicalisation and you said that there were different means and methods by which young people become radicalised. Can I put it to you that the main driver of radicalisation is actually Saudi Arabia? They are the people who are funding these terrorist organisations. Would you agree with me that it was hypocritical and wrong for our own Prime Minister, David Cameron, to attend the funeral of King Abdullah who was little more than a cruel and wicked dictator?

name: Syed Kamall (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. –  Could I just say that I am slightly surprised by that question because I thought you were going to blame the EU for the causes of terrorism, like you blame the EU for everything. Actually, I have to say, you are absolutely right. Saudi Arabia is not the main driver but it is one of the factors we should look at. Saudi Arabia has been using its money unfortunately. When they built mosques in the UK, as a young child I used to think they were immensely beneficent but actually there is a pernicious intent behind what they do, and I think we have to be quite clear about that. We should be strong with the Saudis, as we should be strong with all those who support terrorism by whatever means.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, after this little British electoral game that we will see now, I think, in every part-session of Parliament in forthcoming weeks, let us come back to the informal European Council.  I have read the draft statement. I hope that everybody has already read it. It is very disappointing. We can do better than what is in the draft statement of the informal Council. We have to use this momentum to repeat to some extent what we did after 9/11 and that was to launch a roadmap. We established the European Arrest Warrant and we need to do the same thing.  First of all, a PNR system. We have committed to do so, to work quickly on that, but only on a legally sound system. A system that contains the necessary safeguards and I hope that we can vote for that opinion now, with a huge majority, in a few hours’ time. But I must say to the President of the Council that the Council has to do its work too, because the main files are not blocked in Parliament. The main files on fighting terrorism are blocked in the Council at present: strengthening Europol – blocked in the Council; strengthening Eurojust – blocked in the Council; the Data Protection Directive – blocked in the Council. So what I hope is that this informal meeting will unblock these so that we can go forward.  Secondly, there also needs to be an in-depth discussion about the real thing to do, which is sharing information in the European Union, making of this intelligence service a Eurintel – a European intelligence service – because all the perpetrators in the Paris attacks were known. It is a question of sharing information. Finally, too, strengthening our external Schengen borders. It would be a huge mistake now to say that Schengen is the problem. No, Schengen is not the problem. as Mr Timmermans said, we need to strengthen control of our external borders by fully and systematically using the SES system. So that is my first appeal to you. The second appeal concerns Greece. My opinion is very clear because I followed the debate here between Mr Pittella and Mr Weber a little bit. Let us not rush on this. Let us first give the new Greek Government an opportunity to come forward with a plan, with in-depth reforms, because the people of Greece were right, naturally. They want a change, because neither Pasok nor Nea Demokratia was capable of changing anything because they are the source of the patronage system and the corruption in Greece.  So I am open to hearing Mr Tsiprasʼ proposals and to seeing what he can offer as in-depth reforms, and then we can talk about their debt. Not to first talk about the debt and then the reforms. That will never happen. First the reforms, then we can talk about that.  But there is one thing we will never accept from the new Greek Government: that they want to revive the ghosts of the past by asking for reparations from another country, a Member State, of the European Union. That is not the foundation of the European Union. The foundation of the European Union is not based on revenge. We made that mistake in Versailles, more than 80 to 90 years ago.  Mr Tsipras says he has a moral obligation to do that. Well, in my opinion, Mr Tsiprasʼ moral obligation is not to revive the ghosts of the past; his moral obligation is to work on the future of Greece and the European Union, just as our moral obligation too is to help Greece and to work on this future of the European Union. But certainly not to revive the ghosts of the past.  Finally, Ukraine. OK, we are going to deal with that later, talk about who is doing the job now – Hollande, Merkel, Tusk. The most important thing is that we have a lasting deal in Minsk. That is the most important thing. But to have a lasting deal in Minsk, I think we are obliged to have, within the European Union, a united and strong position. In negotiations with Mr Putin, the only thing that counts is for Europeans to have a united and strong position and, for me, that means three things.  First of all, let us help the Ukrainians with non-lethal means: satellite imaging, intelligence, cyber defence. Let us help them. Secondly, let us also think about new economic sanctions. Finally, let us be united with the United States. Do not let us know again the shame of Kosovo where it was the Americans who had to solve our problems on European soil because we did not have the courage, nor the means, to do so. So I hope that we have a firm position in Minsk, and a united position is the only chance we have to achieve a lasting deal in that most important conflict.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Mr Verhofstadt, I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt for his Mr Coburn would like to ask you a question. (Interruption: Saxe-Coburg) No, Mr Coburn, not Saxe-Coburg. Mr. Saxe-Coburg, .... No, Mr Coburn, please!

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Danke, mein Präsident, though I am not Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, very nice though that might be. Mr Verhofstadt, you keep asking for a pan-European police state, or it seems to me that this is what you are asking for, ruled by a European – how shall we put it? – bureaucratic dictatorship, because this European Union has no democratic merit at all. This House is not proposing legislation. You have no democratic control and you want a police state controlled by the European Union. That does not seem like a good idea to me. Is that what you want?

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – My answer is no, and I do not think that everybody here feels they form part of a European dictatorship. We form part of a European democracy. Mr Coburn, you were elected. Maybe you have forgotten it, but you were elected. Maybe they made the wrong choice in Britain, that is clear, but nevertheless you were elected – because people always have that right in a democracy. Secondly, what are you talking about? We are talking about terrorism today: about fighting against terrorism. We are talking about defending our values against Putin. How do you do it? We can take a stand only through a united Europe, Mr Coburn.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Verhofstadt, I did not know that you were so interested in Saxony-Coburg. So if you want to see a living specimen from this region, that's me. I come from this former Saxe-Coburg region. However, to come to the actual issue, the preparation of the Council summit for the day after tomorrow: it is a summit which takes place in a very special situation and which has a history. History has something to do with the fact that in recent months we have been in a fierce dispute over the future of the European Union. This is also made clear by various examples. The question is: how do we respond to the terrorist attacks in Paris, Belgium and elsewhere? Is our response really the appropriate one to give? Should it really focus on PNR, pnr and the like? Are we really convinced that a PNR agreement could actually prevent terrorist attacks? Is it really the case? In response to a question on the matter, Mr Biden himself acknowledged that the United States had no concrete evidence that PNR and widespread surveillance could actually help prevent terrorism, but that it was more or less a matter of determining who did what in the aftermath. Great! I do not think that is enough. We need further reflection. You will not be surprised that I will, of course, now focus on the issue of Greece. Mr Weber, it would be nice if you could listen to me, because you also made a comment on this earlier. First of all, I have to tell you that I understand very well – I understand it in the light of my own history and the collapse and also the failure of politics – that politicians find it difficult to admit the failure of policies that form their own foundation. And that we then try to deviate and develop strategies, to make claims, to create sideshows that have nothing to do with the issues we face and with the challenges we face. It is not a question of whether there are any problems between individual countries to resolve. This is about the future of the European Union. If you were to ask this question at long last, whether the austerity policy, whether the programme of the Federal Government of Germany has been the right answer over the years, whether what the EU institutions have done, what the troika has done, whether it has led to confidence in the European Union and its future. At the same time, we are facing a deep democratic crisis. And if we are not in a position, with the summit, with the eurogroup meeting, really to provide the first answers that we have really understood what is at stake, then we will all share responsibility for the fact that more and more people are doubting whether this can work. And now to ANEL. Mr Weber, I would like to thank Mr Weber for his work. There is one Member who has been elected to the European Parliament via ANEL. He is a member of the ECR. You will not say, as Chairman of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, that the ECR is an anti-Semitic group. I don't think you're going to seriously say that! That is not what you are going to do. Please, think about what you are explaining here in the future! Let us talk about what is really necessary, what reactions should be taken with regard to Greece.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will start by talking about security, recalling a basic principle of democracy that any law, any rule we adopt which, in itself, constitutes an obstacle to freedom, must be proportionate to the purpose pursued. We consider that the widespread monitoring of the company and, in this case, the establishment of a PNR file that would target everyone and where the data would be kept ad vitam, or at least for extremely long durations, is not proportional to the purpose pursued. Guy Verhofstadt has been precise enough in his criticisms, I will not repeat them here. I share them in full, including the appeal to the Council, which is indeed a bit hypocritical when we know that it is it that it is the Council that blocks most of the initiatives that would increase the real, not theoretical, security of our fellow citizens. First, the principle of proportionality, therefore. Mr. Timmermans, I have greatly appreciated - and I fully share - a central element of your speech. When you ask yourself: "How is it that our societies have become a breeding ground for the seeds of hatred and violence sown by a few individuals? How is it that a number of our fellow citizens, people born here, may have proved sensitive to hate speech and violence?", I think you are asking the fundamental question. This is not a fifth column parachuted out of I do not know which state would want us to harm; it is about our fellow citizens. I hear many elements of your speech and the Council's speech on our shared values, on our common life, on Europe as a space of tolerance. I fully share your concern when you say that when it comes to a community here in Europe starting to question its future as a community, Europe has no future. You mentioned the Jewish community, and I share your concern in that regard. But what about Muslim communities, which are permanently discriminated against in most European countries? Not everywhere, because not all Member States have the same attitude on this issue. Discrimination in hiring, in the education system, in access to culture, economic discrimination... What problems do these communities face when they feel they have no future in Europe? What about the 27 million unemployed and tens of millions of working poor? What about the 125 million Europeans facing poverty and precariousness on a daily basis? What happens when all our citizens feel that this society is not acting in their favour, that this society is no longer theirs? What do I mean by the Council and the Commission? I hear about structural reforms. Reforms aimed at cutting public spending, including education spending, labour income and social security. In short, reforms which, on top of that, continue to make tax competition a dogma and are extremely chilly , as your colleague Commissioner Hill still demonstrates, when it comes to seriously tackling tax evasion and evasion. In short, a policy mix whose result is a permanent increase in exclusion and inequality. Madam Minister, what Europe needs is not a new positive narrative. Our citizens do not have to make a beautiful speech. What they want to see is action, a radical political shift that places at the heart of the European project the objective that Europe has always wanted to pursue: to be an area of prosperity shared - and shared by all, not just a minority of our fellow citizens. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – You speak, and you speculated, about why people within our societies turn against us and turn to terrorism. Would you not agree that at least part of the problem is the very language that you yourself unfortunately end up using when you talk about the Muslim community, the Jewish community, the separate communities. Why not integration rather than separation? Political correctness allows these separate groups within society. Why not talk about a British person who happens to be a Muslim, for example, rather than the other way round? (Applause)

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Etheridge, I think you have a point and indeed speaking about the Greeks or the Germans or the Muslims or the Jews is probably not the right way to speak. You have a point there.  However, it is a fact that statistically some groups in our society suffer from discrimination as a whole. It does not mean that they are not equal and that they are all the same, but when you see massive statistical bias against some communities, well, that is what leads me then to speak about the Muslim communities. But I would agree with you that, indeed, we should not just categorise all societies as groups of people just living next to one another. Mr Timmermans also mentioned that in his speech. He does not want to see, and nor do I, a European society which is just a juxtaposition of individual communities. On that point at least we may agree.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, having listened to the debate this morning, it is clear to me that there are very few people in this room who understand, or dare to admit, the significance of the moment that we have reached. In the wake of the historic Greek elections, there are big questions, not just about the future of the euro area but actually about the future of the European project itself.  There is a great game of poker taking place for the future of this currency. On the one hand we have the EU institutions. Now however much my warnings over the years may have upset people, when I said that the EU would crush and kill and destroy nation-state democracy, I think the behaviour by the key players since the Greek elections justifies everything I have said.  We heard the German Finance Minister, Mr Schäuble, saying that elections change nothing and Mr Juncker – who is not here today, which is disappointing – ought to be hanging his head in shame or perhaps he is busy getting his euros out of Greece, I have no idea. Mr Juncker said that there can be no democratic choice against the European Treaties.  So there it is, folks. It does not matter how you vote. It does not matter what government you elect, these Treaties are designed to be there forever and agreements by previous governments bind parliaments that come for years and years afterwards. What it means is that the European project is, in fact, the very antithesis of the democratic principle. I think these comments, frankly, are disgusting. I guess we are all asking the question of who will blink first.  On the other side, we have got this new, radical left-wing Greek Government. I was not quite sure what to make of them until I saw last week, ambling up Downing Street, Yanis Varoufakis. There he was with his leather bomber jacket and his blue shirt hanging out of the front of his trousers, with his shaven head, hands in pockets, looking a bit like an off-duty nightclub bouncer. I am not normally a fan of Marxist academics, but having seen this fellow, I suspect that perhaps he is the real deal.  At least, I hope he is, because what is at stake – as is clear from the comments we have had from Germany and from people in this Chamber this morning – what is at stake is clear: do the Greek elections mean anything? Yes or no? I hope the Greeks stand firm, whatever the consequences. If they do, the free world will applaud them. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jörg Leichtfried (S&D)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Farage, I have listened to you with great interest. The Sukkus was, you are the only one here who knows and always tells us all what could be different. We can discuss whether this is the case. But if you believe that, I would ask you: you have been in this House for more than ten years now. If you know so much, why have you never written a single report here, never made a single request anywhere? Why are you not taking part in this work here? Why are you not doing anything when you are already so clever and earn very well for it, Mr Farage?

name: Nigel Farage (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – What I was saying was that there is an atmosphere of denial. In the wonderful Latvian Presidency speech this morning, at no point was the word ‘Greece’ mentioned. Mr Timmermans very briefly touched on Greece and many of the speakers ignored the subject.  What I am saying is: people are in denial; we are at a very big, important, historic juncture. And what is at stake is: do general elections in our Member States count for anything or not? Those arguments and those debates are far more important than whether I have written any parliamentary reports or gone native and become part of the system, because I most certainly have not. (Applause)

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI). -
text: Mr. President, dear ladies and gentlemen! Once again, the European Council is meeting and, once again, a policy of failure is manifesting itself at all levels. Point 1: Counter-terrorism. Instead of finally limiting the influx from Islamic countries and focusing surveillance measures on the Islamist sector here and risk communities, fundamental civil rights for all Europeans are being eroded and a surveillance state in Orwellian style is being brought about. Absolutely the wrong way! Point 2: Russia sanctions. This policy of sanctions has already cost Europe more than 20 billion. And instead of continuing to do the same for the Americans, the European Union would be well advised to seek a way of reconciliation and a prosperous common future with the Russians. Point 3: The Situation in Greece, where a left-wing government has now been elected and all the principles of the European Union are to be thrown overboard. I have respect for the Greek people. However, as a representative of Austria, I would like to remind you that the amount owed to us, at least to the EUR 6 billion, must be repaid. To you, ladies and gentlemen, to call for a final stop to adopt a policy which is in the interests of interest groups, power blocs and ideological experiments, but to pursue a policy that actually serves and helps the citizens of Europe.

name: Herbert Reul (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, representative of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the Council. We have discussed the fight against terrorism relatively frequently here and have also said that we urgently need to do something. I am grateful that the Council and also the Commission have now presented very specific measures. I would like us to take very specific decisions beyond talking, because I do not think that the citizens are interested in long and detailed debates on what the meaning and nonsense is, but whether we are interested in whether we are doing something to protect the lives and lives of the people of the European Union from these terrorists, and in particular. I am grateful that the political groups have agreed on the issue of the PNR to make some progress. My second comment is that what has been discussed here on the question of economic and monetary policy, stability policy, particularly in relation to Greece, is already partly adventurous. I really have to say that. Is it not normal for a new government to be treated in the same way as all other governments so far? When the Greek Government takes office here, it has to say to the Irish, Spanish or Portuguese Governments, just as it used to, whether it says 'yes' or 'no' to the existing treaties. What is not normal about this? Is it not perfectly normal to expect someone who receives financial support and solidarity to be prepared to accept that one looks at whether what has been promised is being fulfilled? That is what we call the troika. From me, you can all call it completely different. That's what I'm sick of. But it is clear, Mr Pittella! In this respect, I do not understand at all that there must be supervision, control and agreement on whether what has been discussed is complied with. A little more clearly: Mr Pittella, I am extremely surprised that you say: never again austerity! Do you want to speak in Europe in the future to those who waste the money? That cannot be true! That cannot be the intention you are presenting here! So I expect those who get help to provide their compensation. Now I would like to know how you tell the Italian citizens. Should they pay for Greek Communists to make any election promises? I cannot tell my citizens that. Fairness is paramount. Fairness must also apply to Greeks. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: 'blue card' question. Mr Reul, you have spoken to us, as has Mr Reul. Weber, on the need to comply with the agreed. I would like to remind you that in the European Treaties, in addition to the provisions on budgetary discipline and stability, there are also provisions on fundamental rights, such as the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and that the Troika by system is violating these social rights, as has been noted by decisions of the Commission of the European Social Charter, which you nevertheless despise. How will this issue be dealt with in your opinion?

name: Herbert Reul (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – The decision as to whether the policy in Greece was good or bad will eventually affect other people. I would just like to say that the development in Greece has been a good one, it has evolved. It wasn't all good. Nobody here has said that! Mr Pittella, I did not understand your accusation. Nobody has said that there are great conditions. But progress can be made. And I am curious to see whether the new government will make such progress. At the moment, what Manfred Weber said is true: it is going downhill and not uphill, while in Ireland, in Spain, in Portugal, it is progressing. Progress is being made precisely with this policy, which we have jointly adopted here. Somebody hasn't put that on them.

name: Jörg Leichtfried (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Terrorism has two main objectives: the first objective is to spread fear, fear, which then leads to anger, anger that leads to violence, and violence that leads to unbearable suffering. The second objective, in my view, is not only to carry out attacks on people, but also, especially here in the European Union, in the Member States, to commit attacks on the democratic system, the rule of law and personal freedom. If we want to fight terrorism now, it is a very fine line to go down a path that does not go in that direction that terrorists want. We ourselves should not restrict our freedom, nor should we ourselves ensure that the rule of law is dismantled. It's a big, difficult challenge. If some Members now think that data must be collected without hindrance, I do not know whether that is the solution. Perhaps we have already collected enough data, perhaps we have too few officials who can evaluate this data. Perhaps we have too few police officers on the streets because security has been broken. Perhaps too few people in Europe have a viable prospect in front of them because they are unemployed because they have no education. We need to discuss all this. We, as the European Parliament, are on the right track with this resolution that we are going to adopt today. But as I said, it is a fine line, a very difficult balance. Subject 2,: Greece: Mr Reul, the Socialist Group is against austerity, yes!. On the other hand, people are being deprived of prospects, but so many people are driven into unemployment, into despair. However, we are also in favour of negotiating, talking and considering what can be done better together with a democratically elected government. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Thank you very much, Mr Leichtfried. I very much appreciate you in your speech, and I share that. I just wonder whether the Social Democrats will act today in the same way as you have just said here. Indeed, there is a debate – and this is also in the direction of Mr Reul and Mr Weber: are we now spending EUR 500 million – that is the European Commission's estimate – on a system for storing passenger data, or are we investing this money in the chronically underfunded cross-border cooperation between police and judicial authorities under the umbrella of Europol and Eurojust? That's the question.

name: Jörg Leichtfried (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I believe that this is a very important issue. I believe that it is necessary to invest in all areas of security, where it brings about anything. The question of where it really makes the most sense, especially now, is that this is a question that we must discuss, which we must ask ourselves. I believe that the path we are probably taking in this resolution now – if the vote is to proceed as I believe it could go out – is that this will be the right way forward. But you are right. You have to be incredibly careful about these things.

name: Andrzej Duda (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. The High Representative of the Council, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr S I would like to refer further to the issue of Ukraine, because there are also voices in this House which, as a Pole and a member of the European Parliament, are of great concern. I ask you, I have no doubt that today, as members of the European Union, our task is to help Ukraine at all costs and to ensure that Ukraine maintains its territorial integrity. Let us remember that this is not only a matter of Donbass, but also of Crimea, which has already been seized by Russia. I am very concerned about some of the voices that are falling here that speak almost directly: you have to get along with Russia at all costs, because it is a matter of economic interests. I would like to stress once again: there are no economic interests that would allow us, as honest people, to sell Ukraine.  These negotiations that are taking place today, in which the whole of the European Union does not really participate, but are attended by Germany and France, I think vividly that some people are reminded not so much of the 'Normandy formula' as they used to be of the 'Yalsa formula'. We must not, ladies and down today, allow us not to be jointly and severally represented. I ask, where is President Donald Tusk? Yesterday, Mrs Mogherini said that the 'Normandy formula' had already been the subject of Council conclusions. Then I ask – because I did not hear the answer yesterday – what is the legitimacy, what is the negotiating mandate of Mrs Merkel and Mr Hollande? What are they supposed to negotiate and what are the assumptions? This interests me very much because, as a Pole, I do not agree to sell the Ukrainian state in exchange for some cloudy economic interests. I would like to emphasise this with full force, because I do not think that there are any concerned fellow Members from Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Romania, Slovakia or Hungary in this House. Please bear in mind that, as far as Poland, Slovakia, Hungary and Romania are concerned, we are talking about a war that is happening just outside our borders. We should be involved in these negotiations. What worries me is that Polish government has put this issue before. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Madam President, Dear Mr. Advocate, I agree with you that peace has no alternative and territorial integrity has no alternative, but yesterday Ms Mogherini also spoke of the need for strong decentralisation of Ukraine. Do you see perhaps the solution and solution of the eastern part of Ukraine and in the strong decentralisation of Ukraine?

name: Andrzej Duda (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Absolutely not. History, especially in the 1930s, teaches us the dramatic effects of passivity on the part of Europe. Today, russia must not accept that it should piece together Ukraine and swallow it in parts. This is a question of our responsibility, our responsibility for the integrity of European countries and the integrity of borders – I stress this once again. If we stop this process, if we do not allow it, it will be a success for Europe. If Europe agrees to a rotten compromise, it will be a failure.

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, when we speak of counter-terrorism policies I hear too many hollow phrases and commonplaces on the rule of law and civil liberties. Colleagues, it is not good enough – and I am addressing the Council in particular – to pay lip service to the rule of law in civil liberties, because what it actually means is that there are limits. It does not mean that we can stretch the rule of law and fit in all the measures that we like; it means governments cannot have unlimited and unchecked powers, and it seems that many people have forgotten that. ALDE is pleased that we have reached a compromise on counter-terrorism. Compromises are never easy or pretty, and I hear the Greens’ criticism but I hope that next time they will be on board when we are negotiating a compromise because Parliament, unlike the Council, is able to compromise and achieve results. We need security measures but they must be tailor-made and evidence-based, not based on assumptions, ideology or gut feeling. ALDE will not side with the trigger-happy cowboys who support any repressive measure without evidence. Nor will ALDE side with those who, in a kneejerk reflex, oppose any security measure, equally without evidence. There is a hard-fought compromise on the EU Passenger Name Record (PNR) scheme on the table today and we are committed to working swiftly on this dossier, but it is essential that the Commission and Council deliver. The Commission, Mr Timmermans, must do its job – do not just look to Parliament – and you must demonstrate the necessity and the proportionality of the measures proposed. We cannot support a system for the massive and indiscriminate collection of personal data without the evidence for necessity and proportionality and without adequate safeguards for citizens’ rights. Lastly, we are pleased that an in-depth evaluation must be an integral part of the April security package because, in the past 15 years, a long list of measures has been adopted but there has never been an evaluation of their effectiveness and of what we have in our toolkit. Have the measures been implemented by the Member States? I think, Mr Timmermans, that evaluating policies is also part of better law making.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, Mr Weber, I understand your sadness at the way your friend Mr Samaras lost the Greek elections. I understand your disappointment at the defeat of a policy of extreme unilateral austerity that afflicts not only Greece and the Greeks but the entire eurozone. You represent a party, the CSU, which is to Mrs Merkel's right. But please stop this extreme inflammatory divisive speech, in which neither the Commission nor Mr. Timmermans – who spoke very carefully about Greece and the Greeks – neither the Council nor the Latvian Minister, nor any other of the chairmen of the political groups. I fear that you are far more extreme and divisive than you blame the Greek government. And to comfort you: All the latest polls show that the Greek government has the support of 80% of Greek women and Greeks. And we demand a solution, not a rupture; growth in place of austerity; sweeping reforms in the administration, the public sector, the tax system, the fight against corruption and bureaucracy, to make Greece an equal respectable member of the euro zone, and a debt arrangement, as Mr. Pittela and Mr. Pittela. Lamberts, without burdening European taxpayers with an extra EUR 1. In the Eurogroup that is coming and at the summit we need constructive contributions for a solution of common acceptance and isolation of the cries that want division and division, in order to permanentise unilateral austerity. (Applause) (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Papadimoulis, congratulations to your party and to the Greek people on expressing the democratic voice. In the UK we got out of the exchange rate mechanism in the 1990s, and our economy recovered. In Argentina there was great hardship with the dollar peg: they got out of it, their economy recovered. Do you agree that Greece’s inability to devalue its currency leads, in part, to difficulty with the recovery of the Greek manufacturing and tourism industries; and are there any circumstances at all in which you would support a Greek exit from the euro to solve those problems?

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL)
text: 'blue card' reply. Thank you, Mr Arnott, for the question. Our choice is for Greece to be an equal member of the eurozone with growth, with democracy, with social cohesion, with reforms. Thank you for your advice. If you convince british voters to make you a government, apply them! In Greece we implement the program of the government of SYRIZA. And one more thing: The British Government held a special meeting worrying about the consequences of a – unlikely in my opinion – Grexit for the British economy as well.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Unfortunately, we are in a discussion here where a very large coalition of symbolic politics is emerging in the fight against terrorism. Mr Reul said: let us no longer discuss the meaning and nonsense, but let us simply do it with the retention of data and passenger data. It is precisely this question that is being raised for discussion: what really helps against terror? It is a question of discussing what makes sense and what is helpful. Detroit, Boston, Quebec, Toulouse, Brussels, Paris – all places of worse, devastating recent attacks. And in all these places there has been information about all the perpetrators. In hindsight, in retrospect, this becomes clear. I think we need to look at it and discuss how we can equip the police and judicial authorities to use the information they have. Instead, you resort to the expensive means of general surveillance, place every passenger under general suspicion and think that is the end of the matter. This is not an effective security policy. That is why we cannot take part in this!

name: David Borrelli (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow's summit has on its agenda three different and distant issues, but which fully affect the European Union's ability to react and propose. The Ukrainian question, the fight against terrorism and the crisis of economic and monetary union are a matter for us and they commit us far beyond their respective technical plans. They ask us about our determination to give shape to the founding values of the European Union and about the concrete ability to propose credible solutions. As far as monetary union is concerned, how can we deny that the Greek question is increasingly a measure of the meaning of this Union? I believe that not only Greece but also the many difficulties that other states are struggling with as a result of the austerity policies imposed in the name of a genuine economic and monetary union show that Europe cannot solve the problem of economic governance in the terms in which it is placed. The solution will not come from technical or financial engineering reasoning. The solution can only be given economic value to our common desire to achieve the process of European unification in real difficulties. In other words, by founding, justifying and disseminating a vision of Europe that will make it possible to have a clear picture on the horizon of what is valuable and what is not, what makes sense and what does not, that can put the dignity of the person back at the centre of every decision. The fight against terrorism is a challenge that we cannot escape, and we must respond to it in a complete way, not limited to the internal security aspect alone. We must be able to respond with a broad, profound and not hasty strategy. Today, our founding values are subordinate to the economic dimension, in the belief that their role is secondary or even exhausted. In this vacuum, the inability to counter inhuman and irrational ideologies that cannot be combated by perfect financial budgets, but only by proposals for values shared and applied in practice, first and foremost by the European institutions, has crept into this vacuum.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI). -
text: Madam President, all The Europeanists, including the President of the European Commission, have tried to influence the Greek elections, ostensibly supporting the right-wing candidate, Antonis Samaras. By placing Syriza in power, the Greek people have made it clear that they no longer want the violent austerity policies imposed by the European institutions. He said "no" to the dictatorship of the European institutions on Greek economic policy, "no" to unemployment, "no" to poverty, "no" to debt slavery. Last Wednesday, the ECB took steps to hinder the financing of Greek banks and, in turn, the Greek economy. Juncker explained that EU treaties and other contracts cannot be challenged by democracy; So what remains of the will and sovereignty of the peoples? In fact, the objective is clear: to force the Greek authorities to betray their people, to abandon their electoral commitments and to return to the nails of the European austerity policy. Between Mrs Merkel's intransigence and the ECB's low blows, we are dealing with a Eurodictture, where all blows are allowed to bend democratically elected governments and impose a decided policy in Brussels and Berlin. Ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has clearly become the enemy of democracy.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. These three points of the forthcoming informal summit are seemingly different, but in fact they are closely interconnected. It is devoted to the security of the European Union, the Member States and citizens in a broad way. President Weber said that we need a clear course in this regard. Threats come from different sides, but their sources lie in an unstable situation, particularly in close proximity to the European Union. In order to counter terrorism, we need efforts that lead to closer coordination of security services. We have had information many times after the events, after the terrorist acts, that the knowledge of their perpetrators was, perhaps, poorly coordinated. Let us remember, however, that we cannot agree to too far-reaching restrictions on citizens' rights, because this alone would also mean a victory for terrorists. As we fight for our values, for freedom, let us also remember that citizens have the right to freedom from fear. Commissioner Timmermans rightly says that freedom is impossible without security. In this context, we must work on effective solutions.  The President of the Council invited the President of Ukraine to the Summit. This is very important, because there is a drama taking place in the east of Ukraine, which also affects our situation, both because of political, economic and economic issues, but also because of the great humanitarian crisis that continues there. We have some hopes for what is happening today with the Minsk meeting. But will these solutions stop this escalation? We need to think about how we can also defend ourself against the disinformation that flows from the East. We all know the media conveying a distorted picture of reality. They also affect the perception of this reality in Europe. I would like the situation in Ukraine, and in particular the establishment of these self-proclaimed republics, not to affect the Member States of the European Union. Such threats are signalled, in particular from the Baltic States.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D). -
text: Madam President, the European Union is confronted with daunting challenges in terms of security – internal and external security. I believe we cannot afford to be divided internally and we need to strengthen our social cohesion. Every citizen should have a real chance of hope for the future and be rewarded for his or her efforts. The Greek people were brought to the point of despair, and we need to provide a better solution for the Greek people. This solution should be based on a credible compromise.
