We need a rebalancing of the budget in Greece, but at a more reasonable pace. We need reforms, but the relevant ones are tax collection, public administration and a welfare system with real universal and sustainable coverage, and most of all we need a big push for good investment projects and job creation. What really matters is the method. We should close these Troika methods. We should have a real democratic deal, involving the European institutions with the Greek population, and we also need to make sure that, overall, the Economic and Monetary Union is completed in such a way that it becomes a space not of divergence but of convergence: economic convergence, social convergence and also political convergence. I believe this is a major task for the four presidents in the upcoming discussion. We need a different kind of monetary zone, where all Member States have a real possibility of making progress if they put in the right effort. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Madam President, Madam President, you and your party and your group are talking a lot about growth, investment, but the truth is that they continue to deny the imperative need to renegotiate debts.  I would like you to explain to us here: how, for example, in your country, in Portugal, that you will pay, only in interest on debt, by 2020, three times, I stress, triple what you will receive from the European Union in structural and investment funds, in the absence of a renegotiation, where you plan to go get the resources for the investment you are talking about?

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. "Thank you so much for your question. In fact, I do not consider the solution applied in Portugal to be a good solution, because we have reached the end of the rescue programme with much higher unemployment, with a potential growth decreased and a debt that went from 90 % of GDP to almost 130 %.  Therefore, Portugal, like Greece, is not an example of a well-achieved economic policy. To reduce the burden of debt, the first thing to do is to grow Portugal again. It's getting inflation higher. It's reviewing interest and maturity. And from there, I think we're going to be able to put the Portuguese debt down.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR). -
text: Madam President! I was very disappointed by the statement by the Council and the Commission, which has been essentially empty of content and has only touched on the important points of Greece and Ukraine in the first place. But Mr Weber has said something clear. He said Mr Tsipras had lied to voters. I cannot understand that. I have the impression that Mr Weber is bothered by Mr Tsipras precisely because Mr Tsipras is delivering on what he promised before the election, whereas Mr Weber, as the leader of the Christian Democrats, should perhaps ask how, if the word 'lie' is already used, it is to be judged that a major party has promised. that Germany will never have to pay for the debts of other countries, and has been doing the opposite for five years now. With regard to Ukraine, I also lack the clear words. I think it should have been made very clear that the answer to Russian arms deliveries to the separatists cannot be American arms deliveries to the Ukrainian armed forces. We do not want a proxy war in Ukraine. We need to find other and smarter answers to this challenge.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, I think it is clear that on counter-terrorism our public requires decisive engagement by the 28 Member States. By decisive I mean now. What I heard from the Council and also what we have seen in terms of leaked information by no means meets these expectations. I also believe that we need to be willing to intervene not only politically in crises that are affecting our security but, if need be, also in military terms. I am not sure we are sufficiently aware of the fact that our security is also being affected outside Europe. I have a few points. On arms trafficking, many of the killings and terrorist attacks committed in Europe used European arms. European arms are being used by Islamic State and by the separatists. Something is wrong. We need to review the EU rules in this respect. We need to be able to track down and destroy them. We need to monitor where our arms are going. So I would very much welcome concrete proposals and I call on the Commission to come forward with them quickly. On border controls, I am happy that we are not hearing too much today about free movement, but it is clear that we need to strengthen our border controls. We also need to focus on the EU nationals who are entering and exiting EU territory. My final remark concerns third countries. We should not overlook the fact that we need to work to strengthen the intelligence of countries in the Maghreb, in the North of Africa and in the Middle East, and we need to work with them. This is something that should not be neglected. Finally, just one sentence on Greece ... (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Congressman, I'm sorry. You have said that europe is flooding with weapons and in this context we are somehow contributing to the various conflicts. Although there is a process of return, money is flowing from Russia to Europe. And I ask whether you agree that the various funds coming from Russia should not be accepted by European political organisations?

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I am not sure if I understood the question, or at least the translation. Russian investments in political parties? If the question was whether there are political parties which are financed by Russian capital, the answer is that I do have a serious problem with that. With regard to arms trafficking, I would invite the honourable Member and anybody else to a seminar in this House on the 3rd of next month that will show concrete examples, with taped recordings, of cases of arms trafficking. I think that is alarming.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, Alexis Tsipras, in his inauguration speech in the Greek Parliament, says two things: one, we want to pay the debt; two, we want to find a solution, mutually beneficial to Greece and our partners. Is this radical? No. Proposals from the Greek Government: bridge agreement until June and link debt payment to growth. Is this radical? No. European Central Bank response: no, you continue to do the same thing that has led Greece to disaster. Is this radical? Yes. I want to address the European socialist family: help us to put our feet on the radicals, because if they don't do it now, what awaits us in Europe is really radical. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Iglesias, was it the EU that was running Greece before its accession to the euro? Was it the European Union that was working with concrete figures? Is what Guy Verhofstadt has said not fair? That if you really want to renegotiate some of the basics, is not the first step – as it was with the post-Communist countries in the 1990s – to come with a credible reform, with a lot of sacrifices, and then say this is what we need from you, and then you can negotiate? Is that not the right approach?

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – Dear colleague, I would remind you that in 1953 european countries forgave much of the debt to Germany and, as you know, Greece's three major problems — inequality, unemployment and debt — have not been solved by the policies that have been implemented so far. Democracy means, dear colleague, that when something doesn't work, you can change to do something else. You should be more humble and recognise that the policies it has forced to implement to the Greek Government and other European countries have been completely ineffective in solving the problems of Europeans. And you're responsible for us being in this situation.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of terrorism, it is our absolute duty to protect European citizens. And courage is to tell the truth to public opinion. A rush of security would not protect us, it would damage our democracies by reducing the civil liberties of all. However, our enemy feeds precisely on every democratic setback. It uses the inequalities of our societies to recruit lost and humiliated children. Detection and monitoring are essential. But to prevent radicalization, we must fight to build a society of inclusion, which remains our greatest force against the murderous madness of terrorists. We will not win by using only force. We must also combat the imagination of the clash of civilizations and the reality of humiliation, unemployment and exclusion. To combat terrorism, we must combat the opacity of European tax havens and punish European banks that launder funds intended for terrorists by prohibiting them from operating in Europe, such as HSBC Bank. It's much more effective than spending $500 million on a random NP.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD). -
text: Sometimes the 'fight against terrorism' is no longer an appropriate wording. In Europe, not a formal war is taking place in the first year, there can only be opinions unless, because of its scale: it may appear local, others may talk about the global fire of terrorism. However, whatever the threat of total war, we must also pay attention to the economic things of Europe. Some things, especially financial ones, are very serious about the problems here, but no less worrying has lately been caused by the increasing social exclusion. European countries are emerging very rapidly a new class of deprivation and social exclusion, which is chronically lacking in income consumption and dignified living. I therefore call once again for the introduction of a uniform minimum income per person for subsistence in the Countries of the European Union. I would ask heads of state to call on the European Commission to take a legislative initiative to set minimum basic income criteria that meet the standard of living throughout the European Union. I would like to recall that almost 200 MePs from different Countries of the European Union have already supported such an initiative.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI). -
text: Tomorrow's summit paves the way for even tougher unpopular measures in all the Member States of the European Union, against the background of the negotiation discussions on the new Memorandum of Understanding for Greece. The negotiation is not for the people's interests but for the way in which the people will repay the debt of the plutocracy, whatever name the new agreement is presented. In this house many attribute characteristics to SYRIZA which does not have and to its new government together with the ANEL, because it adopts 70% of the measures of the memorandum which it otherwise condemns and assures that it will respect the Stability Pact which requires the support of large capital and frugal life for the people. The Greek communists are fighting to recover the losses of the people in the direction of disengagement from the European Union by unilaterally writing off the debt, with the people in power. This is the real pro-grassroots way out and that is why we are fighting for it and we believe that the people can also resolutely fight in the next period.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to thank President Tusk and the Latvian Presidency for deciding to give priority to the next European Council to the fight against terrorism, as we, the French EPP delegation, had requested. Ladies and gentlemen, in the fight against terrorism, we cannot take to the streets on 11 January and refuse, on 11 February, the only effective new measure that depends on the European Union! The political question before us is not "Does it need a PNR? Or no PNR?", but "Will we have a European NNP or 28 national NNP?" with, of course, in the latter case, the same problems for freedoms and significantly less effectiveness for the prevention of terrorism. Those who make this choice underestimate the danger of terrorism and trust their national parliament more than the European Parliament to defend freedoms. It is strange, at least on the part of those who are willing to call themselves federalists. Let's be serious! Let's be responsible! The honour and greatness of our democracies is to fight terrorism in accordance with the rules of the rule of law. We have been able to do this: Spain has been able to do so against ETA, the United Kingdom and Ireland against the IRA, Germany, Italy and France against extremist movements on the right or the left. These were internal problems within a country, or binational. War is now declared to all of Europe, to all our countries, to all our common values. A text is ready! Of course, it can be improved, but it must be voted on very quickly. We spend our time criticizing governments that favour "everyone for themselves." For once, governments recognize the limits of national action and call for European action. Our European Parliament must be the first to contribute to it, not the last to resign itself to it.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D). -
text: Mr. President! As Vice-President Timmermans said earlier: we all hope for the talks today in Minsk. Tomorrow, when the Council meets, we will know whether there have been any results and what results have been achieved. We expect two things from the Council: unity and clarity. This clarity means, first of all, that Ukraine knows that it can rely on our support, politically and economically, in enforcing reforms, in steadfastness when it comes to the sovereignty and integrity of the country and when it comes to humanitarian aid. Part of the truth is that we are clearly saying that there will be no military solution to this conflict. The supply of weapons will not help to defuse the conflict, but will have the opposite effect. The truth is that our objective remains to integrate Russia into a pan-European political, economic and security structure. But it must be clear that this presupposes the resolution of the Ukraine conflict. Without substantial progress, there can therefore be no easing of sanctions. I would like to make two requests on the sanctions. On the one hand, it is not enough for sanctions to extend the list of names for any ban until we have the last company chief on this list, but there must then be more substantial things and economic things. I believe that this is part of the fact that we are not calling for weapons to be supplied. The second request, you say, is what sanctions will be lifted and when if there is substantial progress. This form of predictability is good for all concerned.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr President, mr President, mr President-in-Office of the Council, mr President-in-Office of the Council, mr President-in-Office Weber that his attempt to slander the Greek people and the political parties of the current ruling majority will not pass. It seems, Mr Weber, that you have no idea of persons and situations in Greece and your extreme and divisive positions have isolated you even here in the European Parliament. I would therefore remind you that the Troika's decisions on Greece have torn the Greek economy apart and created a huge humanitarian crisis. That is why the Troika must put its hand deep in its pocket and compensate Greece with several hundred billion euros. The Greek people, with the result of the elections of 25 January, sent a decisive message about the end of the Troika and the memorandums, the write-off of the shameful debt and the immediate demand for the payment of German reparations and the occupation loan. The ECB's blackmail policy will not bend the spirit and determination of the Greek people. That is the message to the European Council and the Eurogroup. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 192(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. – You used the right word: humanitarian crisis. It has been used in this Chamber a little today, when there has been talk of Greece. There is indeed a humanitarian crisis, and I am sure that tomorrow's Council will look for a solution. That is why I ask: is it not wrong and unreasonable that, at a time when a compromise is being negotiated, you are digging up these old ghosts and talking, for example, about wartime debts and others? Must we not now have the spirit of seeking a compromise in order to put an end to the humanitarian crisis?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: 'blue card' reply. – War reparations have been identified by the 1946 International Conference. Greece is the only country in which war reparations have not been paid. At the same time, Germany, during the Occupation, forced Greece to give it a loan. All this destroyed the Greek economy. These debts are legal and must be given: EUR 108 billion in total, excluding interest. This is how international legitimacy must be restored. Everyone here says the law must be respected. Well, the law will also be respected in this case. German war reparations and the occupation loan will be paid. That's the reality. (Applause)

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, today this Parliament should condemn the extortion to which the European Central Bank is subjecting the Greek people; a European Central Bank that acts as a gang of mobsters, blackmailing Greece into suffocating those who have decided to get out of the way of austerity and who have decided to get out of the policies that allow the rich to evade taxes, that banks are rescued with public money and that the people go hungry. The European Central Bank's measures are a punishment for those who have dared to vote on the left; they are a punishment for those who have dared to challenge the powerful and put life and dignity above their macroeconomic calculations.  They want to apply a corrective to the Greeks and the Greeks so that they can learn to vote well and not to get out of the fold again; they also want to launch a "warning for navigators" so that no one can ever think of contradicting the almighty of the Bundesbank again.  But let us not deceive ourselves: this is not Syriza against Europe; this is the people against the tycoons and mangants of the European Union.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE). -
text: The only effective counterterrorism action is one that stops more terrorists than helps recruit them. It's a lesson we should learn through past events. However, such a action requires, above all, three preconditions: firstly, terrorist measures must be effective. Our citizens have the right to demand their governments defend effectively against extremist violence. Secondly, counter-terrorism measures must be proportionate and must not over-trample our rights, our dignity and fundamental freedoms, because these values are not at conflict with security. And thirdly, all measures must be taken in the widest possible range of countries. Terrorism is not something we can only fight in our own backyard, we need close, deep and as wide-based international cooperation as possible. For all these reasons, it is essential that the European Union also support in its counter-terrorism policy the measures taken within the Council of Europe, an organisation that shares with us fundamental values and legally binding standards.  This does not, of course, in any way restrict us from interveneing in measures, which, of course, must be proportionate to our rights, because only together with the Council of Europe can we be stronger.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul PNR is an important tool in the fight against terrorism that we urgently need to put in place in order to control those who travel. At a time of terrorism and extremism, we must be able to act decisively and resolutely. I, and we who sit here, we were born and raised in Europe and love the democratic society our ancestors have built up. I am not giving a centimetre to the methods of terrorism.  I have a clear message for you: if you abhor our democratic Western way of life to the point where terrorism is used to introduce a new way of life in Europe, then stay in those countries that better live up to your demands. Because if you do not respect the democracy our ancestors have fought for hundreds of years, you are simply not welcome in our countries. \*(The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, Mr Lundgren, you have just spoken out for the European NRL. However, do you not minimize the risk of civil liberties? Personal information will be disclosed everywhere, including our American partner. Is there not, in your view, a danger to freedoms?

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD)
text: answer ("blue card"). I do not believe that this is a danger to freedom. For those who have, as we say in Sweden, clean flour in the bag, an honest intention and have no shady intentions have nothing to fear from this registration.

name: Gerolf Annemans (NI). -
text: Mr President, the most important question at the forthcoming European Summit is whether we can continue with this Union, and in particular this currency union, after the Greek elections. At the forthcoming Summit, therefore, there is a historical debate about whether the political decision to make a currency, based on fallacies and structural errors from the outset, was not a mistake that we must reverse. There is no such thing as a free lunch. Greece will never be in a position to regain its competitiveness within the euro system. So either, not only in practice but now it is officially said that the eurozone is a transfer system and then, as Obama ordered us the day before yesterday, we have to make a debt write-off or a debt rescheduling variant, or we have to fix the mistakes of yesteryear and give Greece new life, get out of prison. Either Obama or grexit, there aren't many other possibilities. One must apply basic principles of good management and dare to return in modesty to wrong decisions instead of hiding wrong decisions under new wrong decisions over and over again.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that today we really are facing many challenges, as my fellow Members have said, but this is a time when we must not just respond to the needs of the political moment, however delicate it may be. This is an overall challenge that we need to take up and win. As my colleague Alain Lamassoure said very well, do we want a European PMR or do we want 28 national pmrs?  And so it is for everything. These challenges require us to be Europe, Europe proudly Europe, with our values, as the Council has also mentioned. We must put in place a positive narrative, I agree with what the Council has said. So let us be careful because we are seeing a very dangerous escalation. We have moved on from the Cold War – and I am referring to Ukraine – which we thought was forgotten and, in a few weeks, we fear the danger of armed conflict. I believe that Europe, between nobel laureate Barak Obama and Putin, must not only seek but must find a way to peace. That is what our fellow citizens are asking us to do, that is our destiny if we are to be Europe. And then there is terrorism. We need to get out of the preconceptions. As far as immigration is concerned, the dead have also been mentioned before – and I am sorry that Mr Pittella is no longer there – but it is fake buonismo, because when there was the expensive mission to pick up immigrants we had 3 538 deaths, we were always wrong. We need to get out of our preconceptions. We have to face things by looking them in the face, listening to each other, recognizing the real problem we are facing. And finally, Greece. You said well, the Greek people deserve attention. I say more, I say that Greece is the cradle of our civilisation, there is no Europe without Greece and I am convinced that you will also be able, by finding the solution, to bring the solidarity of the whole Parliament to all the Greek people.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D). -
text: Mr. President! Terrorism wants to create fear, is a direct attack on our values. We must not give in to that. "Je suis Charlie" – this call for tolerance and freedom must guide our actions in the review of security measures. Complaints about security vulnerabilities remain implausible as long as existing measures are not used effectively. New measures must meet the criteria of the rule of law. For mass data collections, the ECJ ruling on data retention has set guidelines that must be observed. The Commission must now set out what this means in concrete terms. We need clear common standards in Europe for the safe handling of data. The Council must finally define its position on the whole data protection package. Ultimately, however, it is clear that all security measures will fail if we do not clearly combat the causes. There are many tasks in the field of foreign, development and trade policy. Within the EU, we, the Member States, must step up their efforts in the field of education, social affairs and inclusion. The various forms of discrimination and exclusion must be eliminated in the long term. More than ever, the following applies to all of us: freedom needs security, including social security. But security measures must not always restrict freedom.

name: Николай Бареков (ECR). -
text: Mr President, colleagues, today the debate covers two important topics: terrorism and Greece, I would say SYRIZA. What do they have in common? There is, and that's poverty. Poverty has brought terrorism to Europe, poverty has brought SYRIZA to power. We must clearly acknowledge to ourselves that Europe and the European institutions have failed both in the security system and in the measures that have been implemented in Greece in recent years, which have virtually destroyed the Greek economy. Today, two countries in Europe are europe's external border relative to countries that export terrorism. These are Bulgaria and Greece. I assure you that these countries (Bulgaria and Greece) are no less secure, or even more secure, than France and Belgium. I insist on an extraordinary approach and new measures to the financing and security of the external borders of the Republic of Bulgaria, as well as a special approach to Greece and poverty in these countries.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI). -
text: Mr President, the issue of Greece and the recent changes in the political chessboard have emerged as the leading topic of discussion in Europe's institutions and society. For five years Germany and its satellite countries had imposed memoranda and harsh measures, imposed puppet governments with their propaganda and delivered and delivered special lessons in economics testing the strengths of the Greek, and not only, people. Especially for Greece, the long recession and irrational fiscal measures have led to uncontrolled situations. Defeated Germany, with its long history of two world wars, millions of deaths and inhumane crimes, has declared a new economic war against its partners. Anyone who agrees with her is good, anyone who disagrees must comply. The German cause justifies the means. He's forgotten the world lessons he's learned. Soon the German citizens will understand that it is not everyone else's fault, especially the supposedly lazy Greeks. It is only a matter of time before Merkel realizes that Europe cannot stand a Germany of power and bandit, which constantly threatens and demands. The Greeks do not want a Germany that sends its agents to buy out governments, that does not pay its own debts, such as the owner's loan and war reparations. Germany owes us, we don't owe her. Nazis and fascists are not the executives and voters of Golden Dawn. Some people who ostentatiously move their finger, let's look in the mirror. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I agree with you on the rescue policy. But you want to get debt for given up now. But it is not only Germany that has money in Greece, it is not only Germany that will lose money, but also Slovakia. Czech Republic, but slovenia and other countries, for example. How does Slovakia get us to send you money? I would ask you that.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: 'blue card' reply. We don't want anyone to give us money. It has already been said, and from this Chamber, that all debts will be covered. But you also have to think about what interest rates you have taken, and Germany and Austria and all of you.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Vice-President of the European Commission, Representative of the Council, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has Today and tomorrow at the summit are the fight against terrorism, the Ukraine crisis, Greece. Huge challenges! In view of the debate we have had today, I would like to begin by saying that I think it is the most important thing that we in this European Union stick together, that we stand together. After all, how are we going to fight terrorism effectively, how are we going to help shape a solution for Ukraine if we do not stick together? That is my request to those present to pass this on to those responsible who will meet tomorrow at the summit, that we try to keep our House together here. Secondly, I think we must remain consistent in our policy. Consistency creates reliability, creates trust – I believe, even with an outward view, that we can only show strength if we also have a certain consistency. For me, staying consistent means relying on what we have agreed to. In other words, once agreement has been reached on the rules of the game, these rules must also apply to all countries. That brings me to the subject of Greece. A great deal of unsightly things have been said about Germany today. It's not about Germany - it's about Greece. The European Union and the Member States, as well as my country, have been travelling here in great solidarity with Greece for many years. That is right, and it should remain so. But this cannot be a one-way street, but there is only solidarity, even if there is some consideration. And if you agree on agreements, if you agree on common rules of the game, then you have to stick to them! Anyone who thinks that they can unilaterally break up these rules of the game can do so, but then, please, you have to live with the consequences yourself and not blame all the other Member States in the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: the blue card. – There is a lot of talk about sanctions against Russia, but individual European countries today support Russia by buying energy from it, for example, Lithuania has a gas terminal, but the use is minimal, even Latvia cannot sell, because the Latvian economy is owned by Gazprom. Is it not time to start operating and at least temporarily abandon russia's energy source?

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Ropé, I am not a representative from Latvia, so I cannot comment on that. I can only say that all the Member States have agreed on sanctions against Russia at various stages. These sanctions are also respected. Depending on how the talks are going today in Minsk, further discussion susbly and further consideration will be provided. But the agreements are in place, and the states are sticking to them.

name: Sergei Stanishev (S&D). -
text: Mr President, there is an important Council tomorrow and it is natural to have a heated and extensive debate. On the security issue and counter-terrorism, I would like to underline the fact that we still have a divided European security area: until Bulgaria and Romania are part of Schengen, this undermines our common security. Secondly, on Greece, we do not need arm twisting or a clash between two views. Europe is based on mutual respect and constructive dialogue, and that dialogue will take into consideration not only the results of the elections but also the undertakings that have been given and the unity and cohesion of the eurozone. It is clear that Europe needs a new deal for Greece, a new perspective, and hope for the people. Finally, on the talks in Minsk, we need to be constructive because this bloodshed has to be stopped. We can no longer afford it: there are 1.5 million refugees, internal and external, among them people who are suffering. There are between 300 000 and 500 000 Bulgarians living in Ukraine, and I call on the European Union and the Bulgarian Government to extend humanitarian support to them.

name: Marcel de Graaff (NI). -
text: Mr President, tomorrow the European Council will be meeting on three important items on the agenda, and I am giving the following advice on this: the Greek debt crisis. Tsipras is absolutely right. The approach adopted has completely failed. Therefore: repay debts in full, not a penny of extra credit, and Greece must get out of the euro immediately. Islamic extremism. Thousands of jihadis come in as asylum seekers. Frontex is a complete bubble. That is why: stop Schengen, reintroduce internal borders, limit refugees from Muslim countries. Finally, Ukraine. We do not want a new cold war, and certainly no direct war with Russia. Therefore: de-escalate in Ukraine, no weapons to a government that commits war crimes, and no money to a bankrupt country sick with corruption.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the Paris attack is the first to have been interpreted not as against a particular European country, but as against the whole of Europe. That is why we are doing well in the European Parliament today by adopting a joint resolution, of all political forces, against terrorism. We did not vote on a resolution on the PNR, we voted on an anti-terrorism resolution. And I think whoever for the PNR doesn't sign the Counter-Terrorism Resolution is going to have a hard time explaining it to their constituents. We have differences, we have them, but terrorism has to unite us in the fight against it. Terrorists don't win when they kill. Terrorists win when they manage to separate us from democrats. I'm going to talk about Greece, too. It seems to me that this is a historic moment and that the European Union's response to the situation raised by the Greek Government is a response that will condition the future of Europe. And I pray to everyone not to confuse the new Greek government with the Greek people, because they are completely different things. I believe that if a country gains advantages from non-compliance, all countries will fail to comply. Loyalty will be broken. I believe that if elections are won in a country arguing that You don't have to pay Germany or Portugal or Spain or France, in France, Spain, Portugal, Germany you'll win the elections by saying you don't have to give Greece any more money. I believe that if we awaken in one place in Europe the nationalist ghost of the far left, in the opposite place in Europe will awaken the nationalist ghost of the far right. I believe that if a country does not return what has been lent to it, no other country will lend again. I think the rules are either for everyone, or they're just not for anyone. I believe that this European Parliament can never agree with those who say that Europe is the problem, because those of us here are because we believe that Europe is the solution.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D). -
text: Mr President, in recent weeks, in the context of the fight against terrorism, the european Parliament has been looking forward to it. There have been - and unfortunately - attempts to instrumentalize the debate, in a dummy opposition between, on the one hand, sweet dreamers in Parliament, defenders of individual freedoms and, on the other, a pragmatic and responsible Council. That was not up to the challenge. Fortunately, in-depth discussions have led to the evolution of these positions, particularly on the NRL, and I welcome that. At this point in the debate, it seems to me that we must continue to pay attention to a pitfall that First Vice-President Timmermans put it well in his remarks earlier. This pitfall would consist of focusing exclusively on the implementation of new devices, without properly testing existing tools, their evaluation and full implementation. European action in the fight against terrorism is a long-term action and the toolkit is well-stocked. So let's put these instruments to the test. Among them is the Schengen code, for which I think we must give the right signals. Thus, it would be quite incomprehensible for the Council to concentrate on a reform project that would ultimately enable it to do what it already can do.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: With regard to counter-terrorism measures, I would like to draw the attention of the european Parliament, the European Commission and the participants in tomorrow's meeting of Heads of State or Government to a very important and dramatic fact. This is the fact that, during this time, terrorist groups or elements, whether armed or equipped with explosives, can enter the European Union without further ado. This is because the European Union's external Schengen border is completely unguarded for a very large stretch. It has now been made public by the international press – I am amazed that this was not the case today – that around 1 500 border offenders come through every day on the Hungarian-Serbian border, in the area of Ásotthalom and its surroundings, without any checks. Most of them are Kosovans, but there are a very large number of Syrians, Afghans, people from different African countries. Virtually no one checks their identities or the items they bring with them. I await the Commissioner's reply on what he thinks of this. I am also looking forward to taking action on behalf of the Hungarian people in southern Hungary whose lives are made impossible and made hell by what is happening on the southern border because of the unguarded border.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE). -
text: A very important Council meeting will take place tomorrow. That is why it is also important to take a step back and see how well the actions, decisions and actions we have taken so far have been correct. If we look back at the european Union's response when the crisis erupted, we see that these steps were highly uncertain. What is more, we see that we have forgotten that this is a community, that we are in solidarity with each other, that we must listen to each other's decisions and not put obstacles in each other's paths, but that we must think together. I think we have not already made this mistake in the case of acts of terrorism, which was a very, very good move. We also need to look at the important tasks that lie ahead. I don't know if this extraordinary summit is suitable for this, but we have very important tasks to do. There are 26 million unemployed people in the European Union. In the meantime, the decisions that some Member States have taken and have led to have been made will not be taken. My country, Hungary, for example, has given very important subsidies to workers under the age of 25 in reducing their burden – I am talking about a 14.5% reduction in contributions. Or, in the case of graduates, the government took over the payment of this burden for two years. I think these are good practices. I expect the Commission not only to receive criticism, but also to insert these proposals into joint European decision-making as a result of joint decisions. The issue of migration cannot, of course, be circumvented. It has already been mentioned, but I think that because of political correctness, we are not talking openly about this issue. On the other hand, we do not speak openly about the fact that we have fundamental rights that are threatened – such as the free movement of labour. I expect the Council to answer these questions.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking We have heard that the next summit will have three themes: counter-terrorism, the state of economic and monetary union and ukraine. Mr Timmermans has made this a beautiful word – fear. Fear as a source of radicalization. Let's not be surprised, yes, people feel fear, feel fear, feel fear on the street, at the airport, on the train, at school, etc. They also feel fear of losing their jobs, of the prospect of a low pension, of getting a job in general (especially young people), of fear of being unable to repay their loan and therefore of losing their housing, etc., and finally of a new element – they feel fear of war.  Mr Timmermans, you have said that prudence is needed. Prudence is needed, but action is also needed. People ask who we are based on. You spoke about these new instruments. The fundamental question is: will tomorrow's Council really bring us new solutions, new instruments, new hopes? This will be a source of deradicalisation. Without answers to these questions, deradicalisation is unlikely.  Last but not least, the glorious 90 million aid to Ukraine is EUR 1.83 per Ukrainian citizen, which is not so much.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to express my opinion on the roadmap to monetary union. First of all, the reforms implemented through the roadmap have contributed to the stability of Europe, and I guess we can be proud of them. In particular, the changes in banking supervision and regulation and in crisis management are key for the future of Europe. In my view, the fiscal crisis management system works better than we have seen from the experience of Greece. It has helped many countries to make a turnaround from serious economic crisis to growth. Let me remind our Greek colleagues that, for the time being, the cost of servicing the Greek debt, given the generous support for the credit risk, is lower than for many countries in the European Union, including some donor countries. The issue of the cost of servicing the debt is crucial for Europe and we should do our best to keep this cost down. Sound fiscal management, following the rules and good crisis management are the way forward. The last part of the roadmap concerns fiscal capacity. I am not sure if this is feasible for the time being, as there is significant divergence among those who are supposed to be using this fiscal facility and those who are financing it about how it should work.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D). -
text: Mr President Herman van Rompuy, before becoming President of the European Council, had proposed the holding of an extraordinary European Council in February 2010 to discuss economic governance. It could not take place because Mr van Rompuy had to deal with the urgency of the situation in Greece. In February 2015, for its first European Council, the new President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, also proposed an extraordinary European Council on the issue of economic governance and on a report which is to be that of the four presidents, but which we want to see become the report of the five presidents. Presumably, it will not be able to do so, because other topics have been invited to the agenda: terrorism, Ukraine and Greece. I think the Europeans are getting tired of this situation. These issues, which seem to be able to be postponed until the next day, must in fact now be dealt with as a matter of urgency. For, in the meantime, it is also for this reason that the Greek economy has diverged, tinkered and invented a troika to which the Greek people have just said that they no longer want to subscribe. For imposing structural reform from abroad is to feed Euroscepticism. It is therefore urgent that the European Council does its job, which is to find the way that will enable us to achieve the deepening and completion of economic and monetary union.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE). -
text: I would like to say that this is a Council which has two very important themes: the subject of terrorism and, in particular, the theme of Ukraine, which is a hot topic. But I wanted to focus on the issue of Greece. And I wanted to say that it is not just the economic theme that concerns us here. What I ask the GUE, and even the left-wing MPs, is what they would be saying if by chance any Party of the EPP or even the S&D was connected with a party like the independent Greeks. What would they be saying in this House? When they did what they did to Austria with Mr. Haider, when they often evoked Mr Berlusconi, Hungary, what would they be saying? Now they've bleached everything on the far right, and this coalition of the far right and the far left shows well what we have ahead of us.  But there is one other thing that worries me a lot: it is what will be of the Union's foreign policy, with this government and with these visions. We are in this very serious problem of Ukraine, and the first gesture that the Greek government has is to support Russia and its way of looking at the Ukrainian problem. This is extremely worrying. It is not only the will ingness not to pay, the will to break the commitments that concern us. It is a whole way of being typical of the extreme left, which will call into question what are the values of the European Union, its values of rule of law and its values of fundamental rights. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the blue card procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (GUE/NGL)
text: 'blue card' question. – Dear colleague, the Greek people voted against the policy of austerity imposed on them against their will. Now what are you asking for? Recall his vote?

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. "I do not want them to vote again and I am very respectful of the election result and the choice of the Greeks. What I wanted to tell you was this: how is the far left united to the far right? That's what you didn't explain. Why is Greece supporting Russia in the Ukrainian conflict? That's what you didn't explain. Those were the answers I'd like you to give us. On that day, I could be more reassured with this Greek government, with these kind of statements.  And as far as austerity is about austerity, allow me to tell you one thing: the Portuguese people have also suffered a lot of austerity, and we today, contrary to what some have said here, are clearly better off than we were in 2011. We are on a path of sustainability and coming out of an extremely serious crisis, we are growing, with unemployment falling. So here's a good example that I think we can follow if we implement the right policies at the right time. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the blue card procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL)
text: 'blue card' question. Mr President, it is necessary. Mr President, I would like to ask you: Do you know that a unanimous decision was taken in the Council of Foreign Ministers on Ukraine with the constructive contribution of the Greek Government, which also provoked the positive comments of Federica Mogherini? Do you consider Mrs. Mogherini extremist? Independent Greeks participate in the ECR Eurogroup. Do you also consider British conservative extremists? Are you the extremist?

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. "I don't know why I'm an extremist. I'd like to know. The only thing I say is: the independent Greeks are clearly a far-right group. But I will tell you this: they care as much about Syriza, which is a far-left group. From my point of view on what are the typical values of the European Union, both are in the same group. In fact, that's why they got coalition and that's why Ms. Le Pen supports the Syriza government.  And, moreover, allow me to also tell you, by the way, on the issue of Russia, which every day, as the leaders of the Greek government have done, signals misconceptions in Europe. One day you say one thing, and the other day you say another. Just say what suits you. It says one thing to the Greek public and says something else to European public opinion. And that's the ambiguity I want to denounce here.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, an agreement on Greece is necessary and possible and it would be good if, instead of fanting and making ideology, everyone showed pragmatism and responsibility. On the one hand, it is clear that debts must be paid and that aid cannot be unconditional, but asking for a primary surplus of 4.5% to a country with 26% unemployment is economically senseless and puts debt sustainability at risk and should therefore primarily worry creditors. Agreeing on an extension of maturity, more rational conditionalities and a mechanism for their most democratic verification is possible, even if it takes time. In the meantime, the difference between a bridge loan and a technical extension of the programme under certain revised conditions does not seem unbridgeable, and we call on the Commission to help the governments to fill it by freeing them from their internal political constraints. In fact, another lesson from this affair is that we need a more advanced balance between national democracy and European democracy, and this must also be one of the basic lines of the new relaunch of the process of deepening economic and monetary union.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (PPE). -
text: Mr President, with regard to the economic crisis, monetary stability and the economic development of the States, we must certainly wait for the discussion of the Greek issue today in the extraordinary Eurogroup and tomorrow in the Council. However, we must all remember that the Greek people always assume their responsibilities and that is what they will do now, and the European Union will have to take its own on the basis of solidarity in order to find a compromise that will benefit everyone. Frontal conflicts are not in line with the spirit of recession and progress in the European Union. Greece must remain in the eurozone, and, with the support of its partners and with reforms, it will find its way to growth and prosperity. I am of the opinion that the European South, the Greek people, cannot be strangled any more, nor can a democratically elected government be demonised and damned even before it takes over. After all, this House has decided that the Troika has committed human rights violations through its methodologies and we must not forget that no one or very few have found jobs since the implementation of the memorandums in the countries of the European South from which I too come.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (S&D). -
text: Mr President, development and a programme to ensure it. This is what Greece is looking for in negotiating with its partners. You all know the situation in my country. 25 years of irrational economic policy based on free or cheap money have led to the destruction of production capacity and have not created a new one. And when the bubble burst, panicked governments adopted, embraced, accepted a programme of harsh austerity, unable to give their own answers. But they also implemented this cruel programme in the worst way, refusing reforms that would affect their client state, their customers, large or small. And let me say it again: A programme of harsh austerity that is not accompanied by growth does not give way. What is needed, then, is to ensure reforms, to continue the programme of support but without the socially unjust measures that are also ineffective. And these reforms will be made by Europe together with the Greek government, which is already giving signs of realism, moving away from the impasse of its pre-election rhetoric. And I am not referring, of course, to the far-right component, which can only cause disgust, and there is no reason for the Left and Mrs Zimmer to support it in such a way. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: "blue card" question. The vote must always be respected, and that is a fundamental condition. I hope that, in the face of so much austerity that has been imposed on Greece, the Commission will know the poverty of the Member States because, as it has been a problem and it is for Greece, it can also be a problem for other emerging states, such as Italy. I therefore hope that the Commission and the Commissioners will know very well what the conditions are for the Greek people.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (S&D)
text: 'blue card' reply. I did not understand the question, Mr President, but I would like to say that I am sure that, like all of us, the European institutions are aware of the situation of the Greek people, but they also know that a programme that ensures development is the only way out of this vicious circle. There's no one else, and that's what we're looking for.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D). -
text: Mr President, as the final speaker listed, and having listened to the contributions, I want to say two things. Firstly, we need to learn the lessons of what has happened with regard to the anti-terrorism part of what will be discussed at the informal Council; and secondly we must stay united. Why should we be united on the anti-terrorism fight? First of all, as many people have said, while we are dealing with the Passenger Name Record (PNR) scheme, there is almost a disproportionate concentration on it. Parliament has moved swiftly on this, so we have shown our commitment today, and within a few minutes we will vote on PNR. Yes, it is controversial because the last terrorist outrage, before what we saw on the streets of Paris, was in 2005 in London, and we have since produced the Data Retention Directive, and we have to learn the lessons of what happened. We need legislation which is worthy of our citizens and worthy of this House, and which will stand the tests of time and the European Court of Justice. We have to learn the lessons. So Parliament will move swiftly, but that means that we must be united, and that the Council must do its job. It means that Europol and the Europol Regulation must happen. It means that the data regulation package, which underpins so much of what will happen with PNR, must also happen. You do your job, Council, and the Commission – so eloquently represented by Mr Timmermans – will be there to help us through this, through the informal Council and through our job. That means being unified because, at the end of the day, terrorism is an attack on our security and an attack on life, but if we are united we will have helped our citizens through a profoundly challenging moment in our history. We cannot do that if we do not see the institutions working together. What will that mean in terms of learning other lessons? It means that the causes of radicalisation, and all the other tools in our toolbox aside from PNR, must be our business, as we learn the lessons and cooperate. If our citizens see this, they will see first that we have learned the lessons and then that we can remain united. We will still have differences – this is not a perfect resolution that we will be voting on in a few minutes’ time – but we will have done a service to our citizens in the end.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking We are discussing three fundamental problems. Let us remember that terrorism has its own external conditions and roots, but it is also the result of our mistakes and omissions in Europe. Problem two: the crisis in Greece will not resolve itself. Only Greece can do this with the support of the Union. The Union cannot say no and Greece must not put up too costly conditions. We need concerted action, reform and agreement. Otherwise, a similar situation will occur in other parts of Europe. The Union's biggest omission to Ukraine was the lack of reform support in the country and very modest humanitarian aid. History is such that it is often necessary to choose the lesser evil out of necessity. Sometimes difficult concessions even against each other and today must be made to defend the statehood and development opportunities of the country. Only a developing Ukraine will be attractive for a return in the future. (The President has received a vote from the Member)

name: Ana Gomes (S&D). -
text: Mr President, terrorism is being financed through tax havens while the EU governments and institutions look the other way. Injustice, outrage and terror are what EU taxpaying citizens feel in the face of the Lux Leaks and Swiss Leaks revelations. Will the Council and the Commission finally act against this terror? No other strategy against terrorism will work if we do not ditch the blind austerity that has been strangling growth in Europe and fuelling unemployment, social exclusion and the nihilist ideology driving young Europeans to fight with Daesh – and training closer than ever now in Libya. Terror and destruction is what the Greeks, and the EU, will face if a negotiated solution is not found urgently to enable the Greeks to breathe and to work to pay debts. Last but not least, terror is what the Ukrainians are facing. We do not simply want old Europe and old Russia negotiating over Ukraine. Out of Minsk we want peace for all of Europe.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Today's talks in Minsk will take place on a special day because exactly on the 70th anniversary of the Yarat agreements. 70 years ago, these agreements were not only a humiliating act of Western weakness, but also a drastic violation of the human rights of millions of people in Central Europe. I am talking about this today, because the consequences of this disgrace are still ongoing. The fact that our Parliament did not want to recall this is unfortunately a sad act of contempt for our history and for the millions of people living in half of the European Union. I just hope that tomorrow, after today's talks in Minsk, we will be able to say with a clear conscience that we did not take part in the new Yarcie.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE). -
text: Mr. President, what I certainly want to note is what's going to happen tomorrow. Tomorrow is really the last chance to get to peace and all that we want to say about Ukraine today is certainly that tomorrow's meeting should be a meeting of agreements, a compromise meeting and a meeting from which everyone will come out stronger, braver, because to achieve peace, to win peace is actually real courage.  What I want to underline is a sentence said yesterday by Ms Mogherini, referring to the fact that one of the solutions involving peace in Ukraine is certainly decentralisation. This is how part of the problem can be solved and I am sure that if this concept is included, and decentralisation and subsidiarity are part of European values, it can be very beneficial for the Ukrainian people.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL). -
text: The European Council cannot ignore developments in Greece. It must discuss the problems of the Greek people and respect its verdict against the Memorandum and in favour of a social development policy. And mr. Weber constantly questions, with an undemocratic and unacceptable approach, the results of the elections and that the Greek people highlighted with their vote the Tsipras government. Finally, respect the Republic, Mr Weber! The continued undermining of the Greek people's efforts to get rid of the hoarseness of austerity and unsustainable debt must be stopped. So are the blackmails. The reasonable and fair demands of the Tsipras government must finally be accepted. The struggles of the Greek people are a matter for all of us. If the country's effort succeeds, the benefit will be for all the tested peoples of Europe, affected by the memorial policies of austerity, unemployment and poverty.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the honourable Members’ contributions. I have a few comments to make in reaction to what was said. First of all, do not get me wrong: the Passenger Name Record (PNR) scheme is not the solution to all our problems. PNR is no more than a building block in a huge construction that we need in order to fight radicalisation and terrorism in Europe. Mr Lamassoure hit the nail on the head when he said that we need a European PNR scheme because the alternative will be that Member States will take individual steps, and that is not a good alternative. However, I also believe that we need to put more effort into improving the situation of data protection at European level. Here again, I believe it is better to act collectively in order to make sure that our citizens’ fundamental rights are guaranteed at European level. That is why I believe we need increased efforts on data protection reform. Moving on to the issue of Greece, so much was said about that, and I want to repeat that the Commission is open for dialogue with Greece – on the basis of respect for the Greek people – to look for common solutions. I have to tell you that I was thinking back exactly 40 years to when I was 13 years old and one of my first moments of political consciousness was that I saw the Greek people getting rid of a very ugly military regime that had trampled on their freedoms and rights. From that moment on, we saw European solidarity. It was the efforts of the Council of Europe at the time that helped the Greek people rid themselves of dictatorship. It is too easy to say that there has been no solidarity with the Greek people since then because, for me personally, those 40 years have been marked by the fact that there was a conscious decision by the Greek people for Europe and a conscious decision by Europe to stand next to Greece: to reform and to improve the situation of its citizens. That, in my view, has not changed. So even though there might be a huge debate about the merits of the programmes and the merits of what was done in the past, I would not accept a caricature narrative that the people elsewhere in Europe have not shown solidarity with Greece in the past couple of years. It is not right to say that. There has been a show of solidarity, including by other people in Europe living in conditions not much better than those of the Greeks themselves. That solidarity – if it is up to the Commission – will not change. Moving finally to the issue of fundamental values – and I do not like to put frames on political parties and call them ‘extreme left’ or ‘extreme right’ – let us look at facts and at declarations. It is not, I believe, asking too much of Ms Zimmer to look too at certain utterances by a coalition partner of one of her parties, in this case in Greece. Is it not part of the duty of a coalition partner to tell another partner that, in Europe, we do not say that Jews do not pay taxes? It is not a contribution to tolerance or respect in Europe to say such things. We in Europe, in the European Parliament, in European political parties, do not accept homophobia as an institutional element in another political party. We will oppose that in discussion with coalition partners. I do not think this is too much to ask of a political party which calls itself left-wing. It is not too much to ask if you look back at our European history. It is not too much to ask if you look at what the colonels and their regime did to the Greek people 40 years ago. (Applause)

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, this morning’s debate spared no emotions. Divisions of views among the political groups reflect general divisions of views in Europe, and this is clear evidence that we need to continue our discussions to find a compromise. I have listened attentively to the debate and will ensure that the issues and points raised will be relayed to President Tusk. Meanwhile, I will use the opportunity to reply to some points raised during the debate. As we are short of time, unfortunately, I will not be able to reply to all the points. Many of you referred to the situation in Greece. The Eurogroup is meeting tonight and will address this question. I understand that the Eurogroup President will brief leaders tomorrow. It will also be the first time Prime Minister Tsipras meets his European Council counterparts. The Eurogroup then meets again on 16 February. All in all, we agree that existing agreements should be respected. At the same time, I believe we all agree that Greece is facing profound challenges. It is important to find a solution that will bring Greece back to the path of economic growth. I also believe you will all agree that a solution found for Greece will have to be accepted by all parties. I will dare to compare the EU to a marriage. You bind yourself to someone for better or for worse. You have your disagreements, but in a good marriage you survive the storm, being stronger and wiser, and so should the Union. Exclusion will not lead to a solution. We should not lose sight of our common goals: stability and unity. We have heard many critical remarks addressed to Greece this morning. However, Greece is not the only country in the EU to have a high debt level. The level of public debt in the eurozone in general is very high and it is rising. It is expected to be more than 94% this year – well over the 60% laid down in our Stability and Growth Pact. High debt levels hamper growth in the European Union. We all agree that bringing back growth is the most important challenge we face today. The right policy mix is the answer. The commitment to boosting investment is a step in the right direction. We need to accelerate the implementation of structural reforms in order to strengthen Europe’s competitiveness and growth. It is essential that our public spending should stay on a sustainable path. Today we discussed possible steps to fight against terrorism. I would like to refer once again to the informal Justice and Home Affairs (JHA) ministerial meeting in Riga on 29 January and to the General Affairs Council meeting yesterday, where Member States reiterated the need to put in place an EU Passenger Name Record (PNR) system. We, as the Presidency, are convinced that you understand how crucial PNR information is in detecting travel movements and patterns, and, in particular, monitoring and identifying foreign terrorist fighters and returnees. We believe that the growing number of Member States setting up national PNR systems is in itself a valid reason for harmonisation at EU level. If we fail to do this it might lead to incompatible national systems with very different levels of data protection. We understand that this is a difficult issue for some of you, but we are encouraged by the more positive comments made by several Members. We recognise the importance of the data protection package and the relevant instruments. We believe that, in the digital age, a single data protection regulation will strengthen data protection in Europe. The Latvian Presidency will devote significant efforts to the regulation of data protection, with the aim of achieving a general approach during the JHA Council in March. At the same time we recognise the difficulties of the remaining issues and of horizontal questions. Once a general approach is reached, we will start a trialogue with Parliament. I fully share the view expressed by Mr Weber and Mr Kamall that we need to tackle the problem of propaganda and radicalisation. To address the factors underlying radicalisation we shall seek to develop a comprehensive cross-sectoral approach involving all the policies concerned, including measures to promote a culture of inclusion and tolerance through, for instance, education, youth, social and regional policies. The issue of communication in the context of combating foreign terrorist fighters is challenging and sensitive. We all recognise that the internet plays a central role in radicalisation and in the recruitment of potential foreign terrorist fighters. Distinguished Members, as many of you mentioned, all our thoughts are today with Ukraine. We are, I hope, in a negotiations window. Today further talks are due to take place in Minsk. It is difficult to discuss this today as the situation is so fluid. Obviously the Council and all the EU institutions support the ongoing diplomatic efforts and I hope they will deliver progress for the population on the ground in Eastern Ukraine and in a wider perspective.  There is no alternative to a diplomatic solution to the crisis, based on respect for Ukraine’s independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity. The EU is ready to assist in these diplomatic efforts. Finally, I would like to use the opportunity provided by this morning’s debate to express our deep appreciation of the personal efforts made during the last few days by Mr Hollande and Ms Merkel in seeking a peaceful solution for Ukraine. We remain united in our efforts to withstand the aggressor. Europeans should not forget the tragic historic events of the 20th century. In this regard, our discussion tomorrow will continue in the presence of Mr Poroshenko, who has been invited by President Tusk to the informal meeting of Heads of State or Government. Honourable Members, the Council will work speedily with the other Union institutions to make sure that the EU leaders’ policy guidelines are acted upon. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Presidente. -
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – As the reporter of the European Council's discharge for the financial year 2012 and responsible for the discharge for the financial year 2013, I think it is important to say that the interinstitutional debate on the discharge of the Council and the European Council, which has been on the agenda of the Committee on Budgetary Control and the European Parliament for many years, is not expected to break the deadlock this year. The discharge of the institution is expected to be postponed by the European Parliament again this year. It is in the common interest of the institutions to settle disputes and, in future, to apply discharge to the Council in the same way as the other institutions of the European Union.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. – The First Vice-President of the European Commission expressed in his speech on the informal European Council of 12 February 2015 the need to find an adequate solution to the problem of Greek public debt. Greece is going to need a new multilateral financial assistance programme as of February 28, 2015, as it cannot secure financing in financial markets at reasonable interest rates. At the same time, the conditions of the new loan should be more favourable than in the past in terms of interest rate and repayment period, as well as in terms of conditionality, which should be less intrusive and ideological, and more focused on reforming the public administration and the tax system, and in the fight against corruption. The European Stability Mechanism can raise capital from long-term financial markets at a very low interest rate thanks to the ECB's monetary policy and low inflation. In addition, in order to preserve the necessary expenditure on social services and to combat poverty and social exclusion, the annual primary budget surplus target must be reduced.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This debate confirms the percent of the holy alliance between the right and social democracy. The nuances in speech do not hide the convergence of positions. It applies to New Democracy and PASOK in Greece, it applies to PSD-CDS and PS in Portugal. To those who talk about investment and growth but refuse to accept the need to renegotiate debts, we ask: how do they want to do it? They don't, actually. They don't think they're going to do it. Take the case of Portugal. By 2020, the country will pay only three times in debt interest than it will receive from structural and investment funds from the European Union. What investment is possible under these conditions? The bodo of the rich on belittle of the poor continues. Draghi's quantitative easing program, which nationalizes the risks of sovereign debt purchase operations but sets the back of profits, puts countries like Portugal financing Germany through the interest charged on its debt. Nothing new: it is the people of the periphery who pay the gains of the center. Debt renegotiation is necessary and inevitable, but it is not enough in itself. It is necessary to break with the policies, instruments and mechanisms of capitalist integration, intrinsically unfair, generating asymmetries and inequalities.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. – In particular, colleagues' speeches showed bipartisan agreement on the consequences of a failed single euro policy. The cause of this has been overlooked. Many colleagues talked about the serious consequences of austerity for the Greek people, but no one was talking about the fact that this is a logical consequence not only of irresponsible economic, fiscal and social policies of previous Athens governments, but also of a euro exchange rate far too high for the Greek economy. The disastrous political consequences of this 'peace currency' were also visible in the discussion. Some accused the Greeks of living beyond their means in previous decades. It is not only Greeks, Greens and Socialists who were right to oppose this interference. No one noticed that there was no such criticism of the domestic policy of European partners before the single currency. The others complained passionately about Germany's constant interference in Greece's internal affairs. The fact that the constant talk of German politicians into the internal affairs of other states is a compelling consequence of the single currency has been ignored. It is up to the AfD to mention in the EP the true cause of the economic malaise in the eurozone. As we can see clearly from the example of Greece, the euro is not only leading to economic upheavals, but also, more and more often, to divisions and discord in Europe.

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz (EFDD)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union has faced the answer to the most important question, the question of its existence. It is clear that we are in a clinch where we cannot make any decisions. The clinch that has paralyzed Europe, sending many Member States into the abyss of the economic crisis. What's left of us? A union of two poles divided between the euro area and countries outside it, or a bold, forward-looking decision to amend the Treaties and the political disintegration of the European Union and the transition to an economic union – a European free trade area without political decisions. The end of the European Parliament, the European Commission and unnecessary institutions in the form of the Committee of the Regions and the Economic and Social Committee will be a new opening for Europe. It will allow for rapid economic development without excessive administration and regulations. Today, GDP growth in Europe is slowly approaching 1% per annum, while China, Brazil and the US are recording annual growth of 3-5%. The natural energy and entrepreneurship of Europeans is blocked by a non-life administration and the growth of bureaucracy. Therefore, only a bold decision can bring Europe back on to the path of sustainable economic development and prosperity for Europeans. In the recent EP elections, citizens have massively supported Eurosceptics, giving the green light to such solutions.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. – The First Vice-President of the European Commission expressed in his speech on the informal European Council of 12 February 2015 the need to find an adequate solution to the problem of Greek public debt. The Hellenic Republic will need some form of multilateral financial assistance as of February 28, 2015, as it cannot secure financing on financial markets at reasonable interest rates. At the same time, the conditions of such financing should be more favourable than in the past in terms of interest rate and repayment period, as well as conditionality, which should be less intrusive and ideological, and more focused on reforming the public administration and the tax system, and in the fight against corruption. The European Stability Mechanism can raise long-term financial market capital at a very low interest rate thanks to ecb monetary policy and low inflation. In addition, in order to preserve the necessary spending on social services and to combat poverty and social exclusion, the objective of the primary budget surplus must be reduced.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The ECB's decision on Greek bonds is an act that transcends the technical language of which it is coated. It is a political message with serious consequences for the financial system and the liquidity of the Greek state. What Europe is this that is mobilizing against the will of its peoples? What Europe is this that in Spain supports an enemy government of work, while attacking those governments that from the left are developing a different project: yesterday in Cyprus, today in Greece? Europe must listen to the decision of the Greek people: to reduce the burden of unsustainable debt and to free up resources to combat the humanitarian emergency that the Troika has caused, restoring the essential place of the state in public provision, social services and labour regulation. Europe has in its hands the easing of deficit targets, debt redemption and technical support to the Greek government. Moreover, it has its budgets and competences to fight for upward harmonisation of taxation and labour standards, social cohesion and productive convergence. That is the choice of Europe: democracy or neoliberalism.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – Greece's problems, as expected, have not been solved in one fell swo down with the victory of the radical left Syriza, despite the fact that many European politicians erupted in salutation. I am convinced that being left-wing does not mean that the borrowing will not be edi paid back. Leftism is not in the fact that I promise more even when the national debt is almost twice the national product. It is true, of course, that in recent years Europe's right-wing leaders have reached the tolerance threshold of society: greeks cannot tolerate more austerity, when more than half of young people are unemployed and the scale of the Greek exodus since the years of crisis can only be compared to that of Hungary.  However, seven years after the crisis erupted, the Greek economy is also starting to show signs of life: it could grow by 3% in 2015 and almost 4% in 2016, according to the Commission.
