Spain's economy is growing again after the dark years, Portugal is starting to stabilise. We cannot tell millions of European citizens that their sacrifice was unnecessary, there is another way. A better life requires more power. Syriza's popularity stems only from the fact that they have never taken on the responsibility of governing. If the Greek Prime Minister continues his promising, unreality-free policy, his star will soon be dead, and painful sobering will follow. This is a message to all parties that say they are democratic in Hungary.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. – Following the Eurogroup meeting, at which the 18 euro zone countries failed to agree on a solution to Greece's economic and financial crisis, a meeting of Heads of State and Government of the European Union will be held in the coming days at which the matter is discussed again. I hope that European leaders will reach a financing agreement and that Greece will be an integral part of the euro zone, remaining in the single currency and the European monetary system. Following the Paris attacks, I challenge Member States to engage in working together and to cooperate more actively to combat terrorism. I also believe that the efforts made in recent days by various leaders to ensure peace in Ukraine are of crucial strategic importance. However, I believe that, if necessary, new measures should already be in place or at least new measures to ensure peace as one of the pillars of sustainability of the European Union should already be optimised.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. Terrorist organizations seek to undermine the foundations of our democracy and attack our core values. In order to deal with this threat, the European Union and its Member States share the responsibility to ensure the protection of European citizens and to enable them to live in peace and security.  The European Social Democrats advocate a coordinated approach to addressing this global challenge on an unprecedented scale. A strategy focused on preventing radicalization, counter-terrorism and prosecuting those responsible. A response that respects the essential balance between freedom and security. We expect concrete measures from the Council to strengthen European cooperation against terrorism. It is a question of making the best use of the potential of existing instruments as it is of thinking about mechanisms that could have real added value, such as the European NRL, provided that they fully respect our fundamental rights.  There is also an urgent need for greater social inclusion and integration, the promotion of living together, solidarity and tolerance, first and foremost in schools. Our determination and unity must be unwavering to be able to overcome this ordeal together. Our Europe will come out stronger and more determined.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – The informal Council has really two items on its agenda – the situation in the Ukraine and Greece. The latter could be as dangerous as the former, unless it is treated with farsightedness. At the initial stages of negotiations with Greece, if any take place, brinkmanship could fast become the order of the day. If taken too far, this could lead to an unforgivable collapse.  Governments which have lent billions of their citizens’ monies cannot be expected to write off those amounts overnight. However the people of Greece cannot be expected to give up for too long the prospects of a decent life. They only have one to live. The bailout plan for Greece has not worked. It has imposed too many sufferings on the Greek people. Therefore it must be radically restructured. Perhaps too the eurozone has to be restructured over the medium term even if this will initially appear to be a weakening of the EU’s immense soft power in Europe and elsewhere. If negotiations with Greece are to go beyond brinkmanship, the values that must be asserted need to go beyond technical considerations to tap the sources of a meaningful solidarity.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – With regard to the negotiations between the European Commission, the International Monetary Fund and Greece, I would like to state the following: 1) the enormous debt that Greece has is a responsibility of both the debtor (Greece) and the creditors; 2) Greece as a country cannot be declared bankrupt; it may cease payments to the debt account; 3) in any negotiation between creditors and a debtor-country, the requirement to strike a balance between the debtor's ability to generate income and the duty to pay the debt over time and amounts; 4) Accordingly, creditors and Greece must consider why the initial programme of reform and financing of Greece's debt has not yielded the expected results and adjust this programme to the new reality.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. At the heart of the informal summit of Heads of State is the sense of a Union that is increasingly incapable of credible joint action against threats internally and external to its political, social and economic stability. The fight against terrorism, the Ukrainian conflict and the obvious crisis of economic governance are problems to which, of course, a Eurocracy dominated by the economic dimension and enslaved to financial interests cannot provide an adequate response. These great challenges require real European political leadership and a forward-looking vision that can put the needs and dignity of European citizens, social cohesion and solidarity between Member States at the centre. The real test will be Greece, which has called for a clear change in the sign of solidarity, putting the EU in the dilemma of whether to continue to preserve the interests of the major creditors at all costs, or whether to finally begin to listen to the needs of a population strangled by austerity policies that has expressed a clear rejection of the agreements imposed by the Troika. After all, the future of the Union is at stake here, because ignoring Greece's request would mean not only trampling underfoot the principle of democracy, but also betraying all the values on which the integration project is based.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. Today, here in the European Parliament, we should sit as guarantors of democracy in Europe, the expression and representation of the citizens who wanted to choose us and placed their trust in us, and also their hope. That is why we cannot and must not pretend that what is happening in Greece is not very serious and does not affect all of us very closely. With last week's decision, the ECB wanted to put Greece behind the wall, slapping the Greek people who, with the recent elections, had given a strong signal of change. It is a clear demonstration that the citizens and the elections do not count in this Europe, but we are all slaves to decisions taken in Berlin or Frankfurt. This action by the ECB risks undermining the very concept of democracy. It is not acceptable to stand still in the face of what is happening, we cannot accept that this is normal. We are with the Greek people and their choices, we must not bow to the diktats of Merkel or Draghi. Europe cannot and must not be all this.

name: Presidente. -
text: The next item is voting time.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, I have a point of order which is this: may I congratulate the Parliament on the fact that yesterday there were no votes? In consequence, the peoples of the nation states of Europe had one whole day without yet more job-destroying regulation and rules from this place imposing austerity. (Applause)

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, forgive me for interrupting for a minute. I just wanted you to know that today's vote is going to adopt a legal instrument to save human lives by which, ETSC experts tell us, between 350 and 400 people a year will be prevented from being dead. Imagine: the equivalent of a plane full of people who will not die on European roads. Europe is also useful for this. From here I would like to thank and pay tribute to the associations of victims and relatives of road accident victims, as well as to the traffic authorities, who have accompanied us in these seven intense years of work. He's going after them.

name: Presidente. -
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement with Iceland from the Legal Affairs Committee of the European Parliament as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Louis Aliot (NI)
text: In writing. — This item on the agenda is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts on safeguard measures provided for in the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland, Regulation (EEC) 2843/72 of the Council of 19 December 1972. There is no change in substance in the 1972 texts. Not being able to oppose this re-codification, but not supporting the principle of the obligation to transpose the text into domestic law, it seemed appropriate to refrain.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this proposal as its implementation will provide for greater legal certainty and clarity. The proposal relates primarily to the codification of legal texts. This is important because if you do not codify texts, the several amended former versions of the texts remain. Codification is, in a nutshell, a simplification. Any proposal that provides greater legal clarity and transparency should be welcomed, as it is the complex nature of such texts that frequently leads to unnecessary legal challenges, often at the taxpayers’ expense.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The proposal is a mere codification without changing the content of the underlying acts. Parliament and the Council must agree to this codification, and that is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — The proposed codification allows a new regulation to replace previous acts, for clarity and updating. But there is no need to resort to the means of enforcement. Being opposed in principle to such transfers of sovereignty, I logically abstained in this vote. Member States are competent and more legitimate than the Commission to assess the relevance of an existing regulatory framework, particularly when it concerns export aid, an element of trade policy which I consider to be an essential tool of the member States' sovereign economic policy.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — If these matters were coming before the European Parliament for the first time, we would be voting against because these matters should be within the competence of the Member States. Therefore to vote against is consistent with our position.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this deliberation. This new regulation replaces the various acts that are incorporated into it. It fully preserves its substance and merely groups it together by making the only formal modifications required by the coding operation itself.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal on the safeguard measures provided for in the agreement with Iceland. The purpose of the proposal is to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — In view of the numerous amendments that have been made to Regulation 2843/72 of the Council signed in 1972 on the safeguards provided for in the agreement with Iceland, the Commission wishes to proceed with the codification of that regulation. However, even if it is only "an outright codification of the existing texts" for the sake of clarity, I challenge the Commission on the legitimacy of taking acts of execution with the aim of codifying texts of international law, a prerogative naturally devolved to sovereign states. So that's why I abstained.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — An agreement was signed in 1972 between the EEC and Iceland. At the same time, safeguards and precautionary measures had been provided for in a regulation. This has been modified several times. The proposal aims, for the sake of clarity and transparency, to codify the 1972 regulation and its amendments.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal because it has the positive report of the advisory group, which found that it is only a question of codating Council Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland, and that the proposal does not contain substantial amendments.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report on the safeguard measures provided for in the agreement with Iceland sets out in this context the uniform conditions for the implementation of this regime, by giving the Commission enforcement powers exercised in accordance with Regulation (EU) 182/2011 of the European Parliament and the Council (particularly in the case of export aid having a direct and immediate impact on trade or in the event of urgent reasons). I abstained on this text because, although I recognise the legitimacy of the Commission to adopt immediately applicable enforcement actions, I believe that sovereign Member States are best able to react effectively in this context.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — The Duda report analyses the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. Although this is a technical text, I do not agree with the European Commission's current policies on trade agreements. That is why I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — In the interests of simplifying and clearing EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of the codification of the Regulation on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. The Regulation has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years and, in order to improve clarity and easy understanding of the legislative text, all these provisions should be recast into a new Regulation, respecting the content of the codified texts and making only the relevant formal amendments.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports the codification of the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of Iceland on safeguard measures. As early as 1 April 1987 The Commission has decided that all EU legislation, which has been amended no more than ten times, should be codified and stressed that this requirement is minimal and that Commission departments should endeavour to produce codified versions of the texts for which they are responsible within a shorter period of time in order to ensure that their provisions are clear and easily understandable. This practice has been adopted in European legislation to make it more comprehensible and accessible to citizens.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. This codification text follows the agreement between the EEC and Iceland signed on 22 July 1972. Traditionally, safeguard clauses and precautionary measures are provided. The question of the Commission's legitimacy to adopt immediately applicable enforcement actions remains open.  If the agreement, from the point of view of public international law, was signed by the EEC and Iceland, Member States would be better able to respond effectively, particularly in the face of cases of export aid having a direct and immediate impact on trade. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because I regard the agreement with Iceland as very productive and working correctly.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. — The Commission has decided to proceed with the codification of Regulation (EEC) 2843/72 of the Council of 19 December 1972 relating to the safeguard measures provided for in the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. In essence, the agreement allows Member States to react more effectively if Iceland fails to comply with the rules of the agreement. However, I challenge the Commission on the legitimacy of taking acts of enforcement with the aim of codifying texts of international law, a prerogative naturally devolved to sovereign states.  That is why I abstained on the vote of this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The adoption of a safeguard measure is based on the rules agreed multilaterally, while taking into account the application of those rules in bilateral relations, as resulting from the national regulations or specific, preferential agreements negotiated for the regulation of those relations. The general rules on bilateral specificities shall take into account, in particular, the procedure to be followed in the case of recourse to safeguard measures. The main element which creates the premises for the use of safeguard measures is the increase in imports and its effects, and less the price charged. In this context, protecting the EU single market is essential.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) The proposal is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes. Despite the purely technical nature of the amendments, I voted to abstain on commercial aspects with which I do not agree.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The codification of legislation is a kind of compilation of different European regulations that address the same theme. The aim is to simplify and make European legislation more accessible. I voted in favour of this report on the codification of the safeguards provided for in the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. In view of the fact that the vote in question was limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial modification, the European Parliament adopted its position at first reading, adopting the proposal of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal as its implementation will provide for greater legal certainty and clarity. The proposal relates primarily to the codification of legal texts. This is important because if you do not codify texts, the several amended former versions of the texts remain. Codification is, in a nutshell, a simplification. Any proposal that provides greater legal clarity and transparency should be welcomed, as it is the complex nature of such texts that frequently leads to unnecessary legal challenges, often at the taxpayers’ expense.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — With this proposal for a Regulation, the safeguard measures contained in Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 are simply codified without any amendment to the legal text, as laid down by the Advisory Group composed of the Legal Services of Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. "I preferred to abstain on this text for reasons of coherence. Certainly, the agreement, from the point of view of international law, was signed by the EEC in 1972, at a time when the European Economic Community was still an association of strategic partnership between sovereign states. However, what is the legitimacy of the European Commission to adopt immediately applicable enforcement actions? Once again, the Union's supra-statist will runs counter to pragmatism: the member nation-states are certainly best able to manage these clauses, particularly in the face of cases of export aid having a direct and immediate impact on trade.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 1994 Interinstitutional Agreement provided for an acceleration of the official codification of legislative texts. In the course of its examination of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the codification of Regulation (EEC) No Council Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 of 19 December 1972 on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland, the Consultative Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded by common accord that the proposal was limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I attach great importance to the simplification and clear formulation of Union legislation, so that it becomes more comprehensible and accessible to citizens, offering them new opportunities to assert the rights enshrined in the legislation. I voted in favour of the safeguard measures provided for in the agreement with Iceland because, with this accelerated working method for the official codification of legislative texts, they replace Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 with a new regulation that preserves the correct substance of the acts being codifying and only makes the formal amendments necessary for the work of legislation.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — This is in the best interests of both the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I gave my favourable picture of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. The codification of legislative texts is an indispensable process in order to simplify and facilitate the understanding of European citizens, thus guaranteeing the key principles of the European Union, such as clarity and transparency and contributing to the effective implementation of legislative provisions.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of the proposal is to undertake a codification of Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 of the Council of 19 December 1972 on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. The new Regulation will supersede the various acts incorporated in it; this proposal fully preserves the content of the acts being codified and hence does no more than bring them together with only such formal amendments as are required by the codification exercise itself, so I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) This report concerns a proposal on the codification of EU law. This is a technical procedure provided for in Article 103 of the Regulation to verify that the codification proposal is in fact limited to mere codification, without any substantial changes. Each codification proposal is examined in advance by the legal services of the Commission, the Council and Parliament. The conclusions of this assessment are then sent to the Committee on Legal Affairs for validation and finally voted on in plenary for parliament's final approval. I voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement with Iceland from the Legal Affairs Committee of the European Parliament as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — This resolution deals with the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland signed in 1972. The purpose of this proposal is to now take action and undertake a codification of Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 on the safeguard measures provided for in this agreement. The new Regulation preserves fully the content of the acts being codified and hence does no more than bring them together. Due to the clear procedural nature of this exercise I voted in favour of it.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes the codification within European Union law of the Council Regulation (EEC) No. 2843/72 of 19 December 1972 on the safeguard measures provided for in the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland, which was substantially amended in 1990 and 2014. Safeguards are a trade defence instrument that protects an importing European sector over a period of between four and eight years and gives it time to adapt to a considerable increase in imports. I support this text as a simple exercise in codifying positive law, without any change in substance. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This codification of the safeguards provided for in the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland is welcome. As the regulation in question had been amended many times, it was necessary to provide greater clarity. I am the the one in favour of these procedures which facilitate the understanding of European legislation.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — If the proposed codification allows a new regulation to replace previous acts for clarity and updating, the use of the enforcement route is not necessary. Opposed to such transfers of sovereignty, I abstained in this vote. It also appears that Member States are competent and more legitimate than the Commission to assess the relevance of an existing regulatory framework, particularly when it concerns export aid, an element of trade policy which I consider to be an essential tool in the economic policy of a sovereign state.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — We are voting against the codification of all the texts, because we are not given the opportunity to intervene in the substance of these provisions, which means that we must accept them as they stand.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — In the context of 'Citizens' Europe', great importance is attached to the simplification and clarity of EU law, which is therefore more accessible and understandable to the citizen. This objective cannot be achieved until a large number of provisions remain which have undergone various, often essential, changes and which are dispersed between the original act and subsequent acts of amendment. The purpose of this proposal, which is therefore to codified Council Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland, is in line with the abovementioned considerations concerning the clarity of EU law.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 of 19 December 1972 on the protective measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. "I abstained, because there can be no question of me giving any legitimacy to the process of codifying European law. Indeed, I challenge the superiority of European law over national law and therefore would not give credy, even in the case of an incidental procedure, to giving European law a reference that should not be made.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this report is to codify Council Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 of 19 December 1972 on the protective measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. All acts should be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier to understand by the ordinary citizen. This objective cannot be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially, which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts amending it. For this reason, and in order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed.  For this reason, this is an eminently technical change. The new Regulation will replace the various acts integrated therein, fully preserving the content of the codified acts, introducing only with the formal changes required by the coding process itself.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I am not going to endorse the text because the commercial aspects of the agreement are at the same time as the policies proposed by the European Commission.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — My vote is against the safeguard measures provided for in the agreement with Iceland, because the codification of all the texts does not enable us to intervene in the substance of these provisions and we must, by extension, accept them as they stand.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — I am in favour of the proposal as it is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I support the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. The 1994 Interinstitutional Agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, which pushes for an acceleration of the process of codification of Council Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72, provides access to a new regulation replacing the various ones it incorporates, not by changing it in substance but by making only formal amendments in order to clarify and make the rule more transparent. The proposal for a regulation of the agreement in question will therefore, we hope, provide certainty of applicable law and greater protection of the bilateral rules for safeguarding the agreement.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on safeguard measures provided for in the agreement with Iceland, seeing that this concerns a purely technical measure aiming at the consolidation of legislation to react to recent developments, and the proposal fully preserves the content of the acts being codified.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. — I abstained on this proposal for a regulation on safeguards under the agreement with Iceland. This abstention does not derive from the measures themselves, which are standard in this type of agreement, but because it is eminently questionable that the Commission should adopt enforcement actions in relation to these measures. In my view, it is the Member States that are best able to respond effectively and quickly, particularly in the face of export aid with a direct and immediate impact on trade.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this as it is consolidation of legislation in line with recent developments.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on safeguards provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland on the grounds that the proposal does not change the basics of the existing texts, but concerns only their codification.  This way, the legal texts of the European Union become more accessible to citizens, i.e. clearer and more transparent. The proposal guarantees certainty of rights and reduces the need for research work in the search for the rules in force.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — If the proposed codification allows a new regulation to replace previous acts for clarity and updating, the use of the enforcement route is not necessary. Opposed to such transfers of sovereignty, I abstained in this vote. It also appears that Member States are competent and more legitimate than the Commission to assess the relevance of an existing regulatory framework, particularly when it concerns export aid, an element of trade policy which I consider to be an essential tool in the economic policy of a sovereign state.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which is limited to codifying Regulation (EEC) 2843/72 of the Council of 19 December 1972 on the safeguards provided for in the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. This codification of the positive law will provide more clarity and transparency for European citizens, who must have easy access to European legislation.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — On the agenda item named ‘Safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement with Iceland’, we voted in favour because in our opinion the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing, valid legal texts, without any change in their substance, which help to improve economic relations between the EU and the Republic of Iceland.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — The codification proposal is intended to replace Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72, which was adopted by the European Council on 19 December 1972. The content is only codified and not modified. For this reason, the request must be approved.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the report as it is simply aiming at consolidation of legislation to react to recent developments.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr Duda's report because I agree with the purpose of this proposal, which aims to initiate the codification of Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and Iceland. I agree with the importance and necessity of simplification in order to arrive at ever clearer formulations of Community legislation, so that it becomes more comprehensible and accessible to citizens. This objective cannot be achieved as long as the countless provisions, amended on several occasions and often substantially, remain scattered, forcing those who wish to consult them to seek them both in the original act and in the acts of amendment.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — The Commission wants to codify The Council Regulation (EEC) No. 2843/72 of 19 December 1972 on the safeguard measures provided for in the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. In essence, this agreement allows Member States to react more effectively in the event that Iceland does not comply with the previously established rules. Having said that, I deny the Commission the legitimacy of taking acts of execution for the purpose of codifying texts of international law, a prerogative of sovereign states. I dispute this supranational position. For this reason, I abstained on this text.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement with Iceland from the Legal Affairs Committee of the European Parliament as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — An agreement was signed between the European Economic Community and Iceland on 22 July 1972. In this regard, the modalities for the application of safeguard clauses and precautionary measures are necessary to ensure the application of this Agreement. The aim of this proposal is to codified Council Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and Iceland. The proposed new Regulation fully respects the substance and merely consolidates only the formal amendments required by the coding operation itself. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — This report on the proposal for a regulation aims at the critically important clarity and transparency in order to stand up for the codification of legislative acts. For the sake of transparency of EU regulations, formal codification means a procedure that abolishes acts subject to codification and replaces them with a single act. The purpose of this report on the proposal for a regulation is to codify the Council Regulation of 19 December 1972 on the safeguards provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. Since, according to the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, this proposal is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes and since the advisory groups are invited to adopt a position at first reading, taking over the Commission's proposal, I supported this proposal.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Duda report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland, as the opinion of the Advisory Group on Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission finds that the proposal merely codifies the existing texts. , without modifying their substance.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this proposal to codify the safeguard measures provided for in the EU/Iceland agreement as they are based on the recommendations of the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — Favourable to the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. This proposal is limited to a mere codification of existing texts without any substantial changes.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union attaches great importance to the simplification and clear formulation of Community legislation. However, this desire for clarity cannot be fully realized when the provisions amended remain divided into the form of an original act and acts of amendment.  In view of the above considerations, I voted in favour of the Duda report, as I believe it is essential to codify the provisions that have undergone frequent changes over time, in the name of the desire to guarantee the clarity and transparency of European legislation.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — (DE) The proposal on safeguard measures in the agreement with Iceland received my positive vote, as it is a mere codification of the agreement.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections concerning a given subject for the purpose of simplification, clarity and transparency. The purpose of this proposal is to codify Regulation 2843/72 of the Council of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. This regulation establishes in which situations the Commission is allowed to temporarily restrict imports of an Icelandic product. I am opposed to the Commission's control in this area. These undemocratic technocratic procedures prevent Europe from practising solidarity protectionism, which is the ecological and social emergency of our time. So even if it is only a technical report, I am voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — This report deals only with a technical issue, consisting of the codification of Council Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 of 19 December 1972 on the protective measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report regarding the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement with Iceland because the consultative working party of the legal services of Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposed codification of the existing texts is straightforward and presents no change in their substance. It is crucial that agreements that have been amended on multiple occasions are codified in order to ensure that they are accessible and clear to citizens.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — This proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 of 19 December 1972 on the protective measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. The new Regulation will replace the various acts integrated therein, fully preserving the content of the codified acts, but merely reunite them with the formal changes required by the codification process itself. I congratulate the European Commission on the simplification adopted in order to clarify Union law and make it more accessible and easier to understand for the ordinary citizen, which will allow access to new opportunities and the possibility of benefiting from the specific rights that are given to citizens.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The Commission wants to codify Regulation (EEC) 2843/72 of the Council of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures provided for in the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. In essence, this agreement allows Member States to react more effectively in the event that Iceland does not comply with the previously established rules. Having said that, I deny the Commission the legitimacy of taking acts of execution for the purpose of codifying texts of international law, a prerogative of sovereign states. I dispute this supranational position. For this reason, I abstained on this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — In the Agreement between the EEC and Iceland, provision was made for safeguard measures, designed to mitigate the effects of excessive imports or the possibility of dumping. It is in line with Commission commitments to codification in order to ensure clarity of the law.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which codifies Regulation (EEC) 2843/72 on safeguard measures under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. This regulation has been amended several times and substantially, so that its provisions are now found on the one hand in the original act, on the other hand scattered in the amending acts that followed. In the interests of clarity and simplification of the law, guaranteeing greater legal certainty and better information for citizens, it was therefore necessary to codify this regulation. This process completely preserves its substance and merely brings together in a legible way the various changes that have been made to it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome this proposal for a regulation on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland, given that during its examination the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposal in question was limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without making any substantial changes to its content.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted for this report, because the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland as it regulates the measures provided for under that Protocol.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: scryofa. — Chaith mise vóta i bhfabhar an togra seo toisc go gciallóidh cur i bhfeidhm a leithéid go mbeidh nó soiléireachta agus deimhneacht dhlíthiúil ann. Tá an togra seo bainteach le téacsanna dlíthiúla a chódú. I know seo tábhachtach mar mura ndéantar códú ar an téacs, an rud a bhíonn agat ná an t-iar-théacs le an-chuid leaganacha leasaithe. Simpliú atá and gceist leis an gcódú. Ba chóir fáilte a chuir roimh aon togra a chuireann níos mó soiléireachta dlíthiúla agus follasacht and bhfeidhm toisc gurb as téacsanna de chineál cast agóid dlíthiúla nach bhfuil riachtanach ar chor a bith, agus go minic a bhíonn ar chostas an cháiníocóra.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — In the end, I voted in favour of the agreement, as these are essentially purely formal measures which are an improvement on the status quo to date.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the draft because it concerns the codification of existing legislation. In the same big picture, it would be highly anticipated that Iceland would resume talks on EU membership.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) Since the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — The original text of Regulation No 1001/2013 2843/72/EEC of the Council of 19 December 1972 on the Safeguards provided for in the Agreement with Iceland was adopted as far back as 1972. As such, the Regulation is still in force, but has since undergone some amendments. This codification refers to the part of the Regulation governing the implementation of bilateral safeguard clauses that require uniform conditions for the adoption of safeguards. These measures shall be adopted in accordance with Regulation No 182/2011/EU of the European Parliament and the Council. The Commission, in turn, adopts applicable implementing acts in duly justified cases. Such cases may be situations such as aiding the export of one of the parties and may have a direct and immediate impact on trade. Personally, I have always advocated for transparent legal texts, without the need to consult multiple amendments to texts that, often vaguely, run through various acts, which make it difficult for interested parties to navigate and read, and ultimately to apply these acts. Due to the need to apply this Regulation properly, both between the parties to the agreement and to the stakeholders to which this Regulation has a legal effect, I consider the proposed codification necessary as it contributes to greater legal certainty of the application of the act.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — The Commission wants to codify Regulation (EEC) 2843/72 of the Council of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. In essence, this agreement allows Member States to react more effectively in the event that Iceland does not comply with the previously established rules. Having said that, I deny the Commission the legitimacy of taking acts of execution for the purpose of codifying texts of international law, a prerogative of sovereign states. I dispute this supranational position. For this reason, I abstained on this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support colleague Duda's report on the proposal for a regulation codifying the Council Regulation of 19 December 1972 on the safeguards provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. This brings existing acts together, without losing content or substance, which allows for the simplification of the process of activating the safeguards provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland and its greater transparency.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — I support MEP Andrzej Duda's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on safeguards provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland, on the grounds that the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has pointed out that the proposal is limited to codifying existing texts and does not contain substantive changes.  Wanting to strengthen and expand economic relations between the Community and Iceland while respecting the conditions of competition and contributing to the development and construction of Europe, the EEC and the Republic of Iceland have concluded an agreement that has changed and complementary on several occasions in recent decades. For reasons of better visibility and transparency, it was necessary to initiate and implement the codification procedure for Regulation No 1007/2013. 2843/72 of 1972 relating to the safeguards provided for in the EEC-Iceland Agreement.  The European Parliament hereby supports a simplification that will make Union law clearer and more accessible to EU citizens. I welcome the continued efforts of parliament's professional services, the Council and the Commission in codification procedures.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland because, according to the opinion issued on 17 September 2014 by the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council, the proposal for a regulation is simply a codification of the existing texts. , without any major changes.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Through this recommendation, it is up to the European Parliament to vote in favour of codifying a text in the order of European Union law. To the extent that this does not result in any substantial changes and allows for greater legibility of this right, I vote for it.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — At its meeting of 10 July 2014, the Advisory Group composed of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission reviewed the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council, by which Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 of the Council of 19 December 1972 on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland are codified. It concluded, then, by common agreement, that the proposal under question should be based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive amendments. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — Since the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has given a positive opinion and considers that this proposal is limited to the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments to the texts, there is no reason to vote against or even to abstain.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — In order to simplify and clarity of EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of the codification of the Regulation on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. The Regulation has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years and, in order to improve clarity and easy understanding of the legislative text, all these provisions should be recast into a new Regulation, respecting the content of the codified texts and making only the relevant formal amendments.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal concerns the codification of Council Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 of 19 December 1972 on the protective measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. It is essentially necessary to bring together, with minor formal amendments required by the codification process itself, the system on safeguard measures contained in this Agreement, which is subject to the rules of codecision. The new regulation will replace the various acts integrated therein, fully preserving the content of the codified acts. For all the above, it deserves my vote in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text because it is part of a process of facilitation of Community law, initiated by the inter-institutional agreement of 20 December 1994. When several texts on the safeguards in the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland are being revised, the European Commission has committed to merge the various texts into one in order to make EU law clearer and more concise. It is important that EU legislation remains simple and clear.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to abstain because, over and above a technical assessment of the text, I fundamentally disagree with the European Commission's trade policies under this measure.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I am in favour of the adoption of this text, which is limited to the outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement with Iceland from the Legal Affairs Committee of the European Parliament as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — I support and welcome this proposal, taking into account that the purpose of the proposal is to codify Regulation (EEC) No 2020/2013; 2843/72 of the Council since 19 December 1972 on the safeguards laid down in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland.  The new Regulation will replace the various laws contained in the previous Regulation, so that the proposal constitutes a direct codification of existing texts without substantive changes. I would stress the importance of codifying the rules to make the law clear and transparent. Simplifying and clarification the laws of the European Union makes it more accessible to citizens by giving them new opportunities and the opportunity to exploit the specific rights arising from the law, and therefore I support it.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports cooperation between the EEC and Iceland, particularly regarding attempts to mitigate the effects of excessive imports and the possibility of dumping.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support the proposal for a regulation, as it aims at the critically important clarity and transparency in order to establish the codification of the Council Regulation of 19 December 1972 on safeguards provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland.  The main provisions codified relate to the Agreement between the European Economic Community and Iceland signed in Brussels on 22 July 1972. Therefore, detailed rules are required for the implementation of the safeguard clause and the safeguards provided for in the Treaty. The aim of the new regulation is to supersede the various acts embedded there. The adoption of safeguards requires a level playing field in the implementation of bilateral safeguard clauses of the Agreement.  The Commission should therefore adopt implementing acts that can be applied immediately when the final urgent reasons so require and relate to the situations cited in the proposal, in particular in the case of exports of aids having a direct and immediate impact on trade.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The codification of texts should be an opportunity to re-evaluate their content in substance and not just by type.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on safeguard measures provided for in the agreement with Iceland. I consider the codification procedure to be a priority in order to make EU legislation transparent.  As a member of switzerland, Norway and the EU-Iceland and EEA Joint Parliamentary Committees, I also believe it is important that the various agreements are clear, easy to understand and accessible to all. It is therefore important that the provisions, which have been amended many times, are available in one place, in a collected form. The report contributed to the simple, consolidated edify of that provision.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a regulation on safeguards under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. We thereby join the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council codifying Regulation (EEC) No. 2843/72 of the Council of 19 December 1972 on the safeguard measures provided for in the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland, the advisory group unanimously concluded that the proposal in question was limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The codification of European legislation facilitates the understanding of European Union legislation. This legislative procedure envisages the clarification of the legislative act, but no substantive changes to that act can be introduced through it. The European institutions agreed in 1994 to use an accelerated procedure with a view to the rapid adoption of codified acts.  The legislative proposal which was the subject of the European Parliament's report concerns the codification of Regulation (EEC) No 2377/90. Council Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland(6).  Given that the codification proposal retains the full content of the codified acts and merely regroups them, making only the formal changes required by the codification operation itself and taking into account that the consultative working group of the legal services of the three European institutions recommends supporting this proposal, the European Parliament, by unanimous vote today, supports the proposal to codify the regulation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, one of the fifteen reports from the JURI committee to be voted on at this session. This is a technical amendment to update the legislative text for the sake of greater legal certainty.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement with Iceland from the Legal Affairs Committee of the European Parliament as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This report talks about the codification of the Regulation on protection measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. In 1987, the Commission decided to ask its services for all acts to be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier to understand by the ordinary citizen, which will allow it new opportunities and the possibility to benefit from the specific rights granted to it.  This objective implies administrative simplification. Therefore, it is necessary to code the rules that have been frequently changed. The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed, by interinstitutional agreement of 20 December 1994, that an accelerated procedure could be used for the rapid adoption of codified acts. It should be stressed that the new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein, fully preserving the content of the codified acts and introducing only the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - The proposal on safeguard measures in the agreement with Iceland received my positive vote, as it is a mere codification of the agreement.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this report is to codify Council Regulation (EEC) No 2843/72 of 19 December 1972 on the protective measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Republic of Iceland. The aim of coding is to make it more accessible and easier for ordinary citizens to understand EU legislation, ensuring the clarity and transparency of law by codifling rules that have been frequently changed. Since the new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein, fully preserving the content of the codified acts by introducing only the formal changes required by the codification process itself, we did not oppose this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. — UKIPʼs position is that the UK should be in charge of all issues relating to the application of state aid within the context of our sovereign membership of the WTO and other international agreements.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Louis Aliot (NI)
text: In writing. — The purpose of the proposal is to codify The Council's Regulation (EC) No. 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001 on the measures that the Community can take as a result of a report adopted by the WTO's dispute resolution body on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures. To the extent that the new regulation fully preserves the substance of the original text and therefore merely consolidates the various acts incorporated into it by making the only formal changes required by the coding operation itself, I opposed it by voting against it. In my view, Member States should have more leeway in their trade relations with third countries, and such a regulation prevents them from doing so.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The proposal is a mere codification without changing the content of the underlying acts. Parliament and the Council must agree to this codification, and that is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — The dispute resolution body is a new tool created by the World Trade Organization to subject the laws of nations to the requirements of this institution and multinationals. The European Union here facilitates the interference of organisations totally foreign to the interests of the Member States. For these reasons, I voted against this text. I believe that the only way to find a realistic and effective economic policy is to pursue national policies. The Member States have such divergent interests that it is of course impossible to grant them all, so much so that only Germany today benefits from the policies of a Union which is subject to it. The freedom for each country to protect itself and to establish economic patriotism is one of the alternatives to this failing economic system.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — If these matters were coming before the European Parliament for the first time, we would be voting against because these matters should be within the competence of the Member States. Therefore to vote against is consistent with our position.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this deliberation because it is actually limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal concerning measures relating to anti-dumping and anti-subsidy matters. The purpose of the proposal is to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against this emblematic report of the loss of sovereignty of European states encouraged by the European Commission: the European Commission obediently agrees to comply with the decisions of the WTO's 'dispute settlement body' (DSB). However, by requiring states to amend their laws and regulations to bring them into line with the neoliberal rules it enacts, the WTO benefits only the multinationals that dominate the global market.  This report proposes to take another step in this direction. This would give the Commission the authority to amend or repeal measures in the DSB, as well as to adopt new measures aimed at bringing EU law into line with the DSB's recommendations. Attached to the priority of national law over EU law, especially when it is contrary to the interests of our peoples, I strongly contest the restriction of Member States' room for manoeuvre in the conduct of their trade relations.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — This is the codification, without modification of the substance, of the measures that the Union can take as a result of a report adopted by the WTO's dispute resolution body on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal because it has the positive report of the advisory group, which found that it is only a matter of amending Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001 on the measures that the Community may take from the report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures approved by the CMO Dispute Settlement Body, without the proposal containing structural reforms.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to propose a regulation to establish specific provisions with the aim of enabling the Union, when it deems it appropriate, to bring into line a measure taken under Regulation (EC) 1225/2009 (anti-dumping measures) or (EC) 597/2009 (anti-subsidy measures). This in practice translates into the repeal or modification of the offending measure or the adoption of another enforcement action.  It is anomalous that States cannot maintain full room for manoeuvre in the context of external relations, particularly trade, since the disparities and demands are too different from one country to another in the Union. Moreover, we are subject to this regulation to the European Commission, which imposes a compliance that is in fact sought by the Dispute Settlement Board, which is an offshoot of the WTO. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) Since I do not agree with the European Commission's approach to the positions taken by the World Trade Organization, I voted to abstain on the report we are voting on.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — In the interests of simplifying and clearing EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of the codification of the Regulation on measures to be taken by the Union on the basis of the report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures approved by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body. The Regulation has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years and, in order to improve clarity and easy understanding of the legislative text, all these provisions should be recast into a new Regulation, respecting the content of the codified texts and making only the relevant formal amendments.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports the codification of the regulation measures that the Union can take on the basis of a report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures adopted by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body, without changing the substance of the Regulation itself. The codification of legislation is needed to make it more comprehensible and accessible to citizens.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — I support this proposal, since, according to the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, it is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. Common rules for defence against imports that are subsidized by non-EU countries were put in place by a 2009 Council regulation. The text states that "within the framework of the Marrakesh agreement establishing the World Trade Organization (WTO), a memorandum of understanding on the rules and procedures governing dispute settlement has been adopted. In accordance with this memorandum of understanding, a dispute resolution body (DSB) has been established. [...] Specific provisions should be drawn up to enable the Union, when it deems it appropriate, to make a measure taken ... in line with the recommendations and decisions contained in a report adopted by the DSB." I voted against this text because Member States should keep complete leeway in the conduct of their external trade relations without submitting to compliance by the European Commission with a decision of the DSB, a mere echesion of the WTO.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because I consider serious measures to avoid dumping and subsidy as fundamental to our European economy and to our single market.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. — The European Parliament proposes to endorse the Commission's proposal for a regulation which would allow it to repeal or amend a measure incriminated by a report by the dispute resolution body (DSB). Furthermore, the Commission would be competent to adopt any other enforcement measures necessary to bring EU law into line with the DSB's recommendations. Because I formally challenge the primacy of EU law over national law, especially when its implementation is to comply with the completely questionable injunctions of the WTO, I am opposed to the European Commission being able to arbitrarily change a law which particularly affects the business practice of the Member States. This proposed regulation is part of a strategy to strengthen the European Commission's prerogatives in international law.  Attached to the preservation of France's room for manoeuvre on the international economic scene, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Interinstitutional Agreement of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission sets out how the European legislative process is organised and coordinated. I have expressed myself in favour of this proposal for a regulation, because I believe that the coding procedure confirmed by the Advisory Working Party is an appropriate legal procedure and the proposal for a regulation does not require substantive changes. A related legislative system means effective coordination of regulatory mechanisms. The Consultative Working Party on Legal Services belonging to the three Institutions has reached an agreement on the proposal for a regulation. I believe that the Union should be able to take urgent measures following the work of the WTO Dispute Settlement Body with regard to anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and therefore proposed the codification of the texts.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) The measure is of a technical nature, but I am abstaining. I do not agree with the European Commission's approach to the WTO.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The codification of legislation is a kind of compilation of different European regulations that deal with the same subject. The aim of codification is to simplify European legislation and make it more accessible. In this particular case, we are talking about codifying legislation on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures. It is essential to have maximum clarity and precision on these subjects. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the measures that the Union can take following a report adopted by the WTO Conciliation Body on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures. In view of the fact that the vote in question was limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial modification, the European Parliament adopted its position at first reading, adopting the proposal of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — This proposal for a regulation aims to codify the provisions of Regulation No 1515/2001 without making any formal or substantive amendments to the existing texts.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted against this text, representative of the attempt to erase our sovereignty by a supranational structure. The ability to conduct trade negotiations is an indispensable lever to ensure the prosperity and freedom of any nation-state. The Dispute Settlement Body, ersatz of the WTO, therefore presents itself as a mechanism for comprehensive, even globalised management, i.e. at the expense of dialogue between sovereign states. Moreover, it is not for the European Commission to represent the interests - different or even divergent, in some cases - of each Member State of the Union.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the measure adopted is to make it easier and to codify legislation which has undergone legislative changes and make them clear and transparent. In 1987 the Commission invited the codification of all acts which had been amended no later than ten times, and in 1992 the importance and value of codification of acts was affirmed. In view also of the importance of codification being carried out in full compliance with the procedure for adopting Union acts and the need for CITIZENS of the Union to have easy access to European legislative acts, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I consider the codification of Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001, which aims to tackle the unfair competition represented by dumped imports, to be of great importance. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution because the new regulation replaces the already substantially correct 2001 regulation, making only the formal changes necessary for the codification work, with the aim of adapting the EU's body of legislation.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the measures which the Union may take following a report adopted by the WTO Conciliation Body (DSB) on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures. Those measures serve to protect the single market, on the one hand, from damage to the production system caused by imports of goods offered at prices lower than those of the same goods sold on the home market and, on the other hand, from damage to the production system caused by imports of goods produced by third-country undertakings which have been holders of State aid. Since the proposal for a regulation was approved by the Advisory Group composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, since it is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes, I have decided to conform to the position of the Advisory Group.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — The codification process represents the bringing together of existing texts thereby providing easier access to relevant EU legislation. The purpose of this proposal is to undertake a codification of the Council Regulation on measures that the Community may take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures with safeguard measures. The new Regulation will supersede the various acts incorporated in it, so this proposal fully preserves the content of the acts being codified and does no more than bring them together with only such formal amendments as are required by the codification exercise itself.
