Anti-dumping regulations protect European investors, thereby protecting employment in Europe.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this report, which concerns a proposal on the codification of EU law. It is a technical procedure provided for in Article 103 of the Regulation to verify that the codification proposal is in fact limited to mere codification, without any substantial changes. All consolidation proposals are examined in advance by the legal services of the Commission, the Council and Parliament. The conclusions of these assessments are then sent to the Committee on Legal Affairs for validation and finally voted on in plenary for parliament's final approval.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to undertake a codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001 on the measures that may be taken by the Community following a report adopted by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body concerning anti-dumping and anti-subsidy matters. ‘Dumping’ refers to exporting a product at a price lower than the price normally charged for it in one’s home market, while ‘subsidy’ refers to a financial contribution made by a government or public body which is beneficial to the recipient. Due to the clear procedural nature of the codification exercise I voted in favour of it.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes the codification within European Union law of the Council's Regulation (EC) No. 1515/2001 on the measures that the Community can take following a report adopted by the World Trade Organisation (WTO) dispute resolution body on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures, which was substantially amended in 2014. This text allows the Union, when it deems it appropriate, to make trade defence measures, i.e. anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures, in accordance with the recommendations and decisions contained in a report adopted by the World Trade Organisation's dispute resolution body (DSB) on such measures. I support this text as a simple exercise in codifying positive law without any change in substance. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With this vote, the European Parliament illustrates its desire to encourage greater transparency of European law. Indeed, the codification of the regulation on the measures that the Union can take as a result of a report adopted by the WTO's dispute resolution body on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures is a good move. This brings clarity to a text that has undergone many changes.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — The proposal is to proceed with the codification of Regulation (EC) No. 1515/2001 of the Council of 23 July 2001. I support this proposal on substance and form. On the merits, because anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures are trade defence instruments that combat unfair trade practices in cases where imports are made on conditions that could give rise to action under international trade rules. The regulation aims to enable the EU to make a measure taken within the framework of the Anti-Dumping Measures Regulation or the Anti-Subsidy Measures Regulation in line with the recommendations and decisions contained in a report adopted by the WTO's dispute resolution body on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures. On the form, because the aforementioned regulation has been amended several times and the new regulation, by substituting for the various acts incorporated in it, makes EU law more readable and accessible.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — The dispute resolution body is a new tool created by the World Trade Organization to subject the laws of nations to the requirements of this institution and multinationals. The European Union here facilitates the interference of organisations totally foreign to the interests of the Member States. Reasons why I voted against this text. I believe that the only way to find a realistic and effective economic policy is to pursue national policies. The Member States have such divergent interests that it is of course impossible to grant them all, so much so that only Germany today benefits from the policies of a Union which is subject to it. The freedom for each country to protect itself and to establish economic patriotism is one of the alternatives to this failing economic system.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — We are voting against the codification of all the texts, because we are not given the opportunity to intervene in the substance of these provisions, which means that we must accept them as they stand.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to codified Council Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001 on measures to be taken by the Community on the basis of the report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures approved by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body. The proposal fully respects the content of the codified texts and is therefore limited to regrouping them, making only the formal modifications that the coding operation itself requires. Thus, this codification proposal contributes to the clarity and transparency of EU law, the rules of which are frequently amended.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001 on the measures that the Community may take following a report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures adopted by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. "I can only vote against this text. Foreign policy, and therefore foreign trade policy, can only lift the full sovereignty of states. It is unacceptable that the European Commission - a body of technocrats "in weightlessness" can have any impact on the foreign trade policy of our countries. All the more so when the Commission is the vassal of an institution (ORD) that is even more distant and abstract for our fellow citizens.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself. Anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures are interference with the internal decisions of each country. The least developed and developing countries lose. Each State should have the right to decide on its model of economic and social development. This right cannot be veised, it is a sovereign right, which calls into question the model of export promotion and free trade. All its logic is rivalry by market shares in the name of competition. Not a logic of cooperation, where trade has a role to play in development. The new regulation voted on today will replace the various acts integrated into it, fully preserving the content of the codified acts, introducing only the formal amendments required by the codification process itself. Although we are frontally owe the content of the Regulation, we believe that it is important that all amendments adopted in the meantime be brought together in a single document, facilitating the understanding of the legislation.  Hence our abstention.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — The rules concern measures following reports by the World Trade Organisation's Conciliation Body on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures. I will not support the agreement with a positive vote, as I do not agree with the European Commission's approach to the WTO.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting against anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures because we are not given the opportunity to intervene in the substance of these provisions and we must, by extension, accept them as they stand.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — I am in favour of the proposal as it is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I am aware the Duda report in itself concerns a merely technical matter, but I wanted to grasp this opportunity to raise an issue of great concern, which is the fact that Member States have not so far been able to agree on new EU powers to fight dumping. This means that up until this day we have dumping legislation that has not been revised since 1995 and does not take into account current-day social and environmental concerns. It also means we do not have new powers to fight unfair Chinese exports, which are pushing EU companies out of the market by literally dumping cheap products on our markets.  It is an issue that is of great concern to my country, and in particular to my region of the West Midlands where ceramic companies are struggling because of dumped imports of ceramic table and kitchenware from China; and it is a bitter fact that the UK Government has not been standing behind these companies in the debate on this at EU level.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against this proposal on the possibility for the Union to take anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures for two reasons: on the one hand, the implementation of these measures is conditional on the adoption of a report adopted by the WTO's Dispute Settlement Body, which already leads to a loss of reactivity which leaves the field open to the States practising dumping. On the other hand, experience shows us that the European Commission has never been quick to defend the interests of Europeans in the face of distortions of competition imposed by third countries. In the face of this failure, it is essential that member states are once again able to react to these anti-competitive practices, without waiting for hypothetical action by the European Union.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this as it is consolidation of legislation in line with recent developments.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on measures that the Union can take following a report adopted by the WTO Dispute Resolution Body on anti-dumping and anti-systemic issues, as the proposal leads to codification of acts in the form of a more transparent and accessible right for all European citizens.  Codification simplifies the finding of regulations contained in different acts and texts. I therefore agree with the fact that Commission staff are ordered to codify acts after a maximum of ten amendments, which do not alternate substanomately, so that EUROPEAN Union law is transparent and clear.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted against it and I will explain the reasons for it. The Dispute Settlement Body is a new tool created by the World Trade Organization to bring national laws into line with WTO recommendations. The European Union, once again, facilitates the interference of organisations totally foreign to the interests of the Member States. The Commission's mission will be to bring to the fore all States that have not yet implemented any of its directives.  On the contrary, we members of the National Front believe that the only way to find a coherent, functional and effective economic policy is to return to national policies, rid of supranational institutions. The Member States have such divergent interests that it is of course impossible to grant them all, so much so that only Germany today benefits from the policies of a Union which is subject to it. The freedom for each country to protect itself and to establish economic patriotism is one of the alternatives to this economic system that is failing before our eyes.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which codifies the regulation on the measures that the Union can take following the adoption of a decision by the WTO's dispute resolution body on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures. This codification exercise makes it possible to present European legislation in a clearer and more accessible way to European citizens.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — On the agenda item under the name ‘Measures concerning anti-dumping and anti-subsidy matters’, we voted in favour because in our opinion the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing, valid legal texts, without any change in their substance, which will help to improve import and export control and issues related to trade defence of the EU.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — Simplifying and codifying individual areas of law after multiple amendments is an important measure to give the EU people a better understanding and thus easier access to the exercise of their rights at EU level. This act summarises in a comprehensible and clear way the complex and important legislation on the measures that the Union could take with regard to the effects of common anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures, which have been amended several times in their substance. It also puts an end to this measure of dispersal through various acts. The content and substance of the current legal situation do not change. In order to improve access to EU law for the citizens of the Union, I agree with the proposal that has been tabled.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr Duda's report because the purpose of this proposal is the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001. It concerns the measures that the EU can take following a report produced by the WTO's Conciliation Body (DSB) on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures, in order to have increasingly clear and transparent European legislation.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — The European Parliament here wishes to endorse the Commission's proposal for a regulation allowing it to repeal or amend a measure incriminated by a report by the Dispute Resolution Board (DSB). The Commission would also have jurisdiction to adopt any other enforcement measures necessary to bring EU law into line with the DSB's recommendations. Because I reject the european Union's rule of law over national law, especially when its implementation is to comply with the wto's questionable injunctions, I am against the fact that the European Commission can arbitrarily change a law that mainly affects the commercial practice of the Member States. This proposed regulation is part of a strategy to strengthen the European Commission's prerogatives in international law and therefore runs counter to the very principle of national sovereignty. Not wanting to further weaken France's room for manoeuvre on the international economic scene, I objected to this text.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it rewrote a text that already gave the Brussels Commission jurisdiction to implement the decisions of the World Trade Organization's (WTO) Dispute Settlement Board. However, this attribution of competence is one of the facets of the abandonment by the Member States of the Union of their trade policy to the technocratic of Brussels. I believe that States must regain their sovereignty in this area, so that they can implement intelligent protectionism, at odds with the free trade put in place without precautions by the WTO and the Union.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. "Vote against this text. The sovereignty of each Member State must be respected. A state must be able to maintain control over its trade policy without having to submit to the directives of supranational organizations. It must be able to take all the measures it deems necessary to defend its economy against unfair competition. Imposed standardization may weaken its potential for action.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — In order to ensure greater clarity and transparency of EU law, this proposal seeks to codified Council Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001 on the measures that the Community may take on the basis of the report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures approved by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body. The new Regulation will replace the various acts incorporated into it; the content of the encoded texts is fully respected, merely incorporating those formal modifications required by the encoding operation itself. Therefore, considering that, according to the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, this proposal in question is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts and without substantial amendments, I vote in favour.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The purpose of this proposal is to start the codification process of Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013; 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001 on measures that the Community may take following a report adopted by the WTO Dispute Resolution Body concerning anti-dumping and anti-systemic issues.   The new Regulation brings together different acts that have not lost their substance and introduces only those formal amendments that require the codification process. All CITIZENS of the European Union have the right to clear, simplified and accurate information about their legal obligations and rights, and the European Union has committed to sticking to the principle of transparency. I therefore supported this proposal to codify the Council Regulation on anti-dumping and anti-systemic issues.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Duda report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the measures that the Union can take following a report adopted by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures, as the opinion of the Advisory Group on Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission finds that the proposal merely codifies the existing texts. , without modifying their substance.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this proposal to codify measures concerning anti-dumping and anti-subsidy matters in light of the recommendation from the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the measure adopted is to make more simplifying and codifying legislation which has undergone legislative changes by making them clearer and more transparent. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal concerns the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001 on the measures which the European Union may take in respect of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures. Since the proposal for a regulation drawn up by the rapporteur, Mr Duda, as confirmed by the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without making the same substantial changes, I felt it was right to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — I voted positively in favour of this proposal, as tougher anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures must be put into the EU against dumped or inadmissibly subsidised imports of goods in order to keep the European internal market competitive.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections concerning a given subject for the purpose of simplification, clarity and transparency.  The purpose of this proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 1515/2001 on the measures that the Community may take as a result of a report adopted by the World Trade Organization's (WSB) Dispute Settlement Body (DSB) on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures. Indeed, when the DSB adopts a report on a measure taken by the Union, the Commission may request further information on the measure in question, repeal it or amend it appropriately. I am voting against the WTO's control over European economies, even if it is only a matter of codifying its application.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — This report deals only with a technical issue, consisting of a codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001 on the measures that the Community may take following a report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures adopted by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report regarding the measures concerning anti-dumping and anti-subsidy matters because the consultative working party of the legal services of Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposed codification of the existing texts is straightforward and presents no change in their substance. It is crucial that agreements that have been amended on multiple occasions are codified in order to ensure that they are accessible and clear to citizens.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — Under the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation (WTO), a Memorandum of Understanding on the Rules and Procedures governing Dispute Resolution (MERL) has been concluded, within which the Dispute Settlement Body (DSL) has been established. I agree with this Regulation, as it safeguards the common rules established against imports, which are dumped by non-EU countries, thereby protecting the social status of thousands of people in disadvantaged countries. It should be stressed that the application of this Regulation requires uniform conditions for the adoption of measures following a report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures adopted by the DSB set out in Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 of the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The EP here wishes to endorse the Commission's proposal for a regulation allowing it to repeal or amend a measure incriminated by a report by the Dispute Resolution Board (DSB). The Commission would also have jurisdiction to adopt any other enforcement measures necessary to bring EU law into line with the DSB's recommendations. Because I reject the european Union's rule of law over national law, especially when its implementation is to comply with the wto's questionable injunctions, I am against the fact that the European Commission can arbitrarily change a law that mainly affects the commercial practice of the Member States. This proposed regulation is part of a strategy to strengthen the European Commission's prerogatives in international law and therefore runs counter to the very principle of national sovereignty. Not wanting to further weaken France's room for manoeuvre on the international economic scene, I objected to this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — The file brings together recent developments already in force. In particular, the Commission, pursuant to Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 and Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 as well as this consolidating measure, may repeal/amend or adopt an implementing measure to bring the Union into conformity with any report produced by the WTO’s Dispute Settlement Body.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which codifies Regulation (EC) No. 1515/2001 on the measures that the Union can take as a result of a report adopted by the WTO's dispute resolution body on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures. This regulation has been amended several times and substantially, so that its provisions are now found on the one hand in the original act, on the other hand scattered in the amending acts that followed. In the interests of clarity and simplification of the law, guaranteeing greater legal certainty and better information for citizens, it was therefore necessary to codify this regulation. This process completely preserves its substance and merely brings together in a legible way the various changes that have been made to it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome this proposal for a regulation on the measures that the Union can take following a report adopted by the WTO's Conciliation Body (DSB) on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures, given that during its examination the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of existing texts. , without making any substantial changes to its content.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted for this report because the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the measures the Union can take following a report adopted by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures. This measure also enables the European Union to fight effectively on the basis of World Trade Organisation proposals against illegal, anti-dumping and anti-competitive practices.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — Imports of goods from non-EU countries have always been a sensitive issue for the functioning of our internal market. Since the measures put to the vote are indeed a step towards preventing unduly subsidised imports, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal for measures that the EU may take following the wto dispute settlement body's report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures. The proposal is limited to the codification of legislation without any substantive changes.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) Ladies and gentlemen, since the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — I welcome the rule established by the Commission in 1987 that, after a dozen amendments to a particular act, it must be codified which contributes to the greater certainty of the correct application of the act, especially when it comes to such specific issues as these.  Anti-dumping and anti-systemic issues are governed by the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the measures that the Union can take following a report adopted by the WTO Dispute Resolution Body on anti-dumping and anti-systemic issues. The purpose of this proposal is to consolidate specific provisions allowing the Union to adopt measures taken under Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 (anti-dumping measures) or Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 (anti-subsidy measures). These measures must comply with the recommendations and solutions contained in the report adopted by the World Trade Organisation 's (WTO) dispute resolution authority (DSB) concerning anti-dumping and anti-systemic measures.  I supported this proposal because codification of this text, which has been the subject of several different acts and their amendments, purifies and aggregates (without any change in their content) which will ultimately contribute to greater certainty of its correct application.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — The European Parliament here wishes to endorse the Commission's proposal for a regulation allowing it to repeal or amend a measure incriminated by a report by the Dispute Resolution Board (DSB). The Commission would also have jurisdiction to adopt any other enforcement measures necessary to bring EU law into line with the DSB's recommendations. Because I reject the european Union's rule of law over national law, especially when its implementation is to comply with the wto's questionable injunctions, I am against the fact that the European Commission can arbitrarily change a law that mainly affects the commercial practice of the Member States. This proposed regulation is part of a strategy to strengthen the European Commission's prerogatives in international law and therefore runs counter to the very principle of national sovereignty. Not wanting to further weaken France's room for manoeuvre on the international economic scene, I objected to this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support this report by colleague Duda authorising the start of the codification process for Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001 on measures that the Community may take, following a report adopted by the WTO Dispute Resolution Body on anti-dumping and anti-systemic issues. The new provision provides for the unifying of different acts, without losing substance or changing the content. The launch of this formal procedure will increase the transparency of the process and facilitate the information of interested stakeholders on anti-dumping and anti-system issues, which is why I would like to show my support once again.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — I support MEP Andrzej Duda's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the measures that the Union can take following a report adopted by the WTO Dispute Resolution Body on anti-dumping and anti-systemic issues, on the grounds that the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has pointed out that the proposal is limited to codifying existing texts without substantive changes. The purpose of the proposal is the codification procedure for Regulation No 1000/2013. 1515/2001 of July 23, 2001, which changed several times. The new regulation brings together various scattered acts, which contributes to transparency and transparency. The European Parliament hereby supports a simplification that will make Union law clearer and more accessible to EU citizens. I welcome the continued efforts of parliament's professional services, the Council and the Commission in codification procedures.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the measures that the Union can implement, following a report adopted by the WTO Conciliation Body (DSB) on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures, since this proposal concerns a simple codification of existing texts and is also based on the opinion of the Advisory Group on Legal Services of 17 September 2014.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: in writing. — Anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures affect around 0.25% of all imports into the EU and are often the only way for the EU to protect its industries from the damage caused by unfair dumping practices by companies from outside the EU. Anti-dumping and anti-subsidy instruments need to be adapted to better protect trade in the EU, provide a stable background for businesses and protect the industry. In my opinion, the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001 on the measures that the Union can take on the basis of a report adopted by the WTO dispute resolution body on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy matters could be beneficial.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. " With this recommendation, it is up to the European Parliament to vote in favour of codifying a text in the order of European Union law. The aim of this text is to bring the European Union into compliance and to enable it to take retaliatory measures following a report adopted by the WTO dispute body. Being committed to the principle of reciprocity, I agree with this type of mechanism. Thus, to the extent that this codification does not make any substantial changes and allows for greater legibility of this right, I vote for it.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — The World Trade Organisation (WTO) Dispute Settlement Body (DSL), of which the EU is a member, issues, among others, reports on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures. Council Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001 concerns the measures that the EU may take following a report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures adopted by the DSB. This regulation has been substantially amended and therefore, for reasons of clarity and rationality, it should be codified. At its meeting of 10 July 2014, the Advisory Group composed of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission reviewed the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council, by which Regulation No 1515/2001 is codified. It then concluded, by common agreement, that the proposal under question should be based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive amendments. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — Since the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has given a positive opinion and considers that this proposal is limited to the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments to the texts, there is no reason to vote against or even to abstain.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — In order to simplify and clarity of EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of the codification of the Regulation on measures to be taken by the Union on the basis of the report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures approved by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body. The Regulation has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years and, in order to improve clarity and easy understanding of the legislative text, all these provisions should be recast into a new Regulation, respecting the content of the codified texts and making only the relevant formal amendments.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union attaches great significance to the simplification and clarification of European law in order to make it more accessible and easier to understand and understand by the ordinary citizen. For this reason, and in order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed. This proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001 on the measures which the Community may take following a report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures adopted by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body and does not provide for a change in the substance of the acts it is subject to, as can be read in the text of the opinion. Although it is a purely technical issue, which aims to integrate into a new regulation the various acts integrated into it, it falls into the field of codecision, and therefore requires analysis and voting by the EP. Therefore, if the proposal was approved, it was the subject of my favourable vote.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which is part of the process of facilitating Community law initiated by the inter-institutional agreement of 20 December 1994; it is a codification without changing the text. It is a legislative resolution on the proposed regulation on measures that the Union can take following a report adopted by the World Trade Organization's (WSB) Dispute Settlement Body (DSB) on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures.  The regulation thus allows the European Union, when it deems it appropriate, to make a measure taken in the context of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy in line with the recommendations and decisions of a report adopted by the WTO DSB.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I abstained because I do not agree with the European Commission's approach to the World Trade Organisation.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I am in favour of the adoption of this text, which is limited to the outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — The consolidation of the Dispute Resolution Authority constitutes one of the WTO's greatest achievements, as it allows WTO Member States to lodge complaints regardless of their political or economic power about alleged breaches of WTO rules and to seek reparations.  I voted to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 1515/2001 as it improves the current EU commercial protection system for the benefit of all stakeholders. It focuses on finding practical solutions to real problems and achieves greater efficiency of systems and measures. It is important to note that the fundamental principles and balance of the system are not changing, and therefore I support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because I support the WTO in their aims to properly settle disputes regarding anti-dumping and anti-subsidy matters.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The codification of texts should be an opportunity to re-evaluate their content in substance and not just by type.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on measures that the Union can take, following the report adopted by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy issues.  Transparency of EU legislation is of the utmost importance so that it is clear, easy to understand and accessible to all. It is therefore important that the provisions, which have been amended many times, are available in one place, in a collected form. The report contributed to this by agreeing to a simple, consolidated provision.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on the measures that the Union can take following a report adopted by the WTO's dispute resolution body on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures. When considering the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation to codify the regulation on the measures that the Union can take as a result of a report adopted by the WTO's dispute resolution body on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures, the group agreed that the proposal is effectively limited to an outright codification of existing texts , without altering their substance.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The codification of European legislation facilitates the understanding of European Union legislation. This legislative procedure envisages the clarification of the legislative act, but no substantive changes to that act can be introduced through it. The European institutions agreed in 1994 to use an accelerated procedure with a view to the rapid adoption of codified acts.  The legislative proposal which was the subject of the European Parliament's report concerns the codification of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. Council Regulation (EC) No 151/2001 on measures which the Union may take following a report adopted by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures.  Given that the codification proposal retains the full content of the codified acts and merely regroups them, making only the formal changes required by the codification operation itself and taking into account that the consultative working group of the legal services of the three European institutions recommends supporting this proposal, the European Parliament, by unanimous vote today, supports the proposal to codify the regulation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, one of the fifteen reports from the JURI committee to be voted on at this session. This is a technical amendment to update the legislative text for the sake of greater legal certainty.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Regulation 452/2003 has been amended several times. When discussing and voting on this regulation, we voted against it because it advocates the liberalisation of international trade in an unruly way. All its logic is rivalry for market shares, in the name of competition, and not a logic of cooperation, where trade has a role to play in development.  On the other hand, anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures represent potential interference with each country's internal decisions and threats that may be imposed by the WTO. The least developed and developing countries lose. The new Regulation fully preserves the content of the codified acts by introducing only the formal changes required by the codification process itself. We are frontally owe the content of this regulation. However, in the name of legislative simplification, we abstain.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of this proposal, as tougher anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures against dumped or inadmissibly subsidised imports of goods are to be put into the EU.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 1515/2001 of 23 July 2001 on the measures that the Community may take following a report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures adopted by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself. We believe that anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures are interference with each country's internal decisions, which mean that the least developed and least developed countries are the most affected. Each State should have the right to decide on its model of economic and social development. Although we are frontally oging against the content of the Regulation, we believe that it is important that all the amendments adopted in the meantime be brought together in a single document, facilitating the understanding of the legislation, so we have abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament, as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Louis Aliot (NI)
text: In writing. — The aim of anti-dumping and countervailing measures is to address market distortions created by unfair trade practices, while the objective of safeguard tariff measures is to protect against a sharp increase in imports. According to the European Commission, the combination of the two against a single product can have greater than expected effects in terms of the Union's trade defence policy and objectives.  Such a combination could, according to the Commission, impose an unjustified burden on certain exporting producers seeking to export to the EU, and deny them access to the EU market. The Commission argues that it is not always possible to determine in advance at what precise point this overlap will occur, which is why it seizes the opportunity to amend, suspend or repeal anti-dumping and/or countervailing measures as it sees fit, or to provide for the full or partial exemption from anti-dumping or countervailing duties. This decision is aberrant, as this regulation will allow the European Commission to deprive itself of the few tools of protectionism at its disposal. I have therefore naturally spoken out against this text, which is part of a logic that goes against the expectations of my fellow citizens.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The proposal is a mere codification without changing the content of the underlying acts. Parliament and the Council must agree to this codification, and that is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted against this ideological text that favours free trade at the expense of our manufacturing industries. Our production force is facing competition from countries where labour costs and production costs are very low and the European Union is preventing Member States from protecting themselves in the name of the principle of free movement of capital and goods. The timid measures taken against unfair competition prove ineffective in the face of an entire system that destroys our productive apparatus. However, these small steps were quickly reversed by political forces fiercely committed to defending globalisation and accepting their refusal to accept that countries wishing to export to the Union bear "unjustified financial burdens", thus brushing aside the draft european protectionism.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — If these matters were coming before Parliament for the first time, we would be voting against because these matters should be within the competence of the Member States. Therefore to vote against is consistent with our position.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal on the general effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures. The purpose of the proposal is to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. In this text, Parliament and the Council question what they see as a danger of protectionism which, with regard to only certain imported goods, would result from the simultaneous application of anti-dumping and countervailing measures, on the one hand, and safeguard tariff measures on the other. The aim of the proposed regulation is to enable the Commission - in cases where it considers that exporters seeking to export to the EU are too penalised by financial burdens or by bans on access to the EU market - to amend, suspend or repeal existing anti-dumping and/or countervailing measures, or even exempt imports from anti-dumping/compensatory duties that should, if not, be paid. This revolting sacrifice of the national interest of the Member States in favour of the free-trade dogma which refuses to see any idea of protectionism, national or continental, once again demonstrates the absurdity of the Union's economic and trade policy. I obviously voted against this text.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. "This is the codification of existing texts without altering their substance.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because the advisory group has found that it is a question of codating Council Regulation (EC) No 452/2003 of 6 March 2003 on the measures that the Community may take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures, and not a substantial change.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report proposes a regulation that sets out specific provisions to enable the Commission to act at its discretion, so as to prevent a combination of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguard tariff measures against the same product from imposing an unjustified burden on certain exporting producers seeking to export to the Union, thereby prohibiting them from accessing the EU market.  Although the regulations provide for anti-dumping clauses through collective action measures or a national safeguard clause (which is now severely reduced), the text assumes that the EU must allow exporters seeking to export to the EU not to be penalised by financial burdens or by bans on access to the EU market. The Commission is thus not deviating from the sacrosanct dogma rule of free and undistorted competition and is no longer hesitating to sell off the interests of The Member States by banning all protectionism even as the number of trade barriers in many countries of the world continues to grow, directly affecting industries and services based in Europe. So I obviously voted against this regulation.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — The Duda report analyses the measures which the Union can take with regard to the combined effect of anti-dumping/countervailing duties and safeguard measures. Although this is a proposal that is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, I do not agree with the EU Commission's approach in these areas, I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — In the interests of simplifying and clearing EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of the codification of the Regulation on measures that the Union may take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures. The Regulation has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years and, in order to improve clarity and easy understanding of the legislative text, all these provisions should be recast into a new Regulation, respecting the content of the codified texts and making only the relevant formal amendments.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports the codification of the regulation measures that the Union can take on the basis of a report on anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures adopted by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body, without changing the substance of the Regulation itself. The codification of legislation is needed to make it more comprehensible and accessible to citizens.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — I support this proposal because, according to the competent authorities, it refers only to the codification of existing texts without substantive changes.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. Even when it falls within the eu's jurisdiction, trade policy is not entirely common. Member States have the opportunity to take action against third countries, and even Member States. But the freedom to take action within the community space is increasingly diminished. The former EC Treaty (Article 134) provided for a national safeguard clause, the scope of which is now substantially reduced. Collective defence measures are also planned, particularly against dumping. The text deals with the combined effects of these two types of measures. I voted against this text, in particular on the adaptation of recitals 7 and 8, which state that "it would therefore be appropriate for exporting producers seeking to export to the Union not to bear unjustified financial burdens and to continue to access the EU market.  It is therefore desirable that the objectives of safeguards and anti-dumping and/or countervailing measures can be achieved without the relevant exporting producers being denied access to the EU market."

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted yes because the anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures should be combined with safeguard measures to be more effective.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. — The aim of the Council and European Parliament's proposed regulation is to codify Council Regulation 452/2003 of 6 March 2003 on the measures that the European Community can take on anti-dumping measures. In practical terms, this new regulation will allow the Commission to act in a discretionary manner against a Member State in the area of anti-dumping legislation. If the Commission considers that a combination of anti-dumping measures against an imported product creates an unjustified burden for some exporters, it will be entitled to amend, suspend or repeal any legal or regulatory scheme, and even provide for full or partial exemption from anti-dumping duties. The granting of this jurisdiction is purely scandalous and must be vigorously denounced. It is up to the Member States to decide sovereignly whether an anti-dumping measure is proportional to the risk generated by the importation of a product, and not to the Commission. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on measures that the Union can take with regard to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures, because I believe that the accelerated method for formal codification of the legislative proposal is the most appropriate method of application with a view to expediting the Community legislative process. I stress that the simple codification procedure constitutes a legal limitation which prevents any substantive change made by the European Parliament or the Council, so that we ensure that the measures available to the Union in the event of the combined effect of those measures will be respected and implemented as such.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — The measure concerns the mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes. This is a purely technical measure, therefore, but I abstained. I do not agree with the Commission's policy of applying duties and safeguard measures which lies before this act.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The aim of codification is to simplify and make European legislation more accessible. It is a kind of compilation of different European regulations dealing with the same theme. Codification on the combined effect of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguards is very important for the proper functioning of the single market and international trade. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal for a regulation is to codify the provisions of Regulation No 452/2003 without making any formal or substantive amendments to the existing texts.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. — Once again, the European Union is using trade leverage to increase and expand its powers. Member States, according to the treaties, are supposed to retain the possibility of taking action against third countries and even Member States. However, the Commission is increasingly taking over any trade prerogative, sometimes to the detriment of the interests of the Member States, as seen in the TTIP negotiations with the United States.  That is why, in the name of defending French interests, I voted against this text.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 1994 Interinstitutional Agreement provided for an acceleration of the official codification of legislative texts. The Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, which also met in 2014 to examine this proposal, it determined that the measure was limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial amendments, having also analysed the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 452/2003 of 6 March 2003 on the measures which the Community may take with regard to the combined effect of anti-dumping/countervailing duties and safeguard measures. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — In the case of the imposition of anti-dumping duties, it is necessary to prevent their effect, combined with that of any safeguard measures, from entailing an excessive burden on certain exporters, with the consequent result that they are cut off from the single market. To this end, the Council adopted Regulation (EC) No 452/2003 in 2003 allowing measures to be taken to amend, suspend or repeal anti-dumping or countervailing duties. I voted in favour of this resolution, as I was already in favour of the previous agreement of 2003, and the resolution confines itself to a mere codification of the existing texts, without substantial changes.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the measures which the Union may take with regard to the combined effect of anti-dumping/countervailing duties and safeguard measures. The proposal for a regulation, in the event that dumping is established, provides for the application of import duties, i.e. duties intended to level the final price of the imported goods up to the threshold of the prices in force on the market of origin of the goods, unless it is possible to conclude an agreement with the producers of the imported goods on the minimum price guaranteeing the same result. In view of the fact that the proposal for a regulation is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts without any substantial changes, and in view of the real benefit that the internal market can derive from them in terms of fair competition, I have decided to conform to the position of the Advisory Group.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — The codification process represents the bringing together of existing texts, thereby providing easier access to relevant EU legislation. The purpose of this proposal is to undertake a codification of the Council Regulation on measures that the Community may take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures with safeguard measures. The new Regulation will supersede the various acts incorporated in it, so this proposal fully preserves the content of the acts being codified and does no more than bring them together with only such formal amendments as are required by the codification exercise itself. Anti-dumping regulations protect European investors, thereby protecting employment in Europe.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the measures which the Union may take with regard to the combined effect of anti-dumping/countervailing duties and safeguard measures. This is a purely technical procedure provided for in Article 103 of the Regulation to verify that the codification proposal is in fact limited to mere codification, without any substantial changes.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament, as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to undertake a codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 452/2003 on measures that the Community may take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures with safeguard measures. The new Regulation will supersede the various acts incorporated in it; it fully preserves the content of the acts being codified and hence does no more than bring them together with only such formal amendments as are required by the codification exercise itself. Due to the clear procedural nature of this exercise I voted in favour of it.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes the codification within European Union law of the Council Regulation (EC) No. 452/2003 on the measures that the Union can take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguard measures, which were substantially amended in 2014. The proposed regulation sets out specific provisions to enable the Commission to act at its discretion, so as to prevent a combination of trade defence measures, so-called anti-dumping or countervailing measures, and safeguard tariff measures against the same product, imposing an unjustified burden on certain exporting producers seeking to export to the Union and thereby prohibiting them from accessing the EU market. I support this text as a simple exercise in codifying positive law without any change in substance. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. A regulation, changed several times, loses its intelligibility. That is why we have here wished to codify the regulation on the measures that the Union can take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguard measures, without changing its substance. I supported this measure, which promotes the legibility of this text.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — The proposal aims to codify Regulation (EC) 452/2003 of the Council of 6 March 2003 on the measures that the Community can take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguard measures. I support this proposal on substance and form. On the merits, because the proposed regulation sets out specific provisions to enable the Commission to act in such a way as to prevent a combination of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguard tariff measures against the same product from imposing an unjustified burden on certain exporting producers seeking to export to the Union, thereby prohibiting them from accessing the EU market. On the form, because the aforementioned regulation has been amended several times and the new regulation, by substituting for the various acts incorporated in it, makes EU law more readable and accessible.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted against this text which, once again, favours free trade at the expense of our industries. Indeed, our production force is subject to competition from countries where labour costs and production costs are very low and the European Union prevents Member States from protecting themselves in the name of the principle of free movement of capital and goods. The timid measures taken against unfair competition prove ineffective in the face of an entire system that destroys our productive apparatus. However, these small steps were quickly reversed by some political forces fiercely committed to defending globalisation and assuming their refusal to accept that countries wishing to export to the Union bear "unjustified financial burdens", thus brushing aside the draft European protectionism.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — We are voting against the codification of all the texts, because we are not given the opportunity to intervene in the substance of these provisions, which means that we must accept them as they stand.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — This proposal codified Council Regulation (EC) No 452/2003 of 6 March 2003 on the measures that the Community may take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures. The adoption of the proposal takes into account that research and comparison of numerous acts is required at European level in order to determine the provisions in force, and the consideration of the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, according to which this proposal in question contains a direct codification of existing texts without any change in their content.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 452/2003 of 6 March 2003 on the measures that the Community may take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Regulation No 452/2003 on the measures that the EU may take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures has been amended several times. When discussing and voting on this regulation, we voted against it because it advocates trade liberalisation and the principle of reciprocity and the imposition of retaliatory measures. All its logic is rivalry for market shares in the name of competition and not a logic of cooperation, where trade has a role to play in development. On the other hand, anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures are interference in each country's internal decisions and threats that may be imposed by the WTO. The least developed and developing countries lose. The new regulation voted on today will replace the various acts integrated into it, fully preserving the content of the codified acts, introducing only the formal amendments required by the codification process itself. Since this is a technical change, the disagreement with the basic text justified our abstention.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — The measure involved is Regulation (EC) No 452/2003 on the measures to be taken as a result of the combined effect of duties and safeguard measures. I will not support the regulation as I do not agree with the current approach proposed by the European Commission in the application of duties and safeguard measures.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am against codifying all the texts, because we are not given the opportunity to intervene in the substance of these provisions and we must, by extension, accept them as they stand.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — I am in favour of the proposal as it is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — Mr President, I voted in favour of the report on the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures with safeguard measures, seeing that this concerns a purely technical matter aiming at the  consolidation of legislation to react to recent developments.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against this proposal on the combined effect of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguards. While this proposed regulation merely codifies existing texts, without altering their substance, it is nonetheless unacceptable on its merits. The freedom of Member States to take safeguard measures is increasingly limited. The old EC Treaty, in Article 34, provided for a national safeguard clause whose scope has been reduced under the action of the European institutions. I do not wish to endorse this drift which is gradually depriving States of their means to react.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this as it is consolidation of legislation in line with recent developments.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Proposal of Parliament and the Council on the measures that the Union can take in relation to the combined impact of anti-dumped and anti-systemic measures with safeguards, as I consider that one of the more important roles of the European Union is to provide all its citizens with easy access to legal order acts that directly concern them in such a way that the latter is clear and transparent.  It is codification that focuses on this simplification that does not change the essential content of the acts. I believe that such procedures further enable Union citizens to exercise their special rights.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted against this text, which, once again, would rather facilitate trade than help our industries. Indeed, our production force is subject to competition from third world countries where labour is both cheaper and more servile, but the European Union prevents its Member States from protecting themselves in the name of the sacrosanct principle of free movement of capital and goods. So the Union is trying to protect itself by adopting timid measures to compensate for this unfair competition. Unfortunately, while we were able to welcome such an awareness, some MEPs were quick to revisit this beginning of progress. Not wanting to hinder globalisation, which impoverishes us so much, they thought it appropriate to add that it was out of the question for countries wishing to export to the Union to bear "unjustified financial burdens". And so the meagre attempt at European protectionism disappeared.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I have supported this report which will enable the codification of Regulation (EC) 452/2003 of the Council of 6 March 2003 on the measures that the Community can take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguard measures. This codification exercise is commendable in that it allows for a clearer reading of a amended regulation on multiple occasions.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — On the agenda item under the name ‘Combined effect of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures with safeguard measures’ we voted in favour of that because we believe that the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing, valid legal texts, without any change in their substance. The combined effect of these measures will remedy market distortions on the one hand and will grant relief against greatly increased imports on the other.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — Since its entry into force, its core substance has been amended several times, making it increasingly difficult (1) to ascertain its precise scope and (2) for the persons concerned to exercise their rights as laid down by this Regulation without having to refer to the original instrument and any subsequent amended instruments. It takes an unnecessarily large amount of research to compare all the amendments in order to be consistent with the current legal system, a fact that limits the efficiency of EU law. For the sake of clarity and transparency, these provisions will be codified if there have been more than 10 amendments to them. Especially in international trade, where the legal situation is often not really clear, the rules in the region of origin should be clear and comprehensible for exporters in the interests of legal and planning security. Such codification is now carried out through this regulation, so that there is no change in the substance of the intention of the regulation. It will bring the various legal acts into a compendium, the content of which will not be changed, thereby facilitating access to EU law in WTO DSB decisions on anti-dumping measures. The proposals do not change existing practices, but simplify access and understanding; I therefore agree with this request.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the report as it is simply aiming at consolidation of legislation to react to recent developments.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr Duda's report because the purpose of this proposal is to initiate the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 452/2003 of 6 March 2003 on the measures that the EU may take with regard to the combined effect of anti-dumping/countervailing duties and safeguard measures. The Regulation lays down specific provisions to enable the Commission to act in order to prevent the combination of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures from imposeing an excessive burden on exporting producers to the EU.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — The purpose of the Council's and the European Parliament's proposal for a regulation here is to codify Council Regulation 452/2003 on the measures that the European Community can take on anti-dumping measures. In fact, this new regulation will allow the Commission to act as it sees fit against a Member State in the area of anti-dumping legislation. If the Commission considers that a combination of anti-dumping measures against an imported product creates an unjustified burden on some exporters, it will be entitled to amend, suspend or repeal any legal or regulatory scheme and even provide for full or partial exemption from anti-dumping duties. The attribution of this jurisdiction is truly outrageous and unacceptable. It is up to the Member States to decide sovereignly whether an anti-dumping measure is proportional to the risk generated by the importation of a product and not to the Commission. I voted against it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — This proposal for a Regulation lays down specific provisions which will allow the Commission, where appropriate, to take measures to prevent, on the same product, a combination of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures that place an excessively onerous burden on certain exporting producers wishing to export to the EU, limiting their possibilities of access to the EU market. Taking into account that the new Regulation does not imply substantial changes from the rules previously used, I am voting in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The purpose of this proposal is to start the codification process of Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013; 452/2003 as of 6 March 2003 on measures the Community may take in relation to the combined impact of anti-dumping or anti-systemic measures with safety measures. The new Regulation brings together different acts that have not lost their substance and introduces only those formal amendments that require the codification process.  All CITIZENS of the European Union have the right to clear, simplified and accurate information about their legal obligations and rights, and the European Union has committed to sticking to the principle of transparency. I therefore supported this proposal to codify the Council Regulation on the combined impact of anti-dumping or anti-systemic measures with security measures.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Duda report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the measures which the Union may adopt in relation to the combined effects of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures, as the opinion of the Advisory Group on Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission finds that the proposal merely codifies the existing texts. , without modifying their substance.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this proposal, which follows the recommendations of the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — Favourable to the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the measures which the Union may take with regard to the combined effect of anti-dumping/countervailing duties and safeguard measures. In view of the importance of codification being carried out in full compliance with the procedure for adopting Union acts and given the need for Community citizens to have easy access to European legislative acts, I voted in favour.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to initiate the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 452/2003 of 6 March 2003 on the measures which the EU may take with regard to the combined effect of anti-dumping/countervailing duties and safeguard measures. The Regulation lays down specific provisions to enable the Commission to act, at its own discretion, in order to prevent the combination of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures, with tariff safeguard measures against the same product, from imposeing an excessive burden on certain exporting producers wishing to export to the EU. Since the proposal by the rapporteur, Mr Duda, is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without making the same substantial changes, I have decided to support the report with a vote in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, as the use of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures is intended to eliminate market distortions due to unfair trade practices.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections concerning a given subject for the purpose of simplification, clarity and transparency. The aim of this report is to codify Regulation 452/2003 on the measures that the Union can take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures.  It is this regulation that allows EU member states to take safeguard measures.
