But it is also this regulation that gives the Commission every power to amend, suspend or repeal anti-dumping and/or countervailing measures, or to provide for the full or partial exemption from anti-dumping or countervailing duties. These undemocratic technocratic procedures prevent Europe from practising solidarity protectionism, which is the ecological and social emergency of our time. Having opposed this Commission's control on its merits, I am voting against this technical report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — This report deals only with a technical issue, consisting of the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 452/2003 of 6 March 2003 on the measures which the Community may take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report regarding the combined effect of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures because the consultative working party of the legal services of Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposed codification of the existing texts is straightforward and presents no change in their substance. It is crucial that agreements that have been amended on multiple occasions are codified in order to ensure that they are accessible and clear to citizens.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Regulation because I consider it appropriate that the objectives of safeguard measures and anti-dumping and/or anti-subsidy measures can be achieved without preventing exporting producers from having access to the Union market.  However, I would argue that it is appropriate to provide for specific provisions enabling the Commission to adopt measures to ensure a combination of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and tariff safeguard measures applicable to the same product. In this way, there is a guarantee that the economic and social conditions of workers are improved. I also believe that the Commission may consider it appropriate to amend, suspend or repeal anti-dumping and/or anti-subsidy measures or provide for the partial or total exemption of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy duties that would be adopted. Any suspension, amendment or exemption from anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures may only be granted for a limited period of time, as the objective should be preventive action to prevent this from resulting.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The aim of the Council and European Parliament's proposal for a regulation here is to codify Council Regulation 452/2003 of 6 March 2003 on the measures that the European Community can take on anti-dumping measures. In fact, this new regulation will allow the Commission to act as it sees fit against a Member State in the area of anti-dumping legislation.  If the Commission considers that a combination of anti-dumping measures against an imported product creates an unjustified burden on some exporters, it will be entitled to amend, suspend or repeal any legal or regulatory scheme and even provide for the full or partial exemption from anti-dumping duties. The attribution of this jurisdiction is truly outrageous and unacceptable. It is up to the Member States to decide sovereignly whether an anti-dumping measure is proportional to the risk generated by the importation of a product and not to the Commission. I obviously voted against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — The file concerns measures which may be taken in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures with safeguard measures. Again, it is a codification of existing amendments, solely designed to make the law easier to understand. The amendments brought together simply try to ensure that excessively onerous burdens are not placed on exporting producers from non-EU countries on products which may be subject to both anti-subsidy/anti-dumping measures in addition to safeguard measures/tariff measures.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which codifies Regulation (EC) 452/2003 on the measures that the Union can take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguard measures. This regulation has been amended several times and substantially, so that its provisions are now found on the one hand in the original act, on the other hand scattered in the amending acts that followed. In the interests of clarity and simplification of the law, guaranteeing greater legal certainty and better information for citizens, it was therefore necessary to codify this regulation. This process completely preserves its substance and merely brings together in a legible way the various changes that have been made to it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome this proposal for a regulation on the measures which the Union can take with regard to the combined effect of anti-dumping/countervailing duties and safeguard measures, given that during its examination the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without making any substantial changes to its content.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted for this report because the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the measures that the Union can take with regard to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures. This measure also enables the European Union to fight effectively on the basis of World Trade Organisation proposals against illegal, anti-dumping and anti-competitive practices.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal as I expect positive effects in the fight against unfair trade practices. I therefore believe that the measures mentioned are actually useful in order to combat market distortions.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the draft because it is confined to codifying existing legislation without any substantive changes.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) Since the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — Council Regulation No 452/2003/EU on measures the Union can take in relation to the combined impact of anti-dumping or anti-systemic measures with safeguards was adopted in 2003. The basic text has been changed significantly on several occasions. Back in 1987, the Commission established a rule that, after a dozen amendments to a particular act, it must be codified, thus contributing to greater certainty of the correct application of the act. The text of the Regulation and its amendment fees, covered by this codification, relate to the adoption of a specific provision enabling the Commission to take measures to avoid cases where a combination of anti-subsidy and dumping measures with safeguard tariff measures for one and the same product would put up an insurmountable barrier for individual producers wishing to export in the EU. This could be interpreted as denying access to the Union market and could cause negative consequences for eu international trade with third countries. It is an act that has great significance in regulating trade between the EU (including Croatia) and third countries. Due to the need for its correct application in EU-third country relations on the international market, I supported the proposed codification as it contributes to greater legal certainty of the application of this Regulation.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — The aim of the Council and European Parliament's proposed regulation is to codify Council Regulation 452/2003 of 6 March 2003 on the measures that the European Community can take on anti-dumping measures. In fact, this new regulation will allow the Commission to act as it sees fit against a Member State in the area of anti-dumping legislation.  If the Commission considers that a combination of anti-dumping measures against an imported product creates an unjustified burden on some exporters, it will be entitled to amend, suspend or repeal any legal or regulatory scheme, and even provide for full or partial exemption from anti-dumping duties. The attribution of this jurisdiction is truly outrageous and unacceptable. It is up to the Member States to decide sovereignly whether an anti-dumping measure is proportional to the risk generated by the importation of a product and not to the Commission. I obviously voted against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support this report aimed at starting the codification process for Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013; 452/2003 as of 6 March 2003 on measures the Community may take in relation to the combined impact of anti-dumping or anti-systemic measures with safety measures. The new regulation provides for the pooling of different acts that do not lose substance or alter content.   This formal procedure enhances the transparency of the process and allows citizens to be fully informed through simplified rules about their rights and obligations when it comes to the impact of anti-dumping or anti-systemic measures with security measures.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — I support MEP Andrzej Duda's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the measures the Union can take in relation to the combined impact of anti-dumping or anti-systemic safeguards, on the grounds that the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has pointed out that the proposal is limited to codifying existing texts without substantive changes. The purpose of the proposal is the codification procedure for Regulation No 1000/2013. 452/2003 since 6 March 2003, which has changed several times. The new regulation brings together various scattered acts, which contributes to transparency and transparency. The European Parliament hereby supports a simplification that will make Union law clearer and more accessible to EU citizens. I welcome the continued efforts of parliament's professional services, the Council and the Commission in codification procedures.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — Here, too, I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the measures that the Union may take with regard to the combined effect of anti-dumping/countervailing duties and safeguard measures because, in accordance with the opinion of 17 September 2014 of the Advisory Group on Legal Services, this is a mere codification of the existing texts, without major changes.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Through this recommendation, it is up to the European Parliament to vote in favour of codifying a text in the order of European Union law. The structure of international trade requires effective instruments to ensure equal competition and consumer protection. I therefore welcome any measures to increase the implementation of this type of instrument. Thus, to the extent that this codification does not result in any substantial changes and allows for greater legibility of this right, I vote in for it.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — At its meeting of 10 July 2014, the Advisory Group composed of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission reviewed the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council, which codifies Regulation (EEC) No 452/2003 of the Council of 6 March 2003 on the measures which the Community may take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping measures and safeguard measures. It then concluded, by common agreement, that the proposal under question should be based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive amendments. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — Since the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has given a positive opinion and considers that this proposal is limited to the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments to the texts, there is no reason to vote against or even to abstain.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — In the interests of simplifying and clearing EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of the codification of the Regulation on measures which the Union may take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures. The Regulation has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years and, in order to improve clarity and easy understanding of the legislative text, all these provisions should be recast into a new Regulation, respecting the content of the codified texts and making only the relevant formal amendments.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union considers it extremely important to simplify and clarify European law, making it more comprehensible to the ordinary citizen. In this sense, in order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed. The aim of this proposal, which deserves my vote in favour, is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 452/2003 of 6 March 2003 on the measures that the Community may take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures, while preserving, in full, the content of the codified acts. Like report A8-0033, it is a purely technical issue, which aims to incorporate into a new regulation the various acts integrated into it, but which, as it falls in the field of codecision, requires analysis and voting by the EP. Therefore, if the proposal was approved, it was the subject of my favourable vote.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which is part of the process of facilitating Community law initiated by the inter-institutional agreement of 20 December 1994; it is a codification without changing the text. It is a legislative resolution on the proposed regulation on the measures that the Union can take on the combined effect of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguard measures. The regulation makes it possible to establish specific provisions to enable the Commission to act at its discretion, so as to prevent a combination of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguard tariff measures against the same product from imposing an unjustified burden on certain exporting producers seeking to export to the Union and thereby prohibiting them from entering the EU market.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I abstained because I do not agree with the European Commission's approach to the application of duties and safeguard measures.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I am in favour of the adoption of this text, which is limited to the outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament, as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — Proposal to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013 452/2003 As of 6 March 2003, I support the measures that the Community may take in relation to the combined impact of anti-dumping or anti-systemic measures with security measures on the grounds that, in this way, the various acts incorporated into the regulation will be merged into a single act without substantive changes.  The combination of anti-dumping or anti-systemic measures with safeguards on the same product can be a challenging burden for some producers seeking to export to the Union, thus preventing them from accessing the Union market. This Regulation lays down specific provisions that allow activities to be undertaken that ensure sufficient predictability and legal certainty for all entities concerned, and I therefore support it.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support free access to the Union market so voted in favour of this report. I believe excessively onerous burdens should not be placed on exporting producers from countries outside of the EU on products which may be subject to anti-subsidy/anti-dumping measures in addition to safeguard measures/tariff measures. By consolidating the existing legislation, the Commission can continue to use their powers to ensure no such burden exists.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support this regulation, as its purpose is to codify the regulation of measures that can be taken in accordance with the WTO (World Trade Organisation) report on anti-dumping and anti-systemic issues.  The objectives of the measures mentioned are to regulate and repair market distortions due to unfair trading and to ensure an increase in excessive import growth. The Legal Affairs Committee adopted Andrzej Duda's report on the regulatory proposal between the European Parliament and the Council following the adoption of a report from the WTO's anti-dumping and anti-corruption dispute resolution body.  It was recommended that the European Parliament adopt the proposal at the first hearing and take up the Commission proposal adapted according to the recommendations of the Consultive Working Party.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The codification of texts should be an opportunity to re-evaluate their content in substance and not just by type.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the european Parliament and The Council's proposed regulation on the measures that the Union can take in view of the combined effect of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguard measures. As a reminder, when considering the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation to codify the Council's regulation on the measures that the Community can take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguard measures, the group agreed that the proposal is limited to an outright codification of existing texts , without altering their substance.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. — I supported the report on the Combined Impact of Anti-Dumping or Anti-Systemic Safeguards, as it only codifys existing texts without substantive changes.  I believe that anti-dumping measures represent the basic mechanism of trade policy of the European Union, and are extremely important because of the objective of protecting the European Union market and domestic products from dumped imports from third countries.  As the area of anti-dumping and countervailing measures is one of the most dynamic parts of eu tariff legislation, I consider this draft to regulate protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The codification of European legislation facilitates the understanding of European Union legislation. This legislative procedure envisages the clarification of the legislative act, but no substantive changes to that act can be introduced through it. The European institutions agreed in 1994 to use an accelerated procedure with a view to the rapid adoption of codified acts.  The legislative proposal which was the subject of the European Parliament's report concerns the codification of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. Council Regulation (EC) No 452/2003 of 6 March 2003 on measures which the Community may adopt with regard to the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures.  Given that the codification proposal retains the full content of the codified acts and merely regroups them, making only the formal changes required by the codification operation itself and taking into account that the consultative working group of the legal services of the three European institutions recommends supporting this proposal, the European Parliament, by unanimous vote today, supports the proposal to codify the regulation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, one of the fifteen reports from the JURI committee to be voted on at this session. This is a technical amendment to update the legislative text for the sake of greater legal certainty.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament, as it is a technical report facilitating their codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. — The proposal seeks to amend the Council Regulation of 6 May 2003 on the combined effect of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures and safeguard measures. I wholeheartedly support this proposal because the proposed regulation allows the European Commission to act when the above measures prevent a trader or producer from exporting to the European Union.  After several changes, this latest version is also much more readable and accessible, which only benefits our European law.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself. We are against the liberalisation of international trade based on a supposed market law that only favours the strongest. Each State should have the right to decide its model of economic and social development. This right cannot be veised, it is a sovereign right, which cannot be called into question by any free trade agreement.  Although we are frontally owe against the content of the regulation, we believe that it is important that all amendments adopted in the meantime be brought together in a single document, facilitating the understanding of the legislation. Hence our abstention.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of this proposal because the application of anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures is intended, on the one hand, to eliminate market distortions due to unfair trade practices. On the other hand, the aim of the simultaneous application of safeguard measures is to provide protection against increased imports.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — When discussing and voting on this regulation, we voted against, as it advocates trade liberalisation and the principle of reciprocity and the imposition of retaliatory measures, defending the logic of rivalry for market shares in the name of competition rather than a logic of cooperation for the development of countries. On the other hand, anti-dumping or anti-subsidy measures are interference in each country's internal decisions and threats that may be imposed by the WTO. The least developed and developing countries lose. The new regulation voted on today will replace the various acts integrated into it, fully preserving the content of the codified acts, introducing only the formal amendments required by the codification process itself. Although we are head-on against the content of this Regulation, we believe that it is important that all amendments adopted in the meantime be brought together in a single document, facilitating the understanding of the legislation, so we have abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the common regime applicable to imports from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament as it is a technical report which facilitates its codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Louis Aliot (NI)
text: In writing. — The purpose of the proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 260/2009 of the Council of 26 February 2009 relating to the common import regime. This regime introduces a ban on quantitative import restrictions within the UNION on the basis of the principle of free trade. However, to the extent that the text provides protections for Member States' productions, but not knowing to what extent they will be applicable and/or actually applied, I preferred to abstain on this vote.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The proposal is a mere codification without changing the content of the existing legal texts. Parliament and the Council must agree to this codification, and that is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — While there are some positive points in this text, such as reasoned protectionism or safeguards and surveillance measures, this is a timid first step towards protecting our industries and production. Any brake on ultraliberalism and indiscriminate free trade is to be encouraged, since it calls into question a system in which nation states no longer have freedom. Nevertheless, there are some weaknesses in this text. There is never any mention of the national level or at least the national freedom to promote domestic products. Considering that the nation-state is the only echelon capable of guaranteeing the economic functioning of a society, the elected representatives of the National Front cannot vote in favour of this text. So I decided to abstain. Leaving the possibility for the Union to protect European industries is not enough: it is essential to give Member States priority on these issues and to leave them free to carry out their national economic policies.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — If these matters were coming before Parliament for the first time, we would be voting against because these matters should be within the competence of the Member States. Therefore to vote against is consistent with our position.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this deliberation, because it is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal on common import rules. The purpose of the proposal is to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Although the text contains laudable safeguards and surveillance measures in favour of the protection of the internal market of the Member States (provided they are actually applied), I oppose the free-trade principle which is the basis of this report. Moreover, given the current legislation, we are far from really regaining control of our national productions and economic policies. I therefore abstained on the vote of this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. "This is the codification of existing texts without altering their substance.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal because the advisory group has found that this is only a codification of existing acts, without substantial modification.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report on the common import regime proposes a regulation that establishes the principle of freedom of import of products originating from third countries (with exceptions), subject to possible safeguard measures. This text therefore introduces a ban on quantitative restrictions on the basis of the WTO's principle of free trade, but safeguards and monitoring measures can enable the Union to take measures to protect our internal market and our local production (if this is indeed applied). In light of these elements, I abstained on this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) Despite the technical nature of the changes being voted on, I do not agree with the EU Commission's current policies on trade aspects, so I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — In the interests of simplifying and clearing EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of the codification of the Regulation on the common regime applicable to imports. The Regulation has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years and, in order to improve clarity and easy understanding of the legislative text, all these provisions should be recast into a new Regulation, respecting the content of the codified texts and making only the relevant formal amendments.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports the codification of the regulation on common rules for imports from third countries for textile products. As early as 1 April 1987 The Commission has decided that all EU legislation, which has been amended no more than ten times, should be codified and stressed that this requirement is minimal and that Commission departments should endeavour to produce codified versions of the texts for which they are responsible within a shorter period of time in order to ensure that their provisions are clear and easily understandable. This practice has been adopted in European legislation to make it more comprehensible and accessible to citizens.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — I will vote for this proposal, as the assessment is that it relates only to the codification of existing texts without substantive changes.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. This text recalls the principles of the GATT, in particular the one that prohibits quantitative restrictions, and that the common tariff should suffice. It codifies, without any change in substance, the common regime applicable to imports, particularly within the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO). If the principle of free trade that the WTO promotes is reprehensible and rejectable, the safeguards and surveillance measures contained in the text can enable the Union to take the necessary measures to protect the internal market.  Moreover, we can only regret that quantitative and tariff quotas, allowed for certain products, by these international commitments, are not used for the defence of our domestic productions. So I abstained.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour since I strongly consider that a real Union should have common rules for imports.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. — The aim of the Council and The European Parliament's proposed regulation is to codify Regulation (EC) No. 260/2009 of the Council of 19 October 2009 establishing a common import regime. While I am opposed in principle to this type of text which facilitates free trade and disarms Member States in the face of savage globalisation, I nevertheless stress that it allows monitoring and safeguarding measures to be taken in the interests of producers, when certain massive imports are likely to cause them serious injury. Nevertheless, Member States must re-appropriate tariff and non-tariff quota jurisdiction when vital economic and agricultural sectors are seriously threatened by unfair competition. As the current state of the legislation is not satisfactory, I abstained on the vote of this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — This Regulation shall apply to imports into the European Union of products originating in third countries, with the exception of products subject to their own import arrangements, and textile products subject to a special arrangements.   I have expressed myself in favour of this because the importance of the codified texts is legally certain with regard to the applicable law in relation to the regime relating to EU imports and contributes to a faster and more effective implementation in this regard.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — I abstained. The proposal concerns the mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes. However, I do not agree with the political substance behind the measure on common import arrangements.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — One of the objectives of European legislators is to make Eusurfy legislation simpler and more accessible so that it can be applied as best as possible. Codification is an element that can achieve this goal. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the codification of the common import regime.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — This proposal for a Regulation codifies a number of principles already contained in the regulations on goods imported into the Member States of the Union.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. "I preferred to abstain on this text, which once again symbolizes the European Union's desire to become bogged down in a system that despises the interests of the peoples it is supposed to represent. Indeed, this report is based on the principle of banning quantitative restrictions, that is, the prohibition of restrictions on the import or sale of products originating in the territory of other Member States: it is therefore impossible to defend our domestic productions. However, the report contains interesting safeguards and monitoring measures with a view to protecting the internal market from third countries.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — Consideration should be made of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working method for the official codification of legislative texts. With regard to the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 260/2009 of 26 February 2009 on common rules for imports, the Advisory Group noted by common accord that article 7(4) of the codified proposal for a consolidated text should reintroduce the reference "to Article 235 and there being of Council Regulation (EC) No 2913/92", as currently contained in Article 8(4) of Regulation (EC) No 260/2009, replacing the reference "to Article 79 and therey of Regulation (EC) No 450/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council" in the consolidation proposal. Since the Consultative Group has also concluded by common accord that the proposal is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — With regard to Regulation (EC) No 260/2009, I particularly welcome the principle of freedom of importation of products originating in third countries, without prejudice to any safeguard measures or any products subject to a specific import regime. Since the resolution is limited to a mere codification of the 2009 regulation, without making any substantial changes, I voted in favour of the new text.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common rules for imports. This system was created in order to protect the single market from damage to the production system resulting from significant changes in trade flows such as, but not limited to, sudden and substantial import flows which do not allow European producers to reorganise production in order to counteract its impact. In view of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an "accelerated working method" for the official codification of legislative texts, the Advisory Group composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission met on 10 July 2014 to examine the proposal for a regulation in question presented by the Commission and approved it, verifying that the commission was merely codifying the existing texts. , without any substantial changes. For these reasons, I have decided to conform to the position of the Advisory Group.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — The common rules for imports were established by the Council Regulation of 22 December 1994, codified in 2009. They apply to imports of products originating in third countries, with the exception, on the one hand, of textiles subject to specific import arrangements, discussed under the heading of sectorial measures of the commercial policy, and, on the other, products originating from certain third countries, including Russia, North Korea and the Peopleʼs Republic of China. The proposal is a codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance. A reference to ʽArticle 235 et seq. of Council Regulation (EEC) No 2913/92ʼ, such as that currently appearing in Article 8(4) of Regulation (EC) No 260/2009, should be re-introduced to the text, so I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common rules applicable to imports. Any proposal for such codification is examined in advance by the legal services of the Commission, the Council and Parliament. The conclusions of this assessment are then sent to the Committee on Legal Affairs for validation and finally voted on in plenary for parliament's final approval.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the common regime applicable to imports from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament as it is a technical report which facilitates its codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to undertake a codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 260/2009 on the common rules for imports. The new Regulation will supersede the various acts incorporated in it; it fully preserves the content of the acts being codified and hence does no more than bring them together with only such formal amendments as are required by the codification exercise itself. This Regulation applies to imports of products originating in third countries. Due to the clear procedural nature of this exercise I voted in favour of it.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes the codification within European Union law of the Council's Regulation (EC) No. 260/2009 on the Common Import Regime, which was substantially amended in 2014. This text proposes to introduce the principle of freedom of import of products originating from third countries, subject to possible safeguard measures. I support this text as a simple exercise in codifying positive law without any change in substance. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. A regulation, changed several times, loses its intelligibility. That is why we have here wished to codify the regulation on the measures that the Union can take in relation to the combined effect of anti-dumping or countervailing measures and safeguard measures, without changing the substance of them. I supported this measure, which promotes the legibility of this text.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — While there are some positive points in this text, such as reasoned protectionism or safeguards and surveillance measures, this is a timid first step towards protecting our industries and production. Any brake on ultraliberalism and blind free trade should be encouraged, since it calls into question a system in which nation states no longer have freedom. Nevertheless, there are some weaknesses in this text. There is never any mention of the national level or at least the national freedom to promote domestic products. Considering that the nation-state is the only echelon capable of guaranteeing the economic functioning of a society, we cannot vote in favour of this text. So I decided to abstain. Leaving the possibility for the Union to protect European industries is not enough: it is essential to give Member States priority on these issues and to leave them free to carry out their national economic policies.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — We are voting against the codification of all the texts, because we are not given the opportunity to intervene in the substance of these provisions, which means that we must accept them as they stand.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — The objective of this proposal is to codified Council Regulation (EC) No 260/2009 of 26 February 2009 on the common import regime. The new Regulation will replace those that are the subject of the decoding operation. This proposal therefore adheres to the Commission's guidelines in which it instructed its services to codify all acts, at most after their tenth amendment, stressing that, for the sake of clarity and easy understanding of the provisions, they should seek to codify the texts on an even greater basis.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 260/2009 of 26 February 2009 on the common regime applicable to imports. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The proposal under discussion is based so simply on the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments. Thus, the new Regulation will replace the various acts integrated therein, fully preserving the content of the codified acts, introducing only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself. The codified Regulation lays down the principle of freedom of import of products originating in third countries, subject to any safeguard measures. This Regulation applies to imports into the EU of products originating in non-EU countries, with the exception of textile products subject to a specific import regime and products originating in non-EU countries subject to the specific common import regime of the countries themselves. This legislation is in line with the allocation of exclusive powers to the EU in the field of trade policy, depriving states of this important instrument of sovereignty. Trade policy is now defined not on the basis of the interests and needs of the smallest economies but, on the contrary, of the eu's main powers. This is a purely technical change and is justified. However, our disagreement with the basic act justified our abstention.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — Regulation (EC) No 260/2009 deals with the common rules applicable to imports. I will not support the regulation because the commercial aspects proposed and adopted are at the same time as the European Commission's policies.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting against the common import regime because we are not given the opportunity to intervene in the substance of these provisions and we must, by extension, accept them as they stand.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — I am in favour of the proposal as it is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — Mr President, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common rules for imports, seeing that this concerns a purely technical matter aiming at the consolidation of legislation to react to recent developments.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. "I abstained on this proposal.  The aim is to codify, without altering its substance, the common regime applicable to imports, particularly within the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO). However, we can only regret that quantitative and tariff quotas, allowed for certain products, are never used for the defence of French and European producers.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this as it is consolidation of legislation in line with recent developments.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on common import rules, as I believe that codification of rules that are often changed is necessary in order to make the law clear and transparent.  In this regard, I support an interinstitutional agreement allowing for an accelerated process for the swift adoption of codified acts. This ensures the certainty of rights and accessibility of the same to all citizens, which does not change in content.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. "I preferred to abstain on this text. It is not possible to ignore the contributions it contains: reasoned protectionism, safeguards and surveillance measures, etc. This is a timid first step towards protecting our industries and production, while promoting European products. Any impediment to ultraliberalism and indiscriminate free trade helps, in itself, to encourage, since it calls into question a system in which nation states no longer have a voice. Nevertheless, we cannot ignore the weaknesses of this text. Indeed, there is never any mention of the national level, or at least the national freedom to favour its products at the expense of imports. Considering that the nation-state is the only one able to guarantee the coherence and good economic functioning of its society, we cannot vote in favour of this text. Indeed, allowing the Union to protect its industry is not enough: it is essential to give Member States priority on these issues and to leave them free of their economic policies.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I support this report which proposes the codification of Regulation (EC) 260/2009 of the Council on the Common Import Regime, which was substantially amended in 2014. Without changing its substance, this report offers a clearer reading of the Codified European legislation.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Common rules for imports’, because we believe that the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing, valid legal texts, without any change in their substance. These rules will help to protect the interests of the Union and especially the interests of Union producers, users and consumers.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — The present request provides for an adjustment of the previous regulation under a single regulation, instead of distributing the regulation among different legal acts, as has been the case up to now. This case concerns Council Decision 260/2009, which has already been amended several times, so that codification was necessary with a view to improving legal and planning certainty. The act as such has not been amended and only formal amendments have been made. An effective and sustainable trade policy demands uniform standards, a desire that was no longer present in its current version. I therefore agree with the motion.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the report, as it is simply aiming at consolidation of legislation to react to recent developments.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I welcome this report because the aim of this proposal is to initiate the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 260/2009 of 19 October 2009 on the introduction of common rules applicable to imports. In fact, the regulation introduces the principle of freedom of importation of products originating in third countries, without prejudice to any safeguard measures. It shall apply to imports of products originating in third countries, with the exception of textile products and products originating in certain third countries listed in Council Regulation (EC) No 625/2009.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — The purpose of the Council's and the European Parliament's proposed regulation here is to codify The Council's Regulation (EC) No. 260/2009 establishing a common import regime. In substance, I am opposed to this type of text which facilitates free trade and delivers Member States and their economies to the mercy of savage globalisation. On the form, I note that it allows certain monitoring and safeguarding measures to be taken in the interests of producers, particularly in cases where massive imports are likely to cause serious injury.  However, Member States must be able to regain control of tariff and non-tariff quota jurisdiction when vital economic and agricultural sectors are directly threatened by unfair competition. As the current state of the legislation remains unclear, I voted against it.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. — The regime proposed in this report is part of the free trade economic system. It is impossible for us to put in place either quantitative or tariff barriers for certain products. We are therefore unable to protect our domestic productions, which would enable us to fight unfair competition. Abstention on this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to codified Council Regulation (EC) No 260/2009 of 26 February 2009 on the common import regime.  The proposal fully respects the content of the codified texts and therefore merely regroups them by making only the formal amendments that the coding operation itself requires.  The proposal for a Regulation lays down the principle of freedom for import products from third countries, subject to possible safeguard measures.  The main elements of the proposal for a Regulation are: (1) information and consultation procedure; (2) Union investigation procedure; (3) surveillance measures and (4) safeguards. The Commission should adopt safeguard measures requiring the interests of the Union. Whereas, according to the advisory group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without substantial changes, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The purpose of this proposal is to start the codification process of Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013; 260/200 as of 26 February 2009 establishing common rules for imports. The new Regulation brings together different acts that have not lost their substance and introduces only those formal amendments that require the codification process.  All CITIZENS of the European Union have the right to clear, simplified and accurate information about their legal obligations and rights, and the European Union has committed to sticking to the principle of transparency. I therefore supported this proposal to codify the Council Regulation with regard to common import measures.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Duda report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a common import regime, because the opinion of the Advisory Group on Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission finds that the proposal constitutes a simple codification of existing texts, without modifying their substance.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this regulation on common rules for imports, which follow the recommendations of the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — In favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation on common rules for imports. On the basis of its examination of the proposal, the Advisory Group therefore concluded by common accord that the proposal was limited to a mere codification of existing texts without any substantial changes.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of this proposal is to initiate the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 260/2009 of 19 October 2009 on the introduction of common rules applicable to imports. The regulation introduces the principle of freedom of importation of products originating in third countries. Since the proposal for a regulation by the rapporteur, Mr Duda, as confirmed by the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without making the same substantial changes, I have decided to welcome it. Codification of provisions that have undergone frequent changes over time is necessary if European legislation is to be fully in line with the principles of clarity and transparency.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — (DE) I was positive in favour of the proposal for a common import regime, as it is very important that the Member States should be informed of any risk arising from the development of imports. The import conditions, the development of imports and the various aspects of the economic and commercial situation, as well as any measures necessary, will be examined in the context of a common import regime.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections concerning a given subject for the purpose of simplification, clarity and transparency.  The aim here is to codify the texts relating to the common import regime. In particular, it is this regulation which provides that only the Commission can decide whether to put certain imports under surveillance. These undemocratic technocratic procedures prevent Europe from practising solidarity protectionism, which is the ecological and social emergency of our time. Opposed to the Commission's control over these matters, I vote against this technical report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — This report deals only with a technical issue, consisting of the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 260/2009 of 26 February 2009 on the common regime applicable to imports. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report regarding the common rules for imports because the consultative working party of the legal services of Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposed codification of the existing texts is straightforward and presents no change in their substance. It is crucial that agreements that have been amended on multiple occasions are codified in order to ensure that they are accessible and clear to citizens.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Community has concluded the agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and the European Union's trade policy should be based on uniform principles. I am voting in favour of this Regulation which safeguards the constant and relevant exchange of information between WTO exporting countries to the European Union and the European authorities with regard to hazards arising from the evolution of imports which may make it necessary to establish Union surveillance or to implement safeguard measures. I would also stress the importance of safeguard measures being provided for only for WTO member countries if the product concerned is imported into the Union in such high quantities and in such terms or conditions that they cause or threat to cause serious injury to Union producers of similar or directly competing products. I would also like to safeguard that textile products covered by Council Regulation (EC) No 517/94 are subject to specific treatment at Union and international level and should therefore be excluded from the scope of this Regulation.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The proposed regulation of the Council and the European Parliament is aimed here at the codification of Regulation (EC) No. 260/2009 of the Council of 19 October 2009 establishing a common regime applicable to imports. In substance, I am opposed to this type of text which facilitates free trade and delivers the Member States and their economies to the wild globalisation. On the form, I note that it allows certain monitoring and safeguarding measures to be taken in the interests of producers, particularly in cases where massive imports are likely to cause serious injury. However, Member States must be able to regain control of tariff and non-tariff quota jurisdiction when vital economic and agricultural sectors are directly threatened by unfair competition. As the current state of the legislation remains unclear, I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — Re-drafting to consolidate a number of changes since 2009 to Regulation 260/2009, which it repeals. In particular, takes account of the other files in this group being voted on, especially of the use of safeguard measures, included in Chapter V.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which codifies Regulation (EC) 260/2009 on the common import regime. This regulation has been amended several times and substantially, so that its provisions are now found on the one hand in the original act, on the other hand scattered in the amending acts that followed. In the interests of clarity and simplification of the law, guaranteeing greater legal certainty and better information for citizens, it was therefore necessary to codify this regulation. This process completely preserves its substance and merely brings together in a legible way the various changes that have been made to it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome this proposal for a regulation on common rules for imports, given that during its examination the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposal in question was limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without making any substantial changes to its content.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted for this report because the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the common regime applicable to imports. The report sets out the European Parliament's vision of the common regime applicable to imports and proposes regulations aimed at ensuring a more efficient common system.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that the Commission's proposal, adopted in an unchanged form by the Committee on Legal Affairs through this report, is a beneficial one for the Member States and for Romania, precisely because the changes proposed by the Commission do not make substantive changes to the original document, but only a number of changes in terms of codification. It is also very important to me that in the Advisory Working Group on the Legal Services of the three institutions, this document received a positive opinion.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — The proposal was intended to coordinate import conditions, the development of imports and some secondary aspects of the economic and trade situation among the Member States. I ultimately voted in favour of the proposal because I consider such coordination to be important in order to compete in international competition.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the draft on imports from third countries. Better information and research rules also enable the Commission to apply interim measures, thus better protecting the INTERESTS of the EU.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) Since the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — Council Regulation (EU) No 260/2009 on common import rules adopted in 2009 has been amended significantly. Back in 1987, the Commission established a rule that, after a dozen amendments to a particular act, it must be codified, thus contributing to greater certainty of the correct application of the act. The subject-matter of the basic text of the Regulation concerns imports from third countries to EU territory and the possibility to take measures that the EU can apply if a product is imported into the Union in significantly increased quantities and under such conditions or conditions that may cause or threatening to cause serious harm to the worker (such as importing inappropriately insured products that may cause injury to workers while handling these products), as well as directly competitive products (the threat to destroy domestic production at EU level).  I supported this proposal because codification of the Regulation in question and its subsequent amendments contributes to greater legal certainty of the application of the act, both to Member States and to stakeholders to which the Regulation has a legal effect.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — The purpose of the Council's and the European Parliament's proposed regulation here is to codify Regulation (EC) 260/2009 of the Council of 19 October 2009 establishing a common import regime. In substance, I am opposed to this type of text which facilitates free trade and delivers the Member States and their economies to the wild globalisation. On the form, I note that it allows certain monitoring and safeguarding measures to be taken in the interests of producers, particularly in cases where massive imports are likely to cause serious injury. However, Member States must be able to regain control of tariff and non-tariff quota jurisdiction when vital economic and agricultural sectors are directly threatened by unfair competition. As the current state of the legislation remains unclear, I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I sacrifice this report aimed at starting the codification process of Council Regulation (EC) No 1999/2013. 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 on the establishment of common rules for export. The new regulation provides for the pooling of different acts that do not lose substance or alter content.   This formal procedure enhances the transparency of the process and allows citizens to be fully informed through simplified rules about their rights and obligations when it comes to common import rules.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — Codification of frequently changing acts is essential in simplifying and explaining EUROPEAN Union law in order to make it clearer and more accessible to citizens and to give citizens the opportunity and opportunity to exercise their special rights given to them. The purpose of the proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013. 260/2009 as of 26 February 2009 on common import rules and the new regulation will replace the various acts incorporated therein, which contributes to transparetity and visibility.  Therefore, I support colleague Duda's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on common import rules, as the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has agreed that the proposal is indeed limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — Following the opinion of the Advisory Group on Legal Services of 17 September 2014, I decided to vote in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common rules applicable to imports, since this is a simple codification of existing texts without any substantial changes.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: in writing. — I see the common import rules primarily as safeguard measures designed to prevent possible critical situations, for example where certain products are imported in such increased quantities and under such conditions as to cause injury to the Union industry. A common trade policy of the European Union, supported by appropriate legislation, is necessary in this case. In the interests of clarity and transparency of Union law, I therefore welcome the implementation of the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 260/2009 on common import rules.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Through this recommendation, it is up to the European Parliament to vote in favour of codifying a text in the order of European Union law.  Thus, in the interests of clarity and transparency, it is necessary to increase the legibility of this right for our citizens. To the extent that there are no substantial changes, I am voting for it.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — At its meeting of 10 July 2014, the Advisory Group composed of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission reviewed the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council, which codifies Regulation (EEC) No 260/2009 of the Council of 26 February 2009 on the common regime applicable to imports. It then concluded, by common agreement, that the proposal under question should be based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive amendments. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — Since the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has given a positive opinion and considers that this proposal is limited to the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments to the texts, there is no reason to vote against or even to abstain.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — In order to simplify and clarity of EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of the codification of the Regulation on the common regime applicable to imports. The Regulation has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years and, in order to improve clarity and easy understanding of the legislative text, all these provisions should be recast into a new Regulation, respecting the content of the codified texts and making only the relevant formal amendments.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — Like other reports voted on in this plenary session, we are faced with yet another pure and simple codification of existing texts which do not entail changes in substance to them. This is a frequently used mechanism, which stems from an Interinstitutional Agreement concluded between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working method for the rapid adoption of codified acts. In this particular case, we are faced with the need to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 260/2009 of 26 February 2009 on the common regime applicable to imports.  In this sense, I voted in favour of this report, since it seeks to ensure greater certainty and certainty in european legislation.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which is part of the process of facilitating Community law initiated by the inter-institutional agreement of 20 December 1994; it is an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance. This is a legislative resolution on the proposed regulation on the common import regime. The proposed regulation establishes the principle of freedom of import of products originating in third countries, subject to possible safeguards. It would apply to imports of products from third countries, with the exception of certain textile products and products originating in certain third countries. The proposal also establishes certain procedural elements relating to information, consultation, investigation procedure, monitoring and safeguard measures.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to abstain because my views on trade with third countries are at the same time as the current policies of the European Commission.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I am in favour of the adoption of this text, which is limited to the outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the common regime applicable to imports by mistake; the meaning of my vote would be abstention for the same reasons as in the vote on the common export regime.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — I voted for a proposal to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 260/2009 as of 26 February 2009 on common import rules, thus achieving clear and transparent rights and thus making them more accessible to citizens.  Common rules for imports focus on the interests of Union producers, users and consumers. The purpose of this proposal is to codify the existing regulation in order to replace with the new ones the various acts enshrined in it, and all acts so far will be merged into one with only those formal amendments that are necessary for codification, and therefore I support it.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support having common rules for imports across the Member States so strongly support this.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The codification of texts should be an opportunity to re-evaluate their content in substance and not just by type.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the european Parliament and the Council's proposal for a regulation on the common import regime. I agree with the opinion of the advisory group that the proposal is limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. — I supported the report on the proposal for a Regulation between the European Parliament and the Council on common import rules, as this is about codifying existing texts without substantive changes with a view to establishing common rules for imports into the European Union on the basis of the principle of freedom of import. In my view, these rules oversee the implementation of measures necessary to protect its interests, thereby acting in accordance with the law, obligations and protection of the interests of european Union states at international level. I also consider that it is particularly positive to highlight the duty of member states to inform the Commission in the event that the supervisory needs of common import rules are met, as they will indicate the importance of import conditions and the economic and trade situation.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — It is regrettable that this regime proposed by this report is part of the principle of free trade imposed by the World Trade Organization. Proposals for quantitative limitations and the introduction of tariff barriers for certain products are unfortunately not applicable to our domestic productions, which would allow us to protect them from unfair competition.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. — There are frequent situations where a European legislative act has been amended over the years several times. This puts the European citizen in difficulty who will ultimately not be able to understand what is the essence of the legislative act and which of the existing amendments is the one in force.  The European Commission, with the right to initiate and propose legislative drafts, has always assumed and supported the need for simple and clear legislation so that any European citizen can understand the legislative act and make use of the specific rights conferred on him through it. Clarification of European legislative acts is done through a legislative procedure called codification of legislative acts. With a view to the rapid adoption of codified acts, the European institutions agreed in 1994 to use an accelerated procedure.  The legislative proposal which was the subject of the European Parliament's report concerns the codification of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. Council Regulation (EC) No 260/2009 of 26 February 2009 on the common arrangements applicable to imports. Given that the codification proposal retains the full content of the codified acts and makes only formal changes, the European Parliament, by the unanimous vote granted today, supports the proposal to codify the regulation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, one of the fifteen reports from the JURI committee to be voted on at this session. This is a technical amendment to update the legislative text for the sake of greater legal certainty.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the common regime applicable to imports from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament as it is a technical report which facilitates its codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Regulation 260/2009, codified, lays down the principle of freedom to import products originating in third countries, subject to any safeguard measures. This Regulation applies to imports into the EU of products originating in non-EU countries, with the exception of textile products subject to a specific import regime and products originating in non-EU countries subject to the specific common import regime of the countries themselves. The purpose of this report is to codify the Regulation on the common regime applicable to imports. The new Regulation will replace the various integrated acts, fully preserving the content of the codified acts.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - On the proposal for a common import regime, I voted in favour, as it is very important that the Member States should be informed of any risk arising from the development of imports. The import conditions, the development of imports and the various aspects of the economic and commercial situation, as well as any measures necessary, will be examined in the context of a common import regime.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this report is to codify the Regulation on the common regime applicable to imports. In 1987, the Commission decided to ask its services that all acts should be codified, no later than 10 amendments, in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier for the citizen to understand. The new regulation will replace the various acts integrated therein, fully preserving the content of the codified acts. Regulation No 260/2009, codified, establishes the principle of freedom of import of products originating in third countries, subject to any safeguard measures. This Regulation applies to imports into the EU of products originating in non-EU countries, with the exception of textile products subject to a specific import regime and products originating in non-EU countries subject to the specific common import regime of the countries themselves. In order to be able to use safeguard measures, a product must be imported into the EU in such high quantities and/or under such conditions as to cause or athreat to cause serious injury to EU producers. We didn't object.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. — UKIPʼs position is that the UK should be in charge of all issues relating to application of rules relating to imports. We are therefore voting against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the common export regime applicable to exports from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament as it is a technical report which facilitates its codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Louis Aliot (NI)
text: In writing. — On the basis of the principle of reciprocity, the Commission submits to a vote the codification of the regulation on the common export regime, after that relating to the common import regime, etc. In the same vein as on the text A8-0040/2014 from the same rapporteur, I abstained.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The proposal is a mere codification without any change in the content of the acts in question. Parliament and the Council must agree to this codification, and that is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
