text: In writing. "I abstained on this vote, in order to express a profound disagreement on part of the text. If we can praise a desire to mitigate the effects of the competitiveness gaps between States and thus to lessen those of unfair competition in social matters, I can only denounce the political content of this text. There are plans to give more power to the European institutions and in particular to the Commission with regard to national policies of financial aid to exports. This jurisdiction is, and must remain, only national and within the exclusive jurisdiction of sovereign states.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — If these matters were coming before Parliament for the first time, we would be voting against because these matters should be within the competence of the Member States. Therefore to vote against is consistent with our position.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this deliberation because it is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal on common export rules. The purpose of the proposal is to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — The fundamental principle of the proposed regulation stipulates that EU exports to third countries are not subject to quantitative restrictions. This principle implies that the 'common trade policy should be based on uniform principles', which is not without questioning national subsidies and policies for financial aid to exports. Considering that there is no question of allowing the Commission to take away this competence from the Member States in the name of 'harmonisation' of their export policies for all goods, I abstained.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. "This is the codification of existing texts without altering their substance.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal because the advisory group said that this is only the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 establishing a common regime applicable to exports, without substantial changes thereto.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The proposed regulation establishes the principle that exports to third countries are not subject to any quantitative restrictions. The aim is to harmonize the actions of states on exports for all goods.  The main issue is the issue of subsidies (which must be harmonized in order not to distort competition) and national policies of financial aid to exports. However, this competence should be the responsibility of each Member State rather than the Union, so I abstained.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) Despite the technical nature of the amendments to be voted on on the common import regime, I do not agree with the current policies of the EU Commission, so I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — In the interests of simplifying and clearing EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of the codification of Regulation No 625/2009 on the common export regime. The Regulation has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years and, in order to improve clarity and easy understanding of the legislative text, all these provisions should be recast into a new Regulation, respecting the content of the codified texts and making only the relevant formal amendments.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports the codification of the regulation on common export rules from third countries. The codification of legislation is needed to make it more comprehensible and accessible to citizens. This Regulation provides that exports from the Union to third countries are free of restriction, i.e. no quantitative restrictions have been imposed on them.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — The proposal is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes and I will therefore support it.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. The regulation, in recitals 4 and 5, states that "In all Member States, exports are almost entirely liberated. (...) accept, at EU level, the principle that exports to third countries are not subject to any quantitative restrictions, subject to the derogations provided by this Regulation and without prejudice to the measures that Member States can take in accordance with the Treaty. The Commission should be informed when, as a result of exceptional market developments, a Member State believes that safeguards may be needed." This text is therefore part of the harmonisation of the actions of export states for all goods. The main issue is the issue of subsidies (which must be harmonized in order not to distort competition) and national policies of financial aid to exports. I abstained on this text because it is a competence that belongs to every Member State, and the European Union must not interfere with national policies.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted yes because of the importance of common rules on imports if we want to complete the common market.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The objective of simplifying and clarity of European Union legislation aims to increase coherence and easy access for European citizens, while providing the opportunity to make use of certain legislative procedures. In this context, the common commercial policy is based on uniform principles that apply to the establishment of a common regime applicable to EU exports. Furthermore, this codification proposal was drawn up on the basis of a prior consolidation in 22 official languages of the text and the acts which amended it, carried out by means of a computer system. I welcome in this way the recommendations of the Advisory Working Group on Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on the common export regime.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — The reference is to Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 on common arrangements applicable to exports. In this case, the measure provides for a mere codification of the existing texts, but the political substance upstream is not acceptable. I abstained.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — Codification allows some texts of European legislation to be compiled on the same subject with the aim of simplifying them and making them more accessible. This report focuses on the codification of the common export regime. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — This proposal for a regulation aims to codify the provisions of Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 without making any formal or substantive amendments to the existing texts.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. — This report once again marks the European Union's desire to aspire one by one to the powers of the Member States.  Thus, the approach of harmonizing the export regime- which is apparently coherent - ignores national needs, notably involving a questioning of subsidies and national policies of financial aid to exports. However, it is the latter that make the commercial success of countries such as China, the United States or the BRICS. Because I wish my country the opportunity to pursue an ambitious industrial and trade policy, I abstained on this text.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — Having regard to the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working method for the official codification of legislative texts and having examined the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the codification of Regulation (EC) No Council Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 establishing common arrangements applicable to exports, the Advisory Group concluded by common accord that the proposal is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I strongly agree with the principle of freedom of export, according to which exports from the European Union to third countries are not subject to quantitative restrictions. The common system applicable to them has been governed by Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 and is a subject of enormous importance for the enhancement of our production, in particular with regard to "made in Italy". I therefore voted in favour of the common export regime, since the resolution is limited to a mere codification of the 2009 regulation, without making any substantial changes.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a common arrangements applicable to exports. Indeed, the EU's interests may require appropriate measures to be taken to prevent a critical situation due to a shortage of essential products, to remedy them or to fulfil the international commitments made by the EU or its Member States, in particular as regards trade in basic products.  Given that the proposed regulation does not prevent the adoption or application by EU countries of quantitative restrictions on exports, provided that they are justified on specific grounds, and given that the same proposal for a regulation has been approved by the Advisory Group composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, as it is limited to a mere codification of existing texts , without any substantial changes, I have decided to conform to the position of the Advisory Group.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — Council Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 establishing common rules for exports lays down the principle of freedom of export, stating that exports from the European Union (EU) to non-EU countries are free from quantitative restrictions. The proposal is a codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a common system applicable to exports. These kinds of reports concern proposals relating to the codification of EU law. It is a technical procedure provided for in Article 103 of the Regulation, which is intended to verify that the codification proposal is in fact limited to mere codification, without any substantial changes.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the common export regime applicable to exports from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament as it is a technical report which facilitates its codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to undertake a codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 establishing common rules for exports. The proposed Regulation establishes the basic principle according to which the exportation of products from the European Union to third countries shall be free, that is to say, they shall not be subject to any quantitative restriction, with the exception of those restrictions which are applied in conformity with the provisions of this Regulation. It should apply to all products, whether industrial or agricultural. Due to the clear procedural nature of this exercise, I voted in favour of it.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes the codification within European Union law of The Council's Regulation (EC) No. 1061/2009 establishing a common export regime, which was substantially amended in 2014. This text establishes the principle that exports to third countries are not subject to any quantitative restrictions, subject to the exemptions provided by the regulation and without prejudice to the measures that Member States can take in accordance with the European treaties. I support this text as a simple exercise in codifying positive law without any change in substance. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This text, which the European Parliament voted on, does not raise any particular obstacles. The codification proposal is part of a welcome improvement in the clarity and transparency of the law. It does not alter the substance in any way and is limited to a simple codification of existing texts.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. "I abstained on this vote, in order to express a profound disagreement on part of the text. Indeed, if we can praise a desire to mitigate the effects of the competitiveness gaps between States and thus to lessen those of social dumping, I can only denounce the political content of this text. There are plans to give more power to the European institutions and in particular to the Commission with regard to national policies of financial aid to exports. This jurisdiction is, and must remain, purely and exclusively national and within the exclusive jurisdiction of the sovereign peoples.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — We are voting against the codification of all the texts because we are not given the opportunity to intervene in the substance of these provisions and we must, by extension, accept them as they stand.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — Coding provides legal certainty with respect to the law applicable in a given area and time. Such codification must be carried out in full compliance with the procedure for the adoption of EU acts. This proposal, concerning the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009, 19 October 2009, establishing a common regime applicable to exports, respects the view that no substantive amendment can be introduced in the acts encoded, and is therefore part of the codification methods established by the Commission, which aim to determine the provisions in force that result following the numerous amendments to European legislation.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The aim of the proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 establishing a common export regime. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The proposal under discussion is based so simply on the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments. Thus, the new Regulation will replace the various acts integrated therein, fully preserving the content of the codified acts, introducing only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself. Regulation 1061/2009 establishes the principle of freedom of export, according to which EU exports to non-EU countries are free from quantitative restrictions. This legislation is in line with the allocation of exclusive powers to the EU in the field of trade policy, depriving states of this important instrument of sovereignty. Trade policy is now defined not on the basis of the interests and needs of the smallest economies but, on the contrary, of the eu's main powers. This is a purely technical change and is justified. However, our disagreement with the basic act justified our abstention.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 deals with the common arrangements applicable to exports. I will not support the regulation because the commercial aspects proposed and adopted are at the same time as the European Commission's policies.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting against the common import regime because we are not given the opportunity to intervene in the substance of these provisions and we must, by extension, accept them as they stand.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — I am in favour of the proposal as it is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common rules for exports, seeing that it is a purely technical measure aiming at consolidation of legislation to react to recent developments.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal because I believe that any decision to quantitatively restrict exports to third countries is a matter of sovereign law. The European Commission does not have to interfere in this decision. To take a concrete example, the French wood sector is experiencing serious difficulties due to the massive export of logs to third countries. Sawmills and various wood processors face supply difficulties as a result of these exports.  France should be able to limit the exports of its logs, without suffering from any intervention by the European Union. The latter has largely proved that it has not been aware of the economic difficulties of a particular sector and that it prefers to stick to the application of liberal dogmas, sacrificing the actors concerned if necessary.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this as it is consolidation of legislation in line with recent developments.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on common export rules formally codifying certain legislative texts.  It is through the codification process that it contributes to simplifying and explaining EUROPEAN Union law in the context of Citizens' Europe, so that the legal texts of the Union are as clear and transparent as possible. The scattering of provisions in various acts leads to the need for the swift adoption of codified acts so that the provisions are easy to understand. I also support the adoption of a first reading position based also on the recommendations of Parliament's legal services advisory group.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. "Contrary to what is often believed or said, abstention is not the absence of notice. In this case, I abstained on this vote, in order to express a profound disagreement on part of the text. Indeed, if we can praise a desire to reduce the gaps in competition between States, and thus to lessen the effects of social or economic dumping, it is our duty, members of the National Front, to denounce the political content of this text. For example, it plans to give even more power to the European institutions and in particular to the Commission with regard to national policies of financial aid to exports. This jurisdiction is, and must remain, purely and exclusively national, and the exclusive responsibility of the sovereign peoples. We know that national sovereignty is seen as an obstacle by the European Union, but we will never resolve to accept that. And that is why, once again, the National Front will not support this text and will defend the sovereignty of the French in France.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I supported this report, which is limited to codifying Regulation (EC) 1061/2009 of the Council establishing a common export regime. In doing so, EU law is clearer and more accessible to European citizens

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Common rules for exports’ because we believe that the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance. Through these rules the Union will exercise surveillance over certain exports and the protective measures will be introduced as a safeguard against unforeseen practices.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — Simplification and codification of individual areas of law is necessary in order to reduce bureaucracy and complexity and to give citizens a better understanding and access to the exercise of their rights at EU level. This legislation clearly and clearly summarises the complex and important legislation on the provisions of the common export regulations. These provisions have been changed in substance very often in the past and have been difficult to understand in some cases. The present simplification also puts an end to the dispersal via various acts, without changing the content or substance of the current legal situation. In order to improve access to EU law for the citizens of the Union and the export-oriented economy of Europe, I agree with the proposal that has been tabled.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the report as it is simply aiming at consolidation of legislation to react to recent developments.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of this report, which aims to initiate the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 on the establishment of a common arrangements applicable to exports. The Regulation introduces the principle that exports to third countries are not subject to any quantitative restrictions, without prejudice to the derogations provided for in this Regulation and the measures which Member States may take in accordance with the Treaty. As has already been pointed out in the other daily votes, I believe it is essential to simplify legislation and codify provisions that have been frequently amended, in order to operate with clear and transparent legislation.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — The regulation proposed here provides that exports to third countries will not be subject to any quantitative restrictions. The reason given is to harmonize the actions of states on exports for all goods. It should be noted that the fundamental problem remains and concerns firstly the issue of subsidies (which, too, must be harmonized so as not to create distorted and unfair competition) and secondly national policies of financial aid to exports. Here again the European Union interferes in the affairs of states and again tends to restrict the national sovereignty of the Member States. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. — States are refused to be able to take quantitative restrictions on exports that are subject to the principle of free trade. The aim of this text is to harmonize the practices of states, forcing them to follow the same rules. There is no possibility for Member States to take measures in full sovereignty. Abstention therefore for this text which does not allow Member States to decide on the financial aid they want to allocate to their exports.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — The codification of Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 establishing a common regime applicable to exports is an overriding necessity. Having incorporated a number of amendments into it over the last few years, its codification is aimed at ensuring the clarity and transparency of EU law. It should again be recalled that the content of the encoded texts remains respected, as the built-in modifications are limited to the needs of the coding process. Important elements of this Regulation include: (1) the EU information and consultation procedure, where by which States which, as a result of exceptional market developments, consider that protection measures may be necessary, shall inform the Commission, which in turn will decide and report on the measures taken to the other Member States and; (2) safeguard measures, the aim of which is to limit the free export (it becomes under the authorisation of the Commission) of basic necessities whose timely shortage may pose a problem for one or more EU States. I therefore vote in favour of this proposal for a Regulation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The purpose of this proposal is to start the codification process of Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013; 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 on the establishment of common rules for export. The new Regulation brings together different acts that have not lost their substance and introduces only those formal amendments that require the codification process.  All CITIZENS of the European Union have the right to clear, simplified and accurate information about their legal obligations and rights, and the European Union has committed to sticking to the principle of transparency. I therefore supported this proposal to codify the Council Regulation with regard to common export rules.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Duda report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a common export regime, because the opinion of the Advisory Group on Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission finds that the proposal constitutes a simple codification of existing texts, without modifying their substance.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this regulation for common rules for exports, which take up the recommendations of the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this proposal is to initiate the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 on the introduction of common arrangements applicable to exports. The regulation introduces the principle that exports to third countries must not be subject to any quantitative restrictions, except for exceptions. Since the proposal by the rapporteur, Mr Duda, is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without making the same substantial changes, I felt it appropriate to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — The proposal for a common export regime received my positive vote, since it is essential to examine export conditions, their development and the various aspects of the economic and commercial situation, as well as, where appropriate, the necessary measures in the context of a common export regime.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections concerning a given subject for the purpose of simplification, clarity and transparency.  The aim here is to codify the texts relating to the common export regime. In particular, it is this regulation that allows the Commission to introduce restrictions on certain exports. These undemocratic technocratic procedures prevent Europe from practising solidarity protectionism, which is the ecological and social emergency of our time.  I oppose the Commission's control in this matter and vote against this technical report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — This report deals only with a technical issue, consisting of the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 establishing a common export regime. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report regarding the common rules for exports because the consultative working party of the legal services of Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposed codification of the existing texts is straightforward and presents no change in their substance. It is crucial that agreements that have been amended on multiple occasions are codified in order to ensure that they are accessible and clear to citizens.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — As in imports, the European Union must also have a common policy of support and encouragement of international trade in exports. It is possible to establish, at Union level, the principle that exports to third countries are not subject to quantitative restrictions and should only be taken into account measures which may be taken by Member States in accordance with the Treaty. I am in favour of this Regulation which wishes to examine at European level the conditions under which member states' exports take place, their evolution, the various elements of the economic and commercial situation and, where appropriate, what measures are necessary to be implemented.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The regulation proposed here stipulates that exports to third countries will not be subject to any quantitative restrictions. The reason given is to harmonize the actions of states on exports for all goods.  It should be noted that the fundamental problem remains and concerns firstly the issue of subsidies (which also need to be harmonized so as not to create distorted and unfair competition) and secondly national policies of financial aid to exports. Here again the European Union interferes in the affairs of states and again tends to restrict the national sovereignty of the Member States. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — The measures being consolidated include a possibility for the Commission to require an export authorisation in the case where export may result in a shortage of essential products, or to undertake other appropriate measures to address the problem.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which codifies Regulation (EC) 1061/2009 establishing a common export regime. This regulation has been amended several times and substantially, so that its provisions are now found on the one hand in the original act, on the other hand scattered in the amending acts that followed. In the interests of clarity and simplification of the law, guaranteeing greater legal certainty and better information for citizens, it was therefore necessary to codify this regulation. This process completely preserves its substance and merely brings together in a legible way the various changes that have been made to it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome this proposal for a regulation on a common system applicable to exports, given that during its examination the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without making any substantial changes to its content.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted for this report because the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the common regime applicable to exports. The report sets out the European Parliament's vision of the common export regime and proposes regulations to ensure a more efficient common system.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I supported this report today because it, in turn, supports the Commission's proposal on the common export regime. This regime is beneficial to all Member States, including Romania, and the fact that the document proposed by the Commission does not bring about substantive changes that jeopardise the stability of economies is a good thing; instead, makes changes in terms of coding. It is also very important to me that in the Advisory Working Group on the Legal Services of the three institutions, this document received a positive opinion.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal because I consider the coordination of export arrangements to be an important counterpart to the coordination of import regimes. The joint coordination of imports and exports only makes the common European internal market a global force.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the draft because the new regulation will remove quantitative restrictions on exports to third countries, thereby promoting trade and the economy.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) Since the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — Council Regulation (EU) No 1061/2009 on common export rules was adopted in 2009. The basic text has been changed significantly on several occasions. Back in 1987, the Commission established a rule that, after a dozen amendments to a particular act, it must be codified, thus contributing to greater certainty of the correct application of the act. The basic Regulation on common export rules establishes, inter alia, a fundamental principle that exports of products from the European Union to third countries must be free, meaning that they must not be subject to any quantitative restriction, except those restrictions applicable in accordance with the provisions of that Regulation. This rule applies to all products both industrial and agricultural.  It is an act that has great significance in regulating trade between the EU (including Croatia) and third countries. Due to the need for its correct application both between countries and stakeholders to which this Regulation has a legal effect, I consider the proposed codification necessary because it contributes to greater legal certainty of the application of the act. It was precisely because of the interest of Croatian farmers that I supported this proposal.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — The regulation proposed here provides that exports to third countries will not be subject to any quantitative restrictions. The reason given is to harmonize the actions of states on exports for all goods.  It should be noted that the fundamental problem remains and concerns firstly the issue of subsidies (which also need to be harmonized so as not to create distorted and unfair competition) and, secondly, national policies of financial aid to exports. Here again the European Union interferes in the affairs of states and again tends to restrict the national sovereignty of the Member States. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support this report aimed at starting the codification process for Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013; 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 on the establishment of common rules for export. The new regulation provides for the pooling of different acts that do not lose substance or alter content.   This formal procedure increases the transparency of the process and allows citizens to be fully informed through simplified rules about their rights and obligations when it comes to common rules for export.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — One of the transparency measures of the work of the Commission and other institutions of the European Union is the simplification and explanation of EUROPEAN Union law to make it clearer and more accessible to citizens. In order to achieve this objective, i.e. if the law has to be clear and transparent, the process of codification of frequently changing rules is essential.  The purpose of the proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013. 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 on the establishment of common rules for export. The new regulation will replace various scattered acts, which certainly contributes to transparency and transparency. Therefore, I support MEP Andrzej Duda's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on common export rules, since, according to the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament and the Council, the proposal is indeed limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) This proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the common arrangements applicable to exports is also a mere codification of the existing texts, without major changes, and from this, also with reference to the opinion of 18 September 2014 of the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council, I voted in favour.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: in writing. — A common commercial policy is also an important part of the concept of the common market. Common export rules are governed by the principle of free exports by default, which states that exports from the European Union (EU) to non-EU countries are not subject to any quantitative restrictions. However, as a result of unusual market developments, the EU may have to take protective measures to avoid any critical situation arising from the shortage of basic products in order to remedy such a situation or to fulfil international commitments made by the EU or all EU countries, in particular in the field of trade in basic products. In this case, it is necessary to codify the common rules.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Through this recommendation, it is up to the European Parliament to vote in favour of codifying a text in the order of European Union law. Thus, in the interests of clarity and transparency, it is necessary to increase the legibility of this right for our citizens. To the extent that this codification does not require any substantial changes, I vote for

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — At its meeting of 10 July 2014, the Advisory Group composed of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission reviewed the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council, by which Regulation (EEC) No 1061/2009 of the Council of 19 October 2009 is codified, establishing a common regime applicable to exports. It then concluded, by common agreement, that the proposal under question should be based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive amendments. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — Since the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has given a positive opinion and considers that this proposal is limited to the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments to the texts, there is no reason to vote against or even to abstain.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — In order to simplify and clarity of EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of the codification of Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 on the common export regime. The Regulation has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years and, in order to improve clarity and easy understanding of the legislative text, all these provisions should be recast into a new Regulation, respecting the content of the codified texts and making only the relevant formal amendments.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — In order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed. This is the case with this proposal, which deals with the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009, which establishes a common regime for exports. Like other reports voted on in this plenary session, this is a proposal which is based on the pure and simple codification of existing texts and which does not entail significant amendments, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which is part of the process of facilitating Community law initiated by the inter-institutional agreement of 20 December 1994; it is an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance. The resolution rules on a regulation that establishes the principle that exports to third countries are not subject to any quantitative restrictions, subject to exemptions under the regulation and without prejudice to the measures that Member States can take in accordance with the treaty. It also sets out measures on the Commission's information and consultation procedure as well as safeguard measures.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I abstained because I do not agree with the European Commission's trade policies.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I am in favour of the adoption of this text, which is limited to the outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I abstained in this report on the common export regime from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament, because I am not entirely convinced that the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, is the best option. Indeed, I am not convinced that the procedure does not end up affecting the content of the text at some point.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — The purpose of the proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013; 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 on the establishment of common rules for export. The new regulation will replace the various acts incorporated therein and be merged into a single act with only the formal amendments necessary for codification.  The Common Trade Policy should be based on uniform principles. In the interests of clarity and rationality, this Regulation needs to be codified and I therefore support this proposal.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of these rules because I believe the Commission should ensure a proper authorisation of exports, or other appropriate measures, in cases where a shortage of essential products may occur.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support this report because codification of common export rules is essential for the convenience of them as they are scattered in various provisions and frequently changed. As the acts do not change substantively, the 1994 interinstitutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission may apply an accelerated procedure.  The aim is to achieve clarity and rationality through uniform principles. Exports are largely liberalised and quantitative limits are rarely set. A Member State may nevertheless report to the Commission if it considers that safeguards are necessary due to certain market changes. In this sense, it is important to monitor export trends, the state of the economy and trade, and to adopt safeguards on equal terms.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The codification of texts should be an opportunity to re-evaluate their content in substance and not just by type.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the european Parliament and the Council's proposal for a regulation on the common export regime. As a reminder, when considering the european Parliament and The Council's proposed regulation to codify the Council's regulation of a common export regime, the group agreed that the proposal is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. — I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation between the European Parliament and the Council on common export rules, as it is codifying existing texts without substantive changes. Since I believe that the Common Trade Policy should be based on uniform principles, including in terms of exports, I find this codification extremely useful. I believe that the importance of common export measures is outlined, inter alia, in the contribution to the provisions and conditions of exports, export developments, different aspects of the situation in the economy and trade and the protection of industrial and trade ownership. That is why I believe that joint export measures will help establish more successful international cooperation between member states and reduce violations of international law, as well as other activities that may harm Member States.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — There is a refusal to quantitatively limit exports that are subject to the principle of free trade. The aim of this text is to harmonize the practices of states. There is no possibility for the Member States to take restrictive measures in full sovereignty. Abstention therefore for this text which does not allow Member States to decide on the financial aid they want to allocate to their exports.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. — There are frequent situations where a European legislative act has been amended over the years several times. This puts the European citizen in difficulty who will ultimately not be able to understand what is the essence of the legislative act and which of the existing amendments is the one in force. The European Commission, with the right to initiate and propose legislative drafts, has always assumed and supported the need for simple and clear legislation so that any European citizen can understand the legislative act and make use of the specific rights conferred on him through it. Clarification of European legislative acts is done through a legislative procedure called codification of legislative acts. With a view to the rapid adoption of codified acts, the European institutions agreed in 1994 to use an accelerated procedure. The legislative proposal which was the subject of the European Parliament's report concerns the codification of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. Council Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009 of 19 October 2009 on the establishment of a common system applicable to exports(6). Given that the codification proposal retains the full content of the codified acts and makes only formal changes, the European Parliament, by the unanimous vote granted today, supports the proposal to codify the regulation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, one of the fifteen reports from the JURI committee to be voted on at this session. This is a technical amendment to update the legislative text for the sake of greater legal certainty.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the common export regime applicable to exports from the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament as it is a technical report which facilitates its codification. I have therefore supported the proposal for Parliament to take a single-vote decision in this case, without amendment or debate, as it is a procedure which is not linked to the content of the text, but to formal measures to simplify its treatment, since, if these texts are not codified, the different amended versions of it remain, making it difficult to access.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Under Regulation (EC) No 1061/2009, EU countries may adopt protective measures if they consider them necessary as a result of exceptional market developments. To protect the EU's interests, appropriate measures, such as quantitative export restrictions, may be necessary to avoid or resum a critical situation resulting from shortages of essential products and to implement the international commitments made by the EU or all EU countries, in particular with regard to trade in basic products. The proposal under discussion is based only on the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive changes, fully preserving the content of the codified acts and introducing only the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - The proposal for a common export regime received my positive vote, as it is essential to examine export conditions, their development and the various aspects of the economic and commercial situation, as well as, where appropriate, the necessary measures in the context of a common export regime.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The proposal under discussion, which deals with the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the common regime applicable to exports, is only based on the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments. In 1987, the Commission decided to ask its services that all acts should be codified, no later than 10 amendments, in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier for the citizen to understand.  Regulation EC No 1061/2009 at issue establishes the principle of freedom of export, according to which EU exports to non-EU countries are free from quantitative restrictions. At the same time, the protective measures that may be necessary shall be adopted by the Council acting by a qualified majority on a proposal from the Commission. The latter may also take such measures when immediate action is required. This was just about systematising existing legislation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, we voted in favour of all these reports as they allow for the accession of a number of countries to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. These need to be welcomed as it will help extend the legal framework to countries that are not presently covered by the Hague Convention. In real terms this will provide a pragmatic solution where a child has been abducted and taken to another country without the consent of the parents.  Furthermore, the overarching principle of these reports provides that the welfare of the child should be the first and foremost consideration in childcare proceedings, which is something we all should ensure is paramount at all times.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR). -
text: Mr President, one of the arguments that is often put in my country, as in others, about participation in the EU is that we need to be present at the top tables. But, as we see with international regulations of this kind, the top tables are no longer in Europe. We are talking here about conventions on child abduction, but the same is true about internet regulation, about food standards and so on. The top tables are international; they are global. And what happens as a result of EU membership is that the European Commission takes over representation from the Member States. So whereas Norway and Switzerland and New Zealand and other countries sit independently around those global tables we are represented by somebody else, along with 27 other member governments. In other words, we make a net loss of collective influence and the reason that we cannot see it is because we still fondly imagine that the whole world is focused in Europe. Well guys, take a look at what is happening in the world economy. This is not the centre anymore.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI). -
text: Mr President, I fully agree with what the previous speaker said. In essence, this convention on the international abduction of children is intended to manage jurisdictional conflicts and conflicts of laws that sometimes arise from the separation of couples. Basically, it is excellent, but what is the European Union doing in this? This convention is open in the Hague scheme, that is, open to ratification by all the world's states. Would the Member States no longer have diplomatic service? Would they no longer have a foreign ministry? Are they not able to ratify these texts on their own? What is the legal basis for today's intervention by our Parliament? This is an opinion of the Court of Justice, which I consider to be perfectly abusive and which achieves an extremely important and serious constitutional novation in our eyes.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Gabon's accession report to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Gabon's accession to that Convention.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the accession of Gabon to the Hague Convention, as this proposal will assist authorities in returning wrongfully removed children, and will help to address issues of conflict of laws (competence of courts). In real terms, it will provide a pragmatic solution where a child has been abducted and taken to another country without the consent of one of the parents. Furthermore, the overarching principle of the proposal is that the welfare of the child – something that should always be paramount – should be the first and foremost consideration in child care proceedings. That is why it was necessary to support this proposal.

name: Gerolf Annemans (NI)
text: Written. — The accession of a number of countries to the Hague Convention is to be welcomed. The abduction of one or more children abroad is a traumatic and dramatic event that must be dealt with as quickly as possible in the interests of the children. The question, however, is what will be worth the signature or the word of some acceding countries. For example, a Belgian ex-minister points out the manifest reluctance of the Moroccan authorities in cases of parental abductions. Moreover, it is problematic that the EU is now applying exclusive external jurisdiction in this matter. This means that Member States are in danger of being criticised by the EU if they do take bilateral initiative themselves. While the ultimate goal should be, in any way: to find a quick solution for the children.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an important legal instrument for the protection of children. The aim of this agreement is to avoid international child abductions by increasing cooperation between States parties. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. Gabon's accession to this agreement is to be welcomed. This will extend this sensible legal framework to other countries. This ensures that the best interests of the child are paramount.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Gabon must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I cannot vote in favour: this is a field in which the EU should not have exclusive competence. Under normal circumstances I would abstain.  The assessment of these statesʼ abilities to fully comply with provisions is important for child safety. These countries will be trusted by us to a great extent. The Commission has not undertaken this kind of assessment. The UK Government believes there are ʽserious risks in returning children to a third country that does not respect rule of law or basic legal procedures in family casesʼ. I therefore voted against as this measure has not been properly thought through.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution because it protects children of Gabonese nationals staying on European Union soil from possible illegal abductions.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to accede gabon to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. of 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases and has been ratified by all EU Member States. Often such problems arise when a couple of different nationalities divorce. A lack of cooperation between states is often used to secure custody of a child. The media is full of reports of international child abduction in divorce. The purpose of the Convention is to address these problems at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the State in which the child lives. The Convention also provides for a system to ensure that the abducted child is returned immediately. Gabon's accession to the Convention is a positive thing to ensure that these children are protected.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on International Child Abduction aims to manage jurisdictional disputes and conflicts of laws that usually arise from separations of couples. These are, of course, very sensitive situations and states cannot be over-encouraged in this area. Having said that, I voted against this text, which presents a major problem: the European Union is not a state, so its legal capacity to become a party to the Hague Convention is highly questionable. This prerogative is reserved for states by public international law, and I refuse to vote on a text that implicitly calls it into question. Moreover, the report explains in the explanatory statement that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states".  Thus, the approval of Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of child abduction cannot be within the competence of the European Union.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 is a very important instrument that allows the contracting parties to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. It sets up a system to expedite the return of the abducted child to the country where he or she usually resides. Through the Council's decision, the Member States each accept Gabon's accession to the Convention and therefore the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the European Union and that country.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal because it will solve the problems that are often suffered when couples from different States separate and dispute the custody of their children, even reaching the abduction of them. This Convention will resolve situations at the international level and, more importantly, minors will be protected from illegal abduction. I thank Gabon for joining the Hague Convention.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. Generally, this situation arises when a couple divorces or separates. The statement of reasons for the report thus tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Gabon must not fall within the European scope, so I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction provides for cooperation between signatory States to ensure that a child or child under 16 who has been arbitrarily "abducted" by a parent returns to the place of family residence pending a judicial ruling, unless the return foretoos a serious danger to his or her safety. I believe it is of fundamental importance for the protection of our children that this Convention be ratified and respected by more and more States. I therefore voted to support Gabon's accession among the new signatory countries.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction, and therefore the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome Gabon's accession to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Gabonese community will be protected against illegal abduction.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports gabon's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases. Gabon's accession to the Convention is important because a significant number of EU citizens come from Gabon. So children with relatives in the Gabonese citizens' community will be protected from abduction.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — This document relates to the cooperation of states in the event of a child abduction of an international character. Namely, if parents come from different countries, it often happens that in the event of a disconnect or divorce, they try to exploit legal loopholes and the absence of clearly defined cooperation between countries in order to unlawfully appropriate the child.  The Hague Convention therefore seeks to establish clear international practices in such cases. The betterment of the child is being put to the forefront, and that is why I support the report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of Gabon to the Hague Convention, as this proposal will assist authorities in returning wrongfully removed children, and will help to address issues of conflict of laws (competence of courts). In real terms, it will provide a pragmatic solution where a child has been abducted and taken to another country without the consent of one of the parents. Furthermore, the overarching principle of the proposal is that the welfare of the child – something that should always be paramount – should be the first and foremost consideration in child care proceedings. That is why it was necessary to support this proposal.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted yes because it is fundamental to have Gabon’s adhesion to this Convention in order to protect children in Africa.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. Generally, this situation arises when a couple divorces or separates. The statement of reasons for the report thus tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I formally challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects relating to child abduction. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interest of the European Union, of Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.      Gabon deposited the instrument of accession to the 1980 Convention on 6 December 2010 and the Convention entered into force on 1 March 2011. The Convention, which has so far been ratified by 86 countries, including all EU Member States, is a measure of cooperation in international law.   The Convention merely provides a proportionality relationship which must necessarily exist between the interests of the person and that of society in order to enforce respect for the right of immediate return of the unlawfully displaced or detained child, in agreement with that of respect for family life. Measures to ensure the safety of children are welcome, and citizens can now be protected from the dangers posed by the abuse to which children are subjected.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The Hague Convention is a good thing and the protection of minors must be extended as far as possible to other states that wish to be part of it.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction was established in 1980. All MEMBER States of the European Union are signatories to this convention. This private international law law imposes a uniform legal basis in the event of a child being abducted by one of his parents during a binational separation. Sometimes a parent abducts his child and receives legal custody in his or her home state. The other parent is then required to comply with this decision because of a lack of legal homogeneity between the two states in which the parents are nationals. Such situations must no longer occur. We must ensure that children's rights are applied equally around the world. I voted in favour of Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of Gabon to the Hague Convention, as this proposal will assist authorities in returning wrongfully removed children, and will help to address issues of conflict of laws (competence of courts). In real terms, it will provide a pragmatic solution where a child has been abducted and taken to another country without the consent of one of the parents. Furthermore, the overarching principle of the proposal is that the welfare of the child – something that should always be paramount – should be the first and foremost consideration in child care proceedings. That is why it was necessary to support this proposal.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Some States exploit the lack of cooperation between national authorities in order to obtain custody of minors where there is proceedings pending between two spouses from different countries. Accession to the Hague Convention establishes jurisdiction in the State in which the child resides, limiting disputes over jurisdiction and thus speeding up proceedings. That is why we are voting in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. —I refused to sign in favour of this report for a simple reason: an international convention is a legal standard that must be signed by sovereign states.  The European Union does not have this legal status and its legitimacy is therefore questionable, with regard to its legal capacity to become a party to the Hague Convention. It is clear, however, that child abductions are a very serious issue and therefore states continue to work actively together to prevent these tragedies and take responsibility for the civil aspects they take on.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention is a fundamental instrument for ensuring the return of children unlawfully transferred or detained abroad by a parent and for ensuring respect for custody and visiting rights in all States. My country, Italy, was the only country to support, even before the Court intervened, the Exclusive Competence of the Union in this field, instead of full regulatory and operational coordination between States, instead of approaches aimed at protecting the parent, who is a citizen, also to the detriment of the interests of the child and the rights of citizens of other countries. I believe that, for the proper application of the Convention, the Member States will have to comply with certain requirements: efficient central authorities that can really set themselves as a reference for administrative cooperation; rules preventing discriminatory practices; guarantees of access to justice and, in general, full alignment with the principles of the rule of law. Having said that, I welcome Gabon's accession and, for this reason, I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance which has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. It enables the Contracting States effectively to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international abduction of children. The problem arises in couples who separate, where spouses are of different nationalities, because there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states. In the various States there are legal systems which tend to seek to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality, leaving the right of custody of dubious interpretation. In order to deal with these situations at international level, the Convention places the child at the centre of the problem by establishing that the court of jurisdiction is the court where the child resides. In view of all this, Gabon's accession to the Convention is to be welcomed, given also the favourable opinion of the rapporteur, who fully supports the measure. Children with links to the Gabonese community will thus find protection against abduction at EU level. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 because it is an extremely important instrument, which has already been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. As the Convention introduces a system that allows contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction, Gabon's accession to the Convention is to be welcomed as many EU citizens originate from it. Children with links to the Gabonese community will thus find protection against abduction.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument. It has been ratified by all the EU Member States. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In many instances, these problems arise when a couple has separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those states in order to secure custody of the child. The biggest problem in such cases is the differences between the legal systems of individual states. It may often be that the courts in both of the states concerned declare themselves competent, with each of them awarding custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at an international level.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a key instrument in the context of judicial cooperation between contracting States in the resolution of cases of international child abduction. This Convention seeks to harmonise the legal systems other than those states which normally declare themselves both competent to adjudicate the action and declare custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent, and the criterion of the State of residence of the minor is adopted with the Convention. As this matter currently is the exclusive external competence of the Union, a Council decision is necessary which call for the Member States to accept the access of third countries to the Hague Convention. I support the Hautala report in this regard and congratulate the State of Gabon on its convention, thereby taking a step towards protecting its minors from abduction.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States of Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. In an international scenario in which the mobility of families across national borders is increasing, the phenomenon of the abduction of children is particularly important in the event of couples' crises. Protecting the child from illegal transfer or non-return is a global problem as well as a key element of the EU programme. Article 24 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union states that minors have the right to protection and the interest of them "must be considered pre-e. I therefore support the accession of the Gabonese Republic, because it is only through international cooperation that it is possible to settle the relevant issues of custody of minors and ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. Children with links to the Gabon community can thus be better protected from any danger of abduction.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — We often hear of child abductions taking place in Member States, especially when parents and family members originate from different countries. When this happens within Member States, that child is already protected by legislation, but it is important to protect children also when abducted to non-EU countries. The accession of more countries to the Hague Convention is welcomed as it extends the network of protection for children. The Hague Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In cases where a couple has separated and the parents are from different States, lack of cooperation between these States can create a situation which is not in the best interests of the child involved.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) According to the Convention, it is decided by the vote whether to accept the accession by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction has now been ratified by 86 countries, including all EU Member States. The aim of the Convention is to restore the status quo through the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred or detained through a system of cooperation between the authorities designated by the Contracting Parties. Voting in favour is an obligation to guarantee the rights of all children.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Gabon's accession report to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Gabon's accession to that Convention.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which encourages EU Member States to accept the accession of Gabon to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction. This would allow the Convention to enter into force between Gabon and the EU and thus help to ensure the prompt return of abducted children.  The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction governs cooperation among the contracting states to settle international child abduction cases, including a system to ensure the immediate return of abducted children to their country of habitual residence, so as to allow the judicial authorities of that country to solve the case. All EU Member States have ratified the Convention.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes to support the European Parliament for the accession of the Gabonese Republic to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This international agreement, ratified by all EU Member States, aims to establish a system of cooperation in the context of international child abductions, most often intervening in cases of separation or divorce of binational couples.  In the event of a referral to the courts of the two States concerned, they may declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the State under its jurisdiction. This convention therefore specifies the jurisdiction of national courts and guarantees a system allowing the immediate return of the abducted child. It is necessary for this international regime to be as broad as possible, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Gabonese origin on its soil. In this way, children linked to this community will be protected from illegal abduction. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, ratified by all EU Member States, aims to protect children from international abduction by providing for a procedure for their rapid return. Through the vote on this text, the aim is to invite the Council of the European Union to ask the Member States to accept Gabon's accession. The extension of the territorial scope of the convention in Gabon is a positive sign in the direction of greater protection of children.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
