text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction, because in this way minors with links to the Gabonese community will find greater protection against this phenomenon. This Convention allows cooperation between the Contracting States in order to find solutions to cases of international abduction of children. This problem arises when spouses from different States, as a result of their separation, exploit the lack of cooperation between the States concerned in order to obtain custody of the children. The aim of this Convention is to settle such situations at international level by establishing that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Gabon must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. — Dear Colleagues, I voted in favour of colleague Hautala's report on Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, because I believe that statistics on the increased number of abductions in itself speak to the urgent need for cooperation.  According to the data currently available, in 2008 the number of applications for return of children submitted only within the EU on the basis of the 1980 Hague Convention was 990. That means 35% more than in 2003. Unfortunately, the rise in crimes against children is also high. I cannot help but note that it is the kidnapping that is the first step for trafficking in human beings and exploitation for criminal purposes.  I welcome Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention and call on all Members under this international instrument to take measures to ensure its practical application.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention aims to ensure the immediate return of children who have been moved or unlawfully detained in one of the Contracting States and to ensure that custody and communication rights under the law of one of the Contracting States are respected in the other Contracting States.  This Convention creates the infrastructure and communication channels between 92 states to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to arrange custody issues if parents live in different countries.      We are voting in favour of the accession of other states to the Hague Convention, as it protects children who fall victim to disagreements between their parents. The Convention ensures cooperation between States to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — International child abduction is an extremely important issue. There are many children who are immersed in situations of these characteristics year after year. Globalization has led to a growing increase in children with parents of different nationality. And this has led to an increase in child abductions. We must act diligently.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention provides the private international law framework for recovery of abducted children. Its aim is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to safeguard the prompt return of the child and the mutual enforcement of judgments regarding custody and access rights. The vote refers to the acceptance of Gabon, which has joined the Convention in recent years. This agreement will benefit children and families in Wales so I voted in favour.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome this Proposal from the Council to accept Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention. The issue of defending the rights of the child is of central importance and it therefore seems very positive to include more and more states, especially given that there are a large number of people from countries that are now applying for membership on European soil, which will facilitate the resolution of cases of abduction between a Member State and these third countries. However, while it is good that all the States of the European Union have acceded to the Convention, I cannot help noticing that the concept of 'good of the child' is often interpreted instrumentally. I am thinking, for example, of Germany, whose children's office, the Jugendamt, actuallyes the good of the child for the good of the German child, depriving the non-German parent and the child himself of many fundamental rights, including some of the founding rights of the Hague Convention. Unfortunately, the problem is not confined to Germany alone, and Europe is powerless to witness these abuses, since it does not have the power to intervene in the family law of the individual Member States. That is why I believe that there is an urgent need for harmonisation of legislation in this area.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart. As parents come from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those same States to obtain custody of minors. In these cases, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of the countries concerned to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Convention aims to remedy such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. I voted in favour of gabon's acceptance of the Hague Convention in the best interests of minors who have links to the Gabonese community and who will thus be protected from abduction.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart, and the Convention resolves these types of situations on an international scale, by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the state of residence of the minor. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I am voting against this text because by becoming part of the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction, the European Union is also giving itself a space for interpretation of this text. Let us not be fooled, for under the good intentions of defending the interests of children nothing is done - for example - against the expansion of the barbaric practice of surrogacy within the Union. On the other hand, it is up to the Member States to determine sovereignly who may or may not join the Convention, I challenge, once again, this transfer of competence.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The child abduction situation occurs with some frequency when a couple, with members from different States, is reunited. Not accompanying some of the considerations made during this debate concerning the legal systems of each State, it is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Convention aims to address this type of situation at international level. It is its objective to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the rights of custody and visitation existing in a Contracting State. These are fair and relevant objectives. Gabon deposited the instrument of access to the Convention.  The EU now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the EU. However, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise the participation of international organisations such as the EU. For this reason, the Council had to take a successive decision in order to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seichelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I am pleased that Gabon is adjoining the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, and that is why I voted in favour of the report. The Convention provides effective means of settling disputes arising from international abductions of minors as a result of separation or divorce, by establishing that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — The subject of international child abduction largely concerns spouses or couples in which individuals from different countries of the world choose to abuse the situation and wrongly adopt a child after divorce or break-up. Such situations are helped by the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Children often become a means of dealing with accounts between spouses or former partners with different citizenships. Consequently, the national courts, often outside the European Union, often grant custody rights to the parent who is a citizen of the state to which that court is competent, thanks to certain national tendencies. The Convention resolves such situations in such a way that the assignment of the child is decided by the court in the State where he or she resides, regardless of where one of the parents was brought. The EU now has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice. This means that Member States are no longer acting at their discretion. It is therefore necessary to adopt a Council Decision requiring Member States to accept the accession of Gabon to the Convention in their own territory and thus the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that State. The adoption of the convention in question will provide increased protection for children associated in any way with the Gabonese community.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the accession of other States to the Hague Convention, as it protects children who become victims of disagreements between their parents. The Convention ensures that the children return to their normal residence in the event of abduction.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — I strongly support the adoption of stronger cooperative measures to prevent cases of international child abduction. Greater coordination between states is necessary to avoid the temptation, by one of the parents, to secure custody of a child following a separation or a divorce. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 makes it possible to resolve, at an international level, those cases in which the courts of both of the states concerned declare themselves competent and award custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. Moreover the Convention introduces a system which ensures the immediate return of abducted children. I welcome the accession of Gabon to The Hague Convention. Considering the number of EU citizens of Gabonese origin, this accession is vital to ensure EU-wide protection of the children in question.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. — International law, including EU legislation, is based on the fact that the most vulnerable members of society, children, can enjoy the most effective protection in all circumstances. One of the means of doing so is the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of the abduction of children, ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention establishes a system of international cooperation between the contracting States to resolve cases involving the abduction of children abroad. In most cases, the problem is the divorce of parents of different nationality who are exploiting the lack of international cooperation to obtain custody of children. The biggest problem in these cases is the different legal frameworks of the different States. The purpose of the Convention is to provide redress and redress in such cases. It is therefore essential that as many States as possible can join this Convention.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. — For the institutions of the European Union, the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an instrument of crucial importance that has been ratified by all EU Member States. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, a problem which we unfortunately face very often and which entails great suffering for the parties involved. The objective of the Convention is to resolve this issue at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. Similarly, the Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. Therefore, once the Decision has been analysed, as well as the case-law of the Court of Justice of the EU, I have decided to vote in favour with the desire to promote Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution. Gabon has ratified the Convention, but its acceptance by all EU Member States is necessary for its implementation between that country and the European Union. To the extent that it is an exclusive competence of the EU, the report refers to the Council Decision by asking Member States about its acceptance, and that is why I have supported it.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour and fully support Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, so that minors with links to the Gabon community can also benefit from EU protection measures in the event of separation or dispute between their parents. The Convention is in fact an instrument of guarantee for children of extraordinary effectiveness, in that it intervenes to bring back to the center of conflicts of couples in crisis of different nationalities the rights of minors applicable in their state of residence, overcoming the temptation of preferential management between the individual countries of origin of the parents and the dramatic risk of international abduction of minors. Europe, the guarantor of human rights, is widening the mesh of measures to protect minors in all the countries that so request, thus preventing unjust national legal favouritism and unholy parenting of child fragility.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction includes 93 countries, including all EU countries. I therefore welcomed the inclusion of Gabon. The vote received more than 90% support, which shows the importance of the situation regardless of political views.  The Convention is an essential instrument for ensuring respect for the rights of a child who has been kidnapped by one of his parents. Child abduction is a crime, a violation of human rights, guaranteed by m.in Charter of Fundamental Rights. Every year in the European Union, there are an average of 3000 child abductions between Community countries, kidnappings without the consent of the other parent. In the Committee on Petitions, of which I am a member, we receive many reports of child abdument. These cases are among the most emotional. This shows how significant and frequent this problem is.  The accession of new countries to the Convention is good news, which in the future will result in more efficient investigations into the kidnapping of children.  Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her good work.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Hautala report because The Hague Convention of 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an essential instrument for protecting children belonging to parents from different states that exploit potential conflicts of competence between their national courts in order to secure custody of their child.  I therefore call on all EU Member States to formally accept the accession of Gabon to the Convention, seeing that this is a crucial step to ensure effective implementation and enhanced international cooperation to protect children who fall victim to international abduction. I do urge the Commission to continuously monitor whether the necessary infrastructure is in place to ensure Gabon is in a position to fully implement the Convention.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the accession of Gabon, as well as of other countries, to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction in order to extend cooperation between states as far as possible and to guarantee maximum protection for children who are victims of disputes between parents. All too often the trauma of separation is compounded by the trauma of abduction and removal from one of the parents.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. —I voted against this proposal on Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention.  This convention is certainly very useful in the management of jurisdictional disputes in cases of child abductions, most often as a result of divorces. Nevertheless, I question the legitimacy of the European Union to intervene in the ratification of this convention between the Member States and other States.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as I believe the accession of Gabon to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (the Convention), which seeks to protect children from abduction across international boundaries, is to be welcomed. It is important that countries acceding to the Convention can participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention. Effective measures now need to be put into place to ensure the rights of the child and that cooperation is fully practicable.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention on civil aspects of the abduction of children is a very important legal instrument. All The Member States of the European Union are parties. The Convention provides a system of cooperation for Contracting States to find solutions to cases of child abduction abroad. These problems most often occur in parents who are divering. In order to obtain childcare, a spouse from another State may take advantage of the lack of cooperation between States. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. Often, the courts of both States concerned consider the case to be within their competence and award the right to custody to a parent of their own nationality. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. I therefore consider it of the utmost importance that all states that have not yet done so should accede to the Convention.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. The Convention aims to protect children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council decision on a statement by which Member States in the interest of the European Union accept Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction in 1980, as the protection and promotion of children's rights is one of the Union's priorities.  This includes preventive measures to prevent child abduction and cooperation at international level. I believe that coordinated measures are needed to return the abducted children to their country of residence. I therefore believe that such cases should be regulated by the applicable law of the country in which the children reside, and that it is certainly necessary to condemn and warn of such actions.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Gabon must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This file suggested that Parliament approve the Council proposal to allow Gabon to access the UN Convention that regulates civil aspects on child abduction, mostly concerning cooperation of authorities in case of return of wrongfully-removed children and issues of conflict of laws. As the prevention of child abduction is, since the Brussels Regulations on Matrimonial Matters and Parental Responsibility, an exclusive competence of the EU policy to promote the rights of the child, the EU is the actor at international level to improve the application of the 1980 Convention and to encourage third states to accede to it. Article 38(4) of the 1980 Convention stipulates that the Convention applies between the acceding country and such contracting states as will have declared their acceptance of the accession. Therefore, the EU has to decide whether or not to accept the accession of a country. When affirmative, Member States should make the declaration of acceptance concerning the accession in the interest of the EU, because, as the Convention dates from 1980, it does not recognize international organisations such as the EU as an accessing party. EH Bildu has voted in favour, as the primary matter is broadening the application of the UN Convention on child abduction.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the Council's proposal for a decision on Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes mechanisms for cooperation between contracting states to remedy jurisdictional conflicts, particularly when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Accession of Gabon to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction’ because the EU has exclusive external competence in this field, but the problem is that the Convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organisations. Therefore, the accession of Gabon to the Convention and the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the EU and that country is necessary, especially as many EU citizens are of Gabonese origin. Children with links to the Gabonese community will thus be safeguarded against abduction and protection will be afforded to the children in question.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — One of the European Union's special priorities is to protect children and strengthen children's rights, as set out in Article 3 of the Treaty on European Union. The prevention of child abduction is an important measure in the context of child protection. The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction of 25 October 1980, as a multilateral agreement, forms the basis for the immediate repatriation of children abducted abroad or children detained abroad. In the meantime, 86 countries have signed up to this convention, but the validity of the law required official permission from the EU, even if individual countries have already implemented it. That is why I support the request to include Gabon in the Hague Convention.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR)
text: in writing. — On behalf of the Conservative MEPs in the European Parliament and as Conservative spokesman for Legal Affairs, I voted in favour of this report, as the 1980 Hague Convention is an effective tool in the resolution of international child abduction cases and extending its application to more countries, as long as they fully comply with the obligations under the convention, would enhance the legal certainty for those involved in such disputes. However, I strongly support the assessments which many Member States currently undertake in order to carefully assess any third country’s ability to implement the Convention properly before accepting its accession. These assessments prevent any potential risks which may arise from returning children to a third country which does not respect the rule of law or basic legal procedures in family law cases or does not have a competent authority which could verify a child’s well-being. I therefore support calls for the Commission to urgently produce such assessments for these countries, which it is yet to produce.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — In order for the Convention to apply between Gabon and the EU, the acceptance of all Member States is required. I supported giving the acceptance, as the Convention is an important international instrument, which seeks to protect children from the harmful effects of abduction and retention across international boundaries by providing a procedure to bring about their prompt return.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. — International abduction of children as a result of separation or divorce is a reality which unfortunately occurs with a habitual frequency. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. International cooperation is essential for the resolution of these disputes. Hence my full support for this resolution. Gabon's accession to the Convention and, consequently, the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases concerning the European Union and that country is to be welcomed. It is our moral and political duty to ensure that Gabonese children enjoy protection at European level.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mrs Hautala's report because it will guarantee minors with links to the Gabonese community adequate protection against international abduction. The protection of fundamental human rights, especially when we talk about vulnerable sections of the population, such as children, is of prime importance and must see our political efforts concentrated. In this respect, the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction of 25 October 1980 is a major instrument in the field of international abduction.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Gabon must not fall within the European scope. That is why I abstained.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution. The following eight countries have ratified the Convention, but its acceptance by all EU Member States is necessary for its implementation between them and the European Union. The countries are Singapore, Russia, Albania, Andorra, Seychelles, Gabon, Armenia and Morocco. To the extent that this is a positive step in the international protection of children, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Gabon's accession report to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Gabon's accession to that Convention.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — I consider that the civil aspects of international child abduction referred to in the 1980 Hague Convention, ratified by all EU Member States, should be adopted at international level. This Convention helps to cooperate between States in the face of the different difficulties that may appear in the area of international child abduction. Such accession will promote the elimination of potential difficulties a resulting from differences between the legal systems of nations. I believe that the entry into force of the EU-Gabon Convention should be given the importance of the protection of minors in such conflicts and the large number of people of Gabonese origin in the EU.   I therefore vote in favour of Gabon's proposal for accession to that Convention.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention addresses the problem of cross-border child abuse. These are cases where one parent from a mixed marriage kidnaps a child abroad without the consent of the other parent. States which have acceded to this Convention undertake to take into account the environment in which the child grew up and is no stranger to them and to cooperate in the return of the child. It is therefore in the interest of parents and children that as many states as possible accede to this Convention and that the admissible of children abroad can be resolved with the most nationalities. I am in support of other states joining if the existing states agree.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction is an important instrument ratified by all Member States of the European Union. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between states aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. It is often the case that parents of a child live separately in different countries, so the biggest problem is the national bias of the legal systems of individual states. Courts in both countries may enter their claims as competent and each of the parents who are their nationals may be granted custody of the child. The purpose of the Convention is to deal with such situations at international level, so as to establish that the competent courts and applicable laws are only from the state that is the place of residence of the child.  The Convention also implements a system that ensures the automatic return of children abducted. The European Union now has exclusive jurisdiction in this area as confirmed by the European Court of Justice. I support the Council Decision, which calls on Member States to accept gabonese accession to the Convention, as this is in the interest of the European Union, will contribute to the coherence and uniformity of the application of EU law.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing — I welcome Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention. Children who are somehow connected to the Gabonese community will be protected from kidnapping in this way. Any initiative to expand the number of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction must be supported. This will increase the protection of children from abduction in the territory of the Contracting States and can thus help to return the child to their natural environment more quickly. It is therefore necessary to look for the most effective ways of dealing with international child abduction in order to protect them and strengthen their rights.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Hautala report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on The Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because this Convention adequately addresses at international level the problem of child abduction and, therefore, , is an important legal and political development.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I welcome this report. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument. It has been ratified by all the EU Member States. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. The accession of Gabon to the Convention means that children with links to the Gabonese community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — Favourable to the report on the proposal for a Council Decision on Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on aspects of international child abduction. The aim of the Convention is to introduce a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. The Convention introduces a system to ensure the immediate return of the child who has been abducted.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — The intention of the Hague Convention is to help settle complex situations with regard to the international abduction of children. In view of the fact that a large proportion of EU citizens come from Gabon, I welcome gabon's accession to the Convention. It will help to ensure that children with links to the Gabonese community are adequately protected in the event of international abductions.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — I was positive about gabon's accession, as this Convention establishes a system of cooperation between the Contracting States in order to resolve the cases of international child abduction.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — I welcome Gabon's accession to the international convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. It aims to reduce legal conflicts between different national jurisdictions in cases of difficult separations of binational couples. In this legal procedure, however, the Commission has once again undermined the sovereignty of Member States by seeking recognition of these accessions on behalf of the Union, even though the Convention does not recognise international organisations (such as the Union) as a signatory party. But I vote FOR the protection of children across borders.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — With Gabon's membership of the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, the EU takes another step towards achieving one of its priorities, which is the protection and promotion of the rights of the child. Thus, children of Gabonese origin residing in the EU are protected with regard to abductions.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction aids in establishing the relevant jurisdiction to award custody of the child in question. The EU now has exclusive external competence in facilitating cooperation between contracting states to settle cases of international child abduction but requires each state to accept the accession of new signatories in their own territory. Therefore, I support each Member State’s acceptance of the extension to the Convention as it would ensure the protection of the child’s best interests in cases involving Gabon.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament today voted in favour of the Council's decision to accept Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. In the face of cross-border parental abductions, this convention allows States Parties to overcome differences and inconsistencies between their legal frameworks in order to cooperate with each other in the best interests of the child. In this regard, I would like to commend the work of the European Parliament's Ombudsman for children who are victims of cross-border parental abduction. Now occupied by Irish MEP Mairead McGuinness, this role aims to help parents find solutions aimed primarily at preserving the well-being of the child. In view of the increase in cases of cross-border parental abductions within the Union, The work of Mairead McGuinness is important and demonstrates the European Parliament's commitment to the service of citizens.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction was ratified by all Member States of the Union, with a total of 86 signatory States. This Convention seeks to protect the child, at international level, from the effects of a change of domicile or unlawful retention and to establish the forms to ensure the immediate return of the child to the State of his habitual residence, as well as to ensure the protection of the right of access. Most of the time, the problem arises when separated parents with different nationalities try to ensure custody of their children, making use of the lack of cooperation between the competent authorities, in this case the courts. Generally, the courts of both States complain that they are the only competent authority to clarify these situations. This Convention, for its part, will establish that the competent authorities and laws to be applied are those of the State where the child resides. Because of the importance of this Convention in the protection of children, I am voting in favour of Gabon's support.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Gabon must not fall within the European scope. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — It is important to get as many countries on board as possible. The accession will allow those countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which approves Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects related to the abduction of children on an international scale. This convention is a major instrument in the fight against the illegal detention and displacement of children that occur as a result of family conflicts. In practical terms, it provides for cooperation mechanisms to resolve jurisdictional disputes between jurisdictions in the event of a binational separation. It also guarantees a return system in case of abduction. The larger the number of States parties to this convention, the greater the international guarantee of children's rights.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We believe that the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all EU Member States, in that it introduces a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. The aim is to avoid situations of uncertainty or dangerous legal loopholes. It is stipulates, in fact, that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the State of residence of the child. While the European Union has exclusive external competence in this area (as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13), i.e. individual Member States no longer have the opportunity to act individually by referring to their own legal systems, the problem remains that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organisations. In order to overcome this legal difficulty, the Council has decided that it will be up to the individual Member States to accept, each in relation to its own territory, the accession of new States to the Convention. We therefore welcome Albania's accession to this Convention, so as to ensure that children with links to the Gabonese community can find protection against abduction at EU level.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because Gabon's accession to the Convention is a news to be welcomed, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Gabonese origin on its soil. In this way, children connected to this community will be protected from abduction.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. — However technical these reports may be, they highlight an increasingly topical situation. All statistics show that marriages are falling apart more and more frequently around the world. And the direct consequence of this is the bullying of children. Of course, the accession of these countries to the Hague Convention is to be welcomed, since the most important thing in such cases is that the child is placed in a stable, loving environment as soon as possible.  As Europeans, committed to our fundamental values, including children's rights, these accessions can also be seen as a reminder that it is always in the best interests of the child in our law and practice.  I therefore urge us to at least go beyond the standards of the international convention in relations between EU Member States. We minimise the administrative burden associated with the procedure, make sure that the language requirements cannot be used for stalling, and ensure that a quick and prudent procedure is carried out.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this report, together with all the other documents on the agenda, relating to the acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the EU, of Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. The report refers to situations in which children are placed following divorce or separation of parents, conditions in which they may be abducted, and questions the custody of the child of one of the parents, as well as the establishment of the courts competent to deal with the case.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: scríofa. — Chaith mise vóta i bhfabhar aontachas na Gabúine le Coinbhinsiún Apastaile na Háige mar go gcabhróidh an togra seo leis na húdaráis na páistí sin a tugadh chun siúil go héagórach a thabhairt ar ais. Cabhróidh an togra seo le gnéithe atá bainteach le coinbhleacht dlí chomh maith.  Cuirfidh sé seo réiteach pragmatach ar fáil i gcásanna inar tógadh páistí ó thír amháin go tír eile gan cead faighte, ar a laghad, ó cheann amháin de na tuismitheoirí. Mar aon leis sin, is é an príomhphrionsabal den togra seo ná chun a chinntiú gurb é leas an pháiste an rud is tábhachtaí in aon imeacht dlíthiúil. Creidim gur chóir dó seo a bheith mar thosaíocht i gcónaí. Sin an fáth go raibh sé tábhachtach domsa mo thacaíocht a thabhairt don togra seo.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — Child abductions are associated with considerable emotional suffering for those affected. An important countermeasure here is international standards of protection and contractual agreements. In this respect, I welcomed and voted in favour of the proposal to join Gabon to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because the Hague Convention on child abduction is a crucial piece of legislation. The accession of each new State to the Convention on this issue contributes to international child abduction cases and excludes biased justice. The protection of children's rights must take up a very important role in international relations and justice.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance. The Convention introduces a system which allows contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. In the event that spouses come from different States, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between the States concerned in order to obtain custody of children, and there is often a tendency for the legal systems of individual States to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality. The intention of the Convention is to deal with these situations at international level, and many CITIZENS of the European Union originate in Gabon and children with links to the Gabonese community will thus find protection against abduction. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — International child abduction is synonymous with international parental abductions, however legally, international child abduction originates in private international law, relating to the illegal removal of children from their home by an acquaintance or family member to a foreign country.  In this context, "illegality" originates from "violations of custodial rights", and "home" is defined as the child's regular residence. As he implies, "violation of custodial rights" is a phenomenon of international child abduction that generally involves illegal alienation, which creates conflicts of jurisdiction of laws, multiple bodies and jurisdictions. They can come up with seemingly reasonable but also competing custody decisions with geographically restricted application. Such a result often negatively affects a child's approach and relationship with half their family and can cause the loss of their former language, culture, name and nationality, which violates numerous children's rights, and can also cause serious psychological and emotional trauma to the child and family.  The harmful consequences of such treatment for children and families have been demonstrated in several studies, and international child abduction has been marked as a form of parental alienation and child abuse. By joining the 1980 Gabon Convention, it is possible to protect children in case of adverse developments in their parents' personal relationships.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Gabon is by no means within the European scope. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support the gabonese accession report to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction in 1980. Although Gabon has ratified the Convention, its application to EU member states requires the consent of all Member States.  I believe it is in the interest of all of us that problems that can be caused by the non-compliance of legal systems, if the parents of the child come from two different countries, are adequately regulated. Children's rights must come first, and as children have borne the brunt of legal unregulatedness, I would like to express my full support for this report once again and call on all EU member states to do the same as soon as possible.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. —Every year, eight million children disappear in the world, which would mean that nearly 22,000 children disappear every day. All our efforts should be directed towards ensuring a better future for our children, and so this Convention, signed by all members of the European Union, should ensure a secure future and the realisation of all children's rights.  As the report states, the most common problem is agreeing on the court's jurisdiction to allocate care to children whose parents are from different countries, as well as the lack of communication between the two countries. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such cases in predetermined competent courts and to use the prescribed laws.  Countries that approach it are entering a common system of tackling child abduction. If the legal systems differ too much and the country does not have the means to form a body that will implement the laws and proposals of this Convention, the country cannot even access it.  This is precisely the problem that Gabon's approach to the Hague Convention is taking place so slowly. Gabon submitted the application form to the Convention on 6 December 2010 and entered into force on 1 March 2011. In order to resolve the cases of kidnapped children of Gabon and the European Union, I support this report for accepting accession to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction from 1980.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention is an instrument of the utmost importance because it allows the Contracting States to cooperate in order to find a solution in cases of international abduction of children. The European Union has exclusive external competence in this area, which means that the Member States cannot act on their own. However, the Convention does not establish the autonomous action of international organisations, and that is why the Member States of the Union must accept, each for their own territory, that third countries, in this case Gabon, should join the Convention, so that the Convention can fully apply in cases between the EU and a third country. I am therefore delighted that Gabon is joining the Convention because, thanks to this accession, the children of the Gabonese people will be able to find greater protection against the abductions to which they may be subjected.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — With this text, the European Parliament must assess the appropriateness of the recognition by European Union law of Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. Thus, the European Union and its 28 Member States are united and apply this convention uniformly when such a dispute with Gabon arises. It is important to solve such problems because they are family dramas that occur when parents find themselves confronted with Kafkaesque judicial systems. I am therefore in favour of anything that can improve the dialogue and resolution of family problems between judicial systems.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction, which occur very often following divorces and separations of parents from different States. More specifically, the Convention, seeking to counter the nationalist tendency of the legal systems of each State, provides that these cases must be tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the state of residence of the minor and also provides for a system ensuring the immediate return of the abducted minor. Although this is currently a matter of the EU's exclusive external competence, the fact is that the Convention does not provide for independent intervention by international organisations. To this extent and in order to ensure the protection of minors who have links with the Gabonese community, member states need to accept gabon's support. This proposal for a Council decision rightly calls for such acceptance. I voted in favour.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention, dated 25 October 1980, is an important instrument with regard to the civil aspects of international child abduction. The fact that it is a system of cooperation between the different States makes it easier to find solutions to a problem that persists in our day. Strengthening legislative systems must be an imperative and Gabon's amendment to the Hague Convention must be viewed with great satisfaction.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome Gabon's accession to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Gabonese community will be protected against illegal abduction.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This often occurs when a couple separates. For a husband or wife from another country, it may be tempting to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between states to obtain custody of the children. The major problem remains the differences between the legal systems of the Member States. In such cases, the courts of the two states concerned often declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the state under its jurisdiction. The convention in question therefore aims to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. I welcome the fact that Libreville is joining today.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — Also in the case of this report, we are dealing with a proposal to resolve conflicts of territorial jurisdiction over the international abduction of children, allowing Member States to accept Gabon's acceptance of the 1980 Hague Convention. Since the assumptions are equivalent to those already mentioned for other Contracting States, I consider it essential that Member States accept their support, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report which approves Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction, which all EU Member States have ratified. This convention strengthens cooperation between states, addresses the problem of differences between legal systems that arises and thus establishes the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state where the child resides.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because it is a question of strengthening and extending an important instrument for the protection of children's rights.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) With Mrs Hautala's report we have voted in favour of a text which is very important for the protection of children, who are weak in our society. It is important to be able to guarantee them the best possible safeguard, and with Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention we are moving in this direction.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Gabon's accession.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text which allows Gabon to join the Hague Convention on International Child Abductions. This multilateral treaty protects children abducted outside their usual place of residence. Since the opinion of the Court of Justice on 14 October 2014, the European Union has exclusive jurisdiction over the acceptance of a new state to the convention.  These abductions, which are increasingly common in the divorces of binational couples, give rise to dramatic situations that require a rapid response from the authorities. Membership of the Convention will facilitate cooperation between the European and Gabonese judicial authorities to organise the rapid return of abducted children, so that the competent local judge can make a decision on who is responsible for the custody of the child.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Gabon's accession report to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Gabon's accession to that Convention.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of Gabon to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The accession of Gabon to the Convention is to be welcomed.  Many EU citizens are of Gabonese origin. Children with links to the Gabonese community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing - It is very important that the provisions of this Convention preventing and prior international child abduction are also applied in other countries that have not yet been bound by them or have only acceded to the Convention. I therefore voted in favour. It should be stressed that, even in these very difficult family-legal situations, often with a strong geopolitical context, when national courts tend to rule biased, it is always and at all costs necessary to take into account the rights, well-being and dignity of children. A child cannot be abused in any way and cause him emotional, psychological or physical suffering. Even in a situation where an adult is trying to claim the so-called 'right to a child'. A child is no business item that can be disposed of as an object or a tool for blackmailing another, as unfortunately often happens in these cases. The best interests of the child must always come first and everywhere.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — I support Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction, as this ensures timely and comprehensive protection of vulnerable children. The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction is an important instrument ratified by 86 countries to date, including all members of the European Union.  Abduction problems often arise when parents divorce, especially if the mother and father are from different countries. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these cases internationally, by establishing competent courts and appropriate laws. Proposals for the accession of third countries to the Convention have no effect on the budget of the European Union, and preventing child abduction forms an essential part of EU policy in promoting children's rights. Accordingly, the European Union actively encourages third countries to join the Convention, and I support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support Gabon’s accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. International co-operation is vital in ensuring the protection of the rights of children.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - Prevention of child abduction is an essential part of the European Union's policy for promoting the rights of the child. Therefore, EU activity at international level is also very important, in order to improve the application of the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction since 25 October 1980.  The Convention thus introduces a system of cooperation between states accessing the contract aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction in the event of divorce of parents from different countries. The problem, in turn, is created in a part where the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organisations and therefore requires a Council decision calling on Member States to accept, each in relation to their territory, the accession of Gabon to the Convention and thus the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the EU and that country.  It is desirable that the gabon accession acceptance report enters into force following the formation of a Central Authority assisting EU citizens in this case. In my view, the accession of Gabon to the Convention is very welcome, as many EU citizens are of Gabonese descent and in this way children associated with the Gabonese community will be insured against abduction. It is therefore proposed to adopt this proposal by Parliament without amendments, in order to ensure comprehensive protection of the European Union when it comes to children.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. — The accession to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction in principle is acceptable, and the extension of these international rules to Gabon is to be welcomed. There remains a slight concern that Gabon will need further assessment in order to confirm their full compliance with their obligations; however, this has been raised by the Member States in the Council. As the European Parliament does not have a formal role in this process and is only being asked for consent and as the measure is positive in extending the reach of an international standard in difficult situations, I can support this vote.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The accession of more and more States to the Hague Convention develops the appropriate infrastructures and channels of communication between those States to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to deal with custody issues if parents live in different countries. Cooperation between several states to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction is also promoted.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. — Gabon's accession to the Hague Convention is a necessary step to ensure that Member States parties to the Convention can take as broad a action as possible against the abduction of children abroad. I support this proposal, because the protection of children is of paramount importance in all circumstances and all possible legal instruments must be used.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. "I voted for the convention in question. The aim is to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. The Union now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area under the 1/13 opinion of the Court of Justice. Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. The problem is that the convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem necessities the Council's decision requiring Member States to accept, each on its own territory, Gabon's accession to the Convention and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the European Union and that country. Gabon's accession to the Convention is news to be welcomed; I fully agree with it, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Gabonese origin on its soil. In this way, children linked to this community will be protected from illegal abduction. This is a protection granted to children and will be extended to the whole of the Union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a crucial legal instrument to fight against child abduction. This is the reason why I voted in favour of this report. Protecting the rights and interests of children must be one of the priorities of the EU and by supporting the accession of this country to the Hague Convention we reinforce the legal framework to ensure these key principles.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — The European Union does not have the legal capacity to impose anything in this area under the 1980 Hague Convention. The justification for Gabon's accession to this convention, which is supposed to be in the interests of the European Union, is therefore not valid.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the eight reports accepting the accession of Armenia, Morocco, Singapore, Albania, Russia, Seychelles, Andorra and Gabon to the 1980 Hague Convention. This Convention lays down the framework of private international law for the recovery of abducted children. Its objective is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to ensure the rights of the child, and mutual respect for custody sentences.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. — 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important document. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases. Gabon's accession to the Convention is good news, especially since many EU citizens come from Gabon. So children with relatives in the Gabonese citizens' community will be protected from abduction.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Gabon's accession report to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Gabon's accession to that Convention.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This Convention is essentially intended to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held in any Contracting State and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The following countries have deposited the instrument of membership of the Convention: Albania, Andorra, Armenia, Gabon, Morocco, Singapore, Seychelles, Russia. The European Union now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the European Union. However, although Member States no longer have such competence, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise participation in international organisations such as the European Union. The Council therefore took a successive decision to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of Gabon's accession, as this Convention establishes a system of cooperation between the Contracting States in order to resolve the cases of international child abduction.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — I welcome Parliament's approval of the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of consent of the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (HKÜ). The HKÜ is an almost exemplary solution under international law and an example of fruitful international cooperation for the protection of children. Nothing is worse for a child than a break-up of his parents' relationship. To make matters worse, parents sometimes start a dispute over the child, which is always at the expense of the child. Rarely, but unfortunately still far too often, a parent reacts with child abduction in order to create facts and, for selfish reasons, avoid a custody dispute. The HKÜ provides a sustainable framework to prevent and counteract cross-border child abductions. This cannot in principle prevent the damage done to the child, but it at least offers the possibility of returning the child to his or her usual environment.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of the Convention in question is to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The child abduction situation occurs very often when a couple of people secede, and when the parents come from different states. According to the rapporteur, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the state they represent. The Purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's state of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. Gabon has deposited the instrument of access and we have spoken in favour, as this Agreement is in line with the defence of the interests of minors.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, I referred to this in my previous speech, and I will not speak on all these votes, but just to clarify for the benefit of Members who have indicated their opposition: nobody is suggesting that today’s votes are going to solve all the problems in relation to child abduction. What we are saying – those of us who voted in favour of these resolutions – is that this is an important aspect in terms of international law. We have to ensure that what measures can be put in place, through international cooperation to ensure the safety of children, will be put in place. That is why we supported these resolutions.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I have made my point about all of these Hautala speeches, I do not need any more explanations of votes. It would have been nice to have done so without the interruption of a discourteous member of the French National Front.

name: Presidente. -
text: Thank you. Unfortunately, I have to give you the floor because it appears that you have asked for it.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI). -
text: Mr President, I did not quite understand what Mr Hannan said. Does he want to deprive me of the floor? Is he embarrassed by the fact that I agree with him? I don't know and I won't make him kind enough to look for more. In any case, this case is absolutely staggering. The international status of the Andorra valleys has been established for about nine centuries. It is a co-principality between the Bishop of Urgell, on the Catalan side, and the President of the French Republic, who succeeds our kings of Navarre, themselves heirs of the Counts of Foix. They are represented by their viguier. Until now, in accordance with custom, it was the French co-rince who ensured the international representation of Andorra.
