This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. But the major problem remains the differences between the legal systems of individual Member States. In this case, it is often the case that the courts of the two States concerned declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the state under its jurisdiction.  The hague Convention is therefore intended to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. I welcome the fact that Andorra now adheres to it.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — We are once again dealing with a proposal to resolve conflicts of territorial jurisdiction over the international abduction of children, in the present case, Andorra's 1980 Hague Convention. Since the assumptions are equivalent to those already mentioned for other Contracting States and Andorra being a principality located between northern Spain and the south of France, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report which approves Andorra's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction, which all EU Member States have ratified.  This convention strengthens cooperation between states, addresses the problem of differences between legal systems that arises and thus establishes the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state where the child resides.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because I believe it is essential to promote the protection of children's rights.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made it necessary for the Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept Andorra's accession, each with regard to its territory.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text which allows Andorra to join the Hague Convention on International Child Abductions. This multilateral treaty protects children abducted outside their usual place of residence. Since the opinion of the Court of Justice on 14 October 2014, the European Union has exclusive jurisdiction over the acceptance of a new state to the convention.  These abductions, which are increasingly common in the divorces of binational couples, give rise to dramatic situations that require a rapid response from the authorities. Membership of the Convention will facilitate cooperation between the European and Andorran judicial authorities to organise the rapid return of abducted children, so that the competent local judge can make a decision on who is responsible for the custody of the child.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Andorra's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Andorra's accession to that Convention.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of Andorra to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The accession of Gabon to the Convention is to be welcomed.  Many EU citizens are of Andorran origin. Children with links to the Andorran community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing — It is very important that the provisions of this Convention preventing and prior international child abduction should also apply in other countries which have not yet been bound by them or have merely acceded to the Convention. I therefore voted in favour. It should be stressed that, even in these very difficult family-legal situations, often with a strong geopolitical context, when national courts tend to rule biased, it is always and at all costs necessary to take into account the rights, well-being and dignity of children. A child cannot be abused in any way and cause him emotional, psychological or physical suffering. Even in a situation where an adult is trying to claim the so-called 'right to a child'. A child is no business item that can be disposed of as an object or a tool for blackmailing another, as unfortunately often happens in these cases. The best interests of the child must always come first and everywhere.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — The aim of the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Law Aspects of International Child Abduction is to ensure the swift return of unlawfully removed or detained children through the cooperation of the central institutions of the contracted parties. The Treaty on European Union prioritises the protection and promotion of children's rights and thus prevents child abduction forms an essential part of this policy.  That is why I support and welcome Andorra's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international kidnapping. In particular, I welcome the fact that Andorra has already appointed and designated a central institution to work with European citizens in cases of illegal removal of children to Andorra, and I therefore support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support Andorra's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. International co-operation is vital in ensuring the protection of the rights of children.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - The Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction since 25 October 1980 is a very important instrument ratified by all Member States of the European Union, with the purpose of resolving such cases internationally and introducing a system that ensures the immediate return of children.  The biggest problem is national bias with the legal systems of individual countries, and it often happens that courts of both countries are called competent in solving such cases. European Union action here is very important and it must be determined whether andorra's accession will be accepted by a declaration by the Member States and decided by the Council after consultation with Parliament.  I support the accession of Andorra to the Convention in this case, as this will ensure that many children associated with the Andorra community are insured against abduction. The Committee therefore recommends that the European Parliament approve the proposed Council decision and accept the accession of Andorra.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. — The accession to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction in principle is acceptable, and the extension of these international rules to Andorra is to be welcomed. There remains a slight concern that Andorra will need further assessment in order to confirm their full compliance with their obligations; however, this has been raised by the Member States in the Council. As the European Parliament does not have a formal role in this process and is only being asked for consent and as the measure is positive in extending the reach of an international standard in difficult situations, I can support this vote.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The accession of more and more States to the Hague Convention develops the appropriate infrastructures and channels of communication between those States to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to deal with custody issues if parents live in different countries. Cooperation between several states to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction is also promoted.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. — The accession of Andorra to the Hague Convention is a necessary step to ensure that Member States parties to the Convention can take as broad a action as possible against the abduction of children abroad. I support this proposal, because the protection of children is of paramount importance in all circumstances and all possible legal instruments must be used.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. I voted in favour of this proposal. The purpose of the convention in question is to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. The Union now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area under the 1/13 opinion of the Court of Justice. Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. The problem is that the convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem necessities the Council's decision requiring member states to accept Andorra's accession to the Convention and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the convention between the European Union and that country. Andorra's accession to the Convention is news that should be welcomed, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Andorran origin on its soil.  (Shortened voting explanation under section 170 of the regulation)

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a crucial legal instrument to fight against child abduction. This is the reason why I voted in favour of this report. Protecting the rights and interests of children must be one of the priorities of the EU and by supporting the accession of this country to the Hague Convention we reinforce the legal framework to ensure these key principles.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, as I think that it is of great importance that Andorra enters into the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — The European Union does not have the legal capacity to impose anything in this area under the 1980 Hague Convention. The justification for Andorra's accession to this convention, which is supposed to be in the interests of the European Union, is therefore not valid.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the eight reports accepting the accession of Armenia, Morocco, Singapore, Albania, Russia, Seychelles, Andorra and Gabon to the 1980 Hague Convention. This Convention lays down the framework of private international law for the recovery of abducted children. Its objective is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to ensure the rights of the child, and mutual respect for custody sentences.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. — 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important document. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases. Andorra's accession to the Convention is good news, especially since many EU citizens come from Andorra. So children with ties to the Andorran community will be protected from abduction.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Andorra's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Andorra's accession to that Convention.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This Convention is essentially intended to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held in any Contracting State and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The following countries have deposited the instrument of membership of the Convention: Albania; Andorra; Armenia; Gabon; Morocco; Singapore; Seychelles, Russia. The European Union now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the European Union. However, although Member States no longer have such competence, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise participation in international organisations such as the European Union, so the Council has taken a successive decision in order to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - The proposal for Andorra's accession to the Hague Convention received my positive vote in order to find solutions together at international level to the cases of international child abduction.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — I welcome Parliament's approval of the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of consent of the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Andorra's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (HKÜ). The HKÜ is an almost exemplary solution under international law and an example of fruitful international cooperation for the protection of children. Nothing is worse for a child than a break-up of his parents' relationship. To make matters worse, parents sometimes start a dispute over the child, which is always at the expense of the child. Rarely, but unfortunately still far too often, a parent reacts with child abduction in order to create facts and, for selfish reasons, avoid a custody dispute. The HKÜ provides a sustainable framework to prevent and counteract cross-border child abductions. This cannot in principle prevent the damage done to the child, but it at least offers the possibility of returning the child to his or her usual environment.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of the Convention in question is to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The child abduction situation occurs very often when a couple of people secede and when the parents come from different states. According to the rapporteur, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the state they represent. The Purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's state of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. Andorra has deposited the instrument of access and we have spoken in favour, since this Agreement is in line with the defence of the interests of minors.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI). -
text: Mr President, I go on this line by demonstrating that the opinion of the Court of Justice, on the authority of which one can question - does the opinion have exactly the same authority as a judgment - generates a considerable constitutional novation which, in reality, deprives our States of their freedom in foreign policy.  What would have happened if there was a contradiction, if France had tabled in The Hague, for example, the instruments of ratification and if the vote of our Parliament today had been negative? This is an extremely interesting question which, in my opinion, has not been addressed by the brilliant lawyers who make up our Committee on Constitutional Affairs, our Legal Committee, neither by the Council nor by the Commission. There is a contradiction here that could prove very serious when other texts are adopted.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. — UKIP voted against the report, as the EU now has exclusive external competence in this field, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13. The Member States therefore no longer act on their own account. We believe that the UK should be able to act in its own right.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the accession of the Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention to avoid opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of their parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting the Seychelles to accession to that Convention.

name: Gerolf Annemans (NI)
text: Written. — The accession of a number of countries to the Hague Convention is to be welcomed. The abduction of one or more children abroad is a traumatic and dramatic event that must be dealt with as quickly as possible in the interests of the children. The question, however, is what will be worth the signature or the word of some acceding countries. For example, a Belgian ex-minister points out the manifest reluctance of the Moroccan authorities in cases of parental abductions. Moreover, it is problematic that the EU is now applying exclusive external jurisdiction in this matter. This means that Member States are in danger of being criticised by the EU if they do take bilateral initiative themselves. While the ultimate goal should be, in any way: to find a quick solution for the children.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an important legal instrument for the protection of children. The aim of this agreement is to avoid international child abductions by increasing cooperation between States parties. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The accession of the Seychelles to this agreement is to be welcomed. This will extend this sensible legal framework to other countries. This ensures that the best interests of the child are paramount.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Seychelles must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I cannot vote in favour: this is a field in which the EU should not have exclusive competence. Under normal circumstances I would abstain. The assessment of these statesʼ abilities to fully comply with provisions is important for child safety. These countries will be trusted by us to a great extent. The Commission has not undertaken this kind of assessment. The UK Government believes there are ʽserious risks in returning children to a third country that does not respect rule of law or basic legal procedures in family casesʼ. I therefore voted against as this measure has not been properly thought through.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it protects the children of Seychelles nationals staying on European Union soil from possible illegal abductions

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to accede to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. of 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases and has been ratified by all EU Member States. Often such problems arise when a couple of different nationalities divorce. A lack of cooperation between states is often used to secure custody of a child. The media is full of reports of international child abduction in divorce. The purpose of the Convention is to address these problems at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the State in which the child lives. The Convention also provides for a system to ensure that the abducted child is returned immediately. The accession of Seychelles to the Convention is a positive thing to ensure that these children are protected.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on International Child Abduction aims to manage jurisdictional disputes and conflicts of laws that usually arise from separations of couples. These are, of course, very sensitive situations and states cannot be over-encouraged in this area. Having said that, I voted against this text, which presents a major problem: the European Union is not a state, so its legal capacity to become a party to the Hague Convention is highly questionable. This prerogative is reserved for states by public international law, and I refuse to vote on a text that implicitly calls it into question. Moreover, the report explains in the explanatory statement that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states".  Thus, the approval of Seychelles' accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of child abduction cannot be within the competence of the European Union.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 is a very important instrument that allows the contracting parties to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. It sets up a system to expedite the return of the abducted child to the country where he or she usually resides. Through the Council's decision, Member States each accept Seychelles' accession to the Convention and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the European Union and that country.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal because it will solve the problems that are often suffered when couples from different States separate and dispute the custody of their children, even reaching the abduction of them. This Convention will resolve situations at the international level and, more importantly, minors will be protected from illegal abduction. I thank Seychelles for its accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. Generally, this situation arises when a couple divorces or separates. The statement of reasons for the report thus tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Seychelles must not fall within the European scope, so I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction provides for cooperation between signatory States to ensure that a child or child under 16 who has been arbitrarily "abducted" by a parent returns to the place of family residence pending a judicial ruling, unless the return foretoos a serious danger to his or her safety. I believe it is of fundamental importance for the protection of our children that this Convention be ratified and respected by more and more States. I therefore voted to support the accession of seychelles among the new signatory countries.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Seychelles to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction, and therefore the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome the accession of Seychelles to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Seychelles community will be protected against illegal abduction.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports the accession of Seychelles to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The accession of Seychelles to the Convention is good news. The rapporteur fully supports this accession, especially since many EU citizens come from Seychelles. Children with ties to the Seychelles community would therefore be protected from legal abduction.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — This document relates to the cooperation of states in the event of a child abduction of an international character. Namely, if parents come from different countries, it often happens that in the event of a disconnect or divorce, they try to exploit legal loopholes and the absence of clearly defined cooperation between countries in order to unlawfully appropriate the child.  The Hague Convention therefore seeks to establish clear international practices in such cases. The betterment of the child is being put to the forefront, and that is why I support the report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted yes because I consider it fundamental that this Convention is applied in as many countries as possible, due to its importance.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interest of the European Union, of the accession of the Republic of Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.          Preventing child abduction is an essential part of the EU's policy to promote children's rights, with the European Union active at international level to improve the implementation of the 1980 Hague Convention and encouraging third states to ad.     In view of the fact that the Republic of Seychelles deposited the instrument of accession to the 1980 Convention on 27 May 2008 and the Convention entered into force in the Seychelles on 1 August 2008, EU Member States have now fulfilled their obligation to practically restore a status quo of the cooperation system.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The Hague Convention is a good thing and the protection of minors must be extended as far as possible to other states that wish to be part of it.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention was established in 1980. This convention deals with the civil aspects of international child abduction. The Member States of the European Union are all signatories. It was important to create such an institution. All too often, we hear cases of parents abducting and obtaining custody in their countries of origin without prior consultation with the abducted parent. This situation cannot last. The legal systems of countries must cooperate on this issue, which is so important for the protection of children. I voted in favour of Seychelles joining the Hague Convention.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of the accession of the Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Convention, to which more than 90 states have already acceded, including all EU countries, provides for the immediate return of the child in the event that the child is unlawfully taken away from habitual residence without the consent of the other parent, in violation of the right of custody. In today's vote, Parliament decided to ask the EU Member States to formally recognise seychelles' accession to the Convention.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of the Seychelles to the Hague Convention, as this proposal will assist authorities in returning wrongfully removed children, and will help to address issues of conflict of laws (competence of courts). In real terms, it will provide a pragmatic solution where a child has been abducted and taken to another country without the consent of one of the parents. Furthermore, the overarching principle of the proposal is that the welfare of the child – something that should always be paramount – should be the first and foremost consideration in child care proceedings. That is why it was necessary to support this proposal.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Some States exploit the lack of cooperation between national authorities in order to obtain custody of minors where there is proceedings pending between two spouses from different countries. Accession to the Hague Convention establishes jurisdiction in the State in which the child resides, limiting disputes over jurisdiction and thus speeding up proceedings. That is why we are voting in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. —I refused to sign in favour of this report for a simple reason: an international convention is a legal standard that must be signed by sovereign states.  The European Union does not have this legal status and its legitimacy is therefore questionable, with regard to its legal capacity to become a party to the Hague Convention. It is clear, however, that child abductions are a very serious issue and therefore states continue to work actively together to prevent these tragedies and take responsibility for the civil aspects they take on.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention is a fundamental instrument for ensuring the return of children unlawfully transferred or detained abroad by a parent and for ensuring respect for custody and visiting rights in all States. My country, Italy, was the only country to support, even before the Court intervened, the Exclusive Competence of the Union in this field, instead of full regulatory and operational coordination between States, instead of approaches aimed at protecting the parent, who is a citizen, also to the detriment of the interests of the child and the rights of citizens of other countries. I believe that, for the proper application of the Convention, the Member States will have to comply with certain requirements: efficient central authorities that can really set themselves as a reference for administrative cooperation; rules preventing discriminatory practices; guarantees of access to justice and, in general, full alignment with the principles of the rule of law. Having said that, I welcome the accession of the Seychelles, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance which has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. It enables the Contracting States effectively to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international abduction of children. The problem arises in couples who separate, where spouses are of different nationalities, because there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states. In the various States there are legal systems which tend to seek to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality, leaving the right of custody of dubious interpretation. In order to deal with these situations at international level, the Convention places the child at the centre of the problem by establishing that the court of jurisdiction is the court where the child resides. In view of all this, the accession of the Seychelles State to the Convention is to be welcomed, given also the favourable opinion of the rapporteur, who fully supports the measure. Children with links to the Seychelles community will thus find protection against abduction at EU level. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the seychelles' accession to the 1980 Hague Convention because I agree with the creation of a permanent system of cooperation between the Contracting States on the security of child care. In particular, I welcome the increased protection for minors, since the Convention stipulates that the competent courts and the laws to be applied are those of the states of residence of minors. That is all the more reason why I voted in favour of the Convention because it introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of the child who has been abducted. My vote is consistent with my view that as many States as possible should accede to the Convention in order to increase its effectiveness.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument. It has been ratified by all the EU Member States. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In many instances, these problems arise when a couple has separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those states in order to secure custody of the child. The biggest problem in such cases is the differences between the legal systems of individual states. It may often be that the courts in both of the states concerned declare themselves competent, with each of them awarding custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at an international level.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a key instrument in the context of judicial cooperation between contracting States in the resolution of cases of international child abduction. This Convention aims to harmonise the legal systems other than those states which normally declare themselves both competent to adjudicate the action and declare custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent, and the criterion of the State of residence of the minor is adopted with the Convention. As this matter currently is the exclusive external competence of the Union, a Council decision is necessary which call for the Member States to accept the access of third countries to the Hague Convention. I support the Hautala report in this regard and congratulate the Seychelles on their access to the Convention, thereby taking a step towards protecting their minors from abduction.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States of seychelles' accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. In an international scenario in which the mobility of families across national borders is increasing, the phenomenon of the abduction of children is particularly important in the event of couples' crises. Protecting the child from illegal transfer or non-return is a global problem as well as a key element of the EU programme. Article 24 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union states that children have the right to protection and their interests 'must be considered pre-eed'. I therefore support the accession of the Republic of Seychelles because it is only through international cooperation that it is possible to settle the relevant issues of custody of minors and ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. Children with links to the Seychelles community can thus be better protected from any danger of abduction.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — We often hear of child abductions taking place in Member States, especially when parents and family members originate from different countries. When this happens within Member States, that child is already protected by legislation, but it is important to protect children also when abducted to non-EU countries.  The accession of more countries to the Hague Convention is welcomed as it extends the network of protection for children. The Hague Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In cases where a couple has separated and the parents are from different States, lack of cooperation between these States can create a situation which is not in the best interests of the child involved.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I vote in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of the accession of seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. The aim of the Convention is to provide effective instruments for resolving this type of dispute between countries informally.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the accession of the Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention to avoid opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of their parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting the Seychelles to accession to that Convention.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution that encourages EU member states to accept the accession of the Seychelles to the Hague Child Abduction Convention. This would allow the convention to enter into force between the Seychelles and the EU and thus help to ensure the prompt return of abducted children. All EU member states have ratified the convention.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes to support the European Parliament for the accession of the Republic of Seychelles to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This international agreement, ratified by all EU Member States, aims to establish a system of cooperation in the context of international child abductions, most often intervening in cases of separation or divorce of binational couples. In the event of a referral to the courts of the two States concerned, they may declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the State under its jurisdiction. This convention therefore specifies the jurisdiction of national courts and guarantees a system allowing the immediate return of the abducted child. It is necessary for this international regime to be as broad as possible. In this way, children linked to this community will be protected from illegal abduction. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, ratified by all EU Member States, aims to protect children from international abduction by providing for a procedure for their rapid return. Through the vote on this text, the aim is to invite the Council of the European Union to ask the Member States to accept Seychelles' accession. The extension of the convention's territorial scope to the islands and islands constituting Seychelles fulfils a fundamental european Union objective of strengthening the protection of children at the international level. I have therefore supported this text.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Seychelles' accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction, because in this way minors with links to the Seychelles community will find greater protection against this phenomenon. This Convention allows cooperation between the Contracting States in order to find solutions to cases of international abduction of children. This problem arises when spouses from different States, as a result of their separation, exploit the lack of cooperation between the States concerned in order to obtain custody of the children. The aim of this Convention is to settle such situations at international level by establishing that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Seychelles must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. — Dear Colleagues, I voted in favour of my colleague Hautala's report on the accession of the Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, because I believe that statistics on the increased number of abductions in itself speak to the urgent need for cooperation.  According to the data currently available, in 2008 the number of applications for return of children submitted only within the EU on the basis of the 1980 Hague Convention was 990. That means 35% more than in 2003. Unfortunately, the rise in crimes against children is also high. I cannot help but note that it is the kidnapping that is the first step for trafficking in human beings and exploitation for criminal purposes.  I welcome the accession of the Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention and call on all Member States under this international instrument to take measures to ensure its practical application.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention aims to ensure the immediate return of children who have been moved or unlawfully detained in one of the Contracting States and to ensure that custody and communication rights under the law of one of the Contracting States are respected in the other Contracting States.  This Convention creates the infrastructure and communication channels between 92 states to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to arrange custody issues if parents live in different countries.      We are voting in favour of the inclusion of other states in the Hague Convention, as it protects children who become victims of disagreements between their parents. The Convention ensures cooperation between States to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — The problems posed by the international abduction of minors cannot be denied. The ordeal suffered by victims cannot be overlooked when countries affected by such a case have different laws.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention provides the private international law framework for recovery of abducted children. Its aim is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to safeguard the prompt return of the child and the mutual enforcement of judgments regarding custody and access rights. The vote refers to the acceptance of the Seychelles, which has joined the Convention in recent years. This agreement will benefit children and families in Wales so I voted in favour.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome this Proposal from the Council to accept the accession of the Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention. The issue of the defence of children's rights is of central importance and it therefore seems very positive that more and more states should be included, especially given that there are a great many people on European soil from the countries that are now applying for membership, which will facilitate the resolution of cases of abduction between a Member State and these third countries. However, while it is good that all the States of the European Union have acceded to the Convention, I cannot help noticing that the concept of 'good of the child' is often interpreted instrumentally. I am thinking, for example, of Germany, whose children's office, the Jugendamt, actuallyes the good of the child for the good of the German child, depriving the non-German parent and the child himself of many fundamental rights, including some of the founding rights of the Hague Convention. Unfortunately, the problem is not confined to Germany alone, and Europe is powerless to witness these abuses because it does not have the power to intervene in the family law of the individual Member States. That is why I believe that there is an urgent need for harmonisation of legislation in this area.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart. As parents come from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those same States to obtain custody of minors. In these cases, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of the countries concerned to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Convention aims to remedy such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. I voted in favour of accepting seychelles' acceptance of the Hague Convention in the best interests of minors who have links with the Seychelles community and who will thus be protected from abduction.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart, and the Convention resolves these types of situations on an international scale, by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the state of residence of the minor. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I am voting against this text because, by becoming part of the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction, the European Union is also giving itself a space for interpretation of this text. Let us not be fooled because under the good intentions of defending the interests of children nothing is done - for example - against the expansion of the barbaric practice of surrogacy within the Union. On the other hand, it is up to the Member States to determine sovereignly who may or may not join the Convention, I challenge, once again, this transfer of competence.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The child abduction situation occurs with some frequency when a couple, with members from different States, is reunited. Not accompanying some of the considerations made during this debate concerning the legal systems of each State, it is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Convention aims to address this type of situation at international level. It is its objective to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the rights of custody and visitation existing in a Contracting State. These are fair and relevant objectives. The Seychelles deposited the instrument of adhering to the Convention.  The EU now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the EU. However, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise the participation of international organisations such as the EU. For this reason, the Council had to take a successive decision in order to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I am pleased that the Seychelles is party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, and that is why I voted in favour of the report. The Convention provides effective means of settling disputes arising from international abductions of minors as a result of separation or divorce, by establishing that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — The subject of international child abduction largely concerns spouses or couples in which individuals from different countries of the world choose to abuse the situation and wrongly adopt a child after divorce or break-up. Such situations are helped by the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Children often become a means of dealing with accounts between spouses or former partners with different citizenships. Consequently, the national courts, often outside the European Union, often grant custody rights to the parent who is a citizen of the state to which that court is competent, thanks to certain national tendencies. The Convention resolves such situations in such a way that the assignment of the child is decided by the court in the State where he or she resides, regardless of where one of the parents was brought. The EU now has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice. This means that Member States are no longer acting at their discretion. It is therefore necessary to adopt a Council Decision requiring Member States to accept in their own territory the accession of the Republic of Seychelles to the Convention and thus the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that State. The adoption of the convention in question will provide increased protection for children associated in any way with the Seychelles community.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome the accession of the Seychelles to the Hague Convention.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the accession of other States to the Hague Convention, as it protects children who fall victim to disagreements between their parents. The Convention ensures that the children return to their normal residence in the event of abduction.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — I strongly support the adoption of stronger cooperative measures to prevent cases of international child abduction. Greater coordination between states is necessary to avoid the temptation, by one of the parents, to secure custody of a child following a separation or a divorce. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 makes it possible to resolve, at an international level, those cases in which the courts of both of the states concerned declare themselves competent and award custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. Moreover the Convention introduces a system which ensures the immediate return of abducted children. I welcome the accession of Seychelles to The Hague Convention. Considering the number of EU citizens of Seychelles origin, this accession is vital to ensure EU-wide protection of the children in question.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. — International law, including EU legislation, is based on the fact that the most vulnerable members of society, children, can enjoy the most effective protection in all circumstances. One of the means of doing so is the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of the abduction of children, ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention establishes a system of international cooperation between the contracting States to resolve cases involving the abduction of children abroad. In most cases, the problem is the divorce of parents of different nationality who are exploiting the lack of international cooperation to obtain custody of children. The biggest problem in these cases is the different legal frameworks of the different States. The purpose of the Convention is to provide redress and redress in such cases. It is therefore essential that as many States as possible can join this Convention.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. — For the institutions of the European Union, the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an instrument of crucial importance that has been ratified by all EU Member States. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, a problem which we unfortunately face very often and which entails great suffering for the parties involved. The objective of the Convention is to resolve this issue at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. Similarly, the Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. Therefore, once the Decision has been analysed, as well as the case-law of the Court of Justice of the EU, I have decided to vote in favour with the desire to promote the accession of the Republic of Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution. The Republic of the Seychelles has ratified the Convention, but its acceptance by all EU Member States is necessary for its implementation between the Seychelles and the European Union. To the extent that it is an exclusive competence of the EU, the report refers to the Council Decision by asking Member States about its acceptance, and that is why I have supported it.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour and fully support the accession of the Seychelles to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, so that minors with links to the Seychelles community can also benefit from EU protection measures in the event of separation or dispute between their parents. The Convention is in fact an instrument of guarantee for children of extraordinary effectiveness, in that it intervenes to bring back to the center of conflicts of couples in crisis of different nationalities the rights of minors applicable in their state of residence, overcoming the temptation of preferential management between the individual countries of origin of the parents and the dramatic risk of international abduction of minors. Europe, the guarantor of human rights, is widening the mesh of measures to protect minors in all the countries that so request, thus preventing unjust national legal favouritism and unholy parenting of child fragility.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction includes 93 countries, including all EU countries. I therefore welcomed the inclusion of the Republic of Seychelles. The vote received more than 90% support, which shows the importance of the situation regardless of political views.  The Convention is an essential instrument for ensuring respect for the rights of a child who has been kidnapped by one of his parents. Child abduction is a crime, a violation of human rights, guaranteed m.in. the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Every year in the European Union, there are an average of 3000 child abductions between Community countries, kidnappings without the consent of the other parent. In the Committee on Petitions, of which I am a member, we receive many reports of child abdument. These cases are among the most emotional. This shows how significant and frequent this problem is.  The accession of new countries to the Convention is good news, which in the future will result in more efficient investigations into the kidnapping of children.  Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her good work.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Hautala report because The Hague Convention of 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an essential instrument for protecting children belonging to parents from different states that exploit potential conflicts of competence between their national courts in order to secure custody of their child.  I therefore call on all EU Member States to formally accept the accession of the Seychelles to the Convention, seeing that this is a crucial step to ensure effective implementation and enhanced international cooperation to protect children who fall victim to international abduction.  I do urge the Commission to continuously monitor whether the necessary infrastructure is in place to ensure the Seychelles are in a position to fully implement the Convention.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against this proposal on Seychelles' accession to the Hague Convention.  This convention is certainly very useful in the management of jurisdictional disputes in cases of child abductions, most often as a result of divorces. Nevertheless, I question the legitimacy of the European Union to intervene in the ratification of this convention between the Member States and other States.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as I believe the accession of the Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (the Convention), which seeks to protect children from abduction across international boundaries, is to be welcomed. It is important that countries acceding to the Convention can participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention. Effective measures now need to be put into place to ensure the rights of the child and that cooperation is fully practicable.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention on civil aspects of the abduction of children is a very important legal instrument. All The Member States of the European Union are parties. The Convention provides a system of cooperation for Contracting States to find solutions to cases of child abduction abroad. These problems most often occur in parents who are divering. In order to obtain childcare, a spouse from another State may take advantage of the lack of cooperation between States. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. Often, the courts of both States concerned consider the case to be within their competence and award the right to custody to a parent of their own nationality. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. I therefore consider it of the utmost importance that all states that have not yet done so should accede to the Convention.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. The Convention aims to protect children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on a statement accepting, in the interest of the European Union, the Accession of the Seysela to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction in 1980, as it provides effective assistance to the Seyos to oppose the unjust abduction of children, and to strengthen international cooperation in this area.  Children's rights are one of the priorities of the European Union, but in order to ensure that zero tolerance is met, further efforts are needed through synergical and decisive action. I believe that the Convention is an effective instrument for bridging the problems of legal systems that exist in this context in individual Member States.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Seychelles must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This file suggested that Parliament approve the Council proposal to allow the Seychelles to access the UN Convention that regulates civil aspects on child abduction, mostly concerning the cooperation of the authorities in case of the return of wrongfully-removed children and issues of conflict of laws. As the prevention of child abduction is, since the Brussels Regulations on Matrimonial Matters and Parental Responsibility, an exclusive competence of the EU policy to promote the rights of the child, the EU is the actor at international level to improve the application of the 1980 Convention and to encourage third states to accede it. Article 38(4) of the 1980 Convention stipulates that the Convention applies between the acceding country and such contracting states as will have declared their acceptance of the accession. Therefore, the EU has to decide whether or not to accept the accession of a country. When affirmative, Member States should make the declaration of acceptance concerning the accession in the interest of the EU, because, as the Convention dates from 1980, it does not recognise international organisations such as the EU as an accessing Party. EH Bildu has voted in favour, as the primary matter is broadening the application of the UN Convention on child abduction.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the Council's proposal for a decision on Seychelles' accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes mechanisms for cooperation between contracting states to remedy jurisdictional conflicts, particularly when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Accession of Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction’ because the EU has exclusive external competence in this field, but the problem is that the Convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organisations. Therefore, the accession of Seychelles to the Convention and the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the EU and that country is necessary, especially as many EU citizens are of Seychellois origin. Children with links to the Seychellois community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — One of the European Union's special priorities is to protect children and strengthen children's rights, as set out in Article 3 of the Treaty on european Union. The prevention of child abduction is an important measure in the context of child protection. The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction of 25 October 1980, as a multilateral agreement, forms the basis for the immediate repatriation of children abducted abroad or children detained abroad. In the meantime, 86 countries have signed up to this convention, but the validity of the law required official permission from the EU, even if individual countries have already implemented it. That is why I support the request to include the Seychelles in the Hague Convention.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR)
text: in writing. — On behalf of the Conservative MEPs in the European Parliament and as Conservative spokesman for Legal Affairs, I voted in favour of this report, as the 1980 Hague Convention is an effective tool in the resolution of international child abduction cases and extending its application to more countries, as long as they fully comply with the obligations under the convention, would enhance the legal certainty for those involved in such disputes. However, I strongly support the assessments which many Member States currently undertake in order to carefully assess any third country’s ability to implement the Convention properly before accepting its accession. These assessments prevent any potential risks which may arise from returning children to a third country which does not respect the rule of law or basic legal procedures in family law cases or does not have a competent authority which could verify a child’s well-being. I therefore support calls for the Commission to urgently produce such assessments for these countries, which it is yet to produce.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — In order for the Convention to apply between the Seychelles and the EU, the acceptance of all Member States is required. I supported giving the acceptance, as the Convention is an important international instrument, which seeks to protect children from the harmful effects of abduction and retention across international boundaries by providing a procedure to bring about their prompt return.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. — International abduction of children as a result of separation or divorce is a reality which unfortunately occurs with a habitual frequency. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. International cooperation is essential for the resolution of these disputes, hence my full support for this resolution. Seychelles' accession to the Convention and, consequently, the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases concerning the European Union and that country is to be welcomed. It is our moral and political duty to ensure that the children in question enjoy protection at EU level.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mrs Hautala's report because it will ensure adequate protection against international abductions of children with links to the Seychelles community. As I said in the other reports adopted today, the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 is an instrument of fundamental importance in the field of the protection of children's rights and I am therefore in favour of the accession of a new State.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Seychelles is by no means within the European scope. So I voted against it.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution. The following eight countries have ratified the Convention, but its acceptance by all EU Member States is necessary for its implementation between them and the European Union. The countries are Singapore, Russia, Albania, Andorra, Seychelles, Gabon, Armenia and Morocco. To the extent that this is a positive step in the international protection of children, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the accession of the Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention to avoid opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of their parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting the Seychelles to accession to that Convention.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — With regard to the arguments set out above on the proposal for a Council Decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, I consider the accession of the Republic of Seychelles to that Convention equally important. Therefore, and taking into account that many people in the EU are of Seychelles origin, I am voting in favour of this proposal, considering that with such accession we can guarantee greater protection for minors.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction is an important instrument ratified by all Member States of the European Union. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between states aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. It is often the case that parents of a child live separately in different countries, so the biggest problem is the national bias of the legal systems of individual states. Courts in both countries may enter their claims as competent and each of the parents who are their nationals may be granted custody of the child. The purpose of the Convention is to deal with such situations at international level, so as to establish that the competent courts and applicable laws are only from the state that is the place of residence of the child. The Convention also implements a system that ensures the automatic return of children abducted. The European Union now has exclusive jurisdiction in this area as confirmed by the European Court of Justice. I support the Council Decision, which calls on Member States to accept the accession of the Seysela Convention, as this is in the interest of the European Union, will contribute to the coherence and uniformity of the application of EU law.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing — I welcome the accession of the Republic of Seychelles to the Hague Convention. Children who are somehow connected to the Seychelles community will be protected from kidnapping in this way. Any initiative to expand the number of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction must be supported. This will increase the protection of children from abduction in the territory of the Contracting States and can thus help to return the child to their natural environment more quickly. It is therefore necessary to look for the most effective ways of dealing with international child abduction in order to protect them and strengthen their rights.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Hautala report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of seychelles' accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because this Convention adequately addresses at international level the problem of child abduction and, therefore, , is an important legal and political development.

name: David Martin (S&D)
