text: in writing. — The accession of the Seychelles to the Convention is to be welcomed. I fully support this, especially as many EU citizens are of Seychellois origin. Children with links to the Seychellois community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — In favour of the report on the accession of seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. The intention of the Convention is to establish that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's State of residence.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 provides the Contracting States with the legal basis for resolving questions relating to the international abduction of children. I welcome the seychelles' accession to the Convention, as I believe that it will help to ensure adequate protection for children with links to that community in the event of abduction.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — The accession of the Seychelles to the Hague Convention is to be welcomed, since the Hague Convention no longer allows Member States to act on their own behalf and thus prevents the problem of national bias in the legal systems of individual States. The cooperation of the Contracting States can resolve cases of international child abduction.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — I welcome Seychelles' accession to the international convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. It aims to reduce legal conflicts between different national jurisdictions in cases of difficult separations of binational couples. In this legal procedure, however, the Commission has once again undermined the sovereignty of Member States by seeking recognition of these accessions on behalf of the European Union, even though the Convention does not recognise international organisations (such as the Union) as a signatory party. But I'm voting for the protection of children across borders.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — With the seychelles' agreement with the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, the EU takes another step towards achieving one of its priorities, which is the protection and promotion of the rights of the child. Thus, children from Seychelles residing in the EU are protected from abductions.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction aids in establishing the relevant jurisdiction to award custody of the child in question. The EU now has exclusive external competence in facilitating cooperation between contracting states to settle cases of international child abduction but requires each state to accept the accession of new signatories in their own territory. Therefore, I support each Member State’s acceptance of the extension to the Convention as it would ensure the protection of the child’s best interests in cases involving Seychelles.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. By voting for membership of the 1980 Hague Convention, it is the delicate and painful problem of parental abductions that is particularly targeted. Child abductions are rightly experienced as tragedies by the victim parent. In the plural world, several very different rights are potentially applicable and therefore sources of legal uncertainty in defiance of the interests of families and especially the child. It is often difficult to keep in touch with the child abroad, either because he is too young to speak on the phone or because the "kidnapper" parent prevents that contact. Parental alienation is a common practice. Psychological support is not sufficient in most cases, both before or after the abduction. The sometimes very long absence of 5 or 8 years tinges the joy of the reunion with a feeling of panic at the magnitude of the task. When I was Minister of Foreign Affairs, I had many opportunities to meet with parents who were abducted from their child. I felt the distress of the parents. I very much hope that with the accession to the Hague Convention, parents and children will be able to regain their share of happiness.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — The numerous cases of international child abduction make the ratification of this Convention an essential step in ensuring that no child is unduly removed or taken illegally from the place where he normally lives.  As Seychelles' agreement with the 1980 Hague Convention will strengthen the protection of children at international level, I am in favour of this report.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Seychelles is by no means within the European scope. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — It is important to get as many countries on board as possible. The accession will allow those countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which approves Seychelles' accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention is a major instrument in the fight against the illegal detention and displacement of children that occur as a result of family conflicts. In practical terms, it provides for cooperation mechanisms to resolve jurisdictional disputes between jurisdictions in the event of a binational separation. It also guarantees a return system in case of abduction. The larger the number of States parties to this convention, the greater the international guarantee of children's rights.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We believe that the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all EU Member States, in that it introduces a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. The aim is to avoid situations of uncertainty or dangerous legal loopholes. It is stipulates, in fact, that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the State of residence of the child. While the European Union has exclusive external competence in this area (as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13), i.e. individual Member States no longer have the opportunity to act individually by referring to their own legal systems, the problem remains that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organisations. In order to overcome this legal difficulty, the Council has decided that it will be up to the individual Member States to accept, each in relation to its own territory, the accession of new States to the Convention. We therefore welcome Albania's accession to this Convention, so as to ensure that children from the Seychelles islands can find protection against abduction at EU level.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because the accession of Seychelles is a news that should be welcomed, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Seychelles origin on its soil. In this way, children connected to this community will be protected from abduction.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this report, together with all the other documents on the agenda, relating to the acceptance by the Member States, in the interest of the EU, of seychelles' accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. The report refers to situations in which children are placed following divorce or separation of parents, conditions in which they may be abducted, and questions the custody of the child of one of the parents, as well as the establishment of the courts competent to deal with the case.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — Child abductions are associated with considerable emotional suffering for those affected. An important countermeasure here is international standards of protection and contractual agreements. In this respect, I welcomed and voted in favour of the proposal for the Accession of the Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because the Hague Convention on child abduction is a crucial piece of legislation. The accession of each new State to the Convention on this issue contributes to international child abduction cases and excludes biased justice. The protection of children's rights must take up a very important role in international relations and justice.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance. The Convention introduces a system which allows contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. In the event that spouses come from different States, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between the States concerned in order to obtain custody of children, and there is often a tendency for the legal systems of individual States to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality. The intention of the Convention is to settle these situations at international level and the many CITIZENS of the European Union who are originally from the Seychelles and children with links to the community of people from the Seychelles will thus find protection against abduction. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — More recently, due to intercultural openness and simpler ways of relocation, there has been a frequent phenomenon and the number of mixed marriages has increased. In the event of a divorce, it is essential that the existence and proper functioning of a reliable child protection mechanism is essential.  The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction is currently the most useful binding legislation for the protection of children when it comes to international kidnapping. By increasing the number of co-signers of the Convention, we are also empowering its effects, thus expanding its reach throughout the world to protect one of the most important links of society, our children.  By joining the 1980 Seysela Convention, we ensure that children receive adequate protection in case of adverse developments in relations in their family.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Seychelles is by no means within the European scope. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support the 1980 Seysela Accession Report to the Hague Convention on Civil Law Aspects of International Child Abduction. Although the Seys have ratified this Convention, its application to EU member states requires the consent of all Member States.  I believe it is in the interest of all of us that problems that can be caused by the non-compliance of legal systems, if the parents of the child come from two different countries, are adequately regulated. Children's rights must come first, and as children have suffered the consequences of legal unregulatedness, I would like to express my full support for this report once again and call on all EU member states to do the same as soon as possible.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. —Every year, eight million children disappear in the world, which would mean that nearly 22,000 children disappear every day. All our efforts should be directed towards ensuring a better future for our children, and so this Convention, signed by all members of the European Union, should ensure a secure future and the realisation of all children's rights.  As the report states, the most common problem is agreeing on the court's jurisdiction over the allocation of care to children whose parents are from different countries, as well as the lack of communication between the two countries. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such cases in predetermined competent courts and to use the prescribed laws.  Countries that approach it are entering a common system of tackling child abduction. If the legal systems differ too much and the country does not have the means to form a body that will implement the laws and proposals of this Convention, the country cannot even access it. This is also the problem that seysela's approach to the Hague Convention is taking place so slowly.  The Seyos submitted an application form to the Convention on 27 May 2008 and it entered into force on 1 August 2008. In order to solve the cases of abducted children of the Seys and the European Union, I support this report for accepting accession to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction from 1980.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I am, of course, in favour of the Seychelles having adhered to the Hague Convention and to the adoption of the proposal, so that children in that country can enjoy protection at European level.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. — As a former Minister of Justice, I dealt with bilateral relations between the Czech Republic and the Seychelles. I therefore also welcome the extension of the area of validity and effectiveness of this Convention to that island country.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — With this text, the European Parliament must assess the appropriateness of the recognition by European Union law of Seychelles' accession to the Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. For example, the European Union and its 28 Member States are united and apply this convention uniformly when such a dispute with Seychelles arises. It is important to solve such problems because they are family dramas that occur when parents find themselves confronted with Kafkaesque judicial systems. I am therefore in favour of anything that can improve the dialogue and resolution of family problems between judicial systems.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction, which occur very often following divorces and separations of parents from different States. More specifically, the Convention, seeking to counter the nationalist tendency of the legal systems of each State, provides that these cases must be tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the state of residence of the minor and also provides for a system ensuring the immediate return of the abducted minor. Although this is currently a matter of the EU's exclusive external competence, the fact is that the Convention does not provide for independent intervention by international organisations. To this extent, in order to ensure the protection of minors who have links with the Seichelense community, member states must accept seychelles from the support. This proposal for a Council decision rightly calls for such acceptance. I voted in favour.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention, dated 25 October 1980, is an important instrument with regard to the civil aspects of international child abduction. The fact that it is a system of cooperation between the different States makes it easier to find solutions to a problem that persists in our day. The strengthening of legislative systems must be an imperative and the seychelles' support for the Hague Convention must be viewed with great satisfaction.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Seychelles to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome the accession of Seychelles to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Seychelles community will be protected against illegal abduction.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. But the major problem remains the differences between the legal systems of the Member States. In this case, it is often the case that the courts of the two States concerned declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the state under its jurisdiction.  The hague Convention is therefore intended to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. I welcome the fact that Seychelles is joining today.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 establishes a fundamental instrument of cooperation between contracting states with regard to the international abduction of children. Seychelles too are a country that has close relations with the European Union and it receives and welcomes many citizens of Seichelian origin on its territory. For that reason, it seems logical to me that the Member States accept that the Convention is a member of the Convention.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report which approves Seychelles' accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction, which all the Member States of the European Union have ratified. This convention strengthens cooperation between states, addresses the problem of differences between legal systems that arises and thus establishes the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state where the child resides.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the accession of the Seychelles to the Hague Convention of 1980 because I am convinced that international cooperation on the international abduction of children is one of the actions that we have a duty to take for the benefit of the little ones, which in the not too distant future will be the basis of our society.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because I believe it is essential to promote the protection of children's rights.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Seychelles.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text which allows Seychelles to join the Hague Convention on International Child Abductions. This multilateral treaty protects children abducted outside their usual place of residence. Since the opinion of the Court of Justice on 14 October 2014, the European Union has exclusive jurisdiction over the acceptance of a new state to the convention.  These abductions, which are increasingly common in the divorces of binational couples, give rise to dramatic situations that require a rapid response from the authorities. Membership of the Convention will facilitate cooperation between the European and Seychelles judicial authorities to organise the rapid return of abducted children, so that the relevant local judge can make a decision on who is responsible for the custody of the child.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the accession of the Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention to avoid opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of their parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting the Seychelles to accession to that Convention.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The accession of Seychelles to the Convention is to be welcomed. Many EU citizens are of Seychellois origin. Children with links to the Seychellois community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing — It is very important that the provisions of this Convention preventing and prior international child abduction should also apply in other countries which have not yet been bound by them or have merely acceded to the Convention. I therefore voted in favour. It should be stressed that, even in these very difficult family-legal situations, often with a strong geopolitical context, when national courts tend to rule biased, it is always and at all costs necessary to take into account the rights, well-being and dignity of children. A child cannot be abused in any way and cause him emotional, psychological or physical suffering. Even in a situation where an adult is trying to claim the so-called 'right to a child'. A child is no business item that can be disposed of as an object or a tool for blackmailing another, as unfortunately often happens in these cases. The best interests of the child must always come first and everywhere.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction is an important instrument for the protection and promotion of children's rights. How important it is also that to date the Convention has been ratified by 92 countries, including all members of the European Union. The purpose of the Convention is to deal with cases of unlawful removal of children by one of the parents at international level, by establishing competent courts and appropriate laws.  It should be stressed that the single legal framework applicable between EU Member States and third countries can offer the best solution to sensitive cases of international child abduction. It is about the protection of children and their rights and therefore I support the accession of the Seysela to the Hague Convention of 1980.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support Seychelles’ accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. International cooperation is vital in ensuring the protection of the rights of children.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The accession of more and more States to the Hague Convention develops the appropriate infrastructures and channels of communication between those States to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to deal with custody issues if parents live in different countries. Cooperation between several states to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction is also promoted.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. — The accession of the Seychelles to the Hague Convention is a necessary step to ensure that Member States parties to the Convention can take as broad a action as possible against the abduction of children abroad. I support this proposal, because the protection of children is of paramount importance in all circumstances and all possible legal instruments must be used.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. "I voted for the proposal. The Union now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area under the 1/13 opinion of the Court of Justice. Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. The problem is that the convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem necessities the Council's decision requiring Member States to accept, each on its own territory, Seychelles' accession to the Convention and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the convention between the European Union and that country. The accession of Seychelles is news to be welcomed, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Seychelles origin on its soil. In this way, children linked to this community will be protected from illegal abduction.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a crucial legal instrument to fight against child abduction. This is the reason why I voted in favour of this report. Protecting the rights and interests of children must be one of the priorities of the EU and by supporting the accession of this country to the Hague Convention we reinforce the legal framework to ensure these key principles.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — The European Union does not have the legal capacity to impose anything in this area under the 1980 Hague Convention. The justification for Seychelles' accession to this convention, which is supposed to be in the interests of the European Union, is therefore not valid.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the eight reports accepting the accession of Armenia, Morocco, Singapore, Albania, Russia, Seychelles, Andorra and Gabon to the 1980 Hague Convention. This Convention lays down the framework of private international law for the recovery of abducted children. Its objective is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to ensure the rights of the child, and mutual respect for custody sentences.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support seysela's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention, and I believe that this issue carries the importance of protecting all EU citizens associated with the Seys and children who must be insured against kidnapping in all respects. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such cases internationally and to establish the fact that the competent courts and laws are applicable in the child's country of residence.  The Convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children abducted. The EU has exclusive external competence in this area and the problem arises when the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organisations. EU Member States are invited to accept seysela's accession to the Convention in the interest of the European Union, and the European Parliament should approve the proposed Council decision and accept seysela's accession.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. — The accession to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction in principle is acceptable, and the extension of these international rules to the Seychelles is to be welcomed. There remains a slight concern that the Seychelles will need further assessment in order to confirm their full compliance with their obligations; however, this has been raised by the Member States in the Council. As the European Parliament does not have a formal role in this process and is only being asked for consent and as the measure is positive in extending the reach of an international standard in difficult situations, I can support this vote.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. — 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important document. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the accession of the Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention to avoid opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of their parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting the Seychelles to accession to that Convention.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This Convention is essentially intended to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held in any Contracting State and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The following countries have deposited the instrument of membership of the Convention: Albania; Andorra; Armenia; Gabon; Morocco; Singapore; Seychelles, Russia. The European Union now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the European Union. However, although Member States no longer have such competence, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise participation in international organisations such as the European Union, so the Council has taken a successive decision in order to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - The accession of the Seychelles to the Hague Convention is to be welcomed, as the Hague Convention no longer allows Member States to act on their own behalf, thus preventing the problem of national bias in the legal systems of individual States. The cooperation of the Contracting States can resolve cases of international child abduction.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — I welcome Parliament's approval of the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of consent of the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of the accession of the Seychelles to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (HKÜ). The HKÜ is an almost exemplary solution under international law and an example of fruitful international cooperation for the protection of children. Nothing is worse for a child than a break-up of his parents' relationship. To make matters worse, parents sometimes start a dispute over the child, which is always at the expense of the child. Rarely, but unfortunately still far too often, a parent reacts with child abduction in order to create facts and, for selfish reasons, avoid a custody dispute. The HKÜ provides a sustainable framework to prevent and counteract cross-border child abductions. This cannot in principle prevent the damage done to the child, but it at least offers the possibility of returning the child to his or her usual environment.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of the Convention in question is to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The child abduction situation occurs very often when a couple of people secede and when the parents come from different states. According to the rapporteur, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the state they represent. The Purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's state of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. The Seychelles have deposited the instrument of access and we have spoken in favour, since this Agreement is in line with the defence of the interests of minors.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I supported this proposal, this report, as in the other seven cases, because I think it is very good that the circle of signatories to the 1980 Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction will be expanded. As a member of the National Government of the Czech Republic, I myself dealt with this issue and we ourselves, as the Czech Republic, approached and expanded the circle of signatory states. From my own experience, I can say that this is one of the few international treaties that works perfectly. And it is often the only tool to address the issue of international child abduction when one parent takes a child illegally to another country. I am therefore convinced that this instrument will work in practice and that today we have once again expanded the territory where it will be possible for EU citizens to deal with this difficult situation if their child is taken to the territory of the country that is now accessing this Convention.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! I too, of course, am pleased with any country that accedes to the Hague Convention, because we can easily treat child abductions and child abuse better internationally and can carry out the Convention more effectively in the interests of children and parents. In this context, I would just like to point out that it is also a question of making a breakthrough within the European Union in the spirit of the Hague Convention. We still have grotesque situations. Let me take two examples. On the one hand, Denmark has signed the Hague Convention, but has secured an opt-out within the European Union. This leads to the grotesque situation that child repatriations take place in Canada, but cannot take place in Austria. We still have some catching up to do here. Secondly, it is also a question of harmonising adoption, education and custody rights within the European Union in the first place. For example, large-scale adoptions can take place in the UK without parental consent. We still have homework to do here. But what works internationally should also work within the European Union.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI). -
text: Mr. President, I am continuing my presentation. For example, to return to my country, Article 55 of the French Constitution provides that conventions regularly ratified or approved have, as soon as they are published, a higher authority than that of internal laws, even French ones. That is the basis of our international commitments.  Again, what would happen if, since France had used the provisions of its Constitution, as is usually the case in political and international life, our Parliament had today taken another decision? Does this mean that all Member States are now under the tutelage of the Council, the Commission or the European Parliament and cannot ratify treaties which clearly concern their relations with non-Member States of the European Union without the authorisation of these supranational bodies? Again, this is a true capitis deminutio of our sovereignty, which has gone completely unnoticed in the eyes of most of our colleagues.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. — UKIP voted against the report, as the EU now has exclusive external competence in this field, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13. The Member States therefore no longer act on their own account. We believe that the UK should be able to act in its own right.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Russia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Russia's accession to that Convention.

name: Gerolf Annemans (NI)
text: Written. — The accession of a number of countries to the Hague Convention is to be welcomed. The abduction of one or more children abroad is a traumatic and dramatic event that must be dealt with as quickly as possible in the interests of the children. The question, however, is what will be worth the signature or the word of some acceding countries. For example, a Belgian ex-minister points out the manifest reluctance of the Moroccan authorities in cases of parental abductions. Moreover, it is problematic that the EU is now applying exclusive external jurisdiction in this matter. This means that Member States are in danger of being criticised by the EU if they do take bilateral initiative themselves. While the ultimate goal should be, in any way: to find a quick solution for the children.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an important legal instrument for the protection of children. The aim of this agreement is to avoid international child abductions by increasing cooperation between States parties. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The accession of the Russian Federation to this agreement is to be welcomed. This will extend this sensible legal framework to other countries. This ensures that the best interests of the child are paramount.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Russia must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I cannot vote in favour: this is a field in which the EU should not have exclusive competence. Under normal circumstances I would abstain. The assessment of these statesʼ abilities to fully comply with provisions is important for child safety. These countries will be trusted by us to a great extent. The Commission has not undertaken this kind of assessment. The UK Government believes there are ʽserious risks in returning children to a third country that does not respect rule of law or basic legal procedures in family casesʼ. I therefore voted against as this measure has not been properly thought through.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution because it protects the children of Russian nationals staying on European Union soil from possible illegal abductions.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to include Russia's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. of 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases and has been ratified by all EU Member States. Often such problems arise when a couple of different nationalities divorce. A lack of cooperation between states is often used to secure custody of a child. The media is full of reports of international child abduction in divorce. The purpose of the Convention is to address these problems at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the State in which the child lives. The Convention also provides for a system to ensure that the abducted child is returned immediately. Russia's accession to the Convention is a positive thing to ensure that these children are protected.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on International Child Abduction aims to manage jurisdictional disputes and conflicts of laws that usually arise from separations of couples. These are, of course, very sensitive situations and states cannot be over-encouraged in this area. Having said that, I voted against this text, which presents a major problem: the European Union is not a state, so its legal capacity to become a party to the Hague Convention is highly questionable. This prerogative is reserved for states by public international law, and I refuse to vote on a text that implicitly calls it into question. Moreover, the report explains in the explanatory statement that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states".  Thus, the approval of Russia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of child abduction cannot be within the competence of the European Union.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 is a very important instrument that allows the contracting parties to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. It sets up a system to expedite the return of the abducted child to the country where he or she usually resides. Through the Council's decision, the Member States each accept Russia's accession to the Convention and therefore the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the European Union and that country.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal because it will solve the problems that are often suffered when couples from different States separate and dispute the custody of their children, even reaching the abduction of them. This Convention will resolve situations at the international level and, more importantly, minors will be protected from illegal abduction. I thank Russia for its accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. Generally, this situation arises when a couple divorces or separates. The statement of reasons for the report thus tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Russia must not fall within the European scope, so I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction provides for cooperation between signatory States to ensure that a child or child under 16 who has been arbitrarily "abducted" by a parent returns to the place of family residence pending a judicial ruling, unless the return foretoos a serious danger to his or her safety. I believe it is of fundamental importance for the protection of our children that this convention be ratified and respected by more and more States. I therefore voted in favour of the Russian Federation's accession to it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction, and therefore the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome the accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Russian community will be protected from illegal abduction.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports Russia's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Russia's accession to the Convention is good news. The rapporteur fully supports this accession, especially since many EU citizens come from Russia. Thus, children with ties to the Russian community would be protected from abduction by legal means.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — This document relates to the cooperation of states in the event of a child abduction of an international character. Namely, if parents come from different countries, it often happens that in the event of a disconnect or divorce, they try to exploit legal loopholes and the absence of clearly defined cooperation between countries in order to unlawfully appropriate the child.  The Hague Convention therefore seeks to establish clear international practices in such cases. The betterment of the child is being put to the forefront, and that is why I support the report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted yes because it is fundamental to have Russia’s adhesion to this Convention, in order to protect children in Russia.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interest of the European Union, of the accession of the Russian Federation to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.        The Convention merely provides a proportionality relationship which must necessarily exist between the interests of the person and that of society in order to enforce respect for the right of immediate return of the unlawfully displaced or detained child, in agreement with that of respect for family life.         The Russian Federation deposited the instrument of accession to the 1980 Convention on 28 July 2011 and the Convention entered into force on 1 October 2011. With today's vote, the Hague Convention provides a number of measures to mediate the immediate return of minors who have been illegally displaced or detained in the Russian Federation and requires administrative or legal authorities to act swiftly in the return processes of minors.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The Hague Convention is a good thing and the protection of minors must be extended as far as possible to other states that wish to be part of it.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention was established in 1980 and deals with the civilian aspects of international child abduction. All EU member states have ratified it. The agreement resolves jurisdictional disputes when two jurisdictions each declare themselves competent for custody of children in the context of the separation of a binational couple. Each country must cooperate in the case of child abduction. The same is said for the protection of children. I voted in favour of this resolution which approves Russia's accession to the Hague Conventions.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of the accession of the Russian Federation to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. The Convention, to which more than 90 states have already acceded, including all EU countries, provides for the immediate return of the child, in the event that the child is unlawfully taken away from habitual residence without the consent of the other parent, in violation of the right of custody. In today's vote, Parliament decided to ask eu Member States to formally recognise the Russian Federation's accession to the Convention. I hope that the progressive increase in accessions to the Convention will help to resolve cases of child abduction more efficiently, including by improving the level of coordination at international level on the civil aspects of international child abduction.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of Russia to the Hague Convention, as this proposal will assist authorities in returning wrongfully removed children, and will help to address issues of conflict of laws (competence of courts). In real terms, it will provide a pragmatic solution where a child has been abducted and taken to another country without the consent of one of the parents. Furthermore, the overarching principle of the proposal is that the welfare of the child – something that should always be paramount – should be the first and foremost consideration in child care proceedings. That is why it was necessary to support this proposal.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Some States exploit the lack of cooperation between national authorities in order to obtain custody of minors where there is proceedings pending between two spouses from different countries. Accession to the Hague Convention establishes jurisdiction in the State in which the child resides, limiting disputes over jurisdiction and thus speeding up proceedings. That is why we are voting in favour.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. — At a time when internationalized families are on the rise, international child abductions are becoming more frequent. These situations are complex both humanly and legally. I therefore voted in favour of all the reports proposed by Mrs HAUTALA, which go in the direction of broadening the scope of the Hague Convention and further guarantee the safety of our children. However, the competent European judicial area cannot escape criticism. Even though the "Brussels II bis" regulation is supposed to guarantee enhanced protection for children on European soil by enshrining mutual recognition of judicial decisions relating to marital or parental responsibility, it appears that several jurisdictions of Member States can now be competent for the same case without being bound by the decision of another court. This problem of recognition of decisions creates a legal uncertainty that directly affects the children and parents concerned on European territory. It would therefore be desirable that in the context of the acceptance of Ms. HAUTALA's reports? The Commission is committed to clarifying the modalities for the implementation of the 'Brussels II bis' regulation.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. —I refused to sign in favour of this report for a simple reason: an international convention is a legal standard that must be signed by sovereign states.  The European Union does not have this legal status and its legitimacy is therefore questionable, with regard to its legal capacity to become a party to the Hague Convention. It is clear, however, that child abductions are a very serious issue and therefore states continue to work actively together to prevent these tragedies and take responsibility for the civil aspects they take on.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention is a fundamental instrument for ensuring the return of children unlawfully transferred or detained abroad by a parent and for ensuring respect for custody and visiting rights in all States. My country, Italy, was the only country to support, even before the Court intervened, the Exclusive Competence of the Union in this field, instead of full regulatory and operational coordination between States, instead of approaches aimed at protecting the parent, who is a citizen, also to the detriment of the interests of the child and the rights of citizens of other countries. I believe that, for the proper application of the Convention, the Member States will have to comply with certain requirements: efficient central authorities that can really set themselves as a reference for administrative cooperation; rules preventing discriminatory practices; guarantees of access to justice and, in general, full alignment with the principles of the rule of law. Having said that, I welcome the accession of the Russian Federation, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance which has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. It enables the Contracting States effectively to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international abduction of children. The problem arises in couples who separate, where spouses are of different nationalities, because there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states. In the various States there are legal systems which tend to seek to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality, leaving the right of custody of dubious interpretation. In order to deal with these situations at international level, the Convention places the child at the centre of the problem by establishing that the court of jurisdiction is the court where the child resides. All in all, the accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention is to be welcomed, given also the favourable opinion of the rapporteur, who fully supports the measure. Children with links to the Community of the Russian Federation will thus find protection against abductions at EU level. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — With regard to the accession of the Russian Federation to the important Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, I voted in favour. This is an important and sensitive issue and I agree with the creation of a permanent system of cooperation between the Contracting States on the security of child care. I welcome the Russian Federation's accession to the Convention as the EU has close economic ties with that country. Children with links to the community of people from the Russian Federation will thus find protection against abduction.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument. It has been ratified by all the EU Member States. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In many instances, these problems arise when a couple has separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those states in order to secure custody of the child. The biggest problem in such cases is the differences between the legal systems of individual states. It may often be that the courts in both of the states concerned declare themselves competent, with each of them awarding custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at an international level.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a key instrument in the context of judicial cooperation between contracting States in the resolution of cases of international child abduction. This Convention aims to harmonise the legal systems other than those states which normally declare themselves both competent to adjudicate the action and declare custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent, and the criterion of the State of residence of the minor is adopted with the Convention. As this matter currently is the exclusive external competence of the Union, a Council decision is necessary which call for the Member States to accept the access of third countries to the Hague Convention. I support the Hautala report in this regard and congratulate the Russian State on its access to the Convention, thereby taking a step towards protecting its minors from abduction.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States of the accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. In an international scenario in which the mobility of families across national borders is increasing, the phenomenon of the abduction of children is particularly important in the event of couples' crises. Protecting the child from illegal transfer or non-return is a global problem as well as a key element of the EU programme. Article 24 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union states that children have the right to protection and their interests 'must be considered pre-eed'. I therefore support Russia's accession, because it is only through international cooperation that it is possible to settle the relevant issues of child custody and ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. Children with links to the Russian community can thus be better protected from any danger of abduction.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — We often hear of child abductions taking place in Member States, especially when parents and family members originate from different countries. When this happens within Member States, that child is already protected by legislation, but it is important to protect children also when abducted to non-EU countries.  The accession of more countries to the Hague Convention is welcomed as it extends the network of protection for children. The Hague Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In cases where a couple has separated and the parents are from different States, lack of cooperation between these States can create a situation which is not in the best interests of the child involved.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — This report on the draft Council Decision relates to the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of the accession of the Russian Federation to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. When one parent takes their child out of national boundaries, the other parent faces a very complex and endlessly wrapped court battle. In order to ensure the immediate return of these children, more than 90 states, including all EU countries, have acceded to the 1980 Hague Convention. MePs are today debating the accession of eight new countries to the Convention. The vote on this report can only be in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Russia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Russia's accession to that Convention.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution that encourages EU Member States to accept the accession of Russia to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction. This would allow the Convention to enter into force between Russia and the EU and thus help to ensure the prompt return of abducted children. All EU Member States have ratified the Convention.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes to support the European Parliament for the accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This international agreement, ratified by all EU Member States, aims to establish a system of cooperation in the context of international child abductions, most often intervening in cases of separation or divorce of binational couples. In the event of a referral to the courts of the two States concerned, they may declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the State under its jurisdiction.  This convention therefore specifies the jurisdiction of national courts and guarantees a system allowing the immediate return of the abducted child. It is necessary for this international regime to be as broad as possible, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Russian origin on its soil. In this way, children linked to this community will be protected from illegal abduction. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, ratified by all EU Member States, aims to protect children from international abduction by providing for a procedure for their rapid return. Through the vote on this text, the aim is to invite the Council of the European Union to ask the Member States to accept the accession of the Russian Federation. It is important to extend the territorial scope of the convention to our Russian neighbour in order to ensure better protection of children from international abduction.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Russian Federation's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction, because in this way minors with links to the Community of the Russian Federation will find greater protection against this phenomenon. This Convention allows cooperation between the Contracting States in order to find solutions to cases of international abduction of children. This problem arises when spouses from different States, as a result of their separation, exploit the lack of cooperation between the States concerned in order to obtain custody of the children. The aim of this Convention is to settle such situations at international level by establishing that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Russia must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. — Dear Colleagues, I voted in favour of colleague Hautala's report on the accession of the Russian Federation to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, because I believe that statistics on the increased number of abductions in itself speak to the urgent need for cooperation.  According to the data currently available, in 2008 the number of applications for return of children submitted only within the EU on the basis of the 1980 Hague Convention was 990. That means 35% more than in 2003. Unfortunately, the rise in crimes against children is also high. I cannot help but note that it is the kidnapping that is the first step for trafficking in human beings and exploitation for criminal purposes.  I welcome Russia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention and call on all Member States under this international instrument to take measures to ensure its practical application.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention aims to ensure the immediate return of children who have been moved or unlawfully detained in one of the Contracting States and to ensure that custody and communication rights under the law of one of the Contracting States are respected in the other Contracting States.  This Convention creates the infrastructure and communication channels between 92 states to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to arrange custody issues if parents live in different countries.      We are voting in favour of the accession of other states to the Hague Convention, as it protects children who fall victim to disagreements between their parents. The Convention ensures cooperation between States to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction lays the groundwork for clear regulation in this area at the international level. It aims to provide an agile judicial response through the cooperation of States Parties. It seeks not to be left homeless victims and to have a clearly defined regulation as to the jurisdiction to which each case should be subjected.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention provides the private international law framework for recovery of abducted children. Its aim is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to safeguard the prompt return of the child and the mutual enforcement of judgments regarding custody and access rights. The vote refers to the acceptance of Russia, which has joined the Convention in recent years. This agreement will benefit children and families in Wales so I voted in favour.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome this Proposal from the Council to accept the accession of the Russian Federation to the 1980 Hague Convention. The issue of the defence of children's rights is of central importance and it therefore seems very positive that more and more states should be included, especially given that there are a great many people on European soil from the countries that are now applying for membership, which will facilitate the resolution of cases of abduction between a Member State and these third countries. However, while it is good that all the States of the European Union have acceded to the Convention, I cannot help noticing that the concept of 'good of the child' is often interpreted instrumentally. I am thinking, for example, of Germany, whose children's office, the Jugendamt, actuallyes the good of the child for the good of the German child, depriving the non-German parent and the child himself of many fundamental rights, including some of the founding rights of the Hague Convention. Unfortunately, the problem is not confined to Germany alone, and Europe is powerless to witness these abuses because it does not have the power to intervene in the family law of the individual Member States. That is why I believe that there is an urgent need for harmonisation of legislation in this area.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart. As parents come from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those same States to obtain custody of minors. In these cases, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of the countries concerned to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Convention aims to remedy such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. I voted in favour of accepting Russia's annexe to the Hague Convention in the best interests of minors who have ties to the Russian community and who will thus be protected from abduction.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart and the Convention resolves these types of situations on an international scale, by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the state of residence of the minor. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I am voting against this text because by becoming part of the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction, the European Union is also giving itself a space for interpretation of this text. Let us not be fooled because under the good intentions of defending the interests of children nothing is done - for example - against the expansion of the barbaric practice of surrogacy within the Union. On the other hand, it is up to the Member States to determine sovereignly who may or may not join the Convention, I challenge, once again, this transfer of competence.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The child abduction situation occurs with some frequency when a couple, with members from different States, is reunited. Not accompanying some of the considerations made during this debate concerning the legal systems of each State, it is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Convention aims to address this type of situation at international level. It is its objective to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the rights of custody and visitation existing in a Contracting State. These are fair and relevant objectives. Russia has deposited the instrument of adhering to the Convention.  The EU now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the EU. However, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise the participation of international organisations such as the EU. For this reason, the Council had to take a successive decision in order to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I am pleased that the Russian Federation is adjoining the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, and that is why I voted in favour of the report. The Convention provides effective means of settling disputes arising from international abductions of minors as a result of separation or divorce, by establishing that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — The subject of international child abduction largely concerns spouses or couples in which individuals from different countries of the world choose to abuse the situation and wrongly adopt a child after divorce or break-up. Such situations are helped by the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Children often become a means of dealing with accounts between spouses or former partners with different citizenships. Consequently, the national courts, often outside the European Union, often grant custody rights to the parent who is a citizen of the state to which that court is competent, thanks to certain national tendencies. The Convention resolves such situations in such a way that the assignment of the child is decided by the court in the State where he or she resides, regardless of where one of the parents was brought. The EU now has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice. This means that Member States are no longer acting at their discretion. It is therefore necessary to adopt a Council Decision requiring Member States to accept the accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention in their own territory and thus the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that State. The adoption of the convention in question will provide increased protection for children associated in any way with the Russian community.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome the accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the accession of other States to the Hague Convention, as it protects children who fall victim to disagreements between their parents. The Convention ensures that the children return to their normal residence in the event of abduction.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — I strongly support the adoption of stronger cooperative measures to prevent cases of international child abduction. Greater coordination between states is necessary to avoid the temptation, by one of the parents, to secure custody of a child following a separation or a divorce. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 makes it possible to resolve, at an international level, those cases in which the courts of both of the states concerned declare themselves competent and award custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. Moreover the Convention introduces a system which ensures the immediate return of abducted children. I welcome the accession of Russia to The Hague Convention.
