Considering the number of EU citizens of Russian origin, this accession is vital to ensure EU-wide protection of the children in question.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. — International law, including EU legislation, is based on the fact that the most vulnerable members of society, children, can enjoy the most effective protection in all circumstances. One of the means of doing so is the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of the abduction of children, ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention establishes a system of international cooperation between the contracting States to resolve cases involving the abduction of children abroad. In most cases, the problem is the divorce of parents of different nationality who are exploiting the lack of international cooperation to obtain custody of children. The biggest problem in these cases is the different legal frameworks of the different States. The purpose of the Convention is to provide redress and redress in such cases. It is therefore essential that as many States as possible can join this Convention.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. — For the institutions of the European Union, the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an instrument of crucial importance that has been ratified by all EU Member States. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, a problem which we unfortunately face very often and which entails great suffering for the parties involved. The objective of the Convention is to resolve this issue at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. Similarly, the Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. Therefore, once the Decision has been analysed, as well as the case-law of the COURT of Justice of the EU, I have decided to vote in favour with the desire to promote Russia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution. Russia has ratified the Convention, but its acceptance by all EU Member States is necessary for its implementation between that country and the European Union. To the extent that it is an exclusive competence of the EU, the report refers to the Council Decision by asking Member States about its acceptance, and that is why I have supported it.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour and fully support armenia's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, so that minors with links to the Armenian community can also benefit from EU protection measures in the event of separation or dispute between their parents. The Convention is in fact an instrument of guarantee for children of extraordinary effectiveness, in that it intervenes to bring back to the center of conflicts of couples in crisis of different nationalities the rights of minors applicable in their state of residence, overcoming the temptation of preferential management between the individual countries of origin of the parents and the dramatic risk of international abduction of minors. Europe, the guarantor of human rights, is widening the mesh of measures to protect minors in all the countries that so request, thus preventing unjust national legal favouritism and unholy parenting of child fragility.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction includes 93 countries, including all EU countries. I therefore welcomed russia's inclusion in it. The vote received more than 90% support, which shows the importance of the situation regardless of political views.  The Convention is an essential instrument for ensuring respect for the rights of a child who has been kidnapped by one of his parents. Child abduction is a crime, a violation of human rights, guaranteed by m.in Charter of Fundamental Rights. Every year in the European Union, there are an average of 3000 child abductions between Community countries, kidnappings without the consent of the other parent. In the Committee on Petitions, of which I am a member, we receive many reports of child abdument. These cases are among the most emotional. This shows how significant and frequent this problem is. The accession of new countries to the Convention is good news, which in the future will result in more efficient investigations into the kidnapping of children.  Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her good work.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Hautala report because The Hague Convention of 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an essential instrument for protecting children belonging to parents from different states that exploit potential conflicts of competence between their national courts in order to secure custody of their child. I therefore call on all EU Member States to formally accept the accession of Russia to the Convention, seeing that this is a crucial step to ensure effective implementation and enhanced international cooperation to protect children who fall victim to international abduction. I do urge the Commission to continuously monitor whether the necessary infrastructure is in place to ensure Russia is in a position to fully implement the Convention.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. —I voted against this proposal on Russia's accession to the Hague Convention.  This convention is certainly very useful in the management of jurisdictional disputes in cases of child abductions, most often as a result of divorces. Nevertheless, I question the legitimacy of the European Union to intervene in the ratification of this convention between the Member States and other States.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as I believe the accession of Russia to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (the Convention), which seeks to protect children from abduction across international boundaries, is to be welcomed. It is important that countries acceding to the Convention can participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention. Effective measures now need to be put into place to ensure the rights of the child and that cooperation is fully practicable.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention on civil aspects of the abduction of children is a very important legal instrument. All The Member States of the European Union are parties. The Convention provides a system of cooperation for Contracting States to find solutions to cases of child abduction abroad. These problems most often occur in parents who are divering. In order to obtain childcare, a spouse from another State may take advantage of the lack of cooperation between States. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. Often, the courts of both States concerned consider the case to be within their competence and award the right to custody to a parent of their own nationality. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. I therefore consider it of the utmost importance that all states that have not yet done so should accede to the Convention.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. The Convention aims to protect children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council decision on a statement by which Member States, in the interest of the European Union, accept the accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction from 1980, on the basis that the Convention introduces an international system of cooperation aimed at addressing the global problem of child abduction.  This way opens to the Russian Federation a unified approach to respect and protection of children's rights, which certainly contributes to the strengthening of the social policy of Russian society. The fact is that Russia is lagging behind in developing a common legal framework to protect children's rights. Therefore, I believe that Russian society and the authorities will profit substantially from joining this Convention.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Russia must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - That Convention introduces a system of cooperation between states accessing the contract aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction in the event of the separation of parents from different countries who often take advantage of the lack of cooperation between those states to ensure custody of the child.  The EU has exclusive external competence in this area and therefore a Council decision is needed calling on Member States to accept the accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention and thus its effective entry into force. I strongly support the accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention, and children who are in contact with the Russian community will be insured against kidnapping. It is desirable that the declaration of acceptance of Russia's accession takes effect after the appointment of the Central Authority by Russia.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This file suggested that Parliament approve the Council decision proposal to allow Russia to access the UN Convention that regulates civil aspects on child abduction, mostly concerning the cooperation of the authorities in case of return of wrongfully-removed children and issues of conflict of laws. As the prevention of child abduction is, since the Brussels Regulations on Matrimonial Matters and Parental Responsibility, an exclusive competence of the EU policy to promote the rights of the child, the EU is the actor at international level to improve the application of the 1980 Convention and to encourage third states to accede to it. Article 38(4) of the 1980 Convention stipulates that the Convention applies between the acceding country and such contracting states as will have declared their acceptance of the accession. Therefore, the EU has to decide whether or not to accept the accession of a country. When affirmative, Member States should make the declaration of acceptance concerning the accession in the interest of the EU, because, as the Convention dates from 1980, it does not recognise international organisations such as the EU as an accessing party. EH Bildu has voted in favour, as the primary matter is broadening the application of the UN Convention on child abduction.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the Council's proposal for a decision on Russia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes mechanisms for cooperation between contracting states to remedy jurisdictional conflicts, particularly when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Accession of Russia to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction’ because the EU has exclusive external competence in this field, but the problem is that the Convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organisations. Therefore, the accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention and the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the EU and that country is necessary, especially as the EU has close economic ties with Russia. Children with links to the Russian community will thus be safeguarded against abduction and protection will be afforded to the children in question.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — One of the European Union's special priorities is to protect children and strengthen children's rights, as set out in Article 3 of the Treaty on European Union. The prevention of child abduction is an important measure in the context of child protection. The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction of 25 October 1980, as a multilateral agreement, forms the basis for the immediate repatriation of children abducted abroad or children detained abroad. In the meantime, 86 countries have signed up to this convention, but the validity of the law required official permission from the EU, even if individual countries have already implemented it. That is why I support the request to include the Russian Federation in the Hague Convention.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR)
text: in writing. — On behalf of the Conservative MEPs in the European Parliament and as Conservative spokesman for Legal Affairs, I voted in favour of this report, as the 1980 Hague Convention is an effective tool in the resolution of international child abduction cases and extending its application to more countries, as long as they fully comply with the obligations under the convention, would enhance the legal certainty for those involved in such disputes. However, I strongly support the assessments which many Member States currently undertake in order to carefully assess any third country’s ability to implement the Convention properly before accepting its accession. These assessments prevent any potential risks which may arise from returning children to a third country which does not respect the rule of law or basic legal procedures in family law cases or does not have a competent authority which could verify a child’s well-being. I therefore support calls for the Commission to urgently produce such assessments for these countries, which it is yet to produce.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — In order for the Convention to apply between Russia and the EU, the acceptance of all Member States is required. I supported giving the acceptance, as the Convention is an important international instrument, which seeks to protect children from the harmful effects of abduction and retention across international boundaries by providing a procedure to bring about their prompt return.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The accession of more States to the Hague Convention should be recognised as it enhances the emotional security of children and both parents. The Hague Convention regulates so-called parental kidnappings when one parent, without the consent and knowledge of the other, travels with the child to another country. The Convention restores the situation to the state before the abduction, unless it is incompatible with the best interests of the child (the child has adapted to the new environment). The Convention also facilitates the establishment of contacts between the two parents and the child, which is extremely important in view of the universal right of the child to be contacted and raised by both parents.  When the new member states acceded to the Convention, issues were raised about the revision of EU rules that regulate parental care and responsibility for parents from different EU countries. It is also important to regulate at the level of national law, which recognises parental kidnaping as a crime and ensures fair processes for the care of the child, allowing for an in-depth examination of the child's situation and a review of decisions taken at lower levels. In this context, it is worth stressing the importance of mediation institutions and information campaigns for parents to be aware of the symmetry of their rights and obligations related to the upbringing and care of the child, including the ban on travelling with the child to another country without consent and agreement with the other parent.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. — International abduction of children as a result of separation or divorce is a reality which unfortunately occurs with a habitual frequency. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. International cooperation is essential for the resolution of these disputes. Hence my full support for this resolution. The accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention and, consequently, the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases concerning the European Union and russia is to be welcomed. It is our moral and political duty to ensure that the children in question enjoy protection at Eu ropean Union level.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mrs Hautala's report because, in the light of the close economic ties between the EU and the Russian Federation, it will guarantee children in the territory of the Russian Federation greater protection at EU level. Preventing the abduction of children is, in fact, one of the main objectives of the EU's policy in the area of children's rights. The Convention has also introduced a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Russia is by no means a matter for the European field. So I voted against it.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against this draft resolution because it is trying to make it appear that the European Union would be competent to lead the acceptance by the Member States of the accession of eight countries, including Morocco and Russia, to the Hague Convention on the Fight against International Child Abduction.  However, this convention reserves this acceptance to the States. I therefore do not want to endorse a text that insidiously seeks to strip States of a jurisdiction recognized by public international law.  I should point out in passing that I am in favour of this convention, which has the merit of trying to solve very delicate human problems, and which all the Member States of the European Union have ratified.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution. The following eight countries have ratified the Convention, but its acceptance by all EU Member States is necessary for its implementation between them and the European Union. The countries are Singapore, Russia, Albania, Andorra, Seychelles, Gabon, Armenia and Morocco. To the extent that this is a positive step in the international protection of children, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Russia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Russia's accession to that Convention.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — With regard to the arguments set out above on the proposal for a Council Decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, I consider Russia's accession to that Convention equally important. This Convention promotes the protection of minors in the EU. That is why, and given the large number of economic relations and movement of people between the EU and Russia, I vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction is an important instrument ratified by all Member States of the European Union. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between states aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. It is often the case that parents of a child live separately in different countries, so the biggest problem is the national bias of the legal systems of individual states. Courts in both countries may enter their claims as competent and each of the parents who are their nationals may be granted custody of the child. The purpose of the Convention is to deal with such situations at international level, so as to establish that the competent courts and applicable laws are only from the state that is the place of residence of the child. The Convention also implements a system that ensures the automatic return of children abducted. The European Union now has exclusive jurisdiction in this area, as confirmed by the European Court of Justice. I support the Council Decision, which calls on Member States to accept Russia's accession to the Convention, as this is in the interest of the European Union, will contribute to the coherence and uniformity of the application of EU law.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing — I welcome the accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention. Many citizens of Russian origin also live in the EU. Children who are in some way connected to the Russian community will be protected from kidnapping in this way. Any initiative to expand the number of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction must be supported. This will increase the protection of children from abduction in the territory of the Contracting States and can thus help to return the child to their natural environment more quickly. It is therefore necessary to look for the most effective ways of dealing with international child abduction in order to protect them and strengthen their rights.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Hautala report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of the accession of the Russian Federation to the 1980 Hague Convention on The Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because this Convention adequately addresses at international level the problem of child abduction and, therefore, , is an important legal and political development.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — The accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention is to be welcomed. I fully support this, especially as the EU has close economic ties with Russia. Children with links to the Russian community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — In favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Decision on the accession of the Russian Federation to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention is to be welcomed, especially as the EU has close economic ties with that country.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — Preventing the abduction of children is one of the main objectives of EU policy in the area of children's rights. The primary objective of the Convention is to resolve legal disputes on this issue, ruling that the competent court and the applicable law in this matter are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention has also introduced a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. In view of the above, and in view of the close economic ties between the EU and the Russian Federation, I am voting in favour of russia's accession to the Convention, as it will ensure that children with links to the Convention are given greater protection at EU level.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — (DE) By voting positively on the accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention, I would like to promote the establishment of a system of cooperation between the Contracting States in order to resolve the cases of international child abduction.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — I welcome Russia's accession to the international convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. It aims to reduce legal conflicts between different national jurisdictions in cases of difficult separations of binational couples. In this legal procedure, however, the Commission has once again undermined the sovereignty of Member States by seeking recognition of these accessions on behalf of the European Union, even though the Convention does not recognise international organisations (such as the Union) as a signatory party. I am voting in order to recognise this new membership in the benefit of the protection of children across borders.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — With Russia's annexe to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, the EU takes another step towards achieving one of its priorities, which is the protection and promotion of the rights of the child. Thus, children of Russian origin residing in the EU are protected from abductions.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction aids in establishing the relevant jurisdiction to award custody of the child in question. The EU now has exclusive external competence in facilitating cooperation between contracting states to settle cases of international child abduction but requires each state to accept the accession of new signatories in their own territory. Therefore, I support each Member State’s acceptance of the extension to the Convention as it would ensure the protection of the child’s best interests in cases involving the Russian Federation.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing — I consider the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, ratified by all EU Member States, to be a particularly important instrument enabling States Parties to cooperate more effectively in dealing with cases of international child abduction. I therefore welcome the accession of the Russian Federation to this important convention, and I believe that by working together, we will thus contribute to greater protection of children's rights and to their legal certainty in an international context.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — In order for this Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to have uniform and consistent application in the Union, since all Member States are signatories, and whereas the Union has exclusive competence in the field of international abduction, the European Commission, in the interests of the Union, adopted eight proposals concerning declarations of acceptance by Member States of the acceptance of eight Third States to the 1980 Hague Convention in December 2011.  Following the opinion of the Court of Justice of the Union, which affirmed exclusive external competence, against the Council's view, the Commission submitted these proposals for their proposals to Parliament and the Council.  Because of the importance of this Convention, I consider it extremely important to vote in favour of Russia's support, which obliges it to respect the agreement at international level.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Russia is by no means a matter for the European field. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — It is important to get as many countries on board as possible. The accession will allow those countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which approves Russia's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention is a major instrument in the fight against the illegal detention and displacement of children that occur as a result of family conflicts. In practical terms, it provides for cooperation mechanisms to resolve jurisdictional disputes between jurisdictions in the event of a binational separation. It also guarantees a return system in case of abduction. The larger the number of States parties to this convention, the greater the international guarantee of children's rights.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We believe that the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all EU Member States, in that it introduces a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. The aim is to avoid situations of uncertainty or dangerous legal loopholes. It is stipulates, in fact, that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the State of residence of the child. While the European Union has exclusive external competence in this area (as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13), i.e. individual Member States no longer have the opportunity to act individually by referring to their own legal systems, the problem remains that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organisations. In order to overcome this legal difficulty, the Council has decided that it will be up to the individual Member States to accept, each in relation to its own territory, the accession of new States to the Convention. We therefore welcome Albania's accession to this Convention, so as to ensure that children from the Russian Federation can find protection against abduction at EU level.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because the accession of the Russian Federation is news that should be welcomed, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has close economic ties with Russia. Thus, children linked to this country will be protected from abduction.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this report, together with all the other documents on the agenda, relating to the acceptance by the Member States, in the interest of the EU, of Russia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. The report refers to situations in which children are placed following divorce or separation of parents, conditions in which they may be abducted, and questions the custody of the child of one of the parents, as well as the establishment of the courts competent to deal with the case.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — It is only through international treaties that cases of cross-border child abduction can be effectively addressed. In this respect, I welcomed and voted in favour of the proposal for the accession of the Russian Federation to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because the Hague Convention on child abduction is a crucial piece of legislation. The accession of each new State to the Convention on this issue contributes to international child abduction cases and excludes biased justice. The protection of children's rights must take up a very important role in international relations and justice.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance. The Convention introduces a system which allows contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. In the event that spouses come from different States, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between the States concerned in order to obtain custody of children, and there is often a tendency for the legal systems of individual States to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality. The aim of the Convention is to settle these situations at international level. The EU has close economic ties with that country and children with links to the community of people from the Russian Federation will thus find protection against abduction. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — The primary international instrument intended to protect children from the adverse effects of their illegal removal or detention across the border is the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction.  International child abductions are a serious problem, with the reported number of internationally abducted children worldwide at 300,000 each year. This multilateral agreement currently has 93 co-signaries. The number of abducted children could be further reduced if the number of co-signate states increases. Therefore, I welcome the accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction from 1980.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Russia is by no means a matter for the European field. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support the report on the accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction in 1980, especially in times of crisis and the chilling of relations with the EU. Although the Russian Federation has ratified the Convention, its application to EU member states requires the consent of all member states.  I believe it is in the interest of all of us that problems that can be caused by the non-compliance of legal systems, if the parents of the child come from two different countries, are adequately regulated. Children's rights must come first, and as children have suffered the consequences of legal unregulatedness, I would like to express my full support for this report once again and call on all EU member states to do the same as soon as possible.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — I support a report aimed at adopting declarations of acceptance by Member States of Russia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction, in the interest of the EU. Every year, eight million children disappear in the world, which would mean nearly 22,000 children disappear every day. All our efforts should be geared towards ensuring a better future for our children, and so this Convention, signed by all EU members, should ensure a secure future and the realisation of all children's rights.  As the report states, the most common problem is agreeing on the court's jurisdiction over the allocation of care to children whose parents are from different countries, as well as the lack of communication between the two countries. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such cases in predetermined competent courts and to use the prescribed laws. Countries that approach it are entering a common system of tackling child abduction.  If the legal systems differ too much and the country does not have the means to form a body that will implement the laws and proposals of this Convention, the country cannot even access it. This is precisely the problem that Russia's approach to the Hague Convention has been taking place so slowly – Russia submitted its accession to the Convention on 28 July 2008 and it entered into force on 1 October 2008.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I think it is extremely positive that the Russian Federation has decided to accede to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. As we all know, the EU has close economic and social ties with the Russian Federation, and there are many European citizens who have married Russian citizens. In the event of divorce between nationals of different countries, it is customary for the competent courts of the states concerned to assign the couple's children to the parent who is a national of the State where the child is located, thus facilitating their international abduction. Accession to the Hague Convention, on the other hand, avoids this danger by establishing cooperation between the states of origin of divorced spouses, in order to establish legally the custody of the couple's children.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — With this text, the European Parliament must assess the appropriateness of the recognition by European Union law of Russia's accession to the Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. Thus, the European Union and its 28 Member States are united and apply this convention uniformly when such a dispute with Russia arises.  It is important to solve such problems because they are family dramas that occur when parents find themselves confronted with Kafkaesque judicial systems. Moreover, in view of the situation, I ask that such family situations do not suffer from our conflicting diplomatic relations. I am therefore in favour of anything that can improve the dialogue and resolution of family problems between judicial systems.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction, which occur very often following divorces and separations of parents from different States. More specifically, the Convention, seeking to counter the nationalist tendency of the legal systems of each State, provides that these cases must be tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the state of residence of the minor and also provides for a system ensuring the immediate return of the abducted minor. Although this is currently a matter of the EU's exclusive external competence, the fact is that the Convention does not provide for independent intervention by international organisations. To this extent, in order to ensure the protection of minors who have links with the Russian community, member states must accept Russia's involvement. This proposal for a Council decision rightly calls for such acceptance. I voted in favour.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention, dated 25 October 1980, is an important instrument with regard to the civil aspects of international child abduction. The fact that it is a system of cooperation between the different States makes it easier to find solutions to a problem that persists in our day. Strengthening legislative systems must be an imperative and Russia's involvement in the Hague Convention must be viewed with great satisfaction.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome the accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Russian community will be protected from illegal abduction.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. But the major problem remains the differences between the legal systems of individual Member States. In this case, it is often the case that the courts of the two States concerned declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the state under its jurisdiction. The hague Convention therefore aims to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. I welcome the fact that Russia is joining today.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. — The accession of all parties, as well as european neighbours, to the Hague Convention, the purpose of which is to ensure that children unlawfully removed or kept in any Contracting State are returned quickly is of extremely significant importance. However, I would like to point out that today the actions of some countries, such as the Norwegian authorities, restrict or depriving citizens of other countries of the right of paternity to live there are very worrying. It has been repeatedly reported that parents from Russia, Poland and Lithuania are forced to break the law and kidnap their children from the foster home without seeing any other solution. I would like to draw members' attention to this problem and stress that cultural differences, the traditions of parenting, even the poor knowledge of the language of the local country, the lack of money cannot serve as a basis for depriing children from their rightful parents. In the meantime, the European Parliament must take measures to protect the children and families of european citizens. Norway has already announced a number of illegally removed children and today we are facing a predicament. It is also important that norwegian courts cannot give custody of a child to their grandparents or relatives because they live in another country. We must ensure that the illegal abduction of children is prevented, but on the other hand, we must also protect the interests of children, the interests of the citizens of the European Union. If this is done, parents would no longer have to take drastic steps to save families.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — The purpose of the agreement to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is intended to alleviate conflicts of territorial jurisdiction in this area and to ensure that, in situations of abduction, the immediate return of abducted minors to the State of their residence is guaranteed. That is why I considered it essential to vote in favour of this report, so that Russia, being a country with which the European Union has close political and economic ties, is accepted as a contracting party to this Convention. It should also be said that in this plenary session we voted on 8 such reports.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report which approves Russia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction, which all the Member States of the European Union have ratified.  This convention strengthens cooperation between states, addresses the problem of differences between legal systems that arises and thus establishes the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state where the child resides.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) The accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention of 1980 is a socially important fact for us Europeans. More and more of our fellow citizens are from this country, so I think it is very important that we voted in favour of this report, because the good and serenity of our fellow citizens must take the primacy over all the policies that we can implement.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because I believe it is essential to promote the protection of children's rights.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made it necessary for the Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Russia's accession.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. " I voted in favour of this text which allows the accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention on International Child Abductions. This multilateral treaty protects children abducted outside their usual place of residence. Since the opinion of the Court of Justice on 14 October 2014, the European Union has exclusive jurisdiction over the acceptance of a new state to the convention.  These abductions, which are increasingly common in the divorces of binational couples, give rise to dramatic situations that require a rapid response from the authorities. Membership of the Convention will facilitate cooperation between the European and Russian judicial authorities to organise the rapid return of abducted children, so that the relevant local judge can make a decision on who is responsible for the custody of the child.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Russia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Russia's accession to that Convention.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of the Russian Federation to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention is to be welcomed. The EU has close economic ties with Russia. Children with links to the Russian community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing — It is very important that the provisions of this Convention preventing and prior international child abduction should also apply in other countries which have not yet been bound by them or have merely acceded to the Convention. I therefore voted in favour. It should be stressed that, even in these very difficult family-legal situations, often with a strong geopolitical context, when national courts tend to rule biased, it is always and at all costs necessary to take into account the rights, well-being and dignity of children. A child cannot be abused in any way and cause him emotional, psychological or physical suffering. Even in a situation where an adult is trying to claim the so-called 'right to a child'. A child is no business item that can be disposed of as an object or a tool for blackmailing another, as unfortunately often happens in these cases. The best interests of the child must always come first and everywhere.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — Since the Convention on civil justice aspects of international child abduction signed in the Hague on 25 October 1980 wishes to protect children by ensuring as soon as possible the return of children unlawfully removed or detained in a Contracting State, and wishes to ensure that the rights of care and sighting with a child under the law of one Contracting State are actually respected in another Contracting State, I welcome this decision to join the Hague Convention of Russia.  In my view, it is an important task of the Convention to introduce a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. I consider it positive that the Contracting State will designate a central authority to carry out the obligations provided for by the Convention for such an organ, in particular because the central executive authorities will cooperate with each other and improve cooperation between the competent authorities between the contracting countries in order to ensure the return of the child as closely as possible, and therefore I support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support the Russian Federation’s accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. International cooperation is vital in ensuring the protection of the rights of children.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - That Convention introduces a system of cooperation between states accessing the contract aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction in the event of the separation of parents from different countries, who often take advantage of the lack of cooperation between those states, to ensure custody of the child.  The EU has exclusive external competence in this area and therefore a Council decision is needed calling on Member States to accept the accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention and thus its effective entry into force. I strongly support the accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention, and children who are in contact with the Russian community will be insured against kidnapping. It is desirable that the declaration of acceptance of Russia's accession takes effect after the appointment of the Central Authority by Russia.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing — I support the proposal as it will increase the protection of children of Russian origin from abduction. Especially given that the people of Russia are among the most numerous groups of immigrants from third countries, the approval of this proposal is important.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. — The accession to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction in principle is acceptable, and the extension of these international rules to Russia is to be welcomed. There remains a slight concern that Russia will need further assessment in order to confirm their full compliance with their obligations; however, this has been raised by the Member States in the Council. As the European Parliament does not have a formal role in this process and is only being asked for consent and as the measure is positive in extending the reach of an international standard in difficult situations, I can support this vote.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The accession of more and more States to the Hague Convention develops the appropriate infrastructures and channels of communication between those States, in order to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to deal with custody issues if parents live in different countries. Cooperation between several states to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction is also promoted.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. — The accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention is a necessary step to ensure that Member States parties to the Convention can take as broad a action as possible against the abduction of children abroad. I support this proposal, because the protection of children is of paramount importance in all circumstances and all possible legal instruments must be used.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — The Union now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area under the 1/13 opinion of the Court of Justice. Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. The problem is that the convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem necessities the Council's decision requiring the Member States to accept, each on its own territory, the accession of the Russian Federation to the Convention and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the convention between the European Union and that country. The accession of the Russian Federation is news that should be welcomed, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has close economic ties with Russia. Thus, children linked to this country will be protected from illegal abductions.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a crucial legal instrument to fight against child abduction. This is the reason why I voted in favour of this report. Protecting the rights and interests of children must be one of the priorities of the EU and by supporting the accession of this country to the Hague Convention we reinforce the legal framework to ensure these key principles.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Russiaʼs accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction because, even if a very small one, it is a step forward towards international standards and protection of childhood.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — The European Union does not have the legal capacity to impose anything in this area under the 1980 Hague Convention. The justification for Russia's accession to this convention, which is supposed to be in the interests of the European Union, is therefore not valid.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the eight reports accepting the accession of Armenia, Morocco, Singapore, Albania, Russia, Seychelles, Andorra and Gabon to the 1980 Hague Convention. This Convention lays down the framework of private international law for the recovery of abducted children. Its objective is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to ensure the rights of the child, and mutual respect for custody sentences.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. — 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important document. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases. The accession of the Russian Federation to this Convention is very useful in view of the number of citizens of the Russian Federation or people with Russian roots in the countries of the European Union.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Russia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Russia's accession to that Convention.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This Convention is essentially intended to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held in any Contracting State and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The following countries have deposited the instrument of membership of the Convention: Albania; Andorra; Armenia; Gabon; Morocco; Singapore; Seychelles, Russia. The European Union now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the European Union. However, although Member States no longer have such competence, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise participation in international organisations such as the European Union, so the Council has taken a successive decision in order to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - By approving the accession of the Russian Federation to the Hague Convention, I would like to promote the establishment of a system of cooperation between the Contracting States in order to resolve the cases of international child abduction.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — I welcome Parliament's approval of the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of consent of the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of the accession of the Russian Federation to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (HKÜ). The HKÜ is an almost exemplary solution under international law and an example of fruitful international cooperation for the protection of children. Nothing is worse for a child than a break-up of his parents' relationship. To make matters worse, parents sometimes start a dispute over the child, which is always at the expense of the child. Rarely, but unfortunately still far too often, a parent reacts with child abduction in order to create facts and, for selfish reasons, avoid a custody dispute. The HKÜ provides a sustainable framework to prevent and counteract cross-border child abductions. This cannot in principle prevent the damage done to the child, but it at least offers the possibility of returning the child to his or her usual environment. I am also pleased that, despite sanctions, international cooperation with the Russian Federation still seems to be possible in principle.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of the Convention in question is to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The child abduction situation occurs very often when a couple of people secede, and when the parents come from different states. According to the rapporteur, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the state they represent. The Purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's state of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. Russia has deposited the instrument of support and we have spoken in favour, since this Agreement is in line with the defence of the interests of minors.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI). -
text: Mr. President, bis repetita place. When I was at university I was taught that the great art of pedagogy was repetition. However, I am afraid that most of my colleagues will get tired of it and prefer to stop there and give up the explanations of voting on the other conventions but not, on the other hand, on Mrs Ayala Sender's report on the safety of motorists.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. — UKIP voted against the report, as the EU now has exclusive external competence in this field, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13. The Member States therefore no longer act on their own account. We believe that the UK should be able to act in its own right.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Albania's report on Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Albania's accession to that Convention.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an important legal instrument for the protection of children. The aim of this agreement is to avoid international child abductions by increasing cooperation between States parties. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. Albania's accession to this agreement is to be welcomed. This will extend this sensible legal framework to other countries. This ensures that the best interests of the child are paramount.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I cannot vote in favour: this is a field in which the EU should not have exclusive competence.  Under normal circumstances I would abstain. The assessment of these statesʼ abilities to fully comply with provisions is important for child safety. These countries will be trusted by us to a great extent. The Commission has not undertaken this kind of assessment. The UK Government believes there are ʽserious risks in returning children to a third country that does not respect rule of law or basic legal procedures in family casesʼ. I therefore voted against as this measure has not been properly thought through.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution because it protects the children of Albanian nationals staying on European Union soil from possible illegal abductions.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to accede Albania to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. of 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases and has been ratified by all EU Member States. Often such problems arise when a couple of different nationalities divorce. A lack of cooperation between states is often used to secure custody of a child. The media is full of reports of international child abduction in divorce. The purpose of the Convention is to address these problems at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the State in which the child lives. The Convention also provides for a system to ensure that the abducted child is returned immediately. Albania's accession to the Convention is a positive thing to ensure that these children are protected.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on International Child Abduction aims to manage jurisdictional disputes and conflicts of laws that usually arise from separations of couples. These are, of course, very sensitive situations and states cannot be over-encouraged in this area. Having said that, I voted against this text, which presents a major problem: the European Union is not a state, so its legal capacity to become a party to the Hague Convention is highly questionable. This prerogative is reserved for states by public international law, and I refuse to vote on a text that implicitly calls it into question. Moreover, the report explains in the explanatory statement that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states".  Thus, the approval of Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of child abduction cannot be within the competence of the European Union.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 is a very important instrument that allows the contracting parties to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. It sets up a system to expedite the return of the abducted child to the country where he or she usually resides. Through the Council's decision, the Member States each accept Albania's accession to the Convention and therefore the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the European Union and that country.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal because it will solve the problems that are often suffered when couples from different States separate and dispute the custody of their children, even reaching the abduction of them. This Convention will resolve situations at the international level and, more importantly, minors will be protected from illegal abduction. I thank Albania for its accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. Generally, this situation arises when a couple divorces or separates. The statement of reasons for the report thus tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Albania must not fall within the European scope, so I voted against it. Moreover, when we know that Albania is a hub for child trafficking at European level, we can only disapprove of this demand until these internal problems are resolved.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction provides for cooperation between signatory States to ensure that a child or child under 16 who has been arbitrarily "abducted" by a parent returns to the place of family residence pending a judicial ruling, unless the return foretoos a serious danger to his or her safety. I believe it is of fundamental importance for the protection of our children that this convention be ratified and respected by more and more States. I therefore voted to support Albania's accession among the new signatory countries.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Albania's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction, and therefore the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome Albania's accession to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Albanian community will be protected from illegal abduction.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports Albania's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Russia's accession to the Convention is good news. The rapporteur fully supports this accession, especially since a significant number of EU citizens come from Albania. Children with ties to the Albanian community would therefore be protected from legal abduction.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — This document relates to the cooperation of states in the event of a child abduction of an international character. Namely, if parents come from different countries, it often happens that in the event of a disconnect or divorce, they try to exploit legal loopholes and the absence of clearly defined cooperation between countries in order to unlawfully appropriate the child.  The Hague Convention therefore seeks to establish clear international practices in such cases. The betterment of the child is being put to the forefront, and that is why I support the report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted yes because it is fundamental to have Albania’s adhesion to this Convention, in order to protect children in Albania.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interest of the European Union, of Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.     The European Union has shown an extremely high concern over the prevention of child abductions over the years, constantly improving the implementation of the Convention. That is why Albania deposited the instrument of accession to the 1980 Convention on 4 May 2007 and the Convention entered into force on 1 August 2007 with EU Member States now fulfilling their obligation to practically restore a status quo of the cooperation system.   The Convention basically restores a system of cooperation between the EU and Albania, whereby situations such as the illicit movements of children in that country can be easily identifiable but also punishable. So measures to ensure the safety of children can only be welcomed.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The Hague Convention is a good thing and the protection of minors must be extended as far as possible to other states that wish to be part of it.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction was established on 25 October 1980. The Member States of the European Union have all ratified it. All too often we hear cases of child abduction by a parent who obtains custody in his or her country of origin during a binational separation. A uniform legal basis for determining the jurisdiction in this matter is essential. We must ensure the protection of abducted children. I voted in favour of this resolution approving Albania's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of Albania to the Hague Convention, as this proposal will assist authorities in returning wrongfully removed children, and will help to address issues of conflict of laws (competence of courts). In real terms, it will provide a pragmatic solution where a child has been abducted and taken to another country without the consent of one of the parents. Furthermore, the overarching principle of the proposal is that the welfare of the child – something that should always be paramount – should be the first and foremost consideration in child care proceedings. That is why it was necessary to support this proposal.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Some States exploit the lack of cooperation between national authorities in order to obtain custody of minors where there is proceedings pending between two spouses from different countries. Accession to the Hague Convention establishes jurisdiction in the State in which the child resides, limiting disputes over jurisdiction and thus speeding up proceedings. That is why we are voting in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. —I refused to sign in favour of this report for a simple reason: an international convention is a legal standard that must be signed by sovereign states.  The European Union does not have this legal status and its legitimacy is therefore questionable, with regard to its legal capacity to become a party to the Hague Convention. It is clear, however, that child abductions are a very serious issue and therefore states continue to work actively together to prevent these tragedies and take responsibility for the civil aspects they take on.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention is a fundamental instrument for ensuring the return of children unlawfully transferred or detained abroad by a parent and for ensuring respect for custody and visiting rights in all States.
