My country, Italy, was the only country to support, even before the Court intervened, the Exclusive Competence of the Union in this field, instead of full regulatory and operational coordination between States, instead of approaches aimed at protecting the parent, who is a citizen, also to the detriment of the interests of the child and the rights of citizens of other countries. I believe that, for the proper application of the Convention, the Member States will have to comply with certain requirements: efficient central authorities that can really set themselves as a reference for administrative cooperation; rules preventing discriminatory practices; guarantees of access to justice and, in general, full alignment with the principles of the rule of law. Having said that, I welcome Albania's accession, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance which has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. It enables the Contracting States effectively to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international abduction of children. The problem arises in couples who separate, where spouses are of different nationalities, because there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states. In the various States there are legal systems which tend to seek to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality, leaving the right of custody of dubious interpretation. In order to deal with these situations at international level, the Convention places the child at the centre of the problem by establishing that the court of jurisdiction is the court where the child resides. In view of all this, the accession of the State of Albania to the Convention is to be welcomed, given also the favourable opinion of the rapporteur, who fully supports the measure. Children with links to the Albanian community will thus find protection against abduction at EU level. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Albania's accession to the important Hague Convention of 25 October 1980. Given Albania's geographical proximity and strong cultural ties with my country, I am pleased with this accession. In fact, since the 1990s, there have been many Albanian citizens who have settled in Italy, and now the children of this state will find better protection against abduction.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument. It has been ratified by all the EU Member States. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In many instances, these problems arise when a couple has separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those states in order to secure custody of the child. The biggest problem in such cases is the differences between the legal systems of individual states. It may often be that the courts in both of the states concerned declare themselves competent, with each of them awarding custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at an international level.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a key instrument in the context of judicial cooperation between contracting States in the resolution of cases of international child abduction. This Convention aims to harmonise the legal systems other than those states which normally declare themselves both competent to adjudicate the action and declare custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent, and the criterion of the State of residence of the minor is adopted with the Convention. As this matter currently is the exclusive external competence of the Union, a Council decision is necessary which call for the Member States to accept the access of third countries to the Hague Convention. I support the Hautala report in this regard and congratulate the Albanian State on its access to the Convention, thereby taking a step towards protecting its minors from abduction.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States of Albania's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. In an international scenario in which the mobility of families across national borders is increasing, the phenomenon of the abduction of children is particularly important in the event of couples' crises. Protecting the child from illegal transfer or non-return is a global problem as well as a key element of the EU programme. Article 24 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union states that children have the right to protection and their interests 'must be considered pre-eed'. I therefore support the accession of the Republic of Albania because it is only through international cooperation that it is possible to settle the relevant issues of custody of minors and ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. Children with links to the Albanian community can thus be better protected from any danger of abduction.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — We often hear of child abductions taking place in Member States, especially when parents and family members originate from different countries. When this happens within Member States, that child is already protected by legislation, but it is important to protect children also when abducted to non-EU countries.  The accession of more countries to the Hague Convention is welcomed as it extends the network of protection for children. The Hague Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In cases where a couple has separated and the parents are from different States, lack of cooperation between these States can create a situation which is not in the best interests of the child involved.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — MePs intend to ask EU Member States to formally recognise Albania's accession to the Hague Convention on the International Abduction of Children. The Convention provides effective tools for resolving this type of dispute between countries. It should be added and pointed out that there is a lack of European harmonisation of family law. In this way, states could resolve these cases of child abduction more efficiently. I am voting in favour of Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Albania's report on Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Albania's accession to that Convention.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which encourages EU Member States to accept the accession of Albania to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction. This would allow the Convention to enter into force between Albania and the EU and thus help to ensure the prompt return of abducted children.  The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction governs cooperation among the contracting states to settle international child abduction cases, including a system to ensure the immediate return of abducted children to their country of habitual residence, so as to allow the judicial authorities of that country to solve the case. All EU Member States have ratified the Convention.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes to support the European Parliament for the accession of the Republic of Albania to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This international agreement, ratified by all EU Member States, aims to establish a system of cooperation in the context of international child abductions, most often intervening in cases of separation or divorce of binational couples. In the event of a referral to the courts of the two States concerned, they may declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the State under its jurisdiction.  This convention therefore specifies the jurisdiction of national courts and guarantees a system allowing the immediate return of the abducted child. It is necessary for this international regime to be as broad as possible, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Albanian origin on its soil. In this way, children linked to this community will be protected from illegal abduction. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, ratified by all EU Member States, aims to protect children from international abduction by providing for a procedure for their rapid return. Through the vote on this text, the aim is to invite the Council of the European Union to ask the Member States to accept the accession of the Republic of Albania. Extending the territorial scope of the Convention to Albania is a good move to ensure the best possible protection of the child in situations of international abduction.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of Albania's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction, because in this way minors with links to the Albanian community will find greater protection against this phenomenon. This Convention allows cooperation between the Contracting States in order to find solutions to cases of international abduction of children. This problem arises when spouses from different States, as a result of their separation, exploit the lack of cooperation between the States concerned in order to obtain custody of the children. The aim of this Convention is to settle such situations at international level by establishing that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Albania must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. — Dear Colleagues, I voted in favour of my colleague Hautala's report on Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, because I believe that statistics on the increased number of abductions in itself speak to the urgent need for cooperation.  According to the data currently available, in 2008 the number of applications for return of children submitted only within the EU on the basis of the 1980 Hague Convention was 990. That means 35% more than in 2003. Unfortunately, the rise in crimes against children is also high. I cannot help but note that it is the kidnapping that is the first step for trafficking in human beings and exploitation for criminal purposes.  I welcome Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention and call on all Member States under this international instrument to take measures to ensure its practical application.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention aims to ensure the immediate return of children who have been moved or unlawfully detained in one of the Contracting States and to ensure that custody and communication rights under the law of one of the Contracting States are respected in the other Contracting States.  This Convention creates the infrastructure and communication channels between 92 states to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to arrange custody issues if parents live in different countries.      We are voting in favour of the accession of other states to the Hague Convention, as it protects children who fall victim to disagreements between their parents. The Convention ensures cooperation between States to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — Three EU countries (UK, Germany and Spain) are among the five countries in the world where there are the most cases of international child abduction. Preventing child abduction should be an essential part of EU policy to promote the rights of the child. The rights of the child should be a priority. The best interests of the child over that of the parents must be primed.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention provides the private international law framework for recovery of abducted children. Its aim is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to safeguard the prompt return of the child and the mutual enforcement of judgments regarding custody and access rights. The vote refers to the acceptance of Albania, which has joined the Convention in recent years. This agreement will benefit children and families in Wales so I voted in favour.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome this Proposal from the Council to accept The Hague Convention's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention. The issue of the defence of children's rights is of central importance and it therefore seems very positive that more and more states should be included, especially given that there are a great many people on European soil from the countries that are now applying for membership, which will facilitate the resolution of cases of abduction between a Member State and these third countries. However, while it is good that all the States of the European Union have acceded to the Convention, I cannot help noticing that the concept of 'good of the child' is often interpreted instrumentally. I am thinking, for example, of Germany, whose children's office, the Jugendamt, actuallyes the good of the child for the good of the German child, depriving the non-German parent and the child himself of many fundamental rights, including some of the founding rights of the Hague Convention. Unfortunately, the problem is not confined to Germany alone, and Europe is powerless to witness these abuses because it does not have the power to intervene in the family law of the individual Member States. That is why I believe that there is an urgent need for harmonisation of legislation in this area.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart. As parents come from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those same States to obtain custody of minors. In these cases, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of the countries concerned to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Convention aims to remedy such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. I voted in favour of albania's acceptance of the Hague Convention in the best interests of minors who have links with the Albanian community and who will thus be protected from abduction.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart, and the Convention resolves these types of situations on an international scale, by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the state of residence of the minor. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I am voting against this text because by becoming part of the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction, the European Union is also giving itself a space for interpretation of this text. Let us not be fooled because under the good intentions of defending the interests of children nothing is done - for example - against the expansion of the barbaric practice of surrogacy within the Union. On the other hand, it is up to the Member States to determine sovereignly who may or may not join the Convention, I challenge, once again, this transfer of competence.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The child abduction situation occurs with some frequency when a couple, with members from different States, is reunited. Not accompanying some of the considerations made during this debate concerning the legal systems of each State, it is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Convention aims to address this type of situation at international level. It is its objective to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the rights of custody and visitation existing in a Contracting State. These are fair and relevant objectives. Albania has deposited the instrument for the convention.  The EU now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the EU. However, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise the participation of international organisations such as the EU. For this reason, the Council had to take a successive decision in order to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I am pleased that Albania is adjoining the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, and that is why I voted in favour of the report. The Convention provides effective means of settling disputes arising from international abductions of minors as a result of separation or divorce, by establishing that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — The subject of international child abduction largely concerns spouses or couples in which individuals from different countries of the world decide to abuse the situation and wrongly adopt a child after a divorce or break-up. Such situations are helped by the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Children often become a means of dealing with accounts between spouses or former partners with different citizenships. The national courts, often outside the European Union, often grant custody of a parent who is a citizen of a state to which that court is competent, thanks to certain national tendencies. The Convention resolves such situations in such a way that the assignment of the child is decided by the court in the State where he or she resides, regardless of where one of the parents was brought. The EU now has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice. This means that Member States are no longer acting at their discretion. It is therefore necessary to adopt a Council Decision requiring The Member States to adopt, in their own territory, albania's accession to the Convention and thus the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that State. The adoption of the convention in question will provide increased protection for children associated in any way with the Albanian community.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome Albania's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the accession of other States to the Hague Convention, as it protects children who fall victim to disagreements between their parents. The Convention ensures that the children return to their normal residence in the event of abduction.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — I strongly support the adoption of stronger cooperative measures to prevent cases of international child abduction. Greater coordination between states is necessary to avoid the temptation, by one of the parents, to secure custody of a child following a separation or a divorce. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 makes it possible to resolve, at an international level, those cases in which the courts of both of the states concerned declare themselves competent and award custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. Moreover the Convention introduces a system which ensures the immediate return of abducted children. I welcome the accession of Albania to The Hague Convention. Considering the number of EU citizens of Albanian origin, this accession is vital to ensure EU-wide protection of the children in question.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. — International law, including EU legislation, is based on the fact that the most vulnerable members of society, children, can enjoy the most effective protection in all circumstances. One of the means of doing so is the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of the abduction of children, ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention establishes a system of international cooperation between the contracting States to resolve cases involving the abduction of children abroad. In most cases, the problem is the divorce of parents of different nationality who are exploiting the lack of international cooperation to obtain custody of children. The biggest problem in these cases is the different legal frameworks of the different States. The purpose of the Convention is to provide redress and redress in such cases. It is therefore essential that as many States as possible can join this Convention.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. — For the institutions of the European Union, the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an instrument of crucial importance that has been ratified by all EU Member States. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, a problem which we unfortunately face very often and which entails great suffering for the parties involved. The objective of the Convention is to resolve this issue at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. Similarly, the Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. Therefore, once the Decision has been analysed, as well as the case-law of the Court of Justice of the EU, I have decided to vote in favour with the desire to promote Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution. Albania has ratified the Convention, but its acceptance by all EU Member States is necessary for its implementation between Albania and the European Union. To the extent that it is an exclusive competence of the EU, the report refers to the Council Decision by asking Member States about its acceptance, and that is why I have supported it.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour and fully support Albania's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, so that minors with links to the Albanian community can also benefit from EU protection measures in the event of separation or dispute between their parents. The Convention is in fact an instrument of guarantee for children of extraordinary effectiveness, in that it intervenes to bring back to the center of conflicts of couples in crisis of different nationalities the rights of minors applicable in their state of residence, overcoming the temptation of preferential management between the individual countries of origin of the parents and the dramatic risk of international abduction of minors. Europe, the guarantor of human rights, is widening the mesh of measures to protect minors in all the countries that so request, thus preventing unjust national legal favouritism and unholy parenting of child fragility.  The measure is particularly important because it regulates the relationship with a country with which many European states have very close ties and relationships. We hope that these regulations will give us new and stronger rights for children in Europe.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction includes 93 countries, including all EU countries. I therefore welcomed the inclusion of Albania in it. The vote received more than 90% support, which shows the importance of the situation regardless of political views.  The Convention is an essential instrument for ensuring respect for the rights of a child who has been kidnapped by one of his parents. Child abduction is a crime, a violation of human rights, guaranteed by m.in Charter of Fundamental Rights. Every year in the European Union, there are an average of 3000 child abductions between Community countries, kidnappings without the consent of the other parent. In the Committee on Petitions, of which I am a member, we receive many reports of child abdument. These cases are among the most emotional. This shows how significant and frequent this problem is. The accession of new countries to the Convention is good news, which in the future will result in more efficient investigations into the kidnapping of children.  Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her good work.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Hautala report because The Hague Convention of 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an essential instrument for protecting children belonging to parents from different states that exploit potential conflicts of competence between their national courts in order to secure custody of their child.  I therefore call on all EU Member States to formally accept the accession of Albania to the Convention, seeing that this is a crucial step to ensure effective implementation and enhanced international cooperation to protect children who fall victim to international abduction. I do urge the Commission to continuously monitor whether the necessary infrastructure is in place to ensure Albania is in a position to fully implement the Convention.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I fully support Albania's accession to the Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction, firstly because many European citizens are of Albanian origin and have close links with Albania and, secondly, because it is another important area of cooperation with a country that is ever closer to Europe.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted against this proposal on Albania's accession to the Hague Convention.  This convention is certainly very useful in the management of jurisdictional disputes in cases of child abductions, most often as a result of divorces. Nevertheless, I question the legitimacy of the European Union to intervene in the ratification of this convention between the Member States and other States.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as I believe the accession of Albania to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (the Convention), which seeks to protect children from abduction across international boundaries, is to be welcomed. It is important that countries acceding to the Convention can participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention. Effective measures now need to be put into place to ensure the rights of the child and that cooperation is fully practicable.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention on civil aspects of the abduction of children is a very important legal instrument. All The Member States of the European Union are parties. The Convention provides a system of cooperation for Contracting States to find solutions to cases of child abduction abroad. These problems most often occur in parents who are divering. In order to obtain childcare, a spouse from another State may take advantage of the lack of cooperation between States. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. Often, the courts of both States concerned consider the case to be within their competence and award the right to custody to a parent of their own nationality. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. I therefore consider it of the utmost importance that all states that have not yet done so should accede to the Convention.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. The Convention aims to protect children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on a statement by which Member States, in the interest of the European Union, accept Albania's accession to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction in 1980, because I think it is necessary for Albania to be further involved in the protection of children's rights.  I believe that Albania, in the international law context the Convention provides, will be able to counter malicious child abductions more strongly and efficiently. In this context, international prevention of child abduction and strong cooperation between the signatories of this Convention are important. I support that child abduction cases be dealt with in competent courts and under the applicable law of the countries where children reside, and I strongly condemn any such violence.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Albania must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This report suggested that Parliament approve the proposal for a Council decision to allow Albania to access the UN Convention that regulates civil aspects of child abduction, mostly concerning cooperation of authorities for the return of wrongfully removed children and issues of conflict of laws. As prevention of child abduction is, since the Brussels Regulations on matrimonial matters and parental responsibility, an exclusive competence of the EU policy to promote the rights of the child, the EU is the player at international level to improve application of the 1980 Convention and to encourage third States to accede it. Article 38(4) of the 1980 Convention stipulates that the Convention applies between the acceding country and such Contracting States as will have declared their acceptance of the accession. Therefore, the EU has to decide whether to accept the accession of a country. When it does so, Member States should make the declaration of acceptance concerning the accession in the interest of the EU; because as the Convention dates from 1980, it does not recognise international organisations such as the EU as an accessing Party. EH Bildu has voted in favour, as the primary matter is broadening of the application of the UN Convention on Child Abduction.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the Council's proposal for a decision on Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes mechanisms for cooperation between contracting states to remedy jurisdictional conflicts, particularly when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Accession of Albania to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction’ because the EU has exclusive external competence in this field, but the problem is that the Convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organisations. Therefore, the accession of Albania to the Convention and the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the EU and that country is necessary, especially as many EU citizens are of Albanian origin. Children with links to the Albanian community will thus be safeguarded against abduction and protection will be afforded to the children in question.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — One of the European Union's special priorities is to protect children and strengthen children's rights, as set out in Article 3 of the Treaty on European Union. The prevention of child abduction is an important measure in the context of child protection. The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction of 25 October 1980, as a multilateral agreement, forms the basis for the immediate repatriation of children abducted abroad or children detained abroad. In the meantime, 86 countries have signed up to this convention, but the validity of the law required official permission from the EU, even if individual countries have already implemented it. That is why I support the request to include Albania in the Hague Convention.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR)
text: in writing. — On behalf of the Conservative MEPs in Parliament and as Conservative spokesman for legal affairs, I voted in favour of this report as the 1980 Hague Convention is an effective tool in the resolution of international child abduction cases and extending its application to more countries, as long as they fully comply with the obligations under the Convention, would enhance the legal certainty for those involved in such disputes.  However, I strongly support the assessments which many Member States currently undertake in order to carefully assess any third country’s ability to implement the Convention properly before accepting its accession. These assessments prevent any potential risks which may arise from returning children to a third country which does not respect rule of law or basic legal procedures in family law cases, or does not have a competent authority which could verify a child’s well-being.  I therefore support calls for the Commission to urgently produce such assessments for these countries, which it has yet to produce.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — In order for the Convention to apply between Albania and the EU, the acceptance of all Member States is required. I supported giving the acceptance, as the Convention is an important international instrument, which seeks to protect children from the harmful effects of abduction and retention across international boundaries by providing a procedure to bring about their prompt return.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. — International abduction of children as a result of separation or divorce is a reality which unfortunately occurs with a habitual frequency. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. International cooperation is essential for the resolution of these disputes. Hence my full support for this resolution.  Albania's accession to the Convention and, consequently, the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases concerning the European Union and albania is to be welcomed. It is our moral and political duty to ensure that Albanian children enjoy protection at European Union level.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mrs Hautala's report because I believe that it will help to ensure adequate protection of minors against international abduction. Given the high percentage of Albanian citizens living in EU territory, I welcome Albania's accession to the Hague Convention. The 1980 Hague Convention is a prime instrument in that it introduces a system which allows contracting states to cooperate on the international abduction of children and thus to protect them more effectively.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states.  I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Albania must not fall within the European scope. That is why I abstained.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution. The following eight countries have ratified the Convention, but its acceptance by all EU Member States is necessary for its implementation between them and the European Union. The countries are Singapore, Russia, Albania, Andorra, Seychelles, Gabon, Armenia and Morocco. To the extent that this is a positive step in the international protection of children, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Albania's report on Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Albania's accession to that Convention.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — In accordance with the arguments set out above on the proposal for a Council Decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction, I also consider Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention equally important. In this way, and considering that many EU citizens are of Albanian origin, I vote on this proposal, as this will improve on the protection of minors.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted for Albania’s accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction with respect to the EU’s and Albania’s commitment to protect children.  We know child parental abduction can prove difficult once international borders are involved. The Hague Convention helps alleviate issues nations face when approaching international custody rights. As Albania becomes more integrated with EU society we must accept that these issues will surface from time to time.  As the European Parliament, accepting Albania’s accession will strengthen cooperation between EU and Albanian authorities. As Albania continues its progress towards EU ascension, we Member States must be open to humanitarian progress. I welcome Albania’s accession to the Hague Convention as another nation willing to protect children.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction is an important instrument ratified by all Member States of the European Union. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between states aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. It is often the case that parents of a child live separately in different countries, so the biggest problem is the national bias of the legal systems of individual states. Courts in both countries may enter their claims as competent and each of the parents who are their nationals may be granted custody of the child. The purpose of the Convention is to deal with such situations at international level, so as to establish that the competent courts and applicable laws are only from the state that is the place of residence of the child. The Convention also implements a system that ensures the automatic return of children abducted. The European Union now has exclusive jurisdiction in this area as confirmed by the European Court of Justice. I support the Council Decision, which calls on Member States to accept Albania's accession to the Convention, as this is in the interest of the European Union, will contribute to the coherence and uniformity of the application of EU law.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing — Any initiative to expand the number of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction should be supported. This will increase the protection of children from abduction in the territory of the Contracting States and can thus help to return the child to their natural environment more quickly. It is therefore necessary to look for the most effective ways of dealing with international child abduction in order to protect them and strengthen their rights. Many citizens of Albanian origin also live in the EU. Children who are in some way connected to the Albanian community will be protected from kidnapping in this way.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Hautala report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on The Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because this Convention adequately addresses at international level the problem of child abduction and, therefore, , is an important legal and political development.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — The accession of Albania to the Convention is to be welcomed. I fully support this, especially as many EU citizens are of Albanian origin. Children with links to the Albanian community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Decision on Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Abduction. The main problem in these cases is the tendency of the legal systems of individual States to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality. The aim of the Convention is to deal with such situations at international level.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 1980 introduced a system allowing contracting states to cooperate on the international abduction of children. Its essential aim is to settle international disputes in this specific field, through provisions to establish the competent court and the applicable law. In view of Albania's future accession to the EU and in view of the fact that a high percentage of EU citizens are of Albanian origin, I welcome albania's accession to the Convention.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — (DE) My positive vote on Albania's accession to the Hague Convention should help to resolve cases of international child abduction by introducing a system of cooperation between the Contracting States at international level.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. —I welcome Albania's accession to the international convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. It aims to reduce legal conflicts between different national jurisdictions in cases of difficult separations of binational couples. In this legal procedure, however, the Commission has once again undermined the sovereignty of Member States by seeking recognition of these accessions on behalf of the European Union, even though the Convention does not recognise international organisations (such as the Union) as a signatory party. I vote in support of Albania's efforts towards the uses it might suggest to the occupiers of Kosovo

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — With Albania's membership of the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, the EU takes another step towards achieving one of its priorities, which is the protection and promotion of the rights of the child. Thus, children of Albanian origin residing in the EU are protected from abductions.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction aids in establishing the relevant jurisdiction to award custody of the child in question. The EU now has exclusive external competence in facilitating cooperation between contracting states to settle cases of international child abduction but requires each state to accept the accession of new signatories in their own territory. Therefore, I support each Member State’s acceptance of the extension to the Convention as it would ensure the protection of the child’s best interests in cases involving Albania.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing — I consider the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, ratified by all EU Member States, to be a particularly important instrument enabling States Parties to cooperate more effectively in dealing with cases of international child abduction. I therefore welcome Albania's accession and believe that accession to the Convention will contribute to greater protection of children's rights and legal certainty in the international context.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of Albania's membership of the 1980 Hague Convention, because I believe that, through the international obligations laid down by this Convention, the signatory States will have a legal environment conducive to safeguarding the real interests of children and custody and visiting issues in the Contracting States.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Albania is by no means a matter for the European field. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — It is important to get as many countries on board as possible. The accession will allow those countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which approves Albania's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention is a major instrument in the fight against the illegal detention and displacement of children that occur as a result of family conflicts. In practical terms, it provides for cooperation mechanisms to resolve jurisdictional disputes between jurisdictions in the event of a binational separation. It also guarantees a return system in case of abduction. The larger the number of States parties to this convention, the greater the international guarantee of children's rights.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We believe that the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all EU Member States, in that it introduces a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. The aim is to avoid situations of uncertainty or dangerous legal loopholes. It is stipulates, in fact, that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the State of residence of the child. While the European Union has exclusive external competence in this area (as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13), i.e. individual Member States no longer have the opportunity to act individually by referring to their own legal systems, the problem remains that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organisations. In order to overcome this legal difficulty, the Council has decided that it will be up to the individual Member States to accept, each in relation to its own territory, the accession of new States to the Convention. We therefore welcome Albania's accession to this Convention, so as to ensure that children with links to the Albanian community can find protection against abduction at EU level.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because Albania's accession is a welcome development, especially given the fact that the European Union has many ethnic Albanians on its soil. In this way, children connected to this community will be protected from abduction.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this report, together with all the other documents on the agenda, relating to the acceptance by the Member States, in the interest of the EU, of Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. The report refers to situations in which children are placed following divorce or separation of parents, conditions in which they may be abducted, and questions the custody of the child of one of the parents, as well as the establishment of the courts competent to deal with the case.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — An important measure to combat international child abduction is transnational standards of protection and corresponding contractual conventions. In this respect, I welcomed and voted in favour of the proposal for Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because the Hague Convention on child abduction is a crucial piece of legislation. The accession of each new State to the Convention on this issue contributes to international child abduction cases and excludes biased justice. The protection of children's rights must take up a very important role in international relations and justice.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance. The Convention introduces a system which allows contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. In the event that spouses come from different States, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between the States concerned in order to obtain custody of children, and there is often a tendency for the legal systems of individual States to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality. The aim of the Convention is to settle these situations at international level and the many citizens of the European Union are from Albania and children with links to the Albanian community will thus find protection against abduction. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — Children need a father and a mother and parents are simply expected to be parents, regardless of the circumstances that occur during their life together and ultimately result in divorce.  In the event of such an unravelling of the situation, it is essential that the existence and proper functioning of a reliable child protection mechanism is essential. The Hague Convention on civil justice aspects of international child abduction from 1980 is currently the most useful binding legislation for the protection of children when it comes to international kidnapping, so I welcome Albania's accession to this Convention.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Albania is by no means a matter for the European field. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support the report on Albania's accession to the Hague Convention on Civil Law Aspects of International Child Abduction in 1980, especially as it is a European candidate country for full EU membership Although Albania has ratified the Convention, its application to EU member states requires the consent of all Member States.  I believe it is in the interest of all of us that problems that can be caused by the non-compliance of legal systems, if the parents of the child come from two different countries, are adequately regulated. Children's rights must come first, and as children have suffered the consequences of legal unregulatedness, I would like to express my full support for this report once again and call on all EU member states to do the same as soon as possible.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — In order to resolve the cases of abducted children of Albania and the European Union, I support this report for accepting accession to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction from 1980. Every year, eight million children disappear in the world, which would mean nearly 22,000 children disappear every day. All our efforts should be geared towards ensuring a better future for our children, and so this Convention, signed by all EU members, should ensure a secure future and the realisation of all children's rights.  As the report states, the most common problem is agreeing on the court's jurisdiction over the allocation of care to children whose parents are from different countries, as well as the lack of communication between the two countries. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such cases in predetermined competent courts and to use the prescribed laws. Countries that approach it are entering a common system of tackling child abduction.  If the legal systems differ too much and the country does not have the means to form a body that will implement the laws and proposals of this Convention, the country cannot even access it. This is also the problem that Albania's approach to the Hague Convention is proceeding so slowly – Albania submitted its accession to the Convention on 4 May 2007, and it entered into force on 1 August 2007.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) In the case of Albania too, in view of its close relations and geographical proximity with the European Union, and Italy in particular, I am pleased that albania's accession to the Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction is accepted. With this accession, in the event of divorce of a couple, the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence. Furthermore, in the event that the child is not currently in the territory of residence, the Convention introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — With this text, the European Parliament must assess the appropriateness of the recognition by European Union law of Albania's accession to the Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. Thus, the European Union and its 28 Member States are united and apply this convention uniformly when such a dispute with Albania arises. It is important to solve such problems because they are family dramas that occur when parents find themselves confronted with Kafkaesque judicial systems. I am therefore in favour of anything that can improve the dialogue and resolution of family problems between judicial systems.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction, which occur very often following divorces and separations of parents from different States. More specifically, the Convention, seeking to counter the nationalist tendency of the legal systems of each State, provides that these cases must be tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the state of residence of the minor and also provides for a system ensuring the immediate return of the abducted minor. Although this is currently a matter of the EU's exclusive external competence, the fact is that the Convention does not provide for independent intervention by international organisations. To this extent and in order to ensure the protection of minors who have links with the Albanian community, member states need to accept Albania's membership. This proposal for a Council decision rightly calls for such acceptance. I voted in favour.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention, dated 25 October 1980, is an important instrument with regard to the civil aspects of international child abduction. The fact that it is a system of cooperation between the different States makes it easier to find solutions to a problem that persists in our day. Strengthening legislative systems must be an imperative and Albania's membership of the Hague Convention must be viewed with great satisfaction.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Albania's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome Albania's accession to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Albanian community will be protected from illegal abduction.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. But the major problem remains the differences between the legal systems of the Member States. In this case, it is often the case that the courts of the two States concerned declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the state under its jurisdiction. The hague Convention is therefore intended to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. I welcome the fact that Albania is now joining.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — Because I believe that the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 establishes a fundamental instrument of cooperation between Contracting States with regard to the international abduction of children, I voted in favour of this report, with the aim of promoting concerted and swift solutions to help solve these crimes on an increasingly global scale. Since Albania is a neighbouring country of the European Union, which has many citizens residing in European countries and where conflicts of this order may arise, it is essential that Member States accept the country's membership of the Convention as a means of protecting minors from kidnapping throughout the territory of the European Union.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report which approves Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction, which all the Member States of the European Union have ratified. This convention strengthens cooperation between states, addresses the problem of differences between legal systems that arises and thus establishes the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state where the child resides.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome Mrs Hautala's report because it is a duty to our citizens to cooperate with other countries, in this case Albania, in the field of child abduction. I believe that policies in favour of children are fundamental to our society and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because I believe it is essential to promote the protection of children's rights.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made it necessary for the Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept Albania's accession, each with regard to its territory.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text which allows Albania to join the Hague Convention on International Child Abductions. This multilateral treaty protects children abducted outside their usual place of residence. Since the opinion of the Court of Justice on 14 October 2014, the European Union has exclusive jurisdiction over the acceptance of a new state to the convention.  These abductions, which are increasingly common in the divorces of binational couples, give rise to dramatic situations that require a rapid response from the authorities. Membership of the Convention will facilitate cooperation between the European and Albanian judicial authorities to organise the rapid return of abducted children, so that the relevant local judge can make a decision on who is responsible for the custody of the child.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Albania's report on Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Albania's accession to that Convention.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of the Albania to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The accession of Albania to the Convention is to be welcomed. Many EU citizens are of Albanian origin. Children with links to the Albanian community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing — It is very important that the provisions of this Convention preventing and prior international child abduction should also apply in other countries which have not yet been bound by them or have merely acceded to the Convention. I therefore voted in favour. It should be stressed that, even in these very difficult family and legal situations, often with a strong geo-political context, when national courts tend to rule biased, it is always and at all costs necessary to take into account the rights, well-being and dignity of children. A child cannot be abused in any way and cause him emotional, psychological or physical suffering. Even in a situation where an adult is trying to claim the so-called 'right to a child'. A child is no business item that can be disposed of as an object or a tool for blackmailing another, as unfortunately often happens in these cases. The best interests of the child must always come first and everywhere.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — Since the Convention on civil rights aspects of international child abduction signed in The Hague on 25 October 1980 aims to protect children by ensuring that children are unlawfully removed or detained in a Contracting State as soon as possible, and wishes to ensure that the rights of care and sighting with a child under the law of one Contracting State are actually respected in another Contracting State, I welcome the decision to join the Hague Convention in Albania.  In my view, it is an important task of the Convention to introduce a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. I consider it positive that the Contracting State will designate a central authority to carry out the obligations provided for by the Convention for such an organ, in particular because the central executive authorities will cooperate with each other and improve cooperation between the competent authorities between the contracting countries in order to ensure the return of the child as closely as possible, and therefore I support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support Albania's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. International cooperation is vital in ensuring the protection of the rights of children.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I consider Albania's accession to the Hague Convention acceptable and I support it because in this way children of Albanian origin will be safe in terms of kidnapping after the separation of parents, and other EU citizens who have close ties to the country and its community. Since 25 October 1980, the Hague Convention on civil law aspects of international child abduction has been a very important instrument ratified by all Member States of the European Union and introduces a system of cooperation between states accessing the treaty. The main goal is to solve the problem of kidnapping when the lack of co-operation between the two states is exploited. The EU has exclusive external competence in this area and the problem arises when the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organisations. Member States should each accept Albania's accession to the Convention in relation to their territory, and thus effectively enter into force of the Convention in cases involving the EU and that country. The Council's decision, adopted unanimously after consulting Parliament, should accept Albania's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. — The accession to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction in principle is acceptable, and the extension of these international rules to Albania is to be welcomed. There remains a slight concern that Albania will need further assessment in order to confirm their full compliance with their obligations; however, this has been raised by the Member States in the Council. As the European Parliament does not have a formal role in this process and is only being asked for consent and as the measure is positive in extending the reach of an international standard in difficult situations, I can support this vote.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The accession of more and more States to the Hague Convention develops the appropriate infrastructures and channels of communication between those States to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to deal with custody issues if parents live in different countries. Cooperation between several states to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction is also promoted.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. — Albania's accession to the Hague Convention is a necessary step to ensure that Member States parties to the Convention can take as broad a action as possible against the abduction of children abroad. I support this proposal, because the protection of children is of paramount importance in all circumstances and all possible legal instruments must be used.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the proposal. The Union now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area under the 1/13 opinion of the Court of Justice. Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. The problem is that the convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem necessities the Council's decision requiring Member States to accept, each on its own territory, Albania's accession to the Convention and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the convention between the European Union and that country. Albania's accession is welcome, especially given the fact that the European Union has many ethnic Albanians on its soil. In this way, children linked to this community will be protected from illegal abduction.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a crucial legal instrument to fight against child abduction. This is the reason why I voted in favour of this report. Protecting the rights and interests of children must be one of the priorities of the EU and by supporting the accession of this country to the Hague Convention we reinforce the legal framework to ensure these key principles. However, we need to monitor and to follow up how it is implemented.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — The European Union does not have the legal capacity to impose anything in this area under the 1980 Hague Convention. The justification for Albania's accession to this convention, which is supposed to be in the interests of the European Union, is therefore not valid.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the eight reports accepting the accession of Armenia, Morocco, Singapore, Albania, Russia, Seychelles, Andorra and Gabon to the 1980 Hague Convention. This Convention lays down the framework of private international law for the recovery of abducted children. Its objective is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to ensure the rights of the child, and mutual respect for custody sentences.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. — 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important document. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases. Albania's accession to this Convention is, in my view, one of the most important agreements in this bloc, given the number of cases involving Albanian citizens.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
