To this extent and in order to ensure the protection of minors who have links with the Singaporean community, member states must accept singapore's support. This proposal for a Council decision rightly calls for such acceptance. I voted in favour.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention, dated 25 October 1980, is an important instrument with regard to the civil aspects of international child abduction. The fact that it is a system of cooperation between the different States makes it easier to find solutions to a problem that persists in our day. Strengthening legislative systems must be an imperative and Singapore's agreement with the Hague Convention must be viewed with great satisfaction.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Singapore's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome Singapore's accession to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Singaporean community will be protected against illegal abduction.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. But the major problem often remains the differences between the legal systems of the Member States. The convention in question is also intended to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. Today, I am pleased that Singapore is joining.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — Singapore is one of the countries with which the European Union maintains political, diplomatic and economic ties. For this reason, I considered it essential to vote in favour of this report, so that Member States, in relation to the territory of each one - accept Singapore's participation in the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, with the aim of alleviating conflicts of territorial competence in this area and ensuring that, in situations of abduction , the immediate return of abducted minors to the State of their residence is safeguarded.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report which approves Singapore's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction, which all the Member States of the European Union have ratified.  This convention strengthens cooperation between states, addresses the problem of differences between legal systems that arises and thus establishes the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state where the child resides.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention is a very important text for the protection of minors. That is why I believe it is essential for more countries to join, and I have therefore voted in favour of Singapore's accession to this Convention.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because I believe it is essential to promote the protection of children's rights.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Singapore's accession.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text which allows Singapore to join the Hague Convention on International Child Abductions. This multilateral treaty protects children abducted outside their usual place of residence. Since the opinion of the Court of Justice on 14 October 2014, the European Union has exclusive jurisdiction over the acceptance of a new state to the convention.  These abductions, which are increasingly common in the divorces of binational couples, give rise to dramatic situations that require a rapid response from the authorities. Membership of the Convention will facilitate cooperation between the European and Singaporean judicial authorities to organise the rapid return of abducted children, so that the competent local judge can make a decision on who is responsible for the custody of the child.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Singapore's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of their parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Singapore's accession to that Convention.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of the Singapore to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The accession of Singapore to the Convention is to be welcomed. The EU has close economic ties with Singapore. Children with links to the Singapore community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — Since the Convention on civil rights aspects of international child abduction signed in the Hague on 25 October 1980 wishes to protect children by ensuring as soon as possible the return of children unlawfully removed or detained in a Contracting State, and to ensure that the rights of care and sighting with a child under the law of one Contracting State are actually respected in another Contracting State, I welcome this decision to accede to singapore's Hague Convention.  I believe that the most important task of the Convention is to introduce a system of cooperation between contracting states aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. I consider it positive that the Contracting State will designate a central authority to carry out the obligations provided for by the Convention for such an organ, in particular because the central executive authorities will cooperate with each other and improve cooperation between the competent authorities between the contracting countries in order to ensure the return of the child as urgently as possible. I agree with the Singaporean Rapporteur, who is proposing that Parliament approve the proposal without amendments, to ensure that as many children as they can be protected at European Union level, and therefore I support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support Singapore’s accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. International cooperation is vital in ensuring the protection of the rights of children.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support Singapore's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction, as this document is extremely important for the issue of protecting children's rights.  This way contributes even more to the safety of children, in particular to addressing the problem that often arises when the parents of the child are citizens of different countries. The EU now has exclusive competence in this issue, as confirmed by The Court of Justice's Opinion 1/13, leaving less room for exploitation through poor cooperation between countries.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. — The accession to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction in principle is acceptable, and the extension of these international rules to Singapore is to be welcomed. There remains a slight concern that Singapore will need further assessment in order to confirm their full compliance with their obligations; however, this has been raised by the Member States in the Council. As the European Parliament does not have a formal role in this process and is only being asked for consent and as the measure is positive in extending the reach of an international standard in difficult situations, I can support this vote.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The accession of more and more States to the Hague Convention develops the appropriate infrastructures and channels of communication between those States to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to deal with custody issues if parents live in different countries. Cooperation between several states to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction is also promoted.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. — Singapore's accession to the Hague Convention is a necessary step to ensure that Member States parties to the Convention can take as broad a action as possible against the abduction of children abroad. I support this proposal, because the protection of children is of paramount importance in all circumstances and all possible legal instruments must be used.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — The Union now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area under the 1/13 opinion of the Court of Justice. Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. The problem is that the convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem necessities the Council's decision to accept Singapore's accession to the Convention on its own territory and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the convention between the European Union and that country. Singapore's accession to the Convention is news to be welcomed, especially given the fact that the European Union and Singapore have close economic relations. In this way, children linked to this community will be protected from illegal abduction.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a crucial legal instrument to fight against child abduction. This is the reason why I voted in favour of this report. Protecting the rights and interests of children must be one of the priorities of the EU and by supporting the accession of this country to the Hague Convention we reinforce the legal framework to ensure these key principles. However, we need to monitor and to follow up how it is implemented.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — The European Union does not have the legal capacity to impose anything in this area under the 1980 Hague Convention. The justification for Singapore's accession to this convention, which is supposed to be in the interests of the European Union, is therefore not valid.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the eight reports accepting the accession of Armenia, Morocco, Singapore, Albania, Russia, Seychelles, Andorra and Gabon to the 1980 Hague Convention. This Convention lays down the framework of private international law for the recovery of abducted children. Its objective is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to ensure the rights of the child, and mutual respect for custody sentences.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. — 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important document. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases. Although there is not much Singapore in the European Union, Singapore has a large number of permanent or temporary workers from the European Union with an open immigration policy, which makes its accession to the Convention important.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Singapore's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of their parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Singapore's accession to that Convention.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This Convention is essentially intended to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held in any Contracting State and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The following countries have deposited the instrument of membership of the Convention: Albania; Andorra; Armenia; Gabon; Morocco; Singapore; Seychelles, Russia. The European Union now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the European Union. However, although Member States no longer have such competence, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise participation in international organisations such as the European Union, so the Council has taken a successive decision in order to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - Singapore's accession to the Hague Convention is to be welcomed, as solutions must be found to cases of international child abduction through cooperation between the Contracting States. At present, parents from different countries can take advantage of the often lack of cooperation between the countries concerned in order to obtain custody of the child.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — I welcome Parliament's approval of the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of consent of the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Singapore's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (HKÜ). The HKÜ is an almost exemplary solution under international law and an example of fruitful international cooperation for the protection of children. Nothing is worse for a child than a break-up of his parents' relationship. To make matters worse, parents sometimes start a dispute over the child, which is always at the expense of the child. Rarely, but unfortunately still far too often, a parent reacts with child abduction in order to create facts and, for selfish reasons, avoid a custody dispute. The HKÜ provides a sustainable framework to prevent and counteract cross-border child abductions. This cannot in principle prevent the damage done to the child, but it at least offers the possibility of returning the child to his or her usual environment.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of the Convention in question is to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. Child abduction often occurs when a couple is apart and when parents come from different states. According to the rapporteur, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the state they represent. The Purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's state of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. Singapore has deposited the instrument of access and we have spoken in favour, as this Agreement is in line with the defence of the interests of minors.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. — UKIP voted against the report as the EU now has exclusive external competence in this field as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13. The Member States therefore no longer act on their own account. We believe that the UK should be able to act in its own right.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems which defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Morocco's accession to that Convention.

name: Gerolf Annemans (NI)
text: Written. — The accession of a number of countries to the Hague Convention is to be welcomed. The abduction of one or more children abroad is a traumatic and dramatic event that must be dealt with as quickly as possible in the interests of the children. The question, however, is what will be worth the signature or the word of some acceding countries. For example, a Belgian ex-minister points out the manifest reluctance of the Moroccan authorities in cases of parental abductions. Moreover, it is problematic that the EU is now applying exclusive external jurisdiction in this matter. This means that Member States are in danger of being criticised by the EU if they do take bilateral initiative themselves. While the ultimate goal should be, in any way: to find a quick solution for the children.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an important legal instrument for the protection of children. The aim of this agreement is to avoid international child abductions by increasing cooperation between States parties. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. Morocco's accession to this agreement is to be welcomed. This will extend this sensible legal framework to other countries. This ensures that the best interests of the child are paramount.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I cannot vote in favour: this is a field in which the EU should not have exclusive competence. Under normal circumstances I would abstain. The assessment of these states’ abilities to fully comply with provisions is important for child safety. These countries will be trusted by us to a great extent. The Commission has not undertaken this kind of assessment. The UK Government believes there are ‘serious risks in returning children to a third country that does not respect rule of law or basic legal procedures in family cases’. I therefore voted against as this measure has not been properly thought through.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution because it protects the children of Moroccan nationals staying on European Union soil from possible illegal abductions.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to accede Morocco to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. of 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases and has been ratified by all EU Member States. Often such problems arise when a couple of different nationalities divorce. A lack of cooperation between states is often used to secure custody of a child. The media is full of reports of international child abduction in divorce. The purpose of the Convention is to address these problems at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the State in which the child lives. The Convention also provides for a system to ensure that the abducted child is returned immediately. The accession of Morocco to the Convention is a positive thing to ensure that the children in question are protected.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on International Child Abduction aims to manage jurisdictional disputes and conflicts of laws that usually arise from separations of couples. These are, of course, very sensitive situations and states cannot be over-encouraged in this area. Having said that, I voted against this text, which presents a major problem: the European Union is not a state, so its legal capacity to become a party to the Hague Convention is highly questionable. This prerogative is reserved for states by public international law, and I refuse to vote on a text that implicitly calls it into question. Moreover, the report explains in the explanatory statement that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states".  Thus, the approval of Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of child abduction cannot be within the competence of the European Union.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 is a very important instrument that allows the contracting parties to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. It sets up a system to expedite the return of the abducted child to the country where he or she usually resides. Through the Council's decision, the Member States each accepts Morocco's accession to the Convention and therefore the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the European Union and that country.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal because it will solve the problems that are often suffered when couples from different States separate and dispute the custody of their children, even reaching the abduction of them. This Convention will resolve situations at the international level and, more importantly, minors will be protected from illegal abduction. I thank Morocco for its accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. Generally, this situation arises when a couple divorces or separates. The statement of reasons for the report thus tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Morocco must not fall within the European scope and I therefore voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction provides for cooperation between signatory States to ensure that a child or child under 16 who has been arbitrarily "abducted" by a parent returns to the place of family residence pending a judicial ruling, unless the return foretoos a serious danger to his or her safety. I believe it is of fundamental importance for the protection of our children that this Convention be ratified and respected by more and more States. I therefore voted to support Morocco's accession among the new signatories.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction, and therefore the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome Morocco's accession to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Moroccan community will be protected against illegal abduction.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Morocco's accession to the Convention is good news. The rapporteur fully supports this accession, especially since a significant number of EU citizens come from Morocco. Children with ties to the Moroccan community would therefore be protected from legal abduction.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — This document relates to the cooperation of states in the event of a child abduction of an international character. Namely, if parents come from different countries, it often happens that in the event of a disconnect or divorce, they try to exploit legal loopholes and the absence of clearly defined cooperation between countries in order to unlawfully appropriate the child.  The Hague Convention therefore seeks to establish clear international practices in such cases. The betterment of the child is being put to the forefront, and that is why I support the report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted yes because I consider it fundamental that this Convention is applied in as many countries as possible, due to its importance.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Kingdom of Morocco deposited the instrument of accession to the 1980 Convention on 9 March 2010 and the Convention entered into force on 1 June 2010. With today's vote in the EP, the Hague Convention provides a number of measures to the Kingdom of Morocco to mediate the immediate return of minors who have been illegally displaced or detained in that country and provides for the obligation of administrative or legal authorities to act swiftly in the return processes of minors.       I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interest of the European Union, of the accession of the Kingdom of Morocco to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.      These measures to ensure the safety of children are welcome, and citizens can now be protected from the dangers posed by the abuse to which children are subjected. The Convention, which has so far been ratified by 86 countries, including all EU Member States, is a measure of cooperation in international law.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The Hague Convention is a good thing and the protection of minors must be extended as far as possible to other states that wish to be part of it.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction was established in 1980. All EU Member States have signed this convention, which provides a legal basis for child abduction by a parent. All too often, the media has reported child abduction by a parent who obtained custody in his country during a binational separation. The other parent who is the victim of this abduction finds himself in a situation where he cannot claim custody. We are faced with an inconsistency between different national judicial systems and a lack of cooperation between states. I voted in favour of Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of Morocco to the Hague Convention, as this proposal will assist authorities in returning wrongfully removed children, and will help to address issues of conflict of laws (competence of courts). In real terms, it will provide a pragmatic solution where a child has been abducted and taken to another country without the consent of one of the parents. Furthermore, the overarching principle of the proposal is that the welfare of the child – something that should always be paramount – should be the first and foremost consideration in child care proceedings. That is why it was necessary to support this proposal.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Some States exploit the lack of cooperation between national authorities in order to obtain custody of minors where there is proceedings pending between two spouses from different countries. Accession to the Hague Convention establishes jurisdiction in the State in which the child resides, limiting disputes over jurisdiction and thus speeding up proceedings. That is why we are voting in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. —I refused to sign in favour of this report for a simple reason: an international convention is a legal standard that must be signed by sovereign states.  The European Union does not have this legal status and its legitimacy is therefore questionable, with regard to its legal capacity to become a party to the Hague Convention. It is clear, however, that child abductions are a very serious issue and therefore states continue to work actively together to prevent these tragedies and take responsibility for the civil aspects they take on.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention is a fundamental instrument for ensuring the return of children unlawfully transferred or detained abroad by a parent and for ensuring respect for custody and visiting rights in all States. My country, Italy, was the only country to support, even before the Court intervened, the Exclusive Competence of the Union in this field, instead of full regulatory and operational coordination between States, instead of approaches aimed at protecting the parent, who is a citizen, also to the detriment of the interests of the child and the rights of citizens of other countries.  I believe that, for the proper application of the Convention, the Member States will have to comply with certain requirements: efficient central authorities that can really set themselves as a reference for administrative cooperation; rules preventing discriminatory practices; guarantees of access to justice and, in general, full alignment with the principles of the rule of law. Having said that, I welcome Morocco's accession, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance which has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. It enables the Contracting States effectively to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international abduction of children. The problem arises in couples who separate, where spouses are of different nationalities, because there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states. In the various States there are legal systems which tend to seek to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality, leaving the right of custody of dubious interpretation. In order to deal with these situations at international level, the Convention places the child at the centre of the problem by establishing that the court of jurisdiction is the court where the child resides. In view of all this, the accession of the State of Morocco to the Convention is to be welcomed, given also the favourable opinion of the rapporteur, who fully supports the measure. Children with links to the Moroccan community will thus find protection against abduction at EU level. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980. In view of the importance and sensitivity of the subject under way, I agree with the creation of a permanent system of cooperation between the Contracting States on the security of child care. In particular, I welcome the increased protection for minors, as it is stipulad that the competent courts and the laws to be applied are those of the states of residence of minors. That is all the more reason why I voted in favour of the Convention because it introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of the child who has been abducted. My vote is consistent with the principle that it is better for as many States as possible to accede to the Convention in order to increase its effectiveness.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument. It has been ratified by all the EU Member States. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In many instances, these problems arise when a couple has separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those states in order to secure custody of the child. The biggest problem in such cases is the differences between the legal systems of individual states. It may often be that the courts in both of the states concerned declare themselves competent, with each of them awarding custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at an international level.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a key instrument in the context of judicial cooperation between contracting States in the resolution of cases of international child abduction. This Convention aims to harmonise the legal systems other than those states which normally declare themselves both competent to adjudicate the action and declare custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent, and the criterion of the State of residence of the minor is adopted with the Convention. As this matter currently is the exclusive external competence of the Union, a Council decision is necessary which would call for member states to accept the agreement of third countries to the Hague Convention. I support the Hautala report in this regard and congratulate the Kingdom of Morocco on its membership of the Convention, thereby taking a step towards protecting its minors from abduction.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States of Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. In an international scenario in which the mobility of families across national borders is increasing, the phenomenon of the abduction of children is particularly important in the event of couples' crises. Protecting the child from illegal transfer or non-return is a global problem as well as a key element of the EU programme. Article 24 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union states that children have the right to protection and their interests 'must be considered pre-eed'. I therefore support Morocco's accession, because it is only through international cooperation that it is possible to settle the relevant issues of custody of minors and ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. Children with links to the Moroccan community can thus be better protected from any danger of abduction.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — We often hear of child abductions taking place in Member States especially when parents and family members originate from different countries. When this happens within Member States that child is already protected by legislation, but it is important to protect children also when abducted to non-EU countries. The accession of more countries to the Hague Convention is welcomed as it extends the network of protection for children. The Hague Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In cases where a couple has separated and the parents are from different States, lack of cooperation between these States can create a situation which is not in the best interests of the child involved.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — In 1987 Parliament set up the Office of the Ombudsman of the European Parliament for cases of international child abduction. Its role is to monitor the evolving situation of child abduction and to ensure that children's rights are respected, while parents find a compromise for their children. Today, the vote on the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States of Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction reinforces the path towards the objective of joining all the countries of the world. I am voting in favour of the Kingdom of Morocco joining the Convention.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems which defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Morocco's accession to that Convention.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which encourages EU Member States to accept the accession of Morocco to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction. This would allow the Convention to enter into force between Morocco and the EU and thus help to ensure the prompt return of abducted children. All EU Member States have ratified the Convention.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes to support the European Parliament for the accession of the Kingdom of Morocco to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This international agreement, ratified by all EU Member States, aims to establish a system of cooperation in the context of international child abductions, most often intervening in cases of separation or divorce of binational couples. In the event of a referral to the courts of the two States concerned, they may declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the State under its jurisdiction.  This convention therefore specifies the jurisdiction of national courts and guarantees a system allowing the immediate return of the abducted child. It is necessary for this international regime to be as broad as possible, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has, on its soil, many citizens of Moroccan origin. In this way, children linked to this community will be protected from illegal abduction. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, ratified by all EU Member States, aims to protect children from international abduction by providing for a procedure for their rapid return. Through the vote on this text, the aim is to invite the Council of the European Union to ask the Member States to accept the accession of Morocco, the European Union's major partner in the Mediterranean area. The extension of the territorial scope of the Convention to Morocco is an effective measure to strengthen our international instruments in the face of international child abduction.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction, because in this way minors with links to the Moroccan community will find greater protection against this phenomenon. This Convention allows cooperation between the Contracting States in order to find solutions to cases of international abduction of children. This problem arises when spouses from different States, as a result of their separation, exploit the lack of cooperation between the States concerned in order to obtain custody of the children. The aim of this Convention is to settle such situations at international level by establishing that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Morocco must not fall within the community field, so I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. — Dear Colleagues, I voted in favour of my colleague Hautala's report on Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, because I believe that statistics on the increased number of abductions in itself speak to the urgent need for cooperation.  According to the data currently available, in 2008 the number of applications for return of children submitted only within the EU on the basis of the 1980 Hague Convention was 990. That means 35% more than in 2003. Unfortunately, the rise in crimes against children is also high. I cannot help but note that it is the kidnapping that is the first step for trafficking in human beings and exploitation for criminal purposes.  I welcome Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention and call on all Member States under this international instrument to take measures to ensure its practical application.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention aims to ensure the immediate return of children who have been unlawfully moved or detained in one of the Contracting States, to ensure that custody and communication rights under the law of one of the Contracting States are respected in the other Contracting States.         This Convention creates the infrastructure and communication channels between 92 states to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to arrange custody issues if parents live in different countries.      We are voting in favour of the accession of other states to the Hague Convention, as it protects children who fall victim to disagreements between their parents. The Convention ensures cooperation between States to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — My position, of course, is in favour of the entry into force of that decision and, therefore, the scope of that convention. I hope that the process will be closed as soon as possible within the Council, that it will not be extended over time and that the applicant countries will finally join. A slowdown in this process goes against children's rights, leaving them unsealed. That's why we have to act quickly

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention provides the private international law framework for recovery of abducted children. Its aim is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to safeguard the prompt return of the child and the mutual enforcement of judgments regarding custody and access rights. The vote refers to the acceptance of Morocco, which has joined the Convention in recent years. This agreement will benefit children and families in Wales so I voted in favour.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome this proposal by the Council to accept Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention. The issue of the defence of children's rights is of central importance and it therefore seems very positive that more and more states should be included, especially given that there are a great many people on European soil from the countries that are now applying for membership, which will facilitate the resolution of cases of abduction between a Member State and these third countries. However, while it is good that all the States of the European Union have acceded to the Convention, I cannot help noticing that the concept of 'good of the child' is often interpreted instrumentally. I am thinking, for example, of Germany, whose children's office, the Jugendamt, actuallyes the good of the child for the good of the German child, depriving the non-German parent and the child himself of many fundamental rights, including some of the founding rights of the Hague Convention. Unfortunately, the problem is not confined to Germany alone, and Europe is powerless to witness these abuses because it does not have the power to intervene in the family law of the individual Member States. That is why I believe that there is an urgent need for harmonisation of legislation in this area.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart. As parents come from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those same States to obtain custody of minors. In these cases, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of the countries concerned to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Convention aims to remedy such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. I voted in favour of accepting Morocco's annexe to the Hague Convention in the best interests of minors who have links with the Moroccan community and who will thus be protected from abduction.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart and the Convention resolves these types of situations on an international scale, by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the state of residence of the minor. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I am voting against this text because by becoming part of the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction, the European Union is also giving itself a space for interpretation of this text. Let us not be fooled because under the good intentions of defending the interests of children nothing is done - for example - against the expansion of the barbaric practice of surrogacy within the Union. On the other hand, it is up to the Member States to determine sovereignly who may or may not join the Convention, I challenge, once again, this transfer of competence.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The child abduction situation occurs with some frequency when a couple, with members from different States, is reunited. Not accompanying some of the considerations made during this debate concerning the legal systems of each State, it is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Convention aims to address this type of situation at international level. It is its objective to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the rights of custody and visitation existing in a Contracting State. These are fair and relevant objectives. Morocco has deposited the instrument for the convention.  The EU now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the EU. However, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise the participation of international organisations such as the EU. For this reason, the Council had to take a successive decision in order to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I am pleased that Morocco is party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, and that is why I voted in favour of the report. The Convention provides effective means of settling disputes arising from international abductions of minors as a result of separation or divorce, by establishing that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — The subject of international child abduction largely concerns spouses or couples in which individuals from different countries of the world choose to abuse the situation and wrongly adopt a child after divorce or break-up. Such situations are helped by the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Children often become a means of dealing with accounts between spouses or former partners with different citizenships. Consequently, the national courts, often outside the European Union, often grant custody rights to the parent who is a citizen of the state to which that court is competent, thanks to certain national tendencies. The Convention resolves such situations in such a way that the assignment of the child is decided by the court in the State where he or she resides, regardless of where one of the parents was brought. The EU now has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice. This means that Member States are no longer acting at their discretion. It is therefore necessary to adopt a Council Decision requiring Member States to adopt, in their own territory, the accession of Morocco to the Convention and thus the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that State. The adoption of the convention in question will provide increased protection for children associated in any way with the Moroccan community.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the accession of other States to the Hague Convention, as it protects children who fall victim to disagreements between their parents. The Convention ensures cooperation between States so that children return to their normal residence in the event of abduction.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — I strongly support the adoption of stronger cooperative measures to prevent cases of international child abduction. Greater coordination between states is necessary to avoid the temptation, by one of the parents, to secure custody of a child following a separation or a divorce. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 makes it possible to resolve, at an international level, those cases in which the courts of both of the states concerned declare themselves competent and award custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. Moreover the Convention introduces a system which ensures the immediate return of abducted children. I welcome the accession of Morocco to The Hague Convention. Considering the number of EU citizens of Moroccan origin, this accession is vital to ensure EU-wide protection of the children in question.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. — International law, including EU legislation, is based on the fact that the most vulnerable members of society, children, can enjoy the most effective protection in all circumstances. One of the means of doing so is the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of the abduction of children, ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention establishes a system of international cooperation between the contracting States to resolve cases involving the abduction of children abroad. In most cases, the problem is the divorce of parents of different nationality who are exploiting the lack of international cooperation to obtain custody of children. The biggest problem in these cases is the different legal frameworks of the different States. The purpose of the Convention is to provide redress and redress in such cases. It is therefore essential that as many States as possible can join this Convention.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. — For the institutions of the European Union, the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an instrument of crucial importance that has been ratified by all EU Member States. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, a problem which we unfortunately face very often and which entails great suffering for the parties involved. The objective of the Convention is to resolve this issue at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. Similarly, the Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. Therefore, once the Decision has been analysed, as well as the case-law of the Court of Justice of the EU, I have decided to vote in favour with the desire to promote Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution. Morocco has ratified the Convention, but its acceptance by all EU Member States is necessary for its implementation between that country and the European Union. To the extent that it is an exclusive competence of the EU, the report refers to the Council Decision by asking Member States about its acceptance, and that is why I have supported it.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I fully support morocco's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, so that minors with links to the Moroccan community can also benefit from EU protection measures in the event of separation or dispute between their parents. The Convention is in fact an instrument of guarantee for children of extraordinary effectiveness, in that it intervenes to bring back to the center of conflicts of couples in crisis of different nationalities the rights of minors applicable in their state of residence, overcoming the temptation of preferential management between the individual countries of origin of the parents and the dramatic risk of international abduction of minors. Europe, the guarantor of human rights, is widening the mesh of measures to protect minors in all the countries that so request, thus preventing unjust national legal favouritism and unholy parenting of child fragility.  The measure is particularly important because it regulates the relationship with a country with which many European states have very close ties and relationships. We hope that these regulations will give us new and stronger rights for children in Europe.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction includes 93 countries, including all EU countries. I therefore welcomed morocco's inclusion in it. The vote received more than 90% support, which shows the importance of the situation regardless of political views.  The Convention is an essential instrument for ensuring respect for the rights of a child who has been kidnapped by one of his parents. Child abduction is a crime, a violation of human rights, guaranteed by m.in Charter of Fundamental Rights. Every year in the European Union, there are an average of 3000 child abductions between Community countries, kidnappings without the consent of the other parent. In the Committee on Petitions, of which I am a member, we receive many reports of child abdument. These cases are among the most emotional. This shows how significant and frequent this problem is. The accession of new countries to the Convention is good news, which in the future will result in more efficient investigations into the kidnapping of children.  Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her good work.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Hautala report because The Hague Convention of 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an essential instrument for protecting children belonging to parents from different states that exploit potential conflicts of competence between their national courts in order to secure custody of their child.  I therefore call on all EU Member States to formally accept the accession of Morocco to the Convention, seeing that this is a crucial step to ensure effective implementation and enhanced international cooperation to protect children who fall victim to international abduction. I do urge the Commission to continuously monitor whether the necessary infrastructure is in place to ensure Morocco is in a position to fully implement the Convention.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention on the International Abduction of Children, because Morocco is an important partner for Europe and there are many Moroccan communities in Europe. That is why it is also essential to make cooperation effective in protecting the rights of the many children of European and Moroccan citizens.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted against this proposal on Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention.  This convention is certainly very useful in the management of jurisdictional disputes in cases of child abductions, most often as a result of divorces. Nevertheless, I question the legitimacy of the European Union to intervene in the ratification of this convention between the Member States and other States.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as I believe the accession of Morocco to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (the Convention), which seeks to protect children from abduction across international boundaries, is to be welcomed. It is important that countries acceding to the Convention can participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention. Effective measures now need to be put into place to ensure the rights of the child and that cooperation is fully practicable.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention on civil aspects of the abduction of children is a very important legal instrument. All The Member States of the European Union are parties. The Convention provides a system of cooperation for Contracting States to find solutions to cases of child abduction abroad. These problems most often occur in parents who are divering. In order to obtain childcare, a spouse from another State may take advantage of the lack of cooperation between States. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. Often, the courts of both States concerned consider the case to be within their competence and award the right to custody to a parent of their own nationality. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. I therefore consider it of the utmost importance that all states that have not yet done so should accede to the Convention.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. The Convention aims to protect children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution on the Council proposal on a statement allowing Member States in the interest of the European Union to accept Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction in 1980, on the ground that this way allows Morocco to counter the phenomenon of child abduction present in the country internationally, under common legal instruments.  I support the support given to African countries in strengthening and improving the protection of human rights, and I believe that child abduction cases should be regulated by the applicable law of the country where children reside.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Morocco must not fall within the community field, so I voted against it.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This file suggested that Parliament approve the proposal for a Council decision to allow Morocco to access the UN Convention that regulates civil aspects of child abduction, mostly concerning cooperation of authorities for the return of wrongfully removed children and issues of conflict of laws. As the prevention of child abduction is, since the Brussels Regulations on matrimonial matters and parental responsibility, an exclusive competence of the EU policy to promote the rights of the child, the EU is the player at international level to improve the application of the 1980 Convention and to encourage third States to accede it. Article 38(4) of the 1980 Convention stipulates that the Convention applies between the acceding country and such Contracting States as will have declared their acceptance of the accession. Therefore, the EU has to decide whether to accept the accession of a country. When it does so, Member States should make the declaration of acceptance concerning the accession in the interest of the EU; because as the Convention dates from 1980, it does not recognise international organisations such as the EU as an accessing Party. EH Bildu has voted in favour, as the primary matter is broadening of the application of the UN Convention on Child Abduction.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the Council's proposal for a decision on Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes mechanisms for cooperation between contracting states to remedy jurisdictional conflicts, particularly when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Accession of Morocco to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction’ because the EU has exclusive external competence in this field, but the problem is that the Convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organisations. Therefore, the accession of Morocco to the Convention and the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the EU and that country is necessary, especially as many EU citizens are of Moroccan origin. Children with links to the Moroccan community will thus be safeguarded against abduction and protection will be afforded to the children in question.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — One of the European Union's special priorities is to protect children and strengthen children's rights, as set out in Article 3 of the Treaty on European Union. The prevention of child abduction is an important measure in the context of child protection. The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction of 25 October 1980, as a multilateral agreement, forms the basis for the immediate repatriation of children abducted abroad or children detained abroad. In the meantime, 86 countries have signed up to this convention, but the validity of the law required official permission from the EU, even if individual countries have already implemented it. That is why I support the request to include Morocco in the Hague Convention.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR)
text: in writing. — On behalf of the Conservative MEPs in Parliament and as Conservative spokesman for legal affairs, I voted in favour of this report as the 1980 Hague Convention is an effective tool in the resolution of international child abduction cases and extending its application to more countries, as long as they fully comply with the obligations under the Convention, would enhance the legal certainty for those involved in such disputes.  However, I strongly support the assessments which many Member States currently undertake in order to carefully assess any third country’s ability to implement the Convention properly before accepting its accession. These assessments prevent any potential risks which may arise from returning children to a third country which does not respect rule of law or basic legal procedures in family law cases, or does not have a competent authority which could verify a child’s well-being.  I therefore support calls for the Commission to urgently produce such assessments for these countries, which it has yet to produce.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — In order for the Convention to apply between Morocco and the EU, the acceptance of all Member States is required. I supported giving the acceptance, as the Convention is an important international instrument, which seeks to protect children from the harmful effects of abduction and retention across international boundaries by providing a procedure to bring about their prompt return.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. — International abduction of children as a result of separation or divorce is a reality which unfortunately occurs with a habitual frequency. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. International cooperation is essential for the resolution of these disputes. Hence my full support for this resolution. Morocco's accession to the Convention and, consequently, the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases concerning the European Union and that country is to be welcomed. It is our moral and political duty to ensure that Moroccan children enjoy protection at EU level.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of Mrs Hautala's report. In view of relations between the EU and Morocco, within the framework of the neighbourhood policy, and given the high percentage of Moroccan citizens within the Territory of the Union, I consider morocco's accession to the Hague Convention to be important in such a decisive area.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Morocco must not fall within the European scope. That is why I abstained.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution. The following eight countries have ratified the Convention, but its acceptance by all EU Member States is necessary for its implementation between them and the European Union. The countries are Singapore, Russia, Albania, Andorra, Seychelles, Gabon, Armenia and Morocco. To the extent that this is a positive step in the international protection of children, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems which defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Morocco's accession to that Convention.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — For the same reasons as I have pointed out on the proposal for a Council Decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, I consider that Morocco should also accede to that Convention.  In this way, with many EU inhabitants of Moroccan origin, I vote in favour of the proposal, as it will achieve better protection for minors.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction is an important instrument ratified by all Member States of the European Union. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between states aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. It is often the case that parents of a child live separately in different countries, so the biggest problem is the national bias of the legal systems of individual states. Courts in both countries may enter their claims as competent and each of the parents who are their nationals may be granted custody of the child. The purpose of the Convention is to deal with such situations at international level, so as to establish that the competent courts and applicable laws are only from the state that is the place of residence of the child. The Convention also implements a system that ensures the automatic return of children abducted. The European Union now has exclusive jurisdiction in this area, as confirmed by the European Court of Justice. I support the Council Decision, which calls on Member States to accept Morocco's accession to the Convention, as this is in the interest of the European Union, will contribute to the coherence and uniformity of the application of EU law.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing — I welcome Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention. Children who are in some way connected to the Moroccan community will be protected from kidnapping in this way. Any initiative to expand the number of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction must be supported. This will increase the protection of children from abduction in the territory of the Contracting States and can thus help to return the child to their natural environment more quickly. It is therefore necessary to look for the most effective ways of dealing with international child abduction in order to protect them and strengthen their rights.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Hautala report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on The Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because this Convention adequately addresses at international level the problem of child abduction and is therefore an important legal and political development.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — The accession of Morocco to the Convention is to be welcomed. I fully support this, especially as many EU citizens are of Moroccan origin. Children with links to the Moroccan community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
