text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council Decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States of Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all the Member States of the European Union.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — Preventing the abduction of children is one of the main objectives of EU policy in the area of children's rights. It is no coincidence that the European Union has always been at the forefront, at international level, in support of better application of the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction. The Hague Convention is a central instrument. It introduces a system which enables the Contracting States to cooperate, with the aim of finding solutions in the field of international child abduction. In view of the relations between the EU and Morocco, within the framework of the neighbourhood policy, and in view of the fact that a high percentage of EU citizens are of Moroccan origin, I welcome morocco's accession to the Convention.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — I was positive about Morocco's accession, because the Hague Convention establishes a system of cooperation between the Contracting States in order to resolve the cases of international child abduction.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. —I welcome Morocco's accession to the international convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. It aims to reduce legal conflicts between different national jurisdictions in cases of difficult separations of binational couples. In this legal procedure, however, the Commission has once again undermined the sovereignty of Member States by seeking recognition of these accessions on behalf of the European Union, even though the Convention does not recognise international organisations (such as the Union) as a signatory party. I vote for, and welcome Morocco's action in this area.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — With Morocco's annexe to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, the EU takes another step towards achieving one of its priorities, which is the protection and promotion of the rights of the child. Thus, children of Moroccan origin residing in the EU are protected from abductions.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction aids in establishing the relevant jurisdiction to award custody of the child in question. The EU now has exclusive external competence in facilitating cooperation between contracting states to settle cases of international child abduction but requires each state to accept the accession of new signatories in their own territory. Therefore, I support each Member State’s acceptance of the extension to the Convention as it would ensure the protection of the child’s best interests in cases involving Morocco.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the report on Morocco's application to join the Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This text is of particular importance for Belgium, which hosts a large community of Moroccan origin on its soil. Membership in this convention is essential in a globalized world where mixed marriages are on the rise. This convention clearly determines the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also allows the immediate return of the child who has been abducted. Child abduction in the event of divorce or separation is a tragedy for the child and for the parent deprived of access or custody for many years. It is the denial of the child's right to enjoy the presence of both parents. It will now be up to each Member State to accept, each for its territory, Morocco's accession to that convention.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing — I consider the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, ratified by all EU Member States, to be a particularly important instrument enabling States Parties to cooperate more effectively in dealing with cases of international child abduction. I therefore welcome Morocco's accession to this important convention, especially as a significant number of citizens of Moroccan origin live on EU territory. I believe that by working together, we will thus contribute to greater protection of children's rights and to their legal certainty in an international context.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of Morocco's annexment to the 1980 Hague Convention, as the goodwill of the Kingdom of Morocco shows the importance of this issue in the multilateral context. I believe that only a comprehensive and common response can facilitate dispute resolution and, at the same time, take into account the well-being of the child.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Morocco is by no means within the European scope. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — It is important to get as many countries on board as possible. The accession will allow those countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which approves Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects related to the abduction of children on an international scale. This convention is a major instrument in the fight against the illegal detention and displacement of children that occur as a result of family conflicts. In practical terms, it provides for cooperation mechanisms to resolve jurisdictional disputes between jurisdictions in the event of a binational separation. It also guarantees a return system in case of abduction. The larger the number of States parties to this convention, the greater the international guarantee of children's rights.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We believe that the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all EU Member States, in that it introduces a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. The aim is to avoid situations of uncertainty or dangerous legal loopholes. It is stipulates, in fact, that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the State of residence of the child. While the European Union has exclusive external competence in this area (as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13), i.e. individual Member States no longer have the opportunity to act individually by referring to their own legal systems, the problem remains that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organisations. In order to overcome this legal difficulty, the Council has decided that it will be up to the individual Member States to accept, each in relation to its own territory, the accession of new States to the Convention. We therefore welcome Albania's accession to this Convention, so as to ensure that children with links to the Moroccan community can find protection against abduction at EU level.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because Morocco's accession to the Convention is a news to be welcomed, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Moroccan origin on its soil. In this way, children connected to this community will be protected from abduction.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this report, together with all the other documents on the agenda, relating to the acceptance by the Member States, in the interest of the EU, of the accession of the Kingdom of Morocco to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. The report refers to situations in which children are placed following divorce or separation of parents, conditions in which they may be abducted, and questions the custody of the child of one of the parents, as well as the establishment of the courts competent to deal with the case.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I regard the agreement as an important measure against cross-border child abduction and i strongly support its ratification as far as possible.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because the Hague Convention on child abduction is a crucial piece of legislation. The accession of each new State to the Convention on this issue contributes to international child abduction cases and excludes biased justice. The protection of children's rights must take up a very important role in international relations and justice.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance. The Convention introduces a system which allows contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. In the event that spouses come from different States, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between the States concerned in order to obtain custody of children, and there is often a tendency for the legal systems of individual States to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality. The aim of the Convention is to deal with these situations at international level and the many citizens of the European Union are originally from Morocco and children with links to the Moroccan community will thus find protection against abduction. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — It is difficult to say how common the case of divorce and the cessation of community life between partners of different nationality is, but it is not uncommon to come across sad statistics on international child abductions by such parents. International child abductions are a serious problem, with the reported number of internationally abducted children worldwide at 300,000 each year.  The objectives of the 1980 Hague Convention on civil justice aspects of international child abduction are to ensure as urgent a return as possible of children illegally taken or detained in a contracting state and to ensure that the rights of care and sighting with a child under the law of one Contracting State are actually respected in another Contracting State. Morocco's approach to the 1980 Hague Convention allows for the protection of children in case of adverse developments in their parents' personal relationships.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Morocco is by no means within the European scope. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support morocco's accession report to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction in 1980. Although Morocco has ratified this Convention, its application to EU member states requires the consent of all Member States.  I believe it is in the interest of all of us that problems that can be caused by the non-compliance of legal systems, if the parents of the child come from two different countries, are adequately regulated. Children's rights must come first, and as children have suffered the consequences of legal unregulatedness, I would like to express my full support for this report once again and call on all EU member states to do the same as soon as possible.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. —Every year, eight million children disappear in the world, which would mean that nearly 22,000 children disappear every day. All our efforts should be geared towards ensuring a better future for our children, and so this Convention, signed by all EU members, should ensure a secure future and the realisation of all children's rights.  As the report states, the most common problem is agreeing on the court's jurisdiction over the allocation of care to children whose parents are from different countries, as well as the lack of communication between the two countries. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such cases in predetermined competent courts and to use the prescribed laws.  Countries that approach it are entering a common system of tackling child abduction. If the legal systems differ too much and the country does not have the means to form a body that will implement the laws and proposals of this Convention, the country cannot even access it. This is precisely the problem that Morocco's approach to the Hague Convention is proceeding so slowly.  Morocco submitted its application form to the Convention on 9 March 2010 and entered into force on 1 June 2011. In order to solve the cases of abducted children of Morocco and the European Union, I support this report for accepting the accession to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction from 1980.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — In view of the very high number of EU citizens from Morocco and the large number of unions between European and Moroccan citizens, I very much welcome Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Here, too, the effective entry into force of the Convention will help to settle the delicate situations in which the custody of a child must be decided at international level, while protecting the rights of the child in the best possible way.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — With this text, the European Parliament must appreciate the opportunity for recognition by European Union law of Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. Thus, the European Union and its 28 Member States are united and apply this convention uniformly when such a dispute with Morocco arises. It is important to solve such problems because they are family dramas that occur when parents find themselves confronted with Kafkaesque judicial systems. I am therefore in favour of anything that can improve the dialogue and resolution of family problems between judicial systems.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction, which occur very often following divorces and separations of parents from different States. More specifically, the Convention, seeking to counter the nationalist tendency of the legal systems of each State, provides that these cases must be tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the state of residence of the minor and also provides for a system ensuring the immediate return of the abducted minor. Although this is currently a matter of the EU's exclusive external competence, the fact is that the Convention does not provide for independent intervention by international organisations. To this extent and in order to ensure the protection of minors who have links with the Moroccan community, member states need to accept the annexing of Morocco. This proposal for a Council decision rightly calls for such acceptance. I voted in favour.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. —I supported our position on Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention on International Child Abduction. I also welcome the accession to this convention by seven other countries: Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, the Russian Federation, Albania, Singapore and Armenia.  This reference text is a key legal instrument in the case of international child abduction, for example, during a separation between parents from different countries. These cases always involve dramas that place children and parents in complex situations loaded with strong emotional elements. The text provides contracting states with a clear legal framework and a system of cooperation with a procedure for the return of the abducted child to the country of residence.  While all EU Member States have ratified this convention, the accession of third countries is crucial in order to ensure better protection for children who are victims of cross-border abduction. As far as my country is concerned, I am thinking in particular of my many fellow citizens of Moroccan origin.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention, dated 25 October 1980, is an important instrument with regard to the civil aspects of international child abduction. The fact that it is a system of cooperation between the different States makes it easier to find solutions to a problem that persists in our day. Strengthening legislative systems must be an imperative and Morocco's annexe to the Hague Convention must be viewed with great satisfaction.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome Morocco's accession to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Moroccan community will be protected against illegal abduction.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. But the major problem often remains the differences between the legal systems of the Member States. In such cases, the courts of the two states concerned often declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the state under its jurisdiction. The convention in question is also intended to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. I welcome the fact that Morocco is joining today.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — We are once again dealing with a proposal to resolve conflicts of territorial jurisdiction over international child abduction, in the specific case of Morocco's annexe to the 1980 Hague Convention. As the assumptions are equivalent to those already mentioned for other Contracting States and Morocco being an EU partner country under the European Neighbourhood Policy, with many citizens residing and working in European countries, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report which approves Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction, which all the Member States of the European Union have ratified. This convention strengthens cooperation between states, addresses the problem of differences between legal systems that arises and thus establishes the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state where the child resides.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I consider the fact that Morocco has decided to accede to the 1980 Hague Convention as a very important gesture for the protection of all children. That is why I voted in favour of Mrs Hautala's report.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because it is a question of protecting the rights of the child.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made it necessary for the Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Morocco.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text which allows Morocco to join the Hague Convention on International Child Abductions. This multilateral treaty protects children abducted outside their usual place of residence. Since the opinion of the Court of Justice on 14 October 2014, the European Union has exclusive jurisdiction over the acceptance of a new state to the convention.  These abductions, which are increasingly common in the divorces of binational couples, give rise to dramatic situations that require a rapid response from the authorities. Membership of the Convention will facilitate cooperation between the European and Moroccan judicial authorities to organise the rapid return of abducted children, so that the competent local judge can make a decision on who is responsible for the custody of the child.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems which defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Morocco's accession to that Convention.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of Morocco to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The accession of Morocco to the Convention is to be welcomed. Many EU citizens are of Moroccan origin. Children with links to the Moroccan community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing — It is very important that the provisions of this Convention preventing and prior international child abduction should also apply in other countries which have not yet been bound by them or have merely acceded to the Convention. I therefore voted in favour. It should be stressed that, even in these very difficult family-legal situations, often with a strong geopolitical context, when national courts tend to rule biased, it is always and at all costs necessary to take into account the rights, well-being and dignity of children. A child cannot be abused in any way and cause him emotional, psychological or physical suffering. Even in a situation where an adult is trying to claim the so-called 'right to a child'. A child is no business item that can be disposed of as an object or a tool for blackmailing another, as unfortunately often happens in these cases. The best interests of the child must always come first and everywhere.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — Since the Convention on civil rights aspects of international child abduction signed in the Hague on 25 October 1980 wishes to protect children by ensuring as soon as possible the return of children unlawfully removed or detained in a Contracting State, and wishes to ensure that the rights of care and sighting with a child under the law of one Contracting State are actually respected in another Contracting State, I welcome this decision to join morocco under the Hague Convention.  In my view, it is an important task of the Convention to introduce a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. Morocco's accession to the Convention should be welcomed as many children connected to Moroccan communities will be insured against the risk of abductions, and I therefore support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support Morocco’s accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. International cooperation is vital in ensuring the protection of the rights of children.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. — The accession to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction in principle is acceptable, and the extension of these international rules to Morocco is to be welcomed. There remains a slight concern that Morocco will need further assessment in order to confirm their full compliance with their obligations; however, this has been raised by the Member States in the Council. As the European Parliament does not have a formal role in this process and is only being asked for consent and as the measure is positive in extending the reach of an international standard in difficult situations, I can support this vote.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The accession of more and more States to the Hague Convention develops the appropriate infrastructures and channels of communication between those States to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to deal with custody issues if parents live in different countries. Cooperation between several states to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction is also promoted.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. — Morocco's accession to the Hague Convention is a necessary step to ensure that Member States parties to the Convention can take as broad a action as possible against the abduction of children abroad. I support this proposal, because the protection of children is of paramount importance in all circumstances and all possible legal instruments must be used.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the text. The Union now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area under the 1/13 opinion of the Court of Justice. Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. The problem is that the convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem necessities the Council's decision requiring member states to accept, each on its own territory, Morocco's accession to the Convention and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the convention between the European Union and that country. Morocco's accession to the Convention is news to be welcomed, especially given the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Moroccan origin on its soil. In this way, children linked to this community will be protected from illegal abduction.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a crucial legal instrument to fight against child abduction. This is the reason why I voted in favour of this report. Protecting the rights and interests of children must be one of the priorities of the EU and by supporting the accession of this country to the Hague Convention we reinforce the legal framework to ensure these key principles. However, we need to monitor and to follow up on how it is implemented.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as this is an important step, particularly as it is in the interest of my constituency that Morocco accesses the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and takes steps forward towards international standards in all fields.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — The European Union does not have the legal capacity to impose anything in this area under the 1980 Hague Convention. The justification for Morocco's accession to this convention, which is supposed to be in the interests of the European Union, is therefore not valid.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the eight reports accepting the accession of Armenia, Morocco, Singapore, Albania, Russia, Seychelles, Andorra and Gabon to the 1980 Hague Convention. This Convention lays down the framework of private international law for the recovery of abducted children. Its objective is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to ensure the rights of the child, and mutual respect for custody sentences.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. — 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important document. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases. There is a large number of Moroccan citizens or a population of Moroccan origin in the European Union, which makes ratification a major contribution to this Convention.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems which defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Morocco's accession to that Convention.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. — In this part-session, several countries were on the agenda calling for accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. I am pleased that so many countries, including Russia, Gabon, Andorra and seychelles, are recognising the need for accession.  There is an increasing need for mixed marriages or forms of society with children from parents of different nationalities. Improving this legal framework will only benefit children. Morocco is also applying for membership of this Convention. This is of great importance to our country given the size of the Moroccan community in Belgium.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This Convention is essentially intended to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held in any Contracting State and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The following countries have deposited the instrument of membership of the Convention: Albania; Andorra; Armenia; Gabon; Morocco; Singapore; Seychelles, Russia. The European Union now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the European Union. However, although Member States no longer have such competence, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise participation in international organisations such as the European Union, so the Council has taken a successive decision in order to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of Morocco's accession, as the Hague Convention establishes a system of cooperation between states parties to resolve cases of international child abduction.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — I welcome Parliament's approval of the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of consent of the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Morocco's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (HKÜ). The HKÜ is an almost exemplary solution under international law and an example of fruitful international cooperation for the protection of children. Nothing is worse for a child than a break-up of his parents' relationship. To make matters worse, parents sometimes start a dispute over the child, which is always at the expense of the child. Rarely, but unfortunately still far too often, a parent reacts with child abduction in order to create facts and, for selfish reasons, avoid a custody dispute. The HKÜ provides a sustainable framework to prevent and counteract cross-border child abductions. This cannot in principle prevent the damage done to the child, but it at least offers the possibility of returning the child to his or her usual environment.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of the Convention in question is to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The child abduction situation occurs very often when a couple of people secede and when the parents come from different states. According to the rapporteur, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the state they represent. The Purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's state of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. Morocco has deposited the instrument of access and we have spoken in favour, since this Agreement is in line with the defence of the interests of minors.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. — UKIP voted against the report as the EU now has exclusive external competence in this field as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13. The Member States therefore no longer act on their own account. We believe that the UK should be able to act in its own right.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Armenia's accession to that Convention.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an important legal instrument for the protection of children. The aim of this agreement is to avoid international child abductions by increasing cooperation between States parties. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. Armenia's accession to this agreement is to be welcomed. This will extend this sensible legal framework to other countries. This ensures that the best interests of the child are paramount.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I cannot vote in favour: this is a field in which the EU should not have exclusive competence. Under normal circumstances I would abstain. The assessment of these statesʼ abilities to fully comply with provisions is important for child safety. These countries will be trusted by us to a great extent. The Commission has not undertaken this kind of assessment. The UK Government believes there are ʽserious risks in returning children to a third country that does not respect rule of law or basic legal procedures in family casesʼ. I therefore voted against as this measure has not been properly thought through.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution because it protects the children of Armenian nationals staying on European Union soil from possible illegal abductions.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to accede Armenia to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. of 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases and has been ratified by all EU Member States. Often such problems arise when a couple of different nationalities divorce. A lack of cooperation between states is often used to secure custody of a child. The media is full of reports of international child abduction in divorce. The purpose of the Convention is to address these problems at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the State in which the child lives. The Convention also provides for a system to ensure that the abducted child is returned immediately. The accession of Armenia to the Convention is a positive thing to ensure that the children in question are protected.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on International Child Abduction aims to manage jurisdictional disputes and conflicts of laws that usually arise from separations of couples. These are, of course, very sensitive situations and states cannot be over-encouraged in this area. Having said that, I voted against this text, which presents a major problem: the European Union is not a state, so its legal capacity to become a party to the Hague Convention is highly questionable. This prerogative is reserved for states by public international law, and I refuse to vote on a text that implicitly calls it into question. Moreover, the report explains in the explanatory statement that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states".  Thus, the approval of Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of child abduction cannot be within the competence of the European Union.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 is a very important instrument that allows the contracting parties to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. It sets up a system to expedite the return of the abducted child to the country where he or she usually resides. Through the Council's decision, the Member States each accept Armenia's accession to the Convention and therefore the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the European Union and that country.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal because it will solve the problems that are often suffered when couples from different States separate and dispute the custody of their children, even reaching the abduction of them. This Convention will resolve situations at the international level and, more importantly, minors will be protected from illegal abduction. I thank Armenia for its accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. Generally, this situation arises when a couple divorces or separates. The statement of reasons for the report thus tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Armenia must not fall within the European scope, so I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction provides for cooperation between signatory States to ensure that a child or child under 16 who has been arbitrarily "abducted" by a parent returns to the place of family residence pending a judicial ruling, unless the return foretoos a serious danger to his or her safety. I believe it is of fundamental importance for the protection of our children that this Convention be ratified and respected by more and more States. I therefore voted to support Morocco's accession among the new signatories.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction, and therefore the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome Armenia's accession to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Armenian community will be protected against illegal abduction.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Armenia's accession to the Convention is good news. The rapporteur fully supports this accession, especially since a significant number of EU citizens come from Armenia. Children with ties to the Armenian community would therefore be protected from legal abduction.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — This document relates to the cooperation of states in the event of a child abduction of an international character. Namely, if parents come from different countries, it often happens that in the event of a disconnect or divorce, they try to exploit legal loopholes and the absence of clearly defined cooperation between countries in order to unlawfully appropriate the child.  The Hague Convention therefore seeks to establish clear international practices in such cases. The betterment of the child is being put to the forefront, and that is why I support the report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted yes because it is fundamental for Armenia to join this Convention, in order to protect children in the country.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — Preventing child abduction is an essential part of the EU's policy to promote children's rights, with the European Union active at international level in improving and implementing the 1980 Convention. At the same time, the EU has continuously pursued a policy of encouraging third states to accede to this Convention.      I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interest of the European Union, of Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.      Armenia deposited the instrument of accession to the 1980 Convention on 1 March 2007 and the Convention entered into force on 1 June 2007. Today, in practice, EU Member States have fulfilled their obligation to restore a status quo of the cooperation system.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The Hague Convention is a good thing and the protection of minors must be extended as far as possible to other states that wish to be part of it.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction was established in 1980. The Member States of the Union have all ratified it. Too often in the media, the media has reported child abduction by a parent who obtained custody of the child in his country during a separation from a binational couple. The other parent who is the victim of this abduction finds himself in a situation where he is legally unable to claim custody. We are faced with legal inconsistency and a lack of cooperation between states. I voted in favour of Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of Albania to the Hague Convention, as this proposal will assist authorities in returning wrongfully removed children, and will help to address issues of conflict of laws (competence of courts). In real terms, it will provide a pragmatic solution where a child has been abducted and taken to another country without the consent of one of the parents. Furthermore, the overarching principle of the proposal is that the welfare of the child – something that should always be paramount – should be the first and foremost consideration in child care proceedings. That is why it was necessary to support this proposal.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Some States exploit the lack of cooperation between national authorities in order to obtain custody of minors where there is proceedings pending between two spouses from different countries. Accession to the Hague Convention establishes jurisdiction in the State in which the child resides, limiting disputes over jurisdiction and thus speeding up proceedings. That is why we are voting in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. —I refused to sign in favour of this report for a simple reason: an international convention is a legal standard that must be signed by sovereign states.  The European Union does not have this legal status and its legitimacy is therefore questionable, with regard to its legal capacity to become a party to the Hague Convention. It is clear, however, that child abductions are a very serious issue and therefore states continue to work actively together to prevent these tragedies and take responsibility for the civil aspects they take on.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention is a fundamental instrument for ensuring the return of children unlawfully transferred or detained abroad by a parent and for ensuring respect for custody and visiting rights in all States. My country, Italy, was the only country to support, even before the Court intervened, the Exclusive Competence of the Union in this field, instead of full regulatory and operational coordination between States, instead of approaches aimed at protecting the parent, who is a citizen, also to the detriment of the interests of the child and the rights of citizens of other countries. I believe that, for the proper application of the Convention, the Member States will have to comply with certain requirements: efficient central authorities that can really set themselves as a reference for administrative cooperation; rules preventing discriminatory practices; guarantees of access to justice and, in general, full alignment with the principles of the rule of law. Having said that, I welcome Armenia's accession, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance which has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. It enables the Contracting States effectively to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international abduction of children. The problem arises in couples who separate, where spouses are of different nationalities, because there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states. In the various States there are legal systems which tend to seek to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality, leaving the right of custody of dubious interpretation. In order to deal with these situations at international level, the Convention places the child at the centre of the problem by establishing that the court of jurisdiction is the court where the child resides. In view of all this, the accession of the State of Armenia to the Convention is to be welcomed, given also the favourable opinion of the rapporteur, who fully supports the measure. Children with links to the Armenian community will thus find protection against abduction at EU level. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980. I agree with the creation of a permanent system of cooperation between contracting states on the security of custody of minors. In particular, I welcome the increased protection for minors, as it is stipulad that the competent courts and the laws to be applied are those of the states of residence of minors. As Armenia is a Member State of Euronest (of which I am a member), I am all the more pleased to see further approximation of legislation.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument. It has been ratified by all the EU Member States. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In many instances, these problems arise when a couple has separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those states in order to secure custody of the child. The biggest problem in such cases is the differences between the legal systems of individual states. It may often be that the courts in both of the states concerned declare themselves competent, with each of them awarding custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at an international level.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a key instrument in the context of judicial cooperation between contracting States in the resolution of cases of international child abduction. This Convention aims to harmonise the legal systems other than states which normally declare themselves both competent to adjudicate the action and declare custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent by adopting with the Convention the criterion of the State of residence of the minor. As this matter currently is the exclusive external competence of the Union, a Council decision is necessary which call for the Member States to accept the access of third countries to the Hague Convention. I support the Hautala report in this regard and congratulate Armenia on its convention, thereby taking a step towards protecting its minors from abduction.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States of Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. In an international scenario in which the mobility of families across national borders is increasing, the phenomenon of the abduction of children is particularly important in the event of couples' crises. Protecting the child from illegal transfer or non-return is a global problem as well as a key element of the EU programme. Article 24 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union states that children have the right to protection and their interests 'must be considered pre-eed'. I therefore support the accession of the Republic of Armenia because it is only through international cooperation that it is possible to settle the relevant issues of custody of minors and ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. Children with links to the Armenian community can thus be better protected from any danger of abduction.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — We often hear of child abductions taking place in Member States, especially when parents and family members originate from different countries. When this happens within Member States, that child is already protected by legislation, but it is important to protect children also when abducted to non-EU countries.  The accession of more countries to the Hague Convention is welcomed as it extends the network of protection for children. The Hague Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In cases where a couple has separated and the parents are from different States, lack of cooperation between these States can create a situation which is not in the best interests of the child involved.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — What is meant by the international abduction of minors? The term refers to the situation in which a child is unlawfully taken away from habitual residence or national borders, without the consent of the other parent, in violation of the right of custody. The report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an important step ensuring certain rights for Armenian children and the more than 90 countries that have signed the Convention. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Armenia's accession to that Convention.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution since it encourages EU Member States to accept the accession of Armenia to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction. This would allow the Convention to enter into force between Armenia and the EU and thus help to ensure the prompt return of abducted children. All EU Member States have ratified the convention.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes to support the European Parliament for the accession of the Republic of Armenia to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This international agreement, ratified by all EU Member States, aims to establish a system of cooperation in the context of international child abductions, most often intervening in cases of separation or divorce of binational couples. In the event of a referral to the courts of the two States concerned, they may declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the State under its jurisdiction. This convention therefore specifies the jurisdiction of national courts and guarantees a system allowing the immediate return of the abducted child. It is necessary for this international regime to be as broad as possible, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Armenian origin on its soil. In this way, children linked to this community will be protected from illegal abduction. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, ratified by all EU Member States, aims to protect children from international abduction by providing for a procedure for their rapid return. Through the vote on this text, the aim is to invite the Council of the European Union to ask the Member States to accept Armenia's accession. The extension of the territorial application of the Convention to this country is a positive sign in the direction of greater protection for children who are victims of abduction, which I welcome.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction, because in this way minors with links to the Armenian community will find greater protection against this phenomenon. This Convention allows cooperation between the Contracting States in order to find solutions to cases of international abduction of children. This problem arises when spouses from different States, as a result of their separation, exploit the lack of cooperation between the States concerned in order to obtain custody of the children. The aim of this Convention is to settle such situations at international level by establishing that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Armenia must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. — Dear Colleagues, I voted in favour of my colleague Hautala's report on Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, because I believe that statistics on the increased number of abductions in itself speak to the urgent need for cooperation.  According to the data currently available, in 2008 the number of applications for return of children submitted only within the EU on the basis of the 1980 Hague Convention was 990. That means 35% more than in 2003. Unfortunately, the rise in crimes against children is also high. I cannot help but note that it is the kidnapping that is the first step for trafficking in human beings and exploitation for criminal purposes.  I welcome Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention and call on all Member States under this international instrument to take measures to ensure its practical application.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention aims to ensure the immediate return of children who have been unlawfully moved or detained in one of the Contracting States, to ensure that custody and communication rights under the law of one of the Contracting States are respected in the other Contracting States. This Convention creates the infrastructure and communication channels between 92 states to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to arrange custody issues if parents live in different countries. We are voting in favour of the inclusion of other states in the Hague Convention, as it protects children who become victims of disagreements between their parents. The Convention ensures cooperation between States to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — This Decision allows the accession of a new country , in this case Armenia — to the Convention. EU countries need to accept applicants' membership. The Court confirmed in Its Opinion 1/13 that the EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made it necessary for this Council Decision requesting Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of the applicant country concerned to the Convention and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention provides the private international law framework for recovery of abducted children. Its aim is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to safeguard the prompt return of the child and the mutual enforcement of judgments regarding custody and access rights. The vote refers to the acceptance of Armenia, which has joined the Convention in recent years. This agreement will benefit children and families in Wales so I voted in favour.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome this Proposal from the Council to accept Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention. The issue of the defence of children's rights is of central importance and it therefore seems very positive that more and more states should be included, especially given that there are a great many people on European soil from the countries that are now applying for membership, which will facilitate the resolution of cases of abduction between a Member State and these third countries. However, while it is good that all the States of the European Union have acceded to the Convention, I cannot help noticing that the concept of 'good of the child' is often interpreted instrumentally. I am thinking, for example, of Germany, whose children's office, the Jugendamt, actuallyes the good of the child for the good of the German child, depriving the non-German parent and the child himself of many fundamental rights, including some of the founding rights of the Hague Convention. Unfortunately, the problem is not confined to Germany alone, and Europe is powerless to witness these abuses because it does not have the power to intervene in the family law of the individual Member States. That is why I believe that there is an urgent need for harmonisation of legislation in this area.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart. As parents come from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those same States to obtain custody of minors. In these cases, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of the countries concerned to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Convention aims to remedy such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. I voted in favour of accepting Armenia's acceptance of the Hague Convention in the best interests of minors who have links with the Armenian community and who will thus be protected from abduction.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart, and the Convention resolves these types of situations on an international scale, by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the state of residence of the minor. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I am voting against this text because by becoming part of the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction, the European Union is also giving itself a space for interpretation of this text. Let us not be fooled because under the good intentions of defending the interests of children nothing is done - for example - against the expansion of the barbaric practice of surrogacy within the Union. On the other hand, it is up to the Member States to determine sovereignly who may or may not join the Convention, I challenge, once again, this transfer of competence.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The child abduction situation occurs with some frequency when a couple, with members from different States, is reunited. Not accompanying some of the considerations made during this debate concerning the legal systems of each State, it is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Convention aims to address this type of situation at international level. It is its objective to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the rights of custody and visitation existing in a Contracting State. These are fair and relevant objectives. Armenia has deposited the instrument for the convention.  The EU now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the EU. However, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise the participation of international organisations such as the EU. For this reason, the Council had to take a successive decision in order to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I am pleased that Armenia is adjoining the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, and that is why I voted in favour of the report. The Convention provides effective means of settling disputes arising from international abductions of minors as a result of separation or divorce, by establishing that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the child's state of residence.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — The subject of international child abduction largely concerns spouses or couples in which individuals from different countries of the world choose to abuse the situation and wrongly adopt a child after divorce or break-up. Such situations are helped by the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Children often become a means of dealing with accounts between spouses or former partners with different citizenships. Consequently, the national courts, often outside the European Union, often grant custody rights to the parent who is a citizen of the state to which that court is competent, thanks to certain national tendencies. The Convention resolves such situations in such a way that the assignment of the child is decided by the court in the State where he or she resides, regardless of where one of the parents was brought. The EU now has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice. This means that Member States are no longer acting at their discretion. It is therefore necessary to adopt a Council Decision requiring Member States to adopt, in their own territory, the accession of Armenia to the Convention and thus the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that State. The adoption of the convention in question will provide increased protection for children associated in any way with the Armenian community.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the accession of other States to the Hague Convention, as it protects children who fall victim to disagreements between their parents. The Convention ensures that the children return to their normal residence in the event of abduction.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — I strongly support the adoption of stronger cooperative measures to prevent cases of international child abduction. Greater coordination between states is necessary to avoid the temptation, by one of the parents, to secure custody of a child following a separation or a divorce. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 makes it possible to resolve, at an international level, those cases in which the courts of both of the states concerned declare themselves competent and award custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. Moreover the Convention introduces a system which ensures the immediate return of abducted children. I welcome the accession of Armenia to The Hague Convention. Considering the number of EU citizens of Armenian origin, this accession is vital to ensure EU-wide protection of the children in question.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. — International law, including EU legislation, is based on the fact that the most vulnerable members of society, children, can enjoy the most effective protection in all circumstances. One of the means of doing so is the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of the abduction of children, ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention establishes a system of international cooperation between the contracting States to resolve cases involving the abduction of children abroad. In most cases, the problem is the divorce of parents of different nationality who are exploiting the lack of international cooperation to obtain custody of children. The biggest problem in these cases is the different legal frameworks of the different States. The purpose of the Convention is to provide redress and redress in such cases. It is therefore essential that as many States as possible can join this Convention.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. — For the institutions of the European Union, the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an instrument of crucial importance that has been ratified by all EU Member States. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, a problem which we unfortunately face very often and which entails great suffering for the parties involved. The objective of the Convention is to resolve this issue at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. Similarly, the Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. Therefore, once the Decision has been analysed, as well as the case-law of the Court of Justice of the EU, I have decided to vote in favour with the desire to promote Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution. Armenia has ratified the Convention, but its acceptance by all EU Member States is necessary for its implementation between that country and the European Union. To the extent that it is an exclusive competence of the EU, the report refers to the Council Decision by asking Member States about its acceptance, and that is why I have supported it.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour and fully support armenia's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, so that minors with links to the Armenian community can also benefit from EU protection measures in the event of separation or dispute between their parents. The Convention is in fact an instrument of guarantee for children of extraordinary effectiveness, in that it intervenes to bring back to the center of conflicts of couples in crisis of different nationalities the rights of minors applicable in their state of residence, overcoming the temptation of preferential management between the individual countries of origin of the parents and the dramatic risk of international abduction of minors. Europe, the guarantor of human rights, is widening the mesh of measures to protect minors in all the countries that so request, thus preventing unjust national legal favouritism and unholy parenting of child fragility.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction includes 93 countries, including all EU countries. I therefore welcomed the inclusion of Armenia. The vote received more than 90% support, which shows the importance of the situation regardless of political views.  The Convention is an essential instrument for ensuring respect for the rights of a child who has been kidnapped by one of his parents. Child abduction is a crime, a violation of human rights, guaranteed by m.in Charter of Fundamental Rights. Every year in the European Union, there are an average of 3000 child abductions between Community countries, kidnappings without the consent of the other parent. In the Committee on Petitions, of which I am a member, we receive many reports of child abdument. These cases are among the most emotional. This shows how significant and frequent this problem is. The accession of new countries to the Convention is good news, which in the future will result in more efficient investigations into the kidnapping of children.  Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her good work.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Hautala report because The Hague Convention of 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an essential instrument for protecting children belonging to parents from different states that exploit potential conflicts of competence between their national courts in order to secure custody of their child.
