I therefore call on all EU Member States to formally accept the accession of Armenia to the Convention, seeing that this is a crucial step to ensure effective implementation and enhanced international cooperation to protect children who fall victim to international abduction. I do urge the Commission to continuously monitor whether the necessary infrastructure is in place to ensure Armenia is in a position to fully implement the Convention.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted against this proposal on Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention.  This convention is certainly very useful in the management of jurisdictional disputes in cases of child abductions, most often as a result of divorces. Nevertheless, I question the legitimacy of the European Union to intervene in the ratification of this convention between the Member States and other States.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as I believe the accession of Armenia to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (the Convention), which seeks to protect children from abduction across international boundaries, is to be welcomed. It is important that countries acceding to the Convention can participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention. Effective measures now need to be put into place to ensure the rights of the child and that cooperation is fully practicable.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. — The Hague Convention on civil aspects of the abduction of children is a very important legal instrument. All The Member States of the European Union are parties. The Convention provides a system of cooperation for Contracting States to find solutions to cases of child abduction abroad. These problems most often occur in parents who are divering. In order to obtain childcare, a spouse from another State may take advantage of the lack of cooperation between States. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. Often, the courts of both States concerned consider the case to be within their competence and award the right to custody to a parent of their own nationality. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. I therefore consider it of the utmost importance that all states that have not yet done so should accede to the Convention.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. The Convention aims to protect children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on a statement by which Member States, in the interest of the European Union, accept Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction in 1980, as I strongly support the fact that the protection of children's rights is one of the key priorities of the European Union.  I also support the efforts made internationally to condemn any type of violence against children and to meet the most deprived countries. I therefore believe that this Convention can bridge the problems of legal systems that exist in individual Member States.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in the event of international child abduction. The statement of reasons for the report tells us that "The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Like my National Front colleagues on the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I challenge the Legal Capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction. This approval for Armenia must not fall within the Community field, so I voted against it.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This report suggested that Parliament approve the proposal for a Council decision to allow Armenia to access the UN Convention that regulates civil aspects on child abduction, mostly concerning cooperation of authorities for the return of wrongfully removed children and issues of conflict of laws. As the prevention of child abduction is, since the Brussels Regulations on matrimonial matters and parental responsibility, an exclusive competence of the EU policy to promote the rights of the child, the EU is the player at international level to improve the application of the 1980 Convention and to encourage third States to accede it. Article 38(4) of the 1980 Convention stipulates that the Convention applies between the acceding country and such Contracting States as will have declared their acceptance of the accession. Therefore, the EU has to decide whether to accept the accession of a country. When it does so, Member States should make the declaration of acceptance concerning the accession in the interest of the EU; because as the Convention dates from 1980, it does not recognise international organisations such as the EU as an accessing Party. EH Bildu has voted in favour, as the primary matter is broadening of the application of the UN-Convention on child abduction.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the Council's proposal for a decision on Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes mechanisms for cooperation between contracting states to remedy jurisdictional conflicts, particularly when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Accession of Armenia to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction’. We voted for because the EU has exclusive external competence in this field, but the problem is that the Convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organisations. Therefore, the accession of Armenia to the Convention and the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases involving the EU and that country is necessary, especially as many EU citizens are of Armenian origin. Children with links to the Armenian community will thus be safeguarded against abduction and protection will be afforded to the children in question.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — One of the European Union's special priorities is to protect children and strengthen children's rights, as set out in Article 3 of the Treaty on European Union. The prevention of child abduction is an important measure in the context of child protection. The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction of 25 October 1980, as a multilateral agreement, forms the basis for the immediate repatriation of children abducted abroad or children detained abroad. In the meantime, 86 countries have signed up to this convention, but the validity of the law required official permission from the EU, even if individual countries have already implemented it. That is why I support the request to include Armenia in the Hague Convention.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR)
text: in writing. — On behalf of the Conservative MEPs in Parliament and as Conservative spokesman for legal affairs, I voted in favour of this report as the 1980 Hague Convention is an effective tool in the resolution of international child abduction cases and extending its application to more countries, as long as they fully comply with the obligations under the Convention, would enhance the legal certainty for those involved in such disputes.  However, I strongly support the assessments which many Member States currently undertake in order to carefully assess any third country’s ability to implement the Convention properly before accepting its accession. These assessments prevent any potential risks which may arise from returning children to a third country which does not respect rule of law or basic legal procedures in family law cases, or does not have a competent authority which could verify a child’s well-being.  I therefore support calls for the Commission to urgently produce such assessments for these countries, which it has yet to produce.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — In order for the Convention to apply between Armenia and the EU, the acceptance of all Member States is required. I supported giving the acceptance, as the Convention is an important international instrument, which seeks to protect children from the harmful effects of abduction and retention across international boundaries by providing a procedure to bring about their prompt return.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. — International abduction of children as a result of separation or divorce is a reality which unfortunately occurs with a habitual frequency. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. International cooperation is essential for the resolution of these disputes. Hence my full support for this resolution. Armenia's accession to the Convention and, consequently, the effective entry into force of the Convention in cases concerning the European Union and that country is to be welcomed. It is our moral and political duty to ensure that Armenian children enjoy protection at EU level.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mrs Hautala's report because I believe that the protection and promotion of children's rights are priority issues for the European Union, especially on the issue of child abduction. I therefore welcome Armenia's accession.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states.  I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Armenia must not fall within the European scope. That is why I abstained.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty aimed at protecting children from the detrimental effects of abduction and retention across international borders, providing a procedure for early restitution. The following eight countries have ratified the Convention, but its acceptance by all EU Member States is necessary for its implementation between them and the European Union. The countries are Singapore, Russia, Albania, Andorra, Seychelles, Gabon, Armenia and Morocco. To the extent that this is a positive step in the international protection of children, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Armenia's accession to that Convention.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — As I have already stated in the abovementioned on the proposal for a Council Decision on the Declaration of Acceptance by Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Gabon's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of International Child Abduction, I also believe that Armenia should accede to the Convention on International Child Abduction. I therefore conclude by voting in favour of this proposal because, in particular, many citizens in the EU are of Armenian origin; and that, in this way, we will be able to better protect children in our society.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction is an important instrument ratified by all Member States of the European Union. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between states aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. It is often the case that parents of a child live separately in different countries, so the biggest problem is the national bias of the legal systems of individual states. Courts in both countries may enter their claims as competent and each of the parents who are their nationals may be granted custody of the child. The purpose of the Convention is to deal with such situations at international level, so as to establish that the competent courts and applicable laws are only from the state that is the place of residence of the child. The Convention also implements a system that ensures the automatic return of children abducted. The European Union now has exclusive jurisdiction in this area, as confirmed by the European Court of Justice. I support the Council Decision, which calls on Member States to accept Armenia's accession to the Convention, as this is in the interest of the European Union, will contribute to the coherence and uniformity of the application of EU law.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing — Any initiative to expand the number of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction should be supported. This will increase the protection of children from abduction in the territory of the Contracting States and can thus help to return the child to their natural environment more quickly. It is therefore necessary to look for the most effective ways of dealing with international child abduction in order to protect them and strengthen their rights. Many citizens of Armenian origin also live in the EU. Children who are in some way connected to the Armenian community will be protected from kidnapping in this way.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Hautala report on the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on The Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because this Convention adequately addresses at international level the problem of child abduction and is therefore an important legal and political development.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — The accession of Armenia to the Convention is to be welcomed. I fully support this, especially as many EU citizens are of Armenian origin. Children with links to the Armenian community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — Favourable to the proposal for a Council Decision on the declaration of acceptance by the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Convention introduces a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 introduces a system which enables contracting states to cooperate with the objective of finding sustainable solutions for the international abduction of children. The protection and promotion of children's rights are priorities for the European Union, including in the context of its neighbourhood relations. I have given my assent to Armenia's accession to the Convention because, thanks to it, minors with links with the Armenian community will be able to enjoy greater protection in the event of abduction.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — (DE) By voting positively on Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention, I would like to promote the introduction of a system of cooperation between the Contracting States in order to find solutions to the cases of international child abduction.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. —I welcome Armenia's accession to the international convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. It aims to reduce legal conflicts between different national jurisdictions in cases of difficult separations of binational couples. In this legal procedure, however, the Commission has once again undermined the sovereignty of Member States by seeking recognition of these accessions on behalf of the European Union, even though the Convention does not recognise international organisations (such as the Union) as a signatory party. I am voting in order to recognise this new membership in the benefit of the protection of children across borders.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — With Armenia's membership of the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, the EU takes another step towards achieving one of its priorities, which is the protection and promotion of the rights of the child. Thus, children of Armenian origin residing in the EU are protected from abductions.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction aids in establishing the relevant jurisdiction to award custody of the child in question. The EU now has exclusive external competence in facilitating cooperation between contracting states to settle cases of international child abduction but requires each state to accept the accession of new signatories in their own territory. Therefore, I support each Member State’s acceptance of the extension to the Convention as it would ensure the protection of the child’s best interests in cases involving Armenia.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — The request for the participation of a growing number of countries to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction demonstrates the need to apply common rules at international level, which can respond fairly and fairly to differences in existing legal systems. On the other hand, this Convention intends to reduce and prevent violations of the right of custody and the right of access that may follow.  For the reasons set out above, I am in favour of Armenia's application for the application for the ousto.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Armenia is by no means within the European scope. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — It is important to get as many countries on board as possible. The accession will allow those countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which approves Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention is a major instrument in the fight against the illegal detention and displacement of children that occur as a result of family conflicts. In practical terms, it provides for cooperation mechanisms to resolve jurisdictional disputes between jurisdictions in the event of a binational separation. It also guarantees a return system in case of abduction. The larger the number of States parties to this convention, the greater the international guarantee of children's rights.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We believe that the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance, ratified by all EU Member States, in that it introduces a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. The aim is to avoid situations of uncertainty or dangerous legal loopholes. It is stipulates, in fact, that the competent court and the applicable law are those of the State of residence of the child. While the European Union has exclusive external competence in this area (as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13), i.e. individual Member States no longer have the opportunity to act individually by referring to their own legal systems, the problem remains that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organisations. In order to overcome this legal difficulty, the Council has decided that it will be up to the individual Member States to accept, each in relation to its own territory, the accession of new States to the Convention. We therefore welcome Albania's accession to this Convention, so as to ensure that children with links to the Armenian community can find protection against abduction at EU level.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because Armenia's accession to the Convention is news to be welcomed, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Armenian origin on its soil. In this way, children connected to this community will be protected from abduction.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this report, together with all the other documents on the agenda, relating to the acceptance by the Member States, in the interest of the EU, of Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. The report refers to situations in which children are placed following divorce or separation of parents, conditions in which they may be abducted, and questions the custody of the child of one of the parents, as well as the establishment of the courts competent to deal with the case.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — An important measure against international child abduction is international standards of protection and contractual conventions. In this respect, I welcomed and voted in favour of Armenia's proposal to accede to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because the Hague Convention on child abduction is a crucial piece of legislation. The accession of each new State to the Convention on this issue contributes to international child abduction cases and excludes biased justice. The protection of children's rights must take up a very important role in international relations and justice.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. — The legitimate interests of the child must be taken into account everywhere and at all times, since children who are at war with parental ambitions are themselves victims. The more states join this Convention, the easier it will be to resolve international child abduction conflicts and to ensure effective protection of the best interests of the child internationally. Only countries that work closely with each other will ensure the full well-being of children.  It needs to be noted that when dealing with any issues related to the child, they must be assessed from the point of view of the best interests of the child and ensure that these interests are not prejudiced. The child must not only become a hostage to parental ambitions, but also a victim of imperfect rules of international law and practices for their application. It is therefore essential that, in divorce cases, the fight for which the child will remain with is protected by the best interests of the child and that his or her right to communicate with both parents is guaranteed. It is essential that all states act in a targeted manner to prevent the international abduction of children and that an expeditious system of judicial and administrative authorities is established.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance. The Convention introduces a system which allows contracting states to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abduction. In the event that spouses come from different States, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between the States concerned in order to obtain custody of children, and there is often a tendency for the legal systems of individual States to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality. The aim of the Convention is to deal with these situations at international level and the many CITIZENS of the European Union who originate in Armenia and children with links to the Armenian community will thus find protection against abduction. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — Disturbed relationships between parents as well as their divorce pose a major risk to the health of children, not to mention the violent removal and retention of a child by one of the parents, which constitutes an enhanced stress factor on the child's psyche. In the event of a divorce, it is essential that the existence and proper functioning of a reliable child protection mechanism is essential.  The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction is currently the most useful binding legislation for the protection of children when it comes to international kidnapping. Armenia's approach to the 1980 Hague Convention allows for the protection of children in case of adverse developments in their parents' personal relationships.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — This convention proposes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This is the case, for example, when a couple separates or divorces. However, the statement of reasons for the report cynically explains that "the major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states". Another attack on the national sovereignty of states. That is why, like my fellow front-runners in the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I reject the legal capacity of the European Union to become a party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction. This approval for Armenia is by no means within the European scope. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support armenia's accession report to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction in 1980, especially as it is an Eastern Partnership country. Although Armenia has ratified this Convention, its application to EU member states requires the consent of all Member States.  I believe it is in the interest of all of us that problems that can be caused by the non-compliance of legal systems, if the parents of the child come from two different countries, are adequately regulated. Children's rights must come first, and as children have suffered the consequences of legal unregulatedness, I would like to express my full support for this report once again and call on all EU member states to do the same as soon as possible.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — In order to resolve the cases of abducted children of Armenia and the European Union, I support this report for accepting accession to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction from 1980. Every year, eight million children disappear in the world, which would mean nearly 22,000 children disappear every day. All our efforts should be directed towards ensuring a better future for our children, and so this Convention, signed by all members of the European Union, should ensure a secure future and the realisation of all children's rights.  As the report states, the most common problem is agreeing on the court's jurisdiction over the allocation of care to children whose parents are from different countries, as well as the lack of communication between the two countries. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such cases in predetermined competent courts and to use the prescribed laws.  Countries that approach it are entering a common system of tackling child abduction. If the legal systems differ too much and the country does not have the means to form a body that will implement the laws and proposals of this convention, the country cannot even access it. This is precisely the problem that Armenia's approach to the Hague Convention is taking place so slowly.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I welcome the fact that Armenia has also decided to accede to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction because, thanks to this accession, minors with links with the Armenian community will be able to find protection against the abductions to which they may be subjected.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. — I consider it important and beneficial that the area covered by the Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction will be extended to other States. I particularly welcome the fact that this is also Armenia, because it is important for us from the central and eastern parts of the Union, where traditionally contacts with the countries of the former Soviet Union are intensified, which can also lead to more cases in the area dealt with by the Convention.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — With this text, the European Parliament must appreciate the opportunity for the recognition by European Union law of Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. Thus, the European Union and its 28 Member States are united and apply this convention uniformly when such a dispute with Armenia arises. It is important to solve such problems because they are family dramas that occur when parents find themselves confronted with Kafkaesque judicial systems. I am therefore in favour of anything that can improve the dialogue and resolution of family problems between judicial systems.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction, which occur very often following divorces and separations of parents from different States. More specifically, the Convention, seeking to counter the nationalist tendency of the legal systems of each State, provides that these cases must be tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the state of residence of the minor and also provides for a system ensuring the immediate return of the abducted minor. Although this is currently a matter of the EU's exclusive external competence, the fact is that the Convention does not provide for independent intervention by international organisations. To this extent and in order to ensure the protection of minors who have links with the Armenian community, member states need to accept armenia's support. This proposal for a Council decision rightly calls for such acceptance. I voted in favour.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Hague Convention, dated 25 October 1980, is an important instrument with regard to the civil aspects of international child abduction. The fact that it is a system of cooperation between the different States makes it easier to find solutions to a problem that persists in our day. Strengthening legislative systems must be an imperative and Armenia's amendment to the Hague Convention must be viewed with great satisfaction.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the Convention between the European Union and that country. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of States Parties to find a solution to situations of international child abduction, and has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. I welcome Armenia's accession to the Convention. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Armenian community will be protected against illegal abduction.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on member states to accept, each with regard to their territory, the accession of Russia, Andorra, Seychelles, Albania, Singapore, Morocco, Armenia and Gabon. Our position is to vote for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. But the major problem often remains the differences between the legal systems of the Member States. The convention in question is also intended to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child. Today I voted in favour of Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — Also in the case of this report on Armenia, we are dealing with a proposal to resolve conflicts of territorial competence in the field of international child abduction, allowing Member States to accept their support for the 1980 Hague Convention. Since the assumptions are equivalent to those already mentioned for other Contracting States, I consider it essential that Member States accept their support, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report which approves Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction, which all the Member States of the European Union have ratified.  This convention strengthens cooperation between states, addresses the problem of differences between legal systems that arises and thus establishes the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state where the child resides.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report on Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention because I believe that greater international cooperation on the international abduction of children is essential for all our citizens.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because it is a question of protecting the rights of the child.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been ratified by all Member States. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own. The problem is that the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem has made necessary the Council Decision calling on the Member States to accept, each with regard to their territory, Armenia's accession.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text which allows Armenia to join the Hague Convention on International Child Abductions. This multilateral treaty protects children abducted outside their usual place of residence. Since the opinion of the Court of Justice on 14 October 2014, the European Union has exclusive jurisdiction over the acceptance of a new state to the convention.  These abductions, which are increasingly common in the divorces of binational couples, give rise to dramatic situations that require a rapid response from the authorities. Membership of the Convention will facilitate cooperation between the European and Armenian judicial authorities to organise the rapid return of abducted children, so that the competent local judge can make a decision on who is responsible for the custody of the child.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Armenia's accession to that Convention.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the accession of the Armenia to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The accession of Armenia to the Convention is to be welcomed. Many EU citizens are of Armenian origin. Children with links to the Armenian community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing — It is very important that the provisions of this Convention preventing and prior international child abduction should also apply in other countries which have not yet been bound by them or have merely acceded to the Convention. I therefore voted in favour. It should be stressed that, even in these very difficult family-legal situations, often with a strong geopolitical context, when national courts tend to rule biased, it is always and at all costs necessary to take into account the rights, well-being and dignity of children. A child cannot be abused in any way and cause him emotional, psychological or physical suffering. Even in a situation where an adult is trying to claim the so-called 'right to a child'. A child is no business item that can be disposed of as an object or a tool for blackmailing another, as unfortunately often happens in these cases. The best interests of the child must always come first and everywhere.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — Since the Convention on civil rights aspects of international child abduction signed in the Hague on 25 October 1980 wishes to protect children by ensuring as soon as possible the return of children unlawfully removed or detained in a Contracting State, and wishes to ensure that the rights of care and sighting with a child under the law of one Contracting State are actually respected in another Contracting State, I welcome this decision to join Armenia.  I believe that the most important task of the Convention is to introduce a system of cooperation between contracting states aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. I consider it positive that the Contracting State will designate a central authority to carry out the obligations provided for by the Convention for such an organ, in particular because the central executive authorities will cooperate with each other and improve cooperation between the competent authorities between the contracting countries in order to ensure the return of the child as closely as possible, and therefore I support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support Armenia’s accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. International cooperation is vital in ensuring the protection of the rights of children.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil-Legal Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vital instrument, as confirmed by the fact that it has been ratified by all Member States. The aim of the Convention is to create a system of good cooperation among all signatories in order to jointly try to solve this crucial problem.  To avoid conflicts between Member States, the EU has shifted the entire competence to itself. All of the above points to the conclusion of the need to expand the application of that convention at global level and therefore I support armenia's accession with a view to ensuring that children are protected from possible snatching as much as possible.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. — The accession to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction in principle is acceptable, and the extension of these international rules to Armenia is to be welcomed. There remains a slight concern that Armenia will need further assessment in order to confirm their full compliance with their obligations; however, this has been raised by the Member States in the Council. As the European Parliament does not have a formal role in this process and is only being asked for consent and as the measure is positive in extending the reach of an international standard in difficult situations, I can support this vote.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The accession of more and more States to the Hague Convention develops the appropriate infrastructures and channels of communication between those States to deal with child abduction by one parent but also to make it easier to deal with custody issues if parents live in different countries. Cooperation between several states to return children to their normal residence in the event of abduction is also promoted.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. — The accession of Armenia to the Hague Convention is a necessary step to ensure that Member States parties to the Convention can take as broad a action as possible against the abduction of children abroad. I support this proposal, because the protection of children is of paramount importance in all circumstances and all possible legal instruments must be used.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — The Union now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area under the 1/13 opinion of the Court of Justice. Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. The problem is that the convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organizations. This problem necessities the Council's decision to accept Armenia's accession to the Convention on its own territory and, therefore, the effective entry into force of the convention between the European Union and that country. Armenia's accession to the Convention is news to be welcomed, especially in view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Armenian origin on its soil. In this way, children linked to this community will be protected from illegal abduction.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a crucial legal instrument to fight against child abduction. This is the reason why I voted in favour of this report. Protecting the rights and interests of children must be one of the priorities of the EU and by supporting the accession of this country to the Hague Convention we reinforce the legal framework to ensure these key principles. However, we need to monitor and to follow up on how it is implemented.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — The European Union does not have the legal capacity to impose anything in this area under the 1980 Hague Convention. The justification for Armenia's accession to this convention, which is supposed to be in the interests of the European Union, is therefore not valid.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the eight reports accepting the accession of Armenia, Morocco, Singapore, Albania, Russia, Seychelles, Andorra and Gabon to the 1980 Hague Convention. This Convention lays down the framework of private international law for the recovery of abducted children. Its objective is to ensure that judicial and administrative cooperation is effectively applied to ensure the rights of the child, and mutual respect for custody sentences.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I support the objective of this Convention of avoiding opposition between two national legal systems that defend only the interest of their own national, and not the interest of the child in the event of abduction by one of its parents when they are nationals of different states. This conflict between legal systems must be avoided in order to ensure that the rights of the child prevail, including that of being visited by both parents. I have therefore supported the report from the Committee on Legal Affairs in favour of granting Armenia's accession to that Convention.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This Convention is essentially intended to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held in any Contracting State and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The following countries have deposited the instrument of membership of the Convention: Albania; Andorra; Armenia; Gabon; Morocco; Singapore; Seychelles, Russia. The European Union now has powers in the field of the Convention, in accordance with Decision 1/13 of the Court of Justice of the European Union. However, although Member States no longer have such competence, the 1980 Hague Convention does not recognise participation in international organisations such as the European Union, so the Council has taken a successive decision in order to approve the application for membership by Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - By voting positively on Armenia's accession to the Hague Convention, I would like to promote the introduction of a system of cooperation between the Contracting States in order to find solutions to the cases of international child abduction.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — I welcome Parliament's approval of the proposal for a Council decision on the declaration of consent of the Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of Armenia's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (HKÜ). The HKÜ is an almost exemplary solution under international law and an example of fruitful international cooperation for the protection of children. Nothing is worse for a child than a break-up of his parents' relationship. To make matters worse, parents sometimes start a dispute over the child, which is always at the expense of the child. Rarely, but unfortunately still far too often, a parent reacts with child abduction in order to create facts and, for selfish reasons, avoid a custody dispute. The HKÜ provides a sustainable framework to prevent and counteract cross-border child abductions. This cannot in principle prevent the damage done to the child, but it at least offers the possibility of returning the child to his or her usual environment.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of the Convention in question is to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visiting rights existing in a Contracting State. The child abduction situation occurs very often when a couple of people secede and when the parents come from different states. According to the rapporteur, the main problem lies in the nationalist tendencies of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the state they represent. The Purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's state of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. Armenia has deposited the instrument of access and we have spoken in favour, since this Agreement is in line with the defence of the interests of minors.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the verification of credentials of European parliamentarians from the Committee on Legal Affairs as this is a necessary procedure after each election to the European Parliament. Following the elections, all Member States are responsible for notifying the names of parliamentarians, as well as for verifying that there is no inconsistency between their activities and the mandate of Member of the European Parliament, on the basis of Article 7 of the Act of 20 September 1976.  I have decided to support this report from the conviction that it is for the Member States to carry out this check, as well as to notify the names of the members of the European Parliament declared to be valid.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — At the beginning of each parliamentary term, the European Parliament shall check, in accordance with the Statute for Members and its Rules of Procedure, whether the elected Members meet the conditions for exercising their mandate. Among other things, it checks whether they perform tasks which are incompatible with membership of the European Parliament and whether they have made a statement specifying their professional activities and all other functions which they perform for remuneration. Such an examination is necessary for every new Parliament to function as quickly as possible. I therefore welcome this decision, which declares the mandate of my fellow Members to be valid.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — This proposal recalls the rules of eligibility and the exercise of the mandate of a Member of the European Parliament in the interests of transparency and respect for the rules which tend to eliminate conflicts of interest. In paragraph 4, it takes a negative judgment on the electoral law and eligibility rules of certain Member States. The exercise of democracy can only be carried out within the framework of a nation state. The rules governing the right to vote and eligibility are also the responsibility of the States and cannot be contradicted by the principle of free movement as advanced in the proposal. So I abstained in that vote.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — As a UKIP MEP, it is consistent for me to vote against, as the rejection would have serious consequences for the functioning of the European Union!

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to declare the mandate of members of the European Parliament whose election has been notified by the competent authorities of the Member States. This proposal relates to the results of the direct EP elections held from 22 to 25 May 2014. I support the proposals tabled by the competent authorities of the Member States to immediately submit the names of those who can be replaced by meps, listed in order according to the number of votes received. It is also necessary to complete the examination of the disputes submitted to them without delay and to report to Parliament on the outcome. I support the calls for Member States to ensure that registration formalities relating to the participation of nationals of other Member States in EP elections are simplified, be it the electorate or the candidates, in particular by removing unnecessary administrative barriers.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — This report proposes to declare valid the mandate of MePs in the European Parliament whose election has been communicated by the competent national authorities. However, other proposals put forward in this area do not seem acceptable to me, namely: - the invitation for Member States to ensure that registration procedures relating to the participation of citizens of other Member States in European elections, as voters or candidates, are simplified; - the non-application of the disqualification of the right to vote in European elections for European citizens who have lived in another country. These principles implicitly implying European citizenship prevented me from voting in favour of this text and I abstained.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report proposes to declare valid by the European Parliament the mandate of MePs in the European Parliament whose election has been communicated by the Member States. We find in the appendix the list of MEPs but it is also called in this proposal to ensure that the vote for citizens of other Member States of the European Union is simplified for the European elections, implicitly implying European citizenship. In addition, it is required that the loss of the right to vote should not apply to European elections if European citizens have lived in another country. I therefore abstained on principle on this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Svoboda report because I share the views expressed in it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — Following the relevant analyses, the Parliament has declared valid, without prejudice to any decisions taken by the competent authorities of the Member States in which an election result had been challenged, the mandate of Members of the European Parliament contained in the decision voted in accordance with the rules in force. It also urges the competent authorities of the Member States to conclude as soon as possible the examination of the challenges submitted and to inform Parliament of their outcome. It also calls on Member States to ensure that registration formalities relating to the participation of nationals of other Member States in European elections have been simplified. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it completes the scrutiny of the powers of members of the European Parliament elected in the Member States on 22 May 2014 and publishes the list of Members of the European Parliament currently in force. This is due to the fact that, for some time after the elections in the Member States, disputes concerning the final list of Members of the European Parliament elected in those countries are still ongoing. Disputes arise for various reasons, such as the right to stand for election as defined by national law (a problematic situation arises in Cyprus, Denmark, Ireland, Malta and the United Kingdom) and conflicts of interest incompatible with the duties of a Member of the European Parliament. The approved list of Members of the European Parliament is attached in the Annex to this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — The European Parliament has validated the election of each Member in the 8th legislature. I believe this strengthens the legitimacy of all Members.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted yes because I recognise the legitimate election of me and my colleagues.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. This report proposes to declare the mandate of MEPs in the European Parliament whose election has been communicated by the Member States in accordance with the mandate. We find in an appendix the list of MEPs, but it is also required in this proposal to ensure that the vote for citizens of other Member States of the European Union is simplified for the European elections, clearly implying the existence of European citizenship. In addition, it is required that the loss of the right to vote do not apply to European elections if "European citizens" have lived in another country. That is why I abstained on this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) The report calls on the Member States to simplify the voting and ratification of elected representatives of the European Parliament and to conclude the numerous disputes quickly. I voted in favour.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. — The report on the verification of credentials is carried out at the beginning of each legislature, with the aim of validating the mandates of the members of the European Parliament, on the basis of notifications made by the relevant national authorities after the elections, and verifying that the required declarations have been made in accordance with Article 7(1) and (2) of the Act of 20 September 1976 and Annex I to the Parliament's Rules of Procedure. The annex to the report on credential verification includes the list of all members of the European Parliament. In the initial report, paragraph 5 read as follows: 'Ask the Commission to check whether national legislation providing for an oath of allegiance to the national Constitution or other similar requirement — as is the case, for example, with Article 224(2) of the Organic Law of the General Electoral Regime of Spain — is fully in line with the Act of 20 September 1976 and the Statute of Members of the European Parliament'.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — In each new Parliament, the validity of Members' terms is verified using the data provided by Members. It is necessary for the European Parliament to be as transparent as it is in the eyes of its citizens. It is the duty of the deputies to demonstrate the compatibility of their mandate with their other activities. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the report on the verification of credentials. The report, presented by the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs, which is responsible for verifying members' credentials, refers to the results of the direct election of the European Parliament from 22 to 25 May 2014 and is based on the official communication by each Member State of all the election results. The communication also covered the clarification of the names of the elected candidates and their possible substitutes and the ranking, as shown in the vote. Today's vote therefore concerned the validation by the European Parliament of the mandates of members elected at the last elections who made the planned written statements.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs has taken note of the results of the European elections as communicated by the electoral offices of the various Member States, declaring the election of Members of the European Parliament valid.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. "A position of balance was necessary for this text and that is why I chose abstention.  On the one hand, it is crucial that the elected representatives of the European institutions, which already have a legitimacy that is more than tainted, especially with the suspicions against Mr Juncker which would have facilitated tax exile, that the elected representatives of the people present in the European Parliament are beyond reproach. However, once again the European Union is overstepping its powers and seeking to encroach on those of the Member States. Thus, when Parliament "believes that the loss of the right to vote is tantamount to punishing nationals who have exercised their right of free movement in the European Union" and "in no case can the loss of the right to vote apply to European elections and asks the Commission to ensure that no Member State foresees this possibility". This kind of assertion is a further attack on the sovereignty of the Member States and, as a patriot, I could not vote in favour of this text.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — Article 7 of the 1976 Act specifies the posts which are incompatible with that of a Member of the European Parliament. In addition, in accordance with Rule 11 and Annex I of the Rules of Procedure, Members are required to state precisely the professional activities paid, whereas pursuant to Article 12 of the 1976 Act, the European Parliament shall decide on the objections raised as to the validity of the mandate of its members only in the event of a breach of the provisions of that Act and not in the event of a breach of national electoral provisions. In accordance with Article 12 of the 1976 Act, Parliament must take note of the results of the elections. The United Kingdom Electoral Commission has reported that some nationals of other Member States residing in the United Kingdom have not been able to exercise their right to vote. Deprivation of the right to vote is tantamount to punishing citizens who have exercised their right to free movement within the EU, denying them the right to vote (Article 20 TFEU) and violating the principle of direct universal suffrage (Article 14(3) TEU and Article 1 of the 1976 Act). The European Parliament considers that under no circumstances can deprivation be applied to European elections and calls on the Member States to comply with European law. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the verification of Members' credentials, because I believe in the transparency of the elected institutions in the rule of law. As a Member of Parliament, I am obliged to state precisely my professional activities and any other paid function or activity. It also seems right to me that Parliament should take note of the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the competent authorities of the Member States without any discretion in this regard. However, this provision does not prevent Parliament from reporting, where appropriate, any cases of incompatibility between national electoral legislation, on which the results are based, and EU law.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. On the basis of a report prepared by the Legal Affairs Committee, Parliament verifies the credentials without delay and rules on the validity of the mandate of each of its newly elected Members and also on any dispute referred to it, except those based on national electoral laws. The committee’s report is based on the official notification by each Member State of the full results of the election specifying the names of the candidates elected and those of any substitutes together with their ranking in accordance with the results of the vote.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the verification of the credentials of newly elected Members of the European Parliament. This matter is governed by the Act of 20 September 1976, as amended by Council Decision 2002/772/EC, Euratom of 25 June and 23 September 2002, and by the Regulation of the European Parliament.  Each Member is required to sign two written declarations: the first on the absence of incompatible posts and the second on his own financial interests. Failure to submit the above declarations makes it impossible to validate the mandate. In view of the fact that the JURI Committee, which is responsible for this matter, considered that the requirements for the adoption of this report were met, I felt that I was complying with its position by not finding any evidence to be in place.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — The procedure whereby Parliament takes note of the verification of credentials of those elected as Members of Parliament serves to provide European citizens with a procedure that takes note of their votes but also provides a system whereby Members are required to provide written declarations that include holding of offices and financial interests. This procedure provides European citizens with a transparent procedure. The report also considers issues which are fundamental to a fair electoral process such as disenfranchisement and exercise of electoral rights and seeks to safeguard the right of all EU citizens to vote in elections for the Members of the European Parliament.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — In accordance with the Rules of Procedure, the European Parliament is called upon to verify the credentials of the new Members of the European Parliament in order to declare their mandate valid. In essence, written statements made by Members regarding their professional activities and any other paid function or activity are checked. The rapporteur proposes that Parliament should declare valid, subject to any decisions of the competent authorities of the Member States in which the election results have been contested. In addition, the authorities of the Member States are invited to complete the examination of pending disputes concerning the election of Members of Parliament and to inform Parliament of the results. Pending the end of the disputes that have arisen in the various Member States, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the verification of credentials of European parliamentarians from the Committee on Legal Affairs as this is a necessary procedure after each election to the European Parliament. Following the elections, all Member States are responsible for notifying the names of parliamentarians, as well as for verifying that there is no inconsistency between their activities and the mandate of Member of the European Parliament, on the basis of Article 7 of the Act of 20 September 1976.  I have decided to support this report from the conviction that it is for the Member States to carry out this check, as well as to notify the names of the members of the European Parliament declared to be valid.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour this resolution which states that the Parliament declares valid, the mandate of Malta’s six MEPs (including myself) and all other elected MEPs, whose election has been notified by the competent national authorities and who have made the written declarations as regards their professional activities and any other remunerated functions or activities. This resolution also calls for Member States to ensure that the registration formalities relating to the participation of nationals of other Member States in the European elections are simplified.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The aim of this report is to declare valid, in according with the status of MEPs and subject to possible decisions by the competent authorities of the Member States in which the election results were allegedly contested, the mandate of MEPs elected to the European Parliament in the elections last May. While no challenges and incompatibilities have been found to date, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — The proposal put to the vote recalls the rules of eligibility and the exercise of the mandate of a Member of the European Parliament in the interests of transparency and respect for the rules which tend to eliminate conflicts of interest. However, this proposal, in paragraph 4, has a negative judgment on electoral law and the eligibility rules of certain Member States. The exercise of true and most effective democracy can only be carried out within the framework of a nation state. The rules governing the right to vote and eligibility are also the responsibility of this sovereign state and cannot be contradicted by the principle of free movement as advanced in the proposal. For these reasons, I abstained in this vote.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — Within the EU there must be a civil liberties regime and the protection of the right to vote and to stand as a candidate.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — In some Member States, objections to the election of certain Members of the European Parliament are being considered in accordance with national law and these procedures could lead to the annulment of the election of the members concerned. The Committee on Legal Affairs has jurisdiction to verify the credentials of Members. The report on which the proposal is based, concerning the results of the elections by direct suffrage to the European Parliament held between 22 and 25 May 2014, is based on official communications from all Member States on all electoral results. It takes into account that, in order to verify the credentials of its members in accordance with Article 12 of the 1976 Act, Parliament should take note of the results of the election officially declared by the competent authorities of the Member States, without the possibility of discretion in the case.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — All Member States must indicate the names of candidates elected to the European Parliament and to review complaints about the validity of the election of some Members. At this point there are still delays or non-communication of the names of the elected candidates, as well as unresolved cases. For the proper functioning of the European institutions, in particular Parliament, and for Member States to communicate quickly to the European Parliament not only the names of all elected candidates, but also the list of possible substitutes and to complete without delay the examination of disputes submitted to them and inform Parliament of the results.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The Committee on Legal Affairs has jurisdiction to verify the powers of Members. This report, which includes the list of elected Members, informs on the results of the direct elections to the European Parliament which took place from 22 to 25 May 2014, based on the official communications of all Member States on the final results of those elections.  The rapporteur highlights several important aspects, such as the fact that some nationals of certain Member States who have resided in another country for a certain period of time may have been deprived of the right to vote in their home Member State, which in some cases may also entail the deprivation of the right of eligibility. The rapporteur considers, quite rightly, that the deprivation of the right to vote and eligibility in the Member State of residence to citizens who have exercised the right of free movement within the EU amounts to punishment and violates the principle of direct universal suffrage. It calls on the Commission to ensure that none of the Member States provides for such a possibility. It also calls on the Member States to simplify registration formalities for the participation of nationals from other Member States in European elections, both as voters and as candidates, in particular by removing unnecessary administrative barriers. We voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — At the beginning of each parliamentary term, it is necessary to finalise a report on the verification of the entrustment documents to Members of the European Parliament, as announced by the competent national authorities after the elections. Unfortunately, however, certain formalities are still in place in some Member States, which make it extremely difficult for candidates to participate in elections. Registration formalities should be simplified and more effective so that all citizens have an equal chance of standing and competing for the votes of voters in elections.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report calling on the Member States to simplify the voting and ratification of elected representatives of the European Parliament and to conclude the many disputes quickly.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — Within the EU there must be a civil liberties regime and the right to vote and to stand as a candidate must be guaranteed. My vote is in favour of controlling the mandate.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which concerns a largely technical measure to validate the mandate of the Members of the European Parliament at the beginning of the legislature.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament to verify the validity of the mandate, as I believe it empowers the democratic principles of the European Union and empowers the principle of transparency.  I support the activities of the competent national authorities, but also of the European Parliament, aimed at clearing up disputes concerning Members. I also agree with the prohibition of the deprivation of voting rights and the simplification of administrative barriers arising within electoral cycles. Members of the European Parliament hold a very important duty which must surely be subject to validation and compliance.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — The proposal put to the vote recalls the rules of eligibility and the exercise of the mandate of a Member of the European Parliament in the interests of transparency and respect for the rules which tend to eliminate conflicts of interest. However, this proposal, in paragraph 4, has a negative judgment on electoral law and the eligibility rules of certain Member States. The exercise of true and most effective democracy can only be carried out within the framework of a nation state. The rules governing the right to vote and eligibility are also the responsibility of this sovereign state and cannot be contradicted by the principle of free movement as advanced in the proposal. For these reasons, I abstained in this vote.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. " I voted in favour of the report on the verification of powers and the validity of the mandate of each member of the European Parliament. As no incompatibility has been found, this report confirms the validity of the election of all Members.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Verification of credentials’ because we agree in principle.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The verification of parliamentary seats, which, in accordance with Parliament's Rules of Procedure, is required to be carried out by the Committee on Legal Affairs is, on the one hand, a formality, a simple administrative procedure for our House and, on the other hand, an opportunity to look in detail at the elections to the European Parliament and, given the most important problems, to put forward proposals that could contribute to making the methods of conducting them more effective. Among the communications published by Member States after the Elections held in May 2014 were annotations concerning cases where certain citizens were deprived of their right to vote. This applies to Irish, Danes, Cypriots, Maltese and British living outside their countries. This is a clear example of violations of the rights of EU citizens (the right to free movement of persons and the right to vote), and this is also completely incomprehensible when we consider the technological possibilities available to almost every European. I am signing up to the rapporteur's call on the Commission to eliminate such cases in the future and to oblige Member States to develop effective voting systems for their citizens residing abroad.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
