text: Writing. — This report reviews the functions, ancillary income and other activities of MEPs which are deemed compatible with the office of European Member of Parliament in accordance with Articles 7 (1) and (2) of 20 September 1976. For this reason, the home states had to send to Parliament all the names of the elected candidates to verify the legality of the outcome of the election and to verify the capacity to be admitted to that post. If, in relation to the basic conditions laid down in the 1976 Act, it becomes apparent that the candidate's ancillary activities and functions are incompatible with the exercise of the mandate in Parliament or that there were irregularities in the conduct of the election (such as the withdrawal of the EU's right to vote by citizens who have exercised their freedom of establishment within the EU), the mandate may be annulled. In order to actively respect the right of EU citizens to vote and the credibility of Parliament and its Members, I fully agree with the proposals to safeguard the right to vote and the results presented here to review the activities of Members in terms of compatibility with their mandate.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of Mr Svoboda's report as chairman of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs. The report adopted today is based on the conformity of the last European elections of 22-25 May 2014 and is based on the official communication by each Member State of all the election results. The verification of the credentials of newly elected Members of the European Parliament is governed by the Act of 20 September 1976 on the election of Members of the European Parliament by direct universal suffrage (as amended by Council Decision 2002/772/EC, Euratom of 25 June and 23 September 2002) and by the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. In accordance with Annex VI, Section XVI, point 10 of the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs is responsible for verifying members' credentials.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — This report proposes to have the european Parliament validate the mandate of Members of the European Parliament whose election has been communicated by the Member States. Attached is the list of MPs. However, it should be noted that it is also stated in this text that a simplification of the vote for citizens of other Eu-Member States for the European elections should be encouraged, implicitly implying the notion of 'European citizenship'. In addition, it is required that the loss of the right to vote should not be applied in European elections in the event that European citizens have lived in another country. As a matter of principle, I have decided to abstain on this text.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the verification of credentials of European parliamentarians from the Committee on Legal Affairs as this is a necessary procedure after each election to the European Parliament. Following the elections, all Member States are responsible for notifying the names of parliamentarians, as well as for verifying that there is no inconsistency between their activities and the mandate of Member of the European Parliament, on the basis of Article 7 of the Act of 20 September 1976.  I have decided to support this report from the conviction that it is for the Member States to carry out this check, as well as to notify the names of the members of the European Parliament declared to be valid.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — With this vote I declare that, without prejudice to the possible decisions taken by the competent authorities of the Member States in which an election result had been challenged, the mandate of Members of the European Parliament set out in the Annex to the Decision under the vote. I encourage the competent authorities of the Member States to conclude as quickly as possible the examination of the challenges brought against the eligibility of some members. Finally, I recall that the right to active and passive suffrage in European elections is an inalienable right and, therefore, I urge Member States to provide the voting process to nationals of other EU States in their territory and to the Commission to make a more strong effort to do so that there are no cases of refusal , active and passive, of the right to vote.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Svoboda report on the control of the mandate of Members of the European Parliament listed in Annex I to the decision concerned, because all the candidates elected in the European elections which took place from 22 to 25 May 2014 in the 28 EU Member States, as shown by the audit of the competent Commission of the European Parliament, were legally elected, as the relevant electoral provisions of national laws and the provisions of the Act of 20 September 1976 on the election of representatives to the European Parliament by direct universal suffrage (as amended by Council Decision 2002/772/EC, Euratom of 25 June and 23 September 2002) and Parliament's Rules of Procedure were adopted.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this report which repeats Parliamentʼs request to the competent national authorities not only to notify it promptly of all the names of the elected candidates but also to forward the names of any substitutes, together with their ranking in accordance with the results of the vote.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — This report refers to the results of direct elections to the European Parliament, which took place between 22 and 25 May 2014. It is based on an official communication from each Member State on the election results. The verification of the credentials of newly elected MEPs is governed by the Act of 20 September 1976 on the election of Members of the European Parliament by direct universal suffrage (as amended by Council Decision 2002/772/EC, Euratom of 25 June and 23 September 2002) and by the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. In accordance with Annex VI, Section XVI, point 10 of the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs is responsible for verifying members' credentials. I agree with Mr Svoboda's report, because it fully expresses the conformity of the last European elections with the provisions on the subject.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — I voted on the examination of the mandates, because all the data provided by the Member States were submitted on time and no inconsistencies could be identified in the review of them. According to the reviewbody, all mandates comply with the legislation and can therefore be declared valid.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — In accordance with Article 12 of the 1976 Act, the European Parliament verifies the powers of its members. To this end, it takes note of the results officially proclaimed by the Member States and decides on any challenges that could possibly be raised. This report, having found no irregularities, declares valid the list of members of the 8th Parliament. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — With this formal act, the names of all MEPs elected in the 28 Member States in the elections of 22 to 25 May 2014 are validated and this process will be completed.  All Members wish all my best in fulfilling their mandates.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because of the need for Member States to notify Parliament accurately of all the names of the elected candidates and the names of any substitutes, together with their ranking in accordance with the results of the vote. This is essential to guarantee Parliament’s legitimacy as a democratic institution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — On 20 September 1976 the European Act on the election of representatives to the European Parliament by direct universal suffrage was published. In 1976, positions were defined which are incompatible with the position of Member of the European Parliament and it was identified which professional activities they have, as well as any other paid functions or activities. I am in favour of this report, which criticises the fact that some individuals from certain Member States who have resided in another country for a certain period of time have been deprived of the right to vote and be cast in their Home Member State, as has happened in the United Kingdom. I also believe that all Member States should send quickly the list of Members elected to the European Parliament and the identification of all substitutes in the event of a replacement for elected representatives.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This report proposes to have the European Parliament validate the mandate of MePs in the European Parliament whose election has been communicated by the Member States. Attached is the list of MPs. However, it should be noted that it is also stated in this text that a simplification of the vote for citizens of other Eu-Member States for the European elections should be encouraged, implicitly implying the notion of 'European citizenship'. In addition, it is required that the loss of the right to vote should not be applied in European elections in the event that European citizens have lived in another country. As a matter of principle, I have decided to abstain on this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. " I voted in favour of this text which verifies the validity of the mandate of each of the 751 MEPs (no incompatibility of functions, no recourse). This report concluded that the mandate of all Members of the European Parliament was valid. It calls on Member States to simplify registration procedures on electoral lists to enable all European citizens to make effective use of their right to vote in European elections, regardless of their Member State of residence.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted for this report because the Committee on Legal Affairs has jurisdiction over the verification of Members' powers and this report deals with the results of the direct election to the European Parliament which took place from 22 to 25 May 2014 and is based on official communications by all Member States of the full results of the election.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this report because it comes to strengthen once again the rules on participation in European elections, both as a candidate and as a voter, of the citizens of the European Union. The report also refers to the entire procedure for communicating the names of the candidates elected in the European Parliament elections, to the legal framework governing the verification of their credentials, to the way in which they make the declarations they have to make upon entering the mandate, to the resolution of disputes which may arise as a result of non-compliance with principles relating to the voting system in each Member State (e.g. non-compliance with quotas , where appropriate – the alternating woman-man, on lists, etc.), but also the deprivation of the right to vote and the exercise of electoral rights, which in some countries such as Cyprus, Denmark, Malta, Ireland and the United Kingdom are different from most Member States.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of examining the mandates, as all the formal rules have been complied with and, according to the reviewing body, the mandates also materially complied with the requirements laid down.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the bill because it will make it possible to remove unnecessary administrative barriers and to simplify registration requirements relating to the participation of nationals of other EU Member States in European elections, either as a voter or as a candidate.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — Article 7(1) and (2) of the Act of 20 September 1976 specifies the posts which are incompatible with that of a Member of the European Parliament. Members are required to state precisely the professional activities they perform and any other paid function or activity. In some cases, Member States have partially notified the elected candidates and in some of them the objections to the election of certain Members are being examined and these procedures could lead to the annulment of the election of the Members in question. In order to verify the powers of its Members, Parliament is authorised to report any cases of incompatibility between national electoral legislation, on which the results are based, and European Union law. Nationals of certain Member States who have lived in another country for a certain period of time may be deprived of the right to vote in their Member State of origin. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — This report proposes to have the european Parliament validate the mandate of Members of the European Parliament whose election has been communicated by the Member States. Attached is the list of MPs. However, it should be noted that it is also stated in this text that a simplification of the vote for citizens of other Eu-Member States for the European elections should be encouraged, implicitly implying the notion of 'European citizenship'. In addition, it is required that the loss of the right to vote should not be applied in European elections in the event that European citizens have lived in another country. As a matter of principle, I have decided to abstain on this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support my colleague Pavel's report and the provision that the elections and mandates of all Members are validated. In my view, this confirms and empowers the legitimacy of MEMBERS of the European Parliament to represent citizens and protect their interests on the basis of the votes through which they were elected.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — I support fellow MEP Pavel Svoboda's report on the validity of members' mandates in the European Parliament. Following the last European elections in May 2014, the competent services to the EP, in cooperation with the Member States, initiated and implemented the procedure for determining the validity of members' mandates, and established a list of MEPs whose mandate was declared valid.  Elections to the European Parliament are also governed by national legislation with specific national provisions that are different in each country and European legislation setting common rules for all Member States. The common rules set out the principle of incompatibility of duties with the mandate of Members of the European Parliament.  The European Parliament is the only directly elected body representing the EU's 500 million inhabitants. MEPs influence many segments of the everyday life of the European public, and the procedure for verifying the validity of mandates is one of the elements that guarantees that MEPs will perform their duties independently.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) It seems to me absolutely right, vis-à-vis the voters of the European Union, that the powers of the members of the elected Parliament should be audited by the Committee on Legal Affairs. Of course, the European Parliament will have to refer to and take note of the official results of the elections from the relevant competent authority of the Member State, and in this respect the European Parliament has no discretion, but it is right that the European Parliament should ensure that there are no cases of incompatibility between national electoral legislation and EU law. It is important that Members, so that the system is as transparent as possible, sign at the beginning of their term of office the declaration of the absence of incompatible posts and the declaration of financial interests.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — The last European elections presented two types of irregularities. On the one hand, some Member States have failed in their obligation to report the substitutes of European elected representatives and on the other hand some citizens have not been able, or at least, have experienced difficulties in their right to vote in these elections because of their nationality. Being, of course, committed to democratic values as well as the exercise of the right to vote and to elect this type of election on the basis of his place of residence and not on the basis of his nationality, I voted in favour.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — This Decision concerns the verification of the powers of MEPs elected from 22 to 25 May 2014. Under Article 12 of the Act of 20 September 1976 and Article 3(4) of the Rules of Procedure, the European Parliament must verify the powers of its members, recording to that end the results officially proclaimed by the Member States and deliberating on any complaints made on the basis of the Act, with the exception of those based on national electoral laws. Since all Members have submitted the declaration on the non-performance of incompatible functions and the declaration on their financial interests and that, to date, no complaints have been lodged under the 1976 Act, the Committee on Legal Affairs, which is competent on the basis of the matter, proposes that, subject to any decisions of the competent authorities of the Member States in which the election results have been contested , the mandates of the Members listed in the Annex are declared valid. I voted in favour, also associating myself with the concerns expressed about the deprivation of the right to vote and the simplification of registration formalities relating to the participation of nationals of other Member States in the European elections.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — The transparency effort must be inherent in the European Parliament and the role of the MEP. The proposal put forward is precisely for constant scrutiny to detect aspects that need to be corrected or simplified as soon as possible, as is the case with aspects relating to the deprivation of the right to vote and the exercise of the electoral rights of citizens in their Member State of residence after they have exercised their right of free movement within the EU.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — Following the relevant analyses, the Parliament has declared valid, without prejudice to any decisions taken by the competent authorities of the Member States in which an election result had been challenged, the mandate of Members of the European Parliament contained in the decision voted in accordance with the rules in force. It also urges the competent authorities of the Member States to conclude as soon as possible the examination of the challenges submitted and to inform Parliament of their outcome. It also calls on Member States to ensure that registration formalities relating to the participation of nationals of other Member States in European elections have been simplified. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support this report of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the verification of the powers of those elected to the European Parliament from 22 to 25 May, as it stems from the legal framework inherent in the election of Members of the European Parliament. This concludes the last step envisaged in this legislative framework, which began with the formal submission of applications and culminates in this verification of powers by the European Parliament itself.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — As a democratic institution and directly emanating from European citizens, the European Parliament has a duty to ensure that the European elections are in line.  I supported this report, which recalls that no challenges or incompatibilities have been found to date, thus concluding the validation of the European elections on 25 May.  In particular, this text reminds us of the importance of transparency and respect for electoral rules.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because the report calls on the Member States to simplify the voting and ratification of those elected to the European Parliament.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the verification of credentials of European parliamentarians from the Committee on Legal Affairs as this is a necessary procedure after each election to the European Parliament. Following the elections, all Member States are responsible for notifying the names of parliamentarians, as well as for verifying that there is no inconsistency between their activities and the mandate of Member of the European Parliament, on the basis of Article 7 of the Act of 20 September 1976.  I have decided to support this report from the conviction that it is for the Member States to carry out this check, as well as to notify the names of the members of the European Parliament declared to be valid.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for the verification of Members’ credentials, confirming the results from the Member States of the full elections held in May 2014.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — I supported the report on the verification of the validity of the mandates of members of the European Parliament whose election was notified by the competent national authorities and who made written statements concerning their professional activity.  Given that Article 7 (1) and 2 of the The Act of 20 September 1976 clearly defines duties incompatible with the duty of MEMBERS of the European Parliament, and that Members are required to make detailed statements about their professional activities and any other duties or activities paid, it is important to identify them and verify that everything complies with the rules of procedure. It is important to note that this report also aims to address the problem of confiscation of voting rights.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report which verifies the credentials of the Members who were elected in the 2014 European elections.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament to verify the validity of the mandate, in accordance with Article 3. The Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, which instructs the competent authorities of the Member States to inform Parliament without delay of the names of elected Members, so that the mandates of all Members can begin at the same time, and to declare that they do not perform the duties incompatible with that one.  As it is possible to deny in some Member States the right to vote if their nationals reside for a certain period of time in another country, these are considered to be unfair sanctions whose existence contradicts the basic right to freedom of movement within the EU.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing — I support the proposal because it will lead to clearer rules and, among other things, to the elimination of certain cases of discrimination against voters and candidates in European Parliament elections who are in a country other than their home country.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — Within the EU there must be a civil liberties regime and the right to vote and to stand as a candidate must be guaranteed.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the proposal. We reiterate his request to the authorities of the Member States not only to inform him of the names of the elected candidates, but also to indicate to him those of the possible replacements with their order of classification as resulting from the vote. We also call on the competent authorities of the Member States to complete the examination of the challenges presented to them without delay and to communicate the results to Parliament.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this procedural report by the JURI Commission on the verification of credentials. That report declares valid — although subject to the decisions of the competent authorities of the Member States in which the relevant election had been challenged — the mandate of the members of the European Parliament contained in the Decision whose choice has been notified by the competent national authorities and which have made the written statements provided for on the basis of Article 7 , paragraphs 1 and 2 of the Act of 20 September 1976 and Annex I to the Rules of Procedure of the Parliament.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the verification of credentials of European parliamentarians from the Committee on Legal Affairs as this is a necessary procedure after each election to the European Parliament. Following the elections, all Member States are responsible for notifying the names of parliamentarians, as well as for verifying that there is no inconsistency between their activities and the mandate of Member of the European Parliament, on the basis of Article 7 of the Act of 20 September 1976.  I have decided to support this report from the conviction that it is for the Member States to carry out this check, as well as to notify the names of the members of the European Parliament declared to be valid.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The report calls on Member States to simplify registration formalities concerning the participation of nationals of other Member States in European elections, both as voters and as candidates, in particular by removing unnecessary administrative barriers, and calls on the Commission to ensure that Member States' practices are in line with EU law. To that end, it declares that, subject to any decisions taken by the competent authorities of the Member States in which election results have been contested, the mandate of Members of the European Parliament whose election has been notified by the competent national authorities is valid. We have nothing to either oot or comment on.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - I voted on the examination of the mandates, as all the data provided by the Member States were submitted on time and no inconsistencies could be identified in the review of these. All mandates comply with the legislation according to the reviewbody and can therefore be declared valid.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The report deals with irregularities in european elections in some EU countries. The report calls for the deprivation of the electoral rights of citizens who are not in their country of residence at the time of the elections not to be used in European elections. Calls on the Commission in this regard to ensure that no Member State allows this possibility. The report calls on the Member States to ensure that registration formalities for participating in European elections for citizens of other Member States, both as voters and candidates, are simplificationy, in particular by removing unnecessary administrative barriers. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Pursuant to section 10 of Section XVI of Annex VI to the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs has jurisdiction to verify the powers of Members. This report, which includes the list of elected Members, informs on the results of the direct elections to the European Parliament which took place from 22 to 25 May 2014, based on the official communications of all Member States on the final results of those elections.  We voted in favour of this report which includes precise information on some worrying non-compliances in the electoral process, which needs to be resolved in the near future: nationals of certain Member States who have resided in another country for a certain period of time may have been deprived of the right to vote in their home Member State; several nationals from other Member States residing in the United Kingdom were unable to exercise their right to vote in the last European elections. The rapporteur advocates simplifying registration formalities concerning the participation of nationals of other Member States in European elections, both as voters and as candidates, in particular by removing unnecessary administrative barriers, which could obviate the problem.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like briefly to welcome the resolution that was carried today in respect of the cross-border exchange of information. It is crucially important that we act collectively on this issue because we know that when foreign drivers of foreign cars are driving in any of our Member States the propensity for offences to occur is much greater. That goes back to evidence in 2007, when a Commission report showed that unless you have proper means of enforcement it becomes very easy for people to break the law. So, it is a good day’s work that we have managed to put this resolution through. Bad and dangerous driving behaviour can be affected only if people feel they are going to be caught. And there is a responsibility on all Member States to ensure a proper, adequate flow of information from one country to the next in order to make sure that happens. Lastly I would say this: in my own country, in Ireland, I have been arguing for a very long time that we need to have a joint approach, North and South, to penalty points. We have been trying, on a cross-party basis and with the British Government, to achieve that. I think it makes sense, especially where there is a shared border between two jurisdictions, to have a common approach to penalty points. If today’s resolution on the exchange of information leads to that in countries which are close to one another, it makes absolute sense from a European perspective.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour because I believe it is right that the exchange of information on road traffic offences should be a matter of road safety rather than police cooperation. There are too many cases in which the authorities are unable to punish those guilty of infringements because they are committed by foreign vehicles. Those responsible cannot be traced because their domicile is unknown. For the safety of all, the free movement of persons and their means, in this case of transport, must be matched by the free and rapid movement of information. In the case of offences which seriously endanger road safety, such as speeding or driving under the influence of drugs, the perpetrators must be absolutely traced. If the victims can be anywhere, the culprits must be traced everywhere.

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR). -
text: Mr President! In the Danish People's Party we say yes to more road safety. Therefore, it is also important that those who come to Denmark or other countries and violate traffic rules are also punished for their actions. By exchanging information on road traffic offences, we also believe that some of the types of people who might like to carry out offences may think before they come to the country.  We don't want people to drive too fast. Nor do we want them to be able to drive in a drug-affected state, nor do we think they should be run over to full stop. That is why it is good that we are working together to ensure that people learn to drive properly and thus can also be punished for their wrongdoing. That's why we say yes. That's why I said yes.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! If you will, the report today is based on a fruitful dialogue with the European Court of Justice. There has also already been a directive to this end, where it has been established that we have taken the wrong legal bases. This has now been adapted with this report. I think that is good news for everyone. For me, it is also a contribution to justice: no matter where you are, you have to comply with the rules. This justice, if everyone abides by the traffic rules, also entails a higher level of safety. That in itself is the good story. This can help to increase overall safety in the transport area. There is, of course, also an obligation on ourselves: Parliament must then turn this report into a new directive by 6 May 2015. However, I think that we will also be able to vote on this directive in the same unity as on this report.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of this regulation which is aimed at facilitating the cross-border exchange of information relating to traffic offences. The implementation of this is crucial as it should mean that people who have committed a road traffic offence in a country that they are not resident in can still face the penalties for their actions. This is a particular issue, as has already been said, in Ireland, where unfortunately we have a land border and a minority of drivers have used that border as a mechanism to basically show disregard for road safety laws when travelling on the opposite side.  We know also that drivers from other EU countries have been basically immune when they are driving on Irish roads. So, hopefully we can now reach the point where penalty points can be shared across jurisdictions, because the priority has to be to ensure the safety of all road users.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I voted against this motion, which I am delighted to say the UK Government also opposes. I think the arguments we have heard in favour of it are fundamentally flawed: they boil down to the idea that since cars cross borders we must therefore have a common EU policy, which is the same logic we hear over and over again. This might – I am not sure – be construed as an argument for global government. But it certainly is not an argument for a narrow harmonisation of policies under this particular institutional structure with 28 of the 196 independent states and territories represented at the UN. The myth is that if you do not have Commission involvement you do not get cooperation. It is not true. We have had decades of judicial cooperation: the Hague Convention, extradition treaties recognising time spent in another country’s prison as part of a sentence, etc. It is perfectly possible for two countries if there is a pragmatic case for it, as we just heard suggested by Comrade Carthy a second ago. There is a perfectly good mechanism whereby two sovereign governments come together and reach a bilateral deal. It does not follow that we have to hand the whole thing to an unelected bureaucracy in Brussels.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI). -
text: Mr President, with all repressive against motorists, speeding will now be punished more severely than burning someone else's car, as is practiced quite frequently, for example, in this city of Strasbourg on the occasion of the New Year. What is paradoxical about this Ayala Sender report is what the rapporteur identifies as the causes of the increase in the number of victims. I quote: "This number nevertheless seems to be rising again, which can be explained by various factors". What are these factors? The aging of the car fleet, drastic cuts in infrastructure maintenance spending and the lack of funding for infrastructure and innovations that can improve road safety. In other words, there is no mention at any time, among the causes of the increase in the number of victims, of speeding, which we can see is, in fact, the basis of the text and the device proposed to us. We can reduce the speed to 30 km/h, as here at the exit of Parliament. But why not at 20 km/h, 10 km/h, 5 km/h? It will always be even safer, and there will always be fewer victims. That is the stupid logic we are giving today.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I was surprised that UKIP and some Conservatives have opposed this particular piece of legislation. It can only mean one thing: that in their own country they are in favour of foreign-registered cars, be they driven by citizens of other countries or British expats returning home, having immunity from prosecution when they commit an offence such as drunken driving or gross speeding.  This is incomprehensible. Why should ordinary resident citizens have to pay fines and those who by one means or another are driving a car registered in another country not be punished and not have to face the consequences of their offences? It is not, as Mr Hannan was claiming, an attempt to have common EU policies and regulations on all aspects of driving safety. It is about allowing each country to enforce the rules that exist in each country when they are broken by those resident in other countries. It is a good example, a sensible example, of how we can work together at European level to benefit our citizens.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE). -
text: A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm vótáil ar son an cheithre vóta a bhain leis an tuarascáil seo de réir threoir mo ghrúpa an EPP. Dar ndóigh bhí an tuairim chéanna ag an gcuid is mó de na Feisirí. Bhí tromlach mór ina fabhar agus ní nach ionadh é sin mar tá sé go léir ráite ag an rapóirtéir, Feisire Sender, nuair a labhair sí roimh an vóta.  Sábhálfaidh an tuarascáil seo saolta amach anseo. Maraítear na mílte duine ar bhóithre na hEorpa gach uile bhliain agus is fiú rud éigin a dhéanamh faoi. Táimid ag déanamh sin anois agus taispeánfaidh sé sin gur féidir leis an Aontas oibriú ar son ár saoránach, rud go bhfuil géarghá dúinn a thaispeáint sna laethanta seo agus a lán daoine ag cáineadh. Freisin is léir go raibh na saineolaithe go léir i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo agus is fiú agus is ceart i gcónaí éisteacht leis na saineolaithe agus rinneamar é seo inniu.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: Mr President, honourable Members, I supported the resolution on cross-border exchange of information in road accidents, because I believe that the policy on reducing casualties in transport accidents must be supported and must be followed consistently. The fine for violation of traffic rules is also preventive in nature. Therefore, it is reasonable to make such an exchange. Yes, the protection of personal data is definitely an important civil right, which must also be vigorously defended, but no less important is the preservation of the lives of our compatriots and fellow citizens. I therefore believe that all violations of road traffic rules made by non-residents must necessarily be prosecuted with all the strictness of the law and therefore this data can be transmitted.  I realise that transposing this information into national law will require time and a huge amount of work. I therefore consider that granting the Kingdom of Denmark, Ireland and the United Kingdom a two-year transitional period is a sufficient, normal and real period. In conclusion, I would like to emphasise that I support the prevention policy for road accidents.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because, after four years of institutional blockade and after making the necessary changes to adjust the legal basis, today we can have an instrument that will allow us to fight impunity for foreign drivers and which will ensure that all Europeans, regardless of the registration of their vehicle, are treated equally.  With this Directive, traffic authorities may automatically identify vehicle owners regardless of the country of registration when they have committed infringements which are responsible for more than 75% of road deaths. It will greatly contribute to meeting the challenge of halving the number of road casualties by 2020 and avoiding 350 to 400 deaths per year on our roads, the equivalent of a passenger plane. European citizens will also be able to continue to move on our roads feeling protected and safe.  Given Parliament's strong support, the Commissioner has acceded to Parliament's request and has publicly pledged to accompany the evaluation report scheduled for 2016, which has already been launched, with new proposals to complete the procedure, as we had asked from the outset.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I supported this report on the proposal for a Directive facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety traffic offences — on the basis of the principle that this process must take place through mechanisms to ensure the protection of personal data — by sharing the objective of the report, which is to end the anonymity of drivers not resident in the State in which they commit the infringement and to ensure that they are not left without Sanction. I am convinced that, when it enters into force, this Directive will discourage reckless behaviour and dangerous behaviour on the road, which will save many lives; hence my support for the text.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this regulation, which aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information related to traffic offences. The implementation of this regulation is crucial, as it should mean that people who commit a road traffic offence in a jurisdiction where they are not resident can face the penalties for their actions. This is a particular issue in Ireland, as a minority of drivers have used the border as a means of showing disregard for road safety laws on one side of it or the other. We also know that drivers from other EU countries have been basically immune to Irish traffic laws. Hopefully these problems can now be addressed. The priority must be to ensure the safety of all road users.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — Road safety is one of the main priorities of European transport policy. An important part of this policy is the enforcement of penalties for road traffic offences committed by non-resident drivers. Lawns, driving over a red light or driving under the influence of alcohol would thus be punishable across borders within the EU. This in turn requires a cross-border exchange of information between national administrative authorities: the Member State in which a traffic offence is committed has access to the vehicle registration data of the Member State in which the vehicle is registered. Based on its 2011 directive annulled by the ECJ, the Commission presented a new proposal for a directive in June 2014. I welcome the legal basis (transport) adapted in accordance with the Treaties, which obliges the member states previously excluded (the United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark) to implement the Directive. This ensures that everyone in the EU is treated equally, no matter where their vehicle is registered.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — The original directive of 25 October 2011 was overturned on 6 May 2014 by the European Court of Justice for lack of legal basis. This proposal takes it almost identically but on new legal grounds.  The aim is to force Member States to pass on all traffic offences committed on their territory to the driver's Member State. I consider it preferable to remain in inter-state cooperation with regard to road safety and not subject Member States to additional obligations and I would like to limit the application of the directive to the most serious offences, the excessive penalisation of the lightest offences more akin to the persecution of motorists. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — This report relates to speeding offences; the idea is to be able to transfer licence points across Member States.  Not all Member States are the same; this could lead to unfair cases of people being banned from driving. Block vote 1-2 is difficult: we are uncertain about Amendment 1 because of data protection issues. But we are in favour of Amendment 2 which offers a delay for the UK, Denmark and Ireland.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it is an essential step in the fight against the most serious traffic offences and traffic-related deaths, wherever they occur on European Union soil.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal of broadening the initial Directive 2011/82/EU because it provides the legal basis for improving security of European roads. To begin with, it allows the sharing of information relating to road safety violations between traffic enforcement agencies of Member States at Union level. I think this will help to stop impunity of traffic violators who committed a violation in a state other than their home state because it will be much easier to find, notify and if necessary punish those breaching traffic rules accordingly. In addition, the proposal has broadened the initial scope of the directive by including such offences as driving a vehicle without a helmet, driving while using mobile devices or being under the influence of drugs as well as incorporating such countries the United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark into the agreement. In my opinion it is likely that more extensive scope of resolution will contribute to the lowering of the overall number of fatalities in the EU. Overall, I believe that this resolution, like its predecessor, will ensure greater traffic safety throughout Europe and will work as a deterrent regarding reckless driving.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because, after four years of institutional blockade and after making the necessary changes to adjust the legal basis, today we can have an instrument that will allow us to fight impunity for foreign drivers and which will ensure that all Europeans, regardless of the registration of their vehicle, are treated equally.  With this Directive, traffic authorities may automatically identify vehicle owners regardless of the country of registration when they have committed infringements which are responsible for more than 75% of road deaths. It will greatly contribute to meeting the challenge of halving the number of road casualties by 2020 and avoiding 350 to 400 deaths per year on our roads, the equivalent of a passenger plane. European citizens will also be able to continue to move on our roads feeling protected and safe.  Given Parliament's strong support, the Commissioner has acceded to Parliament's request and has publicly pledged to accompany the evaluation report scheduled for 2016, which has already been launched, with new proposals to complete the procedure, as we had asked from the outset.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which will allow EU Member States to exchange information on road safety offences and undisciplined drivers. Most of the offences, especially speeding, are committed by foreigners and not by the population of the countries in which they were committed. One of the main reasons is that the authorities, who do not know the place where the owner of the vehicle is resident, cannot inform him of the fine. The proposal provides that the authorities of the Member States responsible for road safety may require data on the owner of a vehicle registered abroad if he has committed an infringement in order to inform him of the infringement in the language of the country concerned. The directive contributes to the EU's target of halving the number of road accident victims by 2020 and reducing the number of injured by 40%. I support the proposals to strengthen this system in such a way that infringements can not only be reported, but also put into practice penalties.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — The purpose of this report is to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences, where such offences have been committed in a Member State other than the one where the vehicle in question was registered. Member States would therefore be obliged to pass on traffic offences committed on their territory to the Member State from which the driver is based. The stated intention is to apply 'sanctions for traffic offences committed in the EU which pose a serious threat to road safety'. However, this measure risks unnecessary persecution of drivers who commit minor offences, without really addressing the most serious cases of road violence. I am thinking in particular of criminals who use stolen cars or drug dealers who use the "go-fast" technique, who often do not have a driver's license or identity papers. While I support in principle the sanctions against drivers who take advantage of the current system to commit offences, I am more than reserved about the effectiveness of the measures proposed here: I have therefore voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — The 2011/82/EU Directive facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences came into force on 11 November 2013. It allows the exchange of information between States Parties regarding road offences committed by non-residents that endanger the safety of the driver and other road users such as speeding, driving under the influence of drugs, failure to wear helmets for motorcyclists, use of a mobile phone and traffic on an illegal route. However, the directive was overturned by the Court of Justice on 6 May 2014 because it was approved on an erroneous legal basis, namely police cooperation (rather than transport safety).  However, the Court gave a one-year period to allow the adoption of a new text. There was therefore an urgent need to approve this text which will actively contribute to the European target of halving the number of road fatalities and 40% of the number of injured by 2020. The change in the legal basis will also allow the INCLUSION of the United Kingdom, Denmark and Ireland in the scope.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. — With today's vote, Parliament confirms the agreement reached in December 2014, which will allow the current cooperation between eu countries' police forces to exchange information on traffic offences. Cooperation will also be extended to all 28 Member States (including Denmark, UK and Ireland). This is an important measure to reduce the number of road casualties. The EU has committed to haled the number of fatal road accidents by 2020. It is important here that foreign speedsters or drivers who drive under the influence do not go unpunished. A good exchange of information on traffic offences between EU countries is therefore indispensable.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report and the motion for a resolution is identical to the 2011/82/EU directive which was annulled by the Court of Justice and is represented here by changing the legal basis. The proposed directive aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences committed in a Member State other than the one where the vehicle in question was registered. However, three countries will have authorization to delay the implementation of this proposal: the United Kingdom, Denmark and Ireland.  In principle, if it is necessary for foreign drivers who take advantage of the current system without data exchange to commit offences to be framed, the question of data protection at European level but also of road policy must be asked. Indeed, the Commission is only moving towards the systematic repression of motorists (it is true that speed cameras and other fines bring significant revenues for the States), but nothing is being done in terms of road infrastructure or the development of public transport, especially in rural areas, in order to provide an alternative for motorists. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) The Sender report is balanced and I support it. I am convinced that greater safety on our roads also depends on a better and more effective exchange of information between Member States, including on infringements committed by road users.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because, after four years of institutional blockade and after making the necessary changes to adjust the legal basis, today we can have an instrument that will allow us to fight impunity for foreign drivers and which will ensure that all Europeans, regardless of the registration of their vehicle, are treated equally.  With this Directive, traffic authorities may automatically identify vehicle owners regardless of the country of registration when they have committed infringements which are responsible for more than 75% of road deaths. It will greatly contribute to meeting the challenge of halving the number of road casualties by 2020 and avoiding 350 to 400 deaths per year on our roads, the equivalent of a passenger plane. European citizens will also be able to continue to move on our roads feeling protected and safe.  Given Parliament's strong support, the Commissioner has acceded to Parliament's request and has publicly pledged to accompany the evaluation report scheduled for 2016, which has already been launched, with new proposals to complete the procedure, as we had asked from the outset.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supported police cooperation in all EU countries in the event of road safety offences. From now on, drivers who have violated road safety rules in another EU country will receive fines in their country of residence. The EU has decided to introduce legislation allowing the police to exchange data on offenders between Member States, as most of the offences, in particular speeding, were detected by foreigners and not by the population of the countries in which they were committed. The Directive thus allows the authorities of the Member States responsible for traffic and road safety to require data on the owner of a vehicle registered abroad if he has committed an offence which has constituted a serious risk to road safety in order to inform him of the infringement committed in the language of the country concerned. It was agreed that fines would be applied across the EU for major offences: speeding, driving without a seatbelt, driving through a red traffic light, driving under the influence, driving on the lane and using a mobile phone while driving.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. — I supported the proposed report because, in my opinion, it represents an important step towards improving safety on Europe's roads and reducing the number of deaths. It's never pleasant when we're greeted in a mailbox by a message from the police about a traffic offence that we may not even have realised we had committed. This reminds us that we are more vigilant in the future. This is what we do to keep ourselves and others safe. However, we behave differently abroad, as the likelihood of receipt of a notification of offence is lower than in our home country.  In order to increase the level of road safety throughout Europe, a full exchange of information between EU Member States on traffic offences is therefore crucial. It allows a country to apply the rules applicable to its citizens also to foreign nationals. Any driver will be aware that if he is breached traffic laws, he will be fined. A misdemeanor is a misdemeanor, no matter where it's committed.  However, I would like to stress that countries must act proportionately, both in the prescription of penalties and in their recovery, in accordance with the seriousness of the offence. At the same time, they must also provide adequate transport infrastructure, which has been shown to increase the level of road safety. I hope that Slovenia, where I come from, will also be aware of this.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I wholeheartedly support the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road traffic offences. The speed and cooperation shown by the European institutions on this issue is a positive and encouraging sign, and in this respect we hope that we will continue to work quickly to ensure that the proposal enters into force by May 2015 so that there are no legal gaps. Following the annulment of Directive 2011/82/EU by the Court of Justice of the European Union, its content is re-proposed by adapting the previous text to the renewed legal basis. This is intended to confirm the desire not to allow road traffic offences to be allowed with impunity by maintaining a European code of conduct according to which the anonymity of non-resident drivers is not possible. I particularly welcome the commitment to a strengthened exchange of information between authorities in the different States on security, which will facilitate harmonisation between different national practices.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — I support this report on the cross-border exchange of road safety information as it meets the needs of all participants in this process. Given that this report has achieved enhanced data protection, as well as better cooperation between Member States and the Commission with a view to a timely and complete road safety report, I consider it a step forward from the last report.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal for the cross-border exchange of information on road safety, for two main reasons: on the one hand, this proposal, from the outset, has the main aim of facilitating the repression of speeding, which is identified by automatic radar control equipment. It is therefore not so much the safety of motorists as a spirit of lucre that animates the authors of the proposal; on the other hand, this mechanism technically requires the revealing of personal data to foreign states. These exchanges of data, between states, international organizations and even private companies, tend to multiply. Justified when it comes to combating terrorism or illicit trafficking, these devices become dangerous when they end up affecting all citizens. For my part, I will not endorse this Orwellian drift of the European Union.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this regulation, which aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information related to traffic offences. The implementation of this regulation is crucial, as it should mean that people who commit a road traffic offence in a jurisdiction where they are not resident can face the penalties for their actions. This is a particular issue in Ireland, as a minority of drivers have used the border as a means of showing disregard for road safety laws on one side of it or the other. We also know that drivers from other EU countries have been basically immune to Irish traffic laws. Hopefully these problems can now be addressed. The priority must be to ensure the safety of all road users.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because I consider the exchange of information regarding road safety inside the Union in order to protect our citizens to be very important.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. This report and the motion for a resolution is identical to the 2011/82/EU directive which was annulled by the Court of Justice and is represented with a simple modification of its legal basis. The proposed directive therefore aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences committed in a Member State other than the one where the vehicle in question was registered. However, three countries have been granted authorisation to delay the implementation of this proposal: the United Kingdom, Denmark and Ireland. If it is necessary for foreign drivers who take advantage of the current system to commit offences, the question of data protection at European level and road safety policy must be asked. Indeed, the Commission seems to defend only the systematic repression of motorists, without proposing anything for the strengthening of road infrastructure. So I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The high number of accidents involving non-resident drivers indicates that the cross-border exchange of road traffic information must become a necessity. A common internal market implies rights and obligations assumed by all citizens of the Union.  Thus, drivers of other nationalities must be treated equally, regardless of where they are. Access to a central base, which should not only include deviations from traffic or parking rules, is essential.  There are numerous cases where, as a result of accidents committed in the territory of another State, the authorities face the problem of identifying the domicile of the parties involved. I believe that the strengthening of the common system for verifying the validity of insurance policies should also be taken into account. I was in favour of the proposal for a directive because I am convinced that the exchange of data on deviations from traffic rules will help to reduce the number of infringements and strengthen safety on public roads.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) The basis of the measure is the need to improve road safety, including through a better exchange of information between Member States. I voted in favour.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour because, after four years of institutional blockade and after making the necessary changes to adjust the legal basis, today we can have an instrument that will allow us to fight impunity for foreign drivers and which will ensure that all Europeans, regardless of the registration of their vehicle, are treated equally.  With this Directive, traffic authorities may automatically identify vehicle owners regardless of the country of registration when they have committed infringements which are responsible for more than 75% of road deaths. It will greatly contribute to meeting the challenge of halving the number of road casualties by 2020 and avoiding 350 to 400 deaths per year on our roads, the equivalent of a passenger plane. European citizens will also be able to continue to move on our roads feeling protected and safe.  Given Parliament's strong support, the Commissioner has acceded to Parliament's request and has publicly pledged to accompany the evaluation report scheduled for 2016, which has already been launched, with new proposals to complete the procedure, as we had asked from the outset.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The European Parliament has voted in favour of legislation to end impunity for road offences committed by European motorists. With this new directive, Member States will be able to exchange registration files to locate the owner of the vehicle. I voted in favour of this directive, which will bring our judicial and police systems together to create a coherent single market.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements. With this vote, the European Parliament had a responsibility to adopt the new directive in order to avoid creating legal limbo in this area with negative consequences for the road safety of European citizens following the judgment issued on 6 May 2014 by the COURT of the EU. The Court of First Instance had declared the Directive void because it was adopted on an incorrect legal basis (system for the exchange of information between the competent authorities of the Member States), but had extended its effects for twelve months in order to enable the legislature to correct its defects and adopt a new text in accordance with the legal basis relating to transport safety. I welcome the fact that Parliament has been able to adopt the new version of the directive quickly because it has already shown its potential: since its entry into force in November 2013, the number of infringements by foreign drivers, aware that any infringement committed abroad would be notified to them thanks to this new mechanism , has in fact decreased.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this regulation, which aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information related to traffic offences. The implementation of this regulation is crucial, as it should mean that people who commit a road traffic offence in a jurisdiction where they are not resident can face the penalties for their actions. This is a particular issue in Ireland, as a minority of drivers have used the border as a means of showing disregard for road safety laws on one side of it or the other. We also know that drivers from other EU countries have been basically immune to Irish traffic laws. Hopefully these problems can now be addressed. The priority must be to ensure the safety of all road users.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — We are voting in favour of this directive. The exchange of information in the field of road safety is a key step in the process of European integration and in reducing the number of accident victims.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. " With this report, the European Parliament wants all motorists to be persecuted in the same way.  If, on the face of it, the principle of equality that presided over the drafting of this text can be considered commendable, what lies behind the Commission's text is the possibility for the European Union to punish all motorists, instead of the Member States. The report explains in the explanatory statement: "Parliament has proposed to strengthen the scheme by making it possible not only to report offences, but also to apply sanctions, as is the case when a resident driver commits an offence in his own country". Understand: the European Union wants to centralise the means to impose, or even prosecute, motorists in the Member States, at the expense of national peculiarities and legislation. As a result, I could not vote against this report.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. — It is important that every citizen is treated equally in the EU, no matter which Member State roads they are driving on. However, what is also vitally important is data protection in relation to traffic offences. Information such as national vehicle registration data will be shared across borders in order to track down drivers liable of safety-related offences such as speeding and drink-driving. Ireland will soon be integrated in the cross-border exchange information on road safety related offences.  The previous directive has proved to be effective in mainland Europe and my colleagues and I are positive that the new directive, which will also be extended to Ireland and the UK, will reduce the number of road deaths even further.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. — This measure contains the same text as Directive 2011/82/EU to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements, which was adopted by a very large majority in 2011 by Parliament, with two amendments made. The changes are in line with the judgment of the COURT of the EU on 6 May 2014, which considered that Directive 2011/82/EU had been adopted on an incorrect legal basis concerning police cooperation in criminal matters (Article 87(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union). It has also established that the legal basis is that relating to transport safety. While declaring the directive null and void, the Court of First Instance recognised its relevance and ruled that, in order to avoid a legislative vacuum, the effects of the annulled directive would be maintained for twelve months and that in the meantime the legislator would adopt a new text in accordance with transport safety. Although the Commission brought an action for annulment of the wrong measure, it submitted to Parliament the new text, which was worded quickly, providing for the amendment only of the aspects relating to the legal basis and the territorial scope of application. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements. The reason for this is that this proposal makes two qualitatively significant changes to the text of Directive 2011/82/EU to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements, approved by Parliament by a very large majority and unanimously in the Council in 2011: on the one hand, the change in the legal basis and the related technical changes and, on the other hand, and as a result of the new legal basis for transport, the extension of the scope to the three Member States that had been excluded from the previous directive. This is a mere technical adjustment which leaves the correct previous legal system unchanged.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — For many years, drivers could act with impunity whilst driving in other European countries relatively safe in the knowledge that they would not be prosecuted. That is all to change with the introduction of this directive. I welcome it. This directive, is above all else, about safety! I welcome the cross-party support that it has received in its journey through Parliament. I want to commend the rapporteur on this directive, Inés Ayala Sender, and our own EPP shadow George Bach for the important work they have done on it.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. — With Mrs Sender's report we are facilitating the cross-border implementation of road safety legislation. It is crucial to speed up the exchange of information on offences and ensure a high level of protection for EU drivers. I am convinced that this legislation will contribute to reducing the number of offences committed by drivers from other Member States and introduce a strong deterrent to these drivers, since an offence committed in another Member State can be attributed to the driver in the Member State of residence. Directive 2011/82/EC on the cross-border exchange of information on traffic rule offences, adopted on 25 October 2011, which had been declared null and void by the EU Court on the basis of legal reasons, is therefore taken up. The new text respects the Court's judgment, introducing a new legal basis, transport safety, and adds the territorial scope of application to Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — I fully support the new proposal for a directive to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road traffic offences, which was approved by a very large majority in the European Parliament in 2011 and is currently being transposed by 20 Member States. It seems appropriate to me that every citizen should be treated in the same way and that, in the event of a breach of the Highway Code, the offender, whatever his state of residence, should be notified of the infringement committed, obviously in full respect of the protection of personal data. New cases of infringements which endanger not only the safety of the driver but all other road users should also be included in the scope of the directive: driving under the influence of drugs, failure to use a helmet for motorcyclists, using a mobile phone when driving and driving in a prohibited lane. The willingness of Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland to adhere to and transpose this directive unreservedly is also significant, as it demonstrates a strong commitment to contributing to the radical reduction of road fatalities.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — Improving road safety is a prime objective of the transport policy in the EU. The proposed directive ensures a high level of protection for all road users in the Union by facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety related traffic offences. The lack of consistent enforcement of sanctions for road traffic offences considerably jeopardises road safety. The enforcement of sanctions, where those offences are committed with a vehicle registered in a Member State other than the Member State where the offence took place, needs to be facilitated, the EU needs to ensure equal treatment of drivers as between resident and non-resident offenders, and to grant the Member State of the offence access to vehicle registration data of the Member State of registration.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Improving road safety is a primary objective of the Union's transport policy with the aim of reducing the number of victims, injuries and material damage. The consistent application of penalties for infringements committed in the Union that seriously endanger road safety is important. Often the financial penalties provided for certain types of road traffic offences are not applied if the infringements are committed with a vehicle registered in a Member State other than the Member State in which the infringement was committed. The aim of this Directive is to ensure that investigations into road safety offences are also ensured in such cases. This proposal contains the same text as Directive 2011/82/EU to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements, It was approved by a very large majority in Parliament in 2011, but makes two qualitatively significant changes: on the one hand, the change in the legal basis and the related technical changes and, on the other hand, and as a result of the new legal basis for transport, the extension of the scope to the three Member States that had been excluded from the previous directive. For these reasons, I could only vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I supported this report on the proposal for a Directive facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety traffic offences — on the basis of the principle that this process must take place through mechanisms to ensure the protection of personal data — by sharing the objective of the report, which is to end the anonymity of drivers not resident in the State in which they commit the infringement and to ensure that they are not left without Sanction. I am convinced that, when it enters into force, this Directive will discourage reckless behaviour and dangerous behaviour on the road, which will save many lives; hence my support for the text.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which will continue to allow Member States access to each other’s national vehicle registration data in order to track people who commit certain safety-related offences. The European Court of Justice annulled the previous directive because of an incorrect legal basis (police co-operation) and the legislators have agreed on a new text within the one-year deadline set by the Court. The directive has already proved to be a very effective first step in countering impunity on EU roads. It will serve as a deterrent for foreign drivers who will now be aware that it is possible for them to be notified of any offence they commit whilst abroad.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support the rapporteur's position that Parliament must adopt a new directive on cross-border road penalties in due course, in order to avoid a legal vacuum, but also to guarantee the maximum possible level of road safety in the Member States.  On the other hand, even citizens, who are generally dissatisfied when they receive a notification of a traffic violation, also consider a positive thing that all EU citizens will be treated equally, regardless of the place of registration of the vehicle. We must not forget, at the same time, that this directive aims to achieve the target of a 50% reduction in the number of road deaths by 2020.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report aims to ensure a high level of protection for all road users in the EU while facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences. It puts an end to a system with obvious shortcomings, since it tolerated the impunity of European citizens committing traffic offences when they pass through other Member States. In fact, at present, about 21% of traffic offences recorded in France by the "speed" and "red light" speed cameras are committed by drivers of vehicles registered abroad, or about 4 million of the infringement messages transmitted by speed cameras each year. Considering that it is necessary for reasons of road safety and equal treatment of road users to punish drivers of foreign-registered vehicles in the same way as domestic drivers, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The directive on the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences was subsequently invalidated by the European Court of Justice in 2011. I am pleased to see that the amendments resulting from the Court's judgment were quickly taken into account by the European Commission so that this directive could continue to apply in a sustainable way. In practical terms, this directive will allow a driver to be punished for an offence committed while travelling in another Member State. This reinforces the deterrent nature of the controls at work.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this directive because I consider it to be a step towards completing the process of European integration. The proposal, which takes up Directive 2011/82 annulled by the Court of Justice of the European Union, will facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements (such as speeding or drink-driving) and will end the anonymity of non-resident drivers. It will also ensure that road traffic offences do not go unpunished and will demonstrate that all drivers in the European Union have the same rights and duties. Road safety can only be achieved by certain rules, common and respected by all.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Reducing the number of road accident victims is a goal that should be common to all Member States. Road safety is not just a matter of subsidiarity. It requires a collective awareness to ensure the same protection for all European drivers across the European Union. It is in this sense that the European Parliament has just agreed its position on the directive on the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences.  Drivers who commit a traffic offence (speeding, crossing a red light, driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, driving without a seatbelt, using a mobile phone while driving, using prohibited lanes, lack of a helmet) in a country other than theirs will not go unpunished. Today in France, 21% of traffic offences recorded by speed and red light speed cameras are committed by drivers of foreign-registered vehicles, or about 4 million of the infringement messages transmitted by speed cameras.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. — In today's world, the security challenges faced by the authorities of the Member States require closer cooperation between home affairs bodies. Surely there are much more significant and serious security policy issues in which it is important to rethink and make forms of cooperation more effective. But I believe that this debate today, as well as our current topic, the exchange of information on infringements that threaten road safety, is a small step in the right direction, which will facilitate, assist the authorities of the Member States and increase their effectiveness.
