This House has supported this legislation once, and now we have to do it again. After all, the aim, of course, is not to punish citizens, but to take a united action against offenders. We would like to confirm that the rules apply to all citizens of the Union. This is a positive example of the EU's legislative action that we must definitely support. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. — This cross-border legislation allows for the prosecution of offences committed in another country beyond national borders and the collection of fines for offences committed in another country. This new text, which EU Member States will be obliged to include in their legislation, replaces the 2011 directive; this one, based on bad legal grounds, was cancelled in the spring of 2014. This is a step forward because now data protection must be taken into account, and Denmark, Ireland and the United Kingdom will also be obliged to apply it.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. " I voted in favour of adopting this directive because it guarantees equal treatment of non-resident drivers and residents.  Its aim is to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences committed in a Member State other than the one where the vehicle in question was registered.  Member States will have reciprocal access to vehicle registration data through an electronic data exchange network. These exchanges should identify drivers who commit traffic violations abroad. The offences covered are: speeding, failure to wear a seatbelt, crossing a red light, driving while intoxicated, driving under the influence of drugs, failure to wear a helmet, driving on a prohibited lane, illegal use of a mobile phone or other communications equipment while driving.  The measures in this directive are not new. This directive echoes the provisions of a directive adopted on 25 October 2011 but whose legal basis was challenged by the Commission and overturned by the Court of Justice in its judgment of 6 May 2014.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. — Like the vast majority of Members of Parliament, I stand fully behind the principle of cooperation toward tackling avoidable deaths and injuries on roads across Europe caused by reckless or illegal driving.  Working together often works best, however it can only happen if the system of informative exchange does not become ineffective or bureaucratic. I am mindful that the recent ruling by the European Court of Justice has compelled the UK Government to now opt-in to this Directive. Such coercion illustrates how the EU has degraded the capacity of Member States to legislate for their own citizens. The UK Department for Transport tell us that many of their previous concerns around the Directive have been tackled. This includes fears that vehicle owners, instead of drivers, will be wrongly targeted by the new powers, and concern that private data could be shared wrongly or incur severe cost for storage. These have not fully been addressed. I have heard from various constituents who have been subject to disproportionate penalties for offences in other Member States. I would call on the UK Government to provide reassurances that this Directive will act in the best interests of motorists across the United Kingdom.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — The original directive of 25 October 2011 was overturned on 6 May 2014 by the European Court of Justice for lack of legal basis. This proposal takes it almost identically but on new legal grounds. The aim is to force Member States to pass on all traffic offences committed on their territory to the driver's country of origin. I consider it preferable to remain in inter-state cooperation with regard to road safety and not subject Member States to additional obligations and I would like to limit the application of the directive to the most serious offences, the excessive penalisation of the lightest offences more akin to the persecution of motorists. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this report given the urgency of adopting a broad consensus proposal, which will prevent a legal vacuum from being created in a mechanism which has already been transposed into national law of different States of the Union and which is doing well in road safety. This mechanism has a powerful deterrent effect by eliminating the impunity afforded by anonymity in serious traffic offences committed by drivers from a country other than that of the place of the infringement. In addition, the proposal incorporates and reinforces the suggestions of the European Data Protection Supervisor.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — We are voting against because it enables all Member States to access the personal data of citizens of other Member States.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the cross-border exchange of information on road-safety-related traffic offences. This will mean that drivers from all EU Member States can be prosecuted for traffic infringements wherever in the EU they commit the offence. I believe that any measure that makes the roads safer for my constituents in Wales is to be welcomed.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Although Europe is living up to the ambitious aim of reducing road accidents by 50% by 2020 compared to 2010, I believe that something can still be done to lower the European average of 52 deaths per million inhabitants. One of the main actions is certainly the certainty of the penalty in the event of an infringement that has taken place in a Member State other than the one of registration, thus preventing the driver travelling in a foreign State from feeling exempt from compliance with the current rules of the Highway Code. It is therefore with this in mind that I welcome the new proposal for Directive 2011/82/EU aimed at facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements which, in accordance with the judgment of the EU Court, is based on a legal basis relating to transport safety and includes the three Previously Excluded Member States.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — This Directive aims to ensure a high level of protection for all users of the Union road network by facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on traffic offences relating to road safety and, consequently, the application of penalties where such offences are committed with a vehicle registered in a Member State other than that in which the infringement was committed. I voted in favour of this proposal which aims to reduce the number of road accidents, which are responsible for the death and temporary or permanent incapacity of thousands of European and national citizens.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Court of Justice of the EU had ruled that transport safety is the appropriate legal basis. The content of the provisions of the Directive showed that the system for exchanging information between the competent authorities of the Member States, on which it was based, constituted the means and not the objective of the Directive, which summesed improving road safety. Despite declaring the directive null and void, the Court recognised its relevance and stated that, in order to avoid a legal vacuum, the provisions of the annulled Directive should remain for 12 months. The Commission has therefore put forward a new proposal for a directive, which deserves my agreement, although it was responsible for promoting the application for annulment, since it was the first to show interest in submitting to Parliament as soon as possible a new text to replace the text of the Directive only on the points relating to the legal basis and territorial scope. This Directive should be adopted before 6 May 2015 with the aim of avoiding legal limbo in almost all Member States which have already incorporated the provisions of the annulled Directive into their national law. I voted in favour, recalling that we always consider it a priority to ensure maximum road safety.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. "We could have voted for this text if the common sense amendments tabled by my colleague Marie-Christine Arnautu had been accepted. These amendments were aimed at the need for exchanges to take place on the basis of cooperation between states, for these exchanges to concern only serious offences and for the NGOs concerned to be involved. Dogmatism trumps reason. I'm against you against this text.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This Directive aims to ensure greater protection for all road network users in the various Member States by facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on traffic offences relating to road safety and, consequently, the application of penalties where such offences are committed with a vehicle registered in a Member State other than that in which the infringement was committed. The offences referred to in the Directive are speeding, non-wearing of a seat belt, failure to comply with the obligation to stop imposed by the red light to regulate traffic, driving under the influence of alcohol, driving under the influence of psychotropic substances, non-wearing a safety helmet, movement in a prohibited lane and the unlawful use of a mobile phone or other communication device while driving. The amendment proposed by the European Commission aims to change the legal basis following the decision of the European Court of Justice while maintaining the existing level of protection. These are relevant and justified changes. The changes introduced by the report are to ensure that the processing of vehicle registration data including personal data is subject to specific data protection provisions.  We voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — The European Union must find a way to punish those drivers who commit means of transport beyond the borders of their home state, thus contributing to reducing road mortality. We must send a clear signal to the citizens of the European Union that everyone will be treated equally, regardless of where they have their vehicle registered. By amending the legal basis of the Directive, it is possible to extend the validity of the new rules to Ireland, Denmark and the United Kingdom which did not fall within the scope of the original Directive.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I support this measure, which stems from the need to improve road safety, including through a better exchange of information between Member States.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting against the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety-related traffic offences, because it enables all Member States to access the personal data of citizens of other Member States.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. — The study of road infringement data in the EU shows that the percentage of non-residents involved in traffic violations is higher than that for domestic traffic, especially with regard to speeding. One of the main reasons for the greatest number of infringements of foreign vehicles is that the authorities, by ignoring the vehicle owner's domicile, cannot notify him of the penalty, especially in the case of infringements captured by automatic radar systems. Although the problem had been tried to be resolved through bilateral treaties, experience has shown that they have not worked properly, so it must be addressed together at European level. We must move forward with the analysis of the proposal and reach an agreement enabling a new directive to be adopted in order to avoid leaving in legal limbo virtually all Member States which have already incorporated the provisions of the annulled Directive into national law, therefore contributing to a reduction in road accidents and road fatalities as a result of road accidents.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because, after four years of institutional blockade and after making the necessary changes to adjust the legal basis, today we can have an instrument that will allow us to fight impunity for foreign drivers and which will ensure that all Europeans, regardless of the registration of their vehicle, are treated equally.  With this Directive, traffic authorities may automatically identify vehicle owners regardless of the country of registration when they have committed infringements which are responsible for more than 75% of road deaths. It will greatly contribute to meeting the challenge of halving the number of road casualties by 2020 and avoiding 350 to 400 deaths per year on our roads, the equivalent of a passenger plane. European citizens will also be able to continue to move on our roads feeling protected and safe.  Given Parliament's strong support, the Commissioner has acceded to Parliament's request and has publicly pledged to accompany the evaluation report scheduled for 2016, which has already been launched, with new proposals to complete the procedure, as we had asked from the outset.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) Italian and European citizens have long been calling for measures to increase road safety in order to avoid as far as possible the tragedy of accidents which destroy thousands of families every year. Despite the delays caused by the council's slow work, in today's vote we have approved a measure in the European Parliament that puts an end to cross-border impunity for those irresponsible drivers who, for example, drink-driving or drug-related driving. Today we can be pleased that we have established a strong deterrent with which we hope to be able to save so many human lives. It is another step towards the fundamental political and moral goal of reducing road fatalities by 50% by 2020.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour and supported the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements, to ensure that the amendments to Directive 2011/82/EU are approved as soon as possible, thus enabling Parliament and the Member States to take all necessary measures to achieve the objective of halving the number of road fatalities by 2020 and reducing the number of injured by 40%. We hope that the results achieved so far in the field of road safety will be confirmed and extended between now and 2020 and that the constant work of confrontation with the associations of relatives who are victims of the road, the competent authorities and the new instruments available for research and protection of road safety will allow us to pursue higher objectives, which will allow us to experience the road as a link to always be undertaken with a great sense of responsibility and no longer as a threat of danger.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Sender report on the proposal for a directive on facilitating cross-border exchange of information on road safety related traffic offences because it is unacceptable that foreign-registered drivers who commit a traffic offence and put other people’s lives at risk when abroad can get away with this, simply because Member States cannot trace them when they return home. I therefore find it deeply disappointing that UK MEPs on the right have voted against this resolution, signalling they are not concerned about holding to account foreign drivers who commit offences within the UK.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this report given the urgency of adopting a broad consensus proposal, which will prevent a legal vacuum from being created in a mechanism which has already been transposed into the national law of different States of the Union and which is doing well in road safety. This mechanism has a powerful deterrent effect by eliminating the impunity afforded by anonymity in serious traffic offences committed by drivers from a country other than that of the place of the infringement. In addition, the proposal incorporates and reinforces the suggestions of the European Data Protection Supervisor.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. — There is currently a strong sense of impunity among drivers on the roads of other Member States.  Coming from a French cross-border region in the heart of Europe, at the crossroads between Germany, Luxembourg and Belgium, I see every day, on our roads, drivers who do not reside in France, driving with a strong sense of impunity. While trade is increasingly dense and Europeans are increasingly mobile, the penalties applied for infringement do not apply in the same way everywhere, given different laws. This goes against the interests of European citizens who cross their state's border daily to work, and those who, in the millions, take to the road every year to spend, for example, their holidays in another Member State.  Moreover, until harmonised sanctions are imposed throughout Europe, road safety cannot be significantly improved.  I have therefore voted strongly in favour of this European text, which represents a real concrete step forward for Europeans.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report as I believe it is crucial to set up procedures for the exchange of information on road traffic offences. The offences included in the legislation are related to the main road risk factors: speeding, failing to use a seat-belt; using a mobile phone while driving; and drink-driving. The European Transport Safety Council estimates that more than 26 000 citizens lost their lives on Europe’s roads last year; it is therefore crucial to act on this issue.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the proposed directive to ensure a high level of protection for all road users in the European Union. This protection will be achieved by facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences committed in a Member State other than the one where the vehicle in question was registered.  It is clear that, because of freedom of movement within the European Union, we need to ensure a more uniform application of the security rules determined by each of the Member States in which we operate.  It is common sense to want to end the anonymity of non-resident drivers and to ensure that any traffic offences they may commit do not go unpunished.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because, after four years of institutional blockade and after making the necessary changes to adjust the legal basis, today we can have an instrument that will allow us to fight impunity for foreign drivers and which will ensure that all Europeans, regardless of the registration of their vehicle, are treated equally.  With this Directive, traffic authorities may automatically identify vehicle owners regardless of the country of registration when they have committed infringements which are responsible for more than 75% of road deaths. It will greatly contribute to meeting the challenge of halving the number of road casualties by 2020 and avoiding 350 to 400 deaths per year on our roads, the equivalent of a passenger plane. European citizens will also be able to continue to move on our roads feeling protected and safe.  Given Parliament's strong support, the Commissioner has acceded to Parliament's request and has publicly pledged to accompany the evaluation report scheduled for 2016, which has already been launched, with new proposals to complete the procedure, as we had asked from the outset.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I have supported the adoption of new legislation which will soon enable the identification of persons who commit offences in other European states than their own. In practical terms, this text provides for mutual access to registration data, which allows the identification of vehicle owners in the event of infringements committed in another Member State, and thus the sending of tickets abroad. I hope that this legislation will deter potential offenders from dangerous driving practices, thereby reducing road accidents. It is also a question of eliminating discrimination between motorists in the face of respect for rules that must apply to all. I regret, however, that we have not been able to go any further to force the indelicate to pay these fines, but this will be the next step on which we will have to decide, after the evaluation of this text scheduled for 2016.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because, after four years of institutional blockade and after making the necessary changes to adjust the legal basis, today we can have an instrument that will allow us to fight impunity for foreign drivers and which will ensure that all Europeans, regardless of the registration of their vehicle, are treated equally.  With this Directive, traffic authorities may automatically identify vehicle owners regardless of the country of registration when they have committed infringements which are responsible for more than 75% of road deaths. It will greatly contribute to meeting the challenge of halving the number of road casualties by 2020 and avoiding 350 to 400 deaths per year on our roads, the equivalent of a passenger plane. European citizens will also be able to continue to move on our roads feeling protected and safe.  Given Parliament's strong support, the Commissioner has acceded to Parliament's request and has publicly pledged to accompany the evaluation report scheduled for 2016, which has already been launched, with new proposals to complete the procedure, as we had asked from the outset.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. — We stress that our vote in favour of the Ayala Sender report concerns compliance with the ROK rules and the exchange of such information between Member States. However, we have strong reservations about the collection of data and information by the Commission, because it is not clear in the document exactly what information will be forwarded by the Member States, at the risk that it will infringe personal data.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I supported the proposal to facilitate cross-border exchange of information on road safety traffic offences. The objective of the proposal is to allow for an exchange of vehicle registration information between Member States to identify drivers who commit a road traffic offence in a Member State other than the one where their vehicle is registered. The offences covered are speeding, driving under the influence of alcohol, not using a seat belt and failing to stop at a red light. This directive replaces a previous directive which essentially would have had the same effect but a dispute arose over its legal base. All of the different issues have now been sorted out and we can expect this new legislation to enter into force in the near future.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Dear Mr President, honourable Members, My Colleague Sander's report is important not only because it reflects a judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union as regards the legal basis of Directive 2011/82/EU to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety-related traffic offences and the opinion of the European Data Protection Supervisor with regard to information exchanged between Member States, but also because it generally improves the text of the Directive. I believe that the proposed amendments thus contribute to the effective implementation of the Directive by ensuring a better level of protection of the personal data of European citizens.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this report given the urgency of adopting a broad consensus proposal, which will prevent a legal vacuum from being created in a mechanism which has already been transposed into the national law of different States of the Union and which is doing well in road safety. This mechanism has a powerful deterrent effect by eliminating the impunity afforded by anonymity in serious traffic offences committed by drivers from a country other than that of the place of the infringement. In addition, the proposal incorporates and reinforces the suggestions of the European Data Protection Supervisor.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I supported the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences, as I believe that every driver in the EU should be treated equally if he has committed an infringement, regardless of which country he comes from.  Safety measures related to driving under the influence of drugs, using mobile phones while driving, riding motorcycles without a helmet, riding in a forbidden lane, are some of the changes that contribute to the goal of reducing deaths and injuries on European roads by 50% by 2020.  This proposal for a directive also applies to the Kingdom of Denmark, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and Ireland. In addition to the countries mentioned, countries in the Balkans that are often transitory should also be included, with a large number of European Union citizens moving through them every day.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — The original directive of 25 October 2011 was overturned on 6 May 2014 by the European Court of Justice for lack of legal basis. This proposal takes it almost identically but on new legal grounds. The aim is to oblige Member States to pass on all traffic offences committed on their territory to the one from which the driver is born. I consider it preferable to remain in inter-state cooperation with regard to road safety and not subject Member States to additional obligations and I would like to limit the application of the directive to the most serious offences, the excessive penalisation of the lightest offences more akin to the persecution of motorists. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I supported the report on the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a directive facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Cross-border exchange of information on road safety related traffic offences’ because we believe that this cross-border exchange of information will help to ensure a high level of protection for all road users in the Union, by facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety related traffic offences, and thereby facilitating the enforcement of sanctions, where those offences are committed with a vehicle registered in a Member State other than the Member State in which the offence took place.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — A European system for the exchange of data on drivers of vehicles with foreign registration plates is a key instrument in the fight against offences and road traffic offences within the EU. Above all, it puts an end to the impunity of drivers who are in violation of road law outside their country. The European data exchange system will improve road safety and be much more effective than bilateral agreements between Member States. This is an important step towards achieving the EU's target of halving road deaths and injuries by 40% by 2020. Progress in this area is particularly important in view of the effects of the financial crisis in the form of an increase in the number of outdated vehicles, drastic cuts in infrastructure maintenance expenditure and a lack of funding for new facilities. Given the seriousness of the subject, we cannot allow a loophole to be created in this area, which is why I support the decision to base the act on transport safety legislation instead of the rules on police cooperation in criminal matters, as the directive aims at road safety and the exchange of information is merely a means of action. The resulting extension of the territorial scope of the new law to Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland is also highly desirable as it will ensure harmonisation throughout the EU.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Transport Safety Council estimates more than 26 000 citizens lost their lives on Europe’s roads last year. I therefore voted for new EU procedures that will make it easier to bring non-UK drivers who break the law to justice and am calling on the UK Government to bring the new rules into force as soon as possible.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. — This dossier covers one of the laws in the history of the European Union, which is not very significant in itself, but it is very important for European citizens. Indeed, the lack of cross-border cooperation with the transport police has been a long-standing problem, which has led to a lesser interpretation of the traffic regulations of that Member State for a road user from another Member State, since he had every right to be confident that he could avoid subsequent penalties. The legislation we have just voted on will change that permanently, and I am sure that life will justify our conviction as legislators: from now on, everyone is truly equal: they have the same rights and obligations, come from any EU Member State, they must also comply with the traffic police rules that have been taken on their behalf.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mrs Ayala Sender's report because I believe that improving road safety is a primary objective of the European Union's transport policy. Directive 2011/82/EU aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements. Since its entry into force on 11 November 2013, it has contributed to a significant decrease in the number of infringements by foreign drivers. Finally, I would like to highlight two qualitatively significant innovations: on the one hand, the change in the legal basis and the related technical changes and, on the other, the extension of the scope to the three Member States which had been excluded from the application of the previous directive (United Kingdom, Denmark and Ireland).

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — This report is identical to the 2011/82/EU directive which was overturned by the Court of Justice. The text presented to us here therefore changes the legal basis. The proposed directive aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences committed in a Member State other than the one where the vehicle in question was registered. It should already be noted that three countries will have authorization to delay the implementation of this proposal: the United Kingdom, Denmark and Ireland. In principle, while it is necessary that foreign drivers who take advantage of the current system without data exchanges can be prosecuted when they commit offences, the issue of data protection at European level must still arise. Road safety policy also needs to be reviewed. Indeed, the Commission is only moving towards a policy of systematic repression of motorists (it is true that speed cameras and other fines bring significant revenues for states) while the issue of road infrastructure or the development of public transport - particularly in rural areas to provide an alternative to motorists - are evaded. So I voted against this report.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The exchange of information on road safety-related offences is the culmination of many years of efforts to reduce road accidents, road deaths and injuries and their consequences. Offences generally accumulate on a country-by-country level, but without taking into account offences committed on the roads of other countries. In an era of open and freely accessible road networks, this state had to change. This report leads us in this direction. This is in our common interest.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. I am voting against this report which seeks to oblige Member States to transmit all traffic offences committed on the territory of the Member State from which the driver responsible for these offences originates. Opposed to any decision that would result in the weakening of the sovereignty of a Member State, I find it more sensible to strengthen interstate cooperation without adding obligations. Moreover, I do not think it is necessary to include non-serious offences in this scheme. The tendency to penalize is excessive in these specific cases. It is also regrettable that motorists' associations are not included in the consultation scheme. They play a major role in information and could have been serious interlocutors at a time when motorists feel they are under increasing surveillance.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because, after four years of institutional blockade and after making the necessary changes to adjust the legal basis, today we can have an instrument that will allow us to fight impunity for foreign drivers and which will ensure that all Europeans, regardless of the registration of their vehicle, are treated equally.  With this Directive, traffic authorities may automatically identify vehicle owners regardless of the country of registration when they have committed infringements which are responsible for more than 75% of road deaths. It will greatly contribute to meeting the challenge of halving the number of road casualties by 2020 and avoiding 350 to 400 deaths per year on our roads, the equivalent of a passenger plane. European citizens will also be able to continue to move on our roads feeling protected and safe.  Given Parliament's strong support, the Commissioner has acceded to Parliament's request and has publicly pledged to accompany the evaluation report scheduled for 2016, which has already been launched, with new proposals to complete the procedure, as we had asked from the outset.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I supported this report on the proposal for a Directive facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety traffic offences — on the basis of the principle that this process must take place through mechanisms to ensure the protection of personal data — by sharing the objective of the report, which is to end the anonymity of drivers not resident in the State in which they commit the infringement and to ensure that they are not left without Sanction. I am convinced that, when it enters into force, this Directive will discourage reckless behaviour and dangerous behaviour on the road, which will save many lives; hence my support for the text.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — I supported the report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences. This proposal for a directive will include three Member States (Denmark, Ireland and the United Kingdom) that have not so far participateed in the exchange of information in transport security and will introduce technical changes to the text so far (Directive 2011/82/EU).  I believe that this Directive will encourage Member States of the European Union to share information on traffic violations and to encourage sanctions to ensure greater safety on European roads.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. – With today's vote, the European Parliament has proven that it is leading a coherent policy to tackle road safety issues, an issue that affects the health and life of every single citizen. The goal is clear - reducing casualties as a result of traffic accidents. The Judgment of the Court of Justice of May 2014 on the repeal (on the legal basis) of the previous Directive on cross-border exchange of information on road traffic offences led to the need to re-adopt the text with some amendments. I hope that the new directive will lead to more road safety. Moreover, it will apply in all Member States of the Union, subject to data protection requirements. It is essential to ensure the existence of a European instrument to tackle road traffic offences abroad. Here we are talking about combating the most common examples such as inappropriate speed, non-use of a safety belt, passing a red light, driving while intoxicated, etc. These infringements will be investigated and sanctioned regardless of which Member State they are committed in. I look forward with great interest and hope to the results of the texts adopted today, as well as the Commission's future evaluation of the implementation of the Directive.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing — The purpose of the Directive is to improve road safety. The scope of the directive had to be amended in order to make road safety the legal basis, but also to extend it to apply to all Member States not previously covered. Studies have shown, for example, that the majority of those affected who exceeded the speed limit were foreigners. Austria is a typical example. The competent authorities did not know the residence of the owner of the vehicle and the enforcement of the fine, in particular from automatic radars, was problematic. This relative impunity has had a negative impact on the growth of offences and accidents. The rules of the road had to be harmonised. These rules have already brought about a 40% reduction in accident rate. It was therefore necessary to eliminate all irregularities and extend it to the whole territory of the EU without exception.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Sender report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety-related traffic offences, as this report takes measures both to limit car accidents and to punish unscrupulous drivers.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I strongly support this report which has the potential to save lives.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — Favourable to the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements. The new text introduces the legal basis for transport safety and makes several adjustments to the implementing legislation on data protection in accordance with the new legal basis.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — Directive 2011/82/EU aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements. Since its entry into force in November 2013, it has contributed to a significant decrease in the number of infringements committed by foreign drivers.  Although the proposal retains the text of this directive, it brings two qualitatively significant innovations: on the one hand, the change in the legal basis and, on the other hand, the extension of the scope to the three Member States which had been excluded from the previous measure (United Kingdom, Denmark and Ireland). In the light of the above and in view of the fact that improving road safety is a primary objective of the European Union's transport policy, I voted in favour of the Sender report.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — I have refused to support this proposal, as the previous directive has not been implemented in all Member States either. Clearly, there is a danger that some nations will comply with this directive and that the drivers of those nations of other Member States that refuse to implement it will be ripped off. Unfortunately, until a solution is found that obliges all Member States to impose the same consequences for motorists, I cannot agree with this proposal.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report as the cross-border exchange of information on road safety and traffic offences is an important step in creating safer roads across Europe. This report will also help reduce the number of road deaths by half by 2020 compared to 2011.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — The 2011/82/EU Directive facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences contributes to the EU's target of halving the number of road fatalities and 40% in the number of injured by 2020.  The proposal aims to broaden the territorial scope of this directive to include the three Member States that had remained out of the way (Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland). The report also proposes the adoption of a new legal basis (transport security) more suited to this directive.  Concerned about road safety I vote for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — This proposal takes up the text of Directive 2011/82/EU on the cross-border exchange of information on traffic offences, adopted by a large majority in the European Parliament and in the Council unanimously in 2011, with the exception of two qualitatively significant amendments. On the one hand, the change in the legal basis and subsequent technical changes and, on the other hand, because of that new legal basis for transport, the extension of the scope to the three Member States which were excluded from the previous Directive.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because of the need to prevent the creation of a legal vacuum with regard to cross-border traffic offences. The previous directive was supported by road accident victims’ associations, traffic authorities, road traffic offence prosecutors, road safety associations and by citizens. This new directive will guarantee that all citizens are treated equally in matters involving traffic offences, no matter where their vehicle is registered. I support the rapporteur’s efforts to seek assurances that the new directive will not run counter to the high level of personal data protection.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Court of Justice of the European Union gave rise to the European Commission's request challenging the legal basis of Directive 2011/82/EU, adopted by the European Parliament and the Council. The Directive was annulled but its effects remained in force within a reasonable period of not more than 12 months until a new directive based on the legal basis of Article 91(1)(c) TFEU on road safety was atested.  The content of the Directive only presents technical changes, in particular with regard to data protection. It thus has 8 infringements of traffic rules which could lead to cross-border exchange of information, in particular where the infringement is committed by a vehicle registered in the Member State other than that in which the infringement was committed. Countries such as the United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark will have a transitional period for its application, since with the previous legal basis they were not covered.  This approval is the right decision for a concrete road safety policy. I believe that, at the time of its review in 2016, it would be important to examine the possibility of including further infringements, including non-payment of tolls.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This report is identical to the 2011/82/EU directive which was overturned by the Court of Justice. The text presented to us here therefore changes the legal basis. The proposed directive aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences committed in a Member State other than the one where the vehicle in question was registered. It should already be noted that three countries will have authorization to delay the implementation of this proposal: the United Kingdom, Denmark and Ireland. In principle, while it is necessary that foreign drivers who take advantage of the current system without data exchanges can be prosecuted when they commit offences, the issue of data protection at European level must still arise. Road safety policy also needs to be reviewed. Indeed, the Commission is only moving towards a policy of systematic repression of motorists (it is true that speed cameras and other fines bring significant revenues for states) while the issue of road infrastructure or the development of public transport - particularly in rural areas to provide an alternative to motorists - are evaded. So I voted against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — This measure is fully supported by safety bodies and organisations in the motoring industry such as the AA and the Institute of Advanced Motorists. Research indicates that in the UK, 15% of speed offences alone are committed by non-resident drivers.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which promotes the cross-border exchange of information on the most serious traffic safety offences: driving while intoxicated, driving under the influence of drugs, failure to wear a seatbelt, etc. This text will enable, in respect of fundamental freedoms and the protection of personal data, to make the penalty more systematic for drivers who commit serious offences in a Member State other than that of registering their vehicle. The aim is to improve the protection of all European road users.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences. This proposed directive is a step forward for the protection of road users in the European Union, as it promotes exchanges between the traffic and road safety authorities of the Member States. Thus, when an individual commits an offence outside the state in which his vehicle is registered, his data is communicated to the responsible authorities. This directive, in addition to ensuring equal treatment between European drivers, will be applied in the UK, Ireland and Denmark. The harmonization of information exchanges is necessary to ensure the safety of users of European road networks.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome this new directive aimed at facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements, convinced of the need to put an end to the impunity of foreign vehicles on the roads of the Union. We are sure that it will be a strong deterrent to foreign drivers, who will be aware that any infringement committed abroad can be notified to them thanks to this new mechanism. We hope, together with the rapporteur, that this directive will be adopted within the deadline set by the European Court of Justice, in order to avoid creating a dangerous legal vacuum. Once again, we trust that the relevant bodies in the Member States and the Offices of the European Commission will cooperate effectively and carefully in drawing up regular impact assessments on road safety in Europe.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it allows the traffic and road safety authorities of the Member States to request that they be given the data of the owner of a vehicle registered outside the Member State in which it is travelling, if the latter has committed an offence considered to be very dangerous, in order to be able to notify the individual of the offence committed.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this report because, through the objectives it has set itself, it is only supporting citizens, road users, within the Union, with the aim of improving the cross-border exchange of information related to traffic violations and better cooperation between the relevant competent authorities. With its text, the new directive, which retains much of the content of Directive 2011/82/EU, aims to reduce the number of deaths by 50% by 2020, to which the old directive's objective is to reduce the number of injured from traffic accidents by 40% by 2020.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this regulation, which aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information related to traffic offences. The implementation of this regulation is crucial, as it should mean that people who commit a road traffic offence in a jurisdiction where they are not resident can face the penalties for their actions. This is a particular issue in Ireland, as a minority of drivers have used the border as a means of showing disregard for road safety laws on one side of it or the other. We also know that drivers from other EU countries have been basically immune to Irish traffic laws. Hopefully these problems can now be addressed. The priority must be to ensure the safety of all road users.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — I welcome this decision. The consequences of some drivers feeling "safer" after crossing now de facto non-existent boundaries and opting for riskier, rule-breaking driving are considerable. It costs lives, health and great material damage. This situation is indefensible in today's Union and I hope that steps will soon be taken to bring this system to life.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — After careful consideration, I finally voted against the proposal. It was obvious to me that the proposal was indeed a move in the right direction. However, the proposal stands and falls with the implementation by the Member States, and I simply see the danger of motorists being ripped off in some Member States, while other Member States do not, or only half-heartedly, implement the persecution of conspicuous road users. Experience with the previous scheme also supported such an assessment.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the bill because it will increase road safety on Europe's roads if it is implemented. The number of traffic accidents and traffic offences committed by non-residents is increasing and existing laws do not encourage police cooperation. This can create a sense of impunity, which in turn means a heightened risk of traffic to fellow road users. All citizens, regardless of where their vehicle is registered, must be treated equally. Although the EU wants to reduce the number of road deaths by 50% by 2020, the number has actually increased. This is therefore an urgent change and should be implemented in the Member States as soon as possible.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. — I believe that this directive should enter into force as soon as possible in order to remove the legal vacuum in this area. It should be noted that many countries have invested heavily in the relevant systems, and the exchange of information is already taking place.  This is a necessary tool in the fight against road safety offences. In particular, it will be possible to bring drivers to justice regardless of the country in which their cars are registered, thus complementing the information exchange mechanism already established. In addition, the arrangements will make it easier to recover fines, prevent impunity for foreigners and ensure that all Europeans comply with road traffic rules.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the proposal for a directive on the "cross-border exchange of information on road safety-related traffic offences", because behind the prevention of road accidents and safety in road transport, the creation of cross-border databases with a wealth of elements constituting another system of monitoring, supervision and control of workers is hidden. These are the new mechanisms used to shield the urban state and the power of capital. The proposal for a directive is also part of an effort to promote single control rules in the EU, in the name of transport safety. However, these standards and specifications are modelled by the EU on the basis of the profits of business groups, such as the car industry, motorway construction groups, etc., and are exploited and operated as another area of competition for businesses, to the detriment of real popular interests. Only the people with their struggle, in conflict with their monopolies and power, can guarantee, among other things, with their own power and economy, and security in transport.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — This proposal contains the same text as Directive 2011/82/EU to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements. The amendments made in the proposal concern, on the one hand, the modification of the legal basis and the related technical amendments and, on the other hand, the extension of the scope to the three Member States that had been excluded from the previous directive. These amendments respond to the judgment of the COURT of the EU on 6 May 2014, which ruled that the appropriate legal basis is that relating to transport safety. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. — Safe mobility for all European citizens is also a fundamental right. I agree and therefore support the resolution, which will allow the exchange of information happen under the right legal basis and terms, so that all European drivers share same rights and responsibilities when it comes to road safety. Serious road offences should not be ignored, if we have a single market. Therefore, the precondition for prosecuting serious traffic offences is the exchange of information.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — The adoption of the EU directive on the cross-border exchange of information on traffic safety offences has only taken another important step towards greater road safety in Europe. This is a success in the European Union's continued efforts to improve road safety, road infrastructure, and to provide better training for drivers.  The aim is to halve the number of road fatalities by 2020, compared to 2011. The Directive will ensure that drivers are equalised, as negligent driving that directly endangers other road participants is equally dangerous regardless of national borders. The proposal includes many offences such as driving under the influence of drugs, using a mobile phone while driving or riding a motorcycle without a protective helmet. The previous directive was annulled by the European Court of Justice, because it was based on the wrong legal basis. The European Parliament's rapid response and adjustments ensure continued safety in road transport and the protection of lives. The latest provisions on the protection of personal data have also been respected.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — This report is identical to the 2011/82/EU directive which was overturned by the Court of Justice. The text presented to us here therefore changes the legal basis. The proposed directive aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences committed in a Member State other than the one where the vehicle in question was registered. It should already be noted that three countries will have authorization to delay the implementation of this proposal: the United Kingdom, Denmark and Ireland. In principle, while it is necessary that foreign drivers who take advantage of the current system, without data exchanges, can be prosecuted when they commit offences, the issue of data protection at European level must still arise. Road safety policy also needs to be reviewed. Indeed, the Commission is only moving towards a policy of systematic repression of motorists (it is true that speed cameras and other fines bring significant revenues for states) while the issue of road infrastructure or the development of public transport - particularly in rural areas to provide an alternative to motorists - are evaded. So I voted against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support new rules on the exchange of border traffic information allowing access to national vehicle registration data with a view to monitoring those responsible for non-compliance: speeding, not using a seat belt, driving under the influence of alcohol, driving under the influence of drugs, not wearing a safety helmet and other information that I believe their exchange will contribute to traffic safety.  We must not allow multiple traffic offenders to be able to repeat the same on the roads of other Member States, but all advocate for as much protection and road safety as necessary. In particular, I support provisions improving data protection, calls for cooperation between Member States and the Commission to ensure a timely and complete road safety report, and commits the Commission to consider the directive by November 2016 and submit a new legal proposal to improve road safety.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences. Back in 2007, Commission research pointed to the fact that in the case of traffic violations, the percentage of foreign nationals is higher than at national level.  One of the main reasons for this was the lack of data on foreigners and the inability to send and enforce penalties, especially in the case of traffic cameras. With the introduction of Directive 2011/82/EU, positive results have been evident since day one and indicated that the EU is on track to meet its target of reducing road deaths by 40% by 2020. Nevertheless, a new directive with certain amendments is needed to further increase efficiency. One of the reasons for improving international road safety is significantly reduced investment in infrastructure due to the economic crisis, which has compromised road safety.  I fully justify the changes that have been introduced concerning data protection, traffic safety and access to Denmark, the UK and Ireland, and I therefore support this report.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — In fact, the text of this proposal takes up in its full that of Directive 2011/82/EU, the aim of which is to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements. The new text only amends the aspects relating to the legal basis and the territorial scope of application. In the past, the legal basis was that of police cooperation in criminal matters, while the new legal basis is, and rightly so, that of transport safety. As regards the territorial scope, it is extended to the United Kingdom, Denmark and Ireland, which were not included in the 2011 Directive. Thanks to this new mechanism we will move towards a reduction in the number of infringements, as foreign drivers will be aware that any infringement committed abroad can be notified to them.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. — I am a driver myself and I understand that someone may not like the approval of the cross-border exchange of information on traffic offences, but we must remember that this issue is also about protecting life and health. Statistics clearly show that the current "impunity" of drivers for offences abroad has led to more violations of safe driving rules outside the country where the vehicle is registered than in the home country. However, those who break the rules, including transport rules, should be held accountable according to the standards in force at the place where they are located. For this reason, this standard deserves support.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — The increase in border crossings in the European Union has revealed the inability of the police authorities to enforce the penalties for traffic offences because they cannot be found in the homes of European motorists. The road safety requirement requires a greater capacity for cooperation by national authorities and I therefore welcome a finally effective mechanism to deal with this issue.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — Directive 2011/82/EU on the cross-border exchange of information on traffic offences aimed to end impunity for foreign vehicles on Union roads and to ensure road safety in the EU. In fact, foreign drivers enjoyed some impunity for cross-border offences because of the lack of knowledge by the competent authorities of the address of the vehicle owner.  In 2014, the Court held that that directive was adopted on the basis of an incorrect legal basis and declared it invalid. It acknowledged, however, its relevance, stating that the provisions of the Directive would remain for 12 months in order to avoid a legal vacuum and allow the legislature to adopt a new text. Consequently, the Commission has proposed a new text adapting to the judgment: it introduces transport safety as a legal basis, adds Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland to the territorial scope of application and includes adjustments to data protection enforcement rules.  Because I consider it essential to avoid a legal vacuum in such a priority area as road safety, I voted in favour.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. — The European exchange of information on the most serious traffic violations is an essential part of the fight against road crime in Europe. That is why I support this directive, which prevents us from going back to the time when these offences committed by motorists from other Member States went unpunished. We had already adopted a directive to this effect in 2011 but, under pressure from the Council, police cooperation had been used as a legal basis rather than road safety. The United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark had thus taken advantage of an opt-out clause to exempt themselves from it. In May 2014, the European Court of Justice logically invalidated the directive while giving us a one-year period to adopt a new legal basis.  That is what we are doing today, despite the lack of responsibility of some Members who obey an ideology when it comes to saving lives. In Europe, nearly 30,000 people, including more than 3,000 in France, lose their lives on the roads every year. At a time when road violence is on the rise again in our country, it is anomalous not to support this approach.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. — In this new directive, cooperation between Member States is strengthened with a stronger obligation for recalcitrant countries such as the United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark. In addition, this new version takes into account the issue of data protection based on Directive 95/46/EC. This text is a step forward that marks a return to the issue of road safety at European level.  As a reminder, 73 Europeans die every day on the roads in Europe and 250,000 are seriously injured each year. In France, there was an increase in road deaths in 2014, the first time in 12 years. To remedy this scourge, Europe has a key role to play. Cooperation in sanctions against all drivers who commit offences with impunity when it takes place in another country is a first step. This demonstrates a willingness to apply sanctions consistently.  We regret that the Commission is not going any further by proposing a harmonisation of legislation, particularly on speed limits and alcohol consumption, which remain the main causes of accidents.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. — I supported the resolution on the directive facilitating the exchange of information on traffic offences. The scope of this vote is to extend to the United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark an important 2011 directive ending the anonymity of drivers committing traffic offences outside their Member State of residence. After the Court's ruling, a modified legal basis and clearer data protection provisions, we will avoid, through the sharing of vehicle registration data, that offences go unpunished on the grounds that they were committed "abroad": within two years, offenders will be able to receive their fines at home, regardless of the EU country where the infringement occurred. In my country, the stakes of this text are important: more than 20% of road offences detected by speed and red light speed cameras are committed by drivers of vehicles registered outside France. Certainly, I don't know anyone who enjoys receiving a PV. But we are talking about road safety, equal treatment of road users, and important offences for which national exceptions or impunity were certainly not a good signal.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — All measures aimed at enhancing road safety are welcome, especially when they aim to fill a legal vacuum related to the end of impunity for foreign vehicles on Union roads, enabling all Europeans to be treated equally. Particular attention, however, as the rapporteur has said, to the necessary protection of personal data.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because, after four years of institutional blockade and after making the necessary changes to adjust the legal basis, today we can have an instrument that will allow us to fight impunity for foreign drivers and which will ensure that all Europeans, regardless of the registration of their vehicle, are treated equally.  With this Directive, traffic authorities may automatically identify vehicle owners regardless of the country of registration when they have committed infringements which are responsible for more than 75% of road deaths. It will greatly contribute to meeting the challenge of halving the number of road casualties by 2020 and avoiding 350 to 400 deaths per year on our roads, the equivalent of a passenger plane. European citizens will also be able to continue to move on our roads feeling protected and safe.  Given Parliament's strong support, the Commissioner has acceded to Parliament's request and has publicly pledged to accompany the evaluation report scheduled for 2016, which has already been launched, with new proposals to complete the procedure, as we had asked from the outset.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this report given the urgency of adopting a broad consensus proposal, which will prevent a legal vacuum from being created in a mechanism which has already been transposed into the national law of different States of the Union and which is doing well in road safety. This mechanism has a powerful deterrent effect by eliminating the impunity afforded by anonymity in serious traffic offences committed by drivers from a country other than that of the place of the infringement. In addition, the proposal incorporates and reinforces the suggestions of the European Data Protection Supervisor.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I welcome the vote on this proposal for a directive to facilitate the exchange of information on road safety offences. A previous directive on the subject was overturned by the European Court of Justice (ECJ) in May 2014 on the grounds that its legal basis was wrong. However, the ECJ had maintained the effects of the directive for one year, in order to allow the European institutions to adopt a new text without creating a legal vacuum. The new directive therefore takes into account the ECJ's remarks, by seeking its legal basis in transport safety rather than police cooperation. It also sees its territorial scope widen to the extent that Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland, which had initially decided not to apply the first directive, have joined the new text. I therefore welcome today's vote, which marks an important step towards a more effective strengthening of road traffic rules across Europe, preventing European citizens from becoming victims of careless drivers who do not comply with the road code.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — Following the Judgment of the Court of Justice of the EU of 6/05/2014 on Case C-43/12, which considered that Directive 2011/82/EU was adopted on the basis of an incorrect legal basis - that relating to police cooperation, the CJEU decided that transport safety should be the appropriate legal basis. To this end, this proposal has emerged, which aims to create a new Directive, to amend Directive 2011/82/EU on the cross-border exchange of information on traffic code violations, based on two fundamental amendments to the previous text: on the one hand, the creation of a new legal basis for transport safety and, on the other hand, the extension of the scope to the three Member States which had decided not to accede to the previous Directive - Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland. It is therefore a question of adopting a proposal in the field of traffic offences which seeks to avoid a legal vacuum in almost all Member States which have already incorporated the provisions of the annulled Directive into their national law. That is why I considered it appropriate, necessary and urgent to vote in favour of this report on one of the areas considered as one of the Union's political priorities: road safety.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. "I supported this text, which concerns an important aspect of the freedom of movement of European citizens and their safety on the road.  A traffic offence committed in a member country other than the one where the offending vehicle is registered is punishable. The European Union's transport policy must maintain a high level of protection for all road users and must also be harmonised in its application. This requires a consistent and consistent application of sanctions against offences committed on European roads.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of Mrs Ayala Sender's report because the report, which contains mostly the same text as Directive 2011/82/European Union, is intended to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements and therefore serves to ensure greater protection for our citizens. The new Directive amended the legal basis (transport safety), as requested by the Court of First Instance, and also extended its scope to three previously excluded States: the United Kingdom, Denmark and Ireland.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour because the directive aims to increase road safety also through a better exchange of information between Member States.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this report given the urgency of adopting a broad consensus proposal, which will prevent a legal vacuum from being created in a mechanism which has already been transposed into the national law of different States of the Union and which is doing well in road safety. This mechanism has a powerful deterrent effect by eliminating the impunity afforded by anonymity in serious traffic offences committed by drivers from a country other than that of the place of the infringement. In addition, the proposal incorporates and reinforces the suggestions of the European Data Protection Supervisor.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this directive, which ensures that traffic violations committed by drivers in the European Union are not allowed to go unpunished. In France, 21% of speeding or red light traffic offences are caused by foreign-registered motorists. The text allows the exchange of registration files between European countries in order to locate the owner of the offending car.  These exchanges between European police include speeding, crossing a red light, driving under the influence of drugs, failure to wear helmets for motorcyclists, illegal use of a mobile phone or traffic on a prohibited lane. This directive had already come into force at the end of 2013, but due to legal problems, its form had to be revised. The adoption of the new text today puts an end to legal uncertainty and will promote a safer road, especially in border areas.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I supported this report on the proposal for a Directive facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety traffic offences — on the basis of the principle that this process must take place through mechanisms to ensure the protection of personal data — by sharing the objective of the report, which is to end the anonymity of drivers not resident in the State in which they commit the infringement and to ensure that they are not left without Sanction. I am convinced that, when it enters into force, this Directive will discourage reckless behaviour and dangerous behaviour on the road, which will save many lives; hence my support for the text.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. — The previous directive was not based on a proper legal basis. I believe, in fact, that the main aim of this legislation is to improve road safety. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of establishing an effective system for the cross-border exchange of information on those road traffic offences that every day endanger the health and often the lives of our European citizens. We need only think of the fact that every year there are thousands of accidents caused by speeding, driver distraction and drink-driving or drug-inflow driving. Road safety has no borders and, thanks to today's vote, offenders will have to take this into account and assume their responsibilities, regardless of their country of origin. Member States will, in fact, be able to have access to vehicle registration data through a network for the electronic exchange of data, thus ensuring that road traffic offences do not go unpunished.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for new EU procedures that will make it easier to bring non-UK drivers who break the law to justice and am calling on the UK Government to bring the new rules into force as soon as possible. Along with fellow Labour MEPs I voted for a directive to set up procedures for the exchange of information on eight road traffic offences including those linked to the main road risk factors: speeding; failing to use a seat-belt; using a mobile phone while driving; and drink-driving. The European Transport Safety Council estimates more than 26 000 citizens lost their lives on Europe’s roads last year. These new procedures will allow EU countries to exchange information to ensure people who commit serious traffic offences whilst driving a foreign-registered vehicle can be identified and can be traced when they return home.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — Road accidents are the seventh cause of death in Europe. Also, what makes the situation more difficult is the underdeveloped process of exchanging information on traffic offences between Member States. For this reason, I supported a legal instrument that will contribute to saving people's lives.  With the adoption of this procedure, the whole of Europe will have a direct impact on preventing 300-400 road deaths a year. The seriousness of this shortcoming is seen in the results of a study conducted by the European Commission back in 2007, which shows that this year recorded a higher number of traffic violations committed by persons who do not reside in the country where the offence was committed, than from those who are residents.  The reason is that the authorities were unable to hand over the offence to the person who committed the offence given the lack of insight into the home address thereof. Changing information is a key assumption to achieve the common goal of reducing deaths on European roads by 50% by 2020. The Directive has been revised several times and the application of the new directive is expected before 2016 in the Member States. For Croatia, as a transitional country that shares a geographically-transport whole with countries some of which are candidate countries, the smooth exchange of information on traffic violations is of utmost importance for road safety.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — The text of this proposal is the same as with Directive 2011/82/EU on the cross-border exchange of road safety information concerning traffic offences (adopted by a large majority in Parliament and unanimously by the Council in 2011), with the exception of two significant changes.  First, there is the new legal basis, which means that the number of technical changes to be made in the text, and secondly the fact that the legal basis has now been changed in transport, which means that the scope of the directive must be extended, so that it also applies to the three Member States not covered by it before. The system for exchanging information between Member States and their authorities is aimed at directives to improve road safety. 20 of the 25 Member States affected by the directive apply it to national law, and initial indicators indicate that the new system is beginning to have the desired impact.  Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland which previously decided not to participate, have no reservations and are not asking for anything more in the transition period than other Member States have. I support the Directive, in particular by contributing to a 50% reduction in deaths on EU roads by 2020.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I strongly support road safety so voted in favour of all amendments. By exchanging information between Member States, foreign registered drivers who commit certain traffic offences abroad such as speeding and drink-driving can be traced when they return home. This will be greatly important in securing the safety of everyone on the road.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I agree with the report and its two significant changes. They relate to the introduction of a new legal basis, including the implementation of technical changes throughout the text, and the extension of the directive in such a way that it is also applicable to the three Member States that have not been covered by it so far, the United Kingdom, Denmark and Ireland.  We want to ensure a higher level of protection for all drivers in the EU, in particular in terms of facilitating and modifying cross-border information on traffic safety offences. We also want to reduce the number of casualties on European roads, and according to some indicators this directive could reduce this number by up to 50% in the next 5 years. This way we want to encourage cooperation between Member States so that they can all contribute as much as we can to transport safety.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing — I consider the current situation, where, with the exception of immediate policing, drivers cannot be punished for road traffic offences committed in another EU country as unfair, which is why I supported the proposal. I believe that drivers should always be penalised equally for the same road traffic offences, regardless of which european Union country they have registered in.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. — I supported my colleague Ayala Sender's report, as I believe that road safety does not end at the borders of the Member States, but is a European issue. Only through cross-border cooperation will we be able to reduce the number of road deaths by 2020.
