Road safety is something that concerns us all, so we really need to focus on this by sharing data between Member States and quickly identifying offenders, and we will contribute to improving road safety.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support the proposed directive as it aims to improve road safety. It is not, in principle, about strengthening the powers of the police authorities whose activities are supervised at national level, but about ensuring equal treatment of all EU citizens. By facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on traffic offences, the Directive will ensure the effective implementation of sanctions in the event of serious infringements of traffic rules (drink or drug driving, non-red light) caused by a citizen of one Member State in the territory of another Member State. This will strengthen the principle of equal treatment of all transgressers, domestic and foreign. This principle is further strengthened by a provision on the basis of which the person suspected of having breached the rules of the road is to be provided with basic information on that infringement in the official language of his home State.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. — The cross-border exchange of information on road safety related and traffic offences Directive in its original format provided an opt-out for the UK. However, even though the new legal basis for this Directive does not allow the UK to opt-out, I was able to support this vote for two main reasons. Firstly, the UK DVLA already supplies this information to other Member States on request and therefore it will not materially change current practice. Secondly, given the number of non-British vehicles using UK roads currently, it would seem appropriate for the UK authorities to be able to access information on EU drivers who breach UK road safety rules or commit traffic offences whilst in the UK.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. — Our vote in favour of the Ayala Sender report concerns compliance with road traffic rules and the exchange of such information between Member States. Nevertheless, we continue to have strong reservations about the commission's collection of data and information. It is also problematic that it is not clear in the document exactly what information will be forwarded by the Member States, and so there is a risk of a breach of the confidentiality of personal data.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — Drivers who are subject to traffic offences must be checked. However, cross-border exchange of information between countries is a sensitive issue in terms of the management of citizens' personal data and requires delicate handling.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text. Many actors (road accident victims' associations, traffic and road safety authorities and, more generally, associations for whom road safety is a priority), all of whom applauded the adoption of the directive, would not understand that Parliament is not doing everything possible to avoid the formation of a legal vacuum. Not to mention that citizens, most of whom do not rejoice when they receive notification of a traffic violation, welcome the prospect of making this experience as wide a possible, regardless of the country of vehicle registration. This directive could also reverse the trend at a critical time. Indeed, although the EU is once again on track to meet the target of halving the number of road deaths by 2020, this number nevertheless seems to be on the rise again, a phenomenon that can be explained by various factors: the ageing of the car fleet, drastic cuts in infrastructure maintenance spending as a result of the economic crisis , a lack of funding for infrastructure and innovations that can improve road safety, etc.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the revision of the legal basis of the directive introducing the exchange of information between Member States on road offences. The directive on the exchange of cross-border information on road offences will be soon in place throughout the European Union. If it is correctly implemented it will help to save hundreds of lives on our roads. Under the new rules, fines for speeding, ignoring a red light, drink and drug driving and driving while using a mobile phone will be enforced across the EU. On average, an estimated 15% of detected speed offences are committed by non-resident drivers.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. — I supported this report, as the period following the implementation of the Directive indicates a positive downward trend in the number of traffic offences committed on the territory of a Member State by nationals whose car is registered in another Member State.  The applications used in implementing the Directive must allow for easy, fast and efficient exchange of vehicle registration data without creating additional administrative burdens. I take it positive that a Member State independently decides whether to initiate proceedings against certain traffic offences and informs the other Member State in which the vehicle is registered accordingly.  I support new measures to facilitate the exchange of data on offenders and the extension of the list of infringements that are the most common causes of road accidents, a large part of which ends in serious injuries and deaths, as they will have a positive impact on citizens' safety on the roads.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I support the directive on facilitating cross-border exchange of information on road safety related traffic offences. The directive will put an end to a situation in which foreign drivers could drive with impunity on EU roads. The enhanced equal treatment of residents and non-residents will lead to a higher awareness of traffic rules. This will ensure the best possible level of street safety and will promote the aim of European Union to cut the numbers of road victims by 50 % by 2020.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The new directive comes at a critical time. Even if the EU is on target with its aim of cutting road deaths by 50% by 2020, in past years and months there has been an increase in the number of road accident victims for various reasons: people’s cars are getting older; there have been swingeing cuts in infrastructure maintenance spending thanks to the economic crisis; there is a lack of funding for infrastructure and development geared towards improving road safety, etc.  This directive should come into force as soon as possible; this cross-border motoring penalties directive should serve as a non-discriminatory deterrent in countering impunity on the EU’s roads. Despite the fact that people are of course never thrilled to receive a letter telling them they have committed a traffic offence, they will however welcome the fact that everyone in the EU will be treated equally, no matter where their vehicle is registered. Moreover, the road accident victims’ associations, traffic authorities, road traffic offence prosecutors and road safety associations will warmly welcome Parliament’s vote.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — The aim of the report is to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety offences by requiring Member States to pass on traffic offences committed on their territory to the Member State from which the driver originates. Because of the impossibility of being able to integrate motorists' associations into the process and to be able to limit the application of the directive to the most serious offences, thus resulting in excessive penalties for the lightest offences, vote against this report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. — It is very important that the new proposal from the European Commission fills the loophole that resolves the precarious legal situation in the Member States. The legislation will help the EU achieve a 50% reduction in road fatalities. Moreover, with regard to technical amendments, it is very important that the EDPS's opinion is the same as that of the legal services of the three institutions. Therefore, the report has been adopted.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Ayala Sender report in favour of the agreement with the Council, because it favours the exchange of cross-border information on traffic offences. The agreement is sufficiently broad in scope and, although we do not achieve an optimal level of data protection, this protection is guaranteed sufficiently to justify a favourable vote.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. — Dear Colleagues, I support the adoption of the new Directive as soon as possible in order to avoid the risk of a legislative loophole due to the repeal by the Court of Justice of the European Union of Directive 2011/82 to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information on road safety-related traffic offences. Despite its short operation, the repealed Directive has had a strong deterrent effect for foreign road drivers, regardless of the country of registration within the European Union. Thanks to the new rules, any infringement committed abroad can be notified through the mechanism for the exchange of information between the competent authorities of the Member States and lead to the actual application of the sanctions imposed. The European Parliament has always defended improving road safety and reducing the number of road accident victims as its priority. The data to date continues to startle us on its scale - more than 26,000 people die on European roads each year, and an even greater number of injured. In the "war" on the road, children are especially vulnerable, unfortunately even on the footpath. I therefore strongly support the European Commission's efforts through the proposed legislation to ensure a high level of protection for all road users of the European Union.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I supported this report on the proposal for a Directive facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety traffic offences — on the basis of the principle that this process must take place through mechanisms to ensure the protection of personal data — by sharing the objective of the report, which is to end the anonymity of drivers not resident in the State in which they commit the infringement and to ensure that they are not left without Sanction. I am convinced that, when it enters into force, this Directive will discourage reckless behaviour and dangerous behaviour on the road, which will save many lives; hence my support for the text.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. — I wholeheartedly agreed to this instrument to save lives on Europe's roads.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This discussion stems from confusion about the legal basis of the directive which was consensual and necessary. With this review, we have listed as positive its update with the introduction of new types of infringements, as well as greater guarantees in terms of data protection. Being certain that this directive will end with a certain feeling of impunity, it is no less certain that it will not work miracles. In fact, road accidents have deeper causes, such as the ageing of the car fleet, the quality of the road network and the fatigue of drivers. In this sense, we see with great concern the model of public-private partnerships that dominates the construction of the road network in Europe and particularly in Portugal. The result is paid roads through expensive tolls that push a large part of the population to secondary roads without quality and with great damage to the safety of localities. This is just one example. Palliatives are necessary, but do not eliminate the need for background treatments.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - I have refused to support this proposal, as the previous directive has not been implemented in all Member States either. The danger that some nations will abide by this directive and that the drivers of those nations will be ripped off by other Member States that refuse to implement it is obvious. Unfortunately, until a solution is found that obliges all Member States to impose the same consequences for motorists, I cannot agree with this proposal.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the proposal for a directive on the "cross-border exchange of information on road safety-related traffic offences", because behind road accident prevention and safety in road transport is the creation of cross-border databases with a wealth of elements constituting another system of monitoring, supervision and control of workers. These are the new mechanisms used to shield the urban state and the power of capital. The proposal for a directive is also part of an effort to promote single control rules in the EU, in the name of transport safety. However, these standards and specifications are modelled by the EU on the basis of the profits of business groups, such as the car industry, motorway construction groups, etc., and are used and operate as another area of competition for businesses, to the detriment of real popular interests. Only the people with their struggle, in conflict with their monopolies and power, can guarantee, among other things, with their own power and economy, and security in transport.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I supported the report on a directive facilitating the cross-border exchange of information on road safety-related offences. In my view, the adoption of this act will effectively reduce the number of offences committed by reckless drivers from other Member States. Until now, they have avoided liability simply because law enforcement authorities did not have the data of car owners registered in other EU countries and therefore the proceedings could not be initiated effectively. Although attempts were made to solve the problem through bilateral agreements, experience has shown that such methods have caused many conflicts and discontent between the various traffic control authorities. This situation will now be resolved by the entry into force of the legislation in question. I am also firmly convinced that they will effectively improve the level of safety on EU roads and reduce road fatalities.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: Writing. — The new directive on the exchange of traffic offender data between Member States replaces a directive already adopted in 2011 with almost identical content, which was abolished by the Courts of the EU on the basis of the need to change its legal basis. This has now been done and this new directive is based on eu competence in the field of transport security. It is to be welcomed that Parliament and the Council were able to agree on this new directive in a very short time for the new regulation to enter into force in the Member States as previously intended- by 6 May this year, now extended to all EU Member States, including Great Britain, Ireland and Denmark. The directive is positive, because it will finally put an end to the bad practice that drivers who commit serious road traffic offences in other countries of the European Union are not actually penalised or are penalised very rarely. However, it should be stressed that it is now up to the Member States to ensure that this directive makes sense and results, and we expect the authorities of the Member States to act through data-exchange systems, not only to identify and locate the offenders, but also to actually penalise them. Because the main objective of this directive is to improve road safety, which is one of the objectives of EU transport policy, and the number of accident victims on Europe's roads remains high.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing — Today, I voted with a majority of Members to adopt a report aimed at making it impossible for drivers who do not respect the rules of the road outside their home state in the EU to escape fines. I welcome the Commission's swift response to the Court of Justice's judgment that the original 2011 directive had the wrong legal basis. A long-standing legal vacuum in this area would be unnecessary, given the good wording of the original text. The directive has only been changed in two respects. In addition to the aforementioned legal basis (change from police cooperation to transport safety), its territorial scope has also been extended to Denmark, great Britain and Ireland, which have had exceptions up to now.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I voted in favour of the report on the exchange of information on road traffic offenders, because I believe that transport safety is one of the most important issues that we should address at European level. Freedom of movement, which is now the cornerstone of European integration, should also guarantee the possibility of punishing people who are in violation of road rules and pose a real threat to the health and life of EU citizens. Member States should have effective tools to enforce penalties against non-residents who are in violation of national road rules. It should be noted, however, that such an action consisting in the transfer of address information and other personal data of the driver should take into account all restrictions related to the exchange and protection of personal data. European regulations should be particularly concerned with the confidentiality of the information exchanged in the procedures for the transfer of personal data between the relevant authorities of the Member States. I am pleased that the solution adopted provides such protection. At the same time, I would like to express my satisfaction that the Member States – Denmark, Ireland and the United Kingdom – which have hitherto remained outside this system will become part of it after the transitional periods have passed. Perhaps this is the best evidence of the effectiveness of this mechanism. I think it is also worth considering extending these regulations to EU associated countries, in particular those countries that are part of the Eastern Partnership.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - In 2010, the European Commission adopted a strategy that provides for a drastic reduction in road accident deaths by 2020. However, cuts in infrastructure maintenance costs, a lack of policies for innovation in safety and the ageing of the car fleet make it difficult to achieve this goal. We must therefore take all those actions that can help us in this regard, such as this directive to facilitate cross-border trade in infringements. In fact, studies have shown that the percentage of non-residents involved in infringements is generally higher than that corresponding to national traffic, mainly because of the almost total impunity enjoyed by the former due to the difficulty of the local authorities in tracing the foreign culprit. I therefore voted strongly in favour of a rule that aims to facilitate the exchange of information between competent authorities, so as to ensure fair treatment between European citizens, leading everyone to behave more responsibly in driving. I also welcome the fact that during the process it was decided to consult the European Data Protection Supervisor as well, to ensure that the new rules did not in any way infringe citizens' right to privacy.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal as it is part of the type of agreements aimed at enhancing sustainable fisheries by promoting better exploitation of available stocks through the use of industry best practices. I also believe that it would benefit both sides: Senegal, given the financial contribution of around EUR 14 million it would receive in the five years of the Agreement, and the EU, since the Agreement will allow European vessels, mainly Spanish and French tuna vessels, to operate in Senegalese waters. In addition, the satellite monitoring system for ships, as well as the cooperation of the authorities of both parties established by the Protocol, will help Senegal combat illegal, undeclared and irregular fishing. For these and other elements I have considered it relevant to support this Agreement.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — In view of the economic growth opportunities for the coastal state of Senegal resulting from better use of available fish stocks in accordance with the principles of sustainable fisheries, I fully support this partnership agreement between the EU and the Republic of Senegal.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the fisheries partnership agreement with Senegal, considering that anything that can favour our businesses and our production is to be encouraged in this time of crisis. This agreement favours French and Spanish fishermen. This sector has been particularly affected by globalisation with the complicity of the European Union. I think it is fair to give back to the people at least some of what they have lost. Moreover, since Senegalese waters are not or too little exploited, the impact of fishing activity is negligible. However, small producers remain at the forefront of the giants of globalisation and the TTIP currently negotiated by the Commission is likely to reach and complete them.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — This long-standing agreement includes the EU paying to plunder the waters of poorer countries. I do not support it, and therefore cannot support its renewal.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this deliberation because this agreement re-energizes cooperation between the Union and the Republic of Senegal to promote a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in Senegal's fishing areas, in the interests of both sides.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to conclude a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Senegal. One of the principles of the agreement is to create a level playing field for EU fleets by providing that Senegal undertakes not to facilitate other fleets when vessels have the same characteristics and fish for the same species. Senegal will receive a financial contribution of EUR 8 690 000 for annual financial compensation and support for Senegal's fisheries policy. Given the available fish stocks and the possibility of future cooperation on other species, as well as the possibility of supplying quality fish products to the EU market, this new Partnership Agreement is of mutual benefit.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. —I voted for this recommendation to allow EU vessels to fish in Senegalese waters. There are 38 French and Spanish boats that will be able to catch 14,000 tonnes of tuna and 2,000 tonnes of black hake per year. In return, we will invest 750,000 euros per year for the development of Senegal's port infrastructure. It is therefore an agreement that will benefit both the EU and Senegal, while respecting the principle of 'sustainable fishing'. According to the rapporteur of the draft resolution of 21 November 2014, Norica Nicolai, hake stocks in Senegalese waters are not being exploited optimally, so that "the demersal species could thus be revised upwards (...) in the context of a subsequent agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal, without the state of resources being affected too much"

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — This is the new sustainable fisheries partnership agreement between the EU and Senegal. I have spoken in favour, this being based on the principles of sustainable exploitation of fisheries resources, good governance, food security for the Senegalese population and the development of the local fishing sector.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This sustainable fisheries partnership agreement between the EU and Senegal is to replace the previous agreement dating back to 1981. It concerns French and Spanish vessels that work in full transparency and with financial counterparties to finance local infrastructure even as the country suffers unfair competition from "pirate boats" that come illegally to fish in Senegalese waters.  So I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I do not agree with the positions supported in the Nicolai report on the partnership agreement for sustainable fisheries between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal. In view of the demands made by the Veneto and Italian fisheries sector on the Commission and given that they are still unfulfilled, I believe that the EU must first take action to support the Member States and only then should it devote itself to agreements with third countries. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — Senegal is a key partner of the EU. On fisheries, the previous Agreement dates back to 1980 (the oldest in force). Eight years after the expiry of the previous Protocol, on 25 April, new Agreements and Protocols were agreed, good news in line with the increase in fisheries agreements that we have been calling for.  Now, for a period that gives some stability to the sector (five renewable years), fishing opportunities (14 000 tonnes of tuna and 2 000 tonnes of hake) are offered to thirty-eight European vessels for a trade-off of EUR 8 690 000: an adequate value for money. Spain has sixteen sewers (out of twenty-eight totals, twelve for France), seven pipers (out of eight totals, one for France) and the two trawlers. It is a balanced protocol, in accordance with the principles of the reformed common fisheries policy. It is part of the new generation of agreements in which the biological well-being of species with fishing opportunities has been scientifically documented. All parties benefit, including local artisanal fishermen, who receive a significant share of sectoral support, while, in support of the local economy, the capture of tuna pipes and liners must be landed at the port of Dakar.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supports the conclusion of the SUSTAINABLE Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Senegal. The Commission has proposed the conclusion of an agreement on behalf of the EU aimed at establishing a new framework for eu-Senegal cooperation. One of the principles of the agreement is to create a level playing field for EU fleets by providing that Senegal undertakes not to facilitate other fleets than those laid down in the agreement, where the vessels have the same characteristics and fish for the same species. The port of Dakar is a commercial port of Senegal, internationally important due to its geographical location. Given the available fish stocks and the possibility of future cooperation on more species, as well as the possibility of developing the local fishing industry in cooperation with EU vessels and supplying quality fish products to the EU market, this new partnership agreement benefits both parties and parliament has therefore decided to support it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted yes since I consider a Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Senegal to be very productive.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome the approval of this partnership agreement for sustainable fisheries with the Republic of Senegal, because it is a balanced and just act which favours European and Senegalese interests in accordance with the policies pursued so far for development cooperation. The aim of this Treaty is to grant fishing opportunities to EU vessels in Senegalese waters, taking into account scientific data and assessments as well as international commitments on the protection and conservation of tuna and the fight against illegal fishing, the so-called IUU. With this partnership, we intend, with a view to solidarity and aid to developing third countries, to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and Senegal, in order to promote a sustainable fisheries policy and the reasonable exploitation of fishery resources.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — The agreement is detrimental to the Italian fisheries sector. Only French and Spanish fishermen will benefit. I voted against.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Senegalese commercial port of Dakar is of international importance due to its geographical position. The EC conducted negotiations on the basis of the mandate conferred by the Council on behalf of the EU for the renewal of the Agreement between the Government of the Republic of Senegal and the EEC on fishing off the Senegalese coast, which entered into force on 1 June 1981 (renewed in 2002 and expired in 2006) and a protocol setting out fishing opportunities and financial contribution. On 25 April 2014, the negotiators initialled a draft agreement and protocol complying with the Common Fisheries Policy Regulation (CFP) for Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements (APPDs). I support the conclusion by the Council of the Agreement and Protocol(12812/14 – C8-0276/2014 Senegal – 2014/0238(NLE)) aimed at creating a new framework for cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal, framework that will ensure: reasonable economic conditions taking into account the fishing opportunities available, a basis for the conservation and sustainable exploitation of the relevant fisheries stocks, adequate support and sufficient conditions for the local fisheries sector, as well as the opportunity to develop the local fishing industry in partnership with EU vessels and to provide quality fishery products on the EU market.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Republic of Senegal is a key EU partner with which we have long maintained fisheries relations. The previous agreement dates back to 1980. This was the oldest agreement in force. Eight years after the expiry of the previous Protocol, a new Agreement and its corresponding Protocol of Implementation were signed on 25 April. This is good news, in line with the increase in the fisheries agreements and protocols in force that we have been calling for since the beginning of the legislature.  It is a balanced Protocol, which will promote the responsible and sustainable exploitation of resources in the common interest of Senegal and the EU, in accordance with the principles of the reformed CFP and its external dimension.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The protocol to the fisheries agreement between the European Union and Senegal has been renegotiated by the European Commission for a period of five years.  Under this agreement, three categories of vessels will be allowed to fish in Senegalese waters - 28 seiner tuna, 8 canners, and 2 Spanish trawlers. The protocol includes clauses relating to the suspension and denunciation of human rights violations or commitments made in the fight against undeclared or unregulant illegal fishing. I voted in favour of this report approving the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) After careful consideration today, I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries between the European Union and Senegal, giving my approval to its conclusion in view of the fact that the new agreement favours the interests of both parties and improves best practices in the sector, with benefits also for the sustainability of fisheries. I agree with the rapporteur's conclusions, pointing out that these agreements will have a number of positive consequences, first and foremost on relations between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal in this area, renewing and renegotiating the protocols that expired in 2006. In addition, local authorities will be helped to step up the fight against illegal fishing and opportunities to increase the economic activity of EU vessels will increase. I also agree with the issues raised with regard to the need for forecasts that facilitate reasonable economic understanding, real sustainability of fisheries and adequate support for the local fisheries sector. I call on the Commission to monitor the development and implementation of the agreements, to allow dialogue with Parliament and to report on the impact this agreement will have on the fisheries sector in that region.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — This recommendation for the renewal of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership enables local fishermen to increase economic activity in the Senegalese maritime area and allows, for a further five years, the use of the satellite monitoring system for vessels in order to improve the fight against illegal fishing.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. "I wanted to vote in favour of this text, which offers great prospects for our fishermen. The agreement promises the possibility for 28 tuna, 8 canners and 2 trawlers the possibility of fishing up to 14,000 tons of tuna and 2000 tons for black hake. This agreement is therefore in favour of the French fishing industry, and moreover with Senegal, a country with which France continues to maintain close relations because of their common history. Senegal will also benefit from this agreement, as it will receive 1,808,000 euros for these fishing authorizations for the first year, of which 750,000 euros per year for the development of Senegal's sectoral policy. A text that therefore enshrines a win-win agreement that every French patriot, concerned with France's industrial and commercial interests, had to vote for.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries between the EU and the Republic of Senegal with a view to creating a new framework for cooperation between the parties. One of the main reasons why I voted in this way is the level playing field for EU fleets by saying that the Senegalese side undertakes not to grant more favourable conditions to fleets other than those covered by the agreement, whose vessels have the same characteristics and operate on the same species.  I also particularly welcome the fact that the new agreement contains detailed clauses relating to the suspension of the Protocol in the event of human rights violations and non-compliance with the commitments made by the parties against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — Given that the Senegalese economy will undoubtedly prosper from the improved exploitation of available stocks – in accordance with the principles of a sustainable fishery and the best practices in the industry – it is the rapporteur’s opinion that the new FPA and the Protocol established between the European Union and Senegal are in both parties’ interests.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the draft Council decision and its implementing protocol concerning the conclusion of a partnership agreement for sustainable fisheries between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal.  I believe that this cooperation is beneficial to both parties, as it would allow the EU to supply the European market with high-quality fish products, since these stocks are available off the coast of Senegal, while the African country, which is the recipient of the financial compensation, would benefit economically and promote a dynamic fishing industry.  The agreement also creates new jobs for citizens of both partners, promotes a sustainable fisheries policy and provides for specific measures to step up the fight against illegal fishing. Only through a transparent fisheries policy and good governance can we respond to demand from the European market and, at the same time, ensure the conservation of fishery resources.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this recommendation as it purports to provide opportunities for employment, opportunities for EU vessels as well as providing for the possibility of providing conditions regarding the quantity of by-catch.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of a partnership agreement for sustainable fisheries between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal and its implementing protocol. Taking into account opportunities for the Senegalese economy to thrive through better exploitation of available stocks, in accordance with the principles of sustainable fishing and best practices in the sector, the new agreement and the Protocol favour the interests of both parties. In addition, the satellite vessel monitoring system and cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Senegal with regard to the control and monitoring of vessels in Senegalese waters will help local authorities to step up the fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated (IUU) fishing. With a view to increased demand for raw material for canning industries in Senegal, VESSELS flying the UNION flag would also have a great opportunity to increase their economic activity in the region. This would also help local seafarers, who under the provisions of the Protocol will be part of the crews of EU vessels.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal as it is part of the type of agreements aimed at enhancing sustainable fisheries by promoting better exploitation of available stocks through the use of industry best practices. I also believe that it would benefit both sides: Senegal, given the financial contribution of around EUR 14 million it would receive in the five years of the Agreement, and the EU, since the Agreement will allow European vessels, mainly Spanish and French tuna vessels, to operate in Senegalese waters. In addition, the satellite monitoring system for ships, as well as the cooperation of the authorities of both parties established by the Protocol, will help Senegal combat illegal, undeclared and irregular fishing. For these and other elements I have considered it relevant to support this Agreement.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — This resolution calls for the signing of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Senegal. Based on the stocks of fish available and the prospect of future cooperation for other types of fish, as well as the opportunity to develop the local fisheries industry in partnership with EU vessels, and provide the EU market with quality fish products, this new FPA and Protocol is beneficial for both parties. Furthermore, the Satellite-based vessel monitoring system will help the local authorities to step up their fight against Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated fisheries (IUU). In view of all this I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report proposes to update the fisheries partnership between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal, so as to integrate the priorities of the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, voted on last year, and its external component. The agreement, which has been concluded for five years, provides fishing opportunities for 28 seiner tuna, 8 canners and 2 European trawlers and also aims to help revitalise cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal to promote a sustainable fishing policy and responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in Senegal's fishing areas. Finally, the agreement should enable the development of the local fishing sector in partnership with EU vessels, as well as the supply of quality fishing products to EU markets. I fully support this balanced agreement and, for that reason, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. While the first fisheries agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal was in 1981, the protocol renewed in 2002 came to an end in 2006. The end of this cooperation between the EU and Senegal in the fishing sector has resulted in a sharp reduction in the number of European vessels fishing for tuna in Senegalese waters. That is why the partnership agreement in the field of sustainable fisheries between the European Union and Senegal and its implementation protocol adopted by the European Parliament are acts which I wish to stress here the importance, both for the Union and for our Senegalese partner. The EU will thus be able to send more vessels to catch tuna in Senegalese waters, while at least 20% of the seafarers on board these vessels will have to be from Senegal or a country in the Africa, Caribbean and Pacific region.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. — The new Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries between the EU and the Republic of Senegal will benefit the interests of both parties involved. The Republic of Senegal and the European Union will create new jobs. The port of Dakar and the fishing industry will benefit and develop from this partnership. In addition, the satellite vessel monitoring system will monitor vessels in Senegalese waters and help local authorities to step up the fight against illegal and unregulated fishing. For these reasons, I have decided to support the new partnership agreement with the Republic of Senegal.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the fisheries partnership agreement with the Republic of Senegal, considering that anything that can favour our businesses and our production is commendable in this time of crisis. This agreement favours French and Spanish fishermen. This sector has been particularly affected by the globalisation associated with the European Union. I think it is fair to give back to the people at least some of what they have lost. Moreover, Senegalese waters are not exploited or too little exploited, the impact of fishing activity is negligible. However, small producers remain at the forefront of the giants of globalisation and the TTIP currently negotiated by the Commission is likely to reach and complete them.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of this recommendation. It is a sustainable fisheries partnership agreement that replaces the one that expired in 2006. It lays down new conditions with regard to the volume of catches and the economic contribution, among others. This Agreement allows thirty-eight ships of three types (tuna seiners, pipers and trawlers) to be operated in Senegalese waters for five years, of which twenty-five are Spanish. The agreement is positive as it benefits both sides. It promotes the development of sustainable fisheries policies in the Republic of Senegal and will enable the Senegalese authorities to improve the surveillance of their territorial waters, through a satellite monitoring system, to combat illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — The new Fisheries Partnership Agreement and the Protocol thereon promote the interests of both Parties.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. — 30% of the world's seas are overfished and the survival of marine fish stocks may be at risk. I support the proposal for a protocol to the Sustainable Fisheries Agreement between the European Union and Senegal, because it seeks to limit tuna fishing in West Africa to a more sustainable framework than at present. Justified steps to maintain marine fish stocks will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural values of these areas, unlike marine aquaculture areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations.  Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be freed from unduly strict and unnecessary sustainability standards. These are only justified for marine fisheries and aquaculture. Efforts should be made to clearly divide the concept and regulation of marine and freshwater aquaculture in the future.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted against the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal as it is not adequate. The section on Black Hake poses a problem, as does the subversion of the Senegalese provisions on surveillance of fishing activities. We in Wales believe that the sea should be sustainably and responsibly fished, and this agreement is not a productive measure in helping achieve this.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal on fisheries ceased in 2006, resulting in a drastic reduction in the number of EU tuna seiners in Senegalese waters. In this context, the European Commission has negotiated a renewal of the Agreement between the Republic of Senegal and the European Union in the field of sustainable fisheries. One of the principles of the Agreement is to ensure a level playing field for EU fleets and not to grant more favourable conditions to fleets other than those contained in the Agreement, provided that ships have the same characteristics and capture the same species. In addition, the satellite monitoring system and the cooperation established between the EU and the Republic of Senegal on monitoring and locating vessels in Senegalese waters will help local authorities step up their fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing. I voted in favour of this agreement as it establishes adequate support for the fisheries sector at local level, defines the exploitation of fisheries resources in accordance with the principles of sustainable fishing and is an economic opportunity for the Union fishing sector.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The fisheries sector accounts for only 1.3 % of real GDP and EUR 136 million in the Senegalese economy compared to a total export volume estimated at EUR 1.7 billion. The report estimates that in 2011 the total exports of Senegalese fishery products to the EU (mostly frozen) were approximately 40 000 tonnes. Senegal also plays a key role in the landing of both artisanal and industrial fishery products, with around 400 000 tonnes of landed products, of which 90 % comes from artisanal fishing and less than 50 000 tonnes from industrial fisheries. The reports conclude that the conclusion of a new partnership could be advantageous for both sides, helping both the Republic of Senegal and the European Union to create jobs. The EU undertakes that at least 20 % of seafarers on board its vessels fishing in Senegalese waters come from Senegal or an ACP country. The total amount of the expected financial contribution is EUR 13 930 000.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This is another one of the agreements that is part of the tuna fishing agreement network in West Africa. The first fisheries agreement concluded between the EU and Senegal dates back to 2002 and expired in 2006. The new Protocol lasts for five years. The expected financial contribution is 13,930,000 euros, of which 5,240,000 are paid by shipowners to access fishing permits, and 8,690,000 for compensation for access to resources and sector support. The licences shall be distributed in full by the Spanish and French fleets (36 tuna and 2 trawlers), with no other Member States (such as Portugal) expressing interest in the fishing opportunities created by this agreement. Despite the agreement that is a problem and limitation common to other fisheries agreements, in particular as regards the effectiveness and effectiveness of sectoral support, we consider it acceptable for both parties to conclude it. The fisheries control measures envisaged in Senegalese waters under this Agreement to combat illegal, unregulated and unreported (IUU) fishing should be positively recorded.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — The objective of the agreement in question in the sustainable fisheries sector is to establish a new framework for cooperation between the Republic of Senegal and the European Union, since the non-recovery of the Protocols has resulted in a significant decrease in the number of European Union vessels that can fish for tuna in Senegalese waters from 18 to 2 vessels. The new Agreement and the Protocol in question are in the interest of both Parties. The satellite vessel monitoring system will help law enforcement authorities there to monitor unregulated and illegal fishing.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — The fisheries sector is one of the EU's great failures. The management of the Brussels summits and the outstanding and ly topical demands of our fisheries sector should come before anything else.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — The new Fisheries Recovery Agreement and the Protocol promote the interests of both Parties, which is why my vote is in favour of the draft Council Decision establishing a fisheries partnership in the field of sustainable fisheries between the EU and Senegal.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — Senegal is a key trading partner for the European Union for a number of reasons including its strategic location and its efforts in the fight against illegal fishing. I support full commitment by the EU to promote our bilateral agreements. I consequently welcome, eight years after expiration of the last protocol, adoption of this new protocol to allow 38 vessels, fishing mainly tuna, to once again operate in the Senegalese EEZ, subject to EUR 8 690 000 of compensation over the duration of the protocol. The protocol is in strict compliance with the principles of sustainability and good governance and will provide an opportunity to develop the local fishing industry in partnership with the EU vessels. Additionally it will provide the EU market with quality fish products and will not add excessive pressure on the fish stocks. I am convinced that its implementation is in the interests of both parties.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. — Fisheries relations between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal have been developing since 1981, during which time the European Union has signed a number of fisheries agreements with Senegal. The last of these agreements expired in 2006, resulting in a severe reduction in the number of tuna in Senegalese waters. The Commission is currently proposing that the Council welcome the Agreement and the Protocol which aim to create a new framework for cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Senegal. This Protocol will last for five years, will have a financial contribution of EUR 13 930 000 and will be beneficial for both sides, as it will help both the Republic of Senegal and the European Union to create new jobs and advance sustainable fisheries and good governance. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the Partnership Agreement.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Republic of Senegal is a key EU fisheries partner. The new Agreement replaces the 1980 agreement for a renewable five-year period and allows the return of the European fleet to this fishing ground, from which it was excluded since the suspension of the previous agreement in 2006. I voted in favour as this is a very important protocol for the Spanish freezer tuna fleet, which will have sixteen fishing licences, and will offer permits for seven Spanish tuna pipes, based in Bermeo (Biscay), which already used the port of Dakar as the basis for their Atlantic operations and operated in Senegal through private agreements. The Agreement will promote the responsible and sustainable exploitation of resources in the common interest of Senegal and the EU, in accordance with the principles of economic and environmental sustainability of the new common fisheries policy and its external dimension. It is also an agreement that benefits all stakeholders, including local artisanal fishermen, who will receive a significant share of the sectoral aid integrated therein.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the draft resolution on the Council decision on the new fisheries agreement between the European Union and Senegal. An agreement that seems to me to be balanced, that continues the course of the fruitful relations between Europe and the African country and that takes into account many considerations of social and environmental sustainability, as also underlined by the European Parliament's Committee on Development.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Nicolai report because I welcome the enhancement of cooperation between the EU and Senegal to promote a sustainable fisheries policy and sound exploitation of fisheries resources in the Senegalese fishing zones.  I also welcome the fact that under the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement tailored support will be offered to Senegal for conducting scientific research, monitoring and for fighting illegal fishing, as well as for small-scale fishing, including the rehabilitation of degraded ecosystems to allow the recovery of juvenile stocks.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. —I voted for this agreement which will allow European Union ships to fish in Senegalese waters. This agreement includes 12 tuna boats and a French caneur. It is useful because France has to import on average nearly 80% of fish products to satisfy its domestic demand. It comes at a time when Senegal, like many developing countries, is suffering from "pirate" fishing. For example, on 4 January 2014, a Russian vessel, the Oleg Naydenov, was boarded for illegal, unreported, unregulated (INN) fishing in Senegalese waters. He was fined $1 million.  This is not a unilateral exploitation agreement but an agreement that respects each of the parties. In exchange for fishing rights, we pay financial compensation to Senegal, in addition to licence fees paid directly by shipowners, in order to develop the port infrastructure of that country. The problem of immigration will be solved in Africa's economic development.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this recommendation. It is a sustainable fisheries partnership agreement that replaces the one that expired in 2006. It lays down new conditions with regard to the volume of catches and the economic contribution, among others. This Agreement allows thirty-eight ships of three types (tuna seiners, pipers and trawlers) to be operated in Senegalese waters for five years, of which twenty-five are Spanish. The agreement is positive as it benefits both sides. It promotes the development of sustainable fisheries policies in the Republic of Senegal and will enable the Senegalese authorities to improve the surveillance of their territorial waters, through a satellite monitoring system, to combat illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this agreement as it will enhance cooperation between the EU and Senegal to promote a sustainable fisheries policy and sound exploitation of fisheries resources in the Senegalese fishing zones, in the interests of both parties. This agreement will provide an updated framework which takes into account the common fisheries policy and its external dimension.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. — I voted against the Partnership Agreement on Sustainable Fisheries between the European Union and Senegal for three obvious reasons: - All fisheries agreements between the EU and developing countries are designed to maximise the exploitation of seas and oceans in order to disguise the failing European fisheries policy and to keep the European fishing fleet going. This is at the expense of animals, nature, the environment and people on site. Destructive European fisheries policy cannot be maintained by fishing more or elsewhere; it is better to come clean and stop subsidised overfishing; - West African waters are already heavily overfished, while illegal fishing and missing fish population research do not provide up-to-date data. This is especially true for the vulnerable slipjack tuna. It is irresponsible to let European ships fish there;  - Senegal itself is working on new legislation to reduce their fishing pressure; it is contradictory to agree a partnership agreement on fisheries at this very time.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this recommendation. It is a sustainable fisheries partnership agreement that replaces the one that expired in 2006. It lays down new conditions with regard to the volume of catches and the economic contribution, among others. This Agreement allows thirty-eight ships of three types (tuna seiners, pipers and trawlers) to be operated in Senegalese waters for five years, of which twenty-five are Spanish. The agreement is positive as it benefits both sides. It promotes the development of sustainable fisheries policies in the Republic of Senegal and will enable the Senegalese authorities to improve the surveillance of their territorial waters, through a satellite monitoring system, to combat illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the council's draft decision on the conclusion of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal and its Implementation Protocol, as the Agreement creates a renewed framework of cooperation between the EU and Senegal.  In this context, it is important to ensure the sustainable exploitation of fishing resources and support and satisfactory conditions for the local fisheries sector. This way empowers Senegal's economy in line with sustainable fishing and good practices. On the other hand, Union-flagged ships will have greater opportunities to increase economic activity in the region. It is also important to establish a surveillance system that will support local authorities from preventing illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted for the fisheries partnership agreement with the Republic of Senegal. Anything that can support our businesses and our production is good to take in these difficult times. And this is the heart of this agreement, which favours French and Spanish fishermen. This sector has been particularly affected by the globalisation caused by the European Union. We therefore consider that it is right that it be given back a little bit. Having treated them so harshly, having made them left behind by globalisation, finally, the Union cares a little about its fishermen who, like farmers, are the lung of our sovereignty. Especially since we know for a fact that Senegalese waters are not exploited or too little exploited: fishing therefore has no harmful impact on ecology.  Nevertheless, we do not forget that small producers remain at the forefront of the giants of globalisation and the TTIP currently negotiated by the Commission is likely to hit them so hard that they will not be able to recover.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the sustainable fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and Senegal. The protocol to this fisheries agreement has been renegotiated by the European Commission for a period of five years. It respects the principles of sustainable fishing and benefits both parties. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Senegal’ because we believe that opportunities are given for the Senegalese economy to prosper from a better exploitation of the stocks available, in accordance with the principles of a sustainable fishery and the best practices in the industry and that the new Agreement and the Protocol are in both parties’ interests.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — The renewal of the agreement between Senegal and the European Union on sustainable fisheries is to be welcomed with regard to the conservation of biodiversity and nature conservation in Africa, as it is aimed in particular at allowing European vessels access to Senegalese waters, while at the same time subjecting them to the interests of sustainable marine protection, coordinated fishing quotas and scientific recommendations from CECAF and ICCAT. Sustainable fishing is of great interest to Europe's food supply and is also an important step for Senegal's economic development, a development that is currently primarily focused on the agricultural sector. Payments for fishing concessions are strongly based on the world market price and mainly benefit national fishermen. I agree with the renewal of the fisheries agreement with Senegal.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the report as it aims to enhance cooperation between the EU and Senegal to promote a sustainable fisheries policy in the Senegalese fishing zones, in the interests of both parties.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mrs Nicolai's report because I believe that it will form the basis for renewed cooperation between the EU and Senegal. The agreement will promote a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in Senegal's fishing grounds, in the interests of both parties. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal in the fisheries sector are governed by protocols signed between the two States on 1 June 1981. One of the principles underlying the protocol is the establishment of a level playing field for EU fleets in relation to fleets from other territories. The agreement also provides for detailed clauses relating to the suspension and/or denunciation of the Protocol in the event of human rights violations and non-compliance with the commitments made by the parties against illegal fishing.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — The purpose of this agreement is to allow European Union vessels (mainly Spanish and French) to fish in Senegalese waters in exchange for financial compensation and royalties with an estimated total value of EUR 13,930,000, as well as investments in port infrastructure. Although it lacks mechanisms to combat piracy in Senegalese waters, this agreement optimizes resource exploitation and increases transparency. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted for this agreement because it allows EU ships to continue fishing in Senegalese waters. 38 boats will be able to catch 14,000 tonnes of tuna and 2,000 tonnes of black hake per year. Senegal will receive a variable sum of around 1,700,000 euros per year. It is a balanced agreement that respects the interests of both parties.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. — Positive vote for this agreement, the application of which will allow better exploitation of stocks of certain fish, including hake, in Senegalese waters. This can only be beneficial for this country, which is suffering from the abuses of certain foreign trawlers described by the Senegalese authorities as "pirate boats", which come to fish illegally in their territorial waters. These "pirate fishing" practices are numerous in developing countries and endanger their maritime wealth, representing a significant financial loss. It is therefore desirable to support the economies of these countries. This agreement goes in that direction.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Republic of Senegal is a key EU partner with which we have long maintained fisheries relations. Eight years after the expiry of the previous Protocol, a new Agreement and its corresponding Protocol of Implementation were signed on 25 April. This is good news, in line with the increase in the fisheries agreements and protocols in force that we have been calling for since the beginning of the legislature. This is a balanced protocol, which will lead to the responsible and sustainable exploitation of resources in the common interest of Senegal and the EU, in accordance with the principles of the reformed CFP and its external dimension, and I have therefore decided to vote favourably.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal as it is part of the type of agreements aimed at enhancing sustainable fisheries by promoting better exploitation of available stocks through the use of industry best practices. I also believe that it would benefit both sides: Senegal, given the financial contribution of around EUR 14 million it would receive in the five years of the Agreement, and the EU, since the Agreement will allow European vessels, mainly Spanish and French tuna vessels, to operate in Senegalese waters. In addition, the satellite monitoring system for ships, as well as the cooperation of the authorities of both parties established by the Protocol, will help Senegal combat illegal, undeclared and irregular fishing. For these and other elements I have considered it relevant to support this Agreement.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Republic of Senegal is a coastal state of West Africa. The port of Dakar, its commercial port, is important internationally due to its geographical location.  Relations between the EU and the Republic of Senegal in the field of fisheries began on 1 June 1981, with the renewal of a number of protocols expiring in 2006 in 2002, resulting in a severe reduction in the number of EU tuna seers in Senegalese waters. In this context, it was proposed to renegotiate the Partnership Agreement. I voted in favour, as I believe that the agreement will be beneficial for both sides, as it will help to create new jobs. In addition, the satellite monitoring system and cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Senegal on the control and monitoring of vessels in Senegalese waters will help local authorities strengthen their fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing. It will also increase the economic activity of the EU fleet and assist local seafarers who, under the provisions of the Protocol, will be part of the crews of EU vessels.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — On behalf of the European Union, the European Commission has conducted negotiations on the renewal of the Agreement between the Republic of Senegal and the European Economic Community on fishing off the coast of Senegal, which entered into force on 1 June 1981.  The new draft Agreement and protocol were initialled by negotiators on 25 April 2014 at the end of negotiations. The new Agreement abolishes and replaces the existing Agreement and covers a period of five years from its entry into force. The Financial Report defines the general amount of €9.6 million for liabilities and payments of funds in 2014-18. I supported the report on the Sustainable Fisheries Agreement and Partnership between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal, as it will enhance cooperation between the EU and Senegal to promote a sustainable fishing policy and the exploitation of fishing resources in Senegal's fishing zones in the interests of both sides.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Nicolai recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion by the European Union of a Fisheries Partnership Agreement in the field of sustainable fisheries between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal, as well as its Implementing Protocol, on the one hand because the new Agreement with Senegal contains detailed clauses on the suspension of application and/or termination of the Protocol, such as Article 13 on human rights violations and Article 14 on non-compliance with the obligations undertaken by the Contracting Parties in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, and on the other hand because this Recommendation calls on the Commission to submit to Parliament annual reports on the implementation of the Agreement , in particular as regards the multiannual programme referred to in Article 4 of its Implementing Protocol, as well as details of how the funds are allocated under the Agreement.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this proposal. Taking into consideration the opportunities for the Senegalese economy to prosper from a better exploitation of the stocks available, in accordance with the principles of a sustainable fishery and the best practices in the industry, it is my opinion that the new Agreement and the Protocol are in both partiesʼ interests.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal in the fisheries sector began on 1 June 1981 and expired in 2006. The purpose of renewing this Agreement is to create a new framework for cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal in the fisheries sector are governed by protocols signed between the two States on 1 June 1981. These protocols expired in 2006. In this context, the Council authorised the European Commission to renegotiate the Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries with the African country for a period of 5 years.  One of the principles underlying the protocol is the establishment of a level playing field for EU fleets in relation to fleets from other territories. The agreement also contains detailed clauses relating to the suspension and/or denunciation of the Protocol in the event of human rights violations and non-compliance with commitments made against illegal fishing. I voted in favour of this document, as I believe that it will form the basis for renewed cooperation between the EU and Senegal. It will also promote a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in Senegal's fishing grounds, in the interests of both parties.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — (DE) This agreement received my positive vote, because the growth opportunities for the Senegalese economy can only be supported. These result from better use of available stocks in accordance with the principles of sustainable fisheries. Both parties will benefit from the continuation of this agreement. It is to be hoped that the funds made available to the Senegalese Government for this will go to the areas earmarked for this purpose.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — Two out of three fish consumed in Europe are imported. In order to secure its contributions, the Union makes agreements with producing countries, which are often in the process of developing countries, when they lack the know-how, technical and human resources or political will to exploit their fisheries resources. The aim here is to allow French and Spanish vessels to come and fish for tuna and black hake off the coast of Senegal. These provisions cause prices to fall and penalize local artisanal fishermen. In addition, there is uncertainty about black hake stocks, which makes such an authorization dangerous for biodiversity. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Republic of Senegal is a coastal state of West Africa which shares its maritime borders with the Republic of Guinea-Bissau, the Republic of the Gambia, the Cape Verde archipelago and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania. With the exception of the borders with Mauritania in the north and Guinea-Bissau to the south, the maritime borders of the Republic of Senegal are defined and recognised by common agreement. This Agreement provides for a total estimated financial contribution of EUR 13 930 000. This amount shall be distributed as follows: a) EUR 8 690 000, in respect of the financial contribution, directed to annual financial compensation (on the basis of a reference tonnage of 14 000 tonnes per year for highly migratory species) and to support the development of Senegal's sectoral fisheries policy; (b) EUR 5 240 000, corresponding to the estimated amount of the fees due by shipowners in respect of fishing licences. This agreement will be beneficial for both sides and will enable senegal's economic development, helping their people to live better and have better living conditions.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support the conclusion of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Senegal because it will facilitate an escalation of the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing (IUU) in Senegalese waters. This is important as a crackdown on IUU fishing will also benefit local fishermen.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am very pleased with the approval given by the European Parliament to the conclusion of the partnership agreement in the field of sustainable fisheries between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal. Senegal is an important trading partner for the European Union. A new fisheries agreement is an opportunity to consolidate sustainable fishing policy and support the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in Senegal's fishing areas. It will enable us to revitalize our economic and trade cooperation, promote scientific research to combat illegal fishing and continue to maintain a strategic partnership based on the defence of mutual interests.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Commission has negotiated the renewal of the Agreement between the Government of the Republic of Senegal and the European Union on fishing off the Senegalese coast, thus setting the fishing opportunities for European vessels against a financial consideration. The Agreement envisaged that 28 seine tuna vessels, 8 fishing vessels with canes and 2 trawlers (blackhake fishing, a deep demersal species), may fish in waters of the Republic of Senegal in exchange for financial compensation of EUR 1,808,000 in the first year, EUR 1,738,000 in the second, third and fourth year, and EUR 1,668,000 in the fifth year. I am in favour of this Agreement which allows the capture of 14,000 tonnes of tuna and an authorised catch volume of 2,000 tonnes for black hake.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of this agreement is to allow European Union vessels (mainly Spanish and French) to fish in Senegalese waters in exchange for financial compensation and royalties with an estimated total value of EUR 13,930,000, as well as investments in port infrastructure. Although it lacks anti-piracy mechanisms in Senegalese waters, this agreement optimizes resource exploitation and increases transparency. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — The main objectives of the agreement is to provide an updated framework taking into account the priorities of the reformed common fisheries policy and its external dimension, with a view to establishing a strategic partnership between the European Union and Senegal in the field of fisheries. The aim is also to enhance cooperation between the EU and Senegal to promote a sustainable fisheries policy and sound exploitation of fisheries resources in the Senegalese fishing zones, in the interests of both parties.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text, which establishes a sustainable fishing partnership between the European Union and Senegal. The agreement allows French and Spanish tuna, canners and trawlers to fish in Senegalese waters in exchange for nearly 14 million euros. Various clauses reinforce the fairness and sustainability of the agreement: at least 20% of seafarers on board vessels authorized to fish must be from Senegal or an ACP country. Fishing opportunities were assessed on the basis of the scientific advice of the Fisheries Committee for the East Central Atlantic.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We believe that the new partnership agreement between the European Union and Senegal is a great opportunity because, in favour of the interests of both parties, it is a valuable support instrument for increasingly sustainable fishing and for the development and use of best practices in this sector. We are confident, for example, that the new satellite vessel monitoring system and cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal will help local authorities to step up the fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing (IUU fishing). With a view to increased demand for raw material for canning industries in Senegal, European fishing vessels will also have a great opportunity to increase their economic activity in the region. This would also help local seafarers, who under the provisions of the Protocol will be part of the crews of EU vessels.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it is crucial to put in place the criteria for sustainable fishing and to allow the coastal countries of Africa, especially Senegal, to enjoy their full rights in their territorial fishing waters.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this report because the new protocol between the Republic of Senegal and the European Union has produced a new framework for economic cooperation, which is beneficial for both partners. Under the new partnership, the EU undertakes that ships fishing in Senegalese waters will employ 20% Senegalese or ACP sailors, thereby also contributing to the increase in the number of jobs in that region. Satellite monitoring of vessels will also help local authorities fight illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report today not because it is my report, but because this type of partnership agreements for sustainable fisheries between the European Union and third countries are a step forward. This new type of agreement is based on the new common fisheries policy, is developed and can be exchanged in accordance with the latest scientific information on fish stocks, provides for ways in which such agreements can help the labour market and industry in third countries, and which, last but not least, may be suspended and/or denounced as a result of breach of commitments to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, and/or human rights violations.
