These general lines must be part of all future sustainable fisheries agreements between the EU and third countries, and I hope that this will happen.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — I support the fisheries agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal. Sustainable fishing is an important step both for the supply of the European Union and for Senegal's economic development, which is still heavily based on the agricultural and fisheries sectors.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal to establish a framework for cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal, as it will create a level playing field for the EU fleets and Senegal will no longer be able to grant other fleets more favourable conditions than those provided for in that agreement. Better exploitation of fish stocks is also beneficial to the Senegalese economy, in line with the principles of sustainable fisheries and best practice in the field.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. — I welcome the conclusion of this agreement.  The provisions of this agreement will create a level playing field for the EU fleet and ensure fair competition. It should be noted that this partnership benefits both parties by helping both the Republic of Senegal and the European Union to create new jobs and to develop fisheries-related industries.  It should be noted that the EU has a significant responsibility for the conservation and sustainable management of international fisheries resources, and it is therefore essential that every Fisheries Partnership Agreement contains the principles of good regulation of the fisheries sector and sound maritime governance, thereby ensuring that sustainable and responsible fishing is developed worldwide and the value of fishery products is increased.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — There are opportunities for the Senegalese economy to prosper through better exploitation of available stocks, in accordance with the principles of sustainable fishing and best practices in the sector. The satellite monitoring system and cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Senegal with regard to the control and monitoring of vessels in Senegalese waters will help local authorities to step up the fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing. Fishing vessels flying the UNION flag would also have a great opportunity to increase their economic activity in the region, while also helping local seafarers. The available fish stocks and the prospect of future cooperation for other fish species, as well as the desirability of developing the local fisheries sector in partnership with EU vessels and supplying the European market with quality fish products, are elements that make the Partnership Agreement and its protocol of interest to both parties. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — The purpose of this agreement is to allow European Union vessels (mainly Spanish and French) to fish in Senegalese waters in exchange for financial compensation and royalties with an estimated total value of EUR 13,930,000, as well as investments in port infrastructure. Although it lacks anti-piracy mechanisms in Senegalese waters, this agreement optimizes the exploitation of resources and increases their transparency. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — Although the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal was signed as far back as 1981, since 2006 the protocol has not been in force.  I therefore support its renewal initiated last year, as well as the agreement mentioned, as it achieves the objectives of Senegal's national fishing policy, in particular the Republic of Senegal's need for additional scientific research, surveillance and combating overfishing, support for small fishermen and sustainable fishing in order to enable the recovery of the endangered ecosystem.  In all these areas, the EU can help with its experience to achieve a common long-term goal, which is sustainable fishing and protected ecosystem biodiversity.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal and its Implementation Protocol. EU-Senegal cooperation is beneficial for both sides on several points. First of all, this is an opportunity to create new jobs, both for citizens of the Member States and for Senegalese.  Then there is the increase in economic activity in the region, also on both sides, given the untapped fish resources in the Senegal Sea and the demand for raw product from fit Senegalese factories that are constantly growing. This cooperation would also greatly help the development of Dakar and the Senegal fishing industry, which is responsible for 1.3% of G.D.P. and annual exports of EUR 136 million. The European market would be stocked with quality fish from free catches. This cooperation would also be significant in terms of combating illegal fishing led by local authorities through the use of a satellite surveillance system for vessels. In accordance with all of the above and the possibility of future cooperation on other forms of fishing, I am convinced that the recommendation on the draft Council decision, with the implementation of the administrative framework and control activities, could be appropriately implemented.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) Thanks to the conclusion of this agreement, a new framework for cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal is being created. One of the most important principles of the agreement is to ensure a level playing field for EU fleets by committing the Senegalese side not to grant more favourable conditions to fleets other than those specifically indicated in the agreement. Ships must have all the same characteristics and operate on the same species. I hope that this agreement will lead to a fair understanding that will help the country to develop and that, at the same time, attention will be paid to the conservation and sustainable exploitation of existing fish stocks.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Through this vote, the European Parliament must give its approval to the conclusion of negotiations conducted by the European Commission with the Republic of Senegal. In particular, this agreement provides for greater fishing capacity, in proportion to the natural resources available, for EU flags, particularly in France. On the other hand, the European Union's financial contribution and its commitment to workers and local resources seem to me to be balanced. So I'm voting for it.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — The renewal of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Senegal aims to establish a new framework for cooperation, ensuring a level playing field for Union fleets. The Protocol will be in force for five years, with three categories of vessels being allowed to fish in Senegalese waters: 28 tuna seiners, 8 fishing vessels with canes and 2 trawlers (fishing for blackfish). The expected financial contribution is EUR 13 930 000, of which EUR 8 690 000 will be directed towards annual financial compensation and support for the development of Senegal's fisheries sector policy. In view of the opportunities available to senegal's economy to prosper thanks to better exploitation of existing fisheries resources, in accordance with the principles of sustainable fishing and good practice in the sector, I believe that the new Agreement and the new Protocol are advantageous for both parties. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — The partnership agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal in the field of sustainable fisheries is an added value for both parties, in particular for the European Union, as it has the possibility of increasing its economic activity in the region. Satellite monitoring is also important to help local authorities step up their fight against illegal fishing.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — Senegal is a key partner of the EU. On fisheries, the previous Agreement dates back to 1980 (the oldest in force). Eight years after the expiry of the previous Protocol, new Agreements and Protocols were agreed on 25 April, good news in line with the increase in fisheries agreements we have been calling for.  Now, for a period that gives some stability to the sector (five renewable years), fishing opportunities (14 000 tonnes for tuna and 2 000 tonnes for hake) are offered to 38 European vessels for a trade-off of EUR 8 690 000, an adequate value for money. Spain has sixteen sewers (out of a total of twenty-eight, with twelve for France), seven pipes (out of a total of eight, with one for France) and the two trawlers. It is a balanced protocol, in accordance with the principles of the reformed CFP. It is part of the new generation of agreements where means that the biological well-being of species with fishing opportunities has been scientifically documented. All parties benefit, including local artisanal fishermen, with a significant share of sectoral support, while, in order to support the local economy, the capture of tuna pipers and liners must be landed at the port of Dakar.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this recommendation. It is a sustainable fisheries partnership agreement that replaces the one that expired in 2006. It lays down new conditions with regard to the volume of catches and the economic contribution, among others. This Agreement allows thirty-eight ships of three types (tuna seiners, pipers and trawlers) to be operated in Senegalese waters for five years, of which twenty-five are Spanish. The agreement is positive as it benefits both sides. It promotes the development of sustainable fisheries policies in the Republic of Senegal and will enable the Senegalese authorities to improve the surveillance of their territorial waters, through a satellite monitoring system, to combat illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted for this recommendation because the main objective of this fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and Senegal is to update the existing framework so as to integrate the priorities of the reform of the common fisheries policy and its external component, while establishing a strategic partnership between these two parties.  This agreement should help to reinvigorate cooperation between the European Union and Senegal to promote a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in Senegal's fishing areas. It will also participate in the development of the local fishing sector in partnership with EU vessels, as well as in the supply of quality fishing products to EU markets.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — This Recommendation on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of a sustainable fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal, as well as its 5-year implementation protocol, deserves my vote in favour as it makes it possible to renew an agreement which ceased in 2006 , following the first agreement which had entered into force as early as 1981. The end of the Agreement in 2006 resulted in a drastic reduction in the number of tuna seiners in Senegalese waters: of the 18 tuna tuna with EU flags operating there only 2 were able to continue their activities, so it became urgent to conclude a new Agreement. The conclusion of this Agreement will ensure, on the one hand, the level playing field for the Union's fleets by preserving, conserving and exploiting the region's fisheries resources in a sustainable manner and, on the other hand, the conditions for supporting senegalese sectoral fisheries policy (1.3 % of GDP) are guaranteed, in particular through the expected financial consideration of EUR 13 930 000 , attributed with respect for sovereignty and legitimate aspirations and objectives of the country for this sector.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I supported this report, which is part of the renegotiation of the protocol to the fisheries agreement between the European Union and Senegal for a period of five years.  This agreement allows three types of vessels to be allowed to fish in Senegalese waters and the protocol includes clauses relating to the suspension and denunciation of the protocol in the event of human rights violations or commitments made in the fight against illegal fishing.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against because I consider the fisheries agreements between the EU and Senegal to be fundamentally disappointing.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this recommendation. It is a sustainable fisheries partnership agreement that replaces the one that expired in 2006. It lays down new conditions with regard to the volume of catches and the economic contribution, among others. This Agreement allows thirty-eight ships of three types (tuna seiners, pipers and trawlers) to be operated in Senegalese waters for five years, of which twenty-five are Spanish. The agreement is positive as it benefits both sides. It promotes the development of sustainable fisheries policies in the Republic of Senegal and will enable the Senegalese authorities to improve the surveillance of their territorial waters, through a satellite monitoring system, to combat illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this fisheries agreement between the European Union and Senegal, which allows the Senegalese authorities to allocate more than EUR 13 million in exchange for a fishing licence for a limited number of European vessels.  In addition, the EU is committed to ensuring that at least 20% of the sailors on board these vessels fishing in Senegalese waters are from Senegal or an ACP country. This agreement, which respects the principles of sustainable fishing and the preservation of fish stocks, is based on the scientific advice of the Fisheries Committee for the East-Central Atlantic (Copace) and is part of the external part of the common European fisheries policy.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. — I wish to record that my vote is conditioned by the following reservation: It is important that fisheries agreements concluded by the EU with third countries from the developing world seek to safeguard the rights of traditional fishermen while allowing for modern development of the fisheries industry. It is equally important that the rights and interests of traditional fishermen also be safeguarded in Member States, especially in small island communities, as in my country Malta. Traditional fishermen there rightly feel that they are being placed in an unsustainable position. Fishing quotas have been assigned to Member States on a one-size-fits-all basis, as in the allocation of tuna quotas in the Mediterranean. Also in the way by which the quota system and the discards arrangements have been designed, small-scale traditional fishermen were squeezed even harder, while incentives were implemented to encourage them to give up their work. The lifework of these fishermen, if it is maintained and encouraged, could not in any way undermine the operations of the single market in the fisheries sector. Sustainable fisheries arrangements both within and outside the EU should fully respect the rights and interests of traditional fishermen. This is not always happening.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal as it is part of the type of agreements aimed at enhancing sustainable fisheries by promoting better exploitation of available stocks through the use of industry best practices. I also believe that the European Union should ensure that sustainability commitments and good practices are respected.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I have decided to support the Partnership Agreement and its Protocol establishing a new framework for cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal in the fisheries sector. I believe it is essential that the Senegalese side's commitment has been ensured not to grant more favourable conditions to fleets other than those provided for in the agreement. The existence of detailed clauses will also ensure that the protocol can be suspended if the commitments made by both sides against illegal fishing are not respected by each other and in the event of human rights violations. There are real development opportunities for senegal's local fisheries sector which, in partnership with EU vessels, will have the opportunity both to make better and more sustainable use of available stocks and to supply the European market with quality fish products.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Union's fisheries agreements with third countries provide opportunities to make available, in a fair and clear manner, places with exploitable resources in a sustainable way, to promote the proper use of the sea, providing third countries with the tools to combat illegal, irregular or unreported fishing, and to contribute to the development of third countries by providing fair payment for the use of their endogenous resources. This is where the Fisheries Agreement with Senegal is part of this context.  Unlike other fisheries agreements, in this there is a definition of target species and some of the protected species. These facts are to be welcomed. However, the Agreement lacks mention of most protected species, including whales, dolphins, turtles and seabirds, and the definition of methodologies to prevent their disturbance. It is also notethat Appendix 4, referring to protected areas, does not yet contain information. It would be appropriate that, at this time and without prejudice to future changes, this information should be available. Finally, it is pointed out that the fishing observation system, despite being controlled by the third country, is not fully encased by the shipowners. A quarterly contribution of EUR 100, as provided for in the Agreement, seems insufficient to this end.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal. I welcome the agreement and the mutual benefits that both Senegal and the EU will enjoy in accordance with the principles of a sustainable fishery and the best practices in the industry.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the Agreement for the Conclusion of a Strategic Fisheries Partnership between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal, as it provides an updated framework taking into account the priorities of the reformed Common Fisheries Policy and its external dimension.  The Protocol provides new fishing opportunities for European Union vessels in Senegalese waters taking into account available scientific assessments, in the first place assessments of the Fisheries Committee for the Eastern Central Atlantic (CECAF), and respecting the best scientific opinions and recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) within the limits of the surplus available.  Strengthening cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal to support a sustainable fisheries policy and make responsible use of fishing resources in Senegal's fishing zones is in the interests of both parties, and opens up new perspectives on responsible and sustainable fishing necessary to conserve resources for future generations, and I therefore support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support a partnership between the European Union and Senegal in the field of fisheries. Additionally, I am in favour of enhancing cooperation between the EU and Senegal to promote a sustainable fisheries policy and sound exploitation of fisheries resources in the Senegalese fishing zones. I believe this would be beneficial for both parties. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support this Agreement because it is positive for Europe and the Republic of Senegal and brings many benefits for both sides. This route expands the possibilities of exploitation of fish resources in the Senegal fishing zone, allows us to enter the waters under their sovereignty for fishing purposes.  The European market will be supplied with quality fish products in accordance with the above categories based on current stocks, the spread of which is not excluded in the future. The agreement also contributes to the development of the local fishing industry and is based on the best scientific assessments of the Fisheries Committee for the Eastern Central Atlantic (CECAF).

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The new Fisheries Recovery Agreement and the Protocol promote the interests of both Contracting Parties.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this agreement. In view of the development prospects offered to the Senegalese economy by better exploitation, in line with the principles of sustainable fishing and best practices in the sector, of existing fish stocks, I am the rapporteur who points out that both sides will benefit from the conclusion of the new agreement and the new protocol. In addition, the satellite tracking system for ships, as well as cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal on the monitoring and monitoring of vessels sailing in Senegalese waters, support the efforts of local authorities to intensify the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. — I support the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal, which underlines long-term interests in achieving the SDGs, restoring ecosystems and supplies, as well as combating illegal and unregulated fish catching.  I find the agreement useful because in addition to the financial resources allocated by the Union to pay the annual fee, which ensures investment in the fish stock, quotas are also set to prevent overfishing of tuna and hake. I attach particular importance to the provision that vessels holding fishing licenses must ensure that 20% of Senegal nationals or people from ACP group countries are represented in the workforce, thus achieving economic growth on both sides and laying the healthy foundations of a strategic partnership.    Investment in the fishing industry of West African countries, as well as in all other coastal countries with which the EU cooperates on sustainable fisheries, must aim at strengthening a fleet of small fishermen whose fishing is a sustainable way of managing natural resources without significant adverse effects on the sea. For this reason, the requirements coming from the local level by small fishermen who are an indispensable part of the tradition and culture of their environment must also be taken into account.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I do believe that this is a good agreement for the Senegalese economy. It will help its economy to prosper from a better exploitation of the stocks available, in accordance with the principles of a sustainable fishery and the best practices in the industry.  As this is a key element, I believe that the satellite-based vessel monitoring system will help the local authorities to step up their fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fisheries (IUU). Last but not least, this agreement is a win-win outcome for both Senegal and the EU.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — Positive vote for this agreement, the application of which will allow better exploitation of hake stocks in Senegalese waters. This can only be beneficial for this country, which is suffering from the abuses of certain foreign trawlers described by the Senegalese authorities as "pirate boats", which come to fish illegally in Senegalese waters. These "pirate fishing" practices are plentided in developing countries. Every way needs to be done to combat these practices, in order to support the economies of these countries.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. — Fisheries relations between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal date back to 1981. However, after 2006 no protocol scans have been concluded or revised in this area, resulting in a stagnation of these relations. It was therefore necessary to renew the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement. The new agreement repeals and replaces the existing agreement and has as its main objective the provision of an updated framework that takes into account the priorities of the reformed common fisheries policy. The Agreement shall be accompanied by a Protocol governing fishing opportunities for European Union vessels in Senegalese waters.  The European Parliament's report supports the conclusion of this Partnership Agreement, stressing that its signature will be particularly beneficial for both the European Union and the Republic of Senegal. EU-flagged vessels will thus be able to increase their economic activity in the region, new jobs will be created in both the Republic of Senegal and the European Union, and the fishing industry will benefit and develop thanks to this new partnership. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted against supporting the fisheries agreement with Senegal. While the quotas for tuna catches provided for in the agreement are standard and acceptable, quotas for other types of species, such as hake, pose a problem. Moreover, the subversion of Senegal's fisheries monitoring provisions is totally unacceptable.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal as it is part of the type of agreements aimed at enhancing sustainable fisheries by promoting better exploitation of available stocks through the use of industry best practices. I also believe that it would benefit both sides: Senegal, given the financial contribution of around EUR 14 million it would receive in the five years of the Agreement, and the EU, since the Agreement will allow European vessels, mainly Spanish and French tuna vessels, to operate in Senegalese waters. In addition, the satellite monitoring system for ships, as well as the cooperation of the authorities of both parties established by the Protocol, will help Senegal combat illegal, undeclared and irregular fishing. For these and other elements I have considered it relevant to support this Agreement.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. — Senegal is an important trading partner for the European Union. A new agreement on fisheries will benefit sustainable fisheries. In this way, we can reinvigorate our economic and trade cooperation. It also gives us the opportunity to conduct scientific research into the fight against illegal fishing and to work together to strengthen our strategic partnership.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The first agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal on fisheries entered into force on 1 June 1981. The Protocol ceased in 2006. There was then a drastic reduction in the number of tuna seiners in Senegalese waters. In this context, the Council authorised the European Commission to negotiate a renewal of the Agreement between the Republic of Senegal and the European Economic Community, giving rise to a proposal for the conclusion of a new Partnership Agreement in the field of sustainable fisheries. This is a reasonable economic agreement taking into account the fishing opportunities available, and guarantees the basis for the conservation and sustainable exploitation of the fisheries resources concerned. It also includes fair support, as well as sufficient conditions, for the fisheries sector at local level.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of this agreement, as the growth opportunities for the Senegalese economy resulting from better use of available stocks in accordance with the principles of sustainable fisheries can only be supported. Both parties will benefit from the continuation of this agreement. It is to be hoped that the funds made available to the Senegalese Government for this will go to the areas foreseen for this purpose.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I voted in favour of the draft agreement and protocol on the sustainable fisheries partnership between the European Union and the Republic of Senegal. The European Union established relations with the Republic of Senegal in the fisheries area on 1 June 1981 and the renewed protocols concluded in 2002 expired in 2006. Action has therefore been launched to renew the Agreement between the Republic of Senegal and the European Union, which resulted in a proposal for a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement. There is no doubt that adequate governance requires the guarantee of clarity and commitment from stakeholders throughout the protocol period. Given the opportunities for the development of the Senegalese economy resulting from the rational use of available resources, in line with the principles of sustainable fisheries and best practices in industry, the new agreement and protocol are mutually beneficial, building on the available fish stocks and opportunities for future cooperation on other species, and taking into account the opportunity to develop the local fisheries industry in partnership with EU vessels and while ensuring good quality fishery products for the EU market. In addition, a satellite-based vessel monitoring system and cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Senegal on the monitoring and tracking of vessels in Senegalese waters will help local authorities to strengthen the fight against illegal and unregulated fishing.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — This Fisheries Partnership Agreement will enable EU vessels to fish in the waters of the Republic of Senegal. The agreement, which will be concluded for a period of five years, allows for the collection of 14 000 tonnes of tuna and 2 000 tonnes of hake. As with all other fisheries partnership agreements, the agreement includes a commitment to raise local awareness of fish stocks and to develop strategies for the fisheries and development of the local fishing fleet. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe must send out an important political signal, a strong warning, a firm condemnation even of those who consider its allies and who are at its side in the fight against terrorism. I voted in favour because it is clear that Europe does not. Do not be complicit in terrible torture practices justified by a war on terror. Torture is not our weapon in defeating terrorism. The news that emerged from the US Senate report on the CIA is literally horrified. I would add, however, that Europe is also full of secret prisons where torture is practised. We must be the first to demand respect for fundamental rights. One final point, that too, is frightening. What is even more worrying is that after the scandal, when asked whether these methods were justified in the United States, 58% of respondents answered yes.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, the US Senate report confirms the appalling practices that the CIA and the United States have taken in their counter-terrorism and hysteria. I probably think the planet will be more shocked when the United States releases the other 5.5 thousand pages held in the dark. Of course, moral reprochement does not lie in the ineffectiveness of torture, as is the approach of the US Senate. Torture, kidnapping, imprisonment without charges are reprehensible not because they are ineffective, but because they are everywhere and always illegal, inhuman and immoral. That's why the Obama administration is legally and morally compromised by deciding not to prosecute the torturers and perpetrators of torture, including political leadership. Europe must investigate in depth the involvement of each of the Member States and assign responsibility and guarantee that these will not happen again. At the same time, Europe must again send a strong message to the United States to comply with the obvious.

name: Martin Sonneborn (NI). -
text: Mr. President! I voted in favour of a full investigation of CIA practices because I am concerned about Europe. The United States Secret Service has tortured and mistreated prisoners around the world. Days of sleep deprivation, flogging and sardine are among the preferred cultural techniques of CIA employees. The majority of Americans don't think torture is that bad in recent polls. Germany and the US are currently negotiating a new free trade agreement. In addition to genetically modified maize and chlorine chicken, will the secret TTIP negotiations also negotiate the export hits of the American torture industry? Will we also practice music torture in the future, for example with Helene Fischer songs? Will the brand new Waterboards made in the USA soon also be available in German stores, which many conservative politicians across Europe are already looking forward to? I would like to thank the many people present for their attention. Meal!

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of my group’s resolution because I think it is simply impossible for the EU to be seen as a credible actor if it does not call for investigation and prosecution of the gross human rights violations that occurred in CIA prisons. I am disappointed that some groups wanted to water down the message we are sending on this to the US because it concerns a major partner. What happened in the CIA prisons is not only horrifying and legally wrong, it is also counterproductive in the context of our fight against terrorism, which means ultimately the security of our citizens is also on the line. That is why it is really important we investigate whether there has been transportation and illegal detention of prisoners by the CIA in the EU so we can take the steps in line with EU interests if these allegations are proved true. I am of course particularly horrified by allegations that the UK Government has lobbied to have deletion of any references to the UK from this report.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I am waiting here for the opportunity to speak and explain my vote, because I really want to condemn the torture that has been happening. I was shocked at how many cases came to light after they were discovered by the media, but of course even after these people got out of prison. I don't think cruel methods are part of the manifestation of the democratic rule of law. And I was shocked that often, in fact, these people were imprisoned for several years without having the right to access, say, the court, which is an essential component of the democratic rule of law. On the other hand, I also wanted to support the position of my faction both because of loyalty and because of cooperation on the international stage, which, in my opinion, is essential between Europe and the United States. And my resulting vote was a really difficult personal decision.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Torture is unacceptable and there is no discussion here, there is no debate, there is no disagreement here. Let no one say that we share this issue because we do not share. On the other hand, I would like, in the Polish proverb, not to pour a child with a bath, i.e. that a just condemnation of torture and the use of illegal means should not be an excuse to stop fighting Islamic terrorists, to stop fighting any terrorism. I would like to say this very clearly and clearly, we condemn torture, and at the same time we must continue to support those who are fighting the threat that also affects our Parliament, including our citizens, our taxpayers and voters.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, as Article 2 of the Treaty of the European Union clearly states, the Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom and democracy. We have to define and implement a solid and consistent counter-terrorism strategy, but the respect of human rights cannot be negotiated.  The report by the US Senate suggests that the CIA’s methods may have constituted torture. We should establish compensation for damages and identify those responsible for these actions. The CIA perpetrated torture on suspected terrorists also on EU soil. Information about the specific EU countries where this occurred remains classified. We therefore urge the European Council to react to the CIA torture allegations as soon as possible.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! I was personally annoyed that Parliament has lost a great deal of unanimity here as a result of disputes over minor matters. We all agree that everyone is against torture. We also agree that the rule of law must prove itself, especially in difficult situations, and that torture must not be used, even in difficult political situations. But, in my view, there should have been at least two things to stress, but now we are coming to the shortcoming. On the one hand, it should have been stressed more that these terrible things could have taken place, at least with the approval of the Member States of the European Union. So we also have a little bit of personal responsibility here. Secondly, we should have appreciated the progress made in the political debate in the United States.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of this resolution as hopefully it will lay the foundation for an important inquiry report into illegal rendition programmes within Member States. Many European countries – unfortunately and regrettably including my own – have stifled any attempts to conduct real, proper investigations. For our part, in my own party, Sinn Féin, we have been very vocal in our condemnation of the facilitation of secret CIA detention, rendition and interrogation programmes, which unfortunately have been facilitated through the use of a domestic airport in Ireland. I have to say that it is very disappointing that the Irish Government has helped facilitate these illegal actions. So therefore we supported this resolution in the hope that it would provide the necessary safeguards to ensure that these types of practices are not allowed to continue under our noses and against the wishes of the citizens of our states.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR). -
text: Mr President, in the US, as in Europe, there is widespread concern about abuses of civil rights. No one is going to argue with that. I would just ask the Chamber to retain a sense of perspective. Look immediately on Europe’s doorstep and you will find regimes where torture is an instrument of state policy officially, where there are shootings of unarmed demonstrators, murders of journalists, and where there is no judicial process, and that is the fundamental difference. In a country that is governed by the rule of law, abuses are investigated and where proper punished, and that is not the case in a number of countries with which we also have relations.  Of course no country should be beyond criticism and when our American friends are in the wrong they are perfectly capable of self-criticism, as well as accepting criticisms from elsewhere, but let us just keep the bigger picture here. This is a country that is trying to save civilians from bad guys who are trying to kill indiscriminately. They are not in the same moral category as some of the murderous butchers both in government and in terror organisations to our south and east.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I voted for this because we must condemn the use of torture by all means. Those methods cannot be tolerated. Moreover, they fail to prevent terrorist attacks. The climate of impunity regarding the CIA programme still represents a menace towards the values of justice, equity and dignity on which our societies are built. We cannot forget that the concepts of democracy, human rights and rule of law are the core priorities of our society and that the issue of security should not put our values aside.  Member States must conduct independent, in-depth and impartial investigations on these allegations on transportation and illegal detention of prisoners in European countries in order to establish if there have been instances of complicity by some persons and to cooperate in fining and prosecuting the perpetrators of human rights violations.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE). -
text: A Uachtaráin, is dócha go bhfuil a lán tíortha daonlathacha i gcás idir dhá chomhairle faoi conas gur cheart déileáil le sceimhlitheoirí, sceimhlitheoirí mar a chonaiceamar i bPáras le déanaí agus ina lán áiteanna eile timpeall an domhain atá ag éirí níos dainséaraí agus níos dána.  Dar ndóigh is ceart go háirithe in aon chóras daonlathach cearta daoine a chosaint agus go háirithe cloí leis na dlíthe. Nuair nach dtarlaíonn sé sin is ceart é a cháineadh. Chuaigh na Stáit Aontaithe agus an CIA thar fóir is dócha agus ní ceart gan dabht gan é sin a cháineadh mar atáimid ag déanamh anseo inniu. Tá locht á fháil ar mo thír féin freisin nuair nár chuamar ar bord eitleán a bhí in Éirinn ar a slí go dtí na Stáit Aontaithe agus iad a chuardach. B’fhéidir go bhfuil sé sin fíor, ach mar a deirim táimid i gcás idir dhá chomhairle má caithfimid gach duine a chosaint agus is deacair déileáil le daoine nach gcloíonn le haon dlíthe in aon chor.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: Mr President, honourable Members, I did not support this resolution because I did not see in it a strong condemnation and a requirement for punishment of those responsible. There is no doubt that the application of torture, of kidnapping, of civil rights violations is all that this chamber denies, and everything this chamber must fight against. Not to mention that when there are confessions plucked with torture, imagine what kind of fight against terrorism is being talked about then. Then there is a distortion of information, then there is an unnecessary effort, directed in a completely wrong direction.  Yes, civil rights must be respected. Yes, no one can afford to justify breaking the law with another violation of the law. Such a thing would completely compromise the idea of justice, completely compromise the idea of building a better and safer world. Therefore, those responsible must be investigated and effectively prosecuted in order to restore faith in justice and faith in the law and its supremacy.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. — The groups behind the resolution voted by the European Parliament today excluded the EPP and the ECR from the work on the resolution. I therefore chose to abstain from the decision because I intended to vote in favour of the resolution of my own group (EPP).  The EPP resolution strongly condemns harsh methods of interrogation, stresses the importance of complying with international law and calls on the Member States, in the light of the increased cooperation and exchange of information between countries' intelligence services, to ensure full democratic control of these bodies and their activities through appropriate internal, executive, judicial and independent parliamentary control. I support the intentions of Parliament's resolution, that is to say, to condemn torture as a method of interrogation. However, I cannot support the resolution's call for a self-initiated investigation under the auspices of the European Parliament. The US Senate report means that the US is seeking to give a frank public explanation of the CIA programme and it is now up to the EU Member States to draw their own conclusions from this report.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution because, following the revelations in the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture and the accusations that some Member States have cooperated with these practices, the EP strongly condemns the facts again and calls for a follow-up parliamentary inquiry into what happened. It is deplorable that some Member States have contributed to these crimes, already providing secret detention centres, already ignoring the transport of prisoners across their territory.  The resolution calls for criminal proceedings to be brought against those responsible. Torture is not only an abject crime, condemned by all international human rights standards, but also calls into question the basis of our values: respect for human dignity. No democracy can be complicit in such aberrant practices.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The resolution condemns the CIA's practice of torture, as well as the participation and complicity of some EU Member States in these heinous acts. That's why I voted for it. However, despite this, this resolution is far from complete. It does not reflect that these atrocities committed have concrete political leaders, such as Presidents Bush and Obama, as the CIA relies on the presidency of the United States. The report forgets to mention that the victims of this widespread practice were the "enemies" of the United States and the "suspects" of being us. Nor does it allude to the torturers being both the CIA and paramilitaries and mercenaries on the american administration's salary.  The data collected in the U.S. Senate report are just the tip of the iceberg of the brutal dimension of the U.S. use of torture, the country that is self-demining the world's largest democracy.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution as it lays the foundation for an important inquiry into and report on illegal rendition programmes within Member States. It will also pave the way for more pressure to be put on the Council, and on the Member States concerned, to respond once and for all to Parliament’s continued demands, as set out in 2012 and 2013 and in today’s resolution. The ongoing attempts by some European countries to stifle investigation of these human rights abuses are completely unacceptable. My own party, Sinn Féin, has been very vocal in its condemnation of the facilitation of secret CIA detention, rendition and interrogation programmes in Ireland through the use of our domestic airport in Shannon. The Irish Government has helped facilitate the illegal actions of the CIA by permitting the use of its airspace and airports for flights associated with CIA extraordinary rendition operations. Neither Ireland nor any other EU Member State can be complicit in human rights violations.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The European Union's policy on combating terrorism is always guided by respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law. I also expect this approach from the United States of America. I categorically reject torture and other inhuman or degrading treatment.  I therefore welcome a resolution on this matter from Parliament condemning in the strongest possible terms the cruel interrogation methods used by the CIA and calling on the United States of America to investigate and punish the numerous human rights violations arising from CIA secret detention programmes.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. " This resolution is welcome because it calls into question Saudi Arabia's obscurantist legislation. While many Member States are very close to this country, its legal corpus is very similar to that of the so-called Islamic State and the same barbaric punishments are practised there. The resolution draws parallels between Saudi Arabia and the so-called Islamic State. While I welcome this awareness of Saudi barbarism, I abstained, because it is not for the European Parliament to interfere in the internal affairs of a sovereign state.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I am not in favour of the use of torture. Therefore there is much in this report to be commended. However, the full text is not ideal and much of the content is politically naive. Therefore I abstained on this vote.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this deliberation because this report reiterates its strong condemnation of the use of advanced interrogation techniques, which are prohibited by international law and constitute offences, in particular, of the right to freedom, the right to security, the right to humane treatment, the right not to be subjected to torture, the right to the presumption of innocence. , the right to a fair trial, the right to counsel and the right to equal protection before the law.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution because, following the revelations in the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture and the accusations that some Member States have cooperated with these practices, the EP strongly condemns the facts again and calls for a follow-up parliamentary inquiry into what happened. It is deplorable that some Member States have contributed to these crimes, already providing secret detention centres, already ignoring the transport of prisoners across their territory.  The resolution calls for criminal proceedings to be brought against those responsible. Torture is not only an abject crime, condemned by all international human rights standards, but also calls into question the basis of our values: respect for human dignity. No democracy can be complicit in such aberrant practices.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I support this resolution, which aims to assess the torture of suspected terrorists by the US Central Intelligence Board and to entrust the Committee on Civil Liberties and Foreign Affairs and the Subcommittee on Human Rights with a renewed investigation into possible cia movements and illegal detention in European countries.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. "Here, as elsewhere, there seems to be more concern about the rights of the executioners than the rights of the victims. Little suspect of complacency towards the United States, I did not hesitate to vote against this text.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. —I have, of course, supported this resolution, which the EPP did not sign, in which the signatories welcome the decision of the US Senate to publish the summary of the report on the CIA's detention and interrogation programme. They call for the publication of the full text and express the horror of the illegal interrogation practices that have characterized counter-terrorism operations. The resolution calls on the United States to prosecute those responsible for human rights violations in this context and calls on Member States to investigate allegations that there were secret prisons on their territory where persons were detained under the CIA programme. Finally, it instructs its Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs to resume its investigation into allegations of transport and illegal detention of prisoners by the CIA in European countries and to report to plenary within one year.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution in which we denounced the U.S. Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA. The decision to publish the summary on the programme of arrests and interrogations has made us face the reality of the horror of the practices used. I regret that the European People's Party, the majority group of the house, has not joined such an important resolution.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture. This report, which clearly establishes the complicity of a number of EU Member States with the CIA programme, should enable the Union to shed light on these operations and to know the exact culprits of these acts.  It is undeniable that European states must also act of repentance on the issue, but we must go further and rise up now all over the world against such disgraceful practices and avoid getting out of its torpor after the disclosure of such cases.  The practice of torture in abominable conditions and the existence of secret prisons on European territory must alert us and encourage us to uphold the rights to security, freedom and the presumption of innocence and to condemn the use of advanced interrogation techniques that are not worthy of the values we hold dear. Finally, the fight against corruption must also be our priority.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) Although I offer the resolution good ideas, I think it is on the whole unconvincing and unbalanced. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution because, following the revelations in the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture and the accusations that some Member States have cooperated with these practices, the EP strongly condemns the facts again and calls for a follow-up parliamentary inquiry into what happened. It is deplorable that some Member States have contributed to these crimes, already providing secret detention centres, already ignoring the transport of prisoners across their territory.  The resolution calls for criminal proceedings to be brought against those responsible. Torture is not only an abject crime, condemned by all international human rights standards, but also calls into question the basis of our values: respect for human dignity. No democracy can be complicit in such aberrant practices.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — I welcome the decision of the U.S. Senate Intelligence Oversight Committee to release a summary of its report on the CIA's detention and interrogation program. I want to express outrage and strongly condemn the appalling interrogation techniques that characterized these illicit counterterrorism operations, all the more so because the fundamental conclusion of the U.S. Senate is that terrorist attacks were not prevented thanks to information obtained by violent CIA methods. The continuing violation of fundamental rights has been favored by a climate of impunity in the implementation of CIA programs, as confirmed by extensive surveillance programs by the US National Security Agency and the secret services of various Member States.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution as it lays the foundation for an important inquiry into and report on illegal rendition programmes within Member States. It will also pave the way for more pressure to be put on the Council, and on the Member States concerned, to respond once and for all to Parliament’s continued demands, as set out in 2012 and 2013 and in today’s resolution. The ongoing attempts by some European countries to stifle investigation of these human rights abuses are completely unacceptable. My own party, Sinn Féin, has been very vocal in its condemnation of the facilitation of secret CIA detention, rendition and interrogation programmes in Ireland through the use of our domestic airport in Shannon. The Irish Government has helped facilitate the illegal actions of the CIA by permitting the use of its airspace and airports for flights associated with CIA extraordinary rendition operations. Neither Ireland nor any other EU Member State can be complicit in human rights violations.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because I consider human rights violations to be horrible and the perpetrators must be condemned.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE)
text: in writing. - The EP criticises very much the use of torture by the CIA. But the publishing of US Senate report is another proof that the USA is a democracy under the rule of law, able to correct its policy. Therefore the EPP is astonished that the Socialists, Liberals and Greens have tabled a joint motion for a resolution with populists from the right and communists. They even refused to discuss a joint text with the EPP. This is scandalous.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted against this resolution because its content has moved very far away from what was originally intended to be. The debate on the same subject last year would have been sufficient to raise the alarm about the values of fundamental human rights and freedoms that the European Union defends today in the presence of excessive politicisation of this subject.  CIA detention centres are a reality that cannot be challenged. However, we must not lose sight of the fact that the information we have at hand about what happened in these prisons is found in a report presented in the US Senate, but not being appropriated by all political forces, and there are doubts about its content. Beyond the certainty of what has happened, torture and degrading and inhumane treatment cannot be accepted in any democratic society. To do otherwise would do nothing but turn the victims into a man, and their guilt would be no less. States around the world need to be concerned about the safety of their citizens, so that events like those in 2001, in New York, or 2015 in Paris, never happen again.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — I abstained. The resolution has elements that we can support, but it does not convince us because it does not take note of the reality in which the secret services actually have to operate.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution because, following the revelations in the U.S. Senate report on the CIA's use of torture and the accusations that some Member States have collaborated with these practices, the EP strongly condemns the facts again and calls for a follow-up parliamentary inquiry into what happened. It is deplorable that some Member States have contributed to these crimes, already providing secret detention centres, already ignoring the transport of prisoners across their territory.  The resolution calls for criminal proceedings to be brought against those responsible. Torture is not only an abject crime, condemned by all international human rights standards, but also calls into question the basis of our values: respect for human dignity. No democracy can be complicit in such aberrant practices.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the REPORT of the UNITED States Senate on the use of torture by the CIA and I can only endorse the principle that the essential cornerstone of the rule of law is respect for fundamental rights. As I have already said, the techniques of controlled drowning as well as the use of torture and other inhuman or degrading treatment do not deserve comment, but only pity for the prisoner, whoever criminal he is.  I therefore join in parliament's condemnation of the CIA's programme of secret detentions and extraordinary renditions, reaffirming that counter-terrorism policies cannot be pursued without the simultaneous protection of the principle of accountability. I urge the relevant US authorities to publish the report in full, without any more revisions and/or omissions. I am convinced that the European Union, through the decisive contribution of the Commission, must have an internal strategy to protect fundamental rights ecided by investigation activities, even if they are counter-terrorism.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution as it lays the foundation for an important inquiry into and report on illegal rendition programmes within Member States. It will also pave the way for more pressure to be put on the Council, and on the Member States concerned, to respond once and for all to Parliament’s continued demands, as set out in 2012 and 2013 and in today’s resolution. The ongoing attempts by some European countries to stifle investigation of these human rights abuses are completely unacceptable. My own party, Sinn Féin, has been very vocal in its condemnation of the facilitation of secret CIA detention, rendition and interrogation programmes in Ireland through the use of our domestic airport in Shannon. The Irish Government has helped facilitate the illegal actions of the CIA by permitting the use of its airspace and airports for flights associated with CIA extraordinary rendition operations. Neither Ireland nor any other EU Member State can be complicit in human rights violations.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — In recent years, the CIA has also committed numerous human rights violations on European territory (it is estimated that up to 2006 at least 39 prisoners had been questioned using techniques such as sleep deprivation, waterboarding and exposure to cold weather).  We condemn in its own right the carrying out of illegal interrogations and any other acts that affect human rights by the CIA on EU territory and, furthermore, we believe it is right to continue the current investigations in order to verify the presence of secret prisons, facilitating the prosecution of those who have been guilty of using illegal interrogation and detention techniques.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against this motion for a resolution on the U.S. Senate report on the CIA's use of torture. My colleagues from the groups S and D, ALDE, GUE and EFDD (an interesting alliance) are indeed right to condemn the practice of torture, but their text is completely unrealistic from the perspective of the fight against terrorism. Of course, every effort must be made to ensure that human rights are respected, and there is no doubt that there are areas of uncertainty about the CIA's actions in this area. But the motion for a resolution was wrong to oppose respect for human rights and the fight against terrorism. This Manichaean vision cannot lead to realistic and balanced actions in both areas. From this perspective, it is a matter of working with the United States of America, especially since this initiative of the United States Senate shows the goodwill of the United States and therefore it is not a question of backing down in our collaboration to dismantle the jihadist networks. The ECR and EPP co-signers of this resolution have understood this and that is why I voted in favour of their motion for a resolution (RC8-0123/2015).

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA, because in the motion for a resolution (B8-0098/2015) I did not consider paragraph 8, according to which the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs is responsible for resuming its investigation into 'alleged cases of illegal transport and detention of prisoners in European countries by the CIA', acceptable. It is not a matter for the European Parliament, especially given the implications for internal security and the fact that, in order to be able to deepen, we should have access to documents of inquiry and other judicial documents that are right to remain secret for a while longer.  My vote also stems from confidence in strong cooperation between the United States of America and the European Union in various areas, including the fight against terrorism, on the basis of the common shared values of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — Since 2006, the European Parliament has been at the forefront of exposing the truth about European involvement in the CIA rendition and secret detention programmes. In resolutions in 2007, 2009, 2011, 2012 and 2013, the Parliament has consistently promoted accountability and justice in Europe. Its input has been widely recognised in Europe and the US; the landmarks reports of 2007 and 2012 were referenced in particular by the UN, the Council of Europe and historic judgments of its Court of Human Rights on the complicity of EU Member States in CIA rendition and secret detention.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the decision of the European Parliament, to which I have contributed, to the continuation of the work carried out by the TDIP Commission, to which I have had the honour of presiding, on the CIA's use of European countries for the transport and illegal detention of prisoners. In the light of the facts known with the release, albeit partial, of the Us Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA, it is clear that, both in the Member States and in the United States, they lied in 2007. It is also clear that there are still unclarified facts and responsibilities to be determined. No less important, and in line with this Parliament's Resolution of September 2012, it is also clear that, while respecting the separation of powers and the rule of law, there is still work to be done so that situations like these do not happen again. And after the historic US Senate report, no one would understand that the EP pretended nothing had happened.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the summary report by the UNITED States Senate on torture practices used by the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA). The US spy agency has used illegal methods and cruel, inhumane and degrading practices against people who, even if they were to be potential terrorists, are still human beings. Interrogation methods reinforced with "waterboarding", sleep deprivation, rectal water pumps and leg injuries, are methods incompatible with the values underlying a democratic state. President Obama's commitment to the closure of the Guantánamo prison is an important step towards improving the situation and respecting human rights. I support a policy of cooperation aimed at combating terrorism involving all international actors, complying with international obligations and respecting human rights and fundamental freedoms. The European Union must strongly condemn all forms of torture or ill-treatment of detainees, even in the event of the fight against terrorism.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the motion for resolution condemning the practices of enhanced interrogation techniques carried out by the CIA. Losing respect for the dignity of the person is effectively losing the values the EU and the US have fought for over the years. Our societies are based on democracy, rule of law and respect for human rights. If we respond to terrorism by acting against these values we are allowing terrorists to win. In responding to terrorism we must ensure that we remain vigilant about our own rights as well as promoters of the same rights for others. Anti-terrorism measures are not the path towards a diminished responsibility towards democracy, rule of law and human rights, but measures to assist us in securing these values in our societies and to continue to transcend these values in other societies. I cannot accept a situation whereby the European Parliament does not condemn the use of torture, but I note, however, that the language used in this resolution is not the most appropriate.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA. I believe that we have to take a strong stand and condemn without hesitation the use of torture. It is unfortunate, however, that in the resolution the tone and language are at times anti-American. I absolutely do not share this approach. The US is our partner and ally and I welcome that the Obama administration has clearly condemned and stopped those practices. I also did not support the request for a new committee of inquiry on the alleged transportation and illegal detention of prisoners in Europe by the CIA, as there are already ongoing investigations in various Member States.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I could only vote in favour of this resolution. Respect for fundamental rights is an essential element for successful counter-terrorism policies and no emergency situation can ever justify the use of illegal practices. I deeply condemn the gruesome interrogation practices that have characterised these counter-terrorism operations. The use of torture should be condemned with absolute condemnation.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The resolution condemns the CIA's practice of torture, as well as the participation and complicity of some EU Member States in these heinous acts. That's why I voted for it. However, despite this, this resolution is far from complete. It does not reflect that these atrocities committed have concrete political leaders, such as Presidents Bush and Obama, as the CIA relies on the presidency of the United States. The report forgets to mention that the victims of this widespread practice were the "enemies" of the United States and the "suspects" of being us. Nor does it allude to the torturers being both the CIA and paramilitaries and mercenaries on the american administration's salary.  The data collected in the U.S. Senate report are just the tip of the iceberg of the brutal dimension of the U.S. use of torture, the country that is self-demining the world's largest democracy.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution, which deals with US Senate revelations of the CIA’s use of torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment of detainees in the wake of the 9/11 terrorist attacks and the alleged or acknowledged complicity of some EU Member States. The alleged use of European countries by the CIA for the transportation and illegal detention of prisoners was also investigated by a European Parliament temporary committee set up in 2006. The resolution calls for an end to impunity and for a full investigation into Member States’ alleged participation in the CIA operations.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. It is regrettable that on such a subject, the left-wing groups and the Liberals have once again shown themselves closed to discussion and negotiation. The resolution therefore could not take into account the position of our group, which we had to express in a separate motion for a resolution. However, I did not want to vote against the motion for a resolution by the left-wing groups, the Liberals and the EFDD. I have heard some of the demands expressed there, such as the desire to investigate allegations of transport and illegal detention of prisoners by the CIA in European countries, and to report them to plenary within one year. I am therefore in favour of the Member States shedding light on these allegations.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Thirteen years after 9/11 and the war launched by the United States against terrorism, many areas of uncertainty remain around the issue of the CIA's secret prisons on European territory. In December, the U.S. Senate issued a report on the CIA's use of torture. This document reveals evidence suggesting the complicity and responsibility of several European states with regard to the secret detention and rendition programme. While it is clear that the fight against terrorism requires a determined commitment from the Union and its main partners, it is imperative that this fight be framed by the principles of law and respect our fundamental values, starting with the rights and integrity of the human person. States must therefore investigate these centres on their territory and shed light on possible cases of human rights violations. Finally, the Commission, the guardian of the treaties and the Charter of Human Rights, will have to establish whether collaboration with CIA detention programmes constitutes a violation of European law, fundamental rights, and more broadly democratic principles.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. — It took nearly 10 years after the first revelations of CIA clandestine detention centres in Europe in November 2005 for the United States to assume and recognize the use of torture and human rights abuses. But this report must oblige Member States to recognise their responsibilities as well. Investigations must continue and should not stop, as we have repeatedly pointed out. I condemn all forms of torture and reaffirm my commitment to combating terrorism. But for that, we cannot afford to sacrifice our freedoms and fundamental rights. States and politicians who have forgotten it must take responsibility.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — The revelations of the US Senate concerning the CIA's use of torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment of detainees after the terrorist attacks of 11 September, as well as the alleged complicity of certain Member States of the Union, have had a wide public impact. The CIA's alleged use of European countries for the transport and illegal detention of prisoners had already been the subject of an investigation by a temporary committee of the European Parliament set up in 2006. The "extraordinary transfers" programme implemented involved, in the majority of cases, incommunicado detention and torture (simulacrum of drowning, false executions, sleep deprivation for long periods of time and the imposition of painful positions). Like Parliament, in its final report adopted on 14 February 2007, I can only deplore the passivity or blindness of some Member States in the face of illegal CIA operations on their territory. It is time for the European states concerned to start investigating these facts and, if they are established, take appropriate sanctions.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — The joint resolution echoes the U.S. Senate report condemning illegal interrogation practices. However, the various demands made to the Member States are likely to hinder and complicate the fight against terrorism, which is why I voted against it. On the contrary, the ECR Group resolution reaffirms that the effectiveness of counter-terrorism measures and respect for human rights are not contradictory, but are complementary mutually reinforcing objectives, and that security cooperation between EU Member States and the United States needs to be intensified.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. — The Greens/FTA group voted in favour of the resolution on the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture. By instructing the Civil Liberties Committee to resume its investigation into allegations of transport and illegal detention of prisoners by the CIA in European countries, the European Parliament allows the continuation of the work begun by its Temporary Commission as early as 2006. To shed light on these operations and to establish the responsibilities of each one is all the more important for the European Parliament as the report of the US Senate clearly establishes the complicity of a number of EU Member States in the CIA programme. It does not only confirm the existence of secret prisons on European territory or the practice of torture in its most abominable forms. It also reveals probable facts of corruption. States must assume their responsibilities, question their policies and the actions of their secret services. It is a fight for our values and a struggle for a strengthened democracy. That is what the European Parliament voted for today.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — The illegal activity of EU Member States relating to the implementation of torture and participation in the CIA's secret detention and emergency surrender programme must be condemned and this phenomenon must be eliminated.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted against the joint motion and in favour of my group’s own motion on the use of torture by the CIA. This resolution deals with CIA abuses on EU territory, but they are illegal wherever in the world they occur. The EU Member States and high-level government ministers who were involved must face up to their role in the renditions programme. The European Union values peace and justice. My constituents in Wales were shocked at these events. We cannot allow abuses like this to happen again.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution to express my strong condemnation of the cia's programme of secret detention and prisoner surrenders, which is responsible for numerous human rights violations, including through secret detention and non-trial, the use of torture and other forms of inhuman treatment, without respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law, while also expressing my support for measures that can prevent the repetition of these practices in the future.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The EU has always developed internal security and counter-terrorism policies based on police and judicial cooperation and the promotion of the sharing of security information while respecting fundamental rights and the rule of law. Relations between the EU and the US are based on sound partnership and cooperation in many areas, based on common and shared values on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The effectiveness of counter-terrorism measures and respect for human rights are not contradictory, but are complementary mutually reinforcing objectives. However, respect for fundamental rights is an indispensable component for the success of counter-terrorism policies. Therefore, Member States that are conducting independent and effective investigations into human rights violations related to the CIA programme must base their investigations on sound judicial evidence and respect for national judicial systems, EU and international law, the primacy of national security and the sensitive aspects of any ongoing criminal investigations.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) The REPORT of the US Senate on the use of torture by the CIA leaves us astonished and horrified. There is nothing to justify the use of torture on human beings, even against those who have committed the worst crimes.  This is a principle of civilisation which we must defend vigorously and from which we can no longer turn back. While the self-criticism carried out by the US Senate is to be welcomed, we cannot ignore the violations of human rights committed by the CIA. On the other hand, we cannot accept any kind of justification for torture on terrorists, real or presumed, as it is useful if not necessary to collect information for national security. There is nothing, neither in peace nor in war, to justify torture which not only violates the inalienable right to integrity of the human being, but which, moreover, cannot in any way be regarded as a means of seeking the truth.
