The European Union has a duty to lift the veil on secrets and omissions that have covered the cooperation of the Member States in the actions carried out by the CIA on European territory. The European Union undertakes to take a firm stand against what emerged from the US Senate inquiry.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Although the resolution condemns the practice of torture by the CIA, as well as the participation or complicity of some Member States in these atrocious and ineffective acts, it falls short of what is necessary in its political evaluation of this process. It should be noted that the atrocities committed, the subject of the US Senate report (which is far from exhaustive), have concrete, well-identifiable political leaders – both George Bush and Barack Obama – taking into account the direct articulation of this agency with the presidency. It should be noted that this widespread practice was victims of US enemies or only suspects and as perpetrators of torture not only the CIA but also the military forces and mercenaries at the behest of the American administration. And that the figures referred to in the U.S. Senate report are the tip of the iceberg to conceal the real and brutal scale of the us' use of torture. And all this in a country that asserts itself as the greatest democracy in the world or the leader of the free world, always willing to mobilize its own resources and to rally allies to impose its vision of human rights in the world.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — It is unacceptable for the Member States of the European Union to cooperate and actively engage in illegal activities of the US Central Intelligence Service on their territory and to de facto promote the torture practices used in these facilities by doing so. The responsible committees of the European Parliament must be given the space to continue investigating the suspicions in question. The European Union cannot allow fundamental human rights to be violated on its territory, nor can it ensure that victims are given the opportunity for all legal remedies.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I condemn torture without ifs and buts. However, I cannot fully support the resolution because it does have elements that we can support but also others that are not relevant to reality.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the resolution on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA, because the illegal activity of EU Member States concerning the use of torture and participation in the CIA's secret detention and emergency surrender programme must be condemned and this phenomenon must be eliminated.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. "We are all aware today of the terrible chronicles of torture of prisoners by the CIA. From the European Parliament we must condemn with the greatest force these unbecoming practices of a consolidated democracy and contrary to the defence of human rights. The U.S. Senate report has proven that the CIA employed reinforced interrogation techniques outlawed by U.S. law and international treaties prohibiting recourse to torture. The fight against terrorism must respect human dignity, human rights and fundamental freedoms, since respect for human rights is not at odds with effective counter-terrorism measures. However, we must take into account the positive steps taken by President Obama in banning torture and promoting the humane treatment of detainees, as well as efforts to close the Guantanamo detention centre.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution because, following the revelations in the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture and the accusations that some Member States have cooperated with these practices, the EP strongly condemns the facts again and calls for a follow-up parliamentary inquiry into what happened. It is deplorable that some Member States have contributed to these crimes, already providing secret detention centres, already ignoring the transport of prisoners across their territory.  The resolution calls for criminal proceedings to be brought against those responsible. Torture is not only an abject crime, condemned by all international human rights standards, but also calls into question the basis of our values: respect for human dignity. No democracy can be complicit in such aberrant practices.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which strongly condemns, once again (after a report in September 2012, after a report in October 2013), the unacceptable practices of "extraordinary rendition", detention in secret prisons and torture, and above all the complicity of European states with these CIA 'programs'. For years, we have demanded that the Member States involved conduct thorough, impartial and independent investigations into the failures and abuses that have occurred and that the European Union comply with its values; and we recall that in this new report. More precise investigations must be carried out and responsibilities must be established! I hope that the adoption of this report, as well as the recent publication of a U.S. Senate report on this matter, will allow us to move forward in redressing these unacceptable practices!

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for resolution as we need to push for accountability of human rights violations with regards to the CIA rendition and secret detention programmes. We also need to call on EU Member States to investigate any allegations of secret prisons. I believe there is no justification for the use of torture; human rights violations need to be strictly condemned.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. " Following revelations from the U.S. Senate report on the CIA's use of torture and accusations that some Member States have collaborated with these practices, the EP strongly re-condemns the facts and calls for a parliamentary follow-up investigation into what happened.  The resolution calls for criminal proceedings to be brought against those responsible. Torture is not only an abject crime, condemned by all international human rights standards, but also calls into question the basis of our values: respect for human dignity. No democracy can be complicit in such aberrant practices.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. Following the publication of a damning report by the US Senate on the CIA's detention and interrogation programme, I supported the European Parliament's request for an investigation into the AFET, DROI and LIBE committees to ascertain whether EU Member States were involved in these illegal procedures, on the basis of cooperation already highlighted in previous reports. A plenary report will have to be adopted within one year. Torture is not only an unacceptable crime, condemned through international human rights conventions, but above all it calls into question one of the fundamental values we share in Europe, namely respect for human dignity. We must therefore ensure that Member States have not cooperated in these criminal acts, either by providing secret places of detention or by turning a blind eye to the transport of prisoners via their territory. This task will certainly not be easy and we can expect to face obstacles, including the misuse of state secrecy and the classification of documents that result in the closure of criminal proceedings.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution because, following the revelations in the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture and the accusations that some Member States have cooperated with these practices, the EP strongly condemns the facts again and calls for a follow-up parliamentary inquiry into what happened. It is deplorable that some Member States have contributed to these crimes, already providing secret detention centres, already ignoring the transport of prisoners across their territory.  The resolution calls for criminal proceedings to be brought against those responsible. Torture is not only an abject crime, condemned by all international human rights standards, but also calls into question the basis of our values: respect for human dignity. No democracy can be complicit in such aberrant practices.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. — The European Parliament has ordered the resumption of its investigation into allegations of illegal transport and detention of CIA prisoners in European countries and will report on them within a year.  This resolution comes a few weeks after the release of the US Senate report on CIA torture, which I strongly condemn. However, I am embarrassed by the parallelism of the forms that the European Parliament tends to establish with the Member States of the Union, on the assumption that our governments would be the complacent accomplices of these unacceptable practices. The decision to relaunch an investigation should not be an opportunity to base a case against governments and their intelligence services, but to shed light on verified and proven facts.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on the European Parliament's resolution on the REPORT of the United States Senate on the use of torture by the CIA. The report condemns the torture committed by the CIA, calls for an investigation into whether there were secret prisons in the Member States, and commissions an investigative commission on the CIA's alleged use of European countries for the transport and illegal detention of prisoners. In the joint resolution, and partly following the final amendments, many of them tabled by the EPP and drastically reducing the tone of the document, references to secret prisons and the investigation of the detention and illegal transport of prisoners in EU member countries disappear. The final resolution does not fully address the dimension of the torture committed, nor does it delve into the origin and causes thereof.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a joint motion for a resolution on the US Senate torture report by the CIA, on the grounds that I am deeply in the belief that all investigations and prosecution procedures for all criminal acts, including those suspected of being terrorism, should respect the highest attainment of democratic standards and respect for the rule of law and respect for human rights.  Of course terrorism is a major civilizational and security threat, but it should be fought by all available mechanisms in such a way that they are controlled by democratic institutions and do not pose a threat to respect the rights of citizens. I agree that counter-terrorism measures and respect for human rights are not conflicting objectives, that the international fight against terrorism must be conducted with full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and democratic and judicial oversight, that cooperation between the US and the EU is important in this field.  I support a multilateral approach with resolute cooperation with the United States in the global fight against terrorism. I condemn extreme forms of interrogation that are prohibited by international law. I welcome the U.S. Senate report and President Obama's actions as a positive step forward in promoting a more humane treatment of prisoners, and I agree that Member States work strongly together and share information on intelligence and security matters with full democratic oversight guaranteed.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — The joint resolution echoes the U.S. Senate report condemning illegal interrogation practices. However, the various demands made to the Member States are likely to hinder and complicate the fight against terrorism, which is why I voted against it. On the contrary, the ECR Group resolution reaffirms that the effectiveness of counter-terrorism measures and respect for human rights are not contradictory, but are complementary mutually reinforcing objectives and that security cooperation between EU Member States and the United States must be intensified.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. — Rejection of torture and respect for human dignity are basic pillars of democratic societies. That is why, following the revelations in the US Senate report on the torture committed by the CIA and the accusations that some Member States have cooperated with these practices, I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution strongly condemning the facts and calling for a parliamentary follow-up inquiry into what happened. It is deplorable that some Member States have contributed to these crimes, already providing secret detention centres, already ignoring the transport of prisoners across their territory.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament voted this week on the CIA's use of torture. The proposal for Joint Resolution B8-0098/2015 of the S&D Groups, ALDE, GUE/NGL, EFDD and Verts/ALE is the only one that taxatively condemns the use of torture. For this reason, EH Bildu voted in favour of that resolution and against resolutions RC-B8-0123/2015, B8-0123/2015 and B8-0133/2015 submitted by ECR and PPE. But the EU should not look abroad alone—the US and the CIA in this case—when it comes to tackling the scourge of torture. At Community level torture is tortured; Spanish security forces torture euskal Herria, as the successive judgments of the Strasbourg Court of Human Rights have witnessed and corroborated. What the EU demands of the rest of the world must first guarantee it on its territory: to eradicate the use of torture and to act against the Member States that practice it.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I did not support the joint resolution on the U.S. Senate report on the CIA's use of torture. This resolution is unbalanced and does not welcome the work done by the U.S. Senate. Moreover, it does not reaffirm the European Union's commitment to cooperate with the United States in the global fight against terrorism.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA’ because we condemn gruesome interrogation practices, the violent methods applied by the CIA and torture.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The Union was to uphold democracy and respect for human rights, freedom and security from the outset. She has also always been an ally of the United States in the fight against terrorism. It continues to declare its continued willingness to cooperate closely in order not to commit acts of terror, but with constant respect for common values. These two facts do not stand in opposition to each other, on the contrary, respect for human rights allows for an effective fight against terrorism. Therefore, the Union cannot accept the tolerance of methods incompatible with international law and must not allow the use of interrogation methods that violate human dignity. Existing tools and organisations that fight against peace violations and terrorism should be supported and used.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — torture in any form must be condemned. The fight against terror must be compatible with human rights. The us position and THE EU position on this issue are similar in the 2009 US-EU statement: the fight against terrorism must be in line with international law, in particular human rights and humanitarian law. In this context, it is to be welcomed that US President Obama wants to deliver on his 2008 campaign promise to close the military base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. The work of the European intelligence services to safeguard internal security is essential, as is cooperation with the US secret service and other services. However, in any case, the EU Member States must comply with national and EU law in the context of this cooperation. I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. — I had to vote together with the PPE Group against the text. As the key amendments proposed by the PPE were not accepted, the text of the resolution remained seriously unbalanced. The resolution in question cannot be treated as an isolated case. It is part of the EU and USA bilateral relationship which is in a crucial stage as the TTIP talks are entering a decisive phase. The PPE text underlines that transatlantic cooperation has always been based on common values, including promotion of fundamental human rights, but also joint efforts to combat terrorism.  We welcome the fact that the USA Congress has been willing and able to expose deviations in the treatment of prisoners who were heavily suspected of being active terrorists. This is a sign of healthy and strong democracy. We have absolutely no reason to doubt the commitment of American institutions to the basic principles of citizensʼ rights. It is a bit hypocritical to point a finger at President Obama for not having closed down the Guantanamo facility, while ignoring the fact that very few EU governments have been willing to accept prisoners kept there.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — We see from the US Senate report that some measures adopted to counter terrorism have violated human rights and the rule of law. The objectives are to save human lives and dignity in the face of a terrorist threat. The continued silence of some EU States is a disgrace. The Parliament has demanded on numerous occasions that these countries must come clean. They must provide the whole truth about the human rights violations committed and facilitate genuine access to justice for all the victims. Violation of human rights cannot serve as an excuse for combat against terrorism in the name of ‘national security’. Respect for human rights and the rule of law must prevail and these must be the bedrock of it.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament's position on covert detention and extraordinary rendition by the CIA has been consistent over the long term. They stand up for human rights, against kidnapping, illegal, secret detention and torture of reindeer, which very often they are not even sure are guilty of. After 9/11, under the auspices of the so-called war on terror, the American civil service decided to sideline the right to freedom, dignity, due process, as well as the presumption of innocence in order to materialize Guantanamo Bay in place of these hard-won rights. A place where no rights apply and incarceration spends years in a legal vacuum from which there is no escape. Many admired lands of freedom have become a country that discovers the practices of the Spanish Inquisition and has taught us the concept of waterboarding. These practices, unworthy of the 21st century, imported American intelligence services into Europe. The European Parliament has therefore asked several times for investigations and information on, among other things, the where-to-be-found secret prisons on European territory. Time is running out and the European Parliament remains ignored. For the reasons set out above, I am sincerely disappointed that the motion for a joint resolution did not receive the support that I think it deserves and has passed only very narrowly. It remains to be hoped that our willingness to uphold human rights has not buded from the pursuit of trade and that the European Parliament will no longer be ignored.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. - One of the most democratic states in the world has been revealed to be very ugly. Secret prisons, torture and more. The compromise proposal takes correct and decisive action against the main responsible US and its European accomplices on the issue of illegal CIA prisons, and even calls for strategic strengthening of the protection of fundamental rights and an action plan. LIBE would order a new investigation, calling for a full investigation, impeachment and disclosure. Well, that can only be supported. We also want to thank Mr Snowden and everyone who helps make the truth public.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I supported this document because I consider the commitment to democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms to be important, not only in the context of the European Union's internal policies but also in its role as a global player.

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the adoption of this resolution and voted in favour. It is a confirmation of the EP’s long-held position that torture is unacceptable and contrary to international law, wherever torture is practised in the world. I also welcome the fact that the EP continues to press for the closure of Guantánamo. I wish to see the return of London resident Shaker Aamer to the UK to rejoin his wife and family. He is one of those mentioned in the Resolution as cleared for transfer, and the UK Government is prepared to accept him – yet, inexplicably, he remains in Guantánamo. His case shows that the repercussions of extraordinary rendition and torture still continue to affect lives and have ongoing political consequences. The EP’s enquiries deserve to continue until questions are answered and justice is seen to be done.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament discussed on 17 December 2014 with the Council and the Commission the recent revelations of the US Senate on the use of torture by the CIA against those arrested by the terrorist attacks in New York. The CIA's alleged use of European countries for the transport and illegal detention of prisoners was investigated by a temporary commission of the European Parliament, established in 2006. In its final report, adopted on 14 February 2007, Parliament deplored the passivity of some EU Member States in relation to illegal CIA operations. The report then noted that the CIA's "extraordinary deliveries" programme involved, in most cases, "incommunicado detention and the application of torture". This situation was confirmed by the victims or their lawyers, who tested before the parliamentary committee. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution tabled by my Political Group (S&D) together with ALDE, GUE/NGL, Verts/ALE and EFDD.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution because, following the revelations in the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture and the accusations that some Member States have cooperated with these practices, the EP strongly condemns the facts again and calls for a follow-up parliamentary inquiry into what happened. It is deplorable that some Member States have contributed to these crimes, already providing secret detention centres, already ignoring the transport of prisoners across their territory.  The resolution calls for criminal proceedings to be brought against those responsible. Torture is not only an abject crime, condemned by all international human rights standards, but also calls into question the basis of our values: respect for human dignity. No democracy can be complicit in such aberrant practices.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The resolution condemns the CIA's practice of torture, as well as the participation and complicity of some EU Member States in these heinous acts. That's why I voted for it. However, despite this, this resolution is far from complete. It does not reflect that these atrocities committed have concrete political leaders, such as Presidents Bush and Obama, as the CIA relies on the presidency of the United States. The report forgets to mention that the victims of this widespread practice were the "enemies" of the United States and the "suspects" of being us. Nor does it allude to the torturers being both the CIA and paramilitaries and mercenaries on the american administration's salary.  The data collected in the U.S. Senate report are just the tip of the iceberg of the brutal dimension of the U.S. use of torture, the country that is self-demining the world's largest democracy.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I am against the torture of people in general. However, I do not agree with the unequivocal condemnation of the United States, whose policies are influenced by the current government, but not by a clearly democratic constitution. I voted against it because an amendment recognising the democratic nature of the US has been removed from the resolution.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. — Together with the EPP Group, I voted against this resolution. I am absolutely against torture and, at the same time, Condemn the Deaths of More Than 3,000 People in the Terrorist Attacks of 11 September 2001. But the solution is not to point the finger at the American authorities, nor to treat them with superiority, hiding behind a cardboard screen, behind which human rights are also violated in Europe. I want to remind everyone that we are at key moments, the negotiations on the transatlantic treaty must end at the end of this year. Recent events in Paris have shown that we must jointly find a common strategy and methods to fight terrorism. I insist that cooperation with the US must be strengthened at this time. We want to be partners with them, but we are adopting a resolution with content similar to another older resolution on the same subject. It's not the right solution. In addition, the U.S. Senate has found and condemned acts of torture, so they are publicly debated so that it never happens again. I suggest we focus on what we have to do from now on.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The United States Senate shall draw up a report on the use of various forms of torture of detainees between 2001 and 2006 by the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA). The report originally has 6,000 pages, and in December 2014 SSCI (Senate Select Committee on Intelligence) published an executive summary of the report. The report details the actions of CIA officials, including torturing captives, giving misleading or false information about classified CIA programs, and not allowing surveillance of authorities and internal criticism. It also revealed the existence of previously unknown detainees, the fact that more detainees were subjected to much harsher 'treatment' than previously reported, and that far more methods of torture were used than were known. It concluded that the torture of prisoners did not help gain cooperation with detainees and that the program damaged the international reputation of the United States. I support this report because violence and any form of torture are not a civilised and socially acceptable way of obtaining information, and such an act conflicts with basic human rights.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. I voted in favour because the situation is unacceptable from the point of view of European democracy and human rights. I voted with my political group, in particular in support of amendments that require, for example, national investigations to make the US CIA public (ALDE Group amendment, following paragraph 6 of the resolution).

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted against this resolution for the following reasons: I believe that, in the current international context, it is not necessary, urgent or relevant to set up another commission of inquiry into the CIA detention centres. The US authorities are investigating and prosecuting violations of the law committed under the CIA secret surrender and detention programme and have shown their willingness to cooperate in all Member States' requests to this effect. I welcome the decrees issued by the US Presidency to ensure that the US complies with national and international law on the prohibition of torture and cruel, degrading and inhumane treatment. I believe that the US Senate Special Intelligence Committee Report is a positive step in resolving criticism of the programme and demonstrates the readiness of the democratic political system to publicly and honestly take responsibility for the work of the CIA. It makes no sense in the current international context not to understand the need to be united in the fight against terrorism and in the face of the danger posed by the Ukrainian conflict.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing - Written explanation of vote pursuant to Rule 183(1) of the Rules of Procedure Vladimír Maňka 11 February 2015 U.S. Senate report on the CIA's use of torture International conventions do not allow any form of torture of prisoners. Resolving conflicts of war and terrorism with another form of violence cannot contribute to a real solution to the problems that are shaking up the world today. Such practices bring the whole world back centuries. Countries that position themselves as leaders in the field of human rights protection cannot commit cruel torture and disparagement of human dignity in secret prisons and facilities distributed around the world. We cannot agree with such practices.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA, because, among other things, with this proposal the European Parliament finds in a clear and unequivocal way that national security and counter-terrorism policies are not excluded from the principle of accountability and that there can be no impunity for violations of international law and human rights.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this Resolution which ‘Expresses its horror and deep condemnation of the gruesome interrogation practices that characterised these illegal counterterrorism operations; underlines the fundamental conclusion by the US Senate that the violent methods applied by the CIA failed to generate intelligence that prevented further terrorist attacks; recalls its absolute condemnation of torture̕.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) Parliament strongly condemned the CIA's secret detention programme sponsored by the United States because it involved multiple human rights violations such as the use of torture and other inhumane treatment. Europe must send out an important political signal and demand respect for fundamental rights. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I supported the proposed resolution because it reflects my hidden feeling, and that is helplessness. The introductory part of the proposed resolution contains references to a number of resolutions, statements and promises that called for an investigation into violations of the rights of a number of specific people, the inference of the consequences of the torture of people, as well as such concrete steps as the closure of guantánamo prison, not to mention the report by the Commissioner for Human Rights of the Council of Europe on prisoners at the US Military Base Camp Bondsteel in Kosovo. I would like to recall that in the published version of that report to the US Senate Committee, states that participated in the CIA's illegal program are marked with colours. Washington Post journalists identified five, including three from the European Union: Poland, Lithuania and Romania. I do not recall anyone ever presenting a report to national parliaments or the European Parliament on how it is possible that such crimes have taken place and, above all, what has been done so that something like this cannot happen again. The proposed resolution contains an important thesis: respect for human rights and the rule of law is an essential element of a successful counter-terrorism policy. The first thing we need to do in the West if we are to successfully counter the rise of terrorism is to examine conscience. To look for our own mistakes that have caused us not to prevent terrorism, or even those that have insuciated terrorism directly or indirectly.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I supported this document because I think it would be appropriate for the European Union, which has always promoted human rights and fundamental freedoms, to adopt a position of condemnation of the CIA's secret detention and surrender programme. I particularly welcome the reference in the resolution to the complacency of the recent measures taken by US President Obama in an attempt to close the Guantánamo detention centre.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The Us Senate report on the cia's use of torture raises and disseminates a set of practices that have been carried out around the world and in particular in the Member States of the European Union. It is to be welcomed that these facts have been disclosed. On the other hand, we regret the shocking interrogation practices that characterise the operations carried out by the CIA.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — (DE) In Parliament's resolution on the torture of the CIA in the United States, I was clearly opposed to the methods used. An investigation must be made of previous abductions and methods of torture. Human dignity must also be strictly preserved in the field of counter-terrorism and still inviolable.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — This resolution is the starting point for the US Senate report that the CIA used advanced prohibited interrogation techniques, namely torture. This report has undermined previous negotiations by the right-wing majority on this issue. The lenient approach developed by this resolution sees it as "the will of the American political circles to be accountable to the public for the CIA program." It therefore welcomes President Obama's "decrees prohibiting torture" and "his tireless efforts to close the detention center at the US military base at Guantanamo." Recall that its closure was planned for 2009, six years ago... Finally, while the resolution "strongly condemns" the use of torture, it still calls on Member States investigating the CIA's use of torture to "base these investigations on solid judicial evidence". I am voting against this hypocritical resolution.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — I agree that respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law is an indispensable element for the success of counter-terrorism policies.  Access to citizens' data on whatever communication platform should not be free and indiscriminate. However, we cannot neglect the fight against terrorism either and the current information-sharing system has already been responsible for saving countless lives. We must be sensitive to these two visions of the same problem and find a balance in order to protect the fundamental rights of citizens and, on the other hand, not to lighten the fight against terrorism, otherwise it will once again collect human lives.  I voted, however, against this resolution because I believe that a certain left-winger is continuing to mix issues and issues that are not related, namely that of bringing to this resolution a point on the reopening of the process on the infamous CIA flights.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — The PPE had tabled an alternative resolution that in my opinion struck a better balance between the protection of individual liberty and collective security. International cooperation in this field must be conducted with full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and with appropriate democratic and judicial oversight. That alternative resolution also condemned the use of enhanced interrogation techniques and inhumane practices whilst promoting increased cooperation and information sharing between Member States.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I condemn in the strongest terms the unspeakable practices in violation of national and international law committed by the CIA and revealed in the US Senate report. There is nothing, and even the fight against barbarism, to justify such practices. At the same time, we must congratulate the U.S. Senate for having the courage to highlight the very dark passages in his country's modern history. This is a true example of a democratic system of counter-power. However, as MEPs, we must first and foremost focus on the passive and consensual actions of some of our Member States. By turning a blind eye, they have broken their deepest commitment: respect for the rule of law. I welcome the LIBE Commission's request for further investigation. Nevertheless, this democratic control could be extended to a broader committee that also includes national MPs, judges and academics. In the face of such heavy actions, we must find an ambitious and adequate formula; we must have a historical counterweight strong enough to prevent the same mistakes from being repeated.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution relates to the recent U.S. Senate report on the CIA's use of torture. Some european Union countries have been implicated and implicated, more or less directly, in these practices. Indeed, this report confirms allegations of transport and illegal detention of prisoners in secret prisons by the CIA, prisons located in some Member States of the European Union. Equally serious, the report mentions probable facts of corruption, demonstrating once again the submission of some European Union countries to the United States. In fact, this proposal hinders and complicates the fight against terrorism. So I voted against it.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. — A report released by the U.S. Senate on December 9, 2014 shed light on the secret program used by the CIA to interrogate suspected al-Qaeda militants after 9/11. In particular, the report accuses the agency of subjecting several detainees to brutal techniques for several years. It was concluded that the CIA's methods of torture were ineffective. The joint resolution of the EPP and ECR groups stresses that the fight against terrorism and respect for human rights are not contradictory, but complementary. Transatlantic cooperation based on these common values and respect for fundamental rights is a priority in the European Union's external relations.  Our resolution here welcomes the report of the Special Committee of the United States Senate, which is a positive step forward in public and critical opposition to the CIA's detention and interrogation program and demonstrates the willingness of American political circles, with the support of members of both parties represented in Congress, to be accountable to the public on the CIA program.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament has repeatedly condemned the CIA's programme of secret detentions and extraordinary renditions, as it has led to multiple violations of human rights, including the use of torture and other inhuman or degrading treatment. We believe, in fact, that security and counter-terrorism policies absolutely cannot ignore respect for international law and human rights in general. In this regard, we welcome the decision of the US Senate to publish a summary of its report on the CIA's detention and interrogation programme, and indeed we urge that it be published in full without excessive and unnecessary revision. Once again, we strongly condemn the illegal interrogation practices, extraordinary rendition programmes and secret detentions that have taken place, and we call on the United States to cooperate with all requests from EU Member States on information, extradition or effective means of redress for victims. We therefore call for the adoption of an internal Eu ropean Union strategy on fundamental rights and call on the Commission to propose the adoption of this strategy and its action plan.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this text and supported the resolution put forward by the EPP and the ECR, because the text was more balanced and respectful of the national prerogatives of the Member States. It reiterated the importance of human rights, condemned advanced interrogation techniques and called on the Member States concerned to seriously conduct their investigation. The resolution voted instructs the LIBE committee to conduct an investigation when it has neither the legitimacy nor the means to do so: the result cannot be serious.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. — There are no exceptions to the prohibition of torture, and no circumstances can justify the use of torture. Not even if we do it for homeland security reasons. Human dignity and life are universal human values that we must unconditionally respect all over the world. The United States of America, as guardian of democracy, cannot afford to use such terrible means. Especially at a time when terrorists around the world are committing disgusting/horrific/heinous actions against innocent people. Although the protection of the integrity of our fellow citizens (citizens) is of the utmost importance, we must achieve this by means that do not de-unk to the level of terrorists.  We must find the means to achieve maximum security in our countries, while acting with universal human values and rights in mind, both against our own and those of other countries. I therefore fully support the EP's resolution.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution, which follows the publication in December of the US Senate Report, which reveals that in several EU Member States, the authorities, as well as security and intelligence officials, would have collaborated with the CIA on its covert detention and extraordinary surrender programme.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: scríofa. — Chaith mise vóta i bhfabhar an rúin seo mar go gcuireann sé an chéad chéim cun tosaigh i gcomhair tuarascáil fiosrúcháin a bhunú maidir le cláir de ghéilleadh neamhdhleathach laistigh de na Ballstáit. Mar aon leis sin, faoi dheireadh, is bealach é le níos mó brú a chur ar an gComhairle agus ar Bhallstáit áirithe freagairt a thabhairt ar na héilimh leantacha atá tagtha ón bParlaimint agus mar a leagtar amach i rúin ó 2012 agus 2013 agus sa rún seo. Ní féidir glacadh le hiarrachtaí atá ar siúl ag tíortha Eorpacha áirithe fiosrúcháin ar threascairtí ar chearta an duine a stopadh. Tá sé sin do-ghlactha. Le tamall fada anuas anois, bhí agus tá mo pháirtí féin, Sinn Féin, an-ghlórach inár gcáineadh ar an tslí a bhfuil éascú á dhéanamh in Éirinn ar choinneáil rúnda, géilleadh agus ceistiúcháin CIA trí úsáid ár n-aerfoirt intíre i Sionainn. Tá Rialtas na hÉireann ag éascú gníomhaíochtaí neamhdhleathacha de bharr go bhfuil sé ag tabhairt cead do CIA úsáid a bhaint as aerspás agus aerfoirt na hÉireann d’eitiltí atá bainteach le géilleadh urghnách. Ní féidir le hÉirinn ná le haon Bhallstát san Aontas Eorpach a bheith comhpháirteach le sáruithe ar chearta an duine.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament has managed to produce a good document and I have voted in favour of it. The European Union in general, and Romania in particular, where I have led the investigation committee, needs to preserve a firm safeguard of our laws and values. At the same time, we want to maintain good cooperation with the USA, as long as it is understood that in the future their intelligence services will take more care to respect those values of ours.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because I consider the drafting of a comprehensive report to be a very important step, which demonstrates the willingness of the US Government to critically analyse the situation. Joint efforts to combat terrorism must be consistent with international law, based on obligations under international human rights law and humanitarian law.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. In the light of the horrific details presented in the report, the investigation into the alleged transport and illegal detention of prisoners by the CIA in European countries should be reopened as soon as possible. It should be noted that the CIA's secret detention and extraordinary rendition programme has fostered an atmosphere of impunity and allowed for further atrocities. In addition, until now, the creators or direct perpetrators of the detention and interrogation programme have not been brought to legal justice. It is therefore essential that Member States carry out independent, comprehensive investigations into cases of wrongful transmission, detention and torture and finally prosecute those who commit these crimes. Every country must take care of its own security, but it must do so through legitimate action. It is therefore essential that legal loopholes are closed, that the legal process is based on fairness and prevents the future implementation of such opaque programmes.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) The war on terror waged by the United States was a serious violation of human rights, international law, humanitarian law and the principles of the rule of law as a whole. The United States, the 'exporting' country of democracy, has managed to act with impunity, finding itself in an effective world economic situation characterised by unilateralism. The silent cooperation of many European countries in so-called 'redention', illegal transport and enforced disappearances has led to the writing of a black page in contemporary history. Heavy methods of torture, authorised by senior cia and US government leaders to extort information necessary to foil the terrorist attack, have been made possible by the proclamation of a state of emergency and by various ACT acts that have followed under the Bush presidency. I conclude my statement by recalling a rigorous analysis prepared by Cesare Beccaria, who in 1764 affirms, among other things, in his "Crimes and Punishments", the intrinsic incongruity of the technique of torture because this, not respecting the principle of the presumption of innocence, is not functional in the search for the truth and induces, in most cases, false confessions.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The joint resolution, behind the condemnation of the CIA's horrific torture against "terrorist suspects", attempts to obscure the responsibilities of the US Government, as well as the governments of the EU Member States, which cooperated with the US secret services, in kidnappings, illegal detentions and handing over persons to the CIA. It attributes torture and crimes to alleged arbitrariness by the CIA and the secret services of EU Member States, even to phenomena of alleged corruption and bribery of state officials and agents, thus masking the obvious fact that they were committed at the behest of governments, by state mechanisms of the civil state that deeply hostile the people and act to protect the power of the ruling class. Characteristic of the cover-up of the source of all the crimes of the US secret services and EU Member States, its civil power and its governments is also the reference of the resolution that torture did not lead to the posting of information, i.e. it was... Ineffective! Torture, kidnapping, murder of the us, EU and its Member States are components of civil power and its state. The peoples will eliminate them completely by fighting against their monopolies, associations and power.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) Parliament has repeatedly called for the fight against terrorism to be carried out with respect for human dignity, human rights and fundamental freedoms, including in the context of international cooperation in this field. Parliament strongly condemned the US-sponsored CIA's secret surrender and detention programme, which involved multiple human rights violations. Relations between the EU and the US are based on a strong partnership and close cooperation in various areas, based on shared common values of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. On December 3, 2014, after six years of investigation, the AD HOC COMMITTEE of the US Senate on Secret Service published a summary of its study on the CIA's interrogation and detention programme, and the report's conclusions show that the CIA has resorted to enhanced interrogation techniques prohibited by US law and international treaties prohibiting the use of torture , treaties to which the United States is a signatory. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. — I welcome the report of the US Senate Committee as a positive measure for public and critical confrontation with the shocking facts implemented by the CIA, which demonstrates the willingness of the US democratic political system to report openly to the public, with the assistance of members of both congressional political parties, on the agency's agenda. After the sad events in Paris, I am convinced that measures to combat terrorism and respect human rights are not contradictory, but should complement and strengthen each other.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — Torture and policies that support torture as such are not acceptable or desirable in modern society. The U.S. Senate recently released a long-awaited report on the cia's use of torture.  I welcome the Senate's initiative and the report, as a strong democratic procedure by which classified information was presented to the public on the basis of which it is possible to determine whether there were discrepancies in compliance with internationally accepted conventions and human rights laws when it comes to CIA conduct. It is extremely important to shed light on the whole case so that the public is familiar with facts rather than semi-information, because it is a system whose primary function is to protect the safety of citizens and in which citizens should have confidence.  As regards the second human life and the violation of basic human rights established by the UN Conventions, in this case, in particular the Convention against Torture, it is very important to see that measures against terrorism complement human rights respect, so I call for continued committed cooperation between the US and the EU in this regard.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — This resolution relates to the recent U.S. Senate report on the CIA's use of torture. Some european Union countries have been implicated and implicated, more or less directly, in these practices. Indeed, this report confirms allegations of transport and illegal detention of prisoners in secret prisons by the CIA, prisons located in some Member States of the European Union. Equally serious, the report mentions probable facts of corruption, demonstrating once again the submission of some European Union countries to the United States. In fact, this proposal hinders and complicates the fight against terrorism. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I strongly condemn the appalling interrogation techniques that characterised these illegal counter-terrorism operations. In my view, the continuing violation of fundamental rights has been favored by a climate of impunity in the implementation of CIA programmes, as confirmed by extensive surveillance programmes by the US National Security Agency and the secret services of various Member States.  Of concern are the obstacles encountered by national parliaments and faced by judicial investigations into the involvement of certain Member States in the CIA programme, abuses of state secrecy institutes and unsubstantiated declaration of information as confidential resulting in the suspension of prosecutions, resulting in the suspension of human rights violations, which resulted in human rights violations being de facto unpunished.  I support the call for the adoption of an EU internal strategy on fundamental rights and call on the Commission to propose the adoption of this strategy and the action plan associated with it, which is why I supported this resolution.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — I supported the motion for a resolution submitted following statements by the European Council and the Commission on the US Senate summary report on torture by the CIA, as I believe in a legitimate and effective policy based on the rule of law. The EU is founded on a commitment to democracy, human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity and international law.  That is why I find unacceptable cia extradition procedures, unlawful and arbitrary detention, torture and other forms of U.S.-led abuse. However, as the EU-US relationship has always been based on strong partnership and cooperation, common ground also needs to be found on counter-terrorism, as supported by the 2009 US-EU Joint Statement, which stated that counter-terrorism must be in line with human and humanitarian rights. The fight against terrorism requires a multilateral approach and this is why the global alliance against terrorism is of utmost importance. I welcome the positive measures of President Obama, who has issued executive orders banning torture and humane treatment of detainees, and demonstrates his continued commitment to closing the detention facility at Guantanamo Bay. I therefore encourage member states' security agencies and secret services to cooperate and share information intensified, but under appropriate internal, executive, judicial and independent parliamentary scrutiny of their activities.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — I support Parliamentʼs resolution to condemn the Central Intelligence Agency for multiple human rights violations in its treatment of prisoners. The report by the US Senate Select Committee on Intelligence provides ample evidence that parties supported by the United States Government are guilty of profound human rights violations, including torture and humiliation of prisoners, even though such vile methods are not at all viable ways to combat terrorism.  I urge the United States to hold those responsible for these horrible acts accountable as criminals, and to cooperate with EU Member States in their own investigation into allegations of secret prisons and other CIA activities on their own territories.  I additionally call on the Commission to adopt an internal strategy to safeguard thoroughly the fundamental rights of every individual so that we may prevent such barbaric acts, even in the name of freedom and security.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) Although I am a staunch advocate that the fight against terrorism must be done decisively and resolutely, at the same time I believe that it is intransmissible to act with respect for human dignity, human rights and fundamental freedoms on the basis of the EU Treaties. The US Senate report concluded that the CIA had used interrogation techniques prohibited by both US legislation and international treaties, and that they should therefore be strongly condemned. It is essential, and this is why I voted in favour, for everyone to have a fair and proper process of taking responsibility. It is of the utmost importance if we are to maintain public confidence in democratic institutions and have legitimate security policies based on the rule of law.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — I would like to begin by praising the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture and the measures taken by the President of the United States to close Guantanamo. The resolution that the European Parliament was first to address was led mainly by a socialist alliance, thus excluding the EPP Group. I therefore voted against this first resolution, because the resolution subsequently proposed by the EPP Group was more balanced and more applicable in practice. While transparency requirements are crucial, they should not be harmful to the main objective of combating terrorism. As proposed in the resolution presented by the EPP Group, while maintaining a strong discourse against torture, it is up to the focus on cooperation between states and the establishment of mutual trust.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — This resolution underlines that respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law is an indispensable component for the success of counter-terrorism policies. In this regard, and while it is certain that the international fight against terrorism and bilateral or multilateral international cooperation in this area must be conducted in full respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms and under appropriate democratic and judicial control, I join in condemning the CIA Detention and Interrogation Programme and the enhanced interrogation techniques used in this area , which are prohibited by U.S. law and international law. On the other hand, and given that an appropriate principle of accountability is indispensable for preserving citizens' confidence in democratic institutions and for protecting human rights, it is important to welcome the publication of the summary of the us Senate Special Information Committee's report on the CIA Detention and Interrogation Programme, as well as investigations by several Member States into allegations of involvement in the transport and illegal detention of prisoners in European countries by the CIA, as positive steps that demonstrate the willingness of political actors to ascertain responsibilities.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. — By instructing the Civil Liberties Committee to resume its investigation into allegations of transport and illegal detention of prisoners by the CIA in European countries, the European Parliament is allowing the continuation of the work begun by its temporary committee as early as 2006. To shed light on these operations and to establish the responsibilities of each one is all the more important for the European Parliament since the report of the US Senate clearly establishes the complicity of a number of Member States in the CIA programme. It does not only confirm the existence of secret prisons on European territory or the practice of torture in its most abominable forms. It also reveals - and this is new - probable facts of corruption. Some Member States have reportedly accepted sums of money in exchange for their cooperation with the CIA. These are all elements that the European Parliament will have to investigate. Transparency on complicity, revealing the truth and doing justice will not make the bed of terrorism, quite the contrary. It is a fight for our values and a struggle for a strengthened democracy. That is what the European Parliament voted for today.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution which condemns the use of illegal interrogation practices. Respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law is essential, including in counter-terrorism policies.  I welcome the decision of the U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee to release the report on the CIA's detention and interrogation program. It is now the duty of the United States to investigate and prosecute the practices of its agency and we invite it to do so. Beyond the conviction, we urge Member States to shed light on the allegations ed to them: persons detained under the CIA programme, torture or illicit transport of prisoners. To do this, our Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs was tasked with conducting an investigation and publishing the results within one year.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — The publication of the report on the CIA's Detention and Interrogation Program has a bittersweet taste.  On the one hand, it is to be welcomed by the publication of the Us Senate Special Information Committee. On the other hand, it is regrettable the shocking interrogation practices that characterized the operations carried out by the CIA.   In the context of this report, there is also great concern about all the obstacles and obstacles placed when carrying out judicial investigations in national parliaments that were involved in counter-terrorism operations with the CIA.   One must quickly rethink what to do with the illegal arrests by the CIA of prisoners in European countries. One should also think about the strategies of action that have been carried out by the CIA.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution because, following the revelations in the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture and the accusations that some Member States have cooperated with these practices, the EP strongly condemns the facts again and calls for a follow-up parliamentary inquiry into what happened. It is deplorable that some Member States have contributed to these crimes, already providing secret detention centres, already ignoring the transport of prisoners across their territory.  The resolution calls for criminal proceedings to be brought against those responsible. Torture is not only an abject crime, condemned by all international human rights standards, but also calls into question the basis of our values: respect for human dignity. No democracy can be complicit in such aberrant practices.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. — First of all, I would like to stress that this resolution is gaining weight on a number of accents. Firstly, it calls on the United States to cooperate in receiving all requests from EU Member States for information on the investigation carried out. Only in this case can comprehensive research in Europe be ensured and help to uncover the truth. Secondly, the resolution is entrusted to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, with the participation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and, in particular, the Subcommittee on Human Rights, to reopen the investigation into the 'alleged transport and illegal detention of prisoners by the CIA in European countries' and to present a report to plenary within a year. This will also encourage investigations in the Member States, as they will have a greater interest in collecting information themselves before the report is published in the European Parliament. I also take this opportunity to state that I do not justify in any way the use of reinforced interrogation methods that mimic humanity, torture people, and unlawful imprisonment. These are huge mistakes that have been made here in Europe. Although I understand that this cannot compensate for the damage caused, as a European, I want to sympathise with all those people who have been tortured and gone through real hell. I condemn those who have contributed to this, closed their eyes, or pretended not to know what was going on.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union, in the field of its internal security and counter-terrorism policy, bases its activities on police and judicial cooperation, as well as on promoting the sharing of security information, while respecting fundamental rights and the rule of law. For this reason, close cooperation between Member States and between the EU and the US in combating and counter-terrorism action is essential. My vote in favour of this report is that I endorse the position which supports, inter alia, the idea that the international fight against terrorism and bilateral or multilateral international cooperation in this area should be conducted with full respect for human rights and under appropriate democratic and judicial scrutiny and control, so that transatlantic cooperation works fully at the level of the alliance against this global threat.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I abstained because the resolution has elements that we can support, but it is completely divorced from the reality of secret services and their modus operandi.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on the European Parliament's resolution on the REPORT of the United States Senate on the use of torture by the CIA. The report condemns the torture committed by the CIA, calls for an investigation into whether there were secret prisons in the Member States, and commissions an investigative commission on the CIA's alleged use of European countries for the transport and illegal detention of prisoners. In the joint resolution, and partly following the final amendments, many of them tabled by the EPP and drastically reducing the tone of the document, references to secret prisons and the investigation of the detention and illegal transport of prisoners in EU member countries disappear. The final resolution does not fully address the dimension of the torture committed, nor does it delve into the origin and causes thereof.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted against this joint resolution of the groups S and D, ALDE, Greens, GUE and EFDD because, in my opinion, the epp and ECR resolution was more balanced and measured. Indeed, our resolution strongly condemned the CIA's interrogation practices and welcomed the publication of the report of the SPECIAL committee of the U.S. Senate on the excesses of the program conducted by the Agency. We called on President Obama to continue his work towards the closure of the detention centre at the US military base at Guantanamo and the release of detainees who have not been charged.  However, I am not convinced that the establishment of a special European Parliament commission of inquiry on the participation of European countries in the CIA programme, proposed by the joint resolution, is effective or timely. This commission of inquiry would have neither the means, nor the competence, nor the legitimacy to carry out this kind of mission.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. — Almost 15 years after the CIA began the CIA's abduction, internment and torture programmes, even though the facts were known and exploited even by the cinema since 2005 at least, we now have the chance to see an act of repentance by America and the European states that participated in it.  America has used dishonourable methods for its values and those who have followed it in Europe have disgraced the values of Europe.  It is the follow-up and the oblivion of the values that have spawned torture. As in Ukraine today, the same omissions, the same pro-American follow-up and the same disgrace. Will we have to wait 15 years to hear you say: we didn't know, we're sorry? The European Parliament will also have to do its mea-culpa.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The resolution condemns the CIA's practice of torture, as well as the participation and complicity of some EU Member States in these heinous acts. That's why I voted for it. However, despite this, this resolution is far from complete. It does not reflect that these atrocities committed have concrete political leaders, such as Presidents Bush and Obama, as the CIA relies on the presidency of the United States. The report forgets to mention that the victims of this widespread practice were the "enemies" of the United States and the "suspects" of being us. Nor does it allude to the torturers being both the CIA and paramilitaries and mercenaries on the american administration's salary.  The data collected in the U.S. Senate report are just the tip of the iceberg of the brutal dimension of the U.S. use of torture, the country that is self-demining the world's largest democracy.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. — The practices of the CIA used on detainees during their interrogations, uncovered by the report of the US Senate Intelligence Committee, are deeply disturbing. Secret prisons in Poland and Afghanistan also pose questions about how and where the War on Terror was waged. The introduction of so-called ‘enhanced interrogation techniques’ paved the way to the crimes and abuses committed at Abu Ghraib prison. Human dignity should always have the upper hand over the need of military or intelligence agencies. Therefore I voted against.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. — Respect for human rights and the rule of law are fundamental elements in the successful prevention of terrorist policies. The European Parliament has repeatedly condemned the CIA's cover-ups, which have committed a serious violation of human rights by using torture, kidnappings, secret detentions without an existing final conviction and other inhumane arrests. Despite the fact that these inhumane grips justify it as a way of combating and preventing terrorism, we must not and cannot tolerate such human rights violations. Although the CIA is a secret service to the United States, such methods of dealing with detainees or suspects are not acceptable and I strongly condemn them. At the same time, I also welcome the US Senate's decision to publish a CIA report on the detention and interrogation of prisoners. Furthermore, I support the European Parliament's decision, which calls on the Member States to give an insight into whether these cruel acts have also taken place in them, as is suspected. In any case, such gripes must be prevented and all possible levers used in the future so that this does not happen again. As I believe that such gripes are unacceptable and unacceptable, I voted in favour of it in the European Parliament.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because I support the Union’s condemnation of illegal counter-terrorism activities in the United States.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. — The report confirms what we knew about the CIA's action and the implications of the 'fight against terrorism'. In addition, it makes it clear that the abductions and tortures were carried out with the knowledge of the US government, which authorised them to be carried out.      However, the moral value of the CIA Program does not lie in the "ineffectiveness" of torture, such as the approach of the Senate Intelligence Committee. We condemn torture and CIA memoranda for being illegal, inhuman and immoral.        We also consider the Obama administration's decision not to prosecute the torturers and perpetrators of torture, including the political leadership and the authors of the Memorandums, to be legally and morally unacceptable. The investigation and condemnation of torture are the obligations of all States, as provided for in Article 5 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 7 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and Article 7 of the UN Convention against Torture.         Our position is that the US should be called upon to criminalise torture in the manner laid down in the UN Convention against Torture.  The US must also sign and ratify the relevant UN Conventions and Protocols.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — The illegal activity of EU Member States in the use of torture and participation in the CIA's secret detention and emergency surrender programme must be condemned and this phenomenon must be eliminated.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) It is essential to condemn the CIA's programme of detentions and secret actions, which has led to multiple human rights violations (including torture, kidnapping, detention without trial) and it is equally essential to shed light on the connivance of EU Member States in this programme and on suspected corruption practices. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution which, in addition to condemning these actions, calls on the European Commission to propose the adoption of an EU strategy on fundamental rights and instructs Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Subcommittee on Human Rights to resume its investigation into 'alleged cases of illegal transport and detention of prisoners in European countries by the CIA' and to update the European Parliament within one year.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. — We live in a world filled with threats to the security of our allies and our own nations. These threats cross all international boundaries and have given us a common challenge. The rise of ISIS, with the large number of European citizens in its ranks and their ability to return to Europe, has presented the EU with a clear and present danger. Our ability to counter these threats is rooted in our ability to gather and share intelligence. That does not mean that we need to condone torture and disrespect human rights in order to keep our nations safe. Counter-terrorism measures and respect for human rights are not contradictory in nature. I welcome the executive orders issued by President Obama banning torture and ensuring that the US respects the laws, both domestic and international, banning torture and inhumane treatment. I am thankful the Senate committee publicly criticised the CIA’s detention and interrogation programme. I propose greater cooperation between the intelligence agencies of the Member States, as well as the EU and the US. We must work together to provide security for our nations while ensuring we do not infringe on the fundamental human rights of a single human being.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. "I obviously voted in favour of the resolution. We have already repeatedly condemned the CIA's secret detentions and the extraordinary rendition programme, which have resulted in multiple human rights violations, including the use of torture and other inhuman or degrading treatment, abductions, secret detentions, detention without trial and violations of the principle of non-refoulement. These ways of doing things are totally unacceptable and go against my values, let's say our European values!

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. "We are experiencing very convulsive times when human rights are threatened by extremism. But in this context, public authorities cannot be left out of our scrutiny.  Voting in favour of this resolution, I repeat, first of all, my palliative condemnation of the torture and mass surveillance practices carried out by the CIA and, on the other hand, the need for Member States to immediately investigate any signs of human rights violations within the EU in relation to their participation in the CIA's counter-terrorism programme.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. — I voted to adopt the Resolution on the US Senate Report on the Torture of Prisoners by CIA members, as I consider that in times of globalisation, a common approach at international level is unquestionable to successfully counter the creation and dissemination of a terrorist network that itself is becoming global.  The threat of modern terrorism poses a global threat and is no longer aimed at jeopardizing the national security of individual states or the interests of allies, but is taking on a wide scale. We must not allow us to use the methods of those same whose conduct we condemn in countering terrorist threats and suspects for which there is reasonable evidence that they have committed a terrorist act, or states that sponsor terrorism.  I therefore fully agree with the allegations that the international fight against terrorism and cooperation in preventing further terrorist attacks must be primarily consistent with respect for fundamental civilizational values such as human rights and the protection of citizens' security, and that it must be based on valid legal evidence so that terrorism can be defeated within the rule of law.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution. The US Senate’s report on post-9/11 CIA torture revealed shocking truths about the ʽenhanced interrogation techniquesʼ used against foreign prisoners in overseas prisons, including rectal rehydration, sleep deprivation, long periods of standing and threats to prisonersʼ family members.  Several countries hosted US detention centres, including three EU Member States: Poland, Romania and Lithuania. These activities cannot be justified at all. According to the UN Convention against Torture (1984), no exceptional circumstances may be invoked as a justification of torture (Article 2). It is very worrying that the ʽtechniquesʼ were previously authorised by the US authorities. I welcome the publication of the Senate’s report. Regretfully, former high-ranking officials in the US still try to justify these ʽtechniquesʼ which proved to be largely ineffective. The fight against terrorism, the democratic image of both the US and the EU, the positive character of US-EU cooperation are heavily compromised.  It is appropriate to insist on public officials in the US and the EU, responsible for acts of systemic and outrageous breach of fundamental rights, being punished. Europe cannot serve as a beacon of democracy if no appropriate measures are taken in Poland, Romania and Lithuania – all three countries were actively involved in moulding the European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I firmly believe that respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law is an essential element in successful counterterrorism policies. In past resolutions, Parliament has repeatedly condemned the CIA’s secret detention and extraordinary rendition programme, which resulted in multiple human-rights violations, including the use of torture and other inhumane or degrading treatment, abduction, secret detention, detention without trial, and violations of the non-refoulement principle. Despite their particular nature, national-security and counterterrorism policies are not exempt from the principle of accountability, and there can be no impunity for violations of international law and human rights.  I therefore call on our American allies to investigate and prosecute the multiple human rights violations resulting from the CIA rendition and secret detention programmes, and to cooperate with all requests from EU Member States for information, extradition or effective remedies for victims in connection with the CIA programme. EU Member States should also investigate the allegations that there were secret prisons on their territory where people were held under the CIA programme, and prosecute those involved in these operations, taking into account all the new evidence that has come to light.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution supported by all groups except the PP. In this text, Parliament shows a very firm position against the torture used by the CIA on bases such as Guantanamo and alert to the use of European territory to host flights used for illegal hijackings.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The resolution condemns the CIA's practice of torture, as well as the participation and complicity of some EU Member States in these heinous acts. That's why I voted for it. However, despite this, this resolution is far from complete. It does not reflect that these atrocities committed have concrete political leaders, such as Presidents Bush and Obama, as the CIA relies on the presidency of the United States. The report forgets to mention that the victims of this widespread practice were the "enemies" of the United States and the "suspects" of being us. Nor does it allude to the torturers being both the CIA and paramilitaries and mercenaries on the american administration's salary.  The data collected in the U.S. Senate report are just the tip of the iceberg of the brutal dimension of the U.S. use of torture, the country that is self-demining the world's largest democracy.
