name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE)
text: Written. - The VVD praises the US Senate for its very objective and frank report on the role of the CIA in waterboarding, rendition, etc. It is to be welcomed if the MEMBER States of the EU and other countries would mirror the American attitude. The VVD has therefore supported the CIA resolution, whereby ultimately the standing and incumbent magistracy in the Member States determines whether individuals are being persecuted and governments and parliaments decide for themselves what lessons they draw from this affair.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted alongside my colleague in favour of the resolution asking the US Senate to report on the use of torture by the CIA because I express deep condemnation of the gruesome interrogation practices that characterised these illegal counterterrorism operations; I underline the fundamental conclusion by the US Senate that the violent methods applied by the CIA failed to generate intelligence that prevented further terrorist attacks.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. — The CIA's practices go against the letter and spirit of international law. The European Parliament has been condemning these practices for a long time. The criminal or terrorist activity that the suspects were believed to have committed is not an excuse for the government to torture. The Us Senate has had the courage to reveal and dig out this dark page.  As MEPs, we should focus on the (active or) passive cooperation of some European authorities. I hope that the LIBE Committee will be able to do its job in the European Parliament and show as much courage as the UNITED States Senate.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This report has the merit of lifting the tip of the veil on a set of practices carried out by the CIA around the world and in particular in countries of the European Union. It thus reveals the true face of that country, which calls itself the champion of democracy and human rights. Not going as far as it should, the report still points out some positive measures that could contribute to a better understanding of the role of the CIA as well as its methods. It should go further in condemning the imperialist policies behind it and on behalf of those who come up with these practices. It should also go further in condemning the countries that supported these practices in their respective countries. They are, in many cases, countries of the European Union, where human rights should be respected, but which have been conniving with torture and the whole list of practices that are attentive to human dignity that are described in the report.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - I was clearly opposed to the methods used in Parliament's resolution on the torture of the CIA in the United States. An investigation must be made of previous abductions and methods of torture. Human dignity must also be strictly preserved in the field of counter-terrorism and still inviolable.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — I welcome the European Parliament resolution of 11 February 2015 on the report of the United States Senate on torture by the CIA, which, in the end, considers it too weak. It is true that it is absolutely right to strongly condemn the cruel methods of interrogation in the context of these illegal measures to combat terrorism. What is crucial, however, is a full return to the rule of law. The US, like so many other states, still needs to make some progress along this path. It is not enough to publish a report on torture, which has also been blackened in essential places. I want to draw a parallel with the right of self-reporting in German tax law. For tax evaders, self-reporting provides a bridge to a return to legality. However, it is required that it disclose all tax evasion. If he conceals part of it, his self-reporting is ineffective. I think it is right to apply the same standards to the United States. It is not just about torture, but also about secret prisons, illegal kidnappings and surveillance involving the US intelligence services. Returning to the side of the "good" states – where the US should be the global model of a liberal-democratic order of values – requires more than a partial admission of guilt.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The joint resolution, behind the condemnation of the CIA's horrific torture against "terrorist suspects", attempts to obscure the responsibilities of the US Government, as well as the governments of the EU Member States, which cooperated with the US secret services, in kidnappings, illegal detentions and deliveries of persons to the CIA. It attributes torture and crimes to alleged arbitrariness by the CIA and the secret services of EU Member States, even to phenomena of alleged corruption and bribery of state officials and agents, thus masking the obvious fact that they were committed at the behest of governments, by state mechanisms of the civil state that deeply hostile the people and act to protect the power of the ruling class. Characteristic of the cover-up of the source of all the crimes of the US secret services and EU Member States, its civil power and its governments is also the reference of the resolution that torture did not lead to the posting of information, i.e. it was... Ineffective! Torture, kidnapping, murder of the us, EU and its Member States are components of civil power and its state. The peoples will eliminate them completely by fighting against their monopolies, associations and power.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Although the resolution euphesively condemns the practice of torture by the CIA as well as the participation or complicity of some Member States in these atrocious and ineffective acts, it falls short in its political assessment of this process. It should be noted that the inventory of horrors and atrocities that constitutes the US Senate report is a list of the crimes for which both George Bush and Barack Obama are responsible, given the direct articulation of this agency with the presidency. And that this widespread practice was victims of u.S. enemies or just suspects and as actors of torture not only the CIA but also the military forces and mercenaries at the behest of the American administration. And that the figures referred to in the U.S. Senate report are the tip of the iceberg to conceal the real and brutal scale of the us' use of torture. And all this in the country that asserts itself as the most important democracy in the world or the leader of the free world, always willing to mobilize its own resources and to rally allies to impose its vision of human rights in the world. Full clearance of Member States' involvement in this process should remain within the competence of national parliaments and/or national justice authorities.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. — What is the difference between democratic communities that respect human dignity and human rights and the authoritarian and totalitarian communities that violate them?  Among other things, the need to detect weaknesses in individual policies through democratic legislative procedures, civil oversight of repressive bodies and public scrutiny, and to propose appropriate improvements. In order to detect violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms, even if they occur in the legitimate fight against terrorism, to abolish them and thus to strengthen the foundations of the democratic community.  Undemocratic communities are sweeping human rights violations under the carpet, there is no control over repressive bodies, because they, along with the courts, are just an extended deadline for power. What is more, such communities have even emerged, like, say, communist Yugoslavia, with a systematic violation of human rights and fundamental freedoms. The US Senate report on the unacceptable methods of the US security services is therefore welcomed as a positive measure, as the US has spoken out about them publicly and demonstrates the willingness of the US state to openly face interrogation techniques that are contrary to US law and international agreements. A balanced motion for a resolution by the European Parliament on this subject has been proposed by the EPP Group, it represents my views, and I wanted to support it. Unfortunately, we did not vote on it, as the joint resolution of the other groups has already won support.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent terrorist attacks in Europe have not only claimed innocent victims but also caused a huge sense of insecurity and fear among our citizens. I voted in favour of this resolution so that the European institutions and the Member States can effectively use all the instruments at their disposal to protect citizens. We strengthen security and intelligence services that monitor suspected groups, but measures that end up criminalising an entire community and offending Muslims who have nothing to do with or even sympathise with Al Qaeda, or those that affect freedom, a principle that undersoes the European Union, are counterproductive.  The West must do all it can to prevent the attacks to stop the at least seven conflicts that are taking place from Pakistan to Somalia and Nigeria, as in Iraq, Syria, Yemen and Libya, from whose sparks can come flames that would spread throughout Europe. That is the top priority.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE). -
text: I myself have not broken down this resolution, mainly because, in my opinion, the proposed methods in this resolution are not appropriate and in some ways represent the strengthening of the so-called big brother over citizens' rights. There are already sensitive topics where the exchange of information can also mean a degree of control and, above all, excessive interference with human rights. And that is why I consider it important for the European Union to adopt in this area those measures which will in some way also be linked not only to the European Union, but also to the wider European area, with all 47 European countries, which also fall within the so-called scope of action of the Council of Europe. And I consider it important for the European Union to support and accede to the emerging protocol of the European Convention against Terrorism, which relates precisely to the area of radicalisation and recruitment for terrorist activities, and thus contributes to more effective means of combating terrorism.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of the resolution. The text goes in the right direction: unity towards a common challenge. This cannot be safeguarded without the making of creative efforts proportionate to the dangers which threaten it. That is what Robert Schuman declared on 9 May 1950. We should look back to our origin to find the necessary strength to fight terrorism. In the fifties of the last century our response to this big challenge of terror was the EU integration process inspired by the principle of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. I firmly believe this is the way forward once again. We need a transversal action combining cohesion, education and economic policy with security measures that guarantee the respect of fundamental rights and secure legal and public acceptance.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, more than thirteen years after 11 September 2001 and after the attacks in Paris last January, the European Union is once again facing the terrorist threat. Today, as then, I believe that the best response we can give is to show that the European Union is truly united in the fight against all forms of terrorism. The Member States have done a great deal in recent years to try to prevent such attacks, but I believe that much still needs to be done. We now have legislative instruments and advanced cooperation structures, but I am convinced that we still need to work to ensure that these instruments are truly effective and efficient. We must be aware that, in order to try to combat the threat of terrorism in the best possible way, the Member States must cooperate more actively with Europol and Eurojust. Only through real and fair judicial and intelligence cooperation, with the logistical and infrastructural support of the European Union, can we win this battle. The resolution proposed today is a step in the right direction, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I supported this resolution because I wanted the European Parliament to also have a resolution addressing terrorism and the tasks to be performed by the EU. If anyone thinks we can defeat terrorists in the 21st century on the basis that one country will fight terrorists, they are very wrong. Terrorists have a very sophisticated system that needs to be combated both in real life, on the Internet and on social media. The services must cooperate with each other, and the institutions and countries must work together. And I think that is the task that the European Parliament has now started.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR). -
text: Mr President, the immediate aftermath of a terrorist atrocity is the one time when we should not legislate, because a false equation takes hold. People think that the political response should be proportionate to the sense of public outrage rather than proportionate to the need to address an identified security problem.  In the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, on both sides of the Atlantic there were huge grabs of power by the state which would have made no difference in that instance, and which served to reduce our liberty without commensurately increasing our security. We are now doing exactly the same thing; in the aftermath of the abominations in Paris and the aftershocks that were felt in other European cities there is this terrible sense that takes hold – in all legislatures, because politicians are sensitive to public opinion – saying something must be done.  The something that should be done first is to exhaust the powers already at our disposal before we start grabbing for additional powers, and I cannot help noticing in this debate that a number of my colleagues in this House are using the recent atrocities to revive their long-standing calls for a further federalisation of security policy, rather than to address the need which we have in fact identified.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I fully support tackling terrorism at its roots through a preventive, comprehensive and holistic approach. The best way to prevent these attacks is not through torture and violation of human rights but through education and social policies that avoid racism and other pretexts for exclusion. I do not believe that the fight against terrorism should undermine our principles of freedom of movement, human rights and the rule of law.  I would like to highlight the need to share databases and intelligence on terrorism and exchange information between Member States. This proposal, stated in the resolution, should be carried out without delay, as well as the creation of an anti-terrorism European intelligence agency to better counter potential terrorist attacks. That is why I voted for it.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI). -
text: Mr President, there are good things in the resolution that has just been voted on but also, it seems to me, a certain angelism. An essential factor, for example, is not mentioned: it is the breeding ground for terrorism and, in particular, the fact that it is the product of mass immigration mainly from Muslim countries, of which part of the population - not all, of course - is sensitive to the literal and bellicose interpretation of Qur'anic texts. Where did the Kouachi brothers, who were responsible for the Charlie Hebdo editorial killings in Paris, come from? Where did the Coulibalys, respectively responsible for murders in a kosher grocery store and an attempted assassination of Nice police officers, come from? How did they become French? What had they done to justify their presence on the national territory? In what capacity had they been admitted? Who had provided for their maintenance? These are questions that the French government does not ask, because they would lead to a review of the substantive issues. This is also the great shortcoming of the resolution that has just been adopted.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: Mr President, honourable Members, I voted in favour of this resolution because Islamic terrorism poses perhaps the most serious threat to Western civilization in the last century. What is happening along Europe's southern borders, the uncontrolled infestation of illegal migrants, the inability to protect countries' borders are actually the way terrorism enters our territory.  An effective system of interaction between the intelligence organisations of European countries must therefore be established, so the military operation to destroy Islamic terrorism must be expanded and developed where it currently draws its forces - in Iraq, in Syria, in Nigeria, along the entire north coast of the African continent. Because, again, the greatest threat to our civilization, our values, our way of life right now is armed Islamic terrorism, headed by Al Qaeda, Islamic State, Boko Haram and other Islamist organizations.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because the text includes an absolute condemnation of terrorism, a phenomenon which admits no justification, as well as new measures to prosecute and punish terrorist crimes. It also includes measures to strengthen the existing legislative framework for combating terrorism to adapt it to new realities from proportionality and necessity, and always from respect for public freedoms and fundamental rights governing the rule of law.  The resolution calls for greater cooperation between European judicial and police authorities in the fight against terrorism. It is a very strong resolution on prevention, which addresses the root causes of terrorism by proposing measures in the socio-educational field and in the field of 'deradicalization' and the promotion of a culture of tolerance in Europe. The resolution strikes the right balance between the security dimension and respect for freedoms. This weighting is an act of political responsibility that is demanded in the face of a matter as serious as terrorism. The resolution has valued the unity of democrats to defeat terrorism in the face of the threat it poses today to our security, our freedoms, and our model of coexistence.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. " We strongly condemn the terrorist acts perpetrated in France against Charlie Hebdo's workers. We condemn all terrorist acts that occur in many countries. And we do not leave out this condemnation—as most of this house does—state terrorism practiced by countries like Israel against Palestine, practiced in Syria, Lebanon, or the use of drones by the United States against populations in Africa or the Middle East. Defending the need to take action against the financing of terrorism while maintaining privileged relations with countries such as Saudi Arabia that finance, train and support terrorist groups is one more of the contradictions and another sign of the most right-wing hypocrisy in this chamber. That's why I voted against it. The fight against terrorism requires that the root causes of terrorism be attacked; requires profound policy change and respect for international law. And in no way can it legitimize the repressive wave and violation of the rights and freedoms contained in this resolution.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — (SV) Today we voted against the joint resolution on counter-terrorism tabled by the four major political groups in Parliament. The Green Group has tabled its own resolution on measures against terrorism, which we voted in favour of.  While we are in favour of coordinated action against terrorism, we believe that the joint resolution is ineffective. The proposed mass surveillance produces few known positive results. The proposals ignore longer-term preventive measures and neglect fundamental rights. In order to be effective, an anti-terrorism strategy should focus on targeted surveillance of suspects and ensure that authorities have the necessary means and resources and focus on specific risks and concrete suspicions. Better exchange of information between these authorities is also needed. Radicalisation in schools and prisons must be tackled.  The joint resolution is therefore merely a policy of symbolism which gives the impression that we are giving firm answers to the legitimate demands of citizens to feel safe and secure.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — As the recent attacks in Paris and the horrific death of attacks in Belgium have shown, terrorism knows no borders. Only a pan-European response is capable of addressing the problem. The European Parliament's resolution to implement a concrete package of anti-terrorist measures at European level in the short term is extremely commendable. The aim is both to take preventive steps (combating radicalisation) and to improve existing anti-terrorist instruments, such as EU-wide Passenger Data Retention (PNR).

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — Faced with the growing danger of terrorism in Europe, whether imported, financed from the outside or developing more or less autonomously on the territory of the Member States, I share the European Parliament's desire to deal with the problem. Unfortunately, the suggested measures do not live up to the problem, such as data exchange, which is too timid a solution. The real measures to combat terrorism are not even mentioned, including the recovery of their sovereignty by States over the control of their borders in order to control the flows that pass through them and the assessment of the financial participation of certain non-European powers in the development of international terrorism in Europe. So I decided to abstain.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I would like to place on record that I support the EFDD amendments which are well-thought out. I cannot, however, support the whole text. I also supported the Green proposal to protect encryption because of the consequences for secure banking. However, I voted against the overall report because this should be the preserve of Member States.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this deliberation because the measures passed make it possible to strengthen the security of citizens staying in the European Union.

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — Together with the Greens/EFA Group, I voted today against the Joint Motion for a Resolution on Anti-terrorism Measures, as the resolution is sending the wrong message at the wrong time. The resolution agreed by the big four political groups provides a carte blanche for EU governments to scale-back personal freedoms with measures that will fail to properly respond to the terrorist threat.  Instead of pushing for effective measures, the usual suspects who have been continually pushing for mass surveillance and data retention are using the Paris attacks as an excuse to bulldoze through these measures, despite any evidence that they will prove effective in countering the terrorist threat. A coherent counter-terrorism strategy would focus on targeted surveillance of real suspects and ensuring security authorities have the means and resources to focus on specific risks and concrete suspicions, to follow any leads immediately, and to efficiently exchange information about dangerous individuals. This is what we should be trying to achieve. There is also a need to tackle radicalisation in schools and prisons. Finally we are missing a call for a legal definition of profiling. Stepping up mass surveillance will undermine security and is instead a victory for fundamentalists, who are combatting precisely such democratic freedoms.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it offers a comprehensive approach to counter-terrorism policy by addressing both: ways to tackle the root causes of terrorist behaviour and other preventive measures to counter radicalisation. I believe that not only atrocities committed in Paris but all the acts of terrorism and glorification of such acts should be decried in the strongest terms and an appropriate preventive mechanism for dealing with this phenomenon should be implemented. Subject to this, I agree with this resolution by being strongly convinced that freedom and security dimensions are closely interrelated and co-dependent and, hence, there has to be a balance between the two. This means that failing to secure one has detrimental repercussions on the other. In addition, I support the reasoning expressed in the resolution that the European institutions need to invest more in combating the root causes of terrorism and in order to be prepared for counter-terrorism actions at all times. Moreover, as stressed in the text, I agree that it is very important to demand democratic oversight of these efforts to ensure that protection of personal liberty, which is one of the core human rights, is not undermined.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because the text includes an absolute condemnation of terrorism, a phenomenon which admits no justification, as well as new measures to prosecute and punish terrorist crimes. It also includes measures to strengthen the existing legislative framework for combating terrorism to adapt it to new realities from proportionality and necessity, and always from respect for public freedoms and fundamental rights governing the rule of law.  The resolution calls for greater cooperation between European judicial and police authorities in the fight against terrorism. It is a very strong resolution on prevention, which addresses the root causes of terrorism by proposing measures in the socio-educational field and in the field of 'deradicalization' and the promotion of a culture of tolerance in Europe. The resolution strikes the right balance between the security dimension and respect for freedoms. This weighting is an act of political responsibility that is demanded in the face of a matter as serious as terrorism. The resolution has valued the unity of democrats to defeat terrorism in the face of the threat it poses today to our security, our freedoms, and our model of coexistence.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to set measures against terrorism. I support the calls on the Member States to improve the exchange of information needed to combat terrorism, both among themselves and with third countries, to ensure full cooperation with specialised agencies, in particular Eurojust and Europol. I believe that the fight against illicit arms trafficking should be a priority area for the EU in the fight against serious organised international crime, and I support the calls for the proper implementation of the Anti-Money Laundering Directives. It is essential to create a European Passenger Name Record (EOC). (PNR), to ensure the prevention of radicalisation, the improvement of information exchange and the strengthening of the protection of the external Schengen borders.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — As the European Union continues its negotiations with Turkey, which lets the jihadists come and go, while the Libyan authorities, what is left, alert us to the risk of jihadist infiltration among illegal immigrants, the only concrete measure proposed by the Eurobeats is to follow the Anglo-Saxon model and to track airline passengers. However, all intelligence experts tell us that our security services do not currently have the means to monitor the thousands of suspects already spotted on our soil. Therefore, I could not condone the irresponsible blindness of these measures.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. "I supported the motion for a resolution because it develops a comprehensive approach to counter-terrorism. It condemns before and categorically any terrorist act and underlines the serious attack on our democratic values and freedoms. It also stresses the need to address the roots of terrorism and radicalisation, particularly in terms of policies promoting social inclusion. It then calls for closer collaboration within the Union, particularly in the area of intelligence, so that the effectiveness of the current tools (SIS, APIS, Europol, Eurojust, CEPOL, etc.) can be strengthened. In general, it stresses the importance of the exchange of information between the police and judicial authorities of the Union, in accordance, of course, with European law and national rights. It also reiterates the need to effectively combat arms trafficking and to properly implement anti-money laundering directives to enable the elimination of an important source of funding for terrorist networks. Finally, it reiterates the need to develop an adequate foreign policy in order to strengthen links with useful partners in the fight against terrorism, to put an end to the financing of terrorism and to prevent radicalisation.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. It is essential that we now quickly reach agreement on a European PNR system. It is indeed an effective tool in the fight against terrorism and against serious crime; we need it to increase the security of European citizens, of all of us. But, of course, we also need to step up the action by other means. Tackling the onerous radicalisation, by focusing in particular on prevention and dialogue. In many cities, including in my own country, the extremely valuable projects of outreach have been severely cut in recent years. We shouldn't have done that. It is clear that in many cases we will only be able to restore trust and dialogue along this path and that we will have to do much more on it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this joint resolution which strongly condemns the recent attacks in Paris. We need to find coordinated European mechanisms to combat terrorism but without forgetting the importance of individual rights for people acquired within the Union.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Your proposals to fight terrorism at European level seem to be just a new artifice with "measures" in order to look good after the tragic events that have affected France. After the debates we had in the last plenary, I can only make a sad observation of powerlessness in the face of terrorism, which is the result of years of laxity on the part of the Union and the governments of most Member States. That is why I have drafted and tabled with colleagues a proposal for a European resolution on the immediate suspension of the Schengen agreements, in accordance with Article 2, paragraph 2, with the aim of re-establishing border control and preventing the terrorist threat. In addition, we call on the Commission to draw up a list of passenger record data (PNR) and to add a list of passengers prohibited from flying. Finally, it is high time to stop deluding ourselves and the Union must also and above all stop all negotiations on the accession of new countries to the Union, such as Turkey or the Balkan countries. I did abstain on this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) The resolution we are voting on offers good ideas, but in many parts it remains ineffective and i do not agree with it. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. — (SV) I voted against the resolution. The overall reason for this is the resolution's unequivocal focus on repressive and police action. I would like us to evaluate the instruments available in the EU today before new laws and measures are proposed. I do not want the attacks in Paris to be the EU's equivalent of 9/11. America's 15-year war on terrorism has demonstrably been a total failure.  The resolution calls for several measures that are put at the expense of privacy and democratic freedoms in the EU, and which, above all, do not represent any real solutions. These proposals include EU-PNR.  The resolution lacks a deeper understanding of how to counter radicalisation in our societies and does not take into account at all how segregation, exclusion and widening of divides, and Islamophobia create breeding grounds. In addition, the resolution lacks criticism of the failed foreign policy of the EU and the Member States.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because the text includes an absolute condemnation of terrorism, a phenomenon which admits no justification, as well as new measures to prosecute and punish terrorist crimes. It also includes measures to strengthen the existing legislative framework for combating terrorism to adapt it to new realities from proportionality and necessity, and always from respect for public freedoms and fundamental rights governing the rule of law.  The resolution calls for greater cooperation between European judicial and police authorities in the fight against terrorism. It is a very strong resolution on prevention, which addresses the root causes of terrorism by proposing measures in the socio-educational field and in the field of 'deradicalization' and the promotion of a culture of tolerance in Europe. The resolution strikes the right balance between the security dimension and respect for freedoms. This weighting is an act of political responsibility that is demanded in the face of a matter as serious as terrorism. The resolution has valued the unity of democrats to defeat terrorism in the face of the threat it poses today to our security, our freedoms, and our model of coexistence.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it is in favour of Parliament's counter-terrorism measures, especially in the wake of the recent tragic events in Paris. In its resolution, Parliament stresses that prevention strategies to combat terrorism should be comprehensive in order to combat directly the preparation of attacks on EU territory, and should also include the need to respond to the causes of terrorism. The fight against terrorism must aim at combating consistently factors such as radicalisation, which lead to violent extremism, the development of social cohesion and inclusion, political and religious tolerance, the avoidance of ghettoisation, the online incitement to terrorist attacks and the prevention of terrorist attacks, and the prevention of departures in order to join terrorist organisations, the exclusion of recruitment and the restriction of these activities , hinder the provision of financial assistance to terrorist organisations and individuals, ensure, where appropriate, strict prosecution and provide law enforcement authorities with appropriate means to enable them to carry out their duties with full respect for fundamental rights. Another very important element in the fight against the terrorist threat, which Parliament stresses, is education, and Parliament therefore calls on the Member States to invest in education systems to respond to the causes of radicalisation and to promote integration, social inclusion, dialogue, participation, equality, tolerance, intercultural understanding and rehabilitation programmes through education programmes.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. — I express my support for the joint resolution of the five political groups, as it represents, in my view, the right balance between measures to increase the security of Europeans and to preserve the fundamental rights and freedoms without which a united Europe can no longer be imagined. The resolution stresses the need for greater exchange of information between EU Member States and between EU security institutions and calls for more consistent application of rules on the control of organised crime.  As a very important chapter of the resolution, I see the chapter on confronting the causes of terrorism, which places emphasis on promoting social cohesion, dialogue and the widest possible involvement of all social groups.  Because we have to face the original problem, that is, the reasons for the increase in all kinds of extremism that have been occurring in Europe in recent years. Of course, attention must be drawn against the various extremist groups that threaten the security of Europeans, but we must not take disproportionate measures for the sake of problem solving. I see that reducing the causes of various extremism would be achieved primarily through good work, new jobs and good cooperation between people in Europe. People, especially young people, should be given the opportunity to work and develop, and thus hope for a better future. This will also mean reducing the threat of terrorism. At the same time, by eliminating the causes of extremism, we will also eliminate their consequences, that is, horrific acts of terrorism.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on counter-terrorism measures, in which Parliament strongly condemned the recent terrorist acts in Paris and called on the European Union to step up the fight against all forms of radicalisation and violent extremism. On the one hand, by making more efficient use of the platforms, databases and alert systems that already exist at European level, while respecting free movement in the Schengen air and through a clear and common definition with regard to the so-called 'foreign fighters' and, on the other hand, using a renewed European strategy that cooperates closely with the third countries most involved , reviewing the European Neighbourhood Policy, and promoting compliance with international human rights standards by all regional actors, including through the European External Action Service (EEAS). The important spirit of unity that has manifested itself between governments and in the squares of European cities in January must be followed by measures and initiatives that will help to strengthen the sense of security of European citizens.

name: Mario Borghezio (NI)
text: in writing. — Late, ineffective, inconclusive, obvious and terrible. This is Europe in the face of terrorism. It proposes measures dictated by the pathos of the moment (as after the events in Paris), but which are soon forgotten, if not even applied or even archived. Combating the illegal immigration that the EU pretends not to see and which brings with it, as well as desperate, potential warriors of Allah. Re-establish bilateral agreements with the countries from which illegal immigrants leave. Suspending Schengen: Europe's borders, not only external borders but also internal borders, are colanders, it goes from people to weapons, without the slightest control. These are just a few concrete prevention measures for terrorism.  But this cowardly Europe, rather than reacting, prefers to deal with human rights and ignore the danger of Islamic terrorism.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — Terrorism and violent extremism are among the main threats to our security and our freedoms, as demonstrated by the recent terrorist attacks in France. Although Croatia has thankfully not faced terrorist attacks for a long time, we must show solidarity with the countries that have. No one wants to hear it now, but I believe we must not give in to pressure and significantly limit fundamental civil liberties in Europe in the name of counterterrorism.  I would like to tell those advocating the re-erecting of borders between EU countries to show terrorists that they have won. At the same time, I call on all Member States to prevent the movement of suspected terrorists by strengthening controls at external borders, more systematic and effective checks on travel documents, combating illicit arms trafficking and illegal use of someone else's identity, and identifying risk areas.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. Threats against our continent are growing. Our people and our values are at risk in the face of terrorism. Some European nationals are beheaded in conflict zones and are imported into Europe. These events are one of the consequences of the unconsciousness of our rulers in the management of migratory flows. We have left the doors of Europe wide open. We are paying the price today. The asylum system can, as a result, pose many problems. Thus jihadists can infiltrate via, among other things, Lampedusa. The restoration of the Union's internal borders would strengthen controls in order to effectively protect the population from this terror. I abstained on this resolution, which barely poses the problems, and does not propose the necessary solutions given these events.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because in this particular emergency situation Europe is exposed to numerous security threats. Therefore new anti-terrorism measures are fundamental for our security.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — I voted against. The resolution reiterates that freedom of movement is not affected and merely calls for greater police cooperation to combat terrorism. Weak, useless and negative.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. — Security is one of the rights guaranteed by the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. The Union is facing an ever-evolving terrorist threat which, over the past decade, has hit a number of Member States hard, in attacks that have targeted both human beings and the values and freedoms on which the Union is founded. It is estimated that 3,500 to 5,000 EU citizens have left their homes to become foreign fighters with the outbreak of war and violence in Syria, Iraq and Libya. In order to strengthen the security of our citizens, to defend the fundamental values of freedom, democracy and human rights, to respect international law, I support the need for a multidimensional approach to preventing and combating terrorism, as terrorism is a global threat that must be addressed at local, national, European and global level. I also support measures to combat the root causes of terrorism and radicalisation that lead to acts of violent extremism, the implementation and revision of existing law enforcement measures, the EU's internal security and eu law enforcement capabilities, such as the adoption of an external EU strategy to combat international terrorism.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour because the text includes an absolute condemnation of terrorism, a phenomenon which admits no justification, as well as new measures to prosecute and punish terrorist crimes. It also includes measures to strengthen the existing legislative framework for combating terrorism to adapt it to new realities from proportionality and necessity, and always from respect for public freedoms and fundamental rights governing the rule of law.  The resolution calls for greater cooperation between European judicial and police authorities in the fight against terrorism. It is a very strong resolution on prevention, which addresses the root causes of terrorism by proposing measures in the socio-educational field and in the field of 'deradicalization' and the promotion of a culture of tolerance in Europe. The resolution strikes the right balance between the security dimension and respect for freedoms. This weighting is an act of political responsibility that is demanded in the face of a matter as serious as terrorism. The resolution has valued the unity of democrats to defeat terrorism in the face of the threat it poses today to our security, our freedoms, and our model of coexistence.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Paris attacks have reignited the debate on adequate European measures to combat terrorism. The resolution adopted by the European Parliament proposes certain preventive measures and cooperation between Member States. It was important for Parliament to speak with one voice on such an important issue - and regrettable that the Greens and the far left did not understand it. However, this text does not offer a real and immediate solution, when the situation requires it. However, the measures proposed by the EPP were concrete: judicial and police cooperation, strengthening control at external borders and rapid adoption of a European NRP. We must find European solutions to fight terrorism. One of these solutions is the establishment of a European NRP. I find it a pity that, out of pure dogmatism, the Socialists and the Liberals remain opposed to a European NRL which is nevertheless necessary. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on counter-terrorism measures. Indeed, the attack in Paris has shown that it is becoming increasingly important for the European Union to have a common security policy. With the resolution adopted today, the European Parliament, in addition to expressing its condolences to the victims of the recent terrorist attacks in Paris, stressed that the fight against terrorism represents a global challenge and that the European Union, together with the other main regional actors and partners, should play a leading role in dealing with this threat at world level.  Member States must therefore increase the volume of information exchange relevant to the fight against terrorism through the effective use of Union databases and through full cooperation with specialised agencies, in particular Eurojust and Europol, with the aim of providing the best possible support for ongoing investigations into terrorist attacks in Europe.  At the same time, new economic and social policies must be promoted that can mitigate social exclusion and segregation, which give rise to resentments that are often exploited by violent extremists.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) We reiterate the need for greater information coordination between security services at European level, particularly in relation to terrorist organisations. The Paris bombers were known to law enforcement, and the failure to share essential information facilitated the cell's operations responsible for the attacks on the editorial staff of "Charlie Hebdo." However, our belief remains that the problem of so-called 'foreign fighters' is strongly linked to marginalisation and discrimination in the poorest neighbourhoods of our metropolises, which are in danger of becoming real incubators for terrorist movements. For this reason, the best and most effective counter-terrorism measure is the development of programmes that increase social inclusion.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted for this motion for a resolution because the preventive measures it is taking to stem the tide of radicalisation that we are experiencing and above all the European responses it gives to close the loopholes in the existing legislation of our Member States are appropriate. It is necessary to optimise the Schengen rules, because only better police and judicial cooperation between Member States will effectively guarantee freedom of movement at European level. This must be resolved: the fight against cross-border crime requires a stricter use of border controls.  With this in mind, the European NRL should no longer be an option but an obvious one. We must make sacrifices and strike a balance between civil liberties and security, there is no question that strengthening intelligence sharing is about strengthening the security of our countries. However, one point is missing in this resolution, which I regret is the creation of a European public prosecutor's office which is self-imposed. Europol can't take it all. Today the alleged culprits are arrested, but it is very difficult to try them, for reasons of national jurisdiction I therefore call for the establishment of this European prosecutor.

name: Bodil Ceballos (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — (SV) Today we voted against the joint resolution on counter-terrorism tabled by the four major political groups in Parliament. The Green Group has tabled its own resolution on measures against terrorism, which we voted in favour of.  While we are in favour of coordinated action against terrorism, we believe that the joint resolution is ineffective. The proposed mass surveillance produces few known positive results. The proposals ignore longer-term preventive measures and neglect fundamental rights. In order to be effective, an anti-terrorism strategy should focus on targeted surveillance of suspects and ensure that authorities have the necessary means and resources and focus on specific risks and concrete suspicions. Better exchange of information between these authorities is also needed. Radicalisation in schools and prisons must be tackled.  The joint resolution is therefore merely a policy of symbolism which gives the impression that we are giving firm answers to the legitimate demands of citizens to feel safe and secure.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. — The urgency was indeed to adopt a text on the measures to be taken to combat terrorism.  I would, however, like to underline the imperfection of this text: we are thus falling into 'social terrorism', worrying about the rise of fundamentalism on the one hand, but reaffirming the merits of Schengen on the other. MEPs say they are "fundamentally opposed to proposals to suspend the Schengen regime".  Moreover, the proposed measures are more a matter of angelism than a pragmatic analysis of reality: thus, if potential jihadists are radicalized, it is because society stigmatizes them. Yet, despite these imperfections, we must support everything in the direction of the war on terror; that is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. — An EU PNR scheme can be useful but it must be very clear in its scope and purpose and meet stringent data protection standards. When collecting passenger name records, we must be very careful to safeguard the protection of our citizens’ fundamental rights.  The Commission has so far failed to present us with a satisfactory explanation of how these records can be used to detect and prevent terrorism and serious cross-border crime, and of how it will ensure that they will be used for these purposes only. We must also keep in mind that we will be processing wholesale information pertaining to absolutely everyone who flies into Europe, an overwhelming majority of whom are innocent people whose privacy rights must be taken into consideration.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that terrorism must be combated in every way and by all means because, by undermining the security of each of us, it undermines our ability to live our lives freely. I therefore believe that we need an overall approach to the fight against radicalisation and terrorism, aimed at strengthening social cohesion, crime prevention and police operations. The serious terrorist acts that have taken place on EU territory since the attacks of 11 September have had a huge impact on the sense of security among EU citizens, and so I believe that combating the trafficking of firearms must be a priority for us. In particular, cooperation on mechanisms for the exchange of information needs to be further strengthened.  Finally, I would like to express my condolences to the victims of the recent terrorist attacks in Paris and throughout the world, as well as to their families.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — We welcome this show of unity. Today, MEPs hailing from almost all political colours showed unity in their abhorrence of terror and barbarity and showed that they are ready to prevent it. We should keep this unity alive. We should no longer allow terrorism to divide us. Terrorists would win if we are divided. The time to act is now.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support this resolution on terrorism which I vote for. I think it is very important that Parliament has a common position shared by various politicians which reflects our commitment to combating terrorism and protecting its victims. We cannot give in to the pressure of the moment or agree to simplistic and demagogic speeches such as those linking immigration to terrorism and call into question Schengen. This resolution includes a comprehensive view of terrorism. It recognises, on the one hand, the need for further measures, without prejudice to the assessment and optimal use of the instruments already in operation. On the other hand, and not least, it also does not question the freedoms and guarantees of European citizens in the name of alleged security.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on counter-terrorism measures for a number of reasons. In fact, given that competence in the field of European security policy is shared between Europe and the Member States, security measures aimed at safeguarding civil society must necessarily be implemented, on the one hand because the way in which terrorist activity is carried out has changed, having become increasingly important autonomous cells at the expense of a centralised organisation, and, on the other hand, because the way in which terrorist activity is carried out has changed. , since the modus operandi of terrorist attacks has essentially militarised.  The priority in prevention work must be to resolve the problem of 'foreign fighters', i.e. individuals moving to a state other than the state in which they reside or of which they are nationals, in order to plan or prepare a terrorist attack, or in order to provide or receive training always of a terrorist nature. The Member States and Europe should commit themselves to taking all necessary measures, in order to protect European citizens from the terrorist threat and to step up their activity to prevent radicalisation by engaging in dialogue with communities, especially Muslim communities, and with civil society.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — Radicalisation is that which strikes at the heart of European democracy by inciting hatred and violence against citizens, groups, authorities and establishments representing that European democracy which is built on diversity and based on values of respect for human dignity and personal fulfilment in society. Radical propaganda fostering hatred and violence exists within the European Union as well as outside the Union. Radical propaganda does not distinguish between traditional and modern media but is found in speech, in writing as well as on the internet, and often finds opportunity for action through disaffected persons. An EU action plan against radicalisation is a pressing need. Such an action plan is to address different spheres in which radicalisation is known to occur including prisons.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — To create deradicalisation, to strengthen controls at the external borders of the Schengen area, to tighten up the existing rules and to improve the exchange of information between Member States and with European agencies such as Europol and Eurojust. I voted in favour of the resolution adopted during the February plenary session in Strasbourg, in order to protect the EU from terrorist attacks. In order to counter the growing threat from foreign fighters from EU Member States, the House called on Member States to invest in social and educational programmes that tackle the root causes of radicalisation, to oppose online incitement to carry out terrorist acts to prevent recruitment, and to dismantle financial support for terrorist organisations and the trafficking of firearms. MePs also committed themselves to finalising the EU Passenger Name Record Sharing System Directive by the end of the year to ensure that measures to combat terrorism do not undermine citizens' fundamental rights. It should be added that the fight against terrorism must respect the privacy of all European citizens.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. " We strongly condemn the terrorist acts perpetrated in France against Charlie Hebdo's workers. We condemn all terrorist acts that occur in many countries. And we do not leave out this condemnation—as most of this house does—state terrorism practiced by countries like Israel against Palestine, practiced in Syria, Lebanon, or the use of drones by the United States against populations in Africa or the Middle East. Defending the need to take action against the financing of terrorism while maintaining privileged relations with countries such as Saudi Arabia that finance, train and support terrorist groups is one more of the contradictions and another sign of the most right-wing hypocrisy in this chamber. That's why I voted against it. The fight against terrorism requires that the root causes of terrorism be attacked; requires profound policy change and respect for international law. And in no way can it legitimize the repressive wave and violation of the rights and freedoms contained in this resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which strongly condemns the recent Paris attacks and all other acts of terrorism as criminal and unjustifiable, regardless of their motivations. This resolution also asks for a balanced approach to security, including an evaluation of existing measures and their revision if needed. It stresses that, alongside any new security measures, there must also be progress on the reform of the data protection package, which has been blocked by EU Member States for several years. This resolution calls for both the strengthening of our anti-terrorism efforts but also for the preservation of our civic freedoms.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) The fight against international terrorism is one of the European Union's priorities, a global challenge to which Europe can respond effectively only in a united manner.  We have recently seen an escalation of the threat: terrorism can now be linked to any objective, ideology and fundamentalism. It can bind itself to a territory and form the armed arm of national liberation movements, or it can have the characteristics of a transnational terrorist network. Its power has increased due to different conditions, not least the willingness of terrorists to commit suicide and technological progress.  That is why, together with other colleagues, I have proposed the joint resolution on counter-terrorism measures, because cooperation with third countries considered to be priorities (North Africa, the Middle East and South-East Asia) and good management of public policy, through cooperation programmes, assistance and intercultural dialogue, are vital. It is not a question of waged war against an invisible enemy, which cannot be defeated by military means, but of adopting coherent lines of action which connect various policies and which are capable of leading a long-term strategy. It is only by undermining the reasons why prolific terrorism can be thought of eradicating extremism in the long term.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. — I believe that an essential dimension of the fight against terrorism must be the development of policies aimed at protecting and supporting victims and their families, and that is why I believe that all Member States must properly implement the rules on the rights, support and protection of victims of crime, thereby supporting the fundamental right of citizens to security and freedom.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This resolution calls on the European Union to immediately respond to the terrorist threats it faces. The European Union must promote cooperation between Member States by allowing the adoption of a harmonised definition of the phenomenon of 'foreign fighters', by intensifying prevention and the fight against radicalisation, particularly in prison, and by supporting deradicalisation programmes. It must also strengthen the tools available by making more effective use of the Schengen information system, the possibilities for control at the EU's external borders and the capabilities of europol and Eurojust agencies. Finally, the Union must develop a legislative arsenal that respects the freedoms and rights of European citizens, but effectively, with a quick agreement on the PNR Directive and the creation of a European system for monitoring the financing of terrorism. Considering that this resolution respects a balance between the necessary data protection objective and the security imperative of European citizens, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. While this joint resolution contains some interesting proposals, I regret that we have not reached a satisfactory agreement on the issue of the European NRNP. I thereby reject the strict link between the progress of the negotiations on the European NRL and that of the negotiations on the data protection package. While it is essential for the European Union to have a clear legislative framework to guarantee the fundamental right to the protection of personal data, the slowness of its negotiation should not be used as an argument to hinder the urgent adoption of a tool essential to the fight against terrorism in Europe. Strengthening security and protecting fundamental rights are not incompatible. Let us cease to take the safety of European citizens hostage.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — By adopting by a very large majority its resolution on counter-terrorism measures, the European Parliament has demonstrated Europe's capacity to act. The answer must be a firm response within the natural framework of our rule of law. The aim is to put in place a comprehensive strategy to combat radicalisation and terrorism by optimising existing legal frameworks, including the fight against money laundering, the European Arrest Warrant, the establishment of systematic control at the external borders of Schengen, but also to go further by setting up a European NNP, strengthening the powers of Europol and Eurojust , by creating a European prosecutor and monitoring exchanges and networks on the internet.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. — The Greens/FTA group voted against the resolution on counter-terrorism measures. Adopted by four political groups, including socialists and liberals, it promotes a measure that seriously undermines freedoms without responding to the terrorist threat. Effective measures, they prefer mass surveillance and retention of personal data. We refuse to "take advantage" of the Paris attacks, as stated by a member of the UMP (EPP) to promote the famous European PNR. A measure whose effectiveness has yet to be proven. In pronouncing its adoption, the EP advocates widespread surveillance that will not prevent terrorist acts but will lead to fragile democracies.  The NRP is not just an attack on freedoms. It is also a choice of society. That of spending 500 million euros on mass surveillance when they would be more useful in financing targeted surveillance of real suspects, field work, cooperation between police and intelligence services of Member States, including joint investigative teams under the authority of Europol and Eurojust. $500 million worth of money to prevent radicalization, fight unemployment and exclusion, reform prison, build a society of inclusion, our strength against the murderous madness of terrorists.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — The terrorist attacks on the territory of the Union over the past ten years have highlighted a series of gaps and loopholes that need to be addressed in order to improve the prevention of future terrorist attacks. More than ever, the European Union must ensure the safety of all, while guaranteeing the rights and freedoms that form the founding principles of the European project.  I therefore voted in favour of the resolution on counter-terrorism measures, which sets out a series of actions to improve the Union's effectiveness in this area, while respecting this balance. I also supported the adoption of an amendment calling for every effort to finalise the EU's PNR directive by the end of the year.  However, I remain convinced that other measures must also be implemented at short notice: the strengthening of controls at Schengen's external borders, including for EU citizens, increased resources allocated to Europol to combat terrorism and in particular against Islamist propaganda on the internet, and the compulsory exchange of information on jihadists between Member States.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. — Coming from a constituency blighted for so long by organised criminality led by Republican terrorist gangs, I recognise the clear need to combat those involved in this activity to protect our community and economy. However, I also believe that it should not be the primary role of the European Union to do so. National crime-fighting authorities should be the leading power in tracking down and breaking up these crime rings – not EU quangos such as a European Public Prosecutor’s Office. And I hope all Members present will join with me in welcoming the full extension of the UK National Crime Agency to Northern Ireland. This is a huge step forward in the fight against organised crime, and is testament to the fact that no political faction caught up with self-interest should be able to prevent a full fight against fuel and money laundering, as well as illicit trade.  It is somewhat ironic that the Sinn Féin MEP for Northern Ireland has criticised a top Israeli military official as having ‘blood on his hands’, ignoring her own terrorist past and her party’s failing in refusing to support the fight against organised crime through the NCA. I would call on Parliament not to follow this dangerous precedent.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — Faced with the growing danger of terrorism in Europe, whether imported, financed from the outside or developing more or less autonomously on the territory of the Member States, the European Parliament's willingness to take charge of the problem is commendable. However, the suggested measures do not live up to the problem, especially data exchange, which is too timid a solution. The real measures to combat terrorism are also not mentioned: the sovereignty of States over their borders, which allows them to control the flows that pass through them, and the assessment of the financial participation of certain non-European powers in the development of international terrorism in Europe. So I decided to abstain.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. — The Greens/FTA group voted against the resolution on counter-terrorism measures. Adopted by four political groups, including socialists and liberals, it promotes a measure that seriously undermines freedoms without responding to the terrorist threat.
