That of spending 500 million euros on mass surveillance when they would be more useful in financing targeted surveillance of real suspects, field work, cooperation between police and intelligence services of member states, including joint investigative teams under the authority of Europol and Eurojust. $500 million worth of money to prevent radicalization, fight unemployment and exclusion, reform prison, build a society of inclusion, our strength against the murderous madness of terrorists.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted against the resolution presented. The resolution has, in general terms, positive aspects, as it underlines the importance of prevention and respect for individual rights in the fight against terrorism. However, an amendment tabled at the last minute by the Socialist Group and the People's Group includes in the resolution the need to make urgent progress in the adoption of PNR (Passenger Name Record) legislation. This draft legislation should be subject, on the one hand, to the adoption of a data protection package, which we believe should be earlier, and, on the other hand, to the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the validity of the EU-Canada PNR agreement. We believe that including in this resolution the urgency of advancing the PNR contradicts many of the principles set out in the resolution itself, and does not go in the sense of ensuring the privacy and individual rights of European citizens. That is why we voted against the joint resolution.

name: Linnéa Engström (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — (SV) Today we voted against the joint resolution on counter-terrorism tabled by the four major political groups in Parliament. The Green Group has tabled its own resolution on measures against terrorism, which we voted in favour of.  While we are in favour of coordinated action against terrorism, we believe that the joint resolution is ineffective. The proposed mass surveillance produces few known positive results. The proposals ignore longer-term preventive measures and neglect fundamental rights. In order to be effective, an anti-terrorism strategy should focus on targeted surveillance of suspects and ensure that authorities have the necessary means and resources and focus on specific risks and concrete suspicions. Better exchange of information between these authorities is also needed. Radicalisation in schools and prisons must be tackled.  The joint resolution is therefore merely a policy of symbolism which gives the impression that we are making firm demands on the legitimate demands of citizens to feel safe and secure.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — We are voting against because we believe that these measures are not moving in the right direction.; On the contrary, while they introduce too many restrictions against the citizens of Europe, they do not really limit the perfectly real risk of terrorism. The Union has so far failed to monitor the Member States so as not to restrict the application of such measures exclusively to terrorist organisations.

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. - (SV) Today we voted against the joint resolution on counter-terrorism measures tabled by the four major political groups in parliament. The Green Group has tabled its own resolution on measures against terrorism, which we voted in favour of.  While we are in favour of coordinated action against terrorism, we believe that the joint resolution is ineffective. The proposed mass surveillance produces few known positive results. The proposals ignore longer-term preventive measures and neglect fundamental rights. In order to be effective, an anti-terrorism strategy should focus on targeted surveillance of suspects and ensure that authorities have the necessary means and resources and focus on specific risks and concrete suspicions. Better exchange of information between these authorities is also needed. Radicalisation in schools and prisons must be tackled.  The joint resolution is therefore merely a policy of symbolism which gives the impression that we are making firm demands on the legitimate demands of citizens to feel safe and secure.

name: Ismail Ertug (S&D)
text: Writing. — The resolution refers to the terrorist attacks in Paris, 11 September and fighters in Syria, Iraq and Libya. Implicitly, the image of the Muslim perpetrator is conveyed and hidden that Muslims are and can also be victims. On Tuesday, three University of North Carolina students - all three Muslims - were shot dead. Police are also investigating for "hate crime," but initially declined to give a motive. Why do crimes committed by Muslims find such a widespread perception in Europe, but not the crimes committed against Muslims? Cynically said, after the murders in Paris, there was a huge wave of solidarity under the slogan 'Je suis Charlie', but when Muslims are murdered, public sympathy in the EU is hard to hear. The debate in Europe has a dangerous void here: Muslims are always perceived as perpetrators, but never as victims. The European Parliament is called upon to hold a debate on how to counter this distorted perception. Because one thing must be clear: #muslimlivesmatter.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted against the joint motion on anti-terrorism measures, as this resolution is sending the wrong message at the wrong time. The resolution agreed by the other groups in the Parliament gives governments of EU Member States free rein to scale back personal freedoms and liberties with measures that do not properly respond to the terrorist threat. Ensuring our safety does not mean mass-surveillance and fewer rights. The safety of my constituents in Wales is of the highest importance to me, and I want an effective strategy that includes giving priority to tackling the causes of terrorism.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The response of the international community to terrorism must be based on respect for international law, human rights and international humanitarian law. The threat to peace and security that they cause must not, therefore, lead to political exploitation that leads us to call into question invaluable results such as freedom of movement. Such a large mobilisation of foreign terrorist fighters towards conflict zones is a new and destabilising phenomenon. In my opinion, we need strategies that aim to identify the cultural and sociological context in which fighters move and which, as a result, make it possible to combat recruitment and radicalisation. It is my firm belief that civil society organisations, supported by state agencies, can play an essential role in formulating modular strategies that strengthen a multilateral and integrated approach to combating this phenomenon.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Violent terrorism, radicalisation and extremism are now major threats to international peace and security and pose important challenges to the stability of EU Member States to individual security and freedom. I voted in favour of the resolution in a strong condemnation of the tragic terrorist attacks in Paris and to underline the need for best practice sand the proper implementation of instruments to prevent and combat terrorism and radicalisation at local, national, European and global level.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. - With regard to new monitoring and control measures, such as pnr data, it is particularly important to be careful and protect privacy and fundamental civil rights. I voted in favour of this resolution because the text as a whole is balanced and contains clear wordings on the importance of proportionality and that any measures are properly investigated. However, I am sceptical about some of the proposals mentioned.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — Terrorism, radicalisation and violent extremism pose some of the greatest threats to our security and freedoms. Its combat must be based on a plural approach aimed at directly countering the preparation of attacks on the territory of the Union, but also integrating the need to address the root causes of terrorism.  The latest attack in Paris which I strongly condemn has had a significant impact on the sense of security among EU citizens and residents who are facing the serious and growing threat posed by so-called foreign fighters, i.e. individuals moving to a country other than their country of residence or nationality, to perpetrate or plan terrorist acts , give or receive terrorist training, including in the context of armed conflicts and which will be around 3500. Personally, I categorically consent to all terrorist acts, the promotion of terrorism, the glorification of individuals involved in terrorism and the defence of violent and extremist ideologies.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because the text includes an absolute condemnation of terrorism, a phenomenon which admits no justification, as well as new measures to prosecute and punish terrorist crimes. It also includes measures to strengthen the existing legislative framework for combating terrorism to adapt it to new realities from proportionality and necessity, and always from respect for public freedoms and fundamental rights governing the rule of law.  The resolution calls for greater cooperation between European judicial and police authorities in the fight against terrorism. It is a very strong resolution on prevention, which addresses the root causes of terrorism by proposing measures in the socio-educational field and in the field of 'deradicalization' and the promotion of a culture of tolerance in Europe. The resolution strikes the right balance between the security dimension and respect for freedoms. This weighting is an act of political responsibility that is demanded in the face of a matter as serious as terrorism. The resolution has valued the unity of democrats to defeat terrorism in the face of the threat it poses today to our security, our freedoms, and our model of coexistence.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) In recent decades we have seen a surge in regulatory production, both international and national, in the field of terrorism. As the European Parliament, we have a duty to participate in this nomopoietic process, which is necessary for a number of reasons.  Firstly, there is an escalation of the threat: terrorist action can now be linked to any possible objective, ideology and fundamentalism. It can bind itself indifferently to a territory or nation and form the arm armed with national liberation movements, or it can have the characteristics of a transnational terrorist network. The power of terrorist actions has also increased due to a number of conditions, not least the willingness of terrorists to commit suicide and technological progress. States have lost the "monopoly of threat": the challenge comes from individuals and networks that operate at the sub-state level and use materials and resources that are out of control - a national monopoly. It has therefore become difficult to identify which state is entitled to take action against terrorists. The connecting criteria for the exercise of jurisdiction have become evanescent, which tend to be reduced to one: that of the nationality of the victims.  For these reasons, together with an urgent demand for security, together with other colleagues, we have proposed this Joint Resolution on counter-terrorism measures.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. " We strongly condemn the terrorist acts that took place in France. We condemn all the attacks that have occurred in many countries of the world. In this condemnation, we do not leave out, as the majority of parliament does in this resolution, state terrorism practiced by countries such as Israel in Palestine, Syria and Lebanon, or the use of unmanned aircraft (drones) by the US against defenseless populations in Africa, the Middle East or Asia. While defending the need to take measures to combat terrorist financing and maintaining privileged relations with countries that, such as Turkey or Saudi Arabia, among others, finance, train and support terrorist groups, is a clear contradiction. The strong fight that must be fought against terrorism, inside or outside the EU, requires that the root causes of terrorism be attacked; calls for a profound change in policies, respect for international law and the UN Charter; and in no way can it legitimize the repressive and violating wave of rights, freedoms and guarantees that is defended in this resolution.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — The European Union must make the protection of the health and lives of citizens of the Member States one of its main priorities, especially in the wake of the terrorist attacks in Paris. When introducing any new rules, we must not forget the fundamental pillars of the European Union, which undoubtedly include fundamental human rights and freedoms. The European Union is thus unlikely to avoid changes and reform in the Schengen system or the completion of the Passenger Name Record Directive. However, in order for the measures to work at European level, member states themselves need to invest more in programmes to address the acute problem of population radicalisation. Member States and their responsible national authorities have provided Europol and Eurojust with only 50% of the information on terrorism and organised crime on their territory, which must be improved in the future if Europe wants to combat the threat of terrorism effectively.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) This resolution cannot be supported because it does not give political answers worthy of the name to the cause of the fight against terrorism.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting against measures against terrorism, because these measures are not moving in the right direction. On the contrary, while they are adopting too many restrictions against the citizens of Europe, they do not really limit the perfectly real risk of terrorism. The Union has also so far failed to monitor The Member States so as not to restrict the application of such measures exclusively to terrorist organisations.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. — We need joint action, we need a coherent response to terrorism. They must not be allowed to increr hatred, to increranate fear, to create division in our society. This includes countering radicalisation. There is concern and therefore the increasing use of the Internet to increment hatred and violence – the partnership of the largest internet service providers is essential. Addressing the causes of youth radicalisation is challenging.  The resolution now adopted includes the most important tasks: addressing the problem of so-called foreign fighters, combating radicalisation, strengthening cooperation and exchange of information between the competent Member State and international authorities. I also believe that security at the external borders should be strengthened, while respecting the maintenance of smooth border traffic. These steps should not jeopardise one of the most important elements of the ACQUIS, freedom of movement, the functioning of the Schengen system. The events in Paris have also confirmed the urgent need for Europe to provide police training to respond rapidly to these challenges, the CEPOL agency that can provide this.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. — The EU and its Member States have a duty to work together to ensure the safety and freedom of European citizens. However, the fight against terrorism must be based on the principles of necessity, proportionality and respect for fundamental rights. We must always have as a priority the preservation of free movement within the Schengen area, so the control of external borders must be one of our priorities. The evolution of international terrorism, as well as the dangers of foreign fighters (between 3,000 and 5,000 European citizens) fighting in Syria in the ranks of the terrorist and criminal organization ISIS must be taken very seriously for their extreme dangers. Terrorism is a global threat that requires a response based on a multidimensional approach that prioritizes the fight against terrorism and radicalization, and that supports social cohesion, reintegration and political and religious tolerance. Greater control of external borders is essential to prevent terrorists from moving and illicit arms trafficking.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) In these days when the priority is to re-establish the security of our citizens in practice, this resolution seeks to affirm the full support of the entire European Parliament for the implementation by the Council of essential instruments for the fight against terrorism such as the proposal concerning the Passenger Name Record (PNR), the improvement of the exchange of information, the strengthening of controls in areas outside the Schengen area. , as well as efforts in terms of preventing radicalisation. Of course, a fair balance between security and fundamental freedoms must be preserved. With this text, we have reached a good compromise in this respect, going beyond, in fact, some ideological positions that had slowed down many security issues in recent years.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the adoption of the anti-terrorism measures presented in the joint motion for a resolution. Europe, still hurt by the latest events of January 2015, calls on the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, the 2011 resolution on the counter-terrorism strategy and, above all, the new internal security strategy of the European Union, of 17 December 2014, to intervene with concrete and effective measures in the global challenge that is the fight against international terrorism, both with acts aimed at prevention and re-education and with control and punitive actions : greater sharing of data "at risk" between authorities and security agencies, stronger intelligence activity, traceability of weapons, greater attention in the granting of Golden Visa to prevent the rooting of criminal organizations, judicial cooperation between states, the inclusion of sanctions for the financing of terrorist organizations, criminal proceedings against racism and xenophobia.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I voted in favour of the resolution because it highlights one of the most important problems in the world today. Terrorism in all its forms and manifestations is one of the most serious threats to peace and security in the world, and the increase in racism further increases the sense of insecurity among EU citizens. A comprehensive approach to countering radicalisation and terrorism is therefore necessary.  In addition to their mutual cooperation, Member States should cooperate closely with specialised agencies (Eurojust, Europol, CEPOL) to this end, making full use of existing possibilities and available legal and judicial instruments. The common foreign policy should focus on cooperation with third countries, as these can become serious partners in counter-terrorism. External action to build counter-terrorism capabilities and radical propaganda spread online and in other media needs to be stepped up. The possibility of introducing sanctions against states and governments responsible for financing terrorists or terrorist organisations should also be seriously considered.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because recent events clearly indicate the need for a counter-terrorism roadmap which ensures a better use of existing instruments in full respect of citizens’ rights, which creates new instruments where necessary, and connects the dots between action on local, national, EU and international levels. I am deeply concerned by reports stating that, at a time in which increased coordination is desperately needed, British intelligence officials are threatening to stop sharing information with Berlin on jihadists returning from Syria and Iraq, amongst other issues, if Germany pushes ahead with a parliamentary inquiry into British intelligence activities in their country. Second, it is crucial that we fight the root-causes of radicalisation by adopting a preventive approach rather than a reactive one, which includes measures in the fields of education, inclusion and anti-discrimination. Third, we need to reflect thoroughly about our foreign policy and the regimes we have been tolerating. Events in Libya, Egypt and Syria have shown us that repression breeds terrorism rather than stability. Tackling terrorism both inside and outside Europe will require us to start learning lessons from past mistakes – rather than simply repeating them.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. Like the other Members of the National Front, I abstained on this motion for a resolution, as it seems inept: it claims to attack the roots of terrorism, but without naming Islamist fundamentalism as the main source of this scourge. It also proposes to retain the Schengen regime, while the absence of controls at the EU's internal borders greatly facilitates the movement of terrorists. This proposal does not bring anything concrete to the fight against terrorism: it confirms instead the refusal of the Europeanists to act.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted against the resolution presented. The resolution has, in general terms, positive aspects, as it underlines the importance of prevention and respect for individual rights in the fight against terrorism. However, an amendment tabled at the last minute by the Socialist Group and the People's Group includes in the resolution the need to make urgent progress in the adoption of PNR (Passenger Name Record) legislation. We believe that including in this resolution the urgency of advancing the PNR contradicts many of the principles set out in the resolution itself, and does not go in the sense of ensuring the privacy and individual rights of European citizens. That is why we voted against the joint resolution.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. — Improved existing tools, strengthening information exchanges between states, internal security, financing of terrorist organisations, Europol powers, police cooperation, judicial cooperation, coordination, relations with third countries, etc.: the resolution we adopted list of measures to be taken in the fight against terrorism, in the wake of the horrific Charlie Hebdo attacks. In the fight against terrorism, at the level of the European Union, there are two emergencies. Firstly, to improve the functioning of the arsenal of tools that the European Union already has in the fight against terrorism and, above all, to improve the exchange of information between Member States, which was so lacking in the attacks - Europol, Eurojust, SIS, etc. Secondly, to have new tools to fully respond to the threat: genuine strategies for radicalisation, prevention of radicalisation and de-radicalisation, a European NNP that respects the criteria of legality, necessity and proportionality and, above all, a genuine European prosecutor's office competent in the fight against organised crime and terrorism, which we have been calling for for several years; on this last point, I regret that some parliamentary groups refused to include it in the resolution.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as I believe that we need to send a clear message that we are committed to tackling terrorism by looking at every aspect that leads to radicalism; there needs to be a multilayer approach on tackling the root causes of radicalism. Labour MEPs call for better cooperation with agencies such as Europol and Eurojust and full use of existing measures such as the Radicalisation Awareness Network (RAN).

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. — On Wednesday, I voted in favour of measures to strengthen the fight against terrorism in Europe. Indeed, I consider that the threat posed by foreign fighters and terrorism in general requires the establishment of a firm and clear anti-terrorism pact. MEPs called on EU Member States to better combat radicalisation by investing in education programmes or setting up deradicalisation programmes. I also advocate strengthening our borders to ensure more security for our citizens. The rapid adoption of a European NRP also remains an absolute necessity in view of current European issues. This vote must appear to be the first step in strengthening our legislation to effectively combat terrorism. Furthermore, I would like to denounce the irresponsible attitude of the Greens and the extreme left, who did not wish to join this resolution, despite the urgency of the current situation!

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of absolutely condemning terrorism, as well as ensuring further measures to prosecute and punish terrorist crimes. In addition, the text adopted includes measures to strengthen the existing legislative framework for combating terrorism to adapt it to new realities from proportionality and necessity, and always from respect for public freedoms and fundamental rights governing the rule of law.  The resolution calls for greater cooperation between European judicial and police authorities in the fight against terrorism. It is a very strong resolution on prevention, which addresses the root causes of terrorism by proposing measures in the socio-educational field and in the field of 'deradicalization' and the promotion of a culture of tolerance in Europe. The resolution strikes the right balance between the security dimension and respect for freedoms. This weighting is an act of political responsibility that is demanded in the face of a matter as serious as terrorism. The resolution has valued the unity of democrats to defeat terrorism in the face of the threat it poses today to our security, our freedoms, and our model of coexistence.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the resolution on counter-terrorism measures. It is obviously the result of multiple compromises, but in the end, the result is generally satisfactory. This resolution stresses the essential balance that must prevail between security on the one hand and respect for fundamental freedoms and rights on the other. It also promotes a multidimensional approach, addressing both security and socio-economic issues. It clearly highlights the need to fully implement existing arrangements, but also to assess their strengths and weaknesses. Finally, it underlines the need for an external European strategy to combat terrorism. It does not ignore the issue of the European NRL: the European Parliament is committed to working towards the finalisation of the European PNR directive by the end of 2015 and therefore urges the European Commission to draw the consequences of the Court of Justice's judgment on the Data Conservation Directive as soon as possible. Finally, as demanded by the Group, the resolution urges the Council to unblock discussions on the Data Protection package.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because the text includes an absolute condemnation of terrorism, a phenomenon which admits no justification, as well as new measures to prosecute and punish terrorist crimes. It also includes measures to strengthen the existing legislative framework for combating terrorism to adapt it to new realities from proportionality and necessity, and always from respect for public freedoms and fundamental rights governing the rule of law.  The resolution calls for greater cooperation between European judicial and police authorities in the fight against terrorism. It is a very strong resolution on prevention, which addresses the root causes of terrorism by proposing measures in the socio-educational field and in the field of 'deradicalization' and the promotion of a culture of tolerance in Europe. The resolution strikes the right balance between the security dimension and respect for freedoms. This weighting is an act of political responsibility that is demanded in the face of a matter as serious as terrorism. The resolution has valued the unity of democrats to defeat terrorism in the face of the threat it poses today to our security, our freedoms, and our model of coexistence.

name: Eduard-Raul Hellvig (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support the resolution calling on the EU to promote an international partnership against terrorism and to cooperate with regional actors to counter the terrorist threat – from combating causes and preventing radicalisation, to annihilating sources of funding and training opportunities.  The anti-terrorism strategy must, in my opinion, be based on more intensive exchange of information and operational cooperation between national authorities, in order to stop the movement of terrorism suspects and illicit arms trafficking. Particular attention is needed to combat terrorist propaganda and online recruitment, which is why I support the request to internet operators and administrators of communication platforms to cooperate with the competent authorities, as terrorist organisations are increasingly using the internet for communication and attack planning.  I believe that the new roadmap that the European Parliament is asking the Commission and the Counter-Terrorism Council must set up a common European strategy to fight back to the terrorist threat. In this respect, it is urgently necessary to eliminate legislative and operational gaps that facilitate the flow of jihadist combatants. It is worrying that EU states transmit only 50% of information related to terrorism and organised crime to Eurojust and Europol. As a result, I support the creation of a European anti-terrorism platform within Europol.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. — In a resolution on the fight against terrorism, the European Parliament pledged to continue work on the European NNP with a view to finalising by the end of the year. A convoluted formula that demonstrates the reluctance of liberals and the left when it comes to taking appropriate action in the face of new threats of terrorism. In the wake of the terrorist attacks in France, citizens expressed a clear wish: not to bow to terrorists, not to compromise with European values.  The duty of MEPs is to respond with strong and concrete measures: the isolation of radical prisoners in prisons, the loss of nationality in the event of dual nationality, national indignity, the strengthening of the intelligence services' resources to improve the analysis of the data collected, and the strengthening of the cooperation of law enforcement and judicial services with European agencies. Unfortunately, this resolution relies heavily on the exchange of good practices, but offers nothing concrete. Once again, the European Parliament is missing an opportunity to act, with the EPP caught between populist parties that are reluctant to take any European action and left-wing parties terrified by the omniscient and intrusive state theory.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted against the resolution presented. The resolution has, in general terms, positive aspects, as it underlines the importance of prevention and respect for individual rights in the fight against terrorism. However, an amendment tabled at the last minute by the Socialist Group and the People's Group includes in the resolution the need to make urgent progress in the adoption of PNR (Passenger Name Record) legislation. This draft legislation should be subject, on the one hand, to the adoption of a data protection package, which we believe should be earlier, and, on the other hand, to the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the validity of the EU-Canada PNR agreement. We believe that including in this resolution the urgency of advancing the PNR contradicts many of the principles set out in the resolution itself, and does not go in the sense of ensuring the privacy and individual rights of European citizens. That is why we voted against the joint resolution.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — As we face the challenges of terrorism, which are gaining a whole new form, marked unfortunately in last month's events in Paris, I welcome this EP resolution, as it answers many of the questions and challenges that exist in the new circumstances.  Terrorism cannot be viewed unequivocally given its causes, the methods it uses and the way it is excedied. Today's terrorism, except in religious radicalisation, has patterns in problems arising from the immigration process, inability and lack of integration, poverty, inadequate education inability to adequate economic human prosperity. It is not only imported, but also about people who grew up, born in a Western European Democratic Society.  Indoctrination and promotion are based on the latest technologies of modern IT communication where it is no longer local but global. Also special is the process of going on temporary warfare and the impact of such war and prisons on the recruitment of new terrorists. The problem also exists because there is insufficient integration and cooperation between the security and intelligence services of European countries, which in this sense common threats need to share information and act in an integrated way.  This Resolution also tosses illicit arms trafficking and illicit cash flows financing terrorist actions. In particular, I consider it important that the level of free movement of citizens within the Schengen area must not be restricted.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — Faced with the growing danger of terrorism in Europe, whether imported, financed from the outside or developing more or less autonomously on the territory of the Member States, the European Parliament's willingness to take charge of the problem is commendable. However, the suggested measures do not live up to the problem, for example data exchange, which is too timid a solution. The real counter-terrorism measures are also not mentioned, in particular the sovereignty of States over their borders, which would allow them to control the flows that pass through them, and the assessment of the financial participation of certain non-European powers in the development of international terrorism in Europe. So I decided to abstain.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. — I would like to express my agreement with the resolution adopted this morning on counter-terrorism measures. We cannot be kept in a rhetorical debate, often far from reality, between freedom and security. That equation must always be solved in favor of security freely, knowing that there is no one without the other. Today, European citizens are calling on their governments to take more effective and more freedom-friendly measures, and it is up to the European Parliament to balance these mutual demands. The Socialists cannot leave the flag of security in the hands of the right because they will end up imposing a model that will slow down the broad concept of freedom and citizenship that we have on the left. That is why we have agreed with them on a balanced resolution. But we cannot stand by other groups that demand freedom without understanding the moment we live in, the real risks we suffer, and thus assuming an insecurity that citizens do not want.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I am pleased that the European Parliament has supported this comprehensive resolution on counter-terrorism, which considers the root causes of radicalisation and terrorism and pushes for the implementation and review of existing EU measures. We need action both at home, across the EU and an external strategy to ensure a holistic approach to fighting terrorism.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. — The Greens/FTA group voted against the resolution on counter-terrorism measures. Adopted by four political groups, including socialists and liberals, it promotes a measure that seriously undermines freedoms without responding to the terrorist threat. Effective measures, they prefer mass surveillance and retention of personal data. We refuse to "take advantage" of the Paris attacks, as stated by a member of the UMP (EPP) to promote the famous European PNR. A measure whose effectiveness has yet to be proven. In pronouncing its adoption, the EP advocates widespread surveillance that will not prevent terrorist acts but will lead to fragile democracies. The NRP is not just an attack on freedoms. It is also a choice of society. That of spending 500 million euros on mass surveillance when they would be more useful in financing targeted surveillance of real suspects, field work, cooperation between police and intelligence services of Member States, including joint investigative teams under the authority of Europol and Eurojust. $500 million worth of money to prevent radicalization, fight unemployment and exclusion, reform prison, build a society of inclusion, our strength against the murderous madness of terrorists.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. "I supported the resolution on counter-terrorism measures. This resolution calls mainly for the implementation of concrete measures concerning prevention, deradicalisation, the strengthening of controls at our external borders and our surveillance tools, as well as the establishment of a European NP. Thus, this resolution must not be a finality, but rather the first step in strengthening our European legislation.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D)
text: Writing. — In order to combat terrorism, many screws must be turned. The resolution on anti-terrorism measures adopted on Wednesday 11 February contains many important demands, including on the areas of de-radicalisation, the fight against the illegal arms trade in Europe, social inclusion and better cooperation between the authorities. However, we, as the SPÖ-EU delegation, do not support the introduction of an EU-wide PNR system and have voted against this motion. The storage of the data of all EU passengers is inappropriate, disproportionate and incompatible with the fundamental right to the protection of personal data. The ECJ's ruling on data retention must be fully respected. The European Parliament has also decided to have the PNR agreement with Canada examined by the ECJ. In any case, the EU institutions should wait for this examination before proceeding further on this issue. We find it very regrettable that the important issue of the fight against terrorism is being exploited by free-riders to enforce controversial projects such as EU-PNR, which have already failed in the past. That is why we abstained in the final vote.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Anti-terrorism measures’ because we express our firm opposition to the use of drones for extrajudicial killings of terror suspects, and we call for more transparency and accountability regarding the use of drones, including through an EU common position formalising a legal framework for the use of drones.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " I strongly condemn all acts of terrorism, both within and outside Europe. However, countering such acts of violence by force, or retaliating, attacking countries where terrorists are trained, and harassing followers of religions that encourage attacks in the name of higher values, is the wrong way to go. The European Union is founded on democracy and dialogue, and the main idea of its creation was the prevention of armed conflicts. Therefore, remembering why we have united and why we are working together for europe's freedom and security, let us not encourage violence and discrimination. Solidarity and coordination are the basis for effective counter-terrorism. Strengthening internal security in the Member States will strengthen the EU's internal security. Let us not forget that terrorism is a threat with a global dimension, so cooperation on the international stage is essential to ensure that responses to threats are sufficiently rapid and effective. We, as Members of the European Parliament, have a duty to make the idea of dialogue and equality effective, while at the same time reviving radical attitudes and criticising extremist behaviour. Very often it is the lack of understanding and mutual respect that leads to acts of violence. Let us do our best to counter terrorism with reason and calm.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the joint resolution.  This resolution is the follow-up to the debate that was held during the last mini-plenary and is based on the anti-terrorism pact proposed by my group, the EPP Group. It is to be welcomed that other bigger groups are willing to work on this jointly to engage all European forces in the fight against terrorism.  I would like to urge a serious stepping up of the cooperation and exchange of information between Member States. Without such an efficient exchange, prevention and detection will not work. We immediately need setting up of PNR data-sharing, detecting and controlling effectively the export and sales of firearms within the EU and also to and from the EU among the first steps.  The EU has to seriously look into the money flows and how to cut financing of terrorist cells in the EU and elsewhere. Pressure has to be put also on the states that finance radicalisation. I welcome the call on the EEAS to develop a strategy for an EU external strategy combating international terrorism, addressing the sources of terrorism and mainstreaming counter-terrorism.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The Greens/EFA Group today voted against the joint motion for resolution on anti-terrorism measures, as the resolution is sending the wrong message at the wrong time. The resolution agreed by the four bigger political groups provides a carte blanche for EU governments to scale back personal freedoms with measures that will fail to properly respond to the terrorist threat. Instead of pushing for effective measures, the usual suspects who have been continually pushing for mass surveillance and data retention are using the Paris attacks as an excuse to bulldoze through these measures, despite any evidence that they will prove effective in countering the terrorist threat. A coherent counter-terrorism strategy would focus on targeted surveillance of real suspects and ensuring security authorities have the means and resources to focus on specific risks and concrete suspicions, to follow any leads immediately, and to efficiently exchange information about dangerous individuals. This is what we should be trying to achieve. There is also a need to tackle radicalisation in schools and prisons. Finally we are missing a call for a legal definition of profiling. Stepping up mass surveillance will undermine security and is instead a victory for fundamentalists, who are combating precisely such democratic freedoms.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I very much welcome the resolution, as it lays strong emphasis on the need to address the root causes of terrorism, by investing in educational programmes, promoting integration, social inclusion, dialogue, participation, equality, tolerance and understanding among different cultures and religions, as well as rehabilitation programmes. We urgently need to understand why young Europeans, that have grown up here and were part of our society, alienate and radicalise to such an extent that they turn against all the values that stand for the same society they lived in. The EU counter-terrorism and counter-radicalisation roadmap with a comprehensive package of measures is essential, ensuring a better use of existing instruments, where necessary, creating new ones, involving at all levels practitioners in prevention, detection, and protection.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Although the European Parliament is immised with actors advocating different national interests and different ideological aspects, I consider it important that we can agree on certain issues across the political spectrum. I consider the issue of the fight against terrorism to be one of them. However, the motion for a joint resolution did not include two factions, the Greens and the GUE/NGL. I find it sad that the demands of the two factions have not been worked out so that the European Parliament has a truly common acceptable proposal. The proposal does not accentuate the social factors of the whole problem as I would consider right. For example, an amendment that pointed out that poverty, unemployment, and a lack of prospects for full integration into society can lead individuals to the need for destructive behavior that infamously affects society as a whole. I believe that having a debate about radicalism without a comprehensive focus on society's social problems will not lead to the desired goal. Focusing on the consequence, not the cause, has fatal consequences on all social issues, and it is particularly dangerous when this happens on issues that threaten the lives of citizens of both Europe and the world. The proposal so often focuses on ways to obtain information about European citizens and how to monitor them as effectively as possible. I believe that the approach is wrong, which is why I did not agree with the motion for a resolution.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Resolution, tabled by the EPP Group, was supported by all political forces in the EP. The EPP Group has managed to unblock the stalemate in the European Parliament on the setting-up of an EU airline passenger name record (PNR) system and now we have the political commitment to finalise the PNR Directive by the end of this year. The Resolution calls for more specialised measures in tackling the problem of EU citizens travelling to fight for terrorist organisations abroad. It strongly encourages the better exchange of information between Member States’ country law enforcement authorities and EU agencies, something which is currently severely lacking. It calls on Member States to invest in schemes which address the root causes of radicalisation, including educational programmes, promoting integration as well as rehabilitation programmes. It also asks that special attention is given to prisons and detention conditions, with targeted measures to address radicalisation in this environment.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. - Similar to the US measures introduced after 9/11, using the public mood over the Paris attacks, the resolution generally proposes to broaden European policing and data control action. Fortunately, the perpetrators have been found in both places, and therefore it is unjustified for some to seek to create paranoid fear and to carry out as many counter-terrorism measures as possible, such as the EU Passenger Name Record Measure, as soon as possible, without the need for legal necessity or without carrying out an assessment of the current counter-terrorism measures. Avoiding further casualties is a priority, so the resolution cannot be rejected or supported because our aim cannot be the world order 'Orwell: 1984'.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) The broad support of this House for this resolution is confirmation of our commitment to the fight against terrorism, a challenge which is now more global than ever and which needs a global response. A fight that must necessarily be tackled on several fronts, going back to the root of radicalisation, including educational programmes that promote integration, social inclusion, dialogue, participation, equality, tolerance and intercultural and interreligious dialogue. Acting on the causes of radicalisation means acting on the causes that lead to violent extremism, preventing phenomena of social disintegration, counteracting the phenomena of ghettoization. Because it is in social distress that recruiters manage to find new followers to carry out terrorist acts. That is why we must counter the online incitement to carry out terrorist acts and stop the phenomenon of so-called 'foreign fighters'. With this resolution, we strongly condemn terrorism, calling for a comprehensive approach to terrorism, without renouncing the founding values of our Europe and our freedom.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution because the document is the result of intensive negotiation between the different political groups in the European Parliament on a sensitive issue such as terrorism. It is not only a looming threat, but also a problem for all European citizens, and I therefore believe that it must be tackled through a shared approach. In this respect, the Italian Government has taken action with very important anti-terrorism measures. It is clear, however, that it is necessary to maintain a very high alert state.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. — The ever-accelerating rise of terrorism and violent extremism pose a major threat to europe's entire security and the freedom of every citizen. Recent tragic terrorist events, not only within Europe but also in the immediate neighbourhood of the EU, remind us of the need to update and flesh out the current counter-terrorism strategy and to promote cooperation in this area as much as possible between international organisations, Member States and special authorities. The fight against terrorist groups and their support organisations must be one of the EU's main security priorities.   For these reasons, I strongly support this European Parliament resolution and its calls for the Commission and the Council to review and fully assess the EU's current counter-terrorism measures and to adopt an updated counter-terrorism programme.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on counter-terrorism measures. Indeed, since the attacks of January 2015, France is more than ever in open war with a faceless and borderless enemy, terrorism. An outpouring of unity and solidarity has therefore crossed the whole of the European Union in order to defend our values and our freedom. I am convinced that we can only deal effectively with terrorism at European level. To do this, measures such as better police and judicial cooperation between Member States, strengthening controls at external borders or increased surveillance of the Internet must be implemented as quickly as possible to ensure the effective protection of European citizens. It is our responsibility. I regret, however, that the establishment of the European NRL, which I believe is essential and urgent, is not unanimous in all political groups.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — The Members of the National Front have decided to abstain on the joint resolution on counter-terrorism measures, because this text unfortunately shows an incapacitating angelism. While the authors of the resolution say they want to "attack the roots of terrorism" and call on the Commission to 'propose a clear and common definition of 'EU foreign fighters'", they do not have the political courage to name Islamist fundamentalism as the main and essential source of current terrorism. Moreover, the text is cynical when it says it is "fundamentally opposed to proposals to suspend the Schengen regime", even though this regime is a major problem. The inability to carry out internal border checks facilitates the movement of terrorists within the European Union. The fight against terrorism is therefore an additional argument for giving Member States the right and the ability to control their own borders.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. "I chose to abstain in the vote on this resolution because it contains good and bad initiatives. I am in favour of its willingness to fight terrorism. I am also pleased to see that the European Parliament expresses its "deepest sympathy with the French people" following the attacks in Paris in January. On the other hand, I regret that the European Parliament is committed to voting by the end of 2015 on the Directive on the Use of Air Passenger Data (PNR). This directive will seriously undermine the protection of the personal data of these passengers.  In addition, it will go against the sovereignty of States, which will no longer be able to provide such protection for their nationals.  Finally, it poses a philosophical problem of the conception of life in society by organizing the registration of the entire population under the pretext of fighting a handful of terrorists.

name: Barbara Lochbihler (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The Greens/EFA group today voted against the Joint Motion for Resolution on Anti-terrorism Measures, as the resolution is sending the wrong message at the wrong time. The resolution agreed by the 4 bigger political groups provides a carte blanche for EU governments to scale-back personal freedoms with measures that will fail to properly respond to the terrorist threat. Instead of pushing for effective measures, the usual suspects who have been continually pushing for mass surveillance and data retention are using the Paris attacks as an excuse to bulldoze through these measures, despite any evidence that they will prove effective in countering the terrorist threat. A coherent counter-terrorism strategy would focus on targeted surveillance of real suspects and ensuring security authorities have the means and resources to focus on specific risks and concrete suspicions, to follow any leads immediately, and to efficiently exchange information about dangerous individuals. This is what we should be trying to achieve. There is also a need to tackle radicalisation in schools and prisons. Finally we are missing a call for a legal definition of profiling. Stepping up mass surveillance will undermine security and is instead a victory for fundamentalists, who are combatting precisely such democratic freedoms

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because the text includes an absolute condemnation of terrorism, a phenomenon which admits no justification, as well as new measures to prosecute and punish terrorist crimes. It also includes measures to strengthen the existing legislative framework for combating terrorism to adapt it to new realities from proportionality and necessity, and always from respect for public freedoms and fundamental rights governing the rule of law.  The resolution calls for greater cooperation between European judicial and police authorities in the fight against terrorism. It is a very strong resolution on prevention, which addresses the root causes of terrorism by proposing measures in the socio-educational field and in the field of 'deradicalization' and the promotion of a culture of tolerance in Europe. The resolution strikes the right balance between the security dimension and respect for freedoms. This weighting is an act of political responsibility that is demanded in the face of a matter as serious as terrorism. The resolution has valued the unity of democrats to defeat terrorism in the face of the threat it poses today to our security, our freedoms, and our model of coexistence.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. " We strongly condemn the terrorist acts perpetrated in France against Charlie Hebdo's workers. We condemn all terrorist acts that occur in many countries. And we do not leave out this condemnation—as most of this house does—state terrorism practiced by countries like Israel against Palestine, practiced in Syria, Lebanon, or the use of drones by the United States against populations in Africa or the Middle East. Defending the need to take action against the financing of terrorism while maintaining privileged relations with countries such as Saudi Arabia that finance, train and support terrorist groups is one more of the contradictions and another sign of the most right-wing hypocrisy in this chamber. That's why I voted against it. The fight against terrorism requires that the root causes of terrorism be attacked; requires profound policy change and respect for international law. And in no way can it legitimize the repressive wave and violation of the rights and freedoms contained in this resolution.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " In the discussion on terrorism and measures to combat it, I wanted to highlight the huge role of education, which is not adequately exposed in the counter-terrorism strategy and its measures. The protection of external borders, data exchange, cooperation between countries and ensuring internal security are undoubtedly crucial in the fight against terrorism. However, we must remember that the terrorist threat is not limited to the Middle East. More and more young Europeans are adopting very radical views and are able to even kill their values.  It is therefore extremely important that we focus on working with young people, on learning tolerance, respect for other cultures and religions, a culture of discussion and communication. It is the school that is a key element in preventing and countering radicalisation. It should have a dual role.              On the one hand, instill in young people ideas of tolerance, integration, dialogue, respect, cultural diversity and, on the other hand, be sensitive to the manifestations of very radical attitudes among young people. Good communication on the school-student-parent line, taking into account the cultural characteristics of young people, are key prerequisites for countering its radicalisation. It should be emphasised, of course, that this challenge of the indirect fight against extremism does not lie solely with teachers. On the contrary, in order for it to produce results, it is necessary to include the media, NGOs and experts in local communities.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted for the resolution on counter-terrorism measures. I support the adoption of a European strategy against radical networks, online recruitment and terrorist propaganda. We must insist on combating funding through money laundering and organised crime by these groups. Furthermore, we must ask internet and online communication companies to cooperate with governments, law enforcement authorities and civil society to combat the use of internet and social media for the purpose of preparing terrorist attacks, while ensuring that freedom of expression and the right to privacy are respected. I agree that we must not give up the Schengen area, but we must encourage Member States to strengthen the control of documents and persons in suspicious cases, to use data on persons in the Schengen information system and to carry out information-based checks when suspicious persons enter or leave the European Union. Romania ensures the protection of the Union's external border for some 2,000 km, thus playing a vital role in the protection of Union citizens.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The EU and its Members have a shared responsibility to ensure the safety and freedom of the citizens of Europe and to take all appropriate measures to prevent life-threatening actions. To achieve this, counter-terrorism measures should be based on the principles of necessity, proportionality and respect for fundamental rights and be in line with the rule of law and international obligations. Terrorism is a global threat that needs to be addressed at local, national, European and global levels in order to strengthen the security of our citizens, in order to defend the fundamental values of freedom, democracy and human rights. As the security situation in Europe has changed drastically in recent years, mainly due to new conflicts and upheavals in the EU's immediate neighbourhood, the rapid development of new technologies, and a worrying rise in radicalisation leading to violence and terrorism, it underlines the need to improve, intensify and accelerate the global police exchange of information.  The EU's comprehensive counter-terrorism strategy must make full use of its external and development policies to fight terrorism and I therefore support the proposal for this resolution.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution for the following reasons. EU citizens need today, more than ever, a coherent counter-terrorism strategy, with concrete, immediately applicable, deeply proactive and not reactive measures in addressing conflicts.  Such a strategy must also address the root causes of radicalisation and combat poverty, marginalisation, discrimination, corruption.  Member States should invest in educational programmes, rehabilitation, promotion of integration, social inclusion, dialogue, equality, tolerance and understanding between different cultures and religions. I congratulate and support the EP's commitment to act towards the completion of a Single Passenger Register Directive by the end of 2015 at the latest. This instrument will enable an efficient exchange of relevant information and increased border controls. I welcome the adoption of the updated EU legal framework for combating money laundering, the application of which will lead to the blocking of important sources of funding for terrorist organisations. I stress that the lack of concrete, coordinated and effective cooperation involving all relevant actors - Member States, European and national intelligence services and police structures - will lead to an unprecedented scale of the work of terrorist organisations.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing — The events of recent weeks confirm that the fight against terrorism is a matter not only for the European Union, but also for each individual Member State and for every democratic country in the world. It is therefore necessary to adopt a strengthening of the powers of national surveillance of citizens as well as persons heading to conflict countries. Citizens who fight abroad in the ranks of terrorist organisations pose a potential danger to every state. In order to ensure this task, all legitimately available instruments must be used to prevent risks and damage to the lives and health of the population. However, all measures must be implemented in such a way as, on the one hand, to prevent the infiltration of terrorism into EU countries and to prevent acts of terrorism within countries, but at the same time not to violate human rights and freedoms.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on measures against terrorism because the European Parliament clearly and unequivocally states, on the one hand, that security is one of the rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and, on the other hand, that fundamental rights, civil liberties and proportionality are essential parameters for the success of counter-terrorism policies.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution which: ʽCondemns in the strongest terms the atrocities in Paris, and reiterates its deepest sympathy with the people of France and the families of the victims, and its unity in the global fight against terrorism and the attack upon our democratic values and freedomsʼ.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on counter-terrorism measures. It is of the utmost importance that the European Union, its Member States and its partner countries should merge their strategy to combat international terrorism on the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The subject of the present resolution is one of the most serious security issues of our time. I believe that we must place as much emphasis as possible on the fact that the effectiveness of counter-terrorism policy requires a change in the foreign policy of some Member States of the European Union. It is necessary to assess the consequences in kind, for example, of actions such as the bombing of Libya or the support of anti-government forces in Syria. Unfortunately, the motion for a joint resolution does not reflect the need for a self-critical approach that could help improve pro-terrorism policy, but also to understand why illegal immigration to Europe is increasing. Residues of colonial thinking in some metropolises, non-conceptual assistance to developing countries, which, for example, helps more to outlet our agricultural surpluses than agricultural development in the receiving states, rampant arms exports to unstable areas – these are just some of the activities that contribute to the rise of terrorism and the disintegration of states. The concept of the European Union's Mediterranean partnership, as well as its relationship with the African Union, is outdated. It does not reflect dramatic changes in both Europe and MENA – countries in the Middle East and North Africa. However, these ideas are completely absent from the motion for a resolution on which we are voting. I could therefore not support its content and I voted against it.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution, which is the result of intensive negotiation between the various political groups in the European Parliament, because I believe it is necessary for the Assembly of which I am a member to express a shared and multilateral vision of the measures necessary to counter the looming terrorist threat. The latter is, in fact, a problem for all European citizens, beyond their national affiliation, and must therefore be addressed at European level, through a shared, forward-looking and responsible approach. Therefore, a document of intent, which goes beyond the boundaries of political affiliation, was entirely desirable.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — While agreeing with much of the resolution on counter-terrorism measures, the subtext and nuances it creates of a response at European level are problematic. This is because it creates a narrative creates a division between us europeans and them immigrants. Because it says that terrorism is the result of immigration which is, by the way, the speech of the National Front in France. It's wanting to put everything in the same bag, deceiving people by taking advantage of fear politically and mixing two totally different subjects. It is also to insist on a wrong answer which has proven to be a complete failure on the part of the Member States to promote policing and the constant persecution of immigrants and to maintain their non-recognition as full citizens. It does not intend to solve social, political or humanitarian crises. It is only intended to push humanitarian disasters far away from Europe. That's why I voted against it.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — (DE) The proposal on counter-terrorism measures received my negative vote, as the measures proposed in it will not improve the current situation. Only a restrictive immigration policy and a ban on foreign fighters returning would at least reduce the risk to our population. However, these points are not even mentioned in the policy paper.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — In the wake of the Paris attacks, this resolution proposes an arsenal of measures to combat terrorism. If the principle of the free movement of people in the Schengen area is not called into question, the rest of the resolution takes on an ultra-secure tone. Adoption of a new PNR protocol, enhanced data exchange, etc. The resolution also proposes an active role for the European External Action Service (EEAS) in the fight against terrorism. Finally, in terms of prevention, the text advocates "religious tolerance", unaware that only secularism can put an end to religious tensions. I am voting against this resolution.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — I believe that all instruments are important in the fight against terrorism. We cannot be naïve enough to think that terrorists will not always use all the means at their fingertips to achieve their objectives. We likewise have to use every means in our power to fight them.  I therefore agree that the PNR instrument should be used to combat terrorism. The EP must make every effort to adopt all necessary measures to effectively combat terrorism.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it presents a multifaceted strategy to combating terrorism. The resolution includes measures to tackle the root causes of terrorism and violent extremism. It calls for the better use of existing security measures and also calls for the European External Action Service to adopt an EU external strategy for combating international terrorism. I welcome the multiple references to the need to tackle radicalisation in Member States and around the world through the use of foreign development policies which combat poverty, marginalisation and corruption. In light of the reports that ISIL is gaining ground on Malta’s doorstep it is vital that the EU cooperates with security forces in Libya to re-establish the rule of law and deliver on the promises of the Libyan Revolution.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. After intense negotiations, the European Parliament adopted a resolution listing priority areas of action in the fight against terrorism and radicalisation in Europe. Among the major measures advanced is the need to break the national silos of information already known. Refusing to share information limits our chances of actively fighting terrorists. Member States must now take another step forward by giving the European Union the means to combat this scourge that goes beyond our borders, our continent. We must not give in to fear. Data collection is essential as long as it is necessary and within the limits of privacy. I will therefore strongly oppose the creation of a European big brother. However, we must not be naïve, information is the raw material of the fight against terrorism. So we need to establish a framework that ensures that balance. I welcome the European Parliament's decision to tackle the PNR data file while reaffirming its commitment to data protection.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. — The motion for a resolution is an important message to the Hungarian governing parties: it does not mention the relationship between immigration and terrorism. While Europe is taking counter-terrorism measures, Hungarian ruling parties are crying wolf and wanting to latch Hungary doors of the country to migrants. The statements of Viktor Orban and the current government lack any basis in reality, but they only want to hungarian voters, who are increasingly turning away from Fidesz. We believe in a diverse, free, democratic Europe, where we acknowledge that we are very diverse and that the strength of Europe comes from this diversity and diversity.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This text deals with measures relating to the fight against terrorism. It paves the way for a future directive on the PNR, a veritable widespread record that, under the guise of fighting terrorism, will in fact constitute a disproportionate infringement of fundamental freedoms and will prove ineffective in the fight against terrorism, like the US Patriot Act and other mass surveillance. Here, of course, nothing is said about the restoration of national borders and the necessary controls. Worse, the resolution says it is "fundamentally opposed to proposals to suspend the Schengen regime". In addition, there is also a problem of compliance with EU law, as the ECJ has already invalidated similar schemes. If there is a need to do more to combat terrorism, these measures appear disproportionate, which is why I abstained.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which demonstrates the joint commitment of all the political groups in Parliament (except the Greens and the far left) against terrorism. The resolution takes up most of the measures proposed by the EPP to deal with the threat (fighting radicalisation in prisons, combating arms trafficking, strengthening controls at external borders, more effective use of existing files such as the Schengen information system, etc.). An amendment I supported commits the European Parliament to bring the European NNP project to fruition before the end of the year. This European NRL is vital for us to detect terrorists coming and going from training and combat zones.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on counter-terrorism measures. Terrorism today is a dramatic threat to our freedoms and security. The fight against terrorism must take place in two stages: that of prevention and that of action. It is a question of going back on its origins, of understanding radicalisation and of anticipating the gears in which the youngest fall, in particular. Member States must promote social inclusion, involve citizens in targeted educational programmes to avoid isolation and entanglement, and pay particular attention to prison living conditions. Finally, the massive use of social networks by terrorist groups seriously encourages propaganda and the promotion of terrorism. The European Union therefore provides Member States with a multitude of warning tools to help them in this fight, let us show solidarity and do everything possible to prevent further tragedies.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) We consider terrorism, radicalization and violent extremism to be the main threats to our security and freedom. With this resolution we wish to reaffirm our commitment to respect for freedom of expression, fundamental rights, democracy, tolerance and the rule of law. We believe that the EU, its Member States and all partner countries should adopt their own strategy to combat international terrorism on the basis of respect for fundamental rights. We call on the Member States to improve the exchange of information, through the effective use of EU databases and through greater cooperation with specialised agencies (Eurojust/Europol). We are convinced that the fight against terrorism represents a global challenge and that the European Union, together with the other major regional players, should play a leading role in dealing with this threat at world level. Once again, we insist on the need for a coherent, consolidated and proactive common foreign policy, strongly focused on cooperation with third countries that could become valuable allies in the fight against terrorism. We must strengthen political dialogue with different religious communities and see the fight against terrorism as a fundamental part of other policies, development and social and economic inclusion.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted for this text but see it as a step in strengthening our legislation. The text as adopted does not have the will. The rapid adoption of a European NRP remains an absolute necessity in view of current European issues.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — This resolution arose in response to the growing need to attempt to annihilate the scourge called 'terrorism'. Recent events in Paris have shown that the European Union is facing an ever-evolving terrorist threat. I voted for this resolution because it underlines the need to combat the root causes of terrorism and radicalisation that lead to acts of violent extremism, but also to maintain the INTERNAL security of the EU and the EU's law enforcement capabilities and at the same time to adopt an EXTERNAL EU strategy to combat international terrorism.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I have voted for the best possible text of this very important resolution. The spectre of terrorism is hanging now more than ever over the EU and we have to have the vision and courage to take all needed measures, at home and abroad, to prevent and combat such acts and persons, while at the same time safeguarding that which makes up the essence of Europe, our values, liberties and rights.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — I voted against the proposal. For me, the fight against terrorist activities requires decisive action. Unfortunately, I do not recognise this in the proposal. In particular, I do not see a ban on foreign jihadists returning to the country and a much more restrictive immigration policy – both points that I did not mention in the proposal.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the bill. In order to combat terrorism, a European Union intelligence service must be set up to ensure adequate information and analysis and the flow of information between Member States. It is also necessary to strengthen Europol, including the European Counter-Terrorism Centre. Eurojust must also gain strength and the EU External Action Service must include participation in and international implementation of counter-terrorism policy-making. The key word is also the exchange of information between EU Member States.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the unacceptable joint resolution of the People's Party, Social Democrats, Liberals and Conservatives-Reformists because, taking advantage of the pretext of terrorism, it calls for the intensity and proliferation of repressive measures and the strengthening of the already complex national and EU repression mechanisms imposed: limiting and abolishing basic democratic rights and popular freedoms, generalising the passenger file on air transport (PNR) , strengthening cooperation between secret services and repressive mechanisms between the Member States and the EU, a generalised plan linking repression within EU Member States to imperialist interventions in third countries, with particular emphasis on the region of the South-East, Middle East, North Africa. In the same direction, the European Council, with the signature of the SYRIZA-ANEL Government, adopted all the above unacceptable and dangerous decisions. Identifying the "fight against terrorism" with action against "radicalisation", "violent extremism" and "violent ideologies", which constitutes the EU's "counter-terrorism policy", targets the labour-popular movement and its actions, which is also the real target of the entire huge network of repression that is developing in the EU and its Member States, in order to shield the power of monopolies.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — The EU and its Member States have a common responsibility first and foremost to guarantee security and freedom for European citizens and that, in order to achieve freedom and justice, counter-terrorism measures should always be based on the principles of necessity, proportionality and respect for fundamental rights. Freedom of movement in the Schengen area is one of the most important fruits of European integration and our external borders are in fact a common external border. The issue of 'foreign fighters' is not a new phenomenon, but its scale has dramatically increased, posed a very serious threat to the security of EU citizens.
