There is a need for an anti-terrorism pact based on a multi-level approach that also boosts cohesion and inclusion, through the promotion of political and religious tolerance, that analyzes and counterbalances online incitement to carry out terrorist acts and ensures decisive judicial action. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. — Unfortunately, the unfortunate events in Paris have brought the fight against terrorism to the top of European priorities. The problem of rising terrorism is reflected, inter alia, as a result of radicalisation and a changing world order. In the short term, I agree that enhanced cooperation between partners and existing institutions such as Europol, Eurojust, Frontex and CEPOL is crucial. On the other hand, I support the European Commission's proposal for the access and use of passenger data. In the long term, I see it as very important to strengthen specific programmes that would prevent religious radicalisation, not just on the domestic doorstep, and to strengthen people's prospects for personal development. Interfaith dialogue and awareness of genuine and moderate Islam must be strengthened. In times of crisis, it is very important that the European Union does not reduce, but even strengthen its role of developing democracy and peace in its neighbourhood, and accelerating work on the European perspective of the Western Balkans, also in order to combat arms trafficking.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — The recent terrorist attacks in Paris are an indication that terrorism in Europe is an enemy that does not sleep. For those of us who live and work on the foundations of freedom, tolerance and democracy, it is inconceivable to experience such ossuasions of terror in our community as well. In this situation, more than ever, we must jointly threaten forces and work together to find a way to minimise the threat of terrorist attacks. It is important that we all become aware that terrorism has been happening for years in Iraq, Syria and Nigeria where Christians are killed, that it has been happening for months in Ukraine, that it has recently taken place in France, where in addition to attacking journalists, members of the Jewish community have been killed, and thus it becomes clear that terrorists are attacking those who think and believe differently from them. In 2 months, the same can happen in your country. It is imperative that all countries are urgently involved in action to combat terrorism.  Europe needs tighter controls on its external borders, it should be possible to use all available modern technologies while respecting the protection of personal data in order to prevent the migration of terrorists and their activity, and cooperate with non-EU countries. It is our obligation to protect all european union residents from terrorism and to punish those who are at risk of their safety in the strongest possible time.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — This text deals with measures relating to the fight against terrorism. It opens the door to a future directive on the PNR, a veritable widespread record that, under the guise of fighting terrorism, will in fact constitute a disproportionate infringement of fundamental freedoms and will prove ineffective in the fight against terrorism, like the American Patriot Act and other mass surveillance. Here, of course, nothing is said about the restoration of national borders and the necessary controls. Worse, the resolution says it is "fundamentally opposed to proposals to suspend the Schengen regime". In addition, there is also a problem of compliance with EU law, as the ECJ has already invalidated similar schemes. If there is a need to do more to combat terrorism, these measures appear disproportionate, which is why I abstained.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) In recent weeks we are experiencing a sense of strong powerlessness in the major European cities. Following the shocking attacks in Paris last January, the European Union is faced with major and serious threats that can only be defeated with strong solidarity between the Member States, their police and intelligence forces. A European control system is vital if our citizens are to be guaranteed security. The EU has two agencies such as Europol and Eurojust which must be exploited to the full in these circumstances by the Member States, thanks to their skills and wealth of professionalism. We can only guarantee security with more and not less Europe, just as only Europe can guarantee a very high level of protection of human and personal rights, which are often sidelined in these emergency situations. As the resolution rightly mentions in its paragraphs, a strong neighbourhood policy towards the southern shore of the Mediterranean and the Middle East, together with strong action by inclusive social policies in our suburbs, where strong hostility towards the West is growing more and more in some communities, are fundamental steps to ensure security in Europe.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — In New York on September 11, 2001, terrorists attacked tall buildings and last month in Paris they fired on the newsroom of the satirical newspaper "Charlie Hebdo" - a symbol of the high spirituality of a democratic society. The lives of those most feared by criminals, people of free, critical and fearless spirit, have been targeted.  The terrorists, apparently, did not choose their victims "blindly." That is why the reaction of a democratic society, despite deep pain and disgust, must not be a "blind" reaction, but there has long been a strong need for the democratic world to face the roots of the evils of modern terrorism in a more effective way. It grew in dark cracks and neglected corners of our progress.  Repression should therefore be only one dimension of this confrontation. For this reason, I support this Resolution of the European Parliament as a united response from colleagues, regardless of their political affiliation, which offers concrete responses to the different causes of the problems we face, not their retraction.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — I supported a joint resolution on measures against terrorism, as terrorism, radicalisation and violent extremism are certainly among the main threats to our security and our freedoms. The terrorist attacks and violent extremism that several Member States have seriously faced in recent decades, which we are witnessing even after the recent tragic event in Paris, are an indication that the European Union is under a constant, i.e. increasing, terrorist threat and which aims not only at the people but also of the values and freedoms on which the EU is founded.  I personally condemn any terrorist act, the promotion of terrorism, the gloror of those who participate in it, as well as the advocacy of violent ideologies. The primary objective in the coming period is to combat cross-border and organised crime, including terrorism, and to strengthen the ability of EU member states to assess risks and increase resilience to crises. In emergency situations, extraordinary measures must be responded to, in particular where the threat of terrorism is present, without prejudice to the legal state and its values.  I therefore welcome the call for the European External Action Service (EEAS) to adopt the EU's foreign policy strategy to combat international terrorism. All together we need to get involved in solving the crisis, and as an MP from Croatia, I think we can offer good examples of models of integration of fellow Citizens of islamic religion.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — I strongly support this resolution on all its points. I strongly and categorically condemn all terrorist attacks, the promotion of terrorism, the celebration of those involved and the defence of extremist violent ideologies, whether they occur or are defended anywhere in the world. I consider extremist and terrorist groups to be the greatest threat in the world today, which cannot be 100% eliminated, but I believe that a comprehensive approach can significantly improve the security of the population. It is necessary to introduce a 'multi-layered approach' to combating terrorism, not to address it at the time of the planned attacks, but to comprehensively address the root causes of radicalisation leading to violent extremism, e.g. by strengthening social cohesion and an inclusive society and political and religious tolerance, by preventing social exclusion. The internet and its monitoring will increasingly play an essential role in order to preemptively intercept recruitment, terrorist propaganda and, last but not least, the illegal arms trade. But the European Union cannot push through any effective strategy without intensive cooperation with other states – not just those in which terrorist organizations are concentrated – because terrorism knows no borders, and even enhanced EU border controls cannot be the solution on their own.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) In the light of the recent tragic events in Paris, it is essential for all of us that the European Union is united and determined in combating the terrorist threat, and that it does so both by combating the preparation of attacks on EU territory and by tackling and seeking to eliminate the roots of terrorism. It is important that the security of citizens, the defence of the fundamental values of freedom, democracy and human rights are defended and placed at the top of the priorities. Radicalisation leading to violent extremism must be combated in every way, seeking to dismantle financial aid to terrorist organisations through decisive judicial action. Furthermore, as is also indicated in the resolution, controls at the external borders must be increased, with more careful checks on travel documents and greater attention being paid to the categories and sectors at risk.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. — I strongly support the procedure chosen by the European States and also by the European Parliament in the field of counter-terrorism measures. I also welcome the opening of the way to setting up an air passenger data sharing system (PNR), because I consider sharing to be very important and beneficial at a time when thousands of citizens of European states are leaving to fight for Islamist terrorists. Let us not restore borders between the States of the Union, but rather look for tools that will enable the security forces to better find terrorists and thus prevent terrorist activities. We cannot, of course, restrict fundamental human rights, but we cannot at the same time allow terrorists to abuse the freedom that underlies our civilisation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — The events in Paris reminded us of the interest of each Member State in working together in the fight against terrorism. The resolution proposed before the European elected representatives is the result of a soft compromise which, unfortunately, does not sufficiently grasp the height of the stakes. Nevertheless, the European Parliament's agreement in favour of the reintroduction of the PNR and the greater involvement of European institutions and agencies in this fight should be welcomed. The processing of passenger data is an asset for the security of our continent and the mutual trust we can place in each other.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — The tragic events in Paris in January 2015 are a warning that the European Union faces a permanent and evolving terrorist threat. Terrorism is a global threat that must be fought at local, national, European and global level in order to strengthen citizens' security, defend the fundamental values of freedom, democracy and human rights and preserve international law. This resolution reiterates the need to address the threat of terrorism with a strategy based on a multidimensional approach, including combating the underlying factors of radicalisation, combating cyber-terrorism, preventing the movement of people to join the ranks of terrorist organisations, stopping financial support for terrorist organisations and developing international security and data collection cooperation. The resolution also rejects any proposal to suspend the Schengen system and reaffirms the primacy of respect for international law and fundamental rights in the implementation of counter-terrorism measures. I voted in favour.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. — In order to combat terrorism, many screws must be turned. The resolution on anti-terrorism measures adopted on Wednesday 11 February contains many important demands, including on the areas of de-radicalisation, the fight against the illegal arms trade in Europe, social inclusion and better cooperation between the authorities. However, we, as the SPÖ-EU delegation, do not support the introduction of an EU-wide PNR system and have voted against this motion. The storage of the data of all EU passengers is inappropriate, disproportionate and incompatible with the fundamental right to the protection of personal data. The ECJ's ruling on data retention must be fully respected. The European Parliament has also decided to have the PNR agreement with Canada examined by the ECJ. In any case, the EU institutions should wait for this examination before proceeding further on this issue. We find it very regrettable that the important issue of the fight against terrorism is being exploited by free-riders to enforce controversial projects such as EU-PNR, which have already failed in the past. That is why we abstained in the final vote.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. — The European Union cannot give in to terrorism, hatred and barbarism. Through this ambitious resolution, which I fully support, Parliament calls for a comprehensive and coherent strategy to combat this threat that affects us all. Our approach is part of a multidimensional approach, focused on a safe and preventive dimension, and always respectful of the rule of law. In order to prevent the preparation of further attacks on our territory, it is first of all essential to equip the police and judicial authorities with adequate and effective European instruments to enable them to carry out their mission. Some measures already exist, but will need to be reassessed and fully implemented. MEPs also stress the importance of addressing the roots of terrorism and the underlying factors of radicalisation, emphasizing the fundamental role of schools and social inclusion policies. They urge the European Union to participate fully in the establishment of a comprehensive partnership to fight terrorism. Finally, Parliament commits itself with this text to work towards the finalisation of the European NNP directive by the end of the year, which I can only congratulate myself on.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. — Following the recent tragic events in Paris, it is necessary for the European Union and its Member States to adapt their approaches to the terrorist threat. That is why I support the draft joint resolution on counter-terrorism measures. First, it is a reminder of the need for better implementation of existing policies. The roots of radicalisation must be tackled through economic, educational and urban policies facilitating social integration and to improve the implementation of repressive measures already present under the Schengen regime.  Secondly, in the face of a growing and evolving terrorist threat, new means of internal security must emerge in Europe, notably on the exchange of information relating to air passengers. I am pleased that today's vote is unblocking the situation on this issue in Parliament. The resolution clearly supports the adoption of the NPP before the end of the year, while calling for respect for the principle of proportionality and the continuation of negotiations on the protection of personal data. Finally, Member States need to improve their coordination in the fight against terrorism, by bringing their intelligence services and judicial institutions closer together, notably through Europol and Eurojust agencies.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. — The Greens/FTA group voted against the resolution on counter-terrorism measures. Adopted by four political, socialist and liberal groups included, it promotes a measure that seriously undermines freedoms without responding to the terrorist threat. Effective measures, they prefer mass surveillance and retention of personal data. We refuse to "take advantage" of the Paris attacks as stated by a member of the UMP (EPP) to promote the famous European PNR. A measure whose effectiveness has yet to be proven. In pronouncing its adoption, the EP advocates widespread surveillance that will not prevent terrorist acts but will lead to fragile democracies. The NRP is not just an attack on freedoms. It is also a choice of society. That of spending 500 million euros on mass surveillance when they would be more useful in financing targeted surveillance of real suspects, field work, cooperation between police and intelligence services of Member States, including joint investigative teams under the authority of Europol and Eurojust. $500 million worth of money to prevent radicalization, fight unemployment and exclusion, reform prison, build a society of inclusion, our strength against the murderous madness of terrorists.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. — Several serious attacks have been carried out on European soil since the early 2000s, directly affecting our security. I voted in favour of this resolution, which reiterates the need for action at European level to effectively combat the terrorist threat. We call for a multi-dimensional strategy, addressing the problem upstream through educational and social programmes promoting tolerance and, where appropriate, with deradicalisation measures. The policy would also aim to combat incitement to terrorist acts online and to prevent the involvement of new fighters alongside Islamist militias. At the same time, we recall that it is essential to take measures to control the comings and goings within the European Union through an optimised sharing of information between Member States. We need to improve and finalise the PNR Directive in parallel with the data protection legislative package. Finally, the European Union must actively advocate for the establishment of a global partnership to fight terrorism.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — Whereas the advance of terrorism and violent extremism pose a threat to our security and individual freedoms, and considering the latest terrorist developments in some Member States of the European Union, it is imperative to act. The definition of counter-terrorism plans and strategies is important, but respect for the principles advocated in the Charter of human rights must always be taken into consideration. It is important that there is coordinated work between the different Member States and that action is effective. It is important to draw up a comprehensive approach to combating terrorism, which must take into account the internal and external dimension of the situations experienced in the European Union and beyond.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because the text includes an absolute condemnation of terrorism, a phenomenon which admits no justification, as well as new measures to prosecute and punish terrorist crimes. It also includes measures to strengthen the existing legislative framework for combating terrorism to adapt it to new realities from proportionality and necessity, and always from respect for public freedoms and fundamental rights governing the rule of law.  The resolution calls for greater cooperation between European judicial and police authorities in the fight against terrorism. It is a very strong resolution on prevention, which addresses the root causes of terrorism by proposing measures in the socio-educational field and in the field of 'deradicalization' and the promotion of a culture of tolerance in Europe. The resolution strikes the right balance between the security dimension and respect for freedoms. This weighting is an act of political responsibility that is demanded in the face of a matter as serious as terrorism. The resolution has valued the unity of democrats to defeat terrorism in the face of the threat it poses today to our security, our freedoms, and our model of coexistence.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted against the resolution presented. The resolution has, in general terms, positive aspects, as it underlines the importance of prevention and respect for individual rights in the fight against terrorism. However, an amendment tabled at the last minute by the Socialist Group and the People's Group includes in the resolution the need to make urgent progress in the adoption of PNR (Passenger Name Record) legislation. This draft legislation should be subject, on the one hand, to the adoption of a data protection package, which we believe should be earlier, and, on the other hand, to the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the validity of the EU-Canada PNR agreement. We believe that including in this resolution the urgency of advancing the PNR contradicts many of the principles set out in the resolution itself, and does not go in the sense of ensuring the privacy and individual rights of European citizens. That is why we voted against the joint resolution.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted today in favour of the resolution on counter-terrorism measures. Among these measures is the adoption of a "European PNR" (passenger name records, i.e.: a centralised database that will contain detailed files on all passengers transiting through a European airport, kept for five years) linked to progress on the reform of personal data protection and privacy. The resolution also stresses the need to improve, intensify and accelerate the sharing of law enforcement information at the global level and calls for faster and more efficient sharing of relevant data and information. And recalls the need - again and again - to invest in programmes that address the root causes of radicalisation, including educational programmes, integration promotion, social inclusion, dialogue, participation, equality and tolerance.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. — Today, it is very important to pay attention to the causes of terrorism and not to deal with the consequences. It is clear that in many countries it is believed that the abundance of armed soldiers and police forces on the streets will provide security. But is that really the case? Rather, the opposite. This is an excellent example of how the consequences are being combated. Preventing terrorism, especially given that people living in Europe often become terrorists, is a multifaceted process. Firstly, investment in the education system. European values must not remain on paper, they must be introduced in schools. There is no doubt that the promotion of confrontation between different religions, beliefs, people of origin leads to perdition. Secondly, reducing social inequalities. Today, we are growing an increasingly angry society, whose representatives – without a job, unable to access medicines, forgetting and leaving everyone – are becoming more radical. And that leads to self-destruction. Thirdly, we need to ensure the effective work of the responsible authorities. It is not to be tolerated that Kalashnikov machines can be purchased on the streets. We must be sure that those who ensure security are prepared for the challenges, properly informed and know how to act in the face of a threat. Security must be ensured by officials not by weapons, but by continuous consistent work.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — Security is one of the rights enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and one of its fundamental pillars, which is why I welcome and welcome this joint motion for a resolution. The tragic events recently in Paris have warned of the danger of a globally-scale terrorist threat, which must be tackled at local, national, European and global level, through the adoption of preventive measures in the fight against terrorism, based on a multidimensional approach and strategy, combating radicalisation factors and fostering violent extremism. To this end, it is essential to cease financial support for terrorist organisations, to have effective criminal proceedings and to provide law enforcement authorities with instruments appropriate to the performance of their duties.  On the other hand, Member States should adopt cohesion and social inclusion policies that promote political and religious tolerance, avoid ghettos and the entry of people into the ranks of terrorist organisations, as well as recruitment and participation in armed conflicts.  I believe, like the rapporteur, that Member States should use existing platforms, databases and alert systems at European level and any proposal to suspend the Schengen system should be rejected.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this joint resolution, which represents a minimum compromise on counter-terrorism measures. Given the urgency of the current situation, this resolution must be seen as a first step in strengthening our European anti-terrorism legislation.  Our objective, as members of the EPP Group, remains the rapid adoption of a European NPP.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. — Finally, the European Parliament has adopted a common position on the measures to be taken to combat terrorism, in particular the problems of foreign fighters, their financing, the role of the Internet and social media in their enlistment, and their ease of movement. I also voted in favour of the resolution because the text has finally given the green light for a concrete resumption of work on the rapid adoption of the proposal for a directive on the use of reservation code data (EU PNR Directive).

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted against the resolution presented. The resolution has, in general terms, positive aspects, as it underlines the importance of prevention and respect for individual rights in the fight against terrorism. However, an amendment tabled at the last minute by the Socialist Group and the People's Group includes in the resolution the need to make urgent progress in the adoption of PNR (Passenger Name Record) legislation. This draft legislation should be subject, on the one hand, to the adoption of a data protection package, which we believe should be earlier, and, on the other hand, to the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the validity of the EU-Canada PNR agreement. We believe that including in this resolution the urgency of advancing the PNR contradicts many of the principles set out in the resolution itself, and does not go in the sense of ensuring the privacy and individual rights of European citizens. That is why we voted against the joint resolution.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution, although I regret that it does not go further in the responses to terrorism.  The text proposes to put in place specific measures to deal with the problem of European citizens who have gone to fight in Iraq, Syria or Libya alongside terrorist organisations, to deal with the phenomenon of radicalisation in prisons, to combat arms trafficking in Europe, to improve judicial cooperation, to strengthen controls at external borders and to involve internet actors in the fight against terrorism. But that is not enough.  We must learn from the Paris attacks and have concrete tools to ensure the safety of Europeans: the rapid adoption of the PNR directive is therefore a major issue. The European Union must take stock of the current terrorist threat to its citizens.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The Greens/EFA group today voted against the Joint Motion for a Resolution on Anti-terrorism Measures, as the resolution is sending the wrong message at the wrong time. The resolution agreed by the 4 bigger political groups provides carte blanche for EU governments to scale back personal freedoms with measures that will fail to properly respond to the terrorist threat. Instead of pushing for effective measures, the usual suspects who have been continually pushing for mass surveillance and data retention are using the Paris attacks as an excuse to bulldoze through these measures, despite any evidence that they will prove effective in countering the terrorist threat. A coherent counter-terrorism strategy would focus on targeted surveillance of real suspects and ensuring security authorities have the means and resources to focus on specific risks and concrete suspicions, to follow any leads immediately, and to efficiently exchange information about dangerous individuals. This is what we should be trying to achieve. There is also a need to tackle radicalisation in schools and prisons. Finally we are missing a call for a legal definition of profiling. Stepping up mass surveillance will undermine security and is instead a victory for fundamentalists, who are combatting precisely such democratic freedoms.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The Greens/EFA group today voted against the Joint Motion for a Resolution on Anti-terrorism Measures, as the resolution is sending the wrong message at the wrong time. name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. — In the debate on terrorism, hasty conclusions and proposals for rash solutions to the consequences, not the causes of this phenomenon, often fall. I therefore welcome the fact that this resolution underlines the need to focus on combating the roots of terrorism. It is necessary to invest in education, promote integration, social inclusion, dialogue, mutual tolerance and understanding between different cultures and religions. Like freedom of expression, these values form the foundations of European civilisation, and the European Union must not trade them for self-contained and false promises of security. I therefore welcome the fact that proposals to suspend the Schengen system have been excluded from the resolution.  I agree that terrorism must be combated at all levels – whether nationally, Europeanly or globally. I therefore supported the resulting form of the resolution.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. " We strongly condemn the terrorist acts perpetrated in France against Charlie Hebdo's workers. We condemn all terrorist acts that occur in many countries. And we do not leave out this condemnation—as most of this house does—state terrorism practiced by countries like Israel against Palestine, practiced in Syria, Lebanon, or the use of drones by the United States against populations in Africa or the Middle East. Defending the need to take action against the financing of terrorism while maintaining privileged relations with countries such as Saudi Arabia that finance, train and support terrorist groups is one more of the contradictions and another sign of the most right-wing hypocrisy in this chamber. That's why I voted against it. The fight against terrorism requires that the root causes of terrorism be attacked; requires profound policy change and respect for international law. And in no way can it legitimize the repressive wave and violation of the rights and freedoms contained in this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — Along with fellow Labour MEPs, I today voted for greater cooperation between EU countries and a renewed anti-terrorism strategy, following last month’s Paris terror attacks. Labour MEPs have called for better cooperation with agencies such as Europol and Eurojust and full use of existing measures such as the Radicalisation Awareness Network (RAN). In addition, Labour MEPs backed a renewal of discussions on EU passenger name records (PNR) based on strong data protection standards and progression on the EU Data Protection Package, which is being blocked by Member States in the European Council.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — Countering terrorism is a major challenge for the entire European Union, which must jointly lead the fight against social violence and hatred, while ensuring the security of all its citizens and respect for their human and civil rights. We are witnessing more and more social animosity, such as racism, xenophobia and Islamophobia that foster achieved pluralism and social tolerance. We need to act towards achieving overall social progress involving all citizens. In my view, Member States of the European Union should contribute more to social inclusion through their economic, education and social policies in the future, ensuring a level playing field for all groups of society. Since September 11, 2001, 100,000 People's 100,000 People's The European Union has introduced almost 239 anti-terrorism measures.  Repressive measures, control of personal data and the movements of our citizens can be counterproductive, which is why I believe democratic and judicial control over counter-terrorism policies, standardised surveillance of exports of military technology and equipment, and good cooperation with Europol, Eurojust and other intelligence services are needed.  A coherent anti-terrorist strategy should focus on monitoring real threats and provide security services with the means and resources to act on specific threats and to achieve early recognition of specific threats. Political dialogue with third world countries should be strengthened with a view to ensuring the safety of our citizens and citizens without violating their privacy and violating their fundamental rights.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The Greens/EFA Group today voted against the Joint Motion for a Resolution on Anti-terrorism Measures, as the resolution is sending the wrong message at the wrong time. The resolution agreed by the four bigger political groups provides a carte blanche for EU governments to scale-back personal freedoms with measures that will fail to properly respond to the terrorist threat. Stepping up mass surveillance will undermine security and is instead a victory for fundamentalists, who are combating precisely such democratic freedoms

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — I support this resolution, whose comprehensive measures, starting with the fight against the root causes of terrorism and radicalisation leading to violent extremism leading to the adoption of the EU's foreign policy strategy to combat international terrorism, constitute a rounded effective whole.  Terrorism is a global threat that needs to be addressed at local, national, European and global levels in order to increase the security of our citizens, protect fundamental values, freedoms, democracies and human rights, and respect international law. We face a serious and growing threat from so-called 'EU foreign fighters', i.e. individuals going to a country where they do not reside or are nationals in order to carry out or plan acts of terrorism or participate in terrorist training.  Member States themselves must make the best use of existing platforms, databases and warning systems at European level to prevent the movement of suspected terrorists, and to strengthen controls at the external borders, to check travel documents more systematicly and effectively, to combat illicit arms trafficking and the illegal use of someone else's identity.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution as I support the EU’s counter-terrorism measures.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - The European Union and the Member States must take responsibility for safeguarding the security and freedom of European citizens. I support the adoption of these measures, as terrorism in all its forms should be strongly condemned and prevented acts that in any way endanger human lives.  Measures should be based on the principles of necessity and proportionality and nevertheless in accordance with the rule of law and international obligations. Every day we are faced with the fact that terrorism and its promotion is on the rise, so security measures need to be tightened through strengthening control at border crossing points and more systematic checks on travel documents. It is important to encourage a more intensive exchange of police data globally.  Member States should closely monitor events within their own borders so that they can prevent fundamentalism from increasing in time through preaching and hate speech. We can counter fundamentalism by uniting efforts with the Muslim community and establishing a better dialogue.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. — I supported the joint resolution of 5 political groups, as terrorism and violent extremism are among the greatest threats to our security and our freedoms. The European Union is facing a constant and increasingly serious terrorist threat, and we are reminded of the recent events in Paris. I voted in favour of the resolution because it emphasises that a counter-terrorism strategy is needed to address the threats posed by terrorism in general, based on a multi-faceted approach and will comprehensively address the fundamental factors for radicalisation leading to violent extremism. I also supported the resolution because it strongly and categorically condemns all acts of terrorism, the promotion of terrorism, the glorification of those involved in terrorism and the advocacy of extremist violent ideologies wherever they are implemented or defended.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the present resolution on counter-terrorism measures, as it contains, inter alia, many measures which propose not only a solution to the consequences, but also a solution to the causes of the situation. However, I believe that due care must be taken not to take good intentions to reduce the standard that we have built together in the EU. When we mention the possibility of temporarily introducing documentary checks in the context of Schengen cooperation, we should proceed consistently at the internal border according to the possibilities provided by the Schengen Borders Code and avoid a situation where checks in the border territory of individual Member States (e.g. document checks) are carried out in such a way that their effect is equivalent to that of carrying out border controls. In that context, it is possible to mention the judgment of the Court of Justice in the joined-ups C-188/10 and C-189/10.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — Tackling terrorism requires delicate manipulation and a balance between safeguarding the privacy and freedom of movement and actions of people on the one hand and the security of society on the other. Decision-making, the adoption of laws and their implementation should move in the right direction in the fight against terrorism and not towards monitoring and controlling people's lives.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution because I believe that its balanced text can trigger real processes to increase the effectiveness of the fight against terrorism. In addition to strengthening European cohesion through the sharing of best practices, the importance of the role of education in addressing the situation in the long term is also highlighted. It is clear that the brutal attacks carried out by terrorists have shocked Europe. Reactions must be harsh and effective, but this should not limit full respect for fundamental rights. The report has this in mind and makes concrete proposals in addition to mapping the situation. This contribution should be an important basis for further action by the EU institutions and the Member States.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) Although the amendments we have proposed as EFDD have not passed, I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution. Among the counter-terrorism measures within the EU, it is also good to include those aimed at preventing aiding and preventing inaction by the authorities set up. The Union's external actions directed against terrorism should also be preventive in the first place by strengthening intelligence actions. Both internal and external extremism should be addressed with a multi-level approach, including the incentive for social cohesion, inclusion and political and religious tolerance.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. In particular, we welcome the following points: - the resolution stresses the indispensable balance that must prevail between, on the one hand, security and, on the other, respect for fundamental freedoms and rights; - it clearly highlights the need to fully implement existing devices, but also to analyse their strengths and weaknesses. Topics covered include: the need to optimise the use of the Schengen information system, the fight against terrorist propaganda, radical networks and internet recruitment, the strengthening of information exchange and the use of existing databases, the use of measures relating to terrorist financing, the use and evaluation of measures related to arms trafficking, the essential role played by Europol and Eurojust , which needs to be strengthened; - it does not ignore the question of the European NRL: the European Parliament is committed to working towards the finalisation of the European PNR directive by the end of 2015, and therefore urges the European Commission to draw the consequences of the Court of Justice's judgment on the Data Conservation Directive as soon as possible. Finally, as we demanded, the resolution urges the Council to unblock discussions on the "Data Protection" package.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the fight against terrorism. One month after the Paris attacks, this text is of high importance. Among other points, it calls for a better approach to tackle radicalisation but also to prevent recruitment and departures to join terrorist organisations. The text also stresses the need to fight against financial support to terrorist organisations and trafficking of firearms. This resolution calls on the Member States to prevent the movement of terrorist suspects by strengthening external border checks. With this vote, the European Parliament also came to agreement on a deadline of the end of 2015 for finalising the European PNR system and urges the Council to make faster progress on the data protection package in order that talks on the EU PNR directive and the data protection legislative package can proceed in parallel.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The Greens/EFA Group today voted against the joint motion for resolution on anti-terrorism measures, as the resolution is sending the wrong message at the wrong time. The resolution agreed by the four bigger political groups provides a carte blanche for EU governments to scale back personal freedoms with measures that will fail to properly respond to the terrorist threat. Instead of pushing for effective measures, the usual suspects who have been continually pushing for mass surveillance and data retention are using the Paris attacks as an excuse to bulldoze through these measures, despite any evidence that they will prove effective in countering the terrorist threat. A coherent counter-terrorism strategy would focus on targeted surveillance of real suspects and ensuring security authorities have the means and resources to focus on specific risks and concrete suspicions, to follow any leads immediately, and to efficiently exchange information about dangerous individuals. This is what we should be trying to achieve. There is also a need to tackle radicalisation in schools and prisons. Finally we are missing a call for a legal definition of profiling. Stepping up mass surveillance will undermine security and is instead a victory for fundamentalists, who are combating precisely such democratic freedoms.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. " Contrary to rumours, the European Parliament has adopted an ambitious resolution in the fight against terrorism. It was more essential than ever to balance security and respect for fundamental freedoms and rights. Although this resolution addresses security issues more than socio-economic issues (prevention and deradicalisation strategies, inclusion, education, anti-discrimination, etc.), it clearly stresses the need to assess existing arrangements, fully implement them and analyse their flaws. Finally, a measured amendment could be tabled on air passenger data, known as PNRs. Indeed, a European NRL will better combat terrorism and transnational organised crime - provided that this collected data is regulated by a strong legal framework allowing the protection of everyone's privacy. This amendment commits parliament to work towards finalising the Directive on a European NNP by the end of 2015, but above all, it calls on the Council to unblock discussions on the "Data Protection" package.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. — Europe must send clear signals on its priorities, including the protection of the freedom and living space of its citizens. We are witnessing recent terrorist attacks that have left a deep mark on our societies, primarily through the spread of fear and uncertainty.  Therefore, I again take the opportunity to stress the need to work, in addition to creating and adopting new measures to combat terrorism, to strengthen the communications of all levels of government, with a focus on trans-border cooperation between the competent national authorities. The best counterterrorism measures alone are not enough if they are not effectively implemented. As a representative from Croatia, the country that has the longest external border of the EU, I hereby appeal to European support in the implementation of proactive control, control and protection of both the land and sea borders of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: Writing. — The spread of terrorism, even among European citizens, is worrying, and this must also be paid attention to it at European level. I support the resolution on counter-terrorism measures. However, I believe that the radicalisation of minority groups can be prevented by thoughtful integration and respect for cultural diversity.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I supported this motion because terrorism, radicalisation and violent extremism are some of the major threats to our security and our freedoms and therefore affect our fundamental rights. Today, more than ever, we reaffirm European values to defend freedom of expression, fundamental rights, democracy and tolerance without using violence. There must be coordination of measures and anti-terrorist policy control in all Member States to deal with this global threat.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted against this Resolution on counter-terrorism measures. The text basically gives the Commission and the Council carte blanche to continue their mass surveillance strategy, even in the absence of evidence, and authorises the use of measures which clearly constitute a violation of fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. " We strongly condemn the terrorist acts perpetrated in France against Charlie Hebdo's workers. We condemn all terrorist acts that occur in many countries. And we do not leave out this condemnation—as most of this house does—state terrorism practiced by countries like Israel against Palestine, practiced in Syria, Lebanon, or the use of drones by the United States against populations in Africa or the Middle East. Defending the need to take action against the financing of terrorism while maintaining privileged relations with countries such as Saudi Arabia that finance, train and support terrorist groups is one more of the contradictions and another sign of the most right-wing hypocrisy in this chamber. That's why I voted against it. The fight against terrorism requires that the root causes of terrorism be attacked; requires profound policy change and respect for international law. And in no way can it legitimize the repressive wave and violation of the rights and freedoms contained in this resolution.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE)
text: Written. - The VVD is convinced of the need to work very closely together within the EU and also with other countries, such as the US, on the fight against and prevention of terror. The VVD does not consider it necessary to create new institutions now or to grant new Community powers because, in the end, each country is best able to combat terror on its territory, particularly in cities, and to apply prevention. Because of the need for the close cooperation mentioned above, the VVD voted in favour of the anti-terror resolution, despite being reserved for a central role for Brussels.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. — My Labour colleagues and I have voted in favour of more cooperation in the fight again terrorism. European countries must use the tools that are already at their disposal and cooperate better with EU agencies. Any information-sharing has to respect EU and national data protection laws. We need to work hard to ensure we have proper security measures that fully respect fundamental rights – concluding negotiations on the Data Protection Package is one way to achieve this.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. — For me, the balance between privacy and security is of great importance. The link between protecting personal data and keeping track of passenger data on planes shows a healthy balance. The European Union must maintain this balance strictly.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. " The present day brings us acts of barbarism that must be condemned and fought. While considering the need for short-term measures to deal with real problems that concern the people, we must condemn attempts to limit basic rights of citizenship in the fight against terrorism and whose exercise has nothing to do with any terrorist activity. There are urgent measures to combat terrorism. And these bottom measures are to end the interference of rich countries in the internal affairs of poor countries, using false pretexts to exploit their natural resources and drain their trade surpluses. Serious policy measures are needed to combat poverty and unemployment and promote a better distribution of wealth and income.  The solution to the conflicts brought by the West that have destabilised the Middle East will only be achieved by political means, with a serious approach that respects the sovereignty of the peoples and their right to choose their path of development.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - I rejected the proposal on counter-terrorism measures, as the measures proposed in it will not improve the current situation. Only a restrictive immigration policy and a ban on foreign fighters returning would at least reduce the risk to our population. However, these points are not even mentioned in the policy paper.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — The European Parliament resolution of 11 February 2015 on counter-terrorism measures contains many correct and important points, but unfortunately also, unfortunately, in paragraph 22, a passage on so-called passenger name records. I have considered whether I should reject the resolution as a whole because of these and other passages. However, after careful consideration, I voted in favour because, for me, the light in the resolution outweighs the shadows. An important point for me was that so far it has been only a Parliament resolution, but not a specific legislative measure (directive or regulation). A resolution is merely symbolic and not legislative. That is why I should like to point out at this point that I refuse to monitor travellers more and more fully. I will not agree with any legislative initiatives on passenger data that may follow. Because in case of doubt, I choose freedom.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Terrorism is increasingly threatening international peace, security and democracy. Just think of the brutal attack on the satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo on 7 January 2015. It is therefore all the more necessary for the European Union and its Member States to develop their own integrated strategy to combat international terrorism, while always based on respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights. I believe that we must also aim for external actions to combat terrorism internationally, aiming at prevention and combating, for example, the illegal arms trade, from which we must not forget, western countries in particular, make great profits. Member States should make better use of existing instruments in the Schengen context and improve security cooperation with third countries, particularly in the southern neighbourhood.  A united response by the European Union to the challenge of international terrorism has become indispensable and must be pursued together by all European governments. It will certainly require an effort to increase the sharing of information, for example with regard to passengers and air traffic, but a delicate balance between privacy and security is certainly necessary in order to overcome this challenge that concerns us all.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the unacceptable joint resolution of the People's Party, Social Democrats, Liberals and Conservatives-Reformists because, taking advantage of the pretext of terrorism, it calls for the stepping up and proliferation of repressive measures and the strengthening of the already complex national and EU repression mechanisms imposed: limiting and abolishing basic democratic rights and popular freedoms, generalising the passenger file on air transport (PNR) , strengthening cooperation between secret services and repressive mechanisms between the Member States and the EU, a generalised plan linking repression within EU Member States to imperialist interventions in third countries, with particular emphasis on the region of the South-East, Middle East, North Africa. In the same direction, the European Council, with the signature of the SYRIZA-ANEL Government, adopted all the above unacceptable and dangerous decisions. By identifying the "fight against terrorism" with action against "radicalisation", "violent extremism" and the "violent ideologies" that constitute the EU's "counter-terrorism policy", the labour-grassroots movement and its actions are targeted, which is also the real target of the whole huge network of repression that is developing in the EU and its Member States, in order to shield the power of monopolies.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. " For our part we also condemn the terrorist acts that took place in France, just as we condemn all the attacks that have occurred in many countries of the world. We do not leave out, as most ep does, state terrorism by countries such as Israel in Palestine, Syria and Lebanon, or the use of unmanned aircraft by the US against defenceless populations in Africa, the Middle East or Asia. This is yet another episode of the hypocrisy that characterises the majority of the EP, while defending the need to take measures to combat terrorist financing and maintain privileged relations with countries such as Turkey or Saudi Arabia - but not only! -, finance, train and support terrorist groups. It is indeed an act of coherence for those who have advocated support for terrorist groups, notably linked to al-Qaeda or the Islamic State, to destabilise Syria or Iraq.  The firm fight that must be fought against terrorism, inside or outside the EU, requires a profound change in policies and in no way can legitimise the repressive and violating wave of rights, freedoms and guarantees that is strengthened here, removing even more sovereignty of the Member States in the field of justice.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. — Currently, terrorism is the biggest destabilising factor in the EU, in addition to the crisis in Ukraine and the Greek threat to the euro area. I therefore voted in favour of the important resolution, the so-called anti-terrorism pact, which was also strongly supported by ALDE, S&D, ECR, EFDD and some other Members at the initiative of the EPP Group. I am pleased that the resolution was adopted by broad consensus, as this has shown Parliament a unified desire to protect European citizens. The EPP negotiators, Members Hohlmeier and Gonzalez Pons, have done an excellent job and after years of delay we have come to the consensus on the exchange of air passenger data (without forgetting the maximum possible protection of privacy).  In the resolution, we set out a number of concrete measures: limiting the spread of radicalism in prisons, keeping records of jihadists, establishing a legal framework for prosecuting so-called foreign fighters, controlling the financial flows that sustain terrorists, better control of Schengen's external borders, making more frequent use of existing options for occasional internal border controls, and free movement within the EU remains our priority. We have advocated better cooperation between national intelligence services, the establishment of a so-called blacklist of jihadists, cooperation with internet providers to limit the spread of terrorist propaganda across social networks and for educational programmes addressing the root causes of radicalisation.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, yesterday I heard one of the right-wing UK MEPs state that politicians who support freedom of expression, religion and enterprise should feel a chill when hearing the words ‘internet governance’.  Now I value these rights extremely highly and that is why, rather than simply feeling negative or even scared when this issue is raised, I prefer to use my role as an MEP to call on the Commission to use this valuable opportunity offered by the IGF for a truly multi-stakeholder forum for managing the internet. Parliament can play a crucial role in turning this into a reality by participating in the annual IGF meeting, and I urge the Commission to coordinate closely with Parliament to make sure the voices of our citizens are heard.  The colleague I referred to also stated that he does feel, however, that there should be a means of preventing dissemination of material on the internet which facilitates terrorism. Now knowing this, I am convinced that he will welcome the measures proposed by my party which call for reviewing police and CPS guidance to ensure anti-semitism, islamophobia and other hate crimes – prime breeding grounds for extremism – are adequately tackled on social media.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we know that today almost 3 billion people, or about 40% of the global population, are attending the network. Europe, through the Digital Agenda, sees internet access as a right. The Internet Governance Forum, designed according to the principles of multilateralism, multistakeholders, democracy and transparency, is a significant moment to deepen the most important issues but also the critical issues of the network. The last meeting, however, highlighted all its contradictions. Much, in fact, makes us debate, for example, that the decision to hold this important event has established Turkey as the host nation, a nation that still pursues 29 Twitter users for simply expressing criticism of the government. The IGF must keep alive the debate and debate on fundamental issues, such as net neutrality and the digital divide, but it must not forget that the right to freedom of speech must be guaranteed above all on the web as well.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to remind you of the importance of the Internet in our lives both as a means of communication and as a channel of information, as a source of innovation, growth, democracy and pluralism. At the same time, there is a growing need to protect the freedoms of the Internet in all its dimensions, without neglecting the necessary security needs. To this end, I consider invaluable the contribution of the various stakeholders involved in the Forum for Internet Governance, which brings together not only national and international institutions but also other actors who, in supporting civil society bodies, protect and promote a free and independent use of the Internet. The important role played by the Internet Governance Forum, including with the participation of the Commission and Parliament, therefore leads us to be in favour of continuing its work while respecting freedom of expression and at the same time the necessary security needs. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted against the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum. For the climate as well as for human rights or the internet, we can see the inefficiency of these global projects. All are reduced to vain incantations and prove useless in meeting the real challenges posed to our countries and our fellow citizens. At least we could agree here that the internet is not under the control of any American government agency, jeopardizing our freedoms. But when the Commission deplores this state of events, it is to regret not exercising general surveillance on Europeans. It is therefore the States which, as Russia does, can only demand the repatriation of data on their territory and defend their fellow citizens through the exercise of the regal functions.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of renewing the mandate for the Internet Governance Forum, although I would have preferred the rights of the child to be made more explicit, which are also necessary, as fundamental and to be respected. I believe that yesterday was the international day dedicated to safer internet. The debate on this issue is very strong and tomorrow we will hear from the Commission reporting on the application of the directive on sexual abuse and child pornography on the Internet. It will also be important to present a resolution by Parliament, but I hope that the Global Forum will also take this opportunity to deepen what are today real challenges to a dilemma that must certainly see the elements of freedom and the protection of privacy, but I hope not only that of adults but also of minors. We are faced with real forms of deception, grooming, grooming and exploitation, protected by anonymity, of minors and children, and we are also faced with the fact that the regulation we have adopted has not yet been approved, unfortunately, because some Member States do not yet agree and therefore the right to be forgotten for minors as well as the protection of children by parents against social forums have not yet been approved. For these reasons, I hope that the Global Forum will not forget the rights of the child, which are not minor rights.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — A resolution on the renewal of the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance was voted on today. My vote was positive because the renewal of the mandate is a good thing. Furthermore, both the explicit reference to net neutrality and the reference to the Internet as an open and free instrument and a place where fundamental rights and freedoms are non-negotiable are to be welcomed. I believe, however, that some aspects need to be highlighted more stressed. In particular, as a member of the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Internal Market, Culture, Education and the Internal Market, I would have liked an explicit reference to the free and full sharing of knowledge, as well as to the free movement of culture. Another aspect that deserves to be highlighted was the strengthening of the delegation sent by the European Parliament. In my opinion, the Commission must play a central role in view of the representation of the citizens exercised by Members. Finally, it should be stressed more stressed that the European Union must be able to speak with a single voice on this issue, which is of global importance. The governance of the Internet is in fact a fundamental and central issue to be addressed at European level, given that the network is global and we now live in an increasingly digital world, where homo sapiens is turning into homo digitalis.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The objective of the Internet Governance Forum (FGI) is to implement the mandate of the World Summit on the Information Society (WCC) as a contribution to a democratic, transparent and multilateral political dialogue, which expands the range of issues of economic governance on the Internet. This resolution aims to pressure the United Nations Assembly to renew the mandate of the IGI, strengthen its resources and maintain the multilateral model of internet governance. In addition, eu stakeholders are proposed to maintain financial support to their secretariat to ensure the development of an efficient and independent organisation and thus contribute to the democratisation, openness and neutrality of the internet.  These are all objectives which we think are appropriate and fair, so I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. — I support this resolution which promotes an inclusive and multi-stakeholder model of internet governance and the improvement of its international governance in the future.  I am especially pleased that the United States will be abandoning its supervision of the IANA (IP address ranges) function, provided by ICANN, the U.S. law firm in charge of the allocation and management of domain names on the Internet, as early as September 2015. The goal now is the internationalization of ICANN and all contracts ICANN has with the U.S. administration.  Just a few months ago, alongside the wine industry, governments and the Commission, we denounced the poor functioning of ICANN and called for a thorough reform of it. Indeed, its programme of creating and assigning new generic domain names on the internet in the wine sector (.vin/.wine) did not comply at all with European and international legislation on the protection of geographical indications.  We will therefore remain mobilized in the coming weeks and months in favour of global internet management, which, while including the interests of all, also acts in accordance with international law on the protection of quality agricultural and food products.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — On the initiative of the United Nations, the Internet Governance Forum (IGF) was established in 2005 to organise meetings of various stakeholders for a democratic and transparent political dialogue. These meetings will discuss a wide range of issues related to Internet governance, such as.B net neutrality, data security and improving global Internet access. As the mandate of the IGF expires at the end of 2015, the European Parliament calls on the United Nations General Assembly to extend the mandate and make more resources available to it. Because we need a sustainable and forward-looking Internet policy, I very much welcome this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum. Whether it is for climate, human rights or the internet, we can see the inefficiency of these global projects. All are reduced to vain incantations and are unable to meet the challenges faced by peoples. The very ambition to make the internet a transparent, neutral, secure, reliable and infinitely growing global space is utopian. On the other hand, it is possible to find a conciliation around a refusal to see this international network under the influence of a particular interest endangering our freedoms, in particular the interest of a foreign power that deploys surveillance means throughout the world. But when the Commission deplores this state of events, it is to regret not exercising general surveillance on the peoples of Europe. It is the States that alone can demand the repatriation of data on their territory and defend their citizens through the exercise of the regal functions.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Governments should not be interfering in the internet, and freedom should be respected (within the context of the rule of law, of course). Neither should the European Union be interfering.  I therefore voted against.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to extend the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum. The objective of the IGF is to hold forward discussions on a wide range of internet governance issues and, where appropriate, to make recommendations to the international community. The EP sends delegations to each annual IGF meeting; they promote European values and communicate with civil society organisations and representatives of national parliaments involved in those events. It is the EU's duty to increase the influence of these exchanges of views in political debate. I agree that lessons can already be learned from the productive discussions and actions that have taken place so far in the IGF, particularly in the areas of regulatory aspects of electronic communications and data protection.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against it because I consider that "internet governance" - a term used to describe "global arrangements that guarantee the proper functioning, accessibility and technological standards of the internet in all countries" - undermines the interests of Member States. Have the threats to their security and independence not been sufficiently highlighted by the recent revelations about the existence of large-scale U.S. surveillance programs? However, it is not so much the fact that europeans are being spied on that bothers the Commission, but rather the fact that it is unable to do so itself. European nations must be able to protect the personal data of their citizens, as well as maintain control over the governance of their strategic data. I therefore challenge all forms of internet surveillance, whether from the United States or the Commission. Russia provides us with a good example to follow in this regard: it has called, in this forum on internet governance, for data storage to be carried out within its territory. We can - and must - demand it as well to defend the sovereignty and independence of our nations.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The Internet has been the great invention of the last twenty years. It is the responsibility of the European Union to support the Internet Governance Forum and to raise the impact of these exchanges on political debates. Improving internet access around the world is critical, as is continuing efforts to ensure legal protection of net neutrality, which is an indispensable condition for safeguarding freedom of information and expression.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The internet is now one of the only areas in the world to allow freedom of expression, but it is also an indispensable tool for present and future development, although it remains essential to monitor its excesses - such as the terrorist or mafia networks that are also present in numbers. Even if, like the Commission, we can only deplore the American grip on internet governance (patriotic colleagues have also tabled a motion for a resolution for the creation of a European search engine), the Commission must not want to apply itself, to Europeans, surveillance which it denounces elsewhere. Deploring the inefficiency of such governance projects, I therefore voted against the renewal of the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) The text of the resolution is considered and I support it, and I therefore supported it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Resolution because I share the need to renew the mandate of the Forum – of which the EU is also the main contributor, to which it finances 30% of its activities - and the multi-party negotiating approach as a pillar of internet governance.  I also consider it key to ensure, as the Resolution demands, the principle of net neutrality as an indispensable condition for ensuring freedom of information and expression, and promoting innovation, growth and employment. Without neutrality there is no network; therefore, it is essential to ensure an open and independent internet. Europe cannot be left behind when President Obama has clearly opted in in the United States for the creation of the strictest possible measures to protect neutrality, and the FCC president has proposed preventing network access providers from discriminating against content or applications, appealing to internet regulation as a basic public service. Europe must also take advantage of the investment plan to maximize broadband networks and ensure a connected continent, while combating the digital divide. Likewise, the process of globalization of ICANN's functions needs to be completed.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it advocated the extension of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum. The role and function of the Internet Governance Forum (IGF) is to discuss various internet governance issues at the highest level in the world and, where appropriate, to make recommendations to the international community. Growth linked to the internet economy is projected to be close to 11% in the EU and is expected to grow to 5.7% in 2016, with its share of GDP rising by 3.8% in 2010. Overall, the Internet is a key pillar of the Digital Single Market and promotes, inter alia, innovation, growth, trade, democracy, cultural diversity and human rights, and Parliament has therefore induced the UN General Assembly to extend the mandate of the IGF, to increase its resources and to strengthen the multi-task internet governance model.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the renewal of the mandate of the FGI (Forum for The Governance of the Internet). The potential and added value of the Internet is in its dynamism, but it must respect the rights of online users, increasingly guaranteeing access for all regardless of geographical area. Europe now presents an extremely fragmented framework, so we must make every effort at national, European and international level to extend these rights as far as possible. For these very reasons, and given the economic and social importance of the Internet, governance and the rules relating to this instrument must be the result of a public and inclusive debate. The Forum has in the past stimulated an interesting democratic, transparent and multi-participatory dialogue and I therefore support its renewal.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — I support the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum (IGF), as in the past period it has indeed contributed to facilitating open and transparent discussion between participants from different interest spheres, in which support was also given by the European Parliament by sending its delegations to forum meetings. The sustainability, security and stability of internet governance will also be of utmost importance in the coming period, in which the European Parliament should continue to give its full support. I think that the European Parliament should continue to send its delegations to IGF meetings in the future, and thus continue to contribute to the stability and security of internet use.  I also welcome the process of genuine globalisation of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) and the creation of a new governance model, and I expect and hope for a stronger involvement of the European Union in this process.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted no because I personally consider that the Internet Governance Forum did not execute efficiently its mandate.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The emergence of the Internet has practically revolutionized traditional communication patterns. Unfettered access to information has brought many economic advantages and contributed to technological developments.  The inventor of the World Wide Web, Tim Bernes-Lee, argued that the internet is more of a social creation, designed to help people work together. The social impact created by non-discriminatory access to knowledge and the availability of a global information resource has also required more accountability and transparency in the use of the internet. I believe that renewing the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum would give users more confidence and guarantee the veracity of the information content. Strengthening cyber infrastructure security will contribute to the development of e-commerce and strengthen consumers' secure access to electronic transactions.   I support the resolution on renewing the mandate of this forum, because I am convinced that, through its tasks, it will provide solutions for the stability and safety of the Internet.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The Internet must have a regulation for the safety of citizens and the debate on it must be continued.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Internet Governance Forum (IGF) has the role and function of discussing a wide range of issues related to Internet governance and, where appropriate, making recommendations to the international community, based on the mandate of the World Information Society Summit (WSIS) to organise forums for a democratic, transparent and multilateral political dialogue. I would point out that on the basis of the fruitful exchanges that have taken place within the IFG, conclusions can be drawn which can be put into practice, in particular with regard to the regulatory aspects of electronic communications, as well as data security and privacy issues.  I support the renewal by the UN General Assembly of the mandate of the IGF and the strengthening of its resources as well as the need for a coordinated position at European level on internet governance, namely strengthening the sustainability of the multilateral model, making actors and processes at national, regional and international level more inclusive, transparent and accountable.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. — The agreed resolution stresses that the European Parliament has always defended this Forum and has always participated in its meetings, and that its mandate must be renewed and its resources strengthened. And, on a crucial issue such as net neutrality, it stresses the need to ensure an open and independent internet and manifests the "crucial" of continuing efforts to ensure legal protection of net neutrality as an "indispensable condition" to ensure freedom of information and expression and boost growth and employment.
