It therefore goes in line with the Group's position in the face of positions such as that held by the Spanish Government, in favour of opening the door to the 'development of business models based on reasonable traffic management', that is, of differentiated services that take precedence over each other, as the Minister of Industry has shown in his contribution to the European Commission's strategy to complete the digital single market. The resolution also values the process of globalizing ICANN's functions.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Internet Governance Forum (FGI) is an institution that promotes dialogue between the various public and private actors involved in internet governance. The forum sets up a multilateral approach to managing the various challenges related to the internet, such as net neutrality and the protection of fundamental freedoms. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the UN General Assembly to renew the mandate of the Forum in 2015.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the renewal of the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance. The Forum on Internet Governance is an important opportunity for discussion on technological standards and the proper functioning of the Internet, which has been happening every year for almost ten years, involving institutions, businesses and civil society. The Internet has now become a fundamental communication tool with a huge impact on society as a whole and which has the potential to become one of the most powerful resources to successfully face the social, cultural, educational and economic challenges facing a globalised society. Considering that the Forum represents a decisive moment of reflection on the governance of the Internet, in particular with regard to its proper functioning, equal access, security and technological standards, I voted in favour of renewing and supporting the Forum.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — We are voting in favour of renewing the mandate at the Internet Governance Forum. Net neutrality and the protection of personal data are the essential basis for an open platform that allows free expression, freedom of information and, above all, freedom of criticism in a simple and protected way, given that these freedoms are the very pillars of modern democracy.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted against this text, which is yet another attempt to undermine the sovereignty of nations, particularly in the area of data protection. After the recent scandals over US surveillance programmes, the Commission seems offended that it itself has not had the idea of spying on the citizens of the Member States. The European Union therefore finds itself in this Forum negotiating its independence from the United States. Only Russia has dared to raise the question of its independence by requesting, in the context of this forum, that the storage of its data be carried out within its territory. Patriotic Members, because they are committed to defending the interests of France, but also, and above all, protecting the freedom of their fellow citizens, will focus on ensuring that France recovers the management of our country's strategic data.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of renewing the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance, in view of the fact that the Internet is the backbone of the digital single market. I am convinced of the importance of continuing to make efforts to promote the legal protection of net neutrality as an essential prerequisite for safeguarding freedom of information and expression, promoting growth and employment through the creation of internet-related opportunities for innovation and business, and promoting and protecting cultural and linguistic diversity in an optimal way for all. Although the IGF does not adopt formal conclusions, I believe it is the European Union's responsibility to increase the impact of trade in the policy discussion, as this provides a positive and concrete framework for defining the future of the Internet on the basis of a multi-participatory approach.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. — Established in 2006, the Internet Governance Forum (FGI) has as its primary role and function to discuss a wide range of internet governance issues and to make recommendations to the international community if necessary. The Internet is a key pillar in the digital single market, promoting innovation, growth, trade, cultural diversity and human rights. We must therefore be concerned about extending internet access worldwide, maintaining the internet as an open and common resource, rejecting the idea of a state-controlled Internet and recognising that our fundamental freedoms and human rights are non-negotiable and must be protected on the network. With the renewal of the FGI mandate, the strengthening of its resources and the maintenance of the multilateral internet governance model, we are contributing to ensuring, in the future, an open and independent Internet, non-discriminatory access to knowledge, stimulating growth and jobs, promoting and protecting cultural and linguistic diversity and ensuring the legal protection of Internet neutrality , a precondition for safeguarding freedom of expression.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — Today the Internet represents a complex and revolutionary ecosystem, which has brought about many changes in the everyday lives of us citizens, distorting the way we communicate and exchange information, and profoundly influencing the social, political and economic sectors, thus making the labour market more efficient and also improving the supply of goods and services. With its potential to promote sustainable social and economic development, the Internet has so far allowed a continuous exchange of constantly updated knowledge and information, but above all it has promoted virtuous mechanisms of transparency in good governance that often collide with the will of some States to control, censor and monitor the Web and its users , as well as citizens. I am therefore in favour of renewing the IGF's mandate and strengthening the resources made available to it, as I believe in democratic, transparent and multi-participatory political dialogue.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Internet Governance Forum (IGF) offers a positive and concrete context for the shaping of the internet’s future on the basis of a multi-stakeholders approach. The resolution stresses the EU’s responsibility to support and continue to participate in the IGF and the need to improve internet access across the world, and rejects the idea of a state-controlled internet and mass surveillance of the internet. I have thus voted in favour of this resolution which calls on the UN General Assembly to renew the mandate of the IGF, strengthen its resources and maintain the multi-stakeholder model for new internet governance.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the adoption by the European Parliament of the motion for a resolution on the renewal of the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance, during which, annually, representatives of industry and civil society discuss technological standards and the proper functioning of the Internet. It should be stressed that it is the European Union's responsibility to give the Forum due importance in the course of the forthcoming political discussions. With the adoption of the resolution, the European Parliament called on Member States, the Commission and all stakeholders to further strengthen the sustainability of the multi-stakeholder model, making stakeholders more accountable at national, regional and international level. It is essential to reaffirm the legal protection of net neutrality, which is an essential prerequisite for safeguarding freedom of information and expression, and to stimulate, among other things, the sustainable sharing of the common good and to encourage greater participation in decision-making by citizens. Finally, the economic and social importance of online user data, which must be defended, was underlined, as should a level playing field for companies operating on the web.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The objective of the Internet Governance Forum (FGI) is to implement the mandate of the World Summit on the Information Society (WCC) as a contribution to a democratic, transparent and multilateral political dialogue, which expands the range of issues of economic governance on the Internet. This resolution aims to pressure the United Nations Assembly to renew the mandate of the IGI, strengthen its resources and maintain the multilateral model of internet governance. In addition, eu stakeholders are proposed to maintain financial support to their secretariat to ensure the development of an efficient and independent organisation and thus contribute to the democratisation, openness and neutrality of the internet.  These are all objectives which we think are appropriate and fair, so I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — This resolution deals with the renewal of the Internet Governance Forum (IGF) mandate beyond 2015. The IGF is a multi-stakeholder forum for policy dialogue on issues of internet governance. It was created in 2005 and has held an annual meeting since then. The European Parliament has sent ad-hoc delegations to every annual meeting of the IGF. The IGF mandate was initially for five years. It was renewed for another 5 years in 2010. The IGF mandate now expires in 2015. I support the work done by this forum to facilitate transparent discussions amongst stakeholders from all over the world, many of whom had not cooperated closely before. Hence I voted in favour of extending its mandate.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the renewal of the mandate of the Forum on The Governance of the Internet, of which I am also a co-signatory. The Internet is now a real virtual agora that daily joins the historic squares of our cities. The growing importance of the Internet has not, however, yet been accompanied by adequate governance, which guarantees its transparency, full democracy, security and neutrality. I am therefore convinced that the EU, including through the renewal of the mandate of this Forum promoted at the United Nations, must be increasingly a protagonist in international for a and actively work with the main partners in the world for a thorough reorganisation of the stable and effective internet management and governance structure.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The European Parliament calls on the UN General Assembly to renew the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum for five years, which is coming to an end at the end of 2015. This informal and international forum for debate brings together governments, the private sector and civil society each year to discuss issues related to governance and access to the internet, its neutrality and the protection of fundamental freedoms and human rights. Because it is necessary for a specialised body to exist and to organise debates on the subject at the sensitive and crucial as the governance of the internet, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. By this vote, the European Parliament voted overwhelmingly in favour of the renewal of the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance by the Un General Assembly. The Forum's mission is to discuss a wide range of issues related to internet governance and to make recommendations to the international community. It was particularly necessary to recall our commitment to the multi-party model of internet governance by strengthening openness, transparency, and above all the accountability of the digital world.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — Since 2005, key issues of internet governance, such as equal access for all and security, have been discussed annually under the auspices of the UN General Assembly at the Internet Governance Forum. Of course, this inclusive and multi-actor model of internet governance, which enables governments, the private sector and civil society to develop principles, standards, rules and decision-making procedures in their respective roles.  With its resolution, the European Parliament therefore calls for the extension of the mandate of this forum beyond 2015. At the next Internet Governance Forum, which will take place from 10 to 13 November 2015 in Brazil, the European Union will have to ensure that it expresses an ambitious and coherent position, in the service of its political and economic values and interests.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — The role of the Internet Governance Forum is to discuss issues related to internet governance and to make recommendations to the international community. The IPF is making an effective contribution (in cooperation with the MS and the Commission) to the development of a coherent and comprehensive EU strategy and building a positive and concrete framework to shape the future of the internet. The current mandate of the IPF is coming to an end. The UN General Assembly will debate a possible renewal in 2015. I express my support for a renewal of this mandate.  The internet is the backbone of the digital single market. It promotes innovation, growth, trade, democracy, cultural diversity and human rights. Economically, it accounts for almost 11% of the EU's growth and its contribution to GDP is expected to reach 5.7% in 2016. This is therefore a key issue for Europe. Europe must also address many issues related to the internet: regulatory aspects of electronic communications, data security, privacy, net neutrality, protection of fundamental freedoms and human rights online, fight against radicalism, etc.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. - The Internet Governance Forum (IGF) aims to implement the mandate of the Information Society Summit (WSIS) and is responsible for providing a multi-stakeholder global forum enabling governments and representatives of the private and civil sectors to discuss key issues affecting the governance of the Internet. During the ninth IGF held in September 2014, the European Union's top priorities were: enhanced internet access throughout the world; maintaining the Internet as a global, open and common resource; greater accountability and transparency in the multi-player internet governance model; rejection of the state-controlled Internet; and acknowledging that our fundamental freedoms and human rights must not be negotiable and must be protected online. The European Parliament's joint motion for a resolution underlines the importance of the European Union delegation continuing to participate in the Forum and highlights the priorities mentioned above, advocates an open and independent internet as a common global resource, non-discriminatory access to knowledge and the protection of freedom of expression. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum. Whether it is for climate, human rights or the internet, we can see the inefficiency of these global projects. All are reduced to vain incantations and are unable to meet the challenges faced by peoples. The very ambition to make the internet a transparent, neutral, secure, reliable and infinitely growing global space seems utopian. On the other hand, it is possible to find a conciliation around a refusal to see this international network under the influence of a particular interest endangering our freedoms, in particular the interest of a foreign power that deploys surveillance means throughout the world. But when the Commission deplores this state of events, it is to regret not exercising general surveillance on the peoples of Europe. It is the States that alone can demand the repatriation of data on their territory and defend their citizens through the exercise of the regal functions.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. — Dear Colleagues, I supported the proposed resolution on the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, as during its lifetime it has proven to be a successful democratic platform for the exchange of good practices, working mainly for discussions on internet governance.  The Internet plays an increasingly important role in people's lives and daily lives, while also promoting innovation, trade, growth, democracy and cultural diversity. I agree that Parliament, together with the Member States and the Commission, must continue its participation in the future meetings of the Internet Governance Forum with a significant delegation in order to contribute to the effective formulation of a coherent and comprehensive approach by the European Union. I believe that the UN General Assembly should renew the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum and maintain the model involving multiple stakeholders in internet governance in order, among other things, to improve internet access worldwide.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We abstained in the vote on this resolution. We understand the importance of discussion forums on internet governance and more, if possible, the important role to be played by the representation of plural parliamentary delegations within it. However, we do not share the governance model applied so far in internet governance, nor the leading role of U.S.-centric ICANN and large technology companies. We highly value the presence of organized civil society, but we understand that it is in a situation of total asymmetry in the face of large internet companies. In this sense, we understand that internet governance must be strongly democratized and internationalized and must have increasing user participation.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — The need to ensure an open and independent Internet as a global common good, together with future non-discriminatory access to knowledge, is underlined, based on the initiatives and needs of stakeholders as well as freedom of expression, and it is stressed that it is important to continue efforts to ensure the legal protection of net neutrality.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum. The IGF allows democratic and transparent policy dialogue between a multitude of stakeholders. I believe that the Internet should be a public and open space. The IGF should reflect this, so I welcome the reform and extension of its mandate. It is important for my constituents in Wales that Internet freedoms and net neutrality are respected.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The Internet is a fundamental pillar of the digital single market and promotes innovation, economic growth, trade, democracy, cultural diversity and human rights. I voted in favour of this resolution as it is necessary to maintain the multilateral internet governance model to which the Internet Governance Forum makes a valuable contribution, and has already provided lessons on the regulatory aspects of electronic communications, data security and privacy, cybercrime and the protection of critical infrastructure. I also advocate a neutral intranet and a more active role on the part of the EU in its governance.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The TASK of the FGI is to discuss a wide range of issues related to internet governance and, if necessary, to make recommendations to the international community. The European Union's priorities in this area are to extend global internet access, to maintain the Internet as a global, open and common resource, non-discriminatory access to knowledge, greater accountability and transparency of the multilateral internet governance model, rejection of the idea of a state-controlled Internet and recognition that our fundamental human freedoms and rights are non-negotiable and must be protected on the network. For all this, I agree with the renewal of the FGI mandate as well as the strengthening of its resources, increasing the inclusive participation of all stakeholders.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The Internet is a multifaceted, multifunctional tool with multiple facets that are difficult to trace to units.  The positive effects for the dissemination of information, the circulation of good practices and, last but not least, for the promotion of the process of bottom-up democratic participation, generated by the Internet, are now indisputable. At the same time, there is no shortage of concerns about the use of the internet by criminal or terrorist organisations, as well as the fraudulent or criminal use of the weakest and most defenceless, such as minors and the elderly. In this context, the issue of human rights is also particularly important: the Internet is now to be considered a right that must be guaranteed to every person. This issue is strongly linked to freedom of expression, which is often threatened by restrictions on access to the network or the sharing of information content imposed in some countries, including Europe. For these and other reasons, which are included in the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the Internet Global Forum, I believe that we should welcome this initiative launched by the United Nations in 2006 to promote the joint and multilateral political dialogue on the governance of the Internet.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The objective of the Internet Governance Forum (FGI) is to implement the mandate of the World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) as a contribution to a democratic, transparent and multilateral political dialogue that expands the range of internet governance issues. The purpose of this resolution is to pressure the Un General Assembly to renew the FGI mandate, strengthen its resources and maintain the multilateral model of Internet governance. It is also proposed to the EU's stakeholders to maintain financial support to the secretariat to ensure the development of an efficient, independent organisation and thus contribute to the democratisation, openness and neutrality of the internet. These are objectives that seem appropriate and fair to us. The Internet should be a global resource of broad access to knowledge and information, communication, cultural diversity and freedom of expression.  In line with the need to improve safe access, doubts and reservations remain as to the mechanisms and organisations that hold the power to ensure this security. We do not follow attempts to push the provision of some services to the private sector, alienating the public service, which in this regard is the guarantor of social prices to the population and a safe and universal Internet.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — One of the main reasons for the establishment of the Internet Governance Forum was to provide the basis for a forward-looking debate on a wide range of problems relating to the Internet and its management and, in certain cases, to make appropriate recommendations to the international community. Although the Internet Governance Forum does not adopt any formal conclusions, it is important for the European Union to support its functioning in order to help increase the impact of political debates, which often offer a positive and concrete context for shaping the future of internet use. The European Parliament should also participate in future meetings of the Forum on Internet Governance through a delegation, thereby contributing to the creation of a comprehensive and coherent approach by the European Union, together with the Member States and the European Commission. The European Union should learn lessons from the fruitful exchanges of views in the context of the forum's negotiations on Internet governance, in particular on regulatory aspects of electronic communications, data security and privacy.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) Support is reiterated by asking that Parliament should be able to continue to participate with a large and politically inclusive delegation in future FGI meetings.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — My vote is in favour of renewing the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, because it stresses the need to improve internet access at global level and underlines the need to ensure an open and independent internet as a global common good, together with future non-discriminatory access to knowledge, based on stakeholder initiatives and needs , as well as freedom of expression.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted against the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum. This mandate gives the European Union the same standing in the IGF as a nation state. Not only does it give the EU more power but it directly attacks the sovereignty of Member States and the principle of subsidiarity. There would be no additional benefits to the EU being awarded this status in this Forum.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. — The main role of the Internet Governance Forum is to have forward-look discussions on a wide range of issues relating to internet governance, as well as to make recommendations to the international community. The renewal of the MANDATE of the FGI will be discussed at the United Nations General Assembly in 2015, which is why it should be noted that the Internet is a pillar of the digital single market and that, according to various forecasts, the growth relative to the internet economy will be almost 11% in the EU and its contribution to GDP will increase from 3.8% in 2010 to 5.7% in 2016. The Internet must continue to be a neutral, open-to-all resource that allows us to advance data transparency, governance, security and privacy, as well as ensure non-discriminatory access to knowledge, respect for fundamental freedoms and human rights, as well as freedom of expression. For these reasons I think it is important for the European Parliament to continue to support the IGI.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted with conviction for the joint resolution on the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum. I believe that we really need a coherent and comprehensive European approach in order to promote the network and the great opportunities it brings in a free and open way. The Internet Governance Forum must remain an inclusive and open place, with the aim of involving all the main players in the network by empowering them towards common commitments: the principle of net neutrality, respect for freedom of expression online, data protection, access to knowledge and information.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I welcome the result of the vote extending the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum for the next five years. The Forum's mission is not yet over and I am pleased that most of you and your Members are aware of this. The Internet is a public space, by its very nature free and accessible to everyone. It promotes democracy, cultural diversity, the economy. It provides an impetus for innovation and all exchanges. It is intended to serve the EU's digital single market.  The Internet works on the basis of cooperation and trust, it needs clear rules. The internet economy is projected to grow by almost 11% in the EU. By contrast, its share of GDP is expected to increase from 3.8% in 2010 to 5.7% in 2016. 2015 will therefore be a key year for internet governance, as the resolution emphasises. The Internet is a global resource and should never be monopolized by individual groups. It must not become hostage to particular economic or political interests. Its enormous potential must be exploited in guaranteeing the trust of its users by processing their personal data in a secure manner.  The Internet Governance Forum is intended to continue the implementation of the mandate obtained at the World Summit on the Information Society.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against this resolution calling on the UN General Assembly to renew the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance and allocate more resources to it.  The aim of the organization is to facilitate a "democratic, transparent and multilateral" dialogue with the aim of promoting the protection of fundamental online freedoms, including freedom of expression and respect for privacy.  However, this body, under the tutelage of the United Nations, has proved completely ineffective. It is unable to defend the freedom of the Internet, which everyone saw during Edward Snowden's revelations about the US spying system PRISM.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on this resolution. We understand the importance of discussion forums on internet governance and more, if possible, the important role to be played by the representation of plural parliamentary delegations within it. However, we do not share the governance model applied so far in internet governance, nor the leading role of U.S.-centric ICANN and large technology companies. We highly value the presence of organized civil society, but we understand that it is in a situation of total asymmetry in the face of large internet companies. In this sense, we understand that internet governance must be strongly democratized and internationalized and must have increasing user participation.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this as I support the Internet Governance Forum (IGF) and believe that it has facilitated open and transparent discussions amongst stakeholders from all over the world. I would like to see the Forum continued and the EU play a key role in the governance of the Internet with increased globalisation.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on this resolution. We understand the importance of discussion forums on internet governance and more, if possible, the important role to be played by the representation of plural parliamentary delegations within it. However, we do not share the governance model applied so far in internet governance, nor the leading role of U.S.-centric ICANN and large technology companies. We highly value the presence of organized civil society, but we understand that it is in a situation of total asymmetry in the face of large internet companies. In this sense, we understand that internet governance must be strongly democratized and internationalized and must have increasing user participation.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, which is a multi-stakeholder forum for policy dialogue on issues of Internet governance. Although the renewal of the mandate is a consensual subject, I must emphasise the importance of the work of this institution. It promotes open and transparent discussions between stakeholders from all over the world, and facilitates a common understanding of how to maximise Internet opportunities and address risks and challenges that may arise. It is important for the European Parliament to continue to participate with a substantial delegation in future meetings.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum because the internet today is not only a product or service, but is part of our lives. I believe that because of the importance that the internet has within our community, it is necessary to establish the fifth freedom, that is, digital freedom.  I believe that it is necessary not only to renew the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, but to strengthen its role in order to enable efficient work. I believe that it is especially important to warn about all the dangers of the internet, and to establish a clear and strong system that will be able to counter the different types of abuse that are unfortunately largely present in the cyber world.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. " I voted against the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum. Whether it is for climate, human rights or the internet, we can see the inefficiency of these global projects. All are reduced to vain incantations and are unable to meet the real challenges posed to our countries and our fellow citizens.  The very ambition to make the internet a transparent, neutral, secure, reliable and infinitely growing global space seems futile to me, because the internet does not escape the conflicting interests that, on the contrary, constitute it. At least we could agree here that the Internet is not under the influence of a particular interest jeopardizing our freedoms: I mean, of course, the United States. But when the Commission deplores this state of events, it is to regret not carrying out general surveillance on Europeans.  These are therefore states that alone, as Russia does, demand the repatriation of data on their territory and defend their citizens through the exercise of regal functions.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — It is important to support the renewal of the mandate of this important forum on Internet Governance (FGI), which expires in 2015. The IPF enables a democratic and multilateral political dialogue on the future of the internet, the pillar of the digital single market and now a source of a significant share of the Union's growth. It is therefore necessary to discuss issues relating to internet governance and to improve access to it around the world.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum’ because we believe that fundamental freedoms and human rights are not negotiable and must be protected both online and offline.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — Of all the platforms that help to better understand the Internet and engage in a democratic multi-stakeholder dialogue, the Internet Governance Forum is the most successful of its kind. The Forum's recommendations to the international community on the Digital Single Market are of great importance, as is the Role of the Forum in communicating European values and promoting innovation, growth, trade and diversity. The Forum's Internet recommendations make it an indispensable platform for all citizens working in the digital space.  Internet-based economic output already stands at 11% of total GDP in the EU, with expected growth rates in this sector of 5.7%. The greater the economic importance, the more important it is to have a stakeholder forum to exchange opinions and ideas. That is why I support the proposal to extend the mandate of the IGF, in line with the legal protection provisions of this motion for a resolution.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution. Internet governance must be based on a multi-stakeholder approach, providing transparency and full accountability. I urge the UN General Assembly to renew the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum in this regard. And I call upon the EU institutions and Member States to support the multi-stakeholder approach both in discussions and decision-making. In this regard, I also would like to reiterate the call on the Commission, the Member States and all relevant stakeholders in paragraph 6 to further strengthen the sustainability of the multi-stakeholder model by making actors and processes at the national, regional and international levels more inclusive, transparent and accountable. Whereas strengthening security in the Internet is needed to prevent and detect terrorist incidents and radicalisation, this cannot mean a fully state-controlled Internet and mass-surveillance of citizens. Ensuring that human rights are respected also online must be the common underlying principle.  Europe has good cards to provide a balanced answer to the dilemma between privacy and security and could by those means become a role model at a global level.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Internet Governance Forum has facilitated open and transparent discussions amongst stakeholders from all over the world, many of whom had not cooperated closely before. I therefore voted in favour of the report calling to renew the mandate of the Forum, strengthen its resources and maintain the multistakeholder model of internet governance.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) Through this joint motion for a resolution, the European Parliament is submitting to the other European institutions the need to continue to finance the Internet Governance Forum (IGF). The IGF was established by the United Nations in July 2006. His mandate was renewed by the General Assembly during 2010 for the period 2011-2015. Since its inception, the Forum has fostered the establishment of a transparent and multilateral debate on Internet governance, while also helping to enhance the degree of cooperation between institutional stakeholders and members of civil society.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of internet governance is to ensure that it works properly and ensures that any site is accessible everywhere. This is by strengthening the defence of democracy, individual freedoms and human rights. But some time ago, the scandal that erupted in the wake of Snowden's revelations called into question the American management on this subject. The document before us is too conciliatory with respect to U.S. surveillance practices. So he asks the following questions. Is this an admission of impotence on the part of the European Union and a lack of independence from the United States? Can this project call into question the surveillance of the Internet by the United States? Or is there a powerful new geopolitical lever to compel some "reluctant" states according to American interests?  In view of these questions and therefore the lack of clarity in the project, I vote against the principle of centralized "governance" of the internet. In a multipolar world, every nation must be able to store and protect its own strategic information. It's the defense of sovereignism.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Internet Governance Forum (IGF) is a multilateral policy discussion forum among various sectors with interests in internet governance. It was created at the end of 2005 by the Secretary-General of the United Nations following a government resolution at the World Summit on the Information Society (WSO). The agreed resolution stresses that the European Parliament has always defended this Forum and has always participated in its meetings, and that its mandate must be renewed and its resources strengthened. And, on a crucial issue such as net neutrality, it stresses the need to ensure an open and independent internet and manifests the "crucial" of continuing efforts to ensure legal protection of net neutrality as an "indispensable condition" to ensure freedom of information and expression and boost growth and employment. For these reasons I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The objective of the Internet Governance Forum (FGI) is to implement the mandate of the World Summit on the Information Society (WCC) as a contribution to a democratic, transparent and multilateral political dialogue, which expands the range of issues of economic governance on the Internet. This resolution aims to pressure the United Nations Assembly to renew the mandate of the IGI, strengthen its resources and maintain the multilateral model of internet governance. In addition, eu stakeholders are proposed to maintain financial support to their secretariat to ensure the development of an efficient and independent organisation and thus contribute to the democratisation, openness and neutrality of the internet.  These are all objectives which we think are appropriate and fair, so I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Internet Governance Forum (FGI) promotes discussions on a wide range of issues related to internet governance and, where appropriate, makes recommendations to the international community. It is worth noting, for example, the most recent FGI meeting in September 2014 ("Connecting continents for improved internet governance by multiple stakeholders"). The work and issues addressed by the FGI are of considerable interest to the EU. Economically, and the growth of the internet-related economy is projected to be almost 11% in the EU and its contribution to GDP will increase from 3.8% in 2010 to 5.7% in 2016; In turn, the Internet is a key pillar of the digital single market and promotes, inter-rather, innovation, growth, trade, democracy, cultural diversity and human rights. That is why I believe that the work carried out by the FGI is invaluable, and I vote in favour of this request to the United Nations General Assembly, by which we call for a renewed mandate from the IGI and to increase the resources allocated to it.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — The task of the Internet Governance Forum is to foster dialogue between all participants to help improve the social, technical, economic aspects of internet governance, and to seek to use the internet as a neutral platform to ensure freedom of information and expression.  I supported the report on the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, which aims not only to improve the Internet as a global, social, democratic and transparent resource, but also to improve the economic importance of the Internet. In 2010, the share of the internet economy in the GDP of the European Union was 3.8%, and in 2016 the share is expected to increase to 5.7%, which only confirms the importance of the internet for the economic growth of the European Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, because criminal activity through the Internet must be hit and both the integrity of personality and personal data must be protected. For this reason, the model of governance of the internet must be open, pluralistic, participatory, with civil society and universities playing an important role.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution which calls on the UN General Assembly to renew the mandate of the IGF, and to strengthen its resources and the multi-stakeholder model of Internet governance.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of renewing the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance. The renewal of the Internet Governance Forum, born from the UN Conference on the World Summit on the Information Society, is an opportunity for the European Parliament to underline the importance of the network as the backbone of the digital single market. It is essential to improve internet access worldwide, as the Internet fosters innovation, growth, trade, democracy, cultural diversity and human rights. The Internet must have a regulation for the safety of citizens.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Internet Governance Forum (IGF) was formally established by the United Nations in July 2006. His term of office was renewed by the General Assembly during 2010 for the period 2011-2015.  Through this joint motion for a resolution, the European Parliament is submitting to the other Community institutions the need to continue to finance the IGF. At the same time, the European Parliament addresses the United Nations General Assembly in the hope of renewing the Forum's mandate and increasing the resources made available to it.  Since its inauguration, the Forum has fostered the establishment of a transparent and multilateral debate on Internet governance, while also helping to enhance the degree of cooperation between institutional stakeholders and members of civil society.  For all these reasons, I have decided to support this document in favour.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — With the support of the United Nations, the Internet Governance Forum has been bringing together governments, internet companies and civil society since 2005 to develop a coherent policy in the face of global challenges, particularly reliability, net neutrality and the reduction of the digital divide. The resolution welcomes the commitment made by the United States government in March 2014 to transfer the administration of IANA(IP address) functions and also stresses the importance of full accountability and transparency of ICANN (domain name). The resolution also rejects "the idea of a state-controlled internet and large-scale surveillance of the internet" but of course, without naming those who practice such surveillance. Nevertheless, I am voting to renew the mandate of this Forum pending its conclusions next autumn.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Internet is now a global instrument and therefore its administration should be exercised in the common interest. The Internet is today one of the main means of disseminating democratic values in the world, being an indispensable tool in the promotion of all kinds of initiatives, political debate and dissemination of knowledge.  It is therefore essential to develop the Internet so that everyone in the EU can have access to it in an increasingly equal way.   It is also essential that it be safe for all its users, particularly for children who are less able to defend themselves against the potential dangers of their use. We must therefore prevent the government of the Internet from being dominated by any individual entity or group of entities, so that its status as a global public good is maintained. Hence my sense of vote.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — This resolution stresses the importance of the multi-stakeholder model of Internet governance and expresses Parliament’s commitment to this model. It also expresses the need to make the multi-stakeholder approach sustainable through increased inclusivity, transparency and accountability. Therefore, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Internet has undoubtedly established itself in recent years as an essential part of political, social and economic life at the global level. A vehicle of communication, the engine of economic recovery and competitiveness and the guarantor of non-discriminatory access to knowledge, the Internet exerts a considerable influence on society as a whole. I welcome the adoption of the motion for a resolution to renew the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance. By voting to strengthen the capacity of this Forum, we are giving ourselves the means to fight the misuse of the internet and to anticipate possible abuses. A stable mandate for this Forum will enable it to gather the necessary expertise and act effectively in the pursuit of its objectives. This is a step forward in addressing the important challenges posed by the development of the internet, such as the online protection of fundamental freedoms and human rights, the protection of copyrights, the strengthening of the security of children's internet exploration, the fight against cybercrime, the confidentiality of personal data, etc.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Internet has already transformed the world, but I am convinced that transformation is only at its very beginning. Future regulation must make sure the Internet remains open and truly global (i.e. not ‘nationalised’).  Its management should therefore be dealt with accordingly. With this in mind, I supported this resolution extending the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum (IGF) to continue guiding the development of the ‘Net’. I hope that in a UN-sanctioned setting (as is this wide Forum – the IGF) the global character of the Internet will be preserved, and the process of thinking about its future will be marked by inclusiveness, transparency and accountability.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. — The Internet Governance Forum (IGF), established under the auspices of the UN in 2006, covers all stakeholders and has demonstrated in the first decade of its existence that it is an indispensable factor in the global governance of the Internet. Such a global forum, which divides best practices, is particularly needed when the current government introduces an Internet tax in Hungary. It is also important to learn about ways to regulate the Internet, such as the US Internet Taxation Act, which explicitly prohibits the imposition of a data traffic tax. I therefore consider it of the utmost importance that we decide to extend the mandate of the IGF at the UN General Assembly in 2015.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — The objective of the Internet Governance Forums (FGI) is to implement the mandate of the World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) with regard to the organisation of forums for a democratic, transparent and multilateral political dialogue. The aim is to discuss a number of issues related to internet governance and to make recommendations to the international community. I am in favour of this motion for a resolution, because I believe that the UN General Assembly should continue to support this Forum and the European Union should take advantage of this process to hold further public discussions with key stakeholders at European level. I also believe that internet access around the world should be improved, provided that the security and stability of IT services should be guaranteed. This access reinforces the maxim i also endorse that there should be no barriers to free knowledge on the part of citizens.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The resolution aims to renew the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance (under the aegis of the United Nations) which discusses future technological standards and the proper functioning of the internet. The text strengthens the Forum's resources and calls on the United Nations to renew its mandate.  However, this Forum also debates the regulation of the internet. If this is justified in some cases, freedom of access and expression on the Internet for the greatest number, a true fundamental right, should not be restricted under the pretext of combating the excesses of a minority. So I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which calls on the UN General Assembly to renew for five years and strengthen the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance, an informal forum for debate that meets every year. The text also recalls several key principles of internet governance: net neutrality, multi-party governance, protection of fundamental freedoms and human rights.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. — The renewal of the Internet Governance Forum, which was born out of the UN Conference on the World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS), whose task is to discuss issues relating to the governance of the Internet and, where appropriate, to make recommendations to the international community, is an opportunity for the European Parliament to stress the importance of the network as the backbone of the digital single market. It is therefore necessary to improve access to the Internet throughout the world, since the Internet, among other things, promotes innovation, growth, trade, democracy, cultural diversity and human rights. It is equally important to ensure that the Forum continues to be as inclusive as possible, ensuring the continued democratic oversight of the European Parliament through its delegations at future meetings of the Forum, so that it contributes effectively to the formulation of a coherent and comprehensive European approach. At the same time, collective efforts must focus on developing legal protection of net neutrality as an essential prerequisite for safeguarding freedom of information and expression, promoting growth and employment, not forgetting the economic and social importance of the rights to privacy and control of their personal data and the development of appropriate measures to protect child users of the Internet.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted to renew the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, an annual meeting that provides an international framework for discussion. The resolution adopted by Parliament calls on the United Nations to renew the mandate of the forum and to strengthen its resources. Indeed, this Forum helps to maintain a multi-party model of internet governance and to ensure that the web remains a truly global resource. Major principles such as net neutrality and the protection of fundamental freedoms and human rights are also highlighted by this resolution.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — We welcome the work of the Forum on Internet Governance because it has fostered the establishment of an increasingly democratic, transparent and multi-participatory political dialogue. The delegations sent by the European Parliament have certainly played a key role in promoting European values and interacting with civil society organisations and representatives of the national parliaments present at these events. The Internet will play a key role in building a European digital single market and in promoting innovation, growth, trade, democracy, cultural diversity and human rights. For this reason, although the Forum does not adopt formal conclusions, we cannot fail to stress its importance and not continue to make efforts to promote the legal protection of net neutrality, as an essential prerequisite for safeguarding freedom of information and expression. Only in this way will we really be able to foster growth and employment, through the creation of opportunities for innovation and internet-related business.  The European Union must continue to support this multi-participation process, in defence of cultural and linguistic diversity, while contributing to the formulation of a coherent and comprehensive European approach, together with the Member States and the Commission.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. " I voted for this text because the respect of online rights in respect of privacy and the control by users of their personal data is a fundamental right of every individual.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I welcomed and voted on this resolution, which once again underlines the importance of the role of the Internet both globally and in the lives of each of us. The Internet is a fundamental pillar of the Digital Single Market, thus contributing to the development of the economy, trade, cultural exchanges, human interaction, but also democracy and access to information, representing one of the rights of a modern, progressive and democratic society.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. — The objective of the Internet Governance Forum (IGF) is to fulfil the mandate of the World Summit on The Information Society (WSIS) to organise forums for a democratic, transparent and multilateral political dialogue. The main role and function of the IGF is to discuss a wide range of issues related to internet governance and, where appropriate, to make recommendations to the international community. In 2015 the MANDATE of the IGF will expire, so the UN must renew its mandate to allow the Internet Governance Forum to continue its role.  I stress the need for a strong FGI to reach a compromise between stakeholders and to support an independent, including neutral, internet. The resolution supports net neutrality, internet access all over the world, support for online and offline rights, and expresses concern about the attitude of certain countries that censor and restrict access to the internet. I stress that Parliament should continue to participate in future meetings of the IGF with a substantial delegation, in order to contribute effectively to formulating, together with the Member States and the Commission, an EU approach to internet governance.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — The Internet Governance Forum describes global measures to ensure the proper functioning and access to technological standards of the Internet. This is also about barrier-free access – everyone should have internet access without restrictions. I support this proposal and am in favour of net neutrality.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the draft because the Internet Governance Forum is an important platform for international dialogue on Internet-related issues and deserves to be maintained.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Forum on Internet Governance (IGF) aims to implement the mandate given to it by the World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) with regard to the establishment of a democratic, transparent and multi-participatory political dialogue through the forum organisation. The main role and function of the IGF is to promote forward-looking discussions on a wide range of Internet governance issues and, where appropriate, to make recommendations to the international community. The Internet is the backbone of the digital single market and promotes, among other things, innovation, growth, trade, democracy, cultural diversity and human rights. The European Union's main priorities during the 9th IGF in September 2014 were, among others, to extend access to the network globally, to keep the Internet as a global, open and common resource and to reject the idea of state control of the Internet. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — The Internet as the strongest medium of today and the future is advancing in development in all directions, and today represents the most active social platform for discussion on many topics concerning our society. It has already shown countless times its power in initiing change as well as its significant impact on the geopolitical picture of the world. Since just thinking about how to manage such a complex and rapidly changing platform is a topic that covers a wide range of participants in his work, I support the renewal of the Mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance. No other association or body can comprehensively consider the problems and challenges of managing the internet like this one that brings together all relevant stakeholders. Without the work of the Forum, it risks getting things out of hand, and turning the internet into something that will not reflect a united Europe's position on the freedom and independence of sources of information, and on respect for human rights and freedom of speech.  It is also important to continue the fight against network crime, especially in the case of the most vulnerable group of users - minors. Further continuation of the Forum can contribute to the development of a common management policy on a global level, and ensure adequate control of internet services, which is our interest to all.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — The aim of this resolution is to renew the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance (under the aegis of the United Nations), which discusses future technological standards and the proper functioning of the internet. The text strengthens the Forum's resources and calls on the United Nations to renew its mandate.  However, this Forum also debates the regulation of the internet. If this is justified in some cases, freedom of access and expression on the Internet for the greatest number, a true fundamental right, should not be restricted under the pretext of combating the excesses of a minority. So I voted against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of renewing the five-year term of the Forum for the Governance of the Internet, because I believe it is essential that we discuss transparently and immediately the issues concerning the Internet, which nowadays, in fact, governs our lives in almost every aspect. Our Parliament, through its delegation, must continue to engage with all stakeholders involved in order to contribute to this international process by proposing a coherent and comprehensive European approach. With the renewal of the mandate, we also hope to see a greater presence and involvement of the EU in governance, which is heavily controlled by the US, whose presence will already be reduced in part by the transfer of Internet surveillance functions to a global multi-participatory community, on which it will in any case be essential to ensure independence so that it is able to maintain the stability of the Internet. We will have to continue to address security and privacy issues very carefully, so as to guarantee total freedom of expression and information, in an environment that protects personal data from abuse. These protections not only benefit individual citizens, but also ensure that businesses, especially SMEs, can develop their online potential without risk.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I fully support the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, which has provided open and transparent discussions among interested stakeholders in its work so far since 2005, many of which have not cooperated until then. The European Parliament also actively participated in all this by sending delegates to all annual sessions of the Forum.  I believe that the European Parliament, as the only directly elected body by citizens, should continue to actively participate in the work of the Forum and thus contribute constructively and efficiently to the international process of forming a coherent and comprehensive EU approach, together with other stakeholders, the European Commission and EU Member States.  At a time when the internet has become a major medium that in many ways facilitates citizens' lives on a daily basis, the European Union must be unitedly imposed as a global leader of trends and an active participant in global internet governance processes. The European Forum on Internet Governance is the best way to enable such a role for the EU.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the motion for a resolution submitted following the Commission's declaration in accordance with Art. 123rd century. 2. Rules of Procedure on the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum. This recommendation allows for the dissemination of internet access globally, the maintenance of the internet as an open and common tool globally, access to non-discriminatory knowledge and more transparent and accountable internet governance due to the participation of more stakeholders.  The economic and social importance of the right to privacy online and control over one's personal data should be emphasised. This is important for individuals, but also for the growing segment of internet companies. I reject the idea of state control of the Internet and its mass monitoring. Censorship and similar restrictions make it impossible to achieve the objective of this proposal, which is the worldwide connectivity of citizens. Ensuring the legal protection of net neutrality is also of great importance, which is a precondition for protecting freedom of information and expression, enabling progress through innovation and business opportunities related to the internet, which would, among other things, result in employment.  For the purpose of internationalising the core functions of the Internet and online organisations, which is further supported by the US through the globalisation of IANA functions, I support the further funding of the IGF and its place on the priority list of the EU institutions.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Forum on Internet Governance, thanks to the fruitful exchanges taking place within the Internet and the multi-participatory approach, makes it possible to lay the foundations for what the future of the network may be. I am convinced that it is necessary to move towards an open and independent network, protecting and developing "net neutrality" as a basic principle that can allow, for example, the newly formed web-company of an entrepreneur to have the same chance of success as the most established corporations, or ensure that access to a young person's blog is not unfairly slowed down by an Internet provider to allow advertisers to make more money. I hope that the European Union will commit itself to trying to facilitate the conclusion of negotiations and the achievement of a comprehensive agreement on the new governance of the Internet and rules that can guarantee net neutrality at interconnection points between the provider and the rest of the Internet.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Everyday life today is intimately linked to the Internet and the Forum on Internet Governance is trying to propose a political discussion at the international level in order to better control this medium, which is both a vector of growth and knowledge. The European Union is closely involved in the creation of this forum, and through this resolution the European Parliament must vote on its support for this effort, to which I am in favour. The European Union must lead this fight in the long term in order to preserve the internet as an area of freedom and not anarchy.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — The objective of the Internet Governance Forums (FGI) is to implement the mandate of the World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) with regard to the organisation of forums for a democratic, transparent and multilateral political dialogue. The main role and function of the FGI is to discuss a wide range of issues related to Internet governance, presenting recommendations to the international community in this area if necessary. The ad hoc delegations sent by the European Parliament played a key role in promoting European values and interacting with civil society organisations and representatives of national parliaments present at these events, in collaboration with the Member States and the Commission. However, considering that the Internet is a fundamental pillar of the single market, promoting innovation, democracy, cultural diversity and human rights, and whereas growth related to the Internet economy should reach almost 11 % in the EU, I think it is very important to promote this multilateral model of Internet governance and to continue the fruitful exchanges carried out in the context of the FGI. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Un General Assembly to renew the mandate of the FGI.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. — In view of the important decisions on the internet that will have to be taken in the coming years, I voted in favour of the resolution on the renewal of the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance (FGI).  The FGI is now the only international space for political, democratic and transparent dialogue on internet regulation with the participation of all stakeholders. As the U.S. government finally prepares to transfer Internet surveillance functions to the international community, it is essential that the UN General Assembly renews the mandate of the IPF.  This is all the more so since many sensitive topics are about to be discussed: data security, privacy, net neutrality, freedom of expression, indiscriminate access to knowledge and the fight against terrorist radicalisation. It is essential that these topics are addressed at the international level and that, through Parliament's presence in the IPF, we guarantee the internet's contribution to cultural diversity, trade, and growth.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. — The UN General Assembly will soon have to decide whether to renew the Internet Governance Forum (IPF), whose current mandate ends in 2015. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for renewing its mandate, allocating more resources and consolidating the multi-party governance model of the internet that this forum promotes. We welcome the decision of the U.S. Department of Commerce's National Telecommunications and Information Administration to transfer the Internet monitoring functions currently performed by the IP Address Management Agency (IANA) to the global stakeholder community. However, it will be necessary to ensure that this transition is smooth. We call on Member States, the Commission and all interested parties to consolidate the viability of this model by strengthening the openness, transparency and accountability of internet players. Finally, we recall in this text our commitment to the principles of net neutrality, data security, respect for privacy, and the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms on the net.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — Today, the Internet is a fundamental pillar of the digital market. The Internet is increasingly promoting growth, innovation, trade, cultural diversity and even human rights. The multilateral model of Internet governance is an asset and must be supported.  To this end, it is important that Member States, in particular the Commission, strengthen the sustainability of this model. However, it is important that efforts be made to ensure the neutrality and legal protection of the Internet in order to safeguard the freedom of expression and information that is so threatened today.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Resolution because I share the need to renew the mandate of the Forum — of which the EU is also the main contributor, to which it finances 30% of its activities — and the multi-party negotiating approach as a pillar of internet governance.  I also consider it key to ensure, as the Resolution demands, the principle of net neutrality as an indispensable condition for ensuring freedom of information and expression, and promoting innovation, growth and employment. Without neutrality there is no network; therefore, it is essential to ensure an open and independent internet. Europe cannot be left behind when president obama in the United States has clearly opted for the creation of the strictest possible measures to protect neutrality, and the FCC president has proposed preventing network access providers from discriminating against content or applications, appealing to internet regulation as a basic public service. Europe must also take advantage of the investment plan to maximize broadband networks and ensure a connected continent, while combating the digital divide.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on this resolution. We understand the importance of discussion forums on internet governance and more, if possible, the important role to be played by the representation of plural parliamentary delegations within it. However, we do not share the governance model applied so far in internet governance, nor the leading role of U.S.-centric ICANN and large technology companies. We highly value the presence of organized civil society, but we understand that it is in a situation of total asymmetry in the face of large internet companies. In this sense, we understand that internet governance must be strongly democratized and internationalized and must have increasing user participation.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — The aim of the Internet Governance Forum (IPF) is to implement the mandate of the World Summit on the Information Society to organize forums for political, transparent and multilateral dialogue. The resolution I voted on today on the IPF makes it clear that it is up to the EU to support the holding of this forum and to increase the impact of these exchanges in political debates, as it helps to build a positive and concrete framework to shape, on the basis of a multi-party stratum, the future of the internet. This is at a time when some are trying to reduce the connectivity of their citizens globally through censorship and other restrictions.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — This proposal builds on the importance of the Internet Governance Forum (FGI) for democratic, transparent and multilateral political dialogue, the purpose of which is to implement the mandate of the World Summit on the Information Society, which ends this year. With this Report and as can be read in the text of it, an open and independent Internet is intended, as a common global resource, along side non-discriminatory access to knowledge, [stressing] that it is essential to continue efforts to ensure the legal protection of [its] neutrality, an indispensable precondition for safeguarding freedom of information and expression, stimulating growth and employment by developing innovation and internet-related business opportunities , as well as the promotion and protection of cultural and linguistic diversity. To this extent, attention is drawn to the importance of multilateral internet governance, the need for the UN General Assembly to renew its mandate and to strengthen its resources. At EU level, it is important to stress the need to support this process through political exchanges and debates, as well as financial support to enable the development of the Forum as an efficient and independent organisation.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — I supported this resolution because it is essential that the Forum on Internet Governance be able to continue its work under the aegis of the United Nations General Assembly for the next five years.  Today, the internet is an indispensable tool and its governance concerns every citizen. This governance must take into account the importance of net neutrality, the need for multi-party governance and the protection of fundamental freedoms and human rights. The European Union must continue its action and remain vigilant about the tool of freedom that cyberspace must remain.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of renewing the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance because, through the governance of the Internet, we have the opportunity to keep the Internet as an open place, a place where society has rediscovered itself to a large extent, and to leave the space within the Internet to create value, to exploit the trust that the Internet fosters. , so that the Internet is also a place of development and not just, as has often been the case lately, a place of pitfalls, a place of insecurity. Our task, including through the participation of the European Parliament in the Forum on Internet Governance, is to promote real governance.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on this resolution. We understand the importance of discussion forums on internet governance and more, if possible, the important role to be played by the representation of plural parliamentary delegations within it. However, we do not share the governance model applied so far in internet governance, nor the leading role of U.S.-centric ICANN and large technology companies. We highly value the presence of organized civil society, but we understand that it is in a situation of total asymmetry in the face of large internet companies. In this sense, we understand that internet governance must be strongly democratized and internationalized and must have increasing user participation.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the United Nations to renew the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance and to strengthen its resources. The forum brings together representatives of governments, industry and civil society to discuss global arrangements to ensure the smooth functioning, accessibility and technological standards of the internet in all countries.  Internet governance must be based on an inclusive and multi-actor model, and must truly become international, so as not to remain under the influence of economic and political interests of a few. As such, the operation of ICANN, the U.S. private law firm responsible for the allocation of domain names, needs to be thoroughly reviewed.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The objective of the Internet Governance Forum (FGI) is to implement the mandate of the World Summit on the Information Society (WCC) as a contribution to a democratic, transparent and multilateral political dialogue, which expands the range of issues of economic governance on the Internet. This resolution aims to pressure the United Nations Assembly to renew the mandate of the IGI, strengthen its resources and maintain the multilateral model of internet governance. In addition, eu stakeholders are proposed to maintain financial support to their secretariat to ensure the development of an efficient and independent organisation and thus contribute to the democratisation, openness and neutrality of the internet.  These are all objectives which we think are appropriate and fair, so I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the joint motion for a resolution extending the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum (IGF). The IGF is an essential platform that can continue to advocate principles in the future, such as openness and accessibility of the Internet to all or net neutrality. These are also the principles on which the EU builds its digital single market. The demand for the protection of personal data, the protection of intellectual property, copyright and the protection of children in the digital environment from abuse on the Internet (whether through social networks, games, advertisements or inappropriate content) comes to the fore. There are still large gaps in this area. The European Union must be actively involved in the solution, as it does not itself provide adequate protection in this area. Internet governance must respect children's rights to protect their personality, their healthy mental and physical development. It is therefore appropriate that the mandate of the IGF should be extended by the UN General Assembly and that the principles of openness, net neutrality as well as security continue to be promoted by the EU within this platform.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. — The Internet Governance Forum is important for the democratic and transparent functioning of the Internet worldwide. Global internet access has certainly changed its use. You need to be aware of its strength and rapid growth. It is therefore necessary to keep pace with the times and to continue to maintain the Internet as a global, open and accessible source of data. However, it is necessary to ensure that no violations of basic human rights are tolerated online and that users are protected as much as possible. All rights that people have offline must also be implemented there. The fact is that the Internet is a basic pillar of the digital single market, while promoting growth, trade, democracy, cultural diversity, etc. It is necessary to improve and facilitate internet access throughout the world, and also to enable inclusion in the giving of ideas and improvements to all stakeholders involved.
