At the same time, freedom of speech and the publication of information must also be guaranteed, as the strong censorship of certain countries is certainly a concern. Much attention must continue to be paid and, above all, ensure maximum protection of internet users and their personal data. As the Internet Governance Forum recalls and works constructively in all the areas mentioned above, I supported the extension of its mandate for a further five years.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing — The Internet is a global tool and the Digital Agenda has become part of lives, policies or entrepreneurship. It is important to create space for discussion on individual aspects of the digital economy such as data protection, neutrality, electronic signature or online registration of SUP and other SMEs.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — The Aim of the Internet Governance Forum (IGF) is to fulfil its mandate given at the World Information Society Summit (WSIS) to set up a forum to conduct a democratic and transparent dialogue.  Given that the UN General Assembly extended the mandate of the IGF by five years on 20 December 2010, I believe that the IGF has fulfilled its objective and function. I believe that the European Parliament should continue to participate in the meetings of the Internet Governance Forum in the future, but with an emphasis on substance and essential objectives, and therefore I voted against that amendment.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because I support the work of the IGF in the field of internet governance.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution extending the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum as it touches on a number of important aspects of the current discussions on the future of the Internet. Our common goal is to ensure that the Internet remains a global resource that is not owned by a handful of political and intellectual elites, but is available to all. We need to improve the balance and clearly support the credibility of the rules on Internet governance. It is absolutely necessary to renew this mandate, because it reflects the multilateral character that internet governance must have, as it is based on the approach of different stakeholders: government, the private sector and civil society.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. — Privacy issues, the filtering of information by large and private companies/search engines, and the citizen's ability to have free access to the internet are perhaps the most essential prerequisites for the development of the Model of Online Governance proposed by the Forum.          There are a number of points in the report that need to be improved. At the moment the use of the Internet focuses on the developed economic economies of the Western world, while participation/use in developing countries is very limited. This fact has so far not been taken seriously by the Forum. Instead, the Forum focuses on the assignment of important social goods and services to private initiatives to develop entrepreneurship.  However, we must not condemn the effort that is being made. On the contrary, our objective must be to further involve and enlarge the Forum so that we can highlight these shortcomings and minimise them to the greatest extent possible, thus ensuring the right of equal access for all citizens (especially those on the margins, economic, social, cultural) and protecting them from the logic/persistence of commercialisation. In this context, we have decided to vote in favour of the motion to renew the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — It is necessary, at global level, to improve internet access and to ensure an open and independent internet as a common good, as well as future non-discriminatory access to knowledge, based on the initiatives and needs of the parties concerned, as well as freedom of expression.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. — Renewing the mandate of the UN organisation expands the opportunity to protect democratic human rights on the web.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I believe it is essential to renew the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum (IGF), as it is the only multi-participatory platform for the exchange of views on issues related to Internet governance at international level. Internet operators, politicians, lawyers and all the different stakeholders in the sector, including civil society, participate in the forum. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution because it not only urges the UN Assembly to extend the mandate of the IGF, to strengthen its resources and the multi-participatory approach, but also emphasises the need to ensure an open and neutral Internet (net neutrality), non-discriminatory access to knowledge and the safeguarding of freedom of information and expression.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the resolution. Although the IPF does not adopt formal conclusions, it is the responsibility of the European Union to support the holding of this forum and to increase the influence that these exchanges can have on political debates, as this allows us to build a positive and concrete framework to shape, on the basis of a multi-party strategy, the future of the internet. It is important that the Member States and the EU institutions concerned ensure that they continue to regard the IPF as one of their main priorities and to continue their support for the IPF and its secretariat, as well as to contribute to the development of an effective and independent organisation capable of carrying out its mandate and accompanying the constant evolution of the internet governance model.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution calling on the United Nations to renew the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum. The IGF has so far successfully brought together stakeholders for discussions, but more should be done to improve this forum. I count on the Commission which will be participating on behalf of the European Union to work in this direction.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. — In the coming years, the Digital Market in the EU will be one of the keys in order to achieve sustainable economic growth. At the same time, it is our responsibility to be sure that fundamental rights and freedoms are protected on the internet, as well as net neutrality. Expanding the access to internet around the world is the way forward to extend knowledge and future growth, and so this is why I voted in favour of renewing the mandate for the Internet Governance Forum.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — Internet governance is the set of measures taken at the "global level" to organise the internet. It aims to ensure its operation and ensure that any site is accessible everywhere. It wants to strengthen what it believes is the most effective way to defend democracy, individual freedoms and human rights.  Snowden's revelations have called into question the assumed U.S. management of internet governance. This case was indicative of the European Union's delay on this issue. The document is timid with regard to American surveillance practices and Parliament welcomes too timid commitments from the United States. Questions about the FGI: -Is this the admission of impotence of a Union obliged to negotiate its independence with the United States?  - Does it call into question the surveillance of the internet by the United States rather than the surveillance of the internet at all?  - Is there a powerful new geopolitical lever to compel certain "reticent" states to respect human rights and democracy in American sauce?  I vote against the principle of centralised "governance" of the internet with opaque objectives. In a multipolar world, every nation must be able to store and protect its strategic information and data.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Internet has become an extremely important element of innovation, growth, trade, democracy, cultural diversity and human rights in today's society.  The figures show that the internet is currently contributing around 4% to European GDP, and at the end of next year it will reach a contribution of almost 6%. If we add to these concrete figures the fact that the Internet has become an essential means of spreading democracy, of defending fundamental human rights, which cannot be translated into concrete figures, but it is extremely important, it becomes all the more relevant why it is important to renew the mandate of the Forum for Internet Governance.  There is a direct link, as seen in some countries, between internet access and the level of democracy and the rule of law. The Internet Governance Forum can help increase internet access around the world, which will directly lead to increased democracy in these countries. The Forum's mission is to continue efforts to ensure the legal protection of net neutrality, an indispensable condition for guaranteeing freedom of information and expression, stimulating growth and employment, by developing innovation and internet-related business opportunities.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution on the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, which had broad consensus among the Groups. The criteria for the participation of the European Parliament in this Forum, set up to carry out the mandate of the World Summit on the Information Society (WSC) are laid down. The United Nations General Assembly decided on 20 December 2010 to extend the mandate of the Forum for a period of five years and, at the end of 2015, the United Nations Assembly will discuss and decide on the renewal of that mandate.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The objective of the Internet Governance Forum (FGI) is to implement the mandate of the World Summit on the Information Society (WCC) as a contribution to a democratic, transparent and multilateral political dialogue, which expands the range of issues of economic governance on the Internet. This resolution aims to pressure the United Nations Assembly to renew the mandate of the IGI, strengthen its resources and maintain the multilateral model of internet governance. In addition, eu stakeholders are proposed to maintain financial support to their secretariat to ensure the development of an efficient and independent organisation and thus contribute to the democratisation, openness and neutrality of the internet.  These are all objectives which we think are appropriate and fair, so I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. — The use of the Internet is both emanating and democratising and threatening. The Internet provides information and communication, which unfortunately can also be abused. By adopting this resolution to renew the mandate of the Internet Management Forum and increase the capacity of the forum, we are ensuring that it can bring in the necessary expertise and act appropriately. Among other things, it should safeguard the confidentiality of personal data, as well as tackle the fight against cybercrime.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This proposal aims at renewing the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum (IFA), which is a multilateral working platform with the primary function of discussing a wide range of internet governance issues, and may even make recommendations to the international community aimed, inter alia, at promoting the extension of internet access globally, ensuring its maintenance as a comprehensive resource of broad access to knowledge and information , as well as communication, cultural diversity and freedom of expression. The Internet is also a key pillar that promotes innovation and the growth of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises in the various sectors of economic activity. Despite matters relating to access to a secure Internet and the guarantee of the protection of users' personal data, it is essential to continue the work, thereby contributing to its development and deepening, on a multilateral platform that guarantees its democratic character and safeguards the interests of the people s and Member States of the European Union.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of renewing the Internet Governance Forum because I consider the issue of internet freedom and the personal right of access to the internet to be fundamental. I also believe that these issues must be addressed from a political perspective, and the European Union, in the mechanisms already in place and in line with what has already been set up, must be the guarantor of transparency, freedom and access, for example by emphasising that these freedoms are non-negotiable, countering censorship and attempts by some countries to limit the connectivity and availability of information. Furthermore, the work of the Internet Governance Forum must move in the direction of a network that is as open and independent as possible, a shared resource that is available to all, including from the point of view of digital rights, development and sustainable economic recovery. I therefore hope that the resolution we have voted on will be a further step forward for the protection of individual freedoms and for the protection of the Internet as an instrument of knowledge and participation.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. — The aim of the Internet Governance Forum is to promote public debate on transparency and governance on the Internet and to propose policies to improve the functioning of the Internet internationally, with the main aim of achieving maximum access for citizens to it.  The decision to renew his mandate will take place in 2015 at the UN General Assembly. The European Parliament is formally involved in its work, making a substantial contribution to democratic dialogue, promoting European values and strengthening multi-participation in its governance. The contribution of the online economy to European GDP is expected to trend upwards by 2016. According to the resulting data, but also with statements by leaders and actors, the internet adds to innovation, growth and trade, and is a key pillar of the digital single market. The main objective of all stakeholders is the qualitative participation of civil society in this. For the above reasons I voted in favour of the proposal to renew the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing — The Internet Governance Forum (IGF) creates space for information exchange, the search for new solutions and the formulation of visions about the future of the Internet. By voting in favour of the motion for a resolution, I supported the renewal of the Forum and the maintenance of its multi-party report, which includes the sending of a European Parliament delegation to each part-session. I believe that the work of the Forum will help to find answers to the ever-new questions that the information society brings.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum because it addresses the need to improve internet access and stresses that the FGI should remain as comprehensive as possible. In calling for continued efforts to ensure the legal protection of internet neutrality, an indispensable precondition for safeguarding freedom of information and expression, stimulating growth and employment by developing innovation and internet-related business opportunities, as well as promoting and protecting cultural and linguistic diversity. On the other hand, in considering that fundamental freedoms and human rights are non-negotiable and should be protected by regretting that some States, citing security concerns, try to reduce the global connectivity of their citizens and by rejecting an Internet controlled and monitored by the States, the text is in line with my convictions. Furthermore, by urging the UN to renew the MANDATE of the FGI, to strengthen its resources and to maintain the multilateral model of its governance, the resolution embodies a free and democratic view of the use of the Internet by all.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This resolution aims to pressure the UN General Assembly to renew the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, to strengthen its resources and to maintain the multilateral model of Internet governance. It is also proposed to the EU's stakeholders to maintain financial support to the secretariat to ensure the development of an efficient, independent organisation and thus contribute to the democratisation, openness and neutrality of the Internet.  In line with the need to improve safe access, doubts and reservations remain as to the mechanisms and organisations that hold the power to ensure this security. We do not follow attempts to push the provision of some services to the private sector, alienating the public service that in this matter is the guarantor of social prices to the population and a safe and universal Internet.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the joint resolution calling for the renewal of the five-year mandate for the Internet Governance Forum because I believe it is appropriate to support the work of exchanging ideas for the creation of networks between operators, policy makers and stakeholders in general that it has been carrying out since 2005. I therefore regret that the position in favour of permanent renewal has not been more widely shared. I believe it is essential that we have chosen to support the maintenance of a place of discussion on issues that are gradually becoming increasingly crucial both for our society and for our economic fabric. In order to ensure that, in an increasingly digitised society, the protection of privacy and personal data is effectively protected, or that we ensure that efficient net neutrality is maintained, we need a constant and fruitful dialogue between the relevant authorities and stakeholders, citizens and entrepreneurs, who know better than anyone else the real problems in the sector. A dialogue that must necessarily take place in an international context in order to achieve universally shared standards.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. — Free exchange of information and freedom of expression are among the most important commodities of modern and developed societies, and the internet or information motorway plays a key role in guaranteeing these rights. I believe that it is therefore necessary to constantly promote an open and independent Internet as a common global resource, while improving internet access worldwide. In this context, the Internet Governance Forum plays an important role, especially in the commitment to increase the involvement of all stakeholders. Fundamental freedoms and human rights must not be negotiated and must be protected both online and outside. In this respect, we can regret that some countries are trying to limit the global cohesion of their citizens through censorship and other restrictions. That's intolerable. It is therefore essential to continue efforts to ensure the legal protection of net neutrality, which is a necessary precondition for the protection of freedom of information and expression, the strengthening of growth and the creation of jobs. In the face of all these factors, I supported the resolution extending the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, which also emphasises, inter alia, the economic and social importance of the right to privacy online and the importance of controlling users over their personal data.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the horsemeat scandal and other cases of food fraud have brought down consumer confidence and have consequently also caused serious damage to honest producers in the food chain. Today, Europe is called upon to rebuild that confidence, but the right of consumers to know the country of origin of meat used in processed food must not come up against a sharp increase in prices and must not, therefore, generate new demons.  The import of raw materials is essential for the food industry, especially where domestic production does not meet all needs. Together with more information on provenance, consumers should be aware that importing raw materials does not amount to worse quality or less safety. The keywords to be used must therefore be 'greater security', 'more information' and 'greater transparency'.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, we need more food-chain transparency, not only because having low levels of traceability facilitates food fraud, as we witnessed during the horsemeat scandal, but also because it undermines food safety and animal welfare. If we do not know where and how animals were raised, transported and slaughtered, how can we guarantee that their meat is healthy and that they have been treated in a proper humane way? Improving animal welfare and traceability will not be possible if we continue with the current situation, in which millions of animals are transported extremely long distances in terrible conditions. So I urge the Commission to listen to consumers – 90% of whom are calling for labelling, as proposed by this resolution – and to come forward with legislative proposals that address these issues in a comprehensive and effective manner. Food is the key element in the development of sustainable society, and it is time that the Commission stared treating it as such.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of this resolution on country-of-origin labelling. I have to say that I am mindful of the arguments that people put about over-regulation and the additional cost that could follow from such an initiative, but I think the arguments that the consumer makes win out over any potential difficulty that could emerge in terms of additional cost or more regulation. This proposal has been in the offing now since 2011 and, as the previous speaker said, the horsemeat scandal in 2013 is an example of where the internal market was used for financial gain, for processors to effectively sell something that was not there for their own financial end.  I believe consumers have rights here. I believe people want to know where their food comes from. I think it is in the interests of countries like my own, which have a hugely significant agri-foods industry, that we move in this direction. I very much hope that the Commission takes note of this resolution and takes note of the strong consumer sentiment that supports information such as this, so that we can have a sustainable food system, not just in Europe but throughout the world – and also a sustainable food system that people have certainty about, in terms of knowing where their food comes from.

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, naming the provenance of processed meat on the label will be an important step forward, a step forward in protecting the health of consumers, a step forward in combating fraud and counterfeiting. I voted in favour because this measure is in line with a demand for information and transparency that comes from consumers, from European citizens. It will now be up to the Commission to translate these indications into a clear rule. It is necessary – and we want to make this clear – that this rule should not put more costs on to consumers. The right to health is a right that cannot become a greater burden. That is why the relationship between labelling and production costs must be carefully studied. That is why great attention is needed for small and medium-sized enterprises, which in some cases change suppliers three to four times a year, and it is necessary to pay particular attention to products that use multiple types of meat.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would sign every sentence that my previous speaker, My colleague Hayes, has said here, from my faction. I did not favour the position of my faction and voted in favour of the text approved by the ENVI Committee. I agree with the committee's call for legislation to introduce mandatory labelling of the country of origin of meat for processed foods. And I don't think maintaining the principle of volunteering is the right solution. Only a negligible proportion of producers and processors voluntarily provide information on the origin of individual food ingredients. Consumer confidence in food is thus at a very low level and mandatory information on origin could increase it. Surveys carried out by the European Consumer Organisation confirming the Findings of the European Commission show that 70% of the EU population considers information on the country of origin of food and even 90% of the country of origin of meat to be very important. Czech consumer protection organisations also support the adoption of the legislation requested by the ENVI Committee, which is why I am also in favour of mandatory labelling, also because I am a member of the AGRI Committee.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE). -
text: There is no doubt that it is in the interest of consumers to obtain all information on foodstuffs, their composition and origin. I therefore voted in favour and I am pleased that an absolute majority also voted in favour. This is a call to the Commission that it must immediately prepare legislation that reflects the views expressed by the European Parliament in public polls. The indication of the country or place of origin of meat and meat products will not in itself prevent fraud, and I fully agree that the Commission must continue to investigate the practice of indicating the origin of meat contained in processed foods and inform the public of the results of the investigation. All this will help to increase consumer confidence in the products and will encourage the public to seek information and to judge products not based on the beauty of the packaging, but on their content. In addition, consumers who are concerned with ecology will be able to consume a local, of course less polluting product.

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR). -
text: Mr President! I have voted in favour of this labelling of meat, and I think that is a good thing, and that is for the sake of consumers. Traceability, so that you can follow the product from farm to fork, is a consumer requirement, and this should always be followed. It is the right of consumers to know the whole origin and therefore also the country of origin of the food they buy.  Of course, a country-of-origin labelling requirement will never alone prevent fraud. It is part of a chain of requirements to ensure that consumers get the goods they pay for. A secondary effect of country-of-origin labelling may also be that the country or countries will make even greater efforts to meet a high standard of consumer requirements and ensure good animal welfare and good quality in those countries and ensure that those who do not meet this are probably not the ones delivering the food in the future. Consumers must be in the middle, which is why we have agreed to this.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I have moved towards the version of the proposal which, unfortunately, did not win a majority in the end and did not pass. In my discussions with the professional public, but also with the Czech Ministry of Agriculture, I have come to the conclusion that, of course, it is necessary to protect consumer rights, but on the other hand, in addition to consumer information, the cost of the price of food, which should be reasonable, and the bureaucratic burden that we also place on small and medium-sized producers by certain legislation, must also be seen. I therefore personally believe, although this is a complex issue, that it is rather preferable to choose a way where the origin of meat, which is an ingredient in food, is indicated on a voluntary basis. I am convinced, like the Czech Ministry of Agriculture, but also by the Association of Czech Consumers, that too much information will lead to food being more expensive than before, and this is a big problem for me.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! I voted against the resolution. Compulsory labelling harms small and medium-sized enterprises without helping consumers. An impact assessment by the Commission, which we always demand, provides for drastic increases in costs for small and medium-sized enterprises, because it is precisely deposits that would have to be built. The bureaucracy that is then in the upcoming bureaucracy is really disproportionate to the benefits. The left in Parliament, in particular, must slowly accept the question of who is responsible for this unnecessary bureaucracy and, therefore, for the disillusionment with Europe. It is a policy of paternalism that we are increasingly having to experience here, particularly from the left, in Parliament. Let us finally get serious about the EU focusing on the important and the big issues!

name: Sven Schulze (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! I also voted against. That does not mean that I am not in favour of transparency, nor does that mean that I am not in favour of strict food regulations. However, I am annoyed here in this Parliament: I have worked for many years in small and medium-sized enterprises and have seen things being adopted here in Parliament that have ultimately brought us small businesses more bureaucracy and more costs, and the Members here have always said: yes, we are adopting this now, but we must ensure that there is no more bureaucracy and more costs. That is the case here again. We cannot stand up and want to implement this matter in this way and at the same time say that we must ensure that it does not lead to additional costs. This will lead to additional costs! It is definitely not the case that we are having problems here with food regulations or with the quality of food, if we have this labelling as it should come. That is simply one thing where the citizens will ask us again: what do you actually decide in Brussels and Strasbourg? What does this bring us? What did you create for bureaucratic monsters again?

name: Daniel Buda (PPE). -
text: The Commission's report sent to the European Parliament and the Council on the compulsory indication of the country of origin or place of provenance of meat used as an ingredient led me to vote in favour of this resolution.  According to this report, existing traceability systems in the European Union are not adequate for the transmission of origin information along the food chain. It is also stressed that 90% of consumer respondents believe that the indication of origin on the product label is important. Food safety must be a major concern for all actors involved in this process, and the lack of effective regulation that ensures clear traceability of products that reach everyone's tables is a threat to our health.  Consumer distrust automatically generates a decrease in product consumption that will have a major negative impact on both large processors and small processors. We're all going to have to lose.  Clear legislation in this area is a safety belt for a healthy life! Let's not forget that before we're politicians, we're consumers.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR). -
text: Mr President, Robert Burns’ tribute to the haggis begins: Fair fa’ your honest, sonsie face,  Great chieftain o’ the puddin’-race! For those of you here who have enjoyed haggis you will realise that it is quality sheep, but is it quality British sheep, is it quality Scottish sheep? That is the real question.  This particular piece of legislation will ensure that we are certain that when we eat haggis we are eating Scottish haggis, made with Scottish sheep. It will give us confidence in the way that we are able to consume processed food. That is a good thing. That will help not just Scottish farmers and Scottish consumers, but across the whole of the EU. That is why I was comfortable and happy, pleased and proud, to support this particular proposal.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE). -
text: I voted in favour of the resolution on the labelling of the origin of meat in processed foods. Meat traceability requires more than 90 percent of consumers. After a number of scandals in the food sector, consumer confidence in food is being tested. Therefore, adopting this resolution is a step in the right direction to raise confidence in quality food.  The labelling of the origin of meat in foodstuffs also allows the consumer to opt for food produced in the immediate vicinity. Locally produced food, short food chains are the correct direction of European agricultural policy, which must also be supported from an environmental point of view. Today we are also talking a lot about the transatlantic investment-trade agreement, which gives birth to a number of new distrusts. This is another reason why we must ensure that European consumers know clearly which country the meat that is in the food comes from. The European Commission should make efforts to make regulation as cheap and simple as possible.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the need for greater transparency and traceability of food products has become a growing demand, and increasingly, on the part of European citizens, especially following the recent and repeated food fraud, not least that of horsemeat. The request by this House, with which I agree, for the Commission to present legislative proposals to make it compulsory on the labelling of foodstuffs to indicate the origin of meat used in processed foods goes precisely in the direction desired by consumers, but these must not be loaded with higher costs. The existence of stringent rules may not protect us from fraud, but it will help, I am sure, to detect them and, above all, it will provide consumers with the information they need to guide them towards a more informed and safer choice of products. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, I supported the proposal for mandatory country-of-origin labelling for meat in processed food because, as many other speakers have said, research has proven that EU consumers want access to this information. This is also important for farmers in countries like my own – Ireland – who deserve to have their produce recognised but who also need the protection of law, ensuring that companies cannot label products for example as being Irish when in fact they are not. The Bord Bia voluntary labelling scheme in Ireland already includes meat in processed meals and this scheme has had a huge uptake with almost 40 000 producers and 122 processors currently involved. It is clear that this is not just what consumers want but it is also what is in the best interests of farmers and businesses.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE). -
text: I myself supported this proposal, mainly because the arguments of consumers must be over the arguments of corporations, for the most part, the only objective of which, of course, is to make a profit, regardless of the potential victims. It is important to know the origin of meat in processed food, but also, of course, in the original, because health is an important value, but nowadays it is difficult to protect it in a flood of products for which we do not really know where they come from, and this information is also important in making consumer decisions about what they are buying.  In doing so, however, we must ensure that this labelling is understandable and therefore also consumer-friendly. Of course, corporations will not do this in themselves, because it represents an additional cost to the providers of these goods, but we must not sacrifice health to protect only capital interests, and it seems to me that this resolution is a step in the right direction.  However, it must, of course, be ensured that it is implemented in practice in a satisfactory and logical manner.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! We all want healthy food. We all want traceability. I must also say that this is also about the products processed. I have to say that I was unable to vote in favour of the motion. From my point of view, the heading is correct, and the content is quite simple, as they say, unhelpful and unhelpful. I would just like to point out to those colleagues who support the motion that the horsemeat scandal that we had in the European Union would have taken place with the implementation of these laws. For he who cheats is cheating. It doesn't matter if I can trace the horsemeat – it still didn't listen. I believe that we must also allow freedom to conduct a business. Those who offer regional products must also guarantee that the products are truly regional. The manufacturer who says that I guarantee that my products, my pigs from the European Union, will be able to go into the sausage must also be able to decide this freely, and the other, who is active internationally, must be able to do so internationally. A lot of bureaucracy, little effect. That is why we need to continue to discuss this.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I have long supported labelling products and their composition. But for every rule of law, we have to ask whether European consumers need it and what the consequences will be. I think there will be two impacts, both on manufacturers and consumers. In both cases, this will only have an impact on the increase in the price of the final product. I therefore supported the position of the European People's Party, which supports the designation of the origin of meat in processed foods only on a voluntary basis. In our view, EU legislation must have borders, and not every meat must immediately be a library or a trade in a lot of information.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul People care about what they eat. That is why we have pushed for clear information, comprehensible information and origin marking of all fresh meat. It's now. However, the Commission clearly shows that further labelling of ingredients is not feasible. It would increase prices by 9% and it would increase the administrative burden on businesses by 30%, and consumers are not ready to pay for it.  It is also misleading to claim that it would discourage cheating. Mislabelling should be regarded as a crime and we need dissuasive penalties, we need stronger control and we need to implement the rules that exist. More rules are not a solution. My proposal is to improve the voluntary labelling system in place to increase consumer choice and the ability of businesses to profile themselves. That is why I have voted against.  I believe that there will be innovation and technology that will increase transparency and traceability, such as the EPR code. It is high time to bring out real consumer voices. Additional labelling does not protect consumers. I'm going to keep saying damn about the food cheat.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, I supported the resolution. This is not, of course, such a big deal that it needs any explanation, yet I would like to warn this Chamber, and the consumer protection lobby as well, that we may need to rethink the ways of guaranteeing these rights. Already now, when buying a sausage, I need a mighty magnifying glass in order to read the nano-letters on the label. What does the information on the canned fish mean when it says that the fish was caught ‘in region F’? Should I go to a library to find out whether that is in the Atlantic or the Indian Ocean? We should be more careful next time we tackle these problems.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: Mr President, honourable Members, I supported the proposal because I believe that the arguments put forward by the rapporteur and the comments and recommendations made are correct. The report on the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods is important in the range of legal measures to be taken to protect the interests and health of consumers. Every user has the right to know what they are eating, where it is produced and who is responsible for any irregularities. The same applies to control bodies, which will thus be given the opportunity to monitor and control the supply and marketing of meat and meat products. It should be noted that the introduction of mandatory labelling will not further the meat processing undertakings. On the contrary, this would lead to a better look of their product, better marketing and increased competition. The truth is that at the moment we have a problem with illegal imports and dumped imports of meats being processed. This is hurting our businesses. If we illuminate this sector, it will benefit meat processing plants and Member States.  This measure will have a tangible effect on food trade fraud and reduce the share of the informal economy in the sector. In conclusion, the most important thing to be guided by is to protect consumers' right to know what they are buying and what they are eating.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I voted against this resolution because it is based and justified on two premises which are totally false. The first is that labelling will prevent fraud such as horse meat: false. The second is that labelling improves food quality and safety: false and also puerile. Food quality and safety do not depend on a label, but on legislation we have in the European Union to ensure both aspects. For this we do not need more labels, but greater more effective controls and sanctions that deter those who break the law. We already have mandatory labelling for fresh meat, and voluntary for processing. Going further translates into more bureaucracy and costs—especially for small and medium-sized enterprises—which, at the end of the food chain, consumers have to pay. And we mustn't make that obligatory. Nothing is free, but there are costs that are necessary, and superfluous costs like this.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. — (SV) Today the European Parliament voted on the origin marking of meat in processed food. In the past, the European Parliament has supported rules that require clear and comprehensible information and compulsory origin marking to cover all fresh meat. These rules apply and I stand behind them. The Commission has been clear that further labelling of ingredients in processed food is not feasible. It would increase food prices by up to 9% and the administrative burden on businesses by 30%. This would be a major blow to many consumers and, at the same time, it is misleading to claim that it discourages cheating. Mislabelling shall be regarded as an offence to be dealt with by dissuasive penalties, stronger control and implementation of existing rules. I voted in favour of the EPP's amendment on a voluntary labelling system, in order to increase consumer choice and the ability of companies to profile themselves.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — According to a study promoted by the European Commission in June 2013, 90% of the citizens questioned believe that it is important that the origin of processed meat contained in food is visible on the label. Today, manufacturers of processed food can choose whether or not to indicate the origin of the elements that make up their processed product. For example, lasagna processed in Italy may contain meat and other products from other European and non-European countries. The information thus promoted is not transparent and, in our opinion, it is not in line with what consumers are asking for. We believe that, in order to make a conscious choice and to prevent food fraud, meat and other elements that make up Italian products should have clear labelling in the same way as fresh beef. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution promoted by the ENVI Committee.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods because it represents an improvement in the information received by consumers as regards the origin of food. In the meat sector there have been numerous scandals due to the practices of large industries that seek to maximize their profit without addressing the safety and quality of food and its impact on the territory. Consumers are increasingly aware of the need to know the origin of the food they eat as a way to reapopiate the food. In April, the indication of the origin of meat in unprocessed foods will be mandatory, and this resolution calls on the Commission to develop legislative measures to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat also in processed foods, in order to force the large agri-food industry and not only producers with less capital. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, which provides strong measures to ensure that mandatory country-of-origin labelling for processed meat products is included on all processed meats. The benefits of origin labelling are not limited to consumers: it is clear from the number of producers and farmers who have voluntarily opted into the Bord Bia scheme in Ireland that it offers advantages to the food industry. Moreover, this resolution highlights the need for more transparency, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — As a result of the BSE crisis, information on the country of origin for fresh beef and beef products has been required since January 2002. From April 2015, the indication of origin will also be mandatory for fresh, chilled or frozen unprocessed pork, sheep, goat and poultry meat in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 on food information for consumers. In the wake of recent food scandals, such as the horsemeat scandal, the EU is being asked to restore consumer confidence. Information on the origin of meat used as an ingredient contributes to better traceability of the food chain and to greater care on the part of food business operators in the selection of their suppliers. Parliament's resolution urges the Commission to submit a legislative proposal to this effect, which will require the origin marking of meat in processed foods in order to create greater transparency throughout the food supply chain and to provide better information to EU consumers. I can only agree with this view, because I believe that consumers of processed foods should recognise where the meat in the food comes from.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — This motion for a resolution provides additional protection for consumers in the Member States in terms of food and health safety controls. The indication of the place of origin favours the relocation of certain production activities, giving a guarantee of quality, especially in view of the obvious distortions within the European Union in this area. Finally, it is an element aimed at reducing the asymmetry of information that consumers may suffer from, but also allowing the market for meat used in processed foods to be more segmented in order to promote competition between players who respect traceability and origin requirements.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Labelling is no guarantee that meat will be processed correctly. There is a trade-off between consumer desire for transparency and consumer desire to keep costs down, for example. We are talking here about processed foods, which are not a single food item.  If you are sourcing ingredients from different sources on a day-to-day basis, then there are issues with administration. Low-priced products could be lost as a result of this resolution.  Voluntary labelling is one thing; legislation for mandatory labelling is another thing altogether. On the other hand, I recognise that British farmers want to have their products labelled. For their sake, I abstained rather than voting against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because I am in favour of voluntary labelling and not mandatory labelling as this text advocates.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to lay down rules to oblige producers of processed foods containing meat to indicate the origin of meat. A consumer survey by the European Commission showed that 9 out of 10 surveyed are important to know the origin of meat in processed foods. The marking would apply to products such as lasagne or Bologna sauce. I agree that more detailed information on the packaging will help to trace meat suppliers and ensure the quality of meat and to restore consumer confidence in the wake of the horsemeat scandal.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods in the wake of the horsemeat lasagna scandal. Beyond the health reasons that make traceability of food essential, it is perfectly normal for consumers to have access to information about the origin of meat. This will enable them to choose local products and thus support our French breeders who are suffering from unfair competition imposed by the Union.  While regretting that this resolution does not go any further - it is only a question of indicating the place where the last "important transformation" was made, while more precision would be desirable (particularly with regard to the place of breeding, the type of food and especially the method of slaughtering) - I consider the indication of the country of origin as a laudable first step towards consumer protection.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — The origin of beef and unprocessed beef products has been mandatory since 1 January 2002, following the BSE crisis. From April 2015, country of origin will also become mandatory for unprocessed pork, goat and poultry. The resolution calls on the Committee to draw up legislative proposals to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat in processed products. I supported this resolution, which aims to increase transparency throughout the food chain and to better inform European consumers.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods seeks to improve the information given to the consumer. Compulsory labelling aims to contribute to improving transparency and regain consumer confidence after scandals such as horse meat. However, it is not clear what the economic impact will be on the final price of the product and how the introduction of this proposal will affect the competitiveness of companies. We have opted for abstention pending further studies carried out by the European Commission, which we hope will be done in collaboration with consumer and business organisations.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — This has been a very passionate debate, as it concerns the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods. I voted in favour of the obligation to have the country of origin appear on the labelling because of the need for consumers to know the origin of that meat. From April, the obligation for fresh meat will also enter into force.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This legislative proposal aims to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods following the "Spanghero" scandal of horsemeat lasagna.  In order to protect ly well from any health risks, it is obviously necessary to indicate the origin of the ingredients, especially since the impact of labelling remains very small (1 euro cent). It also allows us to prefer the purchase of local products and thus to promote the short circuits that the FN defends. This text is therefore a first step towards greater transparency, even if there are still necessary details to be made concerning, for example, places of birth, livestock or the method of slaughter. I have therefore spoken in favour of this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I think it is the right of every consumer to know exactly where the meat in the food preparations he buys on the shelves comes from. The indication of the country of origin is of fundamental importance for the protection of citizens' health. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the text presented.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The parliamentary resolution calls on the Commission for legislative measures to indicate on the labelling the place of origin of meat used in processed foods. The Socialists have always advocated the labelling of origin for primary products as an element of quality, while we have given our support to any balanced measure aimed at ensuring a traceability system that allows us to easily discover where in the chain deception or counterfeiting has taken place.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it supported the consumer's right to know the country of origin of meat used in processed meat products. Thus, this document has decided that a specific labelling of processed meat products will now have to be introduced. Based on the 2013 A consumer survey by the Food Chain Assessment Consortium, of the various food groups assessed, focused on the country of origin labelling of meat foods. Also, a closer examination of the types of meat processed products showed that more than 90% of the consumers who took part in the survey were concerned that the country of origin was indicated.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) The resolution we have voted on today deals with a very important issue for the European agri-food sector: that of ensuring greater transparency of information for consumers. I am convinced that transparency and traceability help to strengthen the relationship of trust between consumers and businesses, in this way enhancing the many quality products that characterise the different European territories. By adopting this resolution, which I supported with my vote in favour, we intend to encourage the Commission to present its report on the costs and benefits of labelling as soon as possible, which is in fact already awaited by the end of 2014. It will then be possible to enter the legislative phase and arrive at certain indications regarding the origin of the meat present in processed foods, a result that will have to be achieved with a particularly careful eye in order to avoid the increase in costs and administrative burdens.

name: Mario Borghezio (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I have decided to support, through my vote, the motion for a resolution aimed at indicating, in processed foodstuffs containing meat ingredients, the indication of origin of the same, even if it moves within a legislative framework totally insufficient to ensure transparency due to European consumer citizens and the correct value to the agricultural raw material. In the face of this, the food industry's unease about the additional costs that indication of origin could cause, comes second. , to fairly reward the entire agri-food chain and bring out quality production.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — Following major scandals and fraud, there has been a need for a legal solution that would make such cases impossible or at least more difficult. That is why we need to send a signal to the European Commission to propose new regulations. A declaration that does not state that, for example, lasagna produced in Country A contains meat from country B is not fair to consumers and paves the way for various frauds. Such a situation can be solved relatively easily and at no great cost to manufacturers. After all, I find consumer trust invaluable. Furthermore, labelling the country of origin of meat will make it easier for national authorities to combat food fraud and punish perpetrators. I believe that this is in the interest of European consumers, 90% want to know where the meat they eat is from. The Common Market of the European Union creates a number of choices for consumers and producers, but sometimes it also opens loopholes exploited by reckless speculators. Such loopholes should be closed and citizens' health and consumer rights further protected.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the country of origin of meat in processed foods. The Spanghero lasagna scandal only reinforces the legitimate concern of consumers who want more traceability. It is not appropriate to put the interests of industrialists ahead of the health safety of Europeans. The economic argument for the cost represented by this measure seems to be greatly exaggerated by the Commission. Indeed, a study by Que Choisir shows its low impact, in the order of the euro cent. More stringent rules should also be put in place on the indication of where to breed, slaughter and even how it is raised.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted yes because I consider this resolution important for the protection of the health of our citizens.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) The need to know the origins of what we eat is a priority for all of us European citizens, because the protection of our health and the freedom to choose as consumers are inalienable rights at the heart of all the health and environmental interventions that we have adopted here. We cannot fail to accept the call for the Commission to provide for an indication of the origin of meat in processed foods, because transparency for the benefit of consumers is the first criterion to be observed. I believe, however, that it is necessary to provide for an accurate analysis of the costs and benefits, including the legal impact on the internal market and on international trade that the provision of compulsory indication of the country of origin or place of origin would have. Finally, I would like to remind you that the food supply chain does not stop only at the raw material, but consists of processing steps, made of history, culture and experience, such as those used to make "made in Italy" cured meats. It is right to inform consumers about the origin of food, but it is also necessary to enhance and protect the 'savoir faire' of our processing industry, which in many cases gives added value to the raw material.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Commission's report sent to the European Parliament and the Council on the compulsory indication of the country of origin or place of provenance of meat used as an ingredient led me to vote in favour of this resolution.  According to this report, existing traceability systems in the EU are not adequate for the transmission of origin information along the food chain. It is also stressed that 90% of consumer respondents believe that the indication of origin on the product label is important. Food safety must be a major concern for all actors involved in this process, and the lack of effective regulation that ensures clear traceability of products that reach everyone's tables is a threat to our health.  Consumer distrust automatically generates a decrease in product consumption that will have a major negative impact on both large processors and small processors. We're all going to have to lose. Clear legislation in this area is a safety belt for a healthy life! Let us not forget that, before we are politicians, we are consumers.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the measure. Legislative proposals for compulsory indication of the origin of meat were urgently requested. I find the arguments put forward by those who argue against this that the indication is too costly ridiculous! We protect our farmers, protect health and always check where the products we eat come from!

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. — Food labelling should always be considered an added value in the marketing process and when providing guarantees to the consumer; this compensates for what can be considered bureaucratic hurdes or possible price increases, which is also not clear that they will occur. In addition, knowledge of the origin of food may be an advantage in the marketing of products and not a handicap.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution for the mandatory country of origin of meat used in processed foods. The European Union must impose strict meat labelling to improve the traceability of processed foods. This is necessary in order to protect consumers and fight fraud. We must learn from the horsemeat scandal. Through this resolution, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to draw up a proposal to make country-of-origin labelling of meat used in processed foods mandatory.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I would like to express my reluctance to support the mandatory requirement to incorporate labelling with the origin of the product in processed foods. In my view, there is not sufficient depth in the costs or effects of this measure on the processing chain of the product; the benefits of this to the consumer are also not needed and the strength of the single market is jeopardized by introducing nationalism and the reference to geographical origin within the EU.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the indication of the country of origin of meat on the label of processed foodstuffs. With this resolution, Parliament has sent an important signal to the European Commission, clearly asking it to put in place a legislative initiative on the labelling of processed meat that strengthens the principle of compulsory indication of origin of meat, making a decisive contribution to strengthening the health of consumers and ensuring that they can make a conscious choice. It should be remembered that, according to a recent study by the European Commission, 90% of the consumers surveyed consider it important that the label of processed foodstuffs indicates the origin of the meat. Greater transparency would also help to ensure better traceability along the food chain and thus to detect and combat possible infringements, enabling the authorities to conduct more effective investigations into cases of food fraud.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which provides strong measures to ensure that mandatory country-of-origin labelling for processed meat products is included on all processed meats. The benefits of origin labelling are not limited to consumers: it is clear from the number of producers and farmers who have voluntarily opted into the Bord Bia scheme in Ireland that it offers advantages to the food industry. Moreover, this resolution highlights the need for more transparency, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Product traceability should be one of the principles applied more comprehensively in the Common European Market. Consumers have the right to be informed and The Member States have a duty to inform and thereby protect their citizens. We believe, however, that labelling should be compulsory and not voluntary.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. "I have positioned myself in favour of this resolution, which is a first step on the road to consumer protection. The resolution enshrines the traceability of food, an indispensable measure, as we have seen with the horsemeat lasagna scandal. In addition to a primary food safety measure, food tracing will have a lower economic cost, as a Que Choose study has shown. I only regret that the resolution did not go any further, for example by determining the method of slaughter, which is a growing concern among our compatriots.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. — I am glad the European Parliament endorsed my Committee’s proposal, so that we can convince the European Commission to bring a labelling proposal to the table. Families want to know, and should know, where the meat they buy and eat comes from. In fact, consumer surveys show that over 9 out 10 people want to know the origin of the meat contained in the products they choose, especially after last year’s horsemeat scandal. While we must acknowledge that better traceability alone will not put an end to food fraud, better traceability gives consumers information they value and helps food manufacturers and retailers to make better informed decisions when choosing their suppliers. Unprocessed beef prices did not escalate when labelling of origin became mandatory, and neither will those of processed food including meat, according to research conducted by the Commission itself and by consumers’ organisations in the EU.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. — Balance is important when new rules are adopted. It is possible that country of origin labelling for meat in processed foods will have some positive effects, but at the same time the proposal could lead to more red tape and increased costs for the food industry, and thus less competitiveness, rising consumer prices and, above all, job losses.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against this resolution because I believe that the indication of origin for meat used as ingredients does not represent added value for European consumers and therefore is not worth paying the cost. In fact, apart from the cases of fraud in recent years (where the existing rules have been circumvented, so we need better application instead of new rules), fixing the ability of Italian companies to transform is mortifying on origin. A different discourse applies to products protected by Geographical Indications of all kinds (PDO, PGI, etc.) and fresh meat, but we run the risk of flooding the consumer with non-relevant information that makes important information less visible.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted against compulsory origin labelling for meat products used in processed food today as I believe that we need to send a strong message that excessive regulation for SMEs will not be tolerated. This is about protecting jobs. An estimated 99 % of EU businesses have fewer than 250 employees. These firms are the job creators in Ireland and they must be protected against regulation and unnecessary red tape. Irish food companies already adhere to a wide range of food safety, traceability and quality standards. Let us be very clear on this: the proposed measures would not enhance food safety or quality.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. — Labelling on the country of origin or place of provenance of meat and meat products is one of the main concerns of European consumers, especially in the wake of several food scandals that have become public in recent years. Despite the current requirement to make this information mandatory in unprocessed beef and voluntary information for other cases, the practice of fraudulent systems in traceability and information in the food chain has not been avoided. In matters of public health and food safety, I believe that a compulsory regime is the most appropriate, contributing, on the one hand, to a more rigorous system in the traceability of products along the food chain and, on the other hand, to a more enlightened and transparent choice by the consumer, influencing their behaviour at the time of choice. Such a measure should always take into account the principle of proportionality in administrative burdens for operators in the sector and the competent supervisory authorities, trying to mitigate its effects on increased prices, supply breaks and food waste.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. — I voted against this motion for a resolution. I believe that the mere indication of the country of origin or place of origin in meat and meat products cannot prevent cases of fraud such as the recent horsemeat scandal. Although consumers are generally interested in origin marking, the majority of them are not prepared to bear the additional costs resulting from the increased administrative burden. There have been binding rules on the various indications of origin of beef and its products since 2002. In addition, under a new regulation, the indication of origin for unprocessed pork, sheep, goat and poultry meat will also become mandatory from April 2015. It is now crucial that eu food production standards are effectively applied and that stricter traceability rules are adopted to prevent future scandals.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this motion for resolution as it continues to further strengthen consumer protection within the European Union. Consumers have increasingly become more conscious of the food products they wish to acquire. Research has also indicated that it is important for them to know the origin of the meat used in processed food products as well as for the raw product. Some European retailers and manufacturers have already responded to this consumer demand by labelling the origin of meat in processed foods and this may well influence consumer behaviour. Food fraud is to be addressed by providing greater transparency throughout the food chain thereby providing consumers with information. The procedure implemented must however take account of the need to avoid excessive costs and administrative burdens on businesses.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Under Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 on the provision of food information to consumers, the Commission should have adopted specific implementing acts by 13 December 2013 to make it compulsory to indicate the origin of meat used as a primary ingredient where its absence could mislead the consumer as to the actual origin or origin. However, the Commission has never adopted implementing acts to this effect and at the moment, as far as meat used as an ingredient in processed foods is concerned, there is no compulsory labelling and voluntary labelling is a source of confusion and food fraud of various kinds. I could only vote in favour of this proposal, the aim of which is to urge the Commission to make origin labelling compulsory for meat used as an ingredient in processed foods as well. However, the Movement requires a step-by-step approach that starts from the regulation of voluntary labelling through the adoption of implementing acts. In this first phase, we want those who decide to use labelling as a means to do so conscientiously and in accordance with precise rules, while those who decide not to join the voluntary scheme can no longer indicate the origin of the meat in question (with the consequent marketing disadvantages).

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods because it represents an improvement in the information received by consumers as regards the origin of food. In the meat sector there have been numerous scandals due to the practices of large industries that seek to maximize their profit without addressing the safety and quality of food and its impact on the territory. Consumers are increasingly aware of the need to know the origin of the food they eat as a way to reapopiate the food. In April, the indication of the origin of meat in unprocessed foods will be mandatory, and this resolution calls on the Commission to develop legislative measures to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat also in processed foods, in order to force the large agri-food industry and not only producers with less capital. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. - Parliament has drawn conclusions from the scandal of beef dishes mixed with horsemeat and has asked the Commission to present a legislative proposal setting out clearly the origin of the meat for each product. According to the EP, the previous rules proved too light and called on the Commission to submit a new version which, inter alia, makes it mandatory to indicate the place of birth, breeding and killing, as well as the exceptions for trims and minced meat. The decision resulting from the work has been adopted. The new legislation will be mandatory from April 2015. Many have expressed concern that mandatory labelling can not only lead to price increases for food business operators, but also lead to an increase in consumer prices. I do not believe that either aspect can be ignored, but we cannot put consumers at risk for health or food safety. Balancing the two sides is the most important thing for the EU market.  Among the European Parliament's arguments is the advantage of the new legislation that the indication of the origin of meat ingredients can help to monitor ingredients more closely and makes it easier for manufacturers to choose between suppliers and products. I voted in favour of the reporter's proposals.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — The main aim of the resolution is to urge the Commission to make the indication of the origin of meat in processed foods derived from fresh meat of swine, sheep, goats and poultry mandatory, while taking into account its impact assessments and avoiding excessive administrative burdens and costs for consumers and enterprises. Mandatory Union rules on country-of-origin labelling of beef and beef products have been in place since 2002. They were introduced as a consequence of the BSE (bovine spongiform encephalopathy) crisis. From the Commission’s own research 90% of consumers want to know the origin of meat in processed foods. In the wake of the horsemeat scandal there is an even more pressing need for clear information to consumers and more transparency and accountability in the food supply chain. Hence I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. — According to a Commission survey of SMEs, most of them change suppliers three or more times a year in order to guarantee the necessary level of raw materials and quality at an affordable price. I believe that mandatory labelling of the country of origin would lead to increased administrative burdens for SMEs and a significant increase in production costs, as well as an increase in price pressure for farmers, with 90% of these costs to be imposed on consumers.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution adopted today by the European Parliament on the indication of the country of origin in the labelling of meat contained in processed foodstuffs. I believe that, as is already the case with unmanaled meat, the indication of the origin of meat contained in processed products is an essential, if not sufficient, element in order to guarantee a greater degree of traceability in the food chain, providing consumers with more information and promoting increasingly responsible behaviour on the part of operators in the sector in the choice of suppliers. We have always been calling for clear labels at the service of consumers. The resolution also calls on the Commission to submit legislative proposals in this regard. Of course, particular attention will have to be paid in legislation to the need to establish European rules that are effective in consumer protection and that at the same time avoid excessive burdens and costs for companies operating in the sector.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This resolution calls on the European Commission to be more vigilant about the labelling of processed dishes and calls on it to present a new legislative proposal to the European Parliament to do so. Current regulations provide for mandatory labelling for meat, but the provisions for processed dishes are not being implemented at this time. This situation is not satisfactory, and further momentum is needed. Although I ask the question of the ability of Member States to ensure the effectiveness of controls throughout the production chain, requiring significant financial and human resources, I wanted to support the process of clarifying the legislative framework, and I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. By voting on this resolution, we have committed ourselves to better consumer protection in the traceability of meat by strengthening the country of origin indication of meat used in processed foods. Further reflection on labelling would then enhance transparency and confidence in the agri-food sector, following the recent crises.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — With this resolution, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to put forward legislative proposals to make it mandatory to mention the origin of meat used in processed foods.  Following the mad cow crisis, the country of origin was made mandatory for beef. This obligation must now be extended to other food categories and cover all ingredients in processed products. The European Union must demand mandatory, clear and intelligible labelling on the part of all operators - producers as intermediaries. This labelling could also enhance local productions and short circuits. Consumers know that it is better to trust a well-identified industry to dispose of quality products, rather than to sacrifice any culinary culture to a cheap and tasteless product. In substance it is obvious that the food trading system is causing unacceptable excesses; it is no longer a question of producing to sell, but of buying always cheaper to resell by earning the most profits. It is therefore essential to return to a more transparent, clearer and more ethical system with fewer intermediaries.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which calls on the Commission to continue to reflect and adopt a legislative proposal on the issue of meat labelling in processed foods. If we had voted against this resolution, we would have put an end to all debate on the issue. Consumers are asking for more information and more transparency and it is our duty to reconcile them with their diet after the crises we have experienced. It is all the more important to ensure this transparency in relation to the various national regulations, and I am thinking in particular of the rules governing GMOs. Consumers have the right to know what is on their plate, whether the animal may have been fed GMOs (depending on its Member State of origin), and to make an informed choice. Nevertheless, increasing costs and administrative burdens will be a key point in future legislative discussion. We will have to strike the right balance between the interests of consumers and the competitiveness of our businesses. We must pay attention to the fact that this proposal, which is relevant in substance, does not turn into a gas plant.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. — This reform is necessary to ensure the traceability and safety of our food. Too much fraud still persists today, it is time to strengthen European law that is too lax on the issue. It is a public health choice.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
