text: Written. — The N-VA delegation voted against the resolution on the labelling of meat in processed foods. We call for the process of voluntary origin labelling to continue, which is already being applied cost-effectively today. Mandatory origin labelling for meat in processed foods is detrimental for a variety of reasons. Origin labelling indicates the origin, but neither increases quality nor traceability and does not prevent fraud. Moreover, it is a taste of protectionism which is contrary to the principles of the Single European Market and is particularly at a disadvantage to smaller export-oriented regions such as Flanders. The operational and practical feasibility is an objection, as are additional administrative costs and burdens that ultimately lead to a higher price for the consumer (who considers origin labelling to be relatively important but does not want to pay extra for it). The N-VA deplores the lack of realism of the adopted text and believes that a solution to the breached consumer trust is not due to additional rules, but to more controls, strict enforcement of existing agreements and tougher sanctions.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which calls on the Commission to put forward a balanced proposal to make it compulsory to indicate the country of origin of meat used in processed foods, on the basis of an impact assessment and taking into account the costs and red tape. This resolution aims to extend the system that already exists for fresh beef and which will be extended to all fresh meats from April 2015. That's a good measure. Labelling increases transparency throughout the food chain. Consumers are demanding such transparency. In December 2013, the European Commission submitted a report on the possible consequences of mandatory labelling of the country of origin or where the meat used as an ingredient comes from. It estimated the cost of this labelling at an additional cost of 15-50%! It did not propose any legislation but advanced, as a possible alternative, EU/non-EU labelling, advertised as less expensive.  This resolution responds to the content of this report and the figures put forward. These figures seem questionable (according to the French Ministry of Agriculture and UFC Que Choisir). The resolution therefore calls on the Commission to re-examine them.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. — I am a strong advocate of consumers knowing where and how their food has been manufactured, however, I do not believe mandatory country of origin labelling would have helped to prevent the horse-meat scandal. The horse-meat scandal was fraud carried out by criminals only interested in making money. We need better enforcement of the current legislation rather than more red tape.  Furthermore, the unintended consequence of country of origin labelling for Northern Ireland has been to restrict market access for liquid milk to the Republic of Ireland. Country of Origin labelling has been manipulated to exclude produce from Northern Ireland being sold in the ROI. This is clearly a breach of the single market obligations and damaging to farmers in my constituency, Northern Ireland. I have no doubt that mandatory country of origin labelling will exacerbate this problem across the EU if not dealt with correctly.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — The proposed resolution provides additional protection for consumers in member States in terms of food and health safety controls. The indication of the place of origin also favours the relocation of certain production activities that guarantee quality, particularly in view of the obvious distortions in the Union in this area. Finally, it is an element that tends to reduce the asymmetry of information that consumers may suffer from, but also allows for a further segmenting of the market for meat used in processed foods in order to promote competition between players who respect traceability and origin requirements.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. — A recent survey carried out by the European Commission showed approximately 90% of European citizens believe clear labelling is important. Since the horsemeat scandal of 2013, consumers have been concerned with knowing the origin of their food. Country of origin labelling is already mandatory for all meat products; it is the obvious next stage to extend that to meat when it is an ingredient in food products. Another clear advantage is that this will enable the consumer to buy nationally produced meat. As a strong supporter of farmers in Scotland, I welcome any legislation that encourages this. Therefore, I was happy to follow the UK Government and ECR Group line and vote in favour.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. — We are voting in favour of this draft because we believe that it provides the guarantees for consumer protection.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. — I voted against the political resolution on the indication of the country of origin of meat components in processed foods. This proposal would require the European Commission to legisnerat a mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin of meat in processed foods. This request raises serious economic and internal market concerns. Although the Commission's impact assessment shows that 90% of consumers are interested in the country of origin of meat products, 80% of them would not support the indication of the country of origin of the meat if this would lead to an increase in the consumer price of food. If mandatory marking were introduced, the costs for meat processors would increase significantly by 30%. Processors would pass on all the additional costs (90% of these costs according to the Commission) to consumers, and the impact assessment therefore foresams a consumer price increase of 6-9%. Therefore, the country of origin marking should not be introduced on meat products. The majority of these products are typically purchased by poorer people, who would no longer be able to buy these products after a significant price increase. Finally, I must point out that food fraud, known as last year's 'horsemeat scandal', could not be prevented, despite the fact that beef has been compulsory since the 2000 crisis caused by spongified edgy disease (BSE). I therefore ask the Commission, irrespective of the EP's position, to refrain from introducing a mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of calling on the Commission to take action on country of origin labelling for meat in processed foods. I have long campaigned for this and my constituents in Wales, consumers and producers, feel very strongly about this measure too. I hope the Commission will now bring legislation forward.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — According to a study by the European Commission, 90 % of consumers wish to be aware of the origin of meat used in processed foods. In the wake of the horsemeat scandal, the need to provide consumers with clear information and to increase transparency and accountability along the food chain has become even more pressing. I voted in favour of this resolution, reflecting the concern of European citizens and call on the Commission to come forward with proposals for mandatory labelling of meat origin in processed foods. At the same time, a level playing field should be ensured for economic operators in the sector, in particular for SMEs, and the necessary measures should be taken to combat fraud by strengthening control.

name: Fredrick Federley Marit Paulsen Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: Written. "We humans have a genetic and cultural heritage that makes us want to know what we eat, and it is therefore quite natural that we are worried about not knowing what the food packaging contains. The consumer's free, informed choice is important to us. We have therefore supported the resolution calling on the European Commission to present a legislative proposal on mandatory origin labelling of meat in processed foods – something that 90% of European consumers say they want – especially as the resolution so clearly emphasises the need for increased and strengthened controls to ensure that consumer information is actually accurate. Furthermore, as is also reflected in the text of the resolution, we believe that any legislative proposal must, of course, be practicable. A law that is not followed or works could equally have been written in water.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — It is estimated that 30-50 % of the total volume of slaughtered meat is processed into meat-based ingredients for foodstuffs, mainly minced meat, meat preparations and meat products. The consumer must therefore be informed of the country of origin or place of origin of this meat. Indication of origin is mandatory in the EU for unprocessed beef and beef products, and this measure should be extended to meat in processed foods. We must not forget the impact that food-related fraud can have on food safety, consumer health, consumer confidence, the functioning of the food chain and the stability of agricultural prices. Combating this fraud must take priority.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — From April this year, the country of origin will be indicated for unprocessed meat of pigs, goats, sheep and poultry, and since the BSE crisis it has already been mandatory for processed and unprocessed beef.  This resolution proposes to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods. Measures are needed to avoid the excessive and unjustified increase in administrative burdens that the amendment may entail for the row and the need to provide for control mechanisms, enabling the authorities to ensure the effective implementation of these standards. The goal is greater transparency along the food chain, alongside improving information from a consumer perspective.  If this instrument contributes to more stable relationships between meat suppliers and processors and to greater care in the choice of suppliers and products by operators in this sector, focusing on proximity, which may result in the appreciation of national production, then it will be positive. We supported this resolution, although we have some doubts about the concrete implementation of the measure, already expressed in the debate and in written questions to the European Commission. We reserve a final position for the time of consideration of the legislative proposals in question.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted whole much in favour of the resolution because it is a step in the right direction to ensure greater transparency, enabling consumers to make informed choices about what they buy and consume. This is a necessary measure. In fact, more than 90% of citizens consider it important that there should also be a label of origin of meat in processed products. I hope that the European Commission will publish a legislative proposal to this effect as soon as possible.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: writing — European consumers have the right to be protected as far as possible and sufficiently informed about the origin of meat in all processed foods. The European Commission should, as soon as possible, put forward proposals to introduce mandatory country-of-farming, slaughter and processing labelling for all meat in already processed foods and not just for fresh meat. Up to 90% of consumers would clearly welcome the extension of the rules on compulsory origin labelling to meat found in ready meals such as baguettes, sandwiches or various types of semi-finished products. The measure at issue would clearly help people to be better oriented when buying and selecting such products. If something is labelled as a Slovak product, it should mean that the meat in it also comes from Slovakia. With today's rule setting, it may not be a matter of course. Transparent labelling should lead to a deepening of consumer confidence, which has unfortunately been affected by a number of scandals in the past and should contribute to improving food quality, to some extent their safety and, above all, consumer information.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) The resolution urgently calls, as we in the Lega Nord have been calling for for years, for legislative proposals for compulsory indication of origin.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the proposal to label the country of origin for meat in processed foods, because I think it is a resolution that moves towards consumer protection.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the country of origin labelling for processed meat products as it increases the transparency of processed food products and ultimately will benefit consumers. The ECR is committed to transparency and accountability in all European regulation and welcomes this opportunity for consumers to make informed choices.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. — European citizens are increasingly demanding in terms of the safety and composition of the foodstuffs they consume, so they have certain expectations regarding the information available on the origin of the products, in particular on the origin of fresh meat and meat used as an ingredient in processed foods. Consumers want to be informed, have all the possible elements when deciding what to consume and what not to consume. Similarly, mandatory labelling requirements must take into account the principle of proportionality, as well as the administrative burden they place on food business operators and the authorities responsible for their implementation.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) With the vote on labelling, we are opening the door to an important debate to protect consumers and their just demand for transparency. Today we did not vote for or against the indication of origin for meat in processed foods, but we simply asked the Commission to put forward a legislative proposal which we will then debate in Parliament. I am well aware that there are concerns, normal when changing the rules. However, with the position adopted today, we will have the opportunity to deepen later through impact assessments and studies such as, where and whether to do so. To say no today would have meant closing in on an ideological position that our consumers would certainly not have understood.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the indication of origin of meat on the label of processed foodstuffs. This is a pronouncement which takes Europe another important step forward in the protection of consumers, quality and the environment. I believe that the European Commission should push for better traceability along the food chain, thereby promoting more stable relations between meat suppliers and processing companies.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. — The recent horsemeat scandal served to damage consumer trust in the meat sector. Whilst country of origin labelling for processed meat used as an ingredient would not have prevented such fraud, the scandal has nonetheless generated greater consumer interest in, and awareness of, the origin of meat and meat products. As policy-makers we need to take action to meet the expectations of today’s consumers. Introducing mandatory country of origin labelling for meat used as an ingredient would therefore constitute an important step towards rebuilding consumer confidence in the meat sector, and would enable consumers to exercise their desire to make more informed choices.  For these reasons I supported today's resolution calling for the European Commission to bring forward proposals in this respect. Any future proposal must naturally seek to minimise the possible cost burdens on producers and consumers, and I would welcome additional assessments from the Commission on how this could be implemented proportionately and cost-effectively.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. — Labelling the origin of meat integrated into prepared food is essential to restore consumer confidence in the wake of the major agri-food scandal that affected many European manufacturers and countries in 2013.  However, I draw the Commission's vigilance that the availability of information is not enough. It needs to be highlighted and understandable.  It is on this basis that consumers will be able to make an informed choice.  So I voted in favour of the resolution calling for traceability of the meat used.  I expect, however, that the Commission will also include in its proposals the type of slaughter and the mode of feeding, GMO or non-GMO, which are essential information to consumers.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this resolution. It is currently mandatory to indicate the place of origin of unprocessed meat when sold in the EU. Following the scandal of horse meat in frozen lasagna and other processed meat products, the Commission raised with Parliament the possibility of introducing this obligation also for processed meat products. Clearly indicating the type of meat is already mandatory, but it is understood that introducing the obligation to indicate the place of origin would help to ensure traceability of the meat ingredients used. The proposed resolution calls on the Commission to take the necessary measures to ensure this obligation. We voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — EU citizens want and have the right to know where the meat and processed products come from. Consumers do not want to have horsemeath on their plates instead of beef, genetically modified meat or meat from cloned animals. It is therefore necessary to listen to the public and to introduce mandatory posting of information on the origin of meat in order to regain consumer confidence in this sector. In the interests of the rights and health of EU citizens, systematic food quality control is also essential.  I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the Commission should put forward a new legislative proposal on this issue. Its proposed solution must also take into account the minimisation of the additional financial burden on producers and consumers.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. — Mandatory labelling of the country of origin of meat already exists for fresh meat, but this requirement does not exist when meat is used as an ingredient in a processed product. The European Parliament therefore calls in this resolution for consumers to be able to know the origin of meat in all food products. This is a real victory for European consumers! They have the right to full information. Personally, I want to know where the meat used in the sausage I just bought in Metz comes from and if this meat comes from France, Europe or elsewhere. I am also very happy that we have won this battle against the European right which, in line with the business position, was against this labelling obligation!

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution for mandatory country of origin labelling for all meat in processed food. We have country of origin labelling for fresh meat but it is crucial that the same rules apply to meat in processed food. Indeed, 90% of consumers want this information, which will allow them to make more informed decisions about the food they buy. Given the supply chain for meat in processed food operates across borders, EU-wide labelling is the only viable option.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I supported the proposal to ask the EU Commission to come forward with a proposal for mandatory country of origin labelling in processed foods. As of April 2015, fresh or frozen unprocessed meat from pigs, sheep, goats and poultry will have to bear information on where the animal was reared and slaughtered. However, the European Parliament has now asked the Commission to come forward with a proposal to ensure that all meat used as an ingredient in processed food, like ready-made meals should have country of origin labelling. This requirement is already there for fresh beef and beef products since January 2002 because of the BSE crisis. We now need the same regulation for all other meat products.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. — The succession of food scandals in recent years has caused trauma and strong consumer mistrust. The European Union has a duty to address these fears by proposing appropriate legislation. The original mention already exists for unprocessed beef and will also apply from 1 April to other animal species. However, the agri-food industries have argued that the requirement to labelling meat in processed products would result in an excessive cost increase of around 50%, which has yet to be proven. I am pleased that the European Parliament has taken the initiative to revive reflection on this subject, because it is a demand of the citizens and it is the credibility of Europe that is at stake here. We are now waiting to hear the response from the European Commission, which has the power of initiative, but I am sure that it will also be keen to propose legislation that strengthens the traceability of the products we consume.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this resolution. It is currently mandatory to indicate the place of origin of unprocessed meat when sold in the EU. Following the scandal of horse meat in frozen lasagna and other processed meat products, the Commission raised with Parliament the possibility of introducing this obligation also for processed meat products. Clearly indicating the type of meat is already mandatory, but it is understood that introducing the obligation to indicate the place of origin would help to ensure traceability of the meat ingredients used. The proposed resolution calls on the Commission to take the necessary measures to ensure this obligation. We voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I voted for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods, as this definitely best protects the interests of consumers. I note that it should be clearly marked on food labels where processed meat has consumed GMO fodder and whether the meat is also from cloned animals. Since it is important for consumers from Croatia to know if meat comes from neighboring countries, I took this as an additional motive to vote for this resolution.  Otherwise, I believe that the argument of the additional cost is a deplased argument, since the labels already have all the data on the composition of the processed product, its caloric value and other data, and therefore it is necessary to add the country of origin of the meat in the processed products.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — The proposed resolution provides additional protection for consumers in member States in terms of food and health safety controls. The indication of the place of origin also favours the relocation of certain production activities, ensuring a certain guarantee of quality, particularly in view of the obvious distortions in the Union in this area. Finally, it is an element that tends to reduce the asymmetry of information that consumers may suffer from, but also allows for a further segmenting of the market for meat used in processed foods in order to promote competition between players who respect traceability and origin requirements.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted against the resolution on mandatory origin labelling. I note that there are a significant number of reports and analysis which suggest that should mandatory origin labelling be brought in, it would add extra burdens on our SMEs, while at the same time giving a limited result in terms of added value.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - EH Bildu has voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on country labelling of meat in processed food as such a regulation could provide greater transparency and help in addressing the potential impact of food fraud in food safety, consumer health and consumer confidence by strengthening traceability systems and the information provided to consumers. Indeed 90% of consumers consider origin labelling important for the food they consume. The recent horsemeat scandal helped to reveal the murky and complex character of our food chains and heightened consumer demands for better information on where the food they eat comes from. We believe that the Commission must listen to these voices and finally come forward with origin labelling proposals for all meat products, including processed foods. EH Bildu hence considers that a legislative proposal stating that the origin of meat in processed foods should be mandatory is needed.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title ‘Country of origin labelling for meat ingredients in processed food’ because we want to ensure greater transparency throughout the food chain and to better inform European consumers.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I do not support the content of the resolution drawn up by the ENVI Committee, which calls on the European Commission to adopt legislation making it compulsory to indicate the origin of meat contained in processed foods. The new act would significantly increase the cost of producing meat products, as the labelling would have to include both the animal's place of birth, rearing and slaughter. As 90% of processing sites are small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), the new rules would have a negative impact on growth, job creation and the competitiveness of the European economy. It is estimated that administrative costs would increase by 30% and processed meat products would increase by 5-9%. Contrary to the rapporteurs' assumptions, the introduction of an obligation to affix the signs in question will not solve the problems of food falsification, such as the recently disclosed practices of replacing beef with horsemeath. The right action in this direction, on the other hand, is to increase the frequency and increase controls. In this situation, the Commission should not put forward legislative proposals in this regard. I believe that the existing voluntary labelling system is sufficient and that any introduction of such an obligation should be left to the Member States. Although I am in favour of a culture of conscious food choice, the costs of the proposed changes appear to be far greater than the potential benefits. However, in order to be clear about this, I support the rapporteurs' call on the European Commission to resolve as soon as possible the discrepancies in the results of the studies on the price impact of the introduction of this act.

name: Jan Keller (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the motion for a resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat ingredients for processed foods by my vote. First of all, because it is not yet a legislative proposal, but merely a call on the European Commission to look further at the subject, including an assessment of all the impacts on consumers, retailers and manufacturers. A public debate on this subject should take place, whatever its results. On their detailed study, I will then based my position on a possible legislative proposal.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I strongly supported the report. Country of origin labelling will help to restore trust in the food industry, which was badly damaged following the horsemeat scandal. Consumers have a right to know where their meat comes from and Labour MEPs have been calling for this for several years. It will allow consumers to make more informed decisions about the food they buy. This is about clear, honest labelling that does not mislead consumers. If a beef lasagne is labelled as a British product, then this should mean that it was made with British beef.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. — (3) We are in favour of consumers being given real information about the food they buy. That is why we also believe that it is important to be able to obtain country-of-origin labelling on meat in processed products. Of course, we are not trying to impose unnecessary and costly rules on companies, but we are sure that it is easy to work with rules on meat origin. For example, it may be possible to use stickers instead of solid packaging labels. The information on the origin of the meat has already been provided by the companies today. We just support the fact that consumers also get this knowledge. That is why we support the decision on the country of origin labelling of meat in processed products and, of course, we will work to ensure that these rules are made as simple and as cheap as possible to comply with.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — European consumers have been rightly angry several times in recent years at meat suppliers who have withheld information about their origin in order to increase their profits. I believe that it is time for the European consumer to be given all relevant information before buying meat to help him make a truly informed decision. The European Union can help in this regard, and I think it is right that it should put the interests of consumers ahead of those of suppliers who refuse to treat their customers with integrity. Consumer organisations have been calling for meat labelling for several years, and the reasons why they should not be complied with go against the interests of citizens who, in essence, do not ask much. They demand the right to information about the food they consume. I do not believe that these demands are out of the way or exorbitant. On the contrary, I would consider it unreasonable if we denied citizens the right to know the origin of the meat consumed and hid behind pseudo-arguments uploading to companies that refuse to tell their customers the whole truth about their products. I therefore believe that it is my duty to vote in favour of a proposal that will help consumers to be more market-oriented.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. - In a niche way, the natural need for consumers to have the exact origin of meat and meat products on the label is finally realised. The designation of origin 'EU/non-EU' has been rejected by consumers.   Between 30% and 50% of the meat of all animals slaughtered in the EU is presented to consumers in processed products. The EU traceability system in its current form was not suitable for traceability throughout the food chain.  Country-wide or region-wide designation of origin helps prevent and will be useful in detecting food counterfeiting. The resolution should therefore be supported, but I still miss the fact that it is not indicated whether or not the animal was fed GMO food. Unfortunately, there is no progress in this, and many of us are demanding it.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I strongly supported the motion for a resolution that I tabled on behalf of the ENVI Committee, because it fully reflects the desire of European consumers to know the origin of meat in processed products, that is to say, by way of example, frozen lasagna, tortellini or canned sauces, information that is now mandatory only for fresh meat. I believe that the request to the European Commission to present a legislative proposal aimed at compulsory indication is necessary. We have also asked for a careful assessment of the consequences for production, in order to avoid excessive costs and administrative obstacles for companies operating in the sector, especially small and medium-sized enterprises. Today's vote is therefore an important signal for regaining the confidence of European consumers and embarks on a path that will see us engaged with the Council in defining the individual provisions.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution calling on the European Commission to table a legislative proposal to make it mandatory to label (traceable) all meats used in prepared meals. After the horsemeat lasagna scandal, it was our duty to restore consumer confidence by improving transparency and providing full information about the products they buy.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — I supported Parliament's resolution calling on the Commission to legislate for mandatory labelling of the origin of meat in processed products. A Commission text on the subject will strengthen food safety while reassuring consumers. This is all the more necessary after the scandal of horsemeat present in lasagna. I recall that when this case was disclosed, I had written to the President of Parliament requesting a commission of inquiry into cases of fraud in the food sector and ways to strengthen controls. Parliament's request is therefore a step in the right direction, which is why I welcome Parliament's fact that it has not listened to the arguments of the right, which argued that such rules could harm the competitiveness of the sector. The Commission will have to show us that it is more concerned with the well-being of consumers than that of the agri-food giants. That is why I will ensure that this request does not go unheeded.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. "I voted for this text because it allows for better traceability of meat and therefore increased protection for the consumer and the possibility for him to choose local products.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. — Positive vote for this resolution, which aims to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods following the various food scandals (Spanghero company and its horsemeat lasagna). This has alarmed consumers, who are increasingly demanding about the quality and information about the products they buy. This traceability is essential for several reasons. It will allow the consumer to make an informed choice about the food they eat and to support our French breeders who suffer from unfair competition and who have long demanded this traceability.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods because it represents an improvement in the information received by consumers as regards the origin of food. In the meat sector there have been numerous scandals due to the practices of large industries that seek to maximize their profit without addressing the safety and quality of food and its impact on the territory. Consumers are increasingly aware of the need to know the origin of the food they eat as a way to reapopiate the food. In April, the indication of the origin of meat in unprocessed foods will be mandatory, and this resolution calls on the Commission to develop legislative measures to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat also in processed foods, in order to force the large agri-food industry and not only producers with less capital. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I am in a good place for people to be able to buy quality products. However, I do not agree with the central order on what packaging, labels and other product labels should look like. All these measures only make production more expensive and do not respect the fact that some people prefer to buy at a lower price than pay more for detailed marking. As customers themselves, people will determine which company they will trust and from which they will buy the goods. If they do not trust companies that do not label meat satisfactorily and only buy from companies that label products to the customer's liking, then natural self-regulation will occur in the market. Companies with insufficient labelling will see their profits fall, or they will not be able to stand up to the market at all, or they will have to improve labelling. However, I am definitely in a good place so that the customer can freely choose whether he wants a lower price or more detailed marking.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. - It is of utmost importance that we know the origin of all the products we consume. Consumers expect to be duly informed of what they are purchasing and their confidence should be justified. However, I am not convinced that mandatory labelling requirements will offer the necessary certainty. I supported the 'for' position of voluntary labelling as I believe that further research is needed on how mandatory labelling would affect everyone from the small trader to the mass producer. It is desirable to avoid excessive costs and administrative difficulties – we must ensure that mandatory labelling does not impose an additional burden on small and medium-sized enterprises in the sector. Voluntary labelling gives time for adaptation. In addition, the labelling of the country of origin or place of origin for meat and meat products does not in itself prevent fraud. Strict controls, prevention and the fight against food fraud must be an integral part of EU policies. This is what will restore the trust of European consumers.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the text of the resolution in general, although I voted with my political group against Amendment 7D to paragraph 6 (in English: 'stricter rules on traceability are wanted by consumers and could help in investigating food fraud') proposed by the People's Party Group. My group and I were also opposed to the People's Party's amendment on horsemeat (section 7, 8D Amendment 1 — we asked for the text to be deleted, in English: deletes — 'Horsemeat significant share of meat used in processed foods'). The People's Party's Amendment to paragraph 19 (in English: "calls on the Comission to come forward with legislative proposals for mandatory labeling of meat in processed foods" did not go away, otherwise our entire S&D group would vote against the entire resolution. We also did not support the 'compatriots' amendment to recital D (in English: 'pork and poultry represent larger share of meat in processed food and processing different than for beef') and were concerned with the original text of the resolution in this case.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: writing — Maximum consumer awareness of the composition of food and food products is also a way to increase public health. The consumer has the right to decide what food he buys not only in terms of price, but also because of its composition, origin and with regard to his health. We live in a time when different types of allergies are becoming an obvious part of our lives. Precise labelling of food composition is one way to increase the health of the population. Recently, we have witnessed unfair handling in proving the origin of meat in processed foods. It is therefore essential that the Commission urgently submit legislative proposals to address the proof of origin of individual ingredients in processed foods, so as to prevent fraud in the field of nutrition of the population and to strengthen consumer protection.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the labelling of the country of origin for meat in processed foods, because it is necessary to label and enhance the safety and quality of meat so that meat from cloned animals cannot be used. Furthermore, labelling cannot cover up any mixing of beef and horsemeat, as has been found to have taken place in various food scandals in the EU which have resulted in a lack of confidence in the functioning of the single internal market.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. — Food traceability is necessary to ensure health standards and to prevent further incidents such as the Spanghero scandal. This resolution will allow the traceability of the meat, which will protect the consumer, who will be able to buy safely, and also allow him to choose local products. As this resolution is in favour of the protection of the French consumer, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against the motion for a resolution on the indication of the country of origin of meat on the labelling of processed foodstuffs. I consider this proposal to penalise because compulsory indication of origin for meat used as an ingredient would entail considerable additional costs, resulting in price increases for the final product, which could affect the work of small and medium-sized enterprises, which must instead be protected.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I welcome this resolution which reiterates a call for the Commission to take all necessary steps to make the prevention and combating of food fraud an integral part of EU policy and to address structural weaknesses within the overall food chain, in particular by increasing and strengthening monitoring.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against the resolution because I believe that the labelling requirement would not act as a deterrent to food fraud. As reported in a European Commission study on this subject, it is clear that consumers are not prepared to bear an increased cost in exchange for information on the origin of meat.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This report is positive because it aims to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods on labels in order to ensure more transparency throughout the food chain and to better inform European consumers, while taking into account their impact assessments and avoiding excessive spending and administrative burdens. For this reason, I voted in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — Studies have shown that the origin marking of processed meat is one of the most important concerns of consumers. In order to comply with this and to uphold the Union's high food standards and improve consumer protection, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the country of origin labelling for processed meat as I believe consumers have the right to know where the meat they are consuming comes from.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In the wake of the horse lasagna scandal, this resolution reiterates the importance of food labelling and traceability and proposes to reinforce some aspects of it. It welcomes the obligation, in force from April 2015, to indicate the country of origin for unprocessed pork, sheep, goat and poultry. It also stresses the importance of taking horsemeat into account as meat used in processed foods, as well as beef, pork, sheep, goat and poultry, as it constitutes a significant part of the meat used in processed foods. This lucid text admits that "labelling the country or place of origin of meat and meat products does not prevent fraud." But considering that "a rigorous traceability system does help to detect and combat possible infringements", it calls on the Commission to "legislative proposals to make it mandatory to identify the origin of meat in processed foods, in order to ensure greater transparency throughout the food chain and to better inform European consumers". I vote FOR reminding that neither lasagna, horse nor horse lasagna harms health.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — This resolution calls on the Commission to put forward legislative proposals determining the origin of meat in processed foods, such as that used in lasagna. This must be indicated on the label of such products in order to better inform consumers and ensure greater transparency throughout the food chain, while avoiding excessive financial and administrative burdens.  I voted, however, against this proposal because I believe that such a requirement will bring unaffordable costs to manufacturing industries, which will not translate into benefits for consumers.  Currently, this labelling is already done on a voluntary basis and has been sufficient for consumers to be informed, and if they so wish they only consume food with the proper mentions of origin.  At a time when it is necessary to give european industry a positive boost, I do not think it is appropriate to burden it with additional costs to add information that already exists on a voluntary basis.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — The resolution stresses the importance of clear information about the origin of meat from Member States or third countries because this is an important issue for consumers. The labelling is crucial as it allows consumers to make well-informed choices about their purchases. I have therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I support the European Parliament's resolution on the country of origin of meat used in processed foods. Parliament the European Commission is the order to put forward a proposal to make such an indication mandatory. While consumer confidence has been undermined by the scandals of recent years, the aim is to meet the legitimate expectations of consumers who want to know the origin of the meat they buy. It is also a question of treating fresh and processed meat on an equal footing. In addition to better information to consumers, this system should be used to meet the need for transparency and traceability throughout the food chain.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing — Mandatory indication of the country of origin of meat used in processed foods is, in my opinion, the only rational step to ensure greater transparency throughout the food chain and to improve the awareness of European consumers whose confidence has been shaken by horse and other meat scandals in recent years. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution calling on the European Commission to come forward with an appropriate legislative proposal introducing mandatory labelling of the country of origin of meat in the EU, taking into account sanitary safety, product quality, but also the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises in the regions.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. — A measure that has generated heated discussion within all political groups. I voted against the idea that salami producers should be required to list all the countries where the meats used in that salami (for example) were produced. Why is that? Not to unfairly help the industry to have no costs, on account of consumer misinformation, as some colleagues would say, in the first conclusions. It is to protect Romania from stupid prejudices (and undeserved), as was the case with horsemeat, when not Romanian producers cheated, but the label was stuck with thirst precisely to Romania, as a kind of natural location of fraud. Food safety and hygiene rules must be respected by any producer in the EU, with or without the label of origin. And if a producer wants to label the origin of the meat used, he can do so voluntarily, without any opres, developing a direct and special link with his consumers. Here we are talking about protectionism masked behind some big talk about the consumer. The plenary debate almost made clear the equal sign between origin and quality, i.e. origin and fraud. Which is unfair.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. — The shortcomings of the European food safety system were highlighted by the horsemeat scandal that erupted in 2012. The horsemeat scandal has called into question the traceability and transparency of the European food chain. Therefore, the current resolution resolution takes the view that there is a need for traceability of meat into processed foods at EU level. In this way, we could prevent deliberate misleading consumers and cases of food counterfeiting such as this. If meat products are designated by country of origin, supermarkets with high market position would be forced to use only meat products from reliable sources in their products.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — This motion for a resolution identifies some relevant issues on the issue of labelling.  The label indication of the origin of meat in processed foods, as indicated in the impact study presented by the EC, will lead to an increase in production costs. Given that 90% of the companies in the sector are SMEs, they will have an increase in administrative burdens.  However, labelling relating to the country of origin or place of provenance of meat or meat products does not in itself prevent fraud but a strict system will make it possible to detect infringements and take action in due time in that regard. A better traceability system along the food supply chain will help to make relationships between meat suppliers and processors more stable and healthy and will enable consumers to be more secure in their choices. I voted in favour of this proposal for the reasons mentioned above, considering that the European Union should reflect on a labelling system that ensures greater traceability and better food security.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. In view of the recurring scandals in the agri-food industry, consumers are calling more than ever, and rightly so, for full transparency and increased or even guaranteed food security. Many people want the traceability of the meat to be more complete with, for example, the method of slaughter, the mode of feeding or the place of rearing. Upstream, of course, there are producers who aspire to live decently from their work by making quality. Downstream, there are consumers who want to eat safely. The problem lies, it must be said, in the intermediary, these large groups of the agri-food industry that are only sensitive to profitability and profits. The European Union has in fact been very supportive of the latter over the past 30 years, to the detriment of the interests and food security of consumers. However, it seems that a slight inflection is under way, as the Union cannot ignore the recent scandals and legitimate consumer claims. Moreover, this labelling should strengthen the position of national and local sectors (short circuits that are much less polluting). For all these reasons, I voted for this motion for a resolution.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — Origin labelling should be mandatory for all meat, including meat in processed foods. The Commission’s own research found that 90% of consumers want this labelling. The Commission says that labelling meat in processed foods would incur significant costs, which would be passed on to consumers. However, this is based on industry self-reporting. Consumer research in France found that labelling the origin of beef in a frozen lasagne would cost just EUR 0.015.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which calls on the European Commission to adopt a legislative proposal and to continue the reflection to eventually lead to the country of origin for meat used in processed foods. At the same time, I have supported amendments which underline that this new labelling, which will guarantee greater transparency for the consumer, should not harm the competitiveness of our agri-food companies by unreasonably increasing the burdens and constraints on them. Nor should this measure cause a price increase for the end consumer.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. — I have spoken in favour of this resolution, which aims to ask the European Commission for a legislative proposal on the country of origin for meat used in processed foods.  With a view to future negotiations on a legislative proposal, we will have to strike the right balance between the interests of consumers, who are seeking such a measure, and the competitiveness of our businesses.  We need to commit to more information and transparency in this sector, it is the only way to reconcile consumers with their plates.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — Since January 2002, Community rules on the labelling of beef have been in force, which already include an indication of the place of birth, rearing and slaughter. These requirements have certainly raised high expectations among consumers about information on the origin of other types of fresh meat, which is largely consumed in the Union, and meat used as ingredients in processed foods. With this resolution, we are calling on the Commission to present clear, coherent and harmonised legislative proposals providing for the compulsory indication of the country of origin of meat even in processed products. We believe, however, that mandatory labelling requirements should take into account the principle of proportionality, as well as the administrative burden on food business operators and the authorities responsible for implementing the legislation, providing for their own impact analysis and trying to avoid excessive costs. We believe, in fact, that a rigorous traceability system helps to detect and combat fraud, and could be able to restore the confidence of European consumers and influence their behaviour. Food labelling must take account of the transparency and readability of information for consumers, while at the same time allowing European companies to operate in an economically viable manner.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution, which was born out of the need and willingness of consumers to be properly informed about the composition of processed foods from the meat products they consume, but also as a result of recent scandals caused by the fraudulent replacement of beef with horsemeat. The labelling of the country of origin will become mandatory for unprocessed pigmeat, sheep, goat and poultry from April 2015, following the presentation by the EC of legislative proposals concerning the labelling of the country of origin of meat from processed foods, this practice will become mandatory throughout the EU.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: scryofa. — Chaith mise vóta i bhfabhar an rúin seo mar go gcuireann sé bearta láidre and bhfeidhm chun a chinntiú go bhfuil sé éigeantach lipéadú thír tionscnaimh na feola próiseáilte a chur ar na táirgí seo.  Ní hamháin gur buntáiste é seo do thomhaltóirí, ach tá sé soiléir ón méid táirgeoirí agus feirmeoirí atá mar pháirt de scéim Bhord Bia in Éirinn go bhfuil buntáistí soiléire ag a leithéid do thionscal an bhia. Mar aon leis sin, leagann an rún seo béim ar an ngá atá le níos mó follasachta agus sin an fáth gur chaith méóta i bhfabhar.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — I did not support the resolution on the labelling of meat in processed foods, even though a part of the public is calling for it. I hope that the Commission will give good thought to whether to go down this path. Our analyses indicate considerable difficulties in applying this requirement, would lead to significant problems in practice and, in particular, would cause significant costs. These would be borne by consumers. It is equally clear that no regulation is able to prevent fraud in this area. For similar agreements, the balance of benefits and costs should always be considered. The fact that part of the public or interest groups support regulation is not reason enough to create it. For this reason, I do not think this regulation is appropriate, and that is why I did not support it.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — (DE) As I have already mentioned, the continuous and comprehensible labelling of the origin of meat is a crucial factor in protecting the consumer. In order to be able to guarantee this traceability even better in the future and thus to achieve a complete traceability, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because a more stringent traceability system can detect possible infringements and take appropriate measures. The Commission's report shows that more than 90 % of the responding consumers consider the indication of the origin of meat in processed foodstuffs to be important. However, it is necessary to further examine the potential price impact, since action must be carried out in an economically reasonable manner and in accordance with the consumer's purchasing power.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. — This motion for a resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods seeks to improve the information given to the consumer. Compulsory labelling aims to contribute to improving transparency and regain consumer confidence after scandals such as horse meat. However, it is not clear what the economic impact will be on the final price of the product and how the introduction of this proposal will affect the competitiveness of companies. We have opted for abstention pending further studies carried out by the European Commission, which we hope will be done in collaboration with consumer and business organisations.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — Depending on the Member State, it is estimated that between 30% and 50% of the total volume of slaughtered meat is processed into meat for use as food ingredients, mainly minced meat, meat preparations and meat products. According to the aforementioned Commission report on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for meat used as an ingredient, the traceability systems existing in the EU are not adequate to transmit information on origin along the food chain. Article 26(2) of the Regulation on the provision of food information to consumers stipulates that an indication of the country of origin or place of origin shall be obligatory where failure to provide such an indication may mislead the consumer as to the country of origin or place of origin of the food. According to the survey of the various categories of food products conducted in 2013 among consumers by the Consortium for the evaluation of the food supply chain, meat products came first as regards the interest in the indication of origin on the label. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece points out that it is not enough to simply urge the Commission, as set out in the resolution. It requires that it be immediately mandatory and subject to severe penalties for undertakings to list the place of origin of all types of meat, whether fresh or as ingredients of other foodstuffs, without conditions and conditions, in particular as to the costs it entails for undertakings. It categorically rejects the pass-through of any costs to consumers, which will affect the working families, who will pay with increased prices on food even the formal obligations of companies to protect popular health, which are still systematically trampled on for their profitability. As long as monopolies are dominant in the economy and power, they will control the entire food chain. Any measures and controls will always prove ineffective, because in the system of capitalist exploitation the health and nutritional security of workers will always be sacrificed on the altar of the profits of business groups which by all means are prepared to protect all the eu institutions and the governments of its Member States. Measures that really ensure quality, healthy, safe and cheap food for the people presuppose the rupture and exemption from the EU and the power of the monopolistic groups it serves.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. — In this case, we have voted whether to ask the Commission to follow up with a legislative proposal on the matter. Therefore I voted in favour of the resolution in order to have the possibility to have the labelling of origin, avoiding the adoption of a short-sighted position that our consumers would not understand. I consider is of utmost importance to have transparent information about meat’s provenance, because it is what the consumers always ask for, placing the interests of consumers in the centre of decision-making. All the possible additional costs related to the mandatory country-of-origin-labelling for meat in processed foods are economically irrelevant especially when compared to the importance of ensuring clear and complete information enabling the consumers to make informed choices. For the same reasons, this position would not be detrimental to the SMEs since they already process this information.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — The experience and practice to which we are exposed daily in Croatia when it comes to imported goods makes us cautious. Therefore, it would be good for the information to be complete for consumers to know what they are eating and I am committed, that in addition to what is now prescribed, it contains full information about each of the key events in the animal cycle, i.e. place and time of birth, place and time of cultivation and place and time of slaughter.  The lack of some of this information allows manipulation of the data on the first freezing of the product, because for example the meat used in processing can be thawed, processed and its age can be hidden behind the declaration on the date of production of the finished product, without indicating that this meat has already been carried out in the refrigerated room for a number of years or even been frozen and thawed more than once.  Information indicating other processed products containing meat may also be manipulated in the same way. That is why this resolution is a step forward in combating UTPs and the illegal activities to which we are exposed, but also in supporting local agricultural producers and consumers.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. — Food traceability is a major issue for the health and information (and thus freedom) of consumers. By opening the borders widely and imposing the principle of free movement, the European Union has not anticipated the risks of fraud, as was unfortunately seen in the "Spanghero" scandal. The indication of the country of origin proposed today is a first step and it is to be hoped that it will be followed by many others (more precise place, type of breeding, feeding, method of slaughter...). I therefore vote in favour of this resolution, which is still very limited but which has the merit of leading the way.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I supported this resolution because the consumer's right to know what ends up on his plate every day is sacrosanct. The EU already has one of the most demanding legislation in the world on meat labelling and we are certainly one of the parts of the world where food safety is a constant priority for legislators. However, it is also necessary to improve the quality of information with regard to meat in processed products, which we often consume without paying too much attention to what they contain. On the other hand, we must be well aware that including further specifications on the origin of meat leads to a significant increase in costs for processing companies and, of course, the Commission will have to take this very seriously if it proposes a reform of labelling legislation.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — As many as 90% of our citizens want and feel they have the right to be informed about the origin of meat in processed foods they consume. Consumers want to be informed about what they are consuming, no matter what it might mean and a slight increase in product prices. I fully support their wishes and am pleased that most of my colleagues in the European Parliament have made the same decision.  I believe the current system of regulation is inadequate. Under existing regulations, there is a country of origin labelling obligation for fresh beef and veal (since 2002), and labelling will extend from April this year to some other types of fresh meat, such as pork, lamb and poultry. But since there is no such obligation for processed foods, and it is this type of food that goes to 30 to 50% of the total amounts of meat, I welcome this resolution.  Labelling the origin of meat used as an ingredient in food will allow for better traceability in the food supply chain, create more stable links between suppliers and meat processors and increase the attention of food business operators when selecting their suppliers and products. We need to enable consumers to make informed decisions that will be based on transparency across the food chain.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the proposal for a resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods. It is estimated that 30% to 50% of the total amount of meat is processed into meat ingredients for food. A 2013 survey found that over 90% of consumers want to know the origin of meat in processed products. After major scandals of rotten meat and cone sold as beef, there was a need for a legal solution that would make such incidents impossible, and to ensure greater transparency in the food production chain. This would better inform European consumers and regain their trust. The share of SMEs in meat-containing food production is 90%. They play a particular role in creating growth and job creation, contributing to the competitiveness of the European economy and being dedicated to safe and quality food. I believe that creating equal opportunities for stakeholders in the sector is essential and that labelling the origin of meat used as an ingredient in food will provide better traceability in the food supply chain, create more stable links between suppliers and meat processors, and increase the attention of food business operators. I see the only problem in the possible price effects on both consumers and manufacturers, and I think further research is needed to get a clearer picture in this regard.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — I am in favour of the view that country of origin labelling is a beneficial and desirable measure in the case of single-component foods, such as all types of meat, eggs, milk, fruit or vegetables, where cheduling of the country of origin is not a problem. I strongly support the introduction of general requirements for transparent labelling of the origin of foodstuffs, provided that this does have a real impact on raising consumer awareness and, in particular, on the quality of the products that consumers buy. I do not share the view that mandatory origin labelling of meat in industrially processed meat products can in itself be a prevention of cases, as was the case with the horsemeat scandal. Rigorous checks by the relevant supervisory authorities of the Member States shall not replace any labels. For the above reasons, I voted against the European Parliament resolution because I do not believe that the proposed measures will lead to an increase in the quality of products. On the contrary, it is certain that they will lead to price increases, which I do not consider to be the advising 'smart regulation', and consumers certainly do not want it that way either. However, I am in favour of voluntary origin labelling for processed foods, even if it will lead to price increases for some producers, because in this case the consumer will be able to choose for himself, as is already the case, for example, for organic food.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — Information on foodstuffs is important for the protection of the consumer and his well-being. The European Union must increasingly move towards quality and safe food, and that is why labelling must take account of the origin of meat in all the products it contains. This combats food fraud and helps to detect and stop any infringements. I voted in favour of the resolution as a whole because it is important that the Eu ropean Union's food policies go in this direction, although I did not share a few points.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — This resolution gives the European Parliament the opportunity to encourage the European Commission to ensure the traceability of meat ingredients in processed food products. Opinions on such a measure differ, as this could significantly increase the administrative costs of producers at the expense of consumers. That is an argument I hear, but successive food scandals have demonstrated the desire of consumers, that we all are, to know what is on their plates. Labelling will be all the more a guarantee on the Community origin of food. Our continent offers a high standard which is a guarantee of respect for consumers and, by the same token, we must promote the quality of the work of its producers.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — Within the EU, depending on the Member State, the total volume of slaughtered meat processed into meat-based ingredients for foodstuffs, mainly in minced meat, meat preparations and meat products, is estimated at 30 to 50 %. Because indication of origin is already mandatory in the EU for unprocessed beef and beef products, consumer expectations have been raised regarding information on the origin of other types of fresh meat and meat used as an ingredient in processed foods. Indeed, a consumer survey carried out in 2013 by the Food Chain Assessment Consortium showed that more than 90 % of consumers consider it important that the label indicates origin. Therefore, because I believe that greater transparency across the food chair will have a positive impact on health and consumer confidence, while also detecting possible fraud, I voted in favour.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. — After the horsemeat scandal in 2013, we must respond to citizens' aspirations for traceability and transparency. That is why I supported this resolution calling on the Commission to submit a legislative proposal mandating the country of origin of meat used in processed foods.  As with unprocessed beef and soon swine, sheep, goat and poultry, the mandatory indication of the origin of prepared meats will help to strengthen the unpricing competitiveness of European agricultural production at the lowest cost. European breeders, subject to demanding production conditions, deserve recognition of their quality work.  Nevertheless, we will remain careful that the Commission's proposal does not lead to an excessive increase in production costs for SMEs and craftsmen, many of whom are in the agri-food sector.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. — The European Commission, in the face of the horsemeat scandals and the excitement of consumers who rightly claim the right to know what they eat and not be deceived, has come only halfway. It has confined itself to labelling the origin of fresh beef without taking into account meats for processed products such as lasagna, pizzas, chicken nuggets, etc. 90% of EU consumers want to know where the meat they eat comes from. Labelling the country of origin of meat, processed or unprocessed, will meet consumer demands and enable them to make informed choices to eventually lead to a more transparent supply chain that favours short circuits instead of long food transport. Labeling the origin of meat used as an ingredient will ensure better traceability along the food chain and prevent fraud when agribusinesses choose their suppliers and products.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the country of origin of meat used in processed foods, in which we call on the European Commission to put forward legislative proposals to make this mention mandatory. Of course, we ask the Commission to take into account the practicalities of implementing such labelling, but we set it a clear objective: consumers want to know what they are eating and they are saying it forcefully. This is something I have supported for a long time and I hope that now things will move forward. We can see that voluntary labelling in this area, advocated by some, is not enough. It is time to unravel the mystery surrounding the origin of meat in prepared dishes sold throughout the Union, such as lasagna, for example. This will increase transparency throughout the food chain and provide better consumer information. In concrete terms, it will be a matter of extending the system that we have already planned for fresh beef, which will be extended to all fresh meats from April 2015.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — The latest phenomena in some Member States of the European Union concerning the sale of meat and processed food are very worrying. Labelling and mandatory identification of the country of origin of the food being bought prove to be an asset to consumers. European consumers need to have confidence in the food they consume. The successive food frauds that have been going on over recent times and in several Member States are worrying. It is essential to comply with consumer information labelling requirements, and it is important to have effective control legislation on established parameters and fines for institutions that do not comply with them.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this resolution. It is currently mandatory to indicate the place of origin of unprocessed meat when sold in the EU. Following the scandal of horse meat in frozen lasagna and other processed meat products, the Commission raised with Parliament the possibility of introducing this obligation also for processed meat products. Clearly indicating the type of meat is already mandatory, but it is understood that introducing the obligation to indicate the place of origin would help to ensure traceability of the meat ingredients used. The proposed resolution calls on the Commission to take the necessary measures to ensure this obligation. We voted in favour of this resolution

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which calls on the European Commission to put forward a legislative proposal to make it compulsory to indicate the country of origin of meat used in processed foods. I consider that the country of origin of the meat used as an ingredient in prepared meals must be included on the labelling for several reasons. Because such a mention would help to ensure better traceability and transparency throughout the food supply chain and encourage agri-food manufacturers to be more scrupulous in their choices. Because stricter traceability rules will also allow authorities to investigate food fraud more effectively (everyone remembers the horsemeat lasagna scandal). And finally, because legislating to make it mandatory to mention the origin of meat in processed products will also make it possible to better inform European consumers who are more than 90% to consider this new mention important. Finally, it will be up to the EU executive to propose labelling, paying attention both to not causing too much complexity for businesses and to ensure that labels are readable for consumers.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — This (non-legislative) motion for a resolution deals with the need to indicate on the label of products the origin of meat in processed foods in order to ensure greater transparency throughout the food chain. I believe that, for the sake of public health and information for European consumers, all processed foods should include on the label of the packaging the indication of origin of the meat which is used as an ingredient, because as it seems clear to me this simple fact will ensure better traceability along the food supply chain, more stable relationships between suppliers and meat processors and greater diligence in the choice of their respective suppliers. As far as this price measure reflects, I am pleased that the report recommends that the Commission submit legislative proposals to avoid excessive financial and administrative burdens. Finally, I would also stress the need to promote the adoption by the Commission of measures to prevent and combat fraud in the food sector. Unfortunately, this proposal did not receive a favourable vote from my political group, which wanted a voluntary adoption of these measures, and only 60 Members of the EPP, in which I am included, voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution to call for more transparency and information on the origin of meat in processed foods. This text comes at a time when a Commission report states that more than 90% of consumers surveyed believe it is important that the label mentions the origin of meat used in processed foods.  This vote allows us to continue to reflect on the issue of meat labelling and it will be important to take into account the increased costs and administrative burdens in the forthness in the coming debate in order to find the right balance between the interests of our consumers and the competitiveness of our businesses.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) The European Parliament once again calls on the European Commission to adopt a legislative proposal making it compulsory to indicate the origin of meat used in processed foods. However, I voted against it because I believe that the proposal would only increase administrative burdens and costs, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the main producers of this type of product, especially at this time of economic difficulty, when there is talk from several voices of reducing bureaucracy in order to promote growth.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour because the resolution, highlighting the existence of numerous studies reaching very different conclusions from those of the Commission, calls for legislative proposals for the compulsory indication of the origin of meat.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of this resolution. It is currently mandatory to indicate the place of origin of unprocessed meat when sold in the EU. Following the scandal of horse meat in frozen lasagna and other processed meat products, the Commission raised with Parliament the possibility of introducing this obligation also for processed meat products. Clearly indicating the type of meat is already mandatory, but it is understood that introducing the obligation to indicate the place of origin would help to ensure traceability of the meat ingredients used. The proposed resolution calls on the Commission to take the necessary measures to ensure this obligation. We voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for legislation to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat for processed products, as is already the case for fresh meats. The horsemeat scandal in lasagna in 2013 undermined consumer confidence, even though the problem in this case was a fraud and not a lack of indication. We must regain this trust and reconcile Europeans with the content of their plates, through more transparency and information. Indeed, more than 90% of consumers believe it is important that the label of processed food products mention the origin of meat. Nevertheless, I am very cautious about how this indication will be implemented and the additional costs it may entail for the 13,000 European SMEs in the deli-salting sector.
