We will have to answer many questions: how to avoid too much bureaucracy when a traditional pie requires more than 20 different types of meat? How do we ensure the supply of meat from a particular country when prices and production fluctuate? An in-depth impact assessment will be essential before any binding proposal is adopted.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. — (3) We are in favour of consumers being given real information about the food they buy. That is why we also believe that it is important to be able to obtain country-of-origin labelling on meat in processed products. Of course, we are not trying to impose unnecessary and costly rules on companies, but we are sure that it is easy to work with rules on meat origin. For example, it may be possible to use stickers instead of solid packaging labels. The information on the origin of the meat has already been provided by the companies today. We just support the fact that consumers also get this knowledge. That is why we support the decision on the country of origin labelling of meat in processed products and, of course, we will work to ensure that these rules are made as simple and as cheap as possible to comply with.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods because I understand that people, as consumers, have the right to decide what we want to eat and also whether with our decision we want to support the economy and local production, as well as whether we want to contribute to the fight against climate change by buying on short circuits. Buying on short circuits helps to curb energy waste, which is no less important considering that we have reached the peak of oil. In order to decide responsiblely we need to know the countries of origin of food. In April, the indication of the origin of meat in unprocessed foods will be mandatory, and this resolution calls on the Commission to develop legislative measures to make the indication of origin also mandatory for meat from processed foods.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — Opponents of the introduction of the indication of the place of origin of meat claim that this will increase costs for companies that produce processed food, which is linked to a number of different costs resulting from the need to include and update on food labels information on the origin of meat ingredients in processed products. Research shows that the vast majority of consumers are interested in information about their place of origin or even the 'route' that meat has taken from the place of rearing through the place of slaughter and processing. Proponents of signage argue that costs will not rise as research shows. It is worth considering whether the origin record will eliminate the scandals that erupt from time to time and detect abuses in the food industry – probably not, but there is a chance that it will reduce them, introduce greater transparency and a sense of security, and that is what consumers expect. We also do not know what exactly the meat 'country of origin' means. Is it the country where the animal was born or is it the place of slaughter? In conclusion, consumer opinion surveys in this area are insufficient. The preparation of appropriate solutions before legislative work requires further analysis and research, both on the part of the processing industry and the consumer.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted today for mandatory country of origin labelling for all meat in processed food, backing stronger traceability requirements for meat in burgers, ready meals and sandwiches. Ninety per cent of consumers want this information, which will allow them to make more informed decisions about the food they buy. This is about clear, honest labelling that does not mislead consumers. If a beef lasagne is labelled as a British product, then this should mean that it was made with British beef Country of origin labelling will also help to restore trust in the food industry, which was badly damaged following the horsemeat scandal. Labour MEPs believe consumers have a right to know where their meat comes from and we have been calling for this for several years.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. — I think it is important for each consumer to know the composition and origin of the food they consume. This will contribute to greater public awareness and also to better decision-making for better and healthier food.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — As a permanent member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I attach particular importance to the quality and safety of food consumed by eu citizens. For this reason, I supported the proposal to specify the country of origin of meat in processed foods. A survey conducted in 2013 by the Food Chain Evaluation Consortium found that as many as 90% of consumers consider determining the origin of meat in processed products (e.g. lasagna, mixed minced meat) extremely important.  The above should be added to the fact that almost 30-50% of meat is processed into the mentioned meat products and products, which further strengthens the need for better control of the origin of the original raw material. Previous systems specialised in determining the origin of meat in processed foods are not adequate to inform the origin along the entire food chain in processing. In previous years, we have witnessed unacceptable and inadmissible cases in which the horse was sold as beef. The lack of transparency on this issue not only undermines human health, but also the basic civil and consumer rights of EU citizens and citizens.  We cannot say for sure that specifying the origin of meat in processed foods will absolutely stop fraud similar to the one mentioned, but in any case it will significantly reduce them. The greater and better the information of citizens about the origin of their food should always be of unassailability value to us.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. — I am in support of effective consumer protection, not superfluous regulation. I therefore support country of origin labelling for fresh, chilled and frozen meat, as required by the Commission Regulation, which will come into force this April. It can guarantee clear information about the origin of a particular piece of meat from the producer to the consumer. The European Parliament today voted on a call for mandatory labelling of the country of origin of meat ingredients also for processed foods. However, increasing bureaucracy and burdening even the smallest producers will not ensure a higher quality of meat products. Quality control and law enforcement are more important to us consumers. The introduction of mandatory origin labelling for individual components of a product, such as salami in pizza, entails increased costs for producers, which are reflected in the increased price of meat products for the end consumer. Moreover, the information obtained is not even relevant in terms of product quality. It may be interesting, but it is not necessary in terms of quality guarantee. This would only be the case if we accept that a different origin of meat automatically means a different quality. Some producers already routinely indicate information on the country of origin of meat products where consumers require it. That is why I voted in favour of voluntary labelling of the origin of meat for processed foods. However, this proposal did not pass, which is why I did not vote in favour of the resulting form of the resolution.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — At the initiative of the Greens, the European Parliament wants the labels of food containing meat to be listed as to where that meat comes from. Despite strong opposition from the Christian Democrats and the food industry itself, a majority of the European Parliament supports this proposal. A consumer has the right to know where the meat comes from his pea soup or frozen lasagna. This allows consumers to understand how long the food chain is from riek to plate and allows them to tailor their choice accordingly. For example, producers are more likely to opt for local production. Opponents of mentioning the origin of meat in processed products as ready meals say that these rules will make products more than ten percent more expensive. I suspect these statistics have been significantly hyped up. Surely it is absurd that under the guise of too much bureaucracy a producer does not need to know where his meat comes from? Especially after last year's horsemeat scandal, it would grace the food industry if they were to be more open about their manufacturing processes. The European Parliament is now forwarding the proposal to the European Commission. It must ultimately decide whether to deal with this and to come up with legislative proposals.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing — It is important to guarantee the safety and increased quality of food for our consumers. This is secured through the harmonisation of Member States' food and hygiene legislation. Therefore, there is no link between the introduction of a designation of the country of origin of processed meat and the consequent improvement of its quality. The opinion of consumers should also be taken into account, with up to 80% saying that they are not interested in labelling if this increases the price. Mandatory labelling of processed meat will not only make it up to our consumers, who will see an increase in the price of products bought, but also to small and medium-sized enterprises, which account for up to 90% of meat processors in the EU, which will increase administrative costs by up to 30%. In this way, we will not only lower the standard of living of our citizens, but also reduce the level of employment and threaten the existence of SMEs in the EU and Slovakia. Mandatory labelling would mainly limit the variability of the goods offered to SMEs, where up to 90% of the goods are sold unpackaged. The starting point may be the introduction of simple and flexible labelling rules and voluntary labelling in meat products, which are also invoked by the meat processors' associations concerned. At the same time, the introduction of compulsory labelling could lead to an increase in the illegal sale of products and would not guarantee 100% the veracity of the data reported, given that retrospective control is burdensome, not only increasing costs for producers, but also above the current level of control bodies.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I believe that European citizens should be aware of the country of origin of meat in processed foods so backed this resolution.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - The origin of meat is the main cause of concern for consumers, as shown by the fact that 90% of respondents think that origin labelling is important. There are concerns about the potential impact of food fraud on consumer confidence.  Better monitoring within the harness chains should be introduced in order to create a more stable connection between suppliers and processors and thereby increase business attention. This would lead to greater transparency and better consumer information.  However, the principle of proportionality and the way in which excessive costs and excessive administrative burdens that can lead to a rise in product prices should also be taken into account, but if I need to choose and decide, and obviously this Directive is going in this direction, then by voting I opt for the health of European citizens, and therefore Croatian ones.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat ingredients in processed foods. The origin of meat used for an ingredient in processed foods such as lasagne should be labelled according to rules similar to those applicable to fresh beef. We all remember well the horsemeat scandal that upset the European public two years ago. It is necessary to protect consumers who, according to various studies, place food origins on the priority scale that they take into account when purchasing meat-based products. There is a need to strengthen consumer confidence in food safety, which has been shinged by numerous scandals and fraud in the past. We need transparency in the food industry.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I opposed today's vote because I believe that a sufficient level of consumer information can be achieved without an obligation to indicate not only the country of origin but, for example, the city of origin of the raw material used. I believe that, in the context of the possible impact on the final price of the product, it is sufficient if only the country of origin is indicated.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. — Mandatory labelling of country of origin of meat in processed foods is a step towards rebuilding consumer trust in meat products following the horsemeat scandal and enabling consumers to make more informed choices. Country of origin labelling is already in place for beef following the BSE crisis and today’s vote calls for this to be extended to cover meat from pigs, sheep, goats and poultry. I supported today’s vote but hope that when the Commission brings forwards its proposals they will do so whilst minimising any cost burdens on producers and consumers to ensure the measures are implemented proportionately and cost effectively.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — Labelling the origin of meat used as an ingredient in foodstuffs helps to ensure better traceability throughout the food supply chain and helps by reviewing other factors in better evaluation of the products supplied by the consumer.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motion to indicate the country of origin of processed meat components in foodstuffs in the interests of small European entrepreneurs, small producers and consumers.  In order for the motion to succeed, I drew the attention of the Commission and the European Parliament during the debates to the fact that the price-increasing effect can be expected primarily for companies that have so far supplied raw materials from countries of doubtful origin or which do not have adequate quality assurance. In my opinion, consumers have the right to decide what origin to consume, and the fact is that conscious customers prefer raw materials from the European Union. More important than any other aspect raised is consumer confidence and health, as well as the fight against food fraud and the safety that can be guaranteed. However, I believe that the designation of origin of processed meat products also helps EU producers and EU agriculture.  I trust that with this proposal we can effectively address the challenges in the areas mentioned above.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution because I consider it vital to safeguard the rights of citizens who dispute the inadequacy of the traceability systems used in the EU for the transmission of information on the origin of meat along the food chain. The traceability and labelling system should therefore be improved, taking into account, however, the principle of proportionality and the administrative burdens for food business operators and the authorities responsible. A rigorous system helps to counter potential infringements, such as the fraudulent replacement of beef by horsemeat, and thus helps to restore confidence in the products they buy.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. — The EP resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat from processed foods is necessary because it defends some indispensable principles for a healthy and transparent system in public nutrition: fair and transparent information of consumers, the elimination of fraud from the system and, in particular, the provision of public health of Europeans at all costs. At the same time, I do not believe that mandatory labelling should be a process that is suddenly implemented, without giving SMEs in the meat industry time to adapt to the new requirements. My votes on the resolution and the amendments tabled thereto respected the principles I mentioned above, but at the same time aimed at protecting consumers across Europe from uncontrollable price increases that the sudden implementation of mandatory labelling can have. In this respect, which is also reflected in my vote, I believe that voluntary labelling of products covering the country of origin, for a buffer period of time is the optimal solution to this problem. They are for increasing transparency and for informing consumers correctly, but I do not believe that we should subject producers and traders of processed meat at immediate additional costs, which can be found in the final price of the products supplied.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — No more information about the origin of meats on your plates such as ravioli, minces, dumplings, ham pizzas or the mysterious frica?" In any case, this is the demand of the European Parliament voted by a majority this lunchtime. The Commission refuses to mention the origin of these meats claiming extra costs for consumers when the truth is quite different, just 0.67% for companies carrying out this labelling. We demand legislation in this area as well as controls to avoid, a new breach of trust with the consumer as was the case after the crisis of horse lasagna. 90% of citizens think it is important to mention the origin of meat as food components. It is to be believed that the Commission's officials are among the remaining 10%. The Commission, being a spokesperson for the companies, claims its refusal to mention the origin of the meat because of the extra cost that would be incurred to the citizen. The Commission's argument therefore seems to be more dictated by the agri-food sector rather than by the interest of citizens' rights!   Origin labelling is mandatory for fresh meat, but this is also the case for prepared meals.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted against the EP resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat ingredients for processed foods. This resolution calls, inter alia, for the European Commission to present a report and follow-up legislative proposals to make origin labelling of meat compulsory in processed foods. In practice, this measure would mean that the country of origin and the country where the individual meat ingredients were processed would be indicated on the product. This would disproportionately increase the administrative burden, as well as the costs for producers of processed food, and make the label of products even less clear for consumers and ultimately more expensive for the product. These consequences would be particularly pronounced for products of multiple types of meat (e.g. sausages). However I can imagine that, in justified cases, there will be an increase in the administrative burden, I cannot vote in favour of a proposal for which this burden is not compensated by proportional benefits for consumers. This proposal is precisely from this category. I am therefore in support of maintaining the labelling of the origin of meat in processed products on a voluntary basis, as has been the case so far.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. — While the horsemeat scandal exploded a year and a half ago, the European Commission has yet to make any regulatory proposals to fill the legal loopholes. I supported the resolution mandating country-of-origin labelling of meat used as an ingredient in processed products. This resolution won a majority in the parliament's vote in Strasbourg on 10 February. I regret that the EPP has given in to lobbying against the marking of the origin of meat.  Allowing Europeans to choose processed meat products according to the territories, however, generates added value. European breeders will be recognised, even though 89% of consumers in France consider it essential to be able to know the origin of the ingredients that go into the composition of a food product.  While it is proven that for a frozen parmentier hash, the cost would only increase from 3.14 euros to 3.16 euros, increased confidence could even make some consumers return to this type of product!

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I am aware that asking for a mandatory labelling of meat for processed food can create an administrative burden and some economic cost to companies. Nonetheless, from a consumer perspective, giving this information can surely bring a positive outcome.  This resolution is a request to the European Commission to assess the possible consequences of mandatory labelling of meat for processed food and to inform the European Parliament of its conclusions. Hence, I do believe that with the approval of this resolution, we move into the right direction. Only after we evaluate the assessment we have requested to the European Commission, will we decide which decision to take.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — Positive vote for this resolution, which aims to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods following the food scandal in connection with the Spanghero company and its horsemeat lasagna. This has alarmed consumers, who are increasingly demanding about the quality and information about the products they buy. This traceability is essential for several reasons: it will allow the consumer to make an informed choice about the food they consume, to support our French breeders who suffer from unfair competition and who have long demanded this traceability. The argument of the extra cost that labelling would impose is not significant since a study has shown that this extra cost would not exceed one euro cent.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods. This is not the first time such a resolution has been adopted, although the Commission has still not moved a tab. We again send the message that we want legislative proposals in which country of origin labelling is mandatory in processed foods, and not just frescoes.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. - Although, in general, I consider the proposal to place the country of origin on packages of processed meat products to be supported, but the resolution proposed for the vote could not be supported.  I have always advocated that Europe must adhere to the production of quality food, including greater transparency in the food chain, in order to better inform consumers about the origin and composition of products.  However, I believe that this motion for a resolution does not achieve the desired result of informing consumers about the country of origin of meat, but at the same time not in creating disproportionate costs for producers, especially farmers and SMEs.    Similarly, the studies carried out so far by the European Commission do not shed light on the extent of the financial burden on producers, so I believe that the Commission should carry out a more thorough study of the costs of the labelling system before further legislation is drawning. I am confident that we will be able to develop legislation that will allow the consumer to be aware of the food available in the shop so that we can choose healthy local products, without at the same time creating a situation where the cost of the labelling process would have to be borne out by producers of primary products without having to pay the costs of the food chain.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Resolution on the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods because it represents an improvement in the information received by consumers as regards the origin of food. In the meat sector there have been numerous scandals due to the practices of large industries that seek to maximize their profit without addressing the safety and quality of food and its impact on the territory. Consumers are increasingly aware of the need to know the origin of the food they eat as a way to reapopiate the food. In April, the indication of the origin of meat in unprocessed foods will be mandatory, and this resolution calls on the Commission to develop legislative measures to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat also in processed foods, in order to force the large agri-food industry and not only producers with less capital. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR)
text: in writing. — As with other food products, British consumers want to know what meat they are buying and prefer it to be home-grown. I have campaigned regularly for improved food labelling Given that country of origin labelling is already mandatory for all meat products, it is the obvious next stage to extend that to meat when it is an ingredient in food products. As a strong supporter of farmers in the UK and the ‘Buy British’ campaign, I welcome any legislation that encourages clarity in labelling and helps both the customer and producer.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of mandatory country of origin labelling for all meat in processed food. Country of origin labelling will help to restore trust in the food industry, which was badly damaged following the horsemeat scandal. Labour MEPs believe consumers have a right to know where their meat comes from and we have been calling for this for several years.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. — The Single European Market is threatened by the call for mandatory country-based origin labelling. Europe sets standards for food safety, quality and sustainable production. On the other hand, raising awareness by compulsory mention of 'made in the EU' is desirable. However, I would have liked the resolution to have offset the administrative and financial burden seen in compulsory labelling. The resolution adopted will leave it to the Commission to prevent our agri-industry from facing even more administrative burdens through mandatory labelling, while respecting the safety of the food chain.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — In theory it seems positive to us that information on the origin of meat used in processed foods may be visible on the label. We could even extend this standard to all the ingredients of these products. We do, however, have doubts about the operationality of this standard.  This issue, as is invariate in this European Union, is the result of a scandal with an impact on the media and which has pushed the institutions into law, without a mature reflection on the problems. It's one thing to tamper with a product by incorporating horsemeat illegally. It is another thing to impose labelling with the mention of the geographical origin of the shares of meat incorporated into a processed food, without looking at the costs that this entails for the row and without taking care of whether there are control mechanisms to enable the authorities to ensure that these standards are actually met. Not having a closed position on this issue, these are doubts that would be important to debate without rushing into a standard that will always have a strong impact mainly on small and medium-sized enterprises in the sector.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - Studies have shown that origin marking of processed meat is one of the most important concerns of consumers. In order to comply with this and to uphold the Union's high food standards and improve consumer protection, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — I very much welcome the European Parliament resolution of 11 February 2015 on the labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed foods. The various meat scandals of recent years show that there is a gap in protection at the expense of the consumer. Better regulation of the designation of origin cannot prevent food fraud. Fraud always presupposes the breach of existing rules. Better regulations can, however, at least ensure that the perpetrators can be more easily tracked down and taken into civil and, if necessary, criminal liability. I also think it makes sense for meat to be labelled according to national origin. Consumers can then make a choice on the basis of the country of manufacture. Because there are different cultures in the EU for dealing with meat, which refuse to accept the Union's efforts at harmonisation. These cultural differences cannot be regulated by a regulation or directive. On a more fundamental level, I doubt that the Union should have competence in the field of public health and food safety. There is no prospect of being helpful from Brussels, given the cultural differences mentioned above. Regulatory competence should be left to the nation states and, best, to the regions in the national structure.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The problem of falsigging food labels, such as the recent 'horsemein scandal', has led to increased consumer awareness and interest in information on the origin of the meat and its products. Therefore, mandatory labelling of the country of origin of meat is a good step towards regaining consumer confidence in this sector and can meet their expectations that they can choose better labelled products. The labelling obligation for processed meat applies both to the country of origin of the animals and to the country where the meat was last processed. The obligation applies to all types of meat, except beef which is already covered by such a scheme. I voted in favour of the resolution, which calls on the Commission to put forward its own proposals on this issue.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. — This motion for a resolution by the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the labelling of the country of origin for meat in processed foods, which I voted for, has as a priority better information to the consumer, but also to highlight the quality of products for the benefit of producers. Consumer safety is a fundamental and non-negotiable priority of the European family. According to a survey by the Food Chain Assessment Consortium, conducted among consumers in 2013, more than 90% of consumers surveyed consider it important to indicate the origin of products, both meat and different types of processed meat products.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece points out that it is not enough to simply urge the Commission, as set out in the resolution. It requires that it be immediately mandatory and subject to severe penalties for undertakings to list the place of origin of all types of meat, whether fresh or as ingredients of other foodstuffs, without conditions and conditions, in particular as to the costs it entails for undertakings. It categorically rejects the pass-through of any costs to consumers, which will affect the working families, who will pay with increased prices on food even the formal obligations of companies to protect popular health, which are still systematically trampled on for their profitability. As long as monopolies are dominant in the economy and power, they will control the entire food chain. Any measures and controls will always prove ineffective, because in the system of capitalist exploitation the health and nutritional safety of workers will always be sacrificed on the altar of the profits of business groups, which by all means are prepared to protect all the EU institutions and the governments of its Member States. Measures that really ensure quality, healthy, safe and cheap food for the people presuppose the rupture and exemption from the EU and the power of the monopolistic groups it serves.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing — Although the food control system is being improved, measures are being tightened and sanctions are increasing, food scandals are increasing. On the one hand, today consumers have access to a wide range of products, but on the other hand they are faced with foods that are of poor quality and can even seriously endanger their health. In order for buyers to be able to better orientate themselves on the market, it is important that the description of the products includes not only the content, but also the origin of the food. According to a 2013 consumer survey, more than 90% of respondents said that the origin of meat used in processed foods should be indicated on the packaging in order to be able to make a decision based on this information as well. Therefore, in the interests of consumer protection, I agree that it should soon be subject to rules of origin similar to those for fresh beef and meat used as an ingredient in processed foods, such as lasanzas, ravenolas, etc. Although I am not in favour of overre regulating too much regulation, I support this proposal because I believe that consumers have the right to have access to a clear labelling of all food ingredients.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on labelling indicating the country of origin of meat in processed foods because the initiative is balanced, proportionate, ensures greater transparency, corresponds to a commitment to safe and high quality food and is appropriate for the protection of European consumers. After the crisis of bovine spongiform encephalopathy in Europe, horsemeat in the UK, and more recently minced meat in Portugal, all necessary measures should be taken to prevent and combat fraud in the food sector, an integral part of EU policy, in order to address the structural weaknesses of the food chain by increasing and strengthening its control.  The industry in the sector does not suffer as the mandatory labelling requirements must take into account the principle of proportionality and administrative burdens will be distributed between food operators and the responsible authorities, but consumers are clearly benefited by having relevant information on the entire food chain of the product they will ingest.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — From April this year, the country of origin will be indicated for unprocessed meat of pigs, goats, sheep and poultry, and since the BSE crisis it has been mandatory for processed and unprocessed beef.  This resolution proposes to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods. We supported this resolution, although we have some doubts about the concrete implementation of the measure. We reserve a final position for the time of consideration of the legislative proposals in question.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution calling on the European Commission to make origin labelling compulsory for meat used as an ingredient in processed foods, because it is the citizens who are calling for greater transparency. This is an important signal to the European Commission, which has always been wary of this issue, as well as to the processing industry, which has on several occasions objected to the alleged issue of excessive costs. I am in favour of a step-by-step approach based on the regulation of voluntary labelling through the adoption of the implementing acts that the European Commission should have done as early as 13 December 2013. In this way, those who wish to decide to use labelling as a means will do so consciously and in accordance with precise rules, while those who decide not to join the voluntary scheme should no longer be able to indicate the origin of the meat in question, facing the consequent marketing disadvantages.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour because the ACP Assembly of which I am a member is an extraordinary place for debate and discussion, for dialogue, but also for the encouragement of speeches by this Parliament, which has helped to shine a spotlight on major and extremely serious issues. We are thinking only in the last period of Ebola, the violence in Congo, the massacres in Nigeria, the attacks by Boko Haram, the Islamic Fundamentalist offensive that is also spreading in Africa.  Nothing but neocolonialism! Talking about this is instrumental. We debate, but we also act, we send observers and we talk to international bodies, and so do prejudices. Of course, relations are not simple, the heterogeneity of the ACP countries requires careful reflection and a lot of diplomacy. Let us therefore set the objectives and check the results. Our priorities must be: combating violence, protecting human rights, women and minorities and increasing development cooperation, as well as increasing good trade relations.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — As a current member of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, I voted in favour of the text of the report, because its contents support the work of the only multilateral interparliamentary assembly established under an international agreement. I am convinced, however, that profound changes are needed in terms of the measures provided for in the acp countries' development policies in order to ensure full coherence with the objectives set out in principle. The serious contradictions between what is stated in the official texts and what has been put into practice are no longer tolerable. Equally regrettable in the current situation is the weakness shown in the action of the EU and ACP Member States with regard to the practical application of the principle of non-negotiability of human rights clauses and related sanctions in the event of infringements.  I also consider the refusal of the Member States holding the rotating Presidency of the European Council to accept the work of the European session of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, both a serious lack of institutional respect and a clear violation of the commitments made under the Cotonou Agreement. I therefore hope that this will be remedied immediately at the next part-session.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This resolution deals with the annual report prepared by the Committee on Development on the work of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, on the one hand, and the European Union, on the other. However, this text has not taken into account my parliamentary group's proposal to point out that the Cotonou Agreement also contains economic partnership agreements which harm the ACP countries. Nor does it contain a fundamental element for us, which is the need to denounce that the European Development Fund is being used to finance military and security operations on the African continent, which contradicts the main objective of European development aid. By these two elements, in main, I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution, but I abstained.

name: Louis Aliot (NI)
text: In writing. — This is a report that describes the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly and outlines the European Parliament's vision for its future. The report stresses the need to strengthen political dialogue and calls on the ACP-EU APP to develop a common approach to defining the post-2015 development framework. I have spoken out against this report because it contains no notions about the fight against corruption in the ACP countries. I believe that it is also essential, in the current context, to include in this report the concept of managing migration flows within ACP regions and countries, but also in their relations with the countries of the European Union.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. — The ACP Joint Parliamentary Assembly (JPA) consists of representatives of 77 African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries and 77 Members of the European Parliament (EU). It is the 'parliament' of the Cotonou Agreement concluded between these ACP States and the Member States of the European Union. It outlines the intergovernmental relationship between the contracting parties in the areas of development aid, trade, investment and human rights. The JPA meets alternately in an ACP State and a European country in order to promote the interrelationship between North and South. As the only interparliamentary assembly set up within the framework of an international agreement, I congratulate the JPA on the work it has done. I also welcome the fact that it has become an important forum for an open and honest debate on issues that are essential for development cooperation.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. — The report presented to the European Parliament does not propose any strong measures to combat corruption in the political and economic circles in the ACP countries, which often renders ineffective the significant aid provided by the Member States of the European Union. The control of migration flows, whether between different countries in the ACP group or between these countries and the European Union, is totally absent from the report. On the other hand, the report seeks to defend, through non-negotiable clauses, concepts such as gender identity, which have nothing to do with such a text. Faced with this lack of realism and a sense of priorities, I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I do not support the principle of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. Whilst I agree with the sentiment of many amendments, this is not the way to tackle those issues.

name: Janice Atkinson (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The UKIP delegation voted against this report for the following reasons: we believe that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is little more than a front for MEPs to take lavish holidays; we believe that the way for promoting aid work in development nations is better suited through co-operation between HMG and Commonwealth nations.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to evaluate the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (JPA). The JPA is a joint body of the Cotonou Agreement enabling members of the European Parliament and the parliaments of the ACP countries to engage in an open, democratic and comprehensive dialogue on the implementation of this Agreement. The deteriorating political and humanitarian situation in some ACP countries and regions is worrying, and I therefore support calls for the JPA to continue monitoring the situation in the acp countries affected by the crisis, to pay more attention to fragile states and to call on ACP and EU countries to combat the Ebola outbreak in West Africa in a coordinated manner. JPA meetings, including meetings of standing committees, are very important, and I therefore support calls for MEPs to participate more actively.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. — Member of the ACP-APP, I voted against this text, an inconsistent report that ignores the real problems. In particular, it ignores the fundamental issue of the management of migration flows, both within the ACP regions and countries and in their relations with the countries of the European Union. My colleague Louis Aliot had tabled amendments that encouraged these issues to be taken into account, but his committee preferred to ignore, as it did on the issue of corruption, which is still endemic in some ACP countries.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly plays an important role, as it is the only multilateral inter-parliamentary assembly created under the Cotonou Agreements. This allows for an open dialogue with ACP countries, including the implementation of development cooperation within the framework of the EDF and the implementation of EPAs.  In their work, MEPs reaffirmed their deep concern at the deteriorating political and humanitarian situation in several ACP countries and regions. Similarly, the resolution calls on the APP to strengthen the dialogue on human rights and calls for the agreement to replace Cotonou's to include an explicit reference to non-discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity. It also stresses that the post-Cotonou discussions should be an opportunity to analyse in depth the failures and successes of the current agreement in terms of the sustainable socio-economic development of the ACP countries. In this regard, it insists that any EPA should be part of the development goals in order to reduce poverty and ensure fundamental human rights.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the work of the ACP-EU Parliamentary Partnership and, above all, in favour of the European Parliament's political responsibility to take into account the views of the ACP Parliaments on the outcome of the negotiations on the Association Agreements before issuing their opinion.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report is a summary report that chronicles the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (Africa, caribbean and Pacific). It provides an observation and a description of past years and discusses the future of cooperation in this context.  This text is in fact a kind of inventory at the Prévert, a catalogue of descriptions and summaries of actions without real ambitions, since the committee rejected in bulk the amendments tabled by our fellow front-runners to integrate the concept of corruption and the management of migration flows. I have therefore spoken out against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. — (IT) I find the Goerens report, which analyses the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly between 2012 and 2013, unbalanced and i do not agree with it, especially in view of the worsening political and humanitarian situation in several ACP countries and regions. For these reasons, I did not intend to vote in favour of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The ACP-EU PPP, established by the Cotonou Agreement, focuses on the objective of reducing and, in the long term, eradicating poverty, contributing to peace, security and political and democratic stability. The report, which I supported, analyses the activities of the PPP in 2012-2013 and encourages it to remain an open, democratic and comprehensive dialogue framework between MEPs and those of the ACP countries. It highlights the role of national parliaments, local authorities and non-State bodies in the supervision and implementation of the EDF, underlines our concern about the deteriorating humanitarian and political situation in several regions, including Ebola, and calls for an extension of the dialogue on relations after 2020. The Socialist amendments underline the impact of BRICS and other emerging economies on the ACP countries, and call for the agreement replacing Cotonou to include an explicit mention of non-discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity, and for the EP to take into account the views of the ACP Parliaments on the AAE negotiations before issuing an opinion.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it presented an assessment of the work of the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) and EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (JPA). Parliament noted in the resolution that the JPA has, in the long run, become a genuine parliamentary assembly, where there can be an open and sincere debate on key issues of development cooperation and which makes a significant contribution to the development of an equal partnership between acp countries and the EU. Parliament therefore advocated the need to further strengthen this political dialogue and noted the role of the JPA in promoting and defending the rule of law and good governance in the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. — I welcome the fact that the Joint Parliamentary Assembly, as one of the common institutions resulting from the Cotonou Agreement, continues to provide a framework for an open, democratic and comprehensive dialogue between MEMBERS of the European Parliament and parliamentarians from ACP countries (African, Caribbean and Pacific countries) on the implementation of this Agreement, including the supervision of development cooperation under the European Development Fund and the conclusion and implementation of the Economic Partnership Agreement. At the same time, I express deep concern about the increasingly difficult political and humanitarian situation in several ACP countries and regions, particularly the Ebola epidemic. Although the worst is over, it seems, the crisis is far from over, and the indirect consequences will be felt for years to come. The European Union and other developed countries in the world must assist vulnerable ACP countries in rebuilding the economy and health infrastructure in order to avoid future similar threats as much as possible.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. The report simply describes the Assembly's past activities and outlines the European Parliament's vision for the future of the Assembly.  As an alternate member of the delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, I deeply regret that key issues such as the fight against corruption and the management of migration flows are not addressed in the text. So I voted against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted yes since I consider that this Assembly did a great job and has enriched our knowledge and points of view for a better collaboration with African, Caribbean and Pacific countries.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. — The deterioration of the situation in the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries has raised new concerns about the political and humanitarian situation in several ACP regions. This text calls on the Joint Parliamentary Assembly to continue to monitor the situation in the ACP countries in crisis and to pay more attention to those sensitive frameworks. The ACP states and the EU also called for a coordinated fight against the outbreak of the Ebola virus in West Africa. I was in favour of this report because conflict prevention and resolution, as well as regional integration and cooperation, are essential for a better ACP-EU partnership and investment relationship.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. — I voted against. The ACP is a totally useless assembly which is a source of unnecessary expenditure. Between 2012 and 2013, it met four times at very high cost as the political and humanitarian situation in many ACP countries deteriorated.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. — Socialist amendments underline the impact of BRICS and other emerging economies on ACP countries and regions; call for an explicit mention of non-discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity and for the EP to take into account the views of the ACP Parliaments on the outcome of the EPAs negotiations before issuing its assent.  The GUE/NGL amendments signed by Lola Sánchez (Podemos) criticize the use of the EDF to strengthen the African Union's capacity to support and maintain peace in Africa. And they eliminate the mention of the AEEs. We Socialists reject them as we support the good outcome of the peace initiative in cases such as South Sudan, Somalia or the Central African Republic, as well as the AEPs must respond to development objectives that reflect the national and regional interests and needs of the people of the ACP countries in order to reduce poverty, achieve the Millennium Development Goals and respect fundamental human rights, including socio-economic rights, such as the right to food or the right to access basic public services.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. — The Joint Parliamentary Assembly of the States of Africa, the Caribbean, the Pacific and the European Union (ACP-EU APP) brings together the elected representatives of these regions. The aim is to discuss the various issues common to the Member States of the Assembly and to promote North-South interdependence. This report provides an overview of the work of the APA. The APP is a joint institution of the Cotonou Agreement which proves to be very relevant, particularly with regard to the control of the European Development Fund (EDF) and the conclusion and implementation of the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs). I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the European Union's growing involvement in development.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. I consider the report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly to be positive, as it has presented in a timely and precise manner the work of this House, which provides a forum for open and direct discussion of the central themes of development cooperation. Taking into account the situation in some ACP countries, Parliament's resolution also had the merit of emphasising that it would be desirable to strengthen the principle of non-negotiability of human rights clauses and sanctions in the event of non-compliance with these clauses, with particular reference to discrimination based on sex, race or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age, sexual orientation and gender identity, as well as discrimination against persons suffering from HIV/AIDS.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The UKIP delegation voted against this report for the following reasons: 1. We believe that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is little more than a front for MEPs to take lavish holidays. 2. We believe that the way for promoting aid work in development nations is better suited through cooperation between HM Government and Commonwealth nations.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) This House now plays a key role in relations with the ACP countries and, through joint institutions, monitors the progress of negotiations with these countries, putting respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms on the table as a prerequisite for any kind of relationship with the European Union.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. "Another report that knowingly evades the real problems.  Certainly, the report describes the Past activities of the Assembly. But when it comes to discussing the future prospects for collaboration between the European Union and African countries, the Caribbean and the Pacific, no mention is made of the real issues: not a word about cooperation in the fight against corruption or about the management of migration flows. Moreover, all the amendments tabled by patriotic Members seeking to put the above issues on the table were rejected. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, given that the agreement between the members of the ACP Group of States and the EU is based on the objective of reducing and finally erasing poverty and that cooperation also contributes to sustainable economic development, which is the basis of lasting peace and security, as well as to the democratic and political stability of the ACP countries.  I very much welcome the fact that this Parliamentary Assembly has become the forum for open and direct discussion of the central themes of development cooperation, and also to make a significant contribution to the partnership on an equal footing for the ACP countries and for the EU.  Finally, I would like to stress the added value that comes with holding sessions of this House in the EU Member States holding the rotating Presidency of the Council of the European Union, and I believe that this rotation must be maintained in the future.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the fact that the JPA, as one of the joint institutions of the Cotonou Agreement, continues to provide a framework for an open, democratic and comprehensive dialogue between Members of the European Parliament and parliamentarians from ACP countries on implementation of this Agreement, including scrutiny of development cooperation under the EDF and the conclusion and implementation of the EPAs;

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. — The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (APP) represents a unique global partnership in the world that has been developing at institutional and content level and which today encompasses vectors such as aid, economic cooperation, human rights, trade relations between the EU and the six ACP regions and political dialogue. I am pleased once again that the app's ability in its last sessions has been a forum for genuine political dialogue, in addition to its purely administrative issues, on pressing issues such as the future of ACP relations, the Ebola phenomenon, human rights, etc. In the post-Cotonou debate it will be vital to link work with EU development policies, the work of national parliaments, local non-state bodies and regional strategy papers. I support Mr Goerens' report for drawing attention to these and other challenges that prove vital in any serious development partnership, while expressing some concern about the deteriorating political and humanitarian situation in several ACP countries.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly has done an excellent job so far, establishing itself as a key player in ACP-EU relations and cooperation, constantly monitoring all political, economic and social developments in the ACP countries, in order to achieve the Millennium Development Goals, reflecting national and regional interests and the needs of the populations concerned. I very much hope that not only the human rights dialogue will be strengthened, but also the principle of non-negotiability of human rights clauses, especially with regard to discrimination of various kinds based, for example, on sex, race, ethnic origin, religion, belief or disability.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. — The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (JPA), as one of the institutions of the Cotonou Agreement, continues to provide a framework for an open, democratic and comprehensive dialogue between Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) and parliamentarians from African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries on implementation of this agreement. Through the quality of its work the JPA has established itself as a key player in ACP-EU relations and cooperation. The JPA has continued to monitor political, economic and social developments goals and respect for all human rights and fundamental freedoms. I have thus voted in favour of this report.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — (IT) The report as voted on in committee is positive and acceptable. That is why I am voting in favour, even if it does not reflect all the positions expressed by the spokesmen of the M5S delegation during the meetings of this House. The dispute relates in particular to the position of this House in supporting military intervention by other bodies in conflict zones. The M5S delegation expressed its opposition to supporting military intervention, stating that this House must maintain its role of monitoring and acting in ACP-EU cooperation and that it must give priority to peaceful and diplomatic prevention and resolution of conflicts and tensions.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This resolution deals with the annual report prepared by the Committee on Development on the work of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, on the one hand, and the European Union, on the other. However, this text has not taken into account my parliamentary group's proposal to point out that the Cotonou Agreement also contains economic partnership agreements which harm the ACP countries. Nor does it contain a fundamental element for us, which is the need to denounce that the European Development Fund is being used to finance military and security operations on the African continent, which contradicts the main objective of European development aid. By these two elements, in main, I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution, but I abstained.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. — This resolution deals with accepting the annual report assessing the work of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States-European Union (ACP-EU) Joint Parliamentary Assembly for the period of 2012-2013. At the insistence of the Socialists & Democrats Group the report clearly promotes the respect of human rights and non-discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity in the ACP countries. I believe that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly should be a forum where the political dialogue is open, frank and productive, hence I voted in favour of the resolution recommending approval of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report rightly highlights the important role of the Africa-Caribbean-Pacific Joint Parliamentary Assembly (ACP)-European Union in the implementation of the Cotonou Agreement, including development cooperation under the European Development Fund (EDF) and the conclusion and implementation of economic partnership agreements (EPAs). Considering that ACP-EU parliamentary cooperation brings a necessary added value in relations between the European Union and its acp partners by enabling the creation of a genuine space for open and democratic dialogue, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Through this vote, we support the activities of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly for development cooperation based on dialogue based on our common values. This adoption by a very large majority highlights the need for each of the actors concerned, at the local or international level, to get involved in development cooperation. This resolution also rightly underlines the major role played by this Joint Parliamentary Assembly in monitoring the negotiations on the implementation of the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) so that they are in line with the objectives of the Cotonou Agreements.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — The EU-ACP Joint Parliamentary Assembly brings together MEPs in the European Parliament and representatives and elected representatives of the African, Caribbean and Pacific states ("ACP countries") who are signatories to the Cotonou Agreement. It is therefore the only international assembly in which the representatives of these countries sit together, regularly, in order to promote North-South interdependence. As a member of this House, I welcome the open, democratic and comprehensive dialogue we have with our acp counterparts. Since its inception, our assembly has been at the origin of many proposals, such as the development of rural development programmes and micro-projects adapted to the needs of specific communities, the creation of decentralised development policies or the enhancement of the role of women in the development process. Today, I think it is important for the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly to reflect on a partnership that takes into account Africa's economic development and the strong historical cultural ties between the two continents.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. — The report presented to the European Parliament does not propose or suggest strong measures to combat major scourges in the countries understood in the ACP group, namely corruption in political and economic circles, which often renders ineffective the significant aid paid by the Member States of the European Union, or the lack of control of migration flows, whether between different countries in the ACP group or between these countries and the European Union. The report, on the other hand, seeks to defend, through non-negotiable clauses, more vague concepts such as gender identity and which are less related to inter-institutional, international and economic development aid than to the vital needs of the ACP group countries. Faced with this lack of realism and a sense of priorities, I voted against this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The UKIP delegation voted against this report for the following reasons: - We believe that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is little more than a front for MEPs to take lavish holidays. - We believe that the way for promoting aid work in development nations is better suited through co-operation between HM Government and Commonwealth nations.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. — The PPP, as one of the joint institutions of the Cotonou Agreement, stresses in the promotion and defence of the principles set out in Article 9 of the Agreement.  We must underline the crucial role of the national parliaments of the ACP countries, local authorities and non-State actors in the preparatory phases, and congratulate the PPP Bureau on extending its work beyond purely administrative issues. That is why a more strategic approach is needed, in particular related to the negotiations on the post-2015 development framework and EU-ACP relations after 2020.  We have deep concern about the deteriorating political and humanitarian situation in several ACP countries and regions, so THE PPP must strengthen the principle of non-negotiable human rights clauses with regard to discrimination on the grounds of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age, sexual orientation or gender identity , or discrimination against people living with HIV or AIDS.  The post-Cotonou debate should be an opportunity to thoroughly analyse both the failure and success of the current Agreement in terms of sustainable socio-economic development in the ACP countries.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The UKIP delegation voted against this report for the following reasons: - We believe that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is little more than a front for MEPs to take lavish holidays. - We believe that the way for promoting aid work in development nations is better suited through cooperation between HMG and Commonwealth nations.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, supporting the strategic importance of an open dialogue between the ACP countries and the EU, to which the Joint Parliamentary Assembly contributes. The APP is a platform for political dialogue which, by its nature, aims at poverty reduction, respect for fundamental human rights and the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals. The Union has important development cooperation instruments, so the involvement of the APP in the discussion on sustainable economic and social development by acp countries is relevant.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. — The APP is now a forum for frank and open debate on central themes in development cooperation, making a significant contribution to the partnership on an equal footing between the ACP countries and the EU, where poverty reduction and, in the long term, its eradication is a central objective. The APP continues to be an open, democratic and comprehensive framework for dialogue between Members of the European Parliament and members of the ACP countries. However, there is a need to strengthen political dialogue in order to avoid the deterioration of the political and humanitarian situation in several ACP countries and regions. A situation that can have domestic and external repercussions that must be prevented at all costs.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The report addresses the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (AAA) over the past year. In general, with regard to the functioning of the APP, the rapporteur we make positive considerations about the necessary cooperation and inclusion of acp countries and on the enhancement of the role of the APP, criticising the Council and some Member States for devaluing it. ACP-EU cooperation is supported by the existence of joint institutions. This House has proved to be a very rich area of cooperation, mutual knowledge and exchange of experiences. A space where the contradictions that result from the unequal development of capitalism, the deep asymmetries and inequalities that run through the world today are well known. But we also have criticism of this report. In particular with regard to the defence and legitimacy made of the so-called Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs), which are nothing more than free trade agreements imposed on acp countries under blackmail, which are deeply insignificant to their interests and inseparable from undisguised objectives of economic resettlement of these countries by the European powers. A totally different agenda is needed to promote effective cooperation, solidarity and the autonomous and sovereign development of these countries. Hence our abstention.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — The Joint Parliamentary Assembly has succeeded in building a respected position in the framework of cooperation between the European Union and the ACP countries. However, it is very important that the Joint Parliamentary Assembly also oversees developments in the countries in question and must be constantly active so that the assembly's voice has weight after 2020, when the Cotonou Agreement expires.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. — In view of the general deterioration of the ACP countries, it can be said that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, which met four times between 2012 and 2013, was unable to play the role assigned to it.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. — I disagree and vote against it, because this resolution is a typical example of cultural imperialism and because the Union on the one hand gives to the countries in need but on the other it asks them to change their customs and customs in order to give them.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. — Cooperation between parties is vital to achieve the objectives of the European Development Fund and to ensure European policy coherence on political, economic and environmental issues. The ACP-EU Joint Assembly has become a key player in ACP-EU relations and cooperation and plays a fundamental role in achieving common understanding and agreement on issues of mutual concern. It brings more democracy to the dialogue between States and I therefore deplore declining participation by EU Member States in this Conference. EU Member States should be fully committed in this open, democratic and comprehensive dialogue. This is why I believe we need to strengthen this dialogue, especially with the aim of achieving a strong common position in light of the Conference in Paris next November. The long-lasting cooperation between the EU and the ACP States on the issue of adaptation and mitigation responses should be reflected in the burden-sharing of goals in the agreement. I truly hope that the resolutions and other decisions taken by the Assembly will be fully implemented.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. — With regard to the report on the ACCIO-EU Joint Interparliamentary Assembly, I would like to stress that the Economic Partnership Agreement with the countries of the APC should serve development objectives such as combating poverty, the right to food or access to basic public services, in particular with regard to exposed groups such as women, children or national minorities.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. — The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly has been transformed into a genuine parliamentary assembly that provides a forum for open and frank debate on issues of vital importance for development cooperation. Undoubtedly, it represents an open discussion forum that provides concrete results in improving the living conditions of citizens and human rights, and which helps to address common problems in a coordinated manner. The PPP should continue to focus on reducing and, in the long term, eradicating poverty, as well as improving cooperation to contribute to sustainable economic development, which is the basis for lasting peace and security and the political and democratic stability of the ACP countries. We must also continue to call within the PPP for the strengthening of human rights dialogue, in accordance with the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the Cotonou Agreement.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I should like to thank Mr Goerens and congratulate him on his excellent report. I agree, in particular, with the rapporteur's concerns about ACP-EU relations after 2020 and the future of the ACP group. In this respect, I am convinced that this House will be able to contribute with its efforts to achieving development goals that reflect both national and regional interests and the needs of the populations of the ACP countries, in order to reduce poverty, achieve the Millennium Development Goals and ensure respect for fundamental human rights, including socio-economic rights. , such as the right to food or the right of access to basic public services. In my vote in favour, I wanted to acknowledge the role played by the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly in seeking solutions to urgent and often not simple problems.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution on the work of the ACP Assembly. I am pleased that this House continues to provide a framework for open, democratic and global dialogue between Members from different parts of the world and on very broad and relevant issues, such as development cooperation, emigration, human rights, the fight against climate change, etc. The model of democracy in this House will, we hope, be an example of the growth of the rule of law and freedom of association and expression in many countries.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. — Crucial in gaining my support for the report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly was the fact that my Group has been able to secure amendments referring to human rights and non-discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity in the ACP countries, as well as calling for more strategic approach for the ACP-EU JPA. This is particularly important in the run-up to the negotiations on the post-2015 development framework and the post- 2020 Cotonou Framework.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. — I voted against the motion for a resolution on the work of the Africa Caribbean-European Union (ACP-EU) Joint Parliamentary Assembly. Indeed, the report put to the vote of MEPs of the European Parliament calls on the ACP-EU Joint Assembly to develop a common approach to defining a common development framework for the post-2015 term. I regret that the amendments incorporating concepts of anti-corruption have been rejected by the Committee on Development. In addition, the Committee on Development also rejected the proposed amendments to strengthen the management of migration flows within the ACP regions, as well as between these states and the European Union.  This management of intra-ACP flows between the EU and the ACP countries is nevertheless vital to enable a common development that allows the prosperity of stakeholders while limiting the dramas of illegal immigration.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on this resolution. This is an annual report by the Committee on Development on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. ACP-EU cooperation is based on the Cotonou Agreement (2000) which establishes, inter alia, joint institutions, such as this Parliamentary Assembly. The rapporteur gives an overview of the sessions of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly, held, in principle, in the Member State of the presidency on duty. Our amendments in the DEVE Commission pointed out that the Cotonou Agreement also provides for Economic Partnership Agreements (EAS) in which the ACP countries are disadvantaged. We also denounce that the EDF (European Development Fund) is an important source of funding from the African Peace Support Fund, used to finance military and security operations on the continent, which is at odds with the main objective of EU development aid. All our amendments were rejected. That is why we abstained in the vote.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I welcome this report on the activity and work of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly (JPA). The ACP-EU JPA is a forum where the political dialogue should be open, frank and productive. It is crucial to recognise the opportunities and challenges of the present format. S&D MEPs have previously secured amendments referring to human rights and non-discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity in the ACP countries, as well as calling for more strategic approach for the ACP-EU JPA especially with regard to the negotiations on the post-2015 development framework and the EU-ACP relations after 2020 when the Cotonou agreement expires.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report as promoting open, democratic and comprehensive dialogue between parliamentarians is essential for the consolidation of an effective and equal development policy with the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries. That is why I regret that conservative forces, especially the Spanish People's Party, have steadyed against the European Parliament's take into account the views of the ACP parliaments on the outcome of the negotiations on the Economic Partnership Agreements before issuing its assent. Denying or restricting participation rights, a policy very sustained by the People's Group, will have a real cost to be paid by the countries most in need of construction and democratic participation. This is therefore a profoundly wrong policy.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report as I believe the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is a unique body which can strengthen political dialogue between EU politicians and their African counterparts. This body has significant influence in defining the post-2015 development agenda and for furthering EU development goals which seek to give everyone in developing countries a decent standard of living by 2020.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I voted in favour of the Goerens report. I am convinced that an open, structured dialogue between the European Union and the ACP states is extremely necessary today, and that the ACP-European Union Joint Parliamentary Assembly is an excellent forum for its conduct. I also agree with rapporteur Goerens, who emphasises, among other things, the key role of local authorities in the preparatory phase and in the monitoring of national and regional strategy papers and in the implementation of the European Development Fund. In my opinion, regional authorities should be one of the key partners in achieving poverty reduction and sustainable development.
