After all, they play a leading role in solving local problems such as food security, social exclusion, infrastructure, rapid urbanisation and many others. As part of my work in the ACP-European Union Joint Parliamentary Assembly, I would like to pay particular attention to this issue.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on this resolution. This is an annual report by the Committee on Development on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. ACP-EU cooperation is based on the Cotonou Agreement (2000) which establishes, inter alia, joint institutions, such as this Parliamentary Assembly. The rapporteur gives an overview of the sessions of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly, held, in principle, in the Member State of the presidency on duty. Our amendments in the DEVE Commission pointed out that the Cotonou Agreement also provides for Economic Partnership Agreements (EAS) in which the ACP countries are disadvantaged. We also denounce that the EDF (European Development Fund) is an important source of funding from the African Peace Support Fund, used to finance military and security operations on the continent, which is at odds with the main objective of EU development aid. All our amendments were rejected. That is why we abstained in the vote.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — I supported the report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, as it contributes to the development goals for these countries and reflects the needs of the populations of ACP countries.  This is an opportunity for excellent cooperation for the European Union and a dialogue mechanism on topics such as poverty reduction, respect for fundamental human rights, the right to access basic public services, building lasting peace and security, economic development, and the political stability of ACP countries.  These are just some of the needs and interests of the population of these areas, supported by the Cotonou Agreement back in 2000. The progress of these countries is something the EU can help with its co-operation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. — The report presented to the European Parliament does not propose or suggest strong measures to combat major scourges in the countries understood in the ACP group, namely corruption in political and economic circles, which often renders ineffective the significant aid paid by the Member States of the European Union, or the lack of control of migration flows, whether between different countries in the ACP group or between these countries and the European Union. The report, on the other hand, seeks to defend, through non-negotiable clauses, more vague concepts such as gender identity, which are less a matter of inter-institutional relations, international relations and economic development aid than the vital needs of the ACP countries. Faced with this lack of realism and a sense of priorities, I voted against this report.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the work of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly, made up of members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, and the European Union. The Joint Parliamentary Assembly plays a key role in overseeing the implementation of economic partnership agreements, as well as in promoting development goals. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the agenda item under the title «’The work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly’ because we believe that collaboration between states is beneficial for all parties.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. — The ACP-EU JPA, as a multilateral interparliamentary assembly, is a special feature of parliamentary work in the EU and is also the only interparliamentary assembly created under an international agreement, the Cotonou Agreement. The open dialogue between EU and ACP parliamentarians on the implementation of the Cotonou provisions, the monitoring of the European Development Fund and the elements of good governance bring added value for both the EU and the ACP countries. The importance of this institution in terms of creating a European profile, taking into account national specificities in the world, should be highlighted. That is why I support this motion and its calls for greater involvement of the Presidency and national parliaments, greater human rights mainstreaming and the establishment of a framework after 2015.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the report. The ACP-EU JPA is a forum where the political dialogue should be open, frank and productive. It is crucial to recognise the opportunities and challenges of the present format as we start reflecting on the post-Cotonou framework in 2020.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr Goerens' report because I believe that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly continues to promote a common approach in defining the development framework for the post-2015 period. The report highlights the ability of this House to play a strategic role in ACP-EU relations and cooperation. I believe that this House has monitored the political, economic and social developments of the two blocs in order to promote human rights and all fundamental freedoms.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. — This is a summary report that recounts the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific). It provides an overview of the exchanges and actions taken in past years and discusses the future of cooperation between the European Union and the ACP countries. This text is in fact a kind of inventory at the Prévert, a catalogue of descriptions, wishful thinking, old poncifs, a list of summaries of actions without real ambitions since the Commission rejected as a whole all the amendments tabled by the elected front-runners, which aimed to integrate the notions of corruption and the management of migratory flows. So I voted against this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The ACP-EU PPP is the only multilateral inter-parliamentary assembly created by an international agreement, the Cotonou Agreement, which focuses on the objective of reducing and, in the long term, eradicating poverty, as well as contributing to the peace, security and political and democratic stability of the ACP countries. The report analyses THE activities and meetings of the PPP in 2012/2013. It highlights the role of national parliaments, local authorities and non-State bodies in the supervision and implementation of the European Development Fund (EDF). Our concern about the deterioration of the humanitarian and political situation in several ACP countries and regions is underlined, with Ebola also mentioned. It also calls for further dialogue on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020. For these reasons I have resolved to vote favourably.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This resolution deals with the annual report prepared by the Committee on Development on the work of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, on the one hand, and the European Union, on the other. However, this text has not taken into account my parliamentary group's proposal to point out that the Cotonou Agreement also contains economic partnership agreements which harm the ACP countries. Nor does it contain a fundamental element for us, which is the need to denounce that the European Development Fund is being used to finance military and security operations on the African continent, which contradicts the main objective of European development aid. By these two elements, in main, I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution, but I abstained.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Joint Parliamentary Assembly (PPP) is an essential player in ACP-EU relations and cooperation (under an agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) and the European Community and its Member States). It underlines the high quality of its work, which has been to actively monitor political, economic and social changes in the ACP countries in order to promote development objectives and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Assembly follows in a responsible and careful manner the promotion of both regional and subregional integration and cooperation. It is important that the PPP continues to closely monitor changes, in order to ensure that its views are made when considering what options and alternatives can be put in place after the expiry of the Cotonou Agreement (which established the framework for ACP-EU relations in 2000) in 2020. Trusting that the PPP will take into account and implement the recommendations and advice provided by this report, I congratulate its members on their work and approve this report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, as cooperation between MEPs and parliamentary representatives from ACP countries is important for the process of democratisation, respect for human rights and the development of ACP states.  Mutual agreements should serve development objectives and national and regional interests.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Goerens report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, because this Assembly is an important political forum where representatives of the peoples, both EU and ACP States, discuss and cooperate on serious foreign policy issues, such as the political crisis in Somalia or the situation in Mali, as well as on issues with a significant social impact. , such as human resources in the health sector in the ACP countries or the social and environmental impact of coal mines in the ACP countries.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted for this report. Through the quality of its work, the Assembly has succeeded in establishing itself as a key player in ACP-EU relations and cooperation. It has proactively continued to monitor political, economic and social developments in the ACP countries, with a view to promoting development goals and the respect for all human rights and fundamental freedoms, including respect for fundamental social rights, democracy based on the rule of law and transparent and accountable governance that are an integral part of sustainable development.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — The ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly has played and continues to play a key role in monitoring the negotiations and implementation of the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPA), in order to ensure that the outcome of the negotiations respects the economic and development objectives set out in the Cotonou Mandate (2000). For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — This report describes the annual work carried out by the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly with the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries. The document highlights the assembly's ability to play a key role in ACP-EU relations. I believe that it has proactively monitored the political, economic and social developments in these countries, in order to promote the Millennium Development Goals and respect for all human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted in favour of mr Goerens' report, as I believe it is important for the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly to continue to promote a common approach in defining the development framework for the post-2015 period.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. — I voted negatively on the report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly, as this is yet another example of misappropriation within the European Union. Only 5 "information trips", some to very exotic places, cost the taxpayer a huge amount and are therefore unsupported.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The resolution welcomes the role of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly and its objectives: the end of poverty, economic development, democratic stability... The resolution even stresses that "Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) with African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries should serve development goals, which take into account national and regional interests as well as the needs of the people, in order to reduce poverty, and ensure respect for fundamental human rights, including socio-economic rights. , such as the right to food or the right to basic public services." Inconsequential chatter! It also calls on "states that have not yet done so to ratify the revised Cotonou agreement". It should be remembered that this free trade agreement allows the EU to exempt from tariffs on its products in ACP countries. A liberalisation in which the ACP countries have much to lose. In these circumstances, I vote resolutely AGAINST.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. — The work of this House has been very important for the development of relations between the EU and the ACP countries.  There has been a frank and open debate on central issues in development cooperation, thereby contributing significantly to an equal partnership between the ACP countries and the EU. I am sure that the objectives underupparting these work, namely poverty reduction and, in the long term, their eradication, will be achieved in the long term. This cooperation should also contribute to sustainable economic development, which serves as the basis for lasting peace and security, and for the political and democratic stability of the ACP countries.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported this report because it calls on the Joint Parliamentary Assembly (JPA) to continue its role of monitoring crises and promoting greater cooperation between the ACP and EU States. The report also expresses concern over the adoption and discussion of legislation further criminalising homosexuality in some ACP countries. It calls on the JPA to reinforce the principle of non-negotiable human rights clauses and sanctions for failure to respect such clauses.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is a unique body, firmly rooted in relationships based on mutual respect and understanding listening. It is a forum where it is possible to discuss all issues, current issues such as the rights of homosexual people, violence against women, governance issues, the traceability of natural resources, etc. In view of all these debates, we can say that this assembly has gained great experience and can be proud of good results. The ACP-EU APP has a policy of meeting in plenary, twice a year: in Europe, in the country of the EU presidency, and in an ACP country. However, we are seeing that European countries are finding it increasingly difficult to honour this commitment. I would like to take this opportunity to call on the relevant authorities within the Member States to take responsibility by agreeing to hold these foundations. This year, we will have to discuss the future of this unique institutional construction. We will have to define the perpetuation of what is in history a model of unprecedented political cooperation. Political dialogue is the basis of our relations.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. — In 2000, a Partnership Agreement was established between the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, on the one hand, and the European Union and its Member States, on the other, signed in Cotonou. In 2013, the second partnership agreement between both regions was concluded and last year a financing instrument for development cooperation for the period 2014-2020 entered into force. I would like to give my public support to the ACP-EU partnership which has unparalleled status, as it is the only Multilateral Interparliamentary Assembly established under an international agreement to represent a frank and open discussion forum on central themes in development cooperation and to contribute decisively to poverty reduction and, in the long term, to its eradication. I believe that it is essential to continue to support the Interparliamentary Assemblies, but new development objectives should be set to increase the competitiveness of acp countries and improve the quality of life of the people.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This is a summary report that recounts the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific). It provides an overview of the exchanges and actions taken in past years and discusses the future of cooperation between the European Union and the ACP countries. This text is in fact a kind of inventory at the Prévert, a catalogue of descriptions, wishful thinking, old poncifs, a list of summaries of actions without real ambitions since the Commission rejected as a whole all the amendments tabled by the elected front-runners, which aimed to integrate the notions of corruption and the management of migratory flows. So I voted against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. — The draft report analysed the JPA activity in 2012 and 2013 and welcomed its work. I voted in favour of the S&D group tabled 10 amendments referring to human rights and non-discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity in the ACP countries, as well as calling for more a strategic approach for the JPA especially in regards to post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals and the replacement to the Cotonou agreement, which runs out in 2020.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, which brings together MEPs and representatives of the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) states that are signatories to the Cotonou Agreement on development cooperation. The text takes stock of this assembly for 2012 and 2013. In particular, he points out that the ACP-EU Assembly is growing into an increasingly political dimension and is showing an increased presence on the ground: fact-finding missions to Mali, Liberia and Haiti, election observation missions in Mali and Madagascar.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. — (IT) Today we give our whole strong support to the work carried out over the last two years by the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, which has succeeded in establishing itself as a key player in international relations and cooperation. Through close monitoring of all political, economic and social developments in the ACP countries and with a view to promoting development objectives and respect for all human rights and fundamental freedoms, it has continued to play a fundamental role in promoting respect for fundamental social rights and democracy based on the rule of law. We believe, in fact, that transparent and responsible governance is now an integral part of sustainable development. This House is essential as it continues to play a key role also in monitoring the negotiations and the implementation of the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPA), in order to ensure that the outcome of the negotiations respects the economic and development objectives set out in the Cotonou Mandate (2000). In this respect, we call for special attention to continue to be paid to regional and sub-regional integration and cooperation.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it recalls and reinforces the role of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, of which I am the Vice-President.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — The African, Caribbean and Pacific Parliamentary Assembly (ACP) – EU, formed by the Cotonou Agreement, is a multi-parliamentary assembly in which the ACP countries and the EU are in an equal partnership. I voted for this resolution because the APP is a framework in which discussions between ACP MePs and MEPs are conducted openly, honestly and constructively in order to implement the objectives set out in the Cotonou agreement. The resolution also underlines the need to strengthen the political dialogue and the post-Cotonou continuation of the analysis of both positive and negative aspects of the sustainable socio-economic development of the ACP countries, so that, within this framework, no ACP countries are disadvantaged.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted against the report because I totally reject the work of this House and, in particular, consider the high level of travel by Members to be superfluous and excessive burden on the taxpayer.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. — I supported the proposal because I consider it necessary for more meaningful cooperation and for the strengthening of political dialogue in the Joint Parliamentary Assembly, in particular in the promotion and protection of the principles of the rule of law and good governance, but also in view of the current international situation.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The UKIP delegation voted against this report for the following reasons: - We believe that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is little more than a front for MEPs to take lavish holidays. - We believe that the way for promoting aid work in development nations is better suited through co-operation between HM Government and Commonwealth nations.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. — The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly enjoys a unique status, being the only multilateral interparliamentary assembly established under an international agreement, the Cotonou Agreement. The Cotonou Agreement between the members of the ACP Group of States and the EU is based on the objective of reducing and ultimately erasing poverty and cooperation should also contribute to sustainable economic development, which is the foundation of lasting peace and security, as well as to the democratic and political stability of the ACP countries. It would be important to stimulate a continuous informal dialogue, based on substantive analysis, with different categories of stakeholders, official and unofficial, in ACP-EU circles (Joint Parliamentary Assembly, ACP-EU Council, ACP-EU private sector and dialogues with civil society) and in other circles that do not have a direct interest in the ACP-EU reality. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. By refusing to address issues of anti-corruption and migration management, the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly refrains from addressing issues whose resolution is nevertheless a key issue for the future of relations between European and African, Caribbean and Pacific countries. Our amendments on the subject have not been accepted. The text therefore remains to a biased view, far from realities and emergencies. So I can only speak out against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — I support the annual report on the work of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly of the European Union and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Groups of States, as well as the work of this body. I call on this opportunity to make further efforts and achieve the strategic approach of this body in the areas of human rights protection and as part of the negotiations on development goals after 2015.  The Joint Parliamentary Assembly of the European Union and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Groups of States should continue to be a forum for an open, frank and constructive political dialogue.  This report correctly recognises the challenges facing the Joint Assembly, but also the opportunities that the negotiations on the post-Cotono agreement provide, and therefore I express my support to it once again.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the report on the work of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly of countries in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific and the EU. It is a single multilateral, interparliamentary assembly established under the international Cotonou Agreement aimed at reducing and ultimately eradicating poverty and sustainable economic development.  In order to set the foundations for lasting peace and security and the democratic and political security of ACP countries, coordination, coherence and complementarity between the common institutions should be ensured. I therefore welcome the Assembly's call for strengthening human rights dialogue in line with the UN Declaration and to include this topic on the subject of non-discrimination of sexual orientation and gender identity as a regular item on the Assembly's agenda. I also emphasise the significant role of national parliaments of ACP countries, local authorities and non-state actors in the preparatory phase and in monitoring strategic documents for countries and regions and in monitoring the implementation of the European Development Fund. I also consider it important to cooperate with civil society organisations active in individual countries in order to gain a more detailed insight into the issues through their experiences and activities. The Assembly should continue to proactively monitor the political, economic and social development of ACP countries while promoting development goals on human rights and democracy based on the rule of law, transparency and responsible government, which are key factors for sustainable development.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. — The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly has played, and still does, a key role in relations between the ACP countries and the EU. Building on the principles of respect for fundamental freedoms and respect for all human rights, it is able to promote and monitor economic and social developments in the countries concerned, defending democracy and pushing towards transparent governance, with the objective of sustainable development, with a focus on regional and sub-regional cooperation. This House monitors the economic partnership negotiations and agreements, with respect to what is expressed in the Cotonou Mandate, namely that the negotiations respect the economic and development objectives set out in it. In the hope that we will continue in this direction, I hope that we will start thinking now about the possible options once the Cotonou Agreement has come to an end.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — In the context of the Cotonou agreements, the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly has become a key player. It allows both to guide and monitor the European Union's development policy. Through this resolution, the European Parliament must decide on the objectives and support that the European Union gives to this House. To the extent that this allows a knowledge of the field and a lasting relationship of trust, I vote for it.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. — The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly met four times between 2012 and 2013 in Horsens (Denmark), Paramaribo (Suriname), Brussels and Allis Ababa (Ethiopia). In 2012, nine resolutions and one declaration were adopted and, in 2013, nine resolutions were adopted. The three standing committees met four times: in conjunction with the four sessions and twice in Brussels between sessions. I am pleased that the APP, one of the joint institutions of the Cotonou Agreement, continues to provide an open, democratic and comprehensive area of dialogue between Members of the European Parliament and parliamentarians from acp countries with regard to the implementation of that Agreement, including the examination of development cooperation within the framework of the European Development Fund and the conclusion and implementation of economic partnership agreements. Considering that, as the report points out, the APP is a key player in ACP-EU relations and cooperation, and it is important to highlight its role in upstanding the principles of good governance, I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The UKIP delegation voted against this report for the following reasons. - We believe that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is little more than a front for MEPs to take lavish holidays. - We believe that the way for promoting aid work in development nations is better suited through co-operation between HMG and Commonwealth nations.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. — This resolution provides a milestone on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (APP). This text, for which I voted, recalls its role as a platform for open and democratic dialogue between Members of the European Parliament and those of the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific (ACP). The holding of acp-EU APP sessions every six months has not always been respected in recent years, so we call on the Member States leading the rotating presidency of the Council to respect this timetable. We also express our concern about the deteriorating political and humanitarian situation in several ACP countries and regions and reiterate the importance of the APP in alleviating crisis situations through dialogue and cooperation. Agreements between the EU and third countries must be a give-and-take: we stand in favour of economic partnership agreements that serve development objectives and ensure respect for fundamental human rights, such as the right to food and the right to basic public services. Finally, we call on the ACP-EU APP to invest in the definition of the development framework and the post-2015 sustainable development goals.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. — The work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly has proved to be an added value in that it represents an open discussion forum on central issues in cooperation for the reciprocal development of both sides.   This work must continue to be strengthened and supported, as the objectives set out prove to be an added value. However, it is important to continue to strengthen political dialogue and to highlight the role played by the Party Parliamentary Assembly in promoting and defending pre-established objectives.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — The ACP-EU PPP, established by the Cotonou Agreement, focuses on the objective of reducing and, in the long term, eradicating poverty, contributing to peace, security and political and democratic stability. The report, which I supported, analyses the activities of the PPP in 2012-2013 and encourages it to remain an open, democratic and comprehensive dialogue framework between MEPs and those of the ACP countries. It highlights the role of national parliaments, local authorities and non-State bodies in the supervision and implementation of the EDF, underlines our concern about the deteriorating humanitarian and political situation in several regions, including Ebola, and calls for an extension of the dialogue on relations after 2020. The Socialist amendments underline the impact of BRICS and other emerging economies on the ACP countries, and call for an explicit mention of non-discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity to be included in the agreement replacing Cotonou, and for the EP to take into account the views of the parliaments of the ACP countries on the ACA negotiations before issuing an opinion.

name: Teresa Rodriguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on this resolution. This is an annual report by the Committee on Development on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. ACP-EU cooperation is based on the Cotonou Agreement (2000) which establishes, inter alia, joint institutions, such as this Parliamentary Assembly. The rapporteur gives an overview of the sessions of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly, held, in principle, in the Member State of the presidency on duty. Our amendments in the DEVE Commission pointed out that the Cotonou Agreement also provides for Economic Partnership Agreements (EAS) in which the ACP countries are disadvantaged. We also denounce that the EDF (European Development Fund) is an important source of funding from the African Peace Support Fund, used to finance military and security operations on the continent, which is at odds with the main objective of EU development aid. All our amendments were rejected. That is why we abstained in the vote.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — In my view, the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (one of the joint institutions of the Cotonou Agreement) is a space for open and democratic dialogue between MEPs and parliamentarians from ACP countries on the implementation of this agreement, including monitoring development cooperation within the framework of the European Development Fund (EDF) and the conclusion and implementation of economic partnership agreements.  As such, I welcome the fact that the report underlines the crucial role of national parliaments, local authorities and non-state actors in ACP countries in the preparatory phases and monitoring of national and regional strategy documents and during the implementation of the EDF. I would add that I voted in favour of the amendment calling on the European Parliament to have a political responsibility to take into account the views of the ACP parliaments on the outcome of the negotiations on the Economic Partnership Agreements before giving its compliant opinion.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. — As vice-president of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (APP), I would first like to congratulate the SHOULD Commission and in particular the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs of this motion for a resolution on the excellent document presented, which I voted in favour of. I would like to point out its relevance and the fact that it is not excessively long. But also its scope and foresight analysis, complemented by an extremely well-made framework and a level of detail that allows with some accuracy to understand the work of the ACP-EU Partnership under the Cotonou Agreements. On this partnership and its future, I would just like to leave two ideas: one, to highlight the importance of the parliamentary dimension in the context of ACP-EU cooperation. The results obtained by parliamentary diplomacy, as well as the concept itself, have to be evidenced and valued. We should therefore strengthen this aspect, and from now on by the participation of the APP in the current debate on the future of ACP-EU relations in the post-2020 period. And finally, fight for an increasing involvement in the work of the APP of civil society and public administration services that are closer to people, in particular regional governments and municipalities.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. — The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is an open and comprehensive space for dialogue between MEPs and members of the ACP countries on the implementation of the Cotonou Agreement, including the EU's development cooperation policy under the European Development Fund (EDF) and the conclusion and implementation of economic partnership agreements (EPAs). I supported this report, which looks back at the parliamentary work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, which met four times in 2012 and 2013 and underlines the important role of national parliaments, local authorities and civil society in monitoring and implementing European development policy.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) A vote in favour of the report is important in order to promote the work done by the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly and to give due recognition to the role played. The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is an institution that promotes an open, democratic and as comprehensive dialogue as possible between members of the European Parliament and parliaments of the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries, especially on the implementation of the Cotonou Convention.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against because, in view of the worsening political and humanitarian situation in several ACP countries and regions, I believe it must be acknowledged that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly has not been able to carry out the task assigned to it.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on this resolution. This is an annual report by the Committee on Development on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. ACP-EU cooperation is based on the Cotonou Agreement (2000) which establishes, inter alia, joint institutions, such as this Parliamentary Assembly. The rapporteur gives an overview of the sessions of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly, held, in principle, in the Member State of the presidency on duty. Our amendments in the DEVE Commission pointed out that the Cotonou Agreement also provides for Economic Partnership Agreements (EAS) in which the ACP countries are disadvantaged. We also denounce that the EDF (European Development Fund) is an important source of funding from the African Peace Support Fund, used to finance military and security operations on the continent, which is at odds with the main objective of EU development aid. All our amendments were rejected. That is why we abstained in the vote.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, as it recalls the importance of exchanges between MEPs and parliamentarians from ACP countries and calls for stronger political dialogue to promote the principles of good governance and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in these countries.  Parliament expressed its deep concern at the political and humanitarian situation in some ACP countries, including calls for better coordination in the fight against the Ebola epidemic in West Africa. The resolution also calls for an in-depth analysis of the failures and successes of the Cotonou agreements signed in 2000 to define a new ACP-EU mode of cooperation for the post-2020 year.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This resolution deals with the annual report prepared by the Committee on Development on the work of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, on the one hand, and the European Union, on the other. However, this text has not taken into account my parliamentary group's proposal to point out that the Cotonou Agreement also contains economic partnership agreements which harm the ACP countries. Nor does it contain a fundamental element for us, which is the need to denounce that the European Development Fund is being used to finance military and security operations on the African continent, which contradicts the main objective of European development aid. By these two elements, in main, I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution, but I abstained.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. — The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is the only multilateral parliamentary assembly established by the Cotonu International Agreement, which represents a unique opportunity for open debate on difficult issues that are key to good cooperation with developing countries.  The Joint Parliamentary Assembly, which is increasingly parliamentary or political in nature, is the cornerstone of an aecp-EU partnership on an equal partnership and provides a framework for a democratic and comprehensive dialogue between MEPs and MEMBERS of the ACP parliaments on the implementation of the Cotonu Agreement, development cooperation within the Framework of the European Development Fund and the implementation of economic partnership agreements. The role of the Parliamentary Assembly in the future is very important, as the need for enhanced joint parliamentary scrutiny is growing. Its action in the field of political, economic and social development in the ACP countries is aimed at promoting development objectives, ensuring respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and strengthening democracy on the basis of the rule of law. Since this motion for a resolution highlights the importance of the functioning of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly even after the expiry of the Cotunu Treaty in 2020, or encourages the strengthening of its role, I voted to strengthen it.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. — While I agree with many of the points of the report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly , I remained abstaining in the vote. This is due to paragraphs 1, 15 and 16 using terminology and positions that are not universally accepted in EU member states ither, and I believe that they should not be highlighted even in dialogue with our partners from ACP countries.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because I support the cooperation between the African, Caribbean and Pacific group of states, and the European Union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support the report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, as I want the provision of a framework open to democratic and comprehensive cooperation between MEPs and parliamentarians from ACP countries to continue. It is important to eradicate discrimination based on gender orientation, gender identity, religion, belief and age and disability in ACP countries.  Mutual agreements should serve development objectives and national and regional interests. The population needs of ACP countries are to reduce poverty, achieve respect for fundamental human rights and other economic ones, such as the right to food and access to basic public services.  For these reasons, workshops should be organised, at least two permanent co-rapporteurs should be appointed for PCD who would work closely with the Permanent Rapporteur of the European Parliament. In this way, a closer bond between organisations would be achieved.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. — Any EU approach with third countries or with corresponding organisations, in the broadest sense, must be designed and implemented on the basis of respect for culture and culture and its customs and customs, always in conjunction with its specificities, with a view to its sustainable social and economic development.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the report of my eminent colleague Charles Goerens.  Thanks to the quality of its work, the Assembly has managed to position itself as a key player in ACP-EU relations and cooperation. It has proactively continued to monitor political, economic and social developments in ACP countries to promote development goals and respect for all human rights and fundamental freedoms, including respect for fundamental social rights, rule of law democracy and transparent and accountable governance, which are integral to sustainable development. ACP-EU cooperation is supported by a legally binding system and the existence of common institutions. It is important that the APP continue to monitor developments very closely to ensure that its voice is heard when considering the various options and alternatives to be put in place after the Cotonou Agreement expires in 2020. Whatever the possible outcome of the ACP-EU post-2020 negotiations, the parliamentary dimension of the APP must not be diluted, but should continue to play a major role after 2020.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the work of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly (JPA) in 2012-2013. By this vote, I welcome the work accomplished so far and express the wish to strengthen the cooperation between the EU and ACP countries. This parliamentary assembly is a unique forum for political talks between the ACP and EU partners and can give an important impetus to subjects such as the fight against terrorism, poverty or the promotion of human rights and good governance.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. — I support the Report on the Work of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly of ACP-EU Countries and believe that the Assembly must continue its efforts to achieve the priorities of development cooperation between the EU and the ACP group of countries in order to prevent further deepening of the humanitarian and political crisis. Today, more than 1 billion people in the world are below the poverty line and it is inadmissible for the international community, given the instruments at its disposal, to close its eyes when it comes to meeting basic human needs.  I believe that issues such as access to drinking water and sanitation, meeting minimum hygienic conditions, eradicating hunger and poverty, and respecting fundamental human rights have a crucial weight in the 21st century. Effective multilateral cooperation in achieving sustainable development and inclusion of poor, unstable and weak countries in the global economy can only be achieved through the full and transparent mobilisation of available funds and detailed reports on where and how aid funds are spent. As 2015 has been proclaimed the European Year of Development, I call on all parties involved to demonstrate even stronger their desire to concreteise cooperation and jointly fight for reconstruction and assistance to vulnerable countries in order to protect fundamental human rights, freedoms and foster necessary social development.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I supported this report because the ACP has been transformed into a genuine parliamentary assembly that provides a forum for open and frank debate on issues that are of vital importance for development cooperation and contributes favourably to the partnership on equal terms between ACP countries and the EU. The reduction and long-term eradication of poverty is an objective to be achieved, and will be possible if economic development is sustainable, which is the basis for lasting peace and security, the political and democratic stability of ACP countries.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. — The report describes the Assembly's past activities and outlines the European Parliament's vision for the future of the Assembly. However, key concepts such as the fight against corruption and the management of migration flows are missing from the text. Our amendments on this subject have been rejected. As a result, I vote against it.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. — The APC-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly has succeeded in establishing itself as a key player in the relations and cooperation of African, Caribbean and Pacific states with the European Union. It remains a highly concrete tool for monitoring political, economic and social developments in the ACP States. The common objectives set are extremely important – the development of ACP states, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, democracy based on the rule of law and transparent and responsible governance, essential conditions for development. ACP-EU cooperation is based on a common legal system and the existence of common institutions. It is welcome that the Joint Parliamentary Assembly provides a framework for open and democratic dialogue between European parliamentarians and parliamentarians of African, Caribbean and Pacific states. We are talking about an area with difficult and controversial issues, and the existence of a dialogue with the EU sincere lysting and open can only produce beneficial effects among the ACP States. The standard of living, democracy and extremely complicated social problems in the ACP states make cooperation with the European Union absolutely necessary.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) Dialogue with the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific is of fundamental importance in order to be able to raise the destinies of peoples who, even today, after so many years of suffering due to colonialism, are unable to make progress on the path of political stability and economic growth. Open and direct discussion of the central themes of development cooperation is an important step towards poverty eradication, which can be achieved through democratic and comprehensive dialogue between the actors involved. It is necessary to create a policy for economic integration, and the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly can be not only a forum for discussing difficult and controversial issues, but also an instrument of development, trade growth and international dialogue for both the European Union and all those African, Caribbean and Pacific countries that have signed the Cotonou Convention. , the intention of which is precisely the reduction and, finally, the eradication of poverty. The report on the work of the ACP-EU Assembly is a work that we can support in achieving the objectives described above, and I have therefore expressed my support for the text presented.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This resolution deals with the annual report prepared by the Committee on Development on the work of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, on the one hand, and the European Union, on the other. However, this text has not taken into account my parliamentary group's proposal to point out that the Cotonou Agreement also contains economic partnership agreements which harm the ACP countries. Nor does it contain a fundamental element for us, which is the need to denounce that the European Development Fund is being used to finance military and security operations on the African continent, which contradicts the main objective of European development aid. By these two elements, in main, I have not been able to vote in favour of this resolution, but I abstained.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. — The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is a unique body where Europe and the countries around the Atlantic, Caribbean and Pacific countries speak and listen to each other on an equal footing. Within this body, all major and topical issues are discussed. Twice a year, this General Assembly meets, once in an ACP country and once in the country that currently serves as President of the EU. As the resolution shows, we need to look at the future of this institution this year. I believe that we must maintain this unique form of debate.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The Joint Parliamentary Assembly (APP) met four times in 2012 and 2013. The 23rd Session of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly adopted three resolutions drawn up by the standing committees, the 24th adopted three resolutions drawn up by the standing committees. The 25th Session of the APP took place in Brussels (Belgium) because Ireland, in the exercise of the rotating Presidency of the Council of the EU, declined its organisation in Ireland and the 26th Session of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly took place in Alse ababa (Ethiopia). We follow the positive assessment of the rapporteur, who underlines the quality of his work and the fact that he can establish himself as a key player in ACP-EU relations and cooperation.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - I have refused to support the report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly, as this is yet another example of misappropriation within the European Union. Five "information trips" alone, some to very exotic places, cost the taxpayer a huge sum and are therefore unsupported.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. — In this resolution, on the occasion of the '20th anniversary of the International Year of the Family', the European Parliament should have addressed the role of the family as a non-negotiable part of development cooperation. As long as the EU and its institutions, within the framework of Community development cooperation with the ACP countries, do not commit themselves to the universal values of family building on marriage between a man and a woman, and to the right to life, and to implement this commitment actively on the ground, all other efforts in development cooperation will be laudable but largely useless.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing — I supported the Report by Charles Goerens, as it is the intensive cooperation between the representatives of the ACP States and the EU that can help these countries. Nevertheless, I cannot agree with one point. On the one hand, the report criticises MEMBERS of the European Parliament for not attending the Joint Parliamentary Assembly (SPZ), on the other hand it incorporates a provision according to which the absence of assistants in the plenary sessions of the SPD has a significant impact on parliamentary activities. I believe that in such an important report, which expresses its deep concern at the deterioration of the humanitarian situation in the ACP regions and is intended to send a signal of full support to these States, such a statement has nothing to do.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, of which I am a member, for reviewing in its content that it welcomes the role played by this House in the framework of an open, democratic and comprehensive dialogue and because we consider it essential to continue to promote political debates on human rights, cooperation and development. , on public health, among others, which are an asset to deepening relations between the ACP countries and the EU.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The report addresses the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (AAA) over the past year. In general, with regard to the functioning of the APP, the rapporteur we make positive considerations about the necessary cooperation and inclusion of acp countries and on the enhancement of the role of the APP, criticising the Council and some Member States for devaluing it. This House has proved to be a very rich area of cooperation, mutual knowledge and exchange of experiences. A space where the contradictions that result from the unequal development of capitalism, the deep asymmetries and inequalities that run through the world today are well known. But we also have criticism of this report. In particular with regard to the defence and legitimacy made of the so-called Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs), which are nothing more than free trade agreements imposed on acp countries under blackmail, which are deeply insignificant to their interests and inseparable from undisguised objectives of economic resettlement of these countries by the European powers.

name: Die Präsidentin. -
text: Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Before going into the individual items on the agenda, I would like to draw the attention of those who have not yet heard it that another tragic shipwreck of a fully loaded refugee boat south of Sicily has taken place today, probably killing several hundred victims. I would like to say that we as a Parliament are very concerned about this incident – one of many that has unfortunately been repeated over the last few months and years – that we are following developments very closely and that we are also working to ensure that this kind of tragedy does not happen again around our continent.

name: Die Präsidentin. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, in particular in the context of ISIS (2015/2559(RSP)).

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, honourable Members, I am very grateful that you have added this important point to the agenda and also for suggesting a strong resolution on this matter. Let me express at the outset my outrage at the brutal murder of Kayla Mueller, a dedicated aid worker, by ISIS terrorists. Our thoughts are with the family, friends and colleagues of Kayla Mueller. Let me repeat in the strongest way possible: the European Union is committed to the fight against Daesh (ISIS) and other terrorist groups which threaten regional and global stability. We must redouble global efforts to put an end to these murders and to find a political solution to the regional conflicts. Only one word can describe the humanitarian situation in Iraq and Syria: devastation! As a result of both crises there are more than 20 million people in need of urgent humanitarian assistance. This number includes 3.8 million refugees in neighbouring countries: this is a plus of 75% compared to a year ago. The emergence of ISIS has complicated further the dynamics of the two crises. 3.6 million people are trapped in areas controlled by this and other armed opposition groups. Access for aid workers is heavily restricted and many times becomes impossible. The continuation of our aid to those most in need is essential. Showing solidarity with Syria’s neighbours is a must. That is why two weeks ago I visited Lebanon and Jordan, together with Commissioner Hahn. These are the two countries which, along with Turkey, have undertaken a huge burden in terms of refugees, especially taking into consideration the size of their population and the fragility of their political situation. We wanted to send a message of our ongoing strong support, especially to the most vulnerable – women, children, the elderly. Let me say once again: we cannot allow a lost generation of Syrian children. These are messages I repeated previously in Turkey with Federica Mogherini and Johannes Hahn. These are the same message our High Representative conveyed during her mission to Iraq. For my part, I announced a new EUR 136 million aid package to cover urgent needs in Syria and neighbouring countries. This brings the total EU humanitarian funding up to EUR 817 million. These messages of support were very well received. When I visited Syrian refugees in Lebanon, I saw at first hand the human dimension of this tragedy. I met women with six or eight children whose husbands had disappeared in Syria. I met a 14-year-old boy supporting alone his mother and six brothers and sisters. These are the real faces of war. These people and more depend on our help, not only on words of sympathy but on tangible assistance. And this is precisely what we are delivering. They were very grateful for what our assistance has done to improve their living conditions, for example by upgrading the local water system to allow access to fresh water. But the painful truth is that the needs are not at all matched by the available resources. Our funding also contributes to the stability of these countries and the wider region. It is in our own interest to continue to support these countries. This goes beyond humanitarian assistance. We need a comprehensive response, pulling together all European Union instruments: humanitarian aid, relief, longer-term stabilisation. To that end, the Commission is taking its responsibility. It agreed a EUR 1 billion aid package for Syria and Iraq for the current year and next year as part of the joint communication which was adopted last week. This package strengthens Europe’s political credibility. It shows the EU’s leadership. It will be a testimony to the EU’s commitment during the Kuwait III pledging conference in late March. We count now on our Member States to match this amount. This package will be to a large extent about humanitarian assistance, recovery and stabilisation measures. But this alone will not put an end to the conflict. Both crises require a political solution. There is a need for measures addressing the root causes of the conflict. That is why the communication includes counter-radicalisation and counter-terrorism measures. This is why education is an important component of the allocated funding. The barbaric murder of innocent people by ISIS and the brutal attacks in Paris last month further stress the need for a narrative to prevent and counter violent extremism and to counter terrorism. Such measures have been included in the communication. Most of all, we should continue to advocate the respect of international humanitarian law and the humanitarian principles, and the protection of civilians and relief workers. These are our common universal values. They guide our work and enable humanitarian workers to save lives. We will need your support to achieve our goals. And we must work together to succeed.

name: Elmar Brok
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Commissioner, thank you very much for the great efforts you are making to deal with the humanitarian disaster in Syria and Iraq. I was in Baghdad and Erbil a few days ago, I was in refugee camps and I think I have a sense of what is going on. When I see what else is going on in Syria and Iraq, when I see what is going on in Lebanon and Jordan, where the Foreign Affairs Committee will go on Monday, in the refugee camps or otherwise with the refugees in a country like Lebanon – which is home to 1.3 million refugees with a population of 4 million : we should also extrapolate this at home in our cities. what that would mean. I believe that you have our full support for this. But I think we should also make it clear what is going on politically. We have rarely, or in my lifetime, not seen at all to be dealing with a violent group that has no interest whatsoever in negotiating a solution, but which says everything and nothing, and anyone who does not believe it – not only Christians and Yazidis, but also Muslims who have a different view – , mercilessly destroyed. I believe that it is a necessity for us to remind many Islamic states to finally unite here and to confront the proxy war that Tehran and Riyadh are organising in the region and the misconduct of our NATO partner Turkey in some areas, and that we are trying to form an alliance here to combat this violent sect, which is inhumane. I believe that we, as the European Union, must assume this responsibility, as a free world. I do not believe that the 60 coalition partners can do this alone. We must demand the direct responsibility of our neighbours – from Turkey to Qatar, from Tehran to Riyadh – to fulfil their obligations here in order to prevent this da'ish extermination train.

name: Victor Boștinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Mr President, welcoming your intervention and fully agreeing with what my distinguished colleague Elmar Brok on behalf of the EPP said, it is true, today we are facing the greatest humanitarian crisis of the contemporary era. Never on such a scale have so many millions of people been subjected to violence of all kinds over such a long period of time and with consequences that are hard to assess. In Syria, after Assad's violence against his own people, da'esh (Islamic State) violence followed in front of a population that was forced to leave their homes and live in refugee conditions. In Iraq, millions of people were confronted with the consequences of the war. This year alone, more than 1.8 million people have experienced the effects of da'esh intervention, but, we must admit, there are also our mistakes, of the West, in the way we have strategically approached or failed to strategically approach this region, at least from the point of view of our interests. In the face of so many tragedies, our words cannot help much, but I can help the European Commission and the international community to do three things that I think are essential: a strategy to stabilise the region where local and regional actors are vital, as my distinguished colleague from the EPP, Mr Brok, said, we must think beyond prejudice and cliché , that local and regional actors are essential in stabilisation, an urgent strategy to meet the desperate needs of the population under refugee conditions and three, a strategy for the post-conflict evolution of this area, which risks becoming a true humanitarian desert.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria has reached catastrophic proportions, with an estimated 200 000 documented killings in the conflict so far. Clearly the Syrian Assad regime is at the root of the problem, but most recently the existential threat to the region and its minority communities, such as the Christians, Mandaeans, Yazidis, Shia Muslims and LGBTI communities, has come from the barbarous and fanatic so-called Islamic State.  Therefore my group welcomes the most recent Jordanian and UAE escalated air force response against ISIS following the horrific murder of a captured pilot. It has been some six months now since the American President Obama gathered together around 60 countries into a military coalition to degrade and ultimately destroy ISIS. In my mind, the three main target priorities for the coalition must be to interdict and destroy IS money-raising facilities, such as oil installations, and destroy their ammunition dumps and their training camps. Of the more than 3 000 European fighters with IS, sadly over 500 come from my country, the United Kingdom. The UK is a major military power so we must do more from my country to step up the efforts and, along with all the EU states, adopt an uncompromising approach towards EU citizens who have gone abroad to join ISIS and other militant Jihadi groups. We must also coordinate intelligence gathering and sharing and ensure that the laws are in place in our Member States to prosecute those who have committed atrocities, including kidnappings, bombings, false religious conversions and ritual execution of hostages in cold blood.  I would like to take this opportunity also to thank and congratulate the Kurdish Peshmerga and salute their amazing courage and bravery, which has been so evident with the reports confirming their resilience and protection of innocent civilians such as Yazidis, following the recent attacks on them by ISIS, and helping the YPG liberate Kobani in Syria. However, tragically, for the meantime the desperate humanitarian situation continues in the region. EU Member States must do all they can to mobilise the needed resources to the region and help civilians and refugees, particularly in countries like Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey, and to ultimately militarily destroy the evil of ISIS.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, a disaster of historic proportions is taking place in our neighbourhood. On top of the Assad regime’s ongoing use of violence, including the use of barrel bombs against their own Syrian citizens, Daesh (IS) has added new dimensions of unbearable horror and suffering to millions of people’s lives – people who want a future for their children, safety and freedom, just like you and I. Daesh’s barbaric violence sent two million Iraqis on the run in 2014 alone. We saw them with our own eyes as we visited northern Iraq, but most areas throughout Iraq are not even accessible to humanitarian aid organisations because they are so violent. And we see a downward spiral of despair and suffering that, in turn, helps the success of recruiters for jihadist organisations. Now minorities are being specifically targeted in a way that can only be seen as attempted ethnic cleansing. Christians, Yazidis, Kurds, Shabak and others, but most of all Iraqis, are in a very bad situation, and their ill-treatment, like that of LGBT people, must stop. For girls and women who are violently abused by militants, there is no specific psychological help. For youth, there is mostly no education. So, I ask you, when does the risk of a lost generation turn into a sombre reality? We cannot allow this to happen. The situation of refugees and internally displaced persons is already dire. I have seen little children’s feet on frozen ground, but with rising temperatures the risk of epidemics also rises. We need a comprehensive approach because we expect the liberation of Mosul soon, but that will also send many more people fleeing violence again, and even more assistance will be required. If we believe, as I do, that it is in our interest to take action and that domestic and foreign threats are increasingly blurred, we must work not only on increased EU efforts but also with partners, notably in the Middle East, to end the horrors of Islamic State and alleviate the human suffering.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, five million internally displaced persons; nearly four million living under the yoke of evil called Islamic State; 235,000 Syrian refugees in Iraq. These are data that give us the dimension of this humanitarian crisis in Syria and Iraq. But it's not new. This situation wasn't created by ISIS, or was it not true that before in Damascus there were one million Iraqi refugees or another million across Syrian territory? We need to talk about who started this, with intervention in Iraq—the criminal intervention in Iraq—that led to the destruction of the Iraqi state, support for a sectarian government, subsequent destabilization of Syria. This hasn't been casual. We therefore call on the Council, the Commission, also the High Representative, for the participation of many Governments of the European Union, to put all the financial and human resources to help refugees. Any militia must be norefore funded, because many governments in the European Union have done so. We must stop buying oil from Islamic State-controlled fields. Refugees must be given asylum, and above all, we must coordinate with the Government of Iraq — a non-sectarian government, of course - and with the Syrian Government — because I do not understand why they do not coordinate with the Syrian government.  And finally, support the initiative of the UN Special Envoy, Mr de Mistura. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – In fact, Mr Couso, it seems that you are greatly missing Mr Saddam Hussein. You are missing a dictator who invaded a neighbour. Is it possible, after all this time, for somebody in this Parliament which supports democracy, rule of law, human rights, etc. to miss Saddam Hussein and attack in such a manner the intervention of the western countries in Iraq? Is that possible?

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Frunzulic, I should listen to my words and not read whatever you want. I have spoken of the destruction of the Iraqi state—which has nothing to do with Saddam Hussein—in an illegal, illegitimate and criminal intervention that has caused more than a million dead. Therefore, you speak not of your desires, but of what I say. You are more interested in that chaos; that's what he wants, to wipe out the secular states of the area. And then they come to tell us that Christians are expelled. That "quartet" who came together to decide the invasion, who were Catholics and have managed to expel Christians from the Middle East. You have very little shame!

name: Alyn Smith
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would start by commending the fair degree of cross-party working which we have seen in the drawing up of this resolution. I think it is a decent attempt to take stock of where we are in this crisis and to place in context the humanitarian disaster, the risk of radicalisation locally and in our own countries and, indeed, the political acts that have brought us here – because they are all interlinked in various ways. It is important that we realise that the so-called Islamic State is as much a consequence as a cause of how we came to be here. The disastrous intervention in Iraq – and I very much echo a previous speaker’s comments – created the conditions for instability and radicalisation. The politicians responsible for that disastrous, illegal intervention should hang their heads in shame. The situation in Syria was further exacerbated by those conditions and was ignited, as the resolution also highlights, by the plethora of dreadful abuses by the Assad regime, which themselves feed and fuel the conditions in which extremists can thrive. Those conditions have created a flood of refugees which is almost impossible to cope with, greater than the population of Scotland and threatening to trip the neighbouring countries into anarchy as well. The resolution also takes account of the dreadful actions of Islamic State, but in part 3, I believe, we indicate a reasonable way out. We must have a coherent strategy: a cohesive response is needed to coordinate all aspects of engagement. Commissioner, I was glad to hear your view, which you have expressed before, that the solution is political. The EU has cleaner hands than most in this discussion, and cleaner certainly than most of our Member States. We support you in your efforts.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the time has come for all of us in this Chamber to move forward from the frequently repetitive debates every parliamentary session, which increasingly sound like a stuck record. If we genuinely seek a lasting resolution to this regional instability and a tragic humanitarian crisis, then the time has come for Member States and a wider international community, not least moderate Islamic nations, to confront the root of this cancer. Both the Saudi and the Qatari governments must now further face up to their sponsorship, whether indirect or not, of this Frankenstein’s monster that has been created in the form of Islamic State. Furthermore, the Wahhabi-run schools must be directly tackled and stopped from spreading their doctrine of hate. Unless the Saudis accept their role in allowing the propagation of this fundamentalist ideology, the problem will only expand further, as is already happening, not least in Yemen, the next item on today’s agenda.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the humanitarian crisis in Syria and Iraq is only getting worse, as the fighting intensifies from week to week. Humanitarian assistance can only be done properly in good cooperation with local authorities. This is what is practiced in Iraq, whether with the Baghdad government or with the autonomous Kurdistan Regional Government.  It is time to do the same with Syria to help Damascus cope with the humanitarian disaster caused by the actions of armed terrorist groups, the Islamic State in the first place of course, but also the al-Nusra Front, the Islamic Front or the Syrian Revolutionary Front, to name but a few among the dozens of groups that are setting the country on fire.  The European Union and Member States must now reopen their embassies in Damascus, as the new Tunisian government will soon do. The normalization of diplomatic relations with Syria is an indispensable condition not only for the establishment of humanitarian cooperation, but also for resuming security cooperation with Syrian services in order to combat jihadist channels that threaten the stability of European countries.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE). -
text: Madam President, the catastrophic situation in the Middle East is certainly not normal. It has been artificially created by several powers which have been waging proxy wars in the region to gain control of it. Among them, of course, there is Iran, which has been exporting arms, fighters and terrorists in the region.  Islamic State is actually the latest evil incarnation of this process. We must admit our co-responsibility for not supporting change in Syria when this started in its democratic and more modest forms. Delay and hesitancy have favoured radicalisation. The end-of-the-world style results we must face today.  The immediate programme will relieve the needs of the 17 million people in Syria and Iraq who are deserving of it, but an equally immediate challenge is to defeat Islamic State, and this also requires arms and political will, and to create the conditions for displaced persons to return to their homes.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, this morning the European Parliament voted and adopted a Resolution on counter-terrorism measures. It has rightly not been limited to a securitarian approach, but has taken a comprehensive view of measures to be taken to confront and prevent terrorism within and outside the Union. Among these measures, it emphasizes educational measures against indoctrination, cultural measures against sectarianism and social measures against exclusion. It should not be forgotten that a significant part of the militants of the Islamic Army comes precisely from our own countries. Outside the Union, we are facing the two most important crises in the world at the moment. Humanitarian crises that come, as the Commissioner has pointed out, from the great devastation that has occurred in Syria over four years of civil war, with twelve million people displaced, or from which it has occurred in Iraq, with five million people displaced, more than two million of whom are on Islamic Army-controlled territory. We have to give an immediate response, but also in the medium term. Immediate, supporting the Commission's proposal to devote EUR 139 million to respond to the humanitarian crisis, and in the medium term, contributing to stability in the region, contributing to good governance, contributing to the fact that, where there is now no state, there is a power capable of stabilizing reality and preventing so much devastation, so much war , so much suffering, that in many parts they exercise their own governments over citizens and, in others, situations such as those of the Islamic Army.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. We are debating another resolution on the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, particularly in the context of The Islamic State. What does the humanitarian crisis mean in this case? Not only the internal forced displacement and emigration of local people, but the planned cruel murder of Christians, as well as other religious minorities in Syria and Iraq, as recalled in Article 4 and 7 of the resolution prepared by our Group of European Conservatives and Reformists. Last September, our House voted on a similar resolution, but the problem is only getting worse. Swift concrete action is needed. Firstly, it is to block the departures of volunteers from the European Union feeding the ranks of the Islamist militants who carry out these horrific murders. Secondly, it is cutting off the funding of the so-called Islamic State, which flows not only from Saudi Arabia. In view of the helplessness of the European Union's structures in this regard so far, our Parliament should encourage the governments of those Member States that have good contacts with the sponsors of the so-called Islamic State to stop this.

name: Fernando Maura Barandiarán (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, the humanitarian catastrophe in Syria and Iraq is not only a consequence of the developments in these countries. It is also a consequence of the intervention — or absence of intervention — by the European Union, or some of its Member States, in these conflicts. And the advance of the Islamic State is not only our responsibility in large part, it is also our problem.
