Either we act, and we do it together with one voice, or we run the risk that the Islamic State and, with it, the absolute chaos will take over a region that is very close to us, that concerns our security and also affects us because of the true mass of people, refugees who come to our shores asking for our help. It is our interest, but also our concern, in the face of the true extermination of religious and ethnic minorities, to act on the basis of the fundamental values of the European Union and our ongoing commitment to human rights. In view of this, only a common response, a common foreign policy, one voice in the conflicts that concern us are worth it.

name: Sabine Lösing (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President! Our colleague, Mr Couso, is right that the Islamic State would not exist in this form without the previous Western intervention policy. And this concerns not only the war against Iraq, but also the intervention in Libya and the action in Syria, which has contributed significantly to the rise of radical Islamist forces. The repressive repression of Sunnis by the Shiite government in Iraq has also contributed significantly to the rise of ISIS. It must be put under pressure, as must those Western allies who massively support radical Islamist forces – first and foremost Turkey and the Gulf states. What we also need now, moreover, is adequate provision for the refugees, especially on the Turkish-Syrian border, opening up to a humanitarian corridor and a comprehensive reconstruction programme, and an immediate mine clearance programme. I would like to remind Mr Tannock that not only the Peshmerga fighters, but also those close to the PKK, and especially the fighters, have saved the Yazidis and liberated Kobane.

name: Barbara Lochbihler (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President! The Islamic State is responsible for horrific human rights violations in Syria and Iraq. The atrocities committed by ISIS have exacerbated the situation. However, it would be wrong to reduce the causes of the current crisis in the region to ISIS alone. The Assad regime continues to take extreme brutalaction against its own civilian population. Other armed groups and pro-government militias in Syria and Iraq are also responsible for horrific crimes. The international community must make it clear to those responsible on all sides that they will be held accountable for their crimes. I am concerned that the EU's regional strategy on counter-terrorism is too vague, especially when it comes to demanding human rights principles in cooperation with states in the region. The benchmarks for human rights mentioned must be clearly defined. It must be made clear that violating benchmarks will have consequences for cooperation. If we do not demand compliance with human rights standards in anti-terrorist measures, the mistakes of the past will undoubtedly be repeated.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in June 2014 the Islamic State was born, in the indifference of the European Parliament. For months, Europe has been b sinfully underestimating the problem. In July, I put a question to Baroness Ashton, in which I asked, among other things, whether ISIS was a danger to European citizens. I read the answer: 'There is no risk to European citizens unless they go to Iraq'. Instead, on 7 January, ISIS arrived at our house, hit Europe, hit European citizens, struck Paris. According to Europol, 5,000 European fighters in the Middle East could carry out terrorist attacks once they return home. We are at war, a war of civilisation that we must win. The enemy we have at home, the enemy is Islamic terrorism that wants to destroy the West, wants to destroy our traditions, our values. For years in here you said we had to talk. Just! We cannot talk to those who brutally kill children, children who are crucified and buried alive, or to those who behead journalists. I will close with an exhortation: wake up Europe! Alarm clock! No more appeals, no more communications, no more information! We need acts, we need courage, courage and courage.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE). -
text: Madam President, the humanitarian tragedy in Syria and also in Iraq is reaching catastrophic heights, as the Commissioner told us very well: we need solutions. In Syria, we need to support the efforts of the Special Envoy, Mr. de Mistura, to implement this action plan that will allow the freezing of hostilities, at first in Aleppo, and the sending of humanitarian aid. The freezing, even if partial, of these hostilities should also be a good starting point for the launch of political negotiation and an inclusive political transition: it is not desirable that the alternative to the perpetuation of Asad in power should be only ISIS. And since I'm talking about ISIS, in Iraq, fortunately, it seems to lose ground at the military level. But Prime Minister Abadi's government must also make every effort to achieve as much as possible in favour of a reconciliation between Sunnis and Shia that will lead to an inclusive and comprehensive Iraq in which the Kurds also fit and in which the only common enemy is ISIS. The complexity of the relationship, the rivalries between countries, the lines of religious fraction: all this makes regional and international concertation difficult to end the current violence. We need to have the full cooperation of key players in the area – I am referring to Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Iran – especially with regard to border control, and to tackle the financing of terrorist groups, in particular through oil smuggling, as has already been said. ISIS is a very serious threat to all, but also to the Muslim world. The abominable murder of the Jordanian pilot is a tragic test. In addition to the military battle on the ground and political initiatives, there is an ideological dimension in which moderate Arab and Muslim forces must also act.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D). -
text: Madam President! Together with three colleagues, I was in the Kurdistan Autonomous Region at the beginning of January. We wanted to find out first-hand about the situation in the areas directly terrorised by Da'ish. Here, the worn-out and so often abused concept of the "free world" suddenly takes on an elementary meaning, because here our freedom is defended. ISIS henchmans have reclaimed Mosul, a few miles away, by centuries. A mad troupe of ideologically blinded extremists is overcoming everything humanity has achieved in terms of civilisational progress. We have spoken to a lot of people, not just from politics. I just can't get a lot out of my head, like talking to young Yazidi women and girls who had been kidnapped and managed to escape their tormentors. They were literally enslaved, sold like animals, abused and raped by their owners. Some were barely older than ten years. They have had to go through horrible things and will probably suffer their whole lives. Nevertheless, these 250 women are better off than the 5 000 or so women and girls who are still deprived of their freedom. They are in the violence of people who lack humanity, in states with which we have official relations. That's what these women told us. And these people deserve our respect and attention. They need our support. The region's performance is already overstretched. European aid is being handled professionally, but it is only a drop in the ocean. Clearly, more resources are needed here. But we also have our part to play in Europe by preventing Europeans from joining the jihadists.

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR). -
text: Madam President, the escalation of armed conflict – thanks to ISIS – across Iraq and neighbouring Syria has resulted in a serious and worsening humanitarian crisis. There have been new and secondary movements of internally displaced people (IDPs) across the entire region. The numbers are really staggering, with approximately three million in Iraq and 7.6 million in Syria. One issue disclosed at a recent Iraq delegation meeting is that there is very little information on those in ISIS-controlled areas. The real extent of the humanitarian challenge is well hidden. As the brave Peshmerga and Iraqi forces push to regain territory from ISIS, such as at Kobani, so we see the true extent of the underlying damage and deprivation. Many of those internally displaced have been subject to the most unthinkable of crimes, with large numbers of women and children raped or sexually abused by ISIS. There is a great need for counselling support, not just the basics. As President of the Iraq delegation, I encourage international partners, the Iraqi government and the Kurdistan regional government to redouble their efforts in terms of financial and logistical support in providing essential services, land allocation and site preparation for IDP camps. Our thoughts are very much with the people of Iraq and Syria at this very troubled time.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, what is happening in Syria and Iraq is a considerable challenge to Europe, but also to the world, and calls into question what we believe in man and human beings. At the moment, even though, of course, we are doing everything we can and even though the situation is difficult and complex, we are not doing enough. Europe's mobilization is not strong enough and neither is international mobilization. More needs to be done. As far as humanitarianism is concerned, we must do what we can: create humanitarian corridors, make sure that food arrives, help the countries neighbouring Syria, which can no longer afford it, especially Lebanon, which is experiencing a 25% increase in its population. Can we imagine what that means? We need to act economically. We absolutely have to cut off the financial resources of the Islamic State group and we need to put in place an oil embargo that perhaps today we consume in the European Union and, why not, in France? Of course, we have to act at the military level. The European Union must commit itself as such. It must also think about a common defence policy. We have to react politically. We must prioritize our enemies, especially in Syria, and put all the Gulf countries, Iran and Turkey, around the table. We cannot act alone, we cannot act in isolation, we must bring together even more, we must act to fight terrorism because the threat - and this is what makes this war so complex - is not only external, but also internal. Let us take all necessary measures to combat terrorism. I visited the al-Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan less than a year ago. We must act so that those who are there, these women and men, do not lose all hope. Let's act before it's too late. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, do you not think that today we need a complete review of the strategic and diplomatic options, given that France, Great Britain and the United States have nevertheless been responsible for this dramatic policy of the Arab Spring. The consequences must be drawn and, from now on, no longer undertakes diplomatic action with these countries without European consultation. You have made wishful thinking. Of course, we have to act on what is going on there. But do you not think that European countries are entirely responsible for the crises in the Near and Middle East?

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, I would like to remind you that the Arab Springs have reflected the desire of these peoples to free themselves and to empower themselves and that, from this point of view, we have been with them. Do the Western powers have a responsibility in this regard? Yes, I do. The American commitment to Iraq, which fortunately was not supported by France, weighed heavily. I believe that previous interventions in Afghanistan also bring their share of shame and responsibility. The important thing now is to move forward, to mobilize. These are not wishful thinking. The entire international community must seize this danger.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, it is quite true that the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria has worsened dramatically with the self-proclaimed Islamic Army and Islamic State. But it's also true that it didn't start today or yesterday. It is true, yes, that it is very much linked to an absolutely disastrous foreign policy, often pursued by the European Union and the Member States of the European Union. And it is true that it is linked to the invasion of Iraq and it is true that it is linked to the financing of opposition groups in Syria, totally devaluing its fundamentalist character. And that's why the future has an ancient heart. Because to do well in the future, we have to learn from the mistakes of the past. And we need to do much better. We need to stop funding terrorist activities, particularly through off-shores. Why is there the taboo of off-shores? We need to prevent oil from being produced in territories that are occupied by Islamic State from European countries. We need to stop the arms sales. We need a European policy for refugees. We need all this and also, yes, obviously, humanitarian aid. But if we don't get to the bottom, we will continue to make statements and these debates a thousand times, and every time the situation will be worse.

name: Bodil Ceballos (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul You began by mentioning the latest drowning tragedy in the Mediterranean. That is also the starting point I have in this discussion. There are thousands of refugees who die every year on the way to Europe. Millions are fleeing internally or to countries in the immediate area. Only a few reach Europe, and not all countries accept them here. So it is imperative that all EU countries open up to provide protection to, among others, the Syrian refugees. It is also imperative that we all provide humanitarian aid to the refugee camps in the surrounding area.  But the ones who suffer most are the children and, as the Commissioner also said, we must not let an entire generation be lost. The children in the camps need to go to school, and that is also the case. They need to live a reasonably normal life in the midst of disaster, but they will also need psychological support for many, many years to come and not just until the war is over. We must be prepared to take our part in that work when that time is right.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, our thoughts today can only go to the young American Kayla, the last of thousands of people killed by ISIS. In other times, as we know, information on the violence committed by the bloodiest regimes on the planet has always reached us in a fragmented and discontinuous way. Often those same regimes concealed the atrocities and human rights violations they committed. Today we are faced with a completely opposite reality: ISIS does not hide torture, beheadings, violence and mass rape, on the contrary, it exhibits them; it does not deny the barbarity of its terrorists, but trumpeting it before the world by imposing Sharia law and the cruelty of its illegitimate courts. Its victims are Muslims and Christians, children and women, soldiers and civilians, people of all creeds and races.  Therefore, faced with this appalling challenge launched against humanity as a whole, Europe must have its own strong common strategy and is called upon to do so immediately, in all its national and international for a, overcoming all divisions within it. We must do this because before we are popular, socialists, communists, liberal democrats, nationalists or Eurosceptics, we are all people animated by a profound, inescapable, absolute conviction: the one that, faced with the alternative between good and absolute evil, between life and death, between respect for human rights and their denial, we always choose and will choose the good, life and respect for the rights of every human being. That is the thrust of the resolution which I hope will be adopted by all of us.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: With three other members of this Parliament, in January I traveled from Erbil to Dohuk in northern Iraq, speaking to authorities, members of the Christian and Yazidis communities and others on the run, refugees from Syria, visiting idp camps, speaking to many victims of DAESH terrorism.  I have come very critical of the insufficient and misdirected support that the European Union provides in the vital fight against the common enemy. Through Iraq and Syria passes the front line against terrorism, which during our visit was brutally attacking in Paris.  The European Union must build and coordinate an effective strategy to support the eradication of the Islamic State. It must articulate the military support provided by some Member States, strengthen support for the Peshmerga who in Iraqi Kurdistan and Syria are fighting against terrorist forces. It must exercise its political influence with regional powers to prevent them from channeling funding, arms and logistical support into DAESH. The initiative of such coordination must be based on the High Representative, exercising its powers within the framework of the common security and defence policy. As much as some Member States shudder, they have to be confronted with their responsibilities. Only by facing DAESH in Iraq and Syria can we in fact preserve our security. There radicalisation is nourished on European soil. We will have more terrorist attacks in Europe and beyond against European citizens and interests.  At the humanitarian side too, we have to do more and better to support the people. In Member States that, for example, give selective visas to Christians, it is better if they invest in humanitarian support and development so that Christians, Yazidis and other minorities not only have the schools missing in refugee camps but feel they have a future in Iraq. For them, for the people and for their pre-Islamic millennial cultures, as the Goth and Assyrian priests have told us. It was also better for them to work to help free the young women and children trafficked and enslaved by the terrorists and to take in those who managed to escape and who need treatment. This urgently needs a representation of the European Union in Erbil. We also absolutely need an articulated strategy of internal policies that do not continue to finance, to promote the radicalisation of young people, more than 3,000 young Europeans who in Iraq and Syria today spread terror against the people and who are also already operating here near our borders in Libya.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR). -
text: Madam President, when we talk about the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, we should also take note of the negative role played in this whole area by the involvement of Iran, which is trying to be a regional power in this area, which has infiltrated the state structures in Iraq, promoted sectarian violence in Iraq, which has become one of the catalysts for the emergence of the so-called 'islamic state'. Islamic State, and, of course, Iran has also been associated with the Assad regime in Syria, another catalyst for the emergence of the Islamic State. Not to mention Iran's connection to Hezbollah in Lebanon or its recent activities in Yemen. I think we must also have the courage to say that the solution to the situation in this region will be to reduce Iran's influence in the region. So it means that we cannot regard Iran as our ally in the fight against the Islamic State. We cannot accept any offers of exchange of support for concessions such as iran's nuclear program, and we should, above all, seek to reduce Iran's influence in Iraq. One such example could be the fate of the Liberty refugee camp, where members of Iran's Resistance Movement, which unfortunately has terrorist status with the Iraqi government, are staying, even though it has been removed from this list by both the European Union and the United States. We need to make a correction here.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, a lot has been said in describing the situation and there is very little I could add as it has been described precisely and eloquently. One word: really very grave. I would like to express my appreciation for the Commissioner’s personal efforts and I am thinking also, Commissioner, of the efforts of your staff and also the financial package that you have further disclosed.  But I am afraid that this is not sufficient. I think that we need to be aware that we need the strong and united commitment of the European Union and the Member States to be politically engaged in the areas of crisis, and if need be, to be engaged in military terms, wherever it is meaningful, wherever needed and wherever it will lead to a concrete result. I think that this commitment at the moment is insufficient and is missing. The second point I would like to raise, and it has already been described by many previous speakers, is that there are countries in the region which can play a positive political role, but there are also countries which can play a role in financial aid. This is also something where probably we have to be more efficient in exerting the influence that we have. I would even say that maybe the time to seek a donor conference is coming, because the European Union is really bearing the main burden at the moment and the Member States partly so. So I very much welcome your efforts, Commissioner, but I would stress political engagement, wherever needed, military engagement, and once again, influence on the regional powers, on the countries in the region, politically and financially.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, I think there is no one in this Chamber who really knows what we need to do for the people of Syria and Iraq. That's why we're being consumed with a description of these people's sufferings. So there is no debate that humanitarian aid to the people of Syria and Iraq must be increased without delay and that we should offer real aid to the people. It is our obligation, as the European Union and the Member States, to take this issue seriously, to ensure that they have at least the basics for their livelihood. However, we must not forget, in search of the causes of this great evil, the basic responsibility for the current situation. It is brought together by the United States and the States of the European Union: those who in 2003, in the name of supposedly fighting terrorism, started a war that lasts to this day and has completely destabilised the entire Middle East region. Those who, through their actions and omissions, have served what we now call the Islamic State. And we are forced today to discuss the basics of human existence. The European Union must take a new direction in this area.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE). -
text: Madam President, in Syria and Iraq, field hospitals and schools have been destroyed, water and electricity service have been damaged. Daesh continues with real atrocities: sexual abuse, slavery, cruel violence, kidnappings, executions, indiscriminate bombings. They have even ordered the female genital mutilation of all women under the age of 49 to begin. We are faced with a constant violation of human rights and international humanitarian law. Daesh, in its clear intention to expand, has already set foot in Libya, doing nothing but increasing the critical humanitarian situation. The most vulnerable need food, water, health and school, and 139 million euros is a significant amount, but it is an insufficient amount. I refer to what UNHCR says: the six neighbouring countries, which are the most touched by the finger of solidarity, must be shared and helped. In Lebanon, 1.1 million; Turkey, 1.6; Jordan, 621,000; Iraq, 235,000; Egypt and North Africa, 160,000. That's the 3.8 million Syrian refugees. But in Iraq we also have 5.2 million people in need of humanitarian aid, and 2.1 million people are internally displaced. We have to do a lot more.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the disastrous political and humanitarian situation in Iraq and Syria is already being described by previous stakeholders and can already be compared to the great catastrophes in our history. I am going straight to the question of human rights, because I believe that we should give a warning to all actors who are trampling on human rights in the region, going over all the limits. Al Daesh, of course, but not alone; also to Asad, because Asad is getting away with it because we have a greater horror before our eyes, but we will not forget and should not let go of the rapes, abuses, massacres and deaths made spectacle. If there is a strategy to end terrorism, to end the Daesh, we should start to know the faces of who they are. We know a lot about their communication and their strategy, but we need to know the faces because I'm afraid that, in addition to many deaths and a lot of pain, they are managing to hide their faces. I would like to stress the proposal that my group includes in the Resolution, which is to send the United Nations High Commissioner on a mission to Iraq, so that we can identify the crimes that are taking place against humanity to bring its perpetrators to court, because we will not win the war on terror by handing human rights as a currency.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR) -
text: Commissioner, thank you very much for your efforts to address the humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, especially in the context of the terrible work of the Islamic State. We all know about the atrocities they are committing, there is no need to talk about it anymore now. I would like to stress that the humanitarian situation cannot be separated from the security situation, and this, in turn, cannot be viewed outside the political context. After all, all humanitarian aid must be interconnected and move towards a safe political environment. As you probably know, some groups in the area, namely the Chalcedon, Syrian and Assyr people, Turkmens and Jedi, signed a joint declaration last October in the EP in Brussels on local autonomy and self-government under the Kurdish regional government in Iraq. I had the opportunity to chair this meeting and it was a really rare atmosphere and I think it is very important to take these democratic initiatives seriously, because they themselves know best what the people of their region really need. I am very pleased with all the efforts you have made so far for this cooperation. Finally, Commissioner, I respectfully ask you to continue to seek out these local authorities of the minorities concerned and to take them as official partners in your efforts to resolve this humanitarian crisis.

name: Miloslav Ransdorf (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, the basis of the problems in this area was the United States' efforts to balance democracy first with weapons and then with the activities of the secret services. I think this is a fundamental mistake, because democracy cannot be decreed in any way. Democracy is the result of the long development of the rule of law and civil society. And it is only at the end of this development that democracy is being set up. I think we will find that support for secular nationalist regimes in this area is far more appropriate for the present time. Secular nationalist regimes, which are a far more natural partner for us than regimes that are influenced by Islamism one way or another. I think that the EU's position towards the Assad regime in Syria, which is secular and a guarantee of, I would say, civic values, will be reconsidered, after my judgment.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I thought we were talking about a humanitarian crisis, not training on how to achieve democracy. And I think that there may not be anyone in this chamber who would not condemn the actions of IS, and I think that, of course, it would be best if there was allied unified military action against IS with a Security Council mandate. Unfortunately, this has not yet happened, and the humanitarian crisis has grown to huge proportions, and so has IS in the form of a state department organization. It has resources, both human and military and financial, and I think that we should call on all EU states at the moment, but also our allies, to take joint action to stop all these resources, both human and military and financial. We can, of course, analyse the causes of the emergence of the Islamic State, but this will not solve the situation that is now current and which the EU Member States should, but of course, as I say, Europe's allies should also pay due and rapid attention. And it bothers me a little that, thanks to IS, other problems associated with international terrorism seem to fit in. And regimes that support international terrorism, whether they were countries like Iran and others in the past or now. I would like to see some time for these countries, not in this debate, but in one of the others.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I should like to thank the Commissioner for the work that he is doing. The Syrian conflict is now entering its fifth year and there is still no end in sight. The brutality of ISIS has been horrifying. Their acts of barbarity have no religious justification and are war crimes against humanity. Seven million refugees, especially children, are under threat from the winter months right now. It is imperative that funding of the humanitarian emergency is top priority and all necessary actions are taken to ensure the safety and protection of the most vulnerable. It is, however, even more crucial that we sever the problem from the roots. Despite the tragedy facing Syrian civilians under ISIS rule, the ruling Assad regime is responsible for far more deaths, displacements and destruction. Were it not for the Assad regime, ISIS would never have been able to take root in Syria. Even the elimination of ISIS will not end the radicalised opposition groups, and Syria has new groups which are likely to emerge to fill the void. This happened in Iraq where authoritarian and divisive rule opened the door for the emergence of ISIS. The international community must realise that the only way forward for Syria and to defeat ISIS is to address the root cause of the conflict, namely the Assad regime. That is also largely responsible for the humanitarian crisis facing the country. The EU must increase its pressure on the regime and help restore peace and security in the country and thus in the region.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: Madam President, honourable Members, Honourable Commissioner, I am impressed by your work, by the efforts you have made, for which I congratulate you. Indeed, at the moment in Iraq and in Syria we have completely destroyed countries, we have a collapsed infrastructure, we have a vanished statehood, we have a lack of elementary needs, we have cities and societies where there is no electricity, no water, no roads, no schools. All these things are clear and visible. The reason for them, however, is different. And the reason is clear - they did not happen by themselves. This isn't just a natural disaster. And therefore, only humanitarian activities will not be able to be solved. The cause of this humanitarian catastrophe is actually the existence of an ultra-radical, ultra-religious state caliphate, such as Islamic State. This state, this caliphate persecutes Yazidis, persecutes Kurds, persecutes Orthodox, persecutes early Christians, persecutes Shiite Muslims. This regime is a threat to the lives of people in these territories, as well as in Europe. They're what we have to fight.

name: Cornelia Ernst (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President! In January, I was in Iraqi Kurdistan with colleagues from the ALDE and the S&D Group. If I understood one thing there, it is that we Europeans have the task of giving our support to the victims of the Da'ish fascists. There are 5.3 million people living in this region, and in just a few months two million refugees have been added, all minorities from Iraq, who are now living in tent cities or on the streets. Children in particular are under threat. 5 000 Yazidi women and children were kidnapped and 2 000 men were murdered. The Yazidis are experiencing another genocide; 2000 years of history are to be wiped out. What we need now are really clear messages. We need international protection for religious communities and minorities in Iraq. We need money for refugee camps and schools for children, which do not exist at all at the moment. We need financial programmes, programmes to rebuild the yazidi villages, the Shabak and other minorities, including Christians. We need support for the kidnapped women. Let me end with a word from the Bishop of Erbil, who said: help us, make sure that we can stay in Iraq, let us reconcile with the Sunnis!

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE) -
text: It is a sad reality that Syria and Iraq have recently become synonymous with humanitarian crises. Syria's civil war has been going on for four years. A humanitarian crisis for about the same time. We could use scary statistics to illustrate it. The previous speakers mentioned them, so I will not repeat them. The Assad regime's response to these figures is to deny any responsibility. As if that wasn't enough, Syria and Iraq found themselves in another conflict. They oppose the Islamic State extremist groups. ISIS poses dramatic problems for Syria, Iraq, the whole region, but also for Europe. He's using terrorist tactics, he's turning states up, he's throwing people out of their homes. He's a direct threat to our civilization. We see it at home, in the acceding countries, in our direct neighbours.  It is also alarming that many fighters for the Islamic State are foreigners and from the so-called Western world. This reality must be approached responsibly by all the Member States of the European Union. We have a new strategy to mobilise one billion euros for Syria and Iraq over the next two years.  There are already generations of people in both Syria and Iraq whose lives are completely destroyed. We must also think about what awaits us after the end of the war in Syria, how we will contribute to the reconstruction of an absolutely devastated country, how we will restore human dignity to its people. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear colleague Kukan, you are a good connoisseur of the situation in the Balkans, because I know that you are the head of the Delegation for Serbia. You know well the situation in the Balkans, Albania, but also in Bosnia and Herzegovina. My question goes for what you mentioned, that there is a lot of danger among our neighbors, in our countries. I want to apostrophize the problem of Bosnia and Herzegovina here, where authorities say that about three thousand potential terrorists are on the soil of Bosnia and Herzegovina today.  My question is: Do you share my concerns and do you call on both the Commission and all European institutions to help Bosnia and Herzegovina?

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the Blue Card – I have already said in my speech that the Member States of the Union are and should be responsible for this situation. Bosnia and Herzegovina is one of the aspiring countries for future membership of the European Union, and like other countries, it is affected. I think it is good, realistic and I support the proposal by a revered colleague for the Commission to deal with this situation in the future.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let me, at the beginning of this speech, express my discomfort. Since the beginning of this debate, I have heard beautiful words, beautiful speeches of compassion and solidarity with all those , including children, women, who are tortured and killed in Syria, in this civil war, in this genocide they are suffering, under the yoke of the dictator Bashar al-Assad. I also hear many beautiful words spoken to those killed in Iraq and elsewhere, in Libya now, by the organization "Islamic State", which is rampant in its murderous expansionism. And then, finally, I always have the impression that there are few solutions and I would like to say to you, Commissioner: go further! Go further in humanitarian aid. If we had to compare our situation with that of Lebanon, where 18% of the population are refugees, it would be like 15 million people in France, 90 million in Europe! So let's do it! Let's get more food aid, more humanitarian aid! Then let us return to the negotiating table to put an end to this genocide perpetrated by Bashar al-Assad in Syria.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – I congratulate you, Commissioner, on your involvement in the unprecedented humanitarian crisis. The atrocities committed by ISIS have led to the tragedy of millions of people. This wave of refugees will not stop there, there will be many others who will leave the conflict zones and we have a duty to support them with food, shelter and healthcare. We must not, however, forget the support that the states in the region, those that receive refugees, such as Lebanon and Jordan, need. In order to resolve, however, the humanitarian crisis, we must deal seriously and in a coordinated manner with the terrorist threat. Let us now take urgent, concrete and firm measures in the fight against terrorism. For too long, our reaction in the region is just a reaction and we are not proactive. How will these refugees be reintegrated into society? How can we contribute to the construction of infrastructure in which civilians in Syria and Iraq can live, how do we ensure that these conflicts do not recur? The immediate priority is indeed to provide assistance to refugees, but also to develop such a plan for a sustainable future in the region.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D). -
text: Madam President! The Terrorist Organization Islamic State is an existential threat to the people of Syria and Iraq and beyond. The inhumane actions of the terrorists have caused an almost incomprehensible distress. The funds made available so far are not sufficient. I therefore particularly welcome the High Representative's announcement that she will continue to increase EU aid.  It is good and important that Mrs Mogherini has presented us with an EU strategy for the region. The EU and the EU Member States must act together. And we need to develop a comprehensive approach that involves the whole region. In Syria, the Assad regime is still in power, whose cruel repression has caused the civil war. Russia must be involved in diplomatic efforts to resolve the conflict. Russia has actively supported Assad and is still holding its protective hand over the regime.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D). -
text: Madam President, it is not with great moral proclamations or just with them, nor with exercises of imputation of historical responsibility, that we will contribute to the resolution of this very serious problem with which we are confronted. Let us not delude ourselves, this is one of the most serious issues facing the international system today. We have a very serious humanitarian crisis, and I would like to welcome the efforts that the Commission is making to address the same crisis, because that is an absolute priority. But we are faced with a serious political issue that has to be looked at in all its complexity.  We are faced with a region that goes through a process of profound destructuring, and it cannot be evaluated in a simplistic way. There are problems that have an internal origin in the Islamic world. There are problems that have resulted from some external interventions over a long time. Not just the latest, but over many decades. And the European Union has this obligation, not least because this is a region close to the conflict zone, has this obligation to look at this problem and seek to solve it, taking into account all its complexity and focusing mainly on the political dimension in solving the problem.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D). -
text: Madam President, you will probably agree that hardly anything has changed since I last addressed this issue here in the House. If anything, things have gotten worse, not better. This is a shame and a tragedy. It is a shame, as the international community is standing idly by in light of ongoing fighting in Syria, where we have stopped counting the dead. The first 100 000 deaths made huge headlines. The next 200 000 did not illicit even a shrug. It is also a tragedy with far-reaching consequences. What we are getting in not serving these unfortunate people is a more and more traumatised young generation. In a few years’ time they will resort to the same violence and terror that is the route of many tragic events we have witnessed recently. So it is in our immediate interest to call on all powers in Syria and Iraq and beyond to bring to an end the fighting and suffering of the peoples in the region.

name: Goffredo Maria Bettini (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the lives of millions of people are at stake in Syria and Iraq. All energies must be put in place and coordinated. We have said genocide that devastates regions where the West in the past has promoted unforgivable wars. Genocide is a demanding word, requiring appropriate consequences. But one point must be clear: the threat does not only concern the Middle East but also points to the heart of Europe, it sows hatred in the scattered cells of the natives of our cities. For this reason it is not enough for ISIS to be contained, it must be defeated by liberating the territories it has conquered by force, bringing back peace and a possibility of coexistence among all.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE). -
text: Mr President, almost everything has been said about the humanitarian situation. I would like to touch upon two elements that need to be addressed just as urgently as humanitarian needs if we want to ensure that the region will still house its rich mosaic of peoples in the years to come.  First of all, heritage sites need to be protected immediately. Through the destruction of heritage, the identities and histories of minorities and communities are erased. Peoples’ identities and claims that they have a right to be there are tied to the presence of monuments and religious-historical buildings which stand as proof of their presence in the land. It is also documented that IS partially funds its operations through looting and selling archaeological artefacts. Secondly, the issue of the disputed territories urgently needs to be addressed if we wish to see the future of Iraq taking place within the internationally agreed borders. Had diplomatic efforts succeeded in the past, there would not have been the current stalemate between Erbil and Baghdad, and IS might have been defeated earlier because of increased trust and joint operations between the two parties.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D). -
text: Mr President, the advance of jihadist fighters across a wide band of territory in Syria and Iraq has fuelled a massive humanitarian crisis in the region which, I might say, is unprecedented. Fighters from Islamic State – which we should always call Daesh because they are not a state – in Iraq and Syria are terrorising the civilian populations and persecuting religious and ethnic minorities. The situation in Iraq is part of the larger crisis unfolding in the region mainly as a result of Syria’s civil war. Civilians continue to be displaced, as a result of the conflict, to refugee camps where they often have to deal with a shortage of food and medicine. A resolution of the humanitarian crisis requires not only the military defeat of Daesh in Iraq and Syria, but also a political solution that creates a cross-sectarian coalition against jihadism.  I could say that, in order to have a final positive result, the coalition should also address the interests of the Sunni Iraqi groups and tribes that have aligned with Daesh and should garner the support of regional powers like Iran and Saudi Arabia.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE). -
text: Mr President-in-Office, the Syrian civil war has already created the biggest humanitarian catastrophe of this century, and now the horrors of ISIL in Iraq and Syria have also been added to it. It is important that European countries clearly put the border on their own citizens to fight for ISIL. We can also help our partner countries to do this in the form of our own experience: the countries of Central Asia, for example, are very concerned about this issue. Stronger cooperation must, of course, also be done with the Arab states and Turkey, both in the fight against ISIL and in helping refugees. Refugees – helping them must be a priority for humanitarian aid in the European Union. If necessary, development aid resources must also be redirected to humanitarian aid in order to reduce the suffering of these people. Finally, there must be international restrictions that would work both on arms sales and on the transfer of money to ISIL. Thank you.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while we are rightly recriminating the Humanitarian Catastrophe in Syria and Iraq and voting on resolutions, which are also fair and acceptable, and trying to address this issue, in Washington at the moment, the clock is turning back thirteen years with President Obama's request for congressional authorisation for the use of total force against ISIS, including by employing ground troops. We are therefore returning to the real cause of the birth of Daesh, namely military operations carried out over the last few decades without the will to make political efforts not to export democracy as if it were a can of tomatoes, but to help those countries grow it spontaneously.  Unfortunately, I do not see a real solution in this House, which would be to adopt sensible sanctions against those who are still selling, marketing and transporting ISIS illegal oil at the moment, a clear strategy towards the countries that we call allies and which have so far taken an ambiguous position, at least in this whole affair. Bombs kill men, they don't defeat ideas. Daesh's nightmare is also the sleep of reason in the West.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like the whole of Europe to see the image of this House. There are 751 of us and there are no more than forty people here who discuss these issues and then, you, the caste, go around saying that Europe cares about everything and then does not care about our poor and our elderly, but cares about something else, makes wars, makes alliances with the United States and then comes here to cry. You're hypocrites! You're hypocrites! You are like that saying that there is in Italy that says: "the ox gives cuckold to the donkey". You are the same, because after the whole ceremony, I show it, go out and your problem is: where do you eat? What do you drink? Where am I going to buy clothes? You don't give a about what's going on around. All you care about is having your butt warm.

name: László Tőkés (PPE). -
text: Dear Mr President, Ronald Reagan once called Soviet communism the realm of evil. History has shown that an atheist dictatorship can only be defeated by united forces. In one of his last speeches, Tom Lantos listed the three totalitarian regimes of the 20th and 21st centuries and proclaimed a fight against Nazism and Islamic fundamentalism in the footsteps of communism.  In the face of dictatorships that pose a global threat, we have only a chance to stand up to full cooperation around the world. Christian Europe must spearhead this international struggle, in solidarity in faith with christians in Iraq, Syria and all persecuted people affected by the humanitarian catastrophe. God's word exhorts us to do the same: "Open your mouth, in addition to those who are silent, and in the things of those who have been given peril."

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are discussing the greatest humanitarian crisis since the Second World War. A crisis further aggravated by the atrocities and violence perpetrated by the so-called Islamic State, which has launched a campaign of systematic ethnic cleansing, becoming responsible for the horrific war crimes that have plunged the people of northern Syria and Iraq into terror, forcing thousands of people to flee. Given the complexity of the problem, it is therefore becoming increasingly important that the European Union's strategy should include an integrated approach capable of combining military, political, humanitarian and development aspects. I therefore hope that, with the launch of the new strategy to support Syria and Iraq, the European Union will be able not only to provide humanitarian assistance, but also to make its contribution in the fight against extremism in the region and to providing neighbouring countries, in particular Jordan and Lebanon, with the necessary support so that they can cope with the influx of refugees.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE). -
text: Mr. President, when we spoke here a few months ago about the situation in the Middle East, then I asked everyone if they knew what Vukovar was, what Srebrenica was, and if they had ever heard of these places before the tragedies that occurred in Vukovar and Srebrenica. That's when we talked about the possible fall of Kobane. Fortunately, that didn't happen. Kobane today is a free but tremendous political crisis, a tremendous humanitarian crisis and still, unfortunately we are witnessing it, growing by the day. Therefore, I believe that the ultimately decisive synergy action of all those who can jointly solve the problem in the Middle East is necessary. Of course, in addition to the European Union, I also include Turkey, I include Russia, I also include the United States. I expect our Commission to act in this direction, through the synergy of all those forces that can solve the problem in the Middle East.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for your remarks, your suggestions and, of course, your support. I am fully aware that the crises in Syria and Iraq are both likely to stay with us for years to come, unfortunately. I will continue to work closely with my fellow External Relations Commissioners to ensure that the EU’s response will remain strong. It will remain substantial. It will remain tangible. As one of the world’s leading donors in both these crises, the European Union has a strong responsibility to take action. And action we are taking! Ending the suffering of the millions of people affected by these two terrible crises is not only a moral imperative but also – as all of us have said – very much in our own interest. We need stability in our neighbourhood in order to have stability inside our Union. It is obvious. That is why all of us have already agreed on a comprehensive approach as the European response.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: I announce that seven motions for resolutions have been received in accordance with Article 123(2), the vote will take place tomorrow and we are closing the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. – A previous speaker said that IS must be defeated militarily. Yes, but ideas cannot be defeated by military means alone. The root cause of the problem is an ideological one at the heart of the Islamic religion, and it can only be won by moderate Muslims overcoming the extremists. The first step in doing so is for moderate Muslims to reject those religious texts in the Qur’an that encourage or excuse violence. For example: ‘Kill infidels wherever you find them. Make war on infidels. Strike terror into the hearts of infidels’. Moderate Muslims know very well that in the eyes of the fundamentalist extremists they too qualify as ‘infidels’ as much as the unbelievers. The moderate Muslims of the world have a vested interest in bringing their religion into the modern world. The savages of IS will still be savages but their spurious ideological justifications for violence and bestiality must be removed. That can only be done when their fellow Muslims remove the ideological ground from under their feet.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. We are facing the most serious humanitarian crisis since the end of the Second World War. According to the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, more than three million Syrians have fled the civil war. This is a desperate situation to which we must respond ly and without hesitation. The European Union must make every effort to coordinate its neighbours in Syria and Iraq, in order to work together to coalesce against IS, and not to bring the Middle East into the dinghy of barbarism.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. The Syrian crisis is a political Ebola. It infects and kills and the vaccine is not found. It has already caused 220,000 deaths since 2011, 3.2 million refugees. There is no humanitarian crisis greater than the Syrian one in terms of heartyness, it is genocide Financial aid never seems to be enough. I very much welcome the new global strategy presented by High Representative Federica Mogherini for Syria and Iraq. Let us hope that these new funds will really be used for Syrians and Iraqis in difficulty, where difficulties means starving, suffering atrocious violence, living under siege. Let us not forget that migrant hell often begins in Syria and ends dramatically in the Mediterranean. Tragedies that are repeated and seem to have no end.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. Last week, I spent five days in Iraq with the international aid organization Aid to the Church in Need. We visited half a dozen refugee camps on the ground, where we met many families displaced from their homes. We know that the situation caused by the Islamic State is extremely complicated. Yet it is very clear what we Europeans need to do. The international community must do its best to allow refugees to return to their homeland as soon as possible. Based on what we have seen on the ground, I know that this requires a huge joint effort. I personally trust that Mrs Mogherini will do her utmost to increase the humanitarian engagement of the Union and the Member States. Given the seriousness of the crisis, we must also see, unfortunately, that peace cannot be made in northern Iraq without a military solution. If Europe and international organisations cannot succeed in providing assistance, we face a very serious, even irreversible, humanitarian catastrophe in the region. I trust that we will have the strength to do so, together with the local communities: Muslims, Christians or Yazids. We must preserve a 2,000-year-old Christian culture in the Middle East, which is now in danger of being completely eradicated.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The atrocities committed by Da'esh have caused real humanitarian crises in Syria and Iraq. Ethnic and religious cleansing, executions, persecution, abductions, forced conversions, enslavement of children and women, torture, are some examples of the heinous crimes perpetrated by Da'esh. These crimes against humanity cannot go unpunished. We Europeans must help to extinguish these hotbeds of extremism, which pose a threat to the security of the entire region, but also to the security of the whole world. In particular, we must act to stop the flow of foreign fighters who leave every day to join the ranks of this terrorist organization. We must also strengthen our security cooperation with our partners within the framework of the neighbourhood policy and in the Euro-Arab framework. Finally, we must strengthen our humanitarian assistance to the civilian population.  I the for example, I welcome the overall strategy presented by the Commission and the High Representative on 6 February to provide an additional EUR 1 billion for the financing of the many political, social and humanitarian initiatives under way, aimed at combating the threat posed by Da'esh.

name: James Nicholson (ECR)
text: in writing. – The advance of ISIS over the past number of months has shocked the world as we see the group commit some of the most extreme barbaric acts of terror. The rise of ISIS has compounded an already desperate humanitarian situation in Iraq and Syria, both devastated by years of civil war and sectarian violence. Millions in Iraq and Syria have been displaced as ISIS makes advances – adding to those who have already been displaced as a result of the Syrian civil war. In both countries, civilians are inevitably caught up in ISIS violence – from forced conversions to brutal executions. ISIS terrorists are being targeted in both countries by a US-led coalition, though air-strikes have not done enough to eradicate the threat. The UK Government is supporting international efforts to combat the ISIS threat and the UK Parliament has voted in support of air strikes against ISIS targets in Iraq. Another deeply troubling element to the ISIS threat is the number of British and other EU nationals who have been radicalised and have chosen to join with ISIS and fight in Iraq and Syria. This poses a major domestic security threat if or when such ‘foreign fighters’ return home.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission, the High Representative, on the situation in Yemen (2015/2557(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, honourable Members, I am grateful for the opportunity to discuss the situation in Yemen with you today. Yemen occupies a strategic position along the Gulf of Aden and the Red Sea. Every day, hundreds of ships headed to Europe pass through the Bab-el-Mandeb strait. Terrorist organisations like al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) increasingly represent a direct threat to European citizens. It is in our own interest to stand by the aspirations of the Yemeni people for a stable and accountable state, preserving the territorial integrity of the country. When we look back four years ago, Yemen initiated a remarkable transition process, with people taking to the streets calling for dignity, social justice, and their legitimate political and socio-economic rights. Ever since, the EU has stood by Yemen and its people, fully supporting its demands for democratic legitimacy, accountable and participatory public institutions, and a better life for all. Yemenis look to the EU to continue supporting their aspirations, at a moment when the promises of the ‘Arab uprisings’ are in danger of being forgotten. Today, Yemen’s transition is at grave risk. Its daring economic and fiscal difficulties and persisting security challenges are now coupled with the danger that expeditious solutions might lead the country to more turmoil and to the collapse of state authority. The intensification of terrorist attacks in Yemen, including by al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP), cannot be left unchecked. We condemn such terrorist attacks in the strongest terms and reiterate our firm commitment and enduring support to the efforts of the Yemeni authorities and of the international community to tackle terrorist violence, in Yemen and the broader region. Terrorists can only benefit from the weakening of state authority in Yemen. The last two weeks have proved decisive for the balance of power in Sana’a, with what some would qualify as the final takeover of state institutions by the Houthis after the seizure of the Presidential Palace. In response to what they deemed unacceptable pressure on the Executive, the President and the entire Cabinet of Prime Minister Bahah resigned on 22 January, de facto putting the whole Yemeni transition in jeopardy. We consider that the so-called constitutional declaration unilaterally issued by the Houthis last Friday has no legitimacy. We now call on all political forces, in particular the Houthis, to take clear responsibility for their actions, starting by unequivocally rejecting violence and coercion as political tools. Undermining state institutions will only result in further instability, to the detriment of all Yemenis. The attacks on officials and the restriction on the movements of President Hadi, Prime Minister Bahah and a number of other Ministers are clearly unacceptable. But current developments should not be seen in isolation. They are partly the result of initial flaws in the design of the transition – which largely kept traditional power structures untouched. Inaction and lack of resolve on the part of the Executive and traditional political parties, and enduring attempts to undermine the transition process by spoilers, chiefly led by ex-President Saleh, have also been key factors in leading Yemen to the current impasse. There is no other way out of the current crisis than genuine dialogue and an inclusive political process, and we hope that the announcement of the resumption of broad consultations between Yemeni parties under the auspices of the UN on Monday will bear fruit. Any long-term solution should address the underlying causes of instability, which are deeply rooted in local historical and socio-economic power-structure. The real test case will be whether Yemeni parties are ready to work together constructively to foster a compromise, safeguarding the transition’s objectives. We also call on all regional actors to contribute positively to this process.  It is critical for the international community to retain its unity, in order to safeguard the foundations of the Yemeni transition and restore stability, while preserving Yemen’s territorial integrity. It is our belief that the framework provided by the Gulf Cooperation Council Initiative, the outcomes of the National Dialogue Conference (NDC) and the Peace and National Partnership Agreement should remain the reference points for the Yemeni transition. We therefore urge all actors to work constructively towards a swift finalisation of a new constitution. This constitution should meet the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people, reflect the NDC outcomes, and preserve the unity and territorial integrity of Yemen, to which the EU is strongly attached. While undergoing dramatic developments in its political transition and facing security threats, Yemen also urgently needs to tackle its economic situation. The government of Prime Minister Bahah had presented a solid programme in this regard, and a number of courageous steps had been taken to conclude an agreement with the IMF – in particular as regards lowering the fiscal burden represented by fuel subsidies. Decisive actions are needed to improve fiscal sustainability and fight corruption in the public administration, in support of those most in need.  The severe humanitarian crisis may further deepen if political stability is not restored. Almost 16 million Yemenis (more than 60% of the total population) are currently in need of humanitarian aid, including 10.6 million suffering food insecurity and 13.4 million without access to safe water and sanitation. Widespread consumption of and addiction to qat – a mildly narcotic leaf – has a disastrous impact on water use, labour productivity, health and the crowding-out of food crops. EU humanitarian assistance in 2014 reached EUR 124 million (including also EUR 33 million from the Commission). And the EU is committed to continue its support for the Yemeni people. It is essential that all parties safeguard humanitarian principles and ensure humanitarian access on the ground. Ladies and gentlemen, the EU stands by the Yemeni people at this critical juncture and reaffirms its commitment to continue supporting Yemen in its transition.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, I was a member of the European Parliament delegation that visited Sana'a in May 2012: it was a period of optimism about the political transition. The solution, which was negotiated after ten months of protests and resulted in the departure of former President Saleh - with impunity - and the coming to power of President Hadi, then the national dialogue and finally a transitional government, led us to believe that stability was guaranteed in Yemen.  Some even said that the negotiated Yemeni-style transition could serve as a model for other Arab countries. In recent weeks, there has been no need for optimism in Sana'a, because it is the opposite of the result expected two or three years ago. What we are seeing is that the model has not paid off, and some even say that the transition has completely failed in Yemen, because the violence developed by the armed wing of the Houthis shows us that now everything is turned upside down: there is no longer any legitimate authority in Sana'a and we are confused by this terrible spiral of violence.  The obvious solution: everything has to go through a political approach, a constitutional referendum, the holding of elections and a genuine political dialogue that is inclusive: this has always been the European point of view.  I would like to end with a more general remark. It is again a Shiite offensive, a movement that wants to make it seem that a revolution, that an upheaval of the state of things is possible, but we know it very well from experience: Shiite offensives lead to long-term instability.

name: Richard Howitt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, whether we call what has happened in Yemen a coup or not, those now in government have called themselves a revolutionary council and, of course, there are deep concerns about the role of Iran. Nevertheless, Europe must maintain lines of communication and support the UN-led mediation efforts. The alternatives are worse. Clearly, this morning’s news of the closure of the British and other embassies is a further potent sign of the failure of the rule of law in the country. It is only a month since in this chamber we gave a memorial for the Charlie Hebdo attack, and we should recall how responsibility for it was claimed by al-Qaida in Yemen. This is a country where we all need to have some humility. I remember Baroness Ashton in this Chamber saying Yemen was the model for the EU’s comprehensive strategy. President Obama called it a model for the United States counter-terrorism strategy. I know diplomats who say we have devoted considerable help to Yemen but not sufficiently to enable the domestic government to have the capacity to deliver on the reform aspirations of its people. In 2012 I was with Mr Preda and I went and sat in the tents in Sana’a’s Freedom Square, listening to the hopes of the young protestors. I have heard the Yemeni children saying that they have nightmares about the sound of drone attacks – the same stories my own mother told me about the V2 bombs from the Second World War – and I wonder whether the existing efforts are truly countering terrorism or are instead in danger of fuelling it. Today we are looking at what increasingly threatens to be another failed state, and the lessons of Yemen are twofold. First, we must make the right diplomatic responses now to do all we can to avoid the country sliding down even further. But second, if we want to protect our own people and promote our own principles, where reform is under way in the Arab world, we have to do more and better to support it when we can. The failures of a failed state are our failures too.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In one of the least developed countries in the world, with huge areas of poverty (which indeed had huge prospects for development despite great terrorist influences), very drastic reforms need to be introduced very carefully. The abolition of fuel subsidies without immediate social cover appears to have been one of the breeding ground for the Houthi insurgency. It is true that we must unite at the moment. It is true that dialogue should be conducted under the auspices of the United Nations. However, we need to think about the sensible implementation of world trade organisation membership requirements, and at the moment we must take into account that instead of positive development, we have a country in Yemen that poses one of the most serious threats to global security.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Yemen has been a faithful indicator of general trends in the region, from the country's independence to the attempt to establish a socialist state, authoritarian reunification in 1990 or the Arab Spring.  Now, after the Huthis took on Sana, we are facing the end of the Arab Spring experiment, which in this country involved the expansion, reinforcement of Al Qaeda, a disastrous campaign of unmanned aerial vehicle attacks by the United States and the breakdown of the Yemeni state and its army. The United States, France and the United Kingdom have ordered the evacuation of their embassies, but I would like to advise that we do not draw hasty conclusions. The question is not who has the power in the capital and whether it is one of our own. The question we must ask ourselves is whether the one who receives our support is one that promotes stability outside of factionalisms, sectarianisms or integrism.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I welcome the fact that the Foreign Affairs Council is dealing with the situation in Yemen. The conclusions contain key requirements. The house arrest imposed by the Houthi rebels on the resigned president and members of his cabinet is unacceptable. It is now crucial to step up efforts towards political dialogue, because it is only through negotiation that a lasting solution can be achieved. It is necessary to involve all relevant actors. The problem, however, is that the Council's conclusions on the failure of the transition process do not identify a central cause, namely impunity, which has prevailed for years. It is a key contributor to Yemen's instability and must therefore also be identified as a central cause of the conflict. Several people died in protests in Yemen in 2011 and 2012, when former President Salih handed over power to Vice President Hadi. In return, Salih received extensive immunity from prosecution for crimes he was responsible for during his reign. Although Hadi ordered the establishment of a commission of inquiry into human rights violations committed during the uprisings, it was never established. One consequence of absolute impunity was that Salih and his supporters were able to continue to exert considerable influence, thus hindering the transition process. That is why it is important, what the EU is now doing, to revisit these reform initiatives and also to support the UN in them.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the situation in Yemen is particularly dire, with today’s news that the US, France and the UK have all closed their embassies over major security concerns. The recent coup d’état is one further event in a long line of political crises stretching back decades. Protests led by the Southern Democratic Assembly, who seek an independent, Aden-led South Arabia, have remained peaceful, despite further violence breaking out across the country. I believe it vital to support their democratic aspirations for self-determination to help secure a safe, sovereign area in this crucially important strategic point. What the region needs now, more than ever – just like across the Gulf of Aden in Somaliland – is a beacon of hope to show what proud moderates and globally-engaged people can achieve. In South Arabia and Somaliland we can have that possibility.

name: Georg Mayer (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his Just one thing in advance: I come from the Styrian parliament. For example, it was forbidden to read from the paper, as a colleague has done before. That would perhaps help us here too. But one thing is that a new black hole is open in one of the poorest countries in the world. As if we didn't have enough black holes and as if we didn't have enough problem areas on this earth, we're seeing that now in Yemen. The situation has changed dramatically since January. The situation has far-reaching effects on us Europeans, too and above all, of course. Let us take the illusion, ladies and gentlemen, that at the end of the day we will be able to take in all the refugees from Arabia and from the problem areas of the world! From now on, you can be sure, Yemen is of particular interest to all sorts of terrorist organisations that are playing there. This example of Yemen is once again a prime example of how harmful and to the detriment of Europe any American interference in all parts of the world is. This is particularly true of Ukraine.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D). -
text: Mr President, today, 11 February, marks the fourth anniversary of the uprising of the Yemeni people demanding their rightful democratic and civil state. The recent violence and illegal takeover by Houthi militants and the resignation of the Executive threatened the territorial integrity of the country and the stability of the region, making an already dire humanitarian situation worse. Sixty-nine percent of the population rely on some form of humanitarian aid. These problems are likely to intensify as the instability continues. All parties, especially the Houthi movement who are now in control, must return to genuine dialogue and inclusive negotiations. They must take clear responsibility for their actions, rejecting violence and oppression as political tools.  Only a broad political consensus can provide a sustainable solution to the current crisis, and security is an essential prerequisite for the success of the transition. All parties need to cooperate to protect civilians and show immediate and unhindered humanitarian access on the ground. Sadly, although the EU is the leading humanitarian aid donor it plays a minor diplomatic role in Yemen. This must change. Outside power must stop fuelling violence by equipping and funding armed groups. The EU must facilitate the process of state-building in Yemen, promote the political dialogue and democratic reform and help in improving the security situation. We must stand by the people of Yemen at this critical juncture.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, we are obliged to remain engaged within this region and we are obligated to the people of Yemen for three main reasons. Firstly, as ever, it is worth remembering that the problems of today are rooted in the legacy of empire – in Yemen’s case toxic legacies of the Ottoman and British Empires. Secondly, it is the right thing to do. There is a humanitarian disaster where we can assist the UN’s efforts. If we do not, I do not see anybody else stepping up to the plate in any serious way to state-build. Thirdly, if we do not, Yemen will continue even more to become a breeding ground for radicalisation and terrorism against each other and indeed against us.  The fact is that, despite our fairly recent efforts as a European Union, Yemen is not a functioning state. It is this failure of corruption and failure to provide basic services that has so disenfranchised and disengaged the people of Yemen and we must continue to engage in state building. It is not as though we do not have the expertise and resources to that. We have put forward a number of ideas with this. We must be in for the long haul. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Smith, as someone who seeks independence for your own nation from a bigger United Kingdom, do you understand the aspirations of the South Arabian people who seek – after such distress and this long history of being in a situation where a largely Sunni part of the Yemen is currently under the control of a new Shia group – do you understand, actually, that perhaps independence might be a good option for South Arabia here?

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – I certainly do support independence for Scotland because I can speak on behalf of the people of Scotland in this Chamber and a substantial proportion of Scotland. I think it is dangerous to say that that logic applies to every place in every circumstance, and international law is really quite clear that we deal with these matters, on their merits, according to the reality on the ground. I myself am fairly relaxed about constitutional change but that must be managed by the international community peacefully and democratically achieved, and with the support of precisely those organisations like the European Union which must engage in state-building, because the problem that we have in Yemen is rooted in the fact that the people of Yemen see nothing in Sana’a, or indeed any other capital that they are looking to, to actually support them.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the third millennium, the millennium of proxy wars and the hypocrisy of the so-called international community. We have fallen into the middle of a catastrophe since a supposed democratic transition. The Yemen model is now a distant memory, indeed it is about to be a new Syria, yet another piece of the mosaic of violence in the Middle East. We too have our responsibilities, because in the great game of the Middle East, of this region, the clash between Iran and Saudi Arabia and allies for supremacy on the regional chessboard continues. It takes place in Sana'a, but also takes place in Beirut, Baghdad and Damascus. The great powers continue to bet on both sides, moving somewhat casually according to the circumstances, and in the meantime the local populations involved are only defeated, sacrificed and forgotten pawns without anyone having the courage to acknowledge that it is merely a deliberate instability aimed at rewriting the balance of power. Perhaps someone in the Gulf will be tempted to liquidate it by dividing Yemen into northern Yemen and southern Yemen, but that will certainly not be the right solution, and in the meantime in our silence the contenders are being heavily armed pending the decisive confrontation. We must not choose which faction we like the most, but defend the only faction and the only victim: the civilian population. It is not enough to help refugees, we must also eradicate this disease, this perverse game of proxy wars. That is why in the Houthi-Salafist conflict, the great game between Tehran and Riyadh, we must take action and be very tough on those who finance and arm the two factions, whoever they are, and I repeat whoever they are. Because as long as we tolerate sectarian wars out of interest, we ourselves are also adherents of sectarianism.

name: Mario Borghezio (NI). -
