text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the total chaos of Yemen, the news of the closure of several Western embassies is a couple with another shortly before the Houthi leader's statement to announce a presidential council, which is in fact a revolutionary council, which should create a new Parliament, a new Constitution. You don't understand anything about the situation. There is only one thing that is very clear: the failure of Western policies and, in particular, the absolute inconsistency of Eu ropean Union policy. The blah blah contained in the statements by the foreign ministers recently meeting on this very issue is also nothing concrete. We continue to talk freely about human rights, but we fail to make an impact, we fail to realise that Yemen is the most significant example of a process of division often carried out by violently opposed militias in various Arab countries, with the establishment of sub-state areas and Community-type agglomerations. It is a total revolution, in the face of which there is the absence of European policy. Europe is not understanding anything that is happening in these countries.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D). -
text: Mr President, by all accounts the international community, or at the very least the western powers, are closing up shop in Yemen. Today the American Embassy officially closed in Sana’a. The British Embassy has followed suit and a few hours ago the French Embassy also announced that it would close for security reasons. It is a well-known fact that Yemen has been a hotbed of insurgency and terrorist training for many years but now events are coming to a crescendo. The Houthi have taken the capital and effectively it is a coup d’état. Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula remains as active as ever throughout Yemen. Yemen is truly revealed to be not only a failed state, but a failed state with no one to turn to except perhaps Iran, Saudi Arabia or Al-Qaeda, depending on which partisan group wins the ongoing power battle.  The European Union must stand ready to take up even greater responsibilities in the Yemen crisis. A closed embassy always leaves a vacuum in its place – a vacuum for the European Union, and we must do what we can to fill it.  I therefore ask both the Commission and the Council what concrete steps will be taken in the EU to put pressure on the Houthi and to help guide the Yemeni people towards a path of political stability? What initiative will be enacted to ensure that Yemen does not sink further into civil partisan warfare?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI). -
text: On January 22nd, with the resignation of the Western-backed president of the government, Hadi, and the seizure of power by Houthi rebels, a civil war that has lasted since 2004 ended in Yemen. But there is a danger that hostilities will continue in the form of a conflict between the Sunnis who supported President Hadi and the Shiites who support the Huthi. The situation in Yemen is logical to raise concerns in the European Union, because that country, in addition to the strategic importance of its geographical location, is also considered the centre of al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula. That is why, in the past, American aircraft, in cooperation with government forces, bombed al-Qaeda positions. Now that these attacks may stop, there is a risk that al-Qaeda will be strengthened and a large part of the Sunni population will end up with extreme Islamists. We also have a humanitarian crisis: 77,000 people are refugees in their country and many children are being used as soldiers. The West, the European Union, must ensure that stability is given to the region and at the same time that it does not allow terrorists to infiltrate the European Union in the form of refugees.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, it is with deep concern that we note the developments in Yemen, and with the UK and US and other Western nations withdrawing their missions from Yemen, I think the situation is set to get worse.  This week we also heard from a former CIA director that Al-Qaeda in the Arab Peninsula is even bigger than IS, and AQAP is making fast progress on a technological front. Therefore, when the EU Heads of State or Government discuss counter-terrorism tomorrow they need to include measures that increase coordination of intelligence amongst us, with respect to Yemeni Al-Qaeda, and have a plan for concrete action to support UN-sponsored national dialogue and support building a stronger state.  It is also important that we do not just get a dialogue with a single interlocutor at the cost of inclusiveness. Failure to have all the groups on board is why we are where we are in Yemen today. I ask why the talks that began on Monday are already faltering; this indicates the gravity of the task ahead of us.  \*(The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the My question to Neena Gill is whether she believes that the Gulf Cooperation Council can play a role in this area, and what role would be appropriate for the GCC here.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you Mr Rübig – absolutely. It is only time that prevented me from mentioning the GCC. I think it is important that, along with the national dialogue, we also include the GCC, so I think the more players that are involved, the greater the possibility that we could find some kind of possible solution.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D). -
text: Mr President, in fact I am addressing the Council about the tremendously difficult situation of Yemen, a country which is falling into chaos and where different regions are breaking away from each other. This is a hugely difficult situation, taking into consideration the new training bases operated by Al-Qaeda and Daesh in Yemen. At the same time, we are seeing a new situation where the Shia are taking power in Yemen – the Houthis. This probably could fuel the support of Saudi Arabia for the Sunni tribes in Yemen. Finally, we might see a new situation, as happened in Iraq when a new government in Iraq could not – or would not – do the right thing to approach the Sunni tribes in order to establish a national way for the country.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: Mr President, honourable colleagues, respectable audience, Yemen is a classic case, a classic example of a failed state. A failed state like Somalia, a failed state as Iraq already is, as Syria already is. Where there are failed states, there is the rise of radical Sunni terrorism. Such are the Boko Haram militias, such is the Mujahideen Al Shabaab militia, such as al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, located in Yemen.  This is also the real threat to statehood in Yemen, this is the real threat to both the European Union and European civilization. Since the terrorist organization located in Yemen, as you can see, has the opportunity to organize combat attacks, it has the opportunity to operate on the territory of the European Union. This must be addressed by the European Union. This terrorist organization must be controlled in order to have peace.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE). -
text: Mr. President, we know what we want, we know what we won't, but unfortunately we often don't know how. This has happened to us on a number of occasions and unfortunately, especially when we talk about the Arab world, in a way we get into a situation where we just don't know how.  We are talking about many aspects of the crisis in Yemen, political, security, but again unfortunately we are also talking about the humanitarian aspect of the situation in Yemen. Of course, unresolved political crises, political situations, will put us back in a situation where this anguish we have in Yemen today turns into something that will threaten our strategic and security interests.  Therefore, I call on the Commission, I call on the Council and call on our allies to really resolve the situation in Yemen as soon as possible, as we will have the situation again as in many other even worse and crisis countries than Yemen is today.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have moved from Yemen, which was a model for the West in the fight against Al Quaeda, an independent Yemen, a socialist Yemen, to a Yemen that has descended into chaos. We are talking, as many of my fellow Members have said, about a failed state, a state that is in danger of falling into the hands of terrorism. We are even talking about a Yemen in which western embassies are in danger of being closed. In between were the Arab Spring and the wind of the Houtists who took power over the city of Sana'a and behind it was, as my colleague Mr Castaldo rightly said, the proxy war. It remains to be understood what position Iran and Saudi Arabia have in this situation in Yemen – and I believe that this is our subject for discussion – and how they are making other countries descend into chaos. It is clear that we should seek a diplomatic response, but the problem is as if we are not going to talk to the right interlocutors.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the very serious situation in Yemen, which has been plunged into a political vacuum in recent days, is of deep concern. The country has always been a stronghold of Al-Qaeda, split between a Sunni majority and a substantial Shiite minority. It is now on the brink of civil war and in general chaos, where Al-Qaeda extremists find fertile ground. The UNITED Nations Security Council has expressed concern about the situation in Yemen, while many countries are discussing the possibility of closing diplomatic posts as a result of the situation of uncertainty and insecurity in the country. In this situation, a collapsing political system weighs, which does not allow escape routes to the whirlwind of poverty, and the tensions that have been going on in recent days further aggravate an already tragic situation, making it difficult for humanitarian workers to reach the population as well. Europe should be able to foresee and intercept humanitarian and political crises of this magnitude that could also have unforeseeable consequences. Europe cannot shirk its role and must make its voice heard, but in practice.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, I very much welcome the discussion we have just had, particularly at this critical juncture, where the very existence of Yemen as we know it is under threat. The coming weeks and months will be decisive in showing in which direction Yemen is heading. We will monitor developments very closely. I know that our views and analysis of the situation coincide. The EU has no other option but to stay engaged in support of Yemen and its transition. As we have said before, Yemen’s failure would pose a direct threat to the EU, to our allies and to a broader stability in an already troubled region. When we come to answer Mr Kofod’s question, I would like to stress that the European Union can only play a useful role if it works closely with the regional partners, namely the Gulf countries and Saudi Arabia, and with the United Nations. Four years ago, Yemenis courageously took to the streets to end the three-decade long rule of President Saleh and called for dignity, accountability and security. The process initiated in 2011 led to an inclusive consultative process, resulting in remarkable and unprecedented recommendations. Yemen has to fulfil the promises of its transition. Yemen, the region and the international community cannot afford failure or the disintegration of the Yemeni state, and the EU will continue to stand by Yemen.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The debate has been closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. – Yemen is an unneglectable actor in the geopolitical equation of the Middle East. The transition in Yemen has failed, and the political process has fallen victim to competition between the elites. All political forces, especially the Houthis, must take responsibility for their actions and reject violence and coerciveness as political tools. Only a broad political consensus within the main political groups, setting a real path towards a constitutional referendum and free elections, can provide a lasting solution to the current crisis. It is necessary for all parties to establish a real dialogue and participate in intense negotiations in order to contribute to a swift completion of a new Constitution that responds to the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: We move on to the next item, namely the Council and Commission statements on the EU framework for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. In this regard, let me again invite Secretary Kalniρa-Lukaševica to speak for the Council (2015/2558(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - We have a very important debate tonight. The Union is founded on values including respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy and the rule of law. These are the common values of the Member States, and they are an essential element of the European Union’s identity. Member States have to ensure that their internal orders fully respect the rule of law and other fundamental values. The Commission, Parliament and the Council play an important role in safeguarding these essential principles. We recognise that the European Parliament plays an important role in making sure that the Commission and the Council carry out their duties. As you may recall, in June 2013 the Council stated that respecting the rule of law is a prerequisite for the protection of fundamental rights and called on the Commission to take forward the debate in line with the Treaties on the possible need for and shape of a collaborative and systematic method to tackle these issues. The same month, this Parliament called on the EU institutions to develop the necessary EU tools to fulfil the Treaty obligations on fundamental values. The Commission contributed to this debate by means of a communication in March 2014. These initiatives complemented the already-existing tools: the infringement procedure applicable in the case of a breach of EU law, and the ‘atomic bomb’ option provided by Article 7 of the Lisbon Treaty, which allows for the suspension of voting rights in the event of a serious and persistent breach of EU values. The Council discussed on several occasions how to better safeguard the rule of law in the Union. In December last year the Council adopted conclusions establishing an annual political dialogue among Member States to promote and safeguard the rule of law within the EU. The dialogue will respect certain principles such as objectivity, non-discrimination and equal treatment. It will also respect the principle of conferred competences, and it will have to ensure an inclusive approach. This exercise will have to be based on mutual trust. The Presidency will play a central role in making sure that these principles are respected throughout the debate. Right now the Council is working towards organising its first political debate on the rule of law in the course of this year. I am convinced that this dialogue will help us to ensure that the rule of law will continue to be a commonly-shared fundamental value underpinning this Union. I thank you for your attention and am looking forward to a really good debate.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, the clearest way to show what the rule of law means to us in everyday life is to recall what has happened when there is no rule of law. When President Eisenhower marked the first Law Day with these words in 1958, World War II had been over for barely a dozen years. The memories were raw, the images and the fear etched into minds. It has now been 70 years. We commemorated the liberation of the terror camps in this very Hemicycle when we last met in January. President Schulz and I were at Terezin only two weeks ago. Seventy years, yet the alarming backdrop to this anniversary – not just the headlines but also the trends, the patterns that we see – this backdrop has come as a harsh, sobering call for vigilance. This is why I welcome this timely debate. This House’s vigilance on fundamental rights is of utmost importance. We cannot let our societies imperceptibly slip back. We cannot allow illiberal logics to take hold. There is no such thing as ‘illiberal democracy’. Our Union is built on a break from the past, on the principle that societies should be free and open, sheltered from arbitrariness and force. This great leap: that is what Europe stands for. All too often we take all of this for granted. So I cannot repeat it often enough. There can be no Europe without full respect for our common values. Compromising on common values is compromising on the very fabric of European cooperation and therefore weakening it and bringing it to a standstill. The Commission is dedicated to advancing fundamental rights and the rule of law. I have been entrusted by President Juncker with a duty of special significance – and of huge significance to me personally: that of steering and coordinating this work. It is everyday work: mainstreaming fundamental rights is a reflex throughout the policy cycle, from inception to implementation. Together with Commissioners Jourová and Avramopoulos we form a fundamental rights project team, and I will invite other Commissioners to join if necessary. Our aim is to pursue with a 360-degree approach to ensure that fundamental rights are effectively enforced and protected in Member States, based on information gathered on the ground. I am well aware that this House has on different occasions called for an effective and binding instrument supplementary to Article 7. We can clearly all agree on the aim behind these calls, ensuring our common values are fully respected and enforced. The key issue for discussion is that of the best means to achieve this objective. To me, all institutions have important, complementary roles to play. Last December the Council and the Member States agreed to establish an annual dialogue to that effect, and I believe that our debate today serves very much the same purpose. The Commission has its own role, and in line with the Treaties, in recent years it has taken firm action by exerting political pressure, but also by successfully involving the Court of Justice when the rule of law was threatened, for instance on the unlawful retirement of judges or on measures affecting the independence of supervisory authorities. Our approach to infringements pays special attention to rule-of-law-related cases, where implementation of EU legislation raises problems of compatibility with certain aspects of the rule of law. This includes, for example, the right to an effective remedy before a tribunal, or cases where enforcement bodies have insufficient powers or independence. Since December what we call the ‘ex-Third Pillar’ measures in police and judicial cooperation can also be subject to infringement procedures, and here, too, the Commission is ready to take action. I will personally see to it that the Commission acts in a non-ideological manner and assesses each case fairly and objectively, based on the facts of the case and on the law. The Commission will act impartially and treats all Member States equally.  Our purpose is not to sanction individual Member States per se, but rather to address issues through targeted intervention to restore the correct application of EU law. Article 7 provides for potentially far-reaching sanctions. It is not limited in scope to areas covered by EU law, but rather designed to address clear risks of a serious breach. However, past experience has shown that this instrument, which can be triggered by the Commission, the European Parliament or one third of Member States, is not always suited to swift and effective intervention. In particular, there are situations which do not fall under the scope of EU law and cannot be said to meet the threshold of Article 7, but which do raise concern regarding the respect of the rule of law in particular Member States. For this reason, last March the Commission established the EU Rule of Law Framework, which sets out how the Commission will react in this sort of case. It can enter into a political dialogue with the Member State concerned when there is an emerging systematic threat to the rule of law, to prevent it escalating further. When such a rule-of-law crisis emerges in a Member State, the framework also allows the Commission to react swiftly, following an objective assessment of the situation and with full respect to the principle of equal treatment of Member States. The objective is to find a solution with the Member State concerned and to avoid having to trigger the mechanisms of Article 7. Parliament will have an important political role in supporting the Commission’s efforts to convince the Member State concerned to put an end to the rule-of-law crisis. Parliament would be regularly informed of the progress made at each stage of the process. We are keeping a close eye on all issues arising in Member States relating to the rule of law, and I will not hesitate to use the framework if required by the situation in a particular Member State. Let me also use this occasion to address a related issue. Many of you may also wonder about the state of play concerning EU accession to the European Convention on Human Rights, following the opinion of the Court of last December. Accession to the ECHR remains a top priority for the Commission and for me personally. I strongly believe that it would lead to a further strengthening of fundamental values. However, the opinion of the Court has raised a number of significant challenges, and some of them are not easy to meet – which is why I believe we need a reflection period, giving us time for consultations with stakeholders on the best way forward. Though Parliament has welcomed the EU Rule Of Law Framework and the annual debate in the Council, I am aware that there are renewed calls to establish new additional mechanisms for the permanent and regular monitoring that the Member States comply with the EU fundamental rights. My conviction and policy has always been that, if current tools do not deliver, we will have to improve them. I am always ready to reflect on how to enhance respect for our values. However, before embarking on a long discussion on possible new instruments, we must be clear on the problem at stake. Can we say to our citizens that we need yet another monitoring mechanism to fight against radicalisation and extremism, or do we just need to better use the existing and recently-established tools? Experience has shown that there is not so much a need for new reporting or monitoring mechanisms, but rather for the improvement of the European Union’s capacity to act and intervene in certain types of crisis situations relating to the rule of law. That is why, in our view, the framework is well targeted on the key issue at stake, and much already exists in terms of reporting mechanisms and information sources on compliance with fundamental values and the rule of law in Member States. Numerous actors, including Union institutions and agencies – particularly the Fundamental Rights Agency (which, I must say, carries out excellent work) but also the Council of Europe and its Venice Commission, as well as many NGOs – all perform regular monitoring activities and make important assessments. Efforts to make this information more accessible and easier to use must certainly be encouraged. This is why I intend the Annual Colloquium on Fundamental Rights – this is something I announced in Parliament at my hearing – to take place in the autumn, in October or perhaps at the beginning of November. I want all relevant stakeholders – including, of course, Parliament – to take part. I would like to announce here today that I plan for the theme of this year’s Colloquium to be about tolerance, namely how to prevent and combat anti-Semitic, anti-Muslim, anti-Christian, and anti-minority hatred in our societies, which are some of the biggest challenges we face today. I hope that you will engage actively in this important event. I want it to be a visible and meaningful debate. Together, by speaking up and speaking jointly, we can send a powerful political message. I think that would also mean more to our citizens than a protracted institutional debate about mechanisms because, at the end of the day, this is about societies and what binds us together: how we can combat fear – numbing fear, paralysing fear, fear of the other. That is when our common values really have a meaning – what we owe to these values, to our own history, to the future for our children and grandchildren. This is the debate and the actions that citizens expect of us.

name: Daniel Buda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Jacques Chevalier defined the rule of law as the type of political regime in which the power of the state is framed and limited by law. The rule of law has been and will be a major concern of any modern society, which is why values such as human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, tolerance, security and more must be the common denominator in a united Europe, an open and secure Europe, which is permanently serving our citizens and businesses. These values have been and will be inalienable and imprescriptible. A strengthened Europe with strengthened Member States is a safety belt for everyone, regardless of their nationality, just as an independent and effective justice can stimulate business, investment and job creation. The existence of any slippage from these values is likely to create insecurity, which can affect our daily lives. Therefore, the existence of effective mechanisms to penalise any violations of individual fundamental rights and freedoms is absolutely necessary. All the more so because these values, which enshrine the rule of law, can be easily volatile and even democracies seen as consolidated. The European Union as a whole and Romania in particular have demonstrated that they have the capacity to create mechanisms and institutions capable of guaranteeing the security of the rule of law. The current monitoring system allows identification and intervention where infringements of European Union law are found at the level of each Member State. However, further collaboration between the European Parliament, the Member States, the Commission and the Council is needed to strengthen strategies in the field of justice, both at country level and at European Union level, as a guarantee of the functioning of the rule of law. ).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Thank you very much for the opportunity, Honourable Member, Mr Buda. I was very pleased with your speech, I can really identify with every word of it, as it is largely consistent, and I think it is completely consistent with what Mr Timmermans said. But I ask you respectfully that you say the same thing within your own people's party group to fidesz, which operates a government in Hungary whose leader is persistently talking about illiberal democracy. One that has been proven to send hundreds of judges into compulsory retirement for political reasons, and who has a proven record of appointing or holding office officials from troubled backgrounds.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: Answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – I believe that the discussion exists at the level of each group, after all what is happening in each country must be a concern of that country and, indeed, we must be careful at the level of the Commission and the Council to be careful that there are no slippages from democracy and, where they exist, intervene.

name: Birgit Sippel
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The rule of law and democracy are the foundations of the EU, and those who shake them are shaking up the European Union. Respect for European values is a legal obligation for all EU Member States, not only when they implement EU law, but always. Often, however, these values are disregarded, sometimes systematically. The lack of independence of the judiciary, the media, insufficient rights for parliamentary opposition, incitement against or exclusion of minorities are just a few examples. As Europeans, we must not stand by and watch only when fundamental values are so disregarded. On several occasions, therefore, the European Parliament has called for an independent committee of experts to monitor fundamental rights in all EU countries, which can act free of political influence. Neither the Council nor the Commission has been able to present convincing approaches. The recently decided annual lunches of the Member States on rule of law issues are certainly a good start, but they are not enough and, above all, are not a politically neutral and regular review of all Member States. The framework for the protection of the rule of law presented by the Commission also seems to be on paper. The European Parliament should be regularly informed of measures taken. This has not happened so far, either because nothing has taken place or because Parliament is not being informed. To sum up, after all the debates on fundamental rights in recent years, the Council and the Commission are now approaching the problem with triple steps. Okay, but it is not enough. We need the willingness of all Member States and the Commission to openly identify systematic violations of fundamental rights and, if necessary, to impose sanctions. That is our responsibility as representatives of a Union of values.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, our shared values of freedom, democracy and tolerance are, of course, the very foundations of Europe and this Union. Too often I think, though, this Parliament tries to quantify in a scientific way values which simply cannot be quantified. It has been my long experience in life that scoreboards, monitoring indicators and benchmarks often do little to reflect or alleviate the realities of any situation. I believe that instead of developing binding instruments to punish Member States and providing tools for political point-scoring, we should instead ask ourselves, ‘are such mechanisms the most appropriate vehicles for honest, frank and open discussions, and hopefully, therefore, solutions?’ What we need to do is to develop debate and action across the EU on how we can improve fundamental rights and the rule of law within our countries and how we can better, therefore, the lives of our citizens. This Parliament and the Commission should look at how it can help remove barriers to the job market, increase access for those with disabilities, eradicate discrimination against LGBTI persons, assist with social mobility, help create more jobs for young people and remove burdensome red tape from the economy and our businesses, so that Europe’s economy and opportunities for citizens can grow. Opportunities and economic progress in Member States is how you promote fundamental rights. A helping hand is always better than a scolding tongue. We are not each other’s masters, but instead we are each other’s partners. What we do not need are new ways to threaten each other. What we do need to do is to focus on better law-making, better implementation and better and positive ways of talking to one another.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I have to say that I am a bit disappointed because Commissioner Timmermans said that we do not need a protracted institutional debate about mechanisms. I think that is exactly what we need because the fundamental rights and the fundamental values that this Union is based on are laid down in Article 2 of the Treaties. It is the most important article. It is the highest article in the hierarchy and yet the enforcement of that article is the weakest of all the articles in the Treaty. I remember the debates about the eurozone. We said at the time that we did not need binding instruments in the eurozone, we have a gentleman’s agreement and all the Member States will simply have to live up to their commitments. Well, we have seen what that led to. I think it is about time that this European Union, which is developing into a political union, equips itself with the instruments to enforce those values that it is so proud of. We should not only be talking – not only words, no matter if they are in five or six languages – but we should have action in all the languages.  We do need binding instruments, not just conventions, not just silent diplomacy, colloquia – we need binding instruments. That is why my group, the ALDE Group, has proposed the Democratic Governance Pact. We have offered it to the Commissioner and we have debated it since. It can be adopted on the basis of existing treaties and would be similar to the Stability and Growth Pact. It would have similar mechanisms to ensure the enforcement of the values that are all dear to us. For example, we have devised one instrument – and I will show it to you, it looks like a bingo card, it is actually a scoreboard. We have scored all 28 Member States against a set of indicators, like freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, equal treatment, freedom of religion, etc. We have been nice and we have not put the names of the Member States here. I can only tell you that the ones with only green scores are Denmark and Sweden but the rest we will keep anonymous. If we did this exercise with Parliament, with the Council, the Commission and with the national parliaments every year – and here I take up your proposal for an annual debate simultaneously in all the institutions about the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in all Member States, because there I concur very much with the Commissioner – all Member States should be treated equally and should be scrutinised in the same way.  There would be no more debates about single Member States here, or indeed monitoring mechanisms for Bulgaria and Romania as we have them, or only the candidate Member States. No, all Member States should be scrutinised. We will scrutinise not just their budget. We will not talk only about debt and budget deficits but will also talk about the enforcement of our shared values and make the European Union a community of values.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Democracy and the fundamental rights on which the European Union is supposed to rely, in accordance with Article 2 of its founding Treaty, are now being challenged in practice by the institutions of the Union themselves. When the European Commission responds in writing to our question that fundamental rights do not apply within the framework of the Memorandums, this means that citizens of the Member States of the Union who are under the memorandum regime are treated as second-class Europeans and those states as debt colonies. When Commissioner Katainen also states unswerkly that we are not changing policy according to the results of the elections, this suggests contempt for democracy. The dictators of the 20th century prevented elections from being held using military force, while the postmodern authoritarianism of the European elites of the 21st century essentially attempts to annul the elections through economic blackmail. Europe needs a change of course.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Mr President, the Latvian Presidency explains once again that the Council has thought that they are having a conversation once a year about the state of fundamental rights in Europe. Mr Sippel called it a 'lunch', a 'lunch'. Commissioner Timmermans explains that he does not want to do his job ideologically and impartially as befits a real arbitrator. The only problem is that a referee referees in a game for which there are rules of the game. And they're missing here. You can't be impartial if you don't know what to hold on to. And why do we not yet have the rules of the game for a European test of fundamental rights? Because there is no political will. Because we always ask ourselves in this House whether we would like to play this politically? Do we dare to call the critter by its name? Do we dare to speak to our friends? And the answer to that is apparently no. But where we speak to each other about a budget deficit, we should also appeal to each other on respect for the free press, on freedom of association, on anti-discrimination, and that does not happen. It happens at the moment someone joins the football club, but as soon as someone is a member of the football club of 28 players, we say: you can cheat! Mr President, that is not possible. Nor can Commissioner Timmermans keep saying that we will get along with the existing rules. The existing rules are not applied because there is no political will in the Council and in this House. I actually expect you to take steps to do that. I expect the Latvian Presidency to have the courage to do an evaluation.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a considerable gap between legal recognition and the political application of fundamental rights. Despite the wording of Articles 2, 6 and 7 of the Treaty on European Union, the negative and disastrous effects of economic crises, austerity policies, illegal activities, such as corruption and various forms of crime, are still affected by the rights of millions of European citizens. The European Union urgently needs an internal strategy on fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law, so as to ensure consistency with the strategic framework already provided for in external relations. To date, there is no mechanism for effectively assessing and guaranteeing the protection and promotion of common European values, enshrined in European and national legislation. Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union has remained a dead letter and the alternative mechanism proposed to us by the Commission in its recent communication on the rule of law is by no means ambitious in preventing violations of the fundamental rights of the European Union. It is necessary to provide for effective and appropriate monitoring and intervention methods and the application of sanctions when violations of these rights occur. The institutions of the European Union, and in particular the Commission, therefore have a duty to ensure that all European policies are carefully analysed, in order to ensure that the Union does not contribute directly or indirectly to violations of fundamental rights on its territory.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE). -
text: Mr President, it has been said enough by a number of people today, but the rule of law is the foundation of our society and the rule of law is what binds us in Europe. It cannot be stressed enough, not only for our own citizens, but also for the credibility of the EU as a whole. When we talk to Member States, when we talk to people and countries with which we make partnerships, we conclude agreements, we will continue to insist on the rule of law. And rightly so, because without a functioning rule of law, democracy cannot function, no economy can function. That's why it's important that we keep preaching that outwardly – practice what you preach. We must ensure that we keep our own things in order. I am glad that you are here, Mr Timmermans, because two years ago, as Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands, you sent a letter to three of your colleagues on this subject urging you to do more within the EU on fundamental freedoms. A year later, about a year ago – and I would like to congratulate Mrs Viviane Reding on this too – a new framework for fundamental rights within the EU has been developed within the possibilities offered by the Treaty. My question to you, Commissioner Timmermans, is actually very simple: looking back on the letter you sent two years ago, looking back at the experience we have now a year after the Commission published its new communication on the framework for fundamental freedoms, you are satisfied with what is being done at the moment and there are opportunities within the current frameworks to do something more to ensure that all countries are , regardless of where they are in Europe, regardless of what kind of governments are in power, fundamental freedoms are at the top of the agenda?

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Vice-President Timmermans, intervention has been made in this European Parliament on many occasions to say that what began as a financial and economic crisis has become a social crisis as a result of the exasperation of inequalities. And finally, in a political and moral crisis as a result of the sense of injustice and hopelessness, which has been the breeding ground for populism, xenophobia and, ultimately, increasingly anti-European ideas, which call into question the state of the quality of democracy and fundamental rights in the European Union. I agree that the key to the vault of European construction is neither in deficit reduction nor debt control, but in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union, which points out the importance of foundational values: the rule of law, the dignity of the person, fundamental rights , representative democracy and respect for minorities. It must therefore be made quite clear that this fundamental rule of law and rights and the quality of democracy is declining in Europe because there are no mechanisms to ensure the effective implementation and assurance of these principles in the various Member States. It is the so-called 'Copenhagen dilemma': there are rigours in controlling access to the club, but from there is no control over maintaining the quality of democratic standards, protecting minorities and banning discrimination and persecution of these minorities in the European Union. The principles set out in the 2014 Commission Communication are not sufficient for us, nor in the dialogue between member states through the Council. We need , of course, I agree – to establish effective insurance mechanisms, and that is why we must establish an intermediate point between persuasion and infringement or, where appropriate, the imposition of sanctions provided for in Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union, which is virtually impossible to comply with. We need to find an intermediate path between persuasion and the infringement procedure or the sanctions provided for in Article 7, but above all, we need to know that democracy cannot be taken for granted or taken for granted. Democracy cannot be taken for granted in Europe.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR) -
text: I have a few words to say here, too, to my previous speakers on control and supervision. The Member States themselves are a natural space for the development of democracy and human rights. Each of them had to go through a demanding process and meet the so-called Copenhagen criteria. I believe that no one wants to question their own values. If we have any problems or shortcomings in the EU, let us try to have an open debate about them. I am concerned that strict control mechanisms and lessons will be applied to Member States. We know from our history that where the culture of debate ends, that is where the dictatorship of command begins. That is why I am also following with considerable concern some reactions in the EP in recent days regarding the Slovak referendum on the protection of the natural family. I expect tolerance and respect for freedom of expression from my colleagues here in the EP. I therefore ask: is anyone who has expressed their positive attitude towards the natural family a threat to democracy? Member States have sufficient mechanisms to ensure democracy and the protection of human rights. The European Commission should respect them. It is a space for citizens and states themselves to be able to make the right choices and do not need constant control over themselves. The European Parliament must respect the sovereignty of the Member States, not control them. Above all, it is intended to have a respectful dialogue instead of repression.  I therefore call for such an approach to be maintained in this document and for proposals to be sanctioned or addressed to Member States on behalf of some kind of vain proposals such as the 'little democratic process' and so on. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Congressman, I'm sorry. I am not surprised by what you said, because a few days ago you turned to members of the European Parliament in a circular in which you stood by the referendum in Slovakia condemning and discriminating against same-sex marriage. I must ask you, Congressman, how do you think that a discriminatory procedure against a minor can be brought into line with European fundamental rights. It is precisely that these fundamental rights must protect minorities. I would like to ask you why you think that these opinions are in line with the fundamental rights of the European Union.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the Blue Card – Of course, no minorities can be discriminated against, and it is also necessary to be clear about who the minorities are. So, everyone has basic human rights as defined in 1948, I don't know of any others. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Škripek, you were talking about values being imposed and about dictatorship, but is it not true that the referendum failed – fortunately I would say – because only 20% of people bothered to turn out? So that means that the vast majority of people in Slovakia show a lot more respect for LGBT people than you just suggested.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the Blue Card – Madam Colleague, it is fine how many people have come to the urns. The huge scathing anti-campaign that has been conducted has been very unfair and untrue, so I am first and foremost in my opposition to any pressure being exerted against a sovereign Member State, because there is an agreement that, in matters of ethics and conscience, every state, in internal issues relating to the family, for example, decides every state as it wants. Secondly, our referendum is an expression of the opinion of our citizens. I don't understand what you don't like about it.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul When a country wants to join the EU, we set very high standards. Among other things, one must respect fundamental rights and freedoms, one should be a functioning rule of law, a functioning democracy. But the problem arises once the country is a member of the EU. There is a lack of tools to monitor the continued respect of these criteria and we are faced with a fait accompli – the Copenhagen dilemma.  And we can list examples: Hungary, where media freedom is violated and the independence of the judiciary has been curtailed; Lithuania, which has adopted homophobic laws; Romania, which systematically discriminates against parts of its population, namely the Roma.  Today we impose sanctions on those Member States that do not respect economic agreements, but with human rights you can do almost anything. Now is the time for us to impose sanctions on countries that restrict civil rights, and we have seen examples. ALDE has a full scoreboard of these rights demonstrated by Sophia in 't Veld. Time to move from words to action. \*(The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – I would like to ask my previous speaker if she is aware that in Romania all national minorities have the opportunity to learn in their language and that Romania has been given as an example of respect for the rights of national minorities throughout Europe.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: answer ("blue card"). – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr If the Romanians speak their language at school, for those Romanians who are Roma and sit and beg outside our grocery stores and outside our post offices in Sweden. In my hometown of Uppsala, I counted last week 32 people at a few hundred meters in the city begging, literally in a snow drift, because they are systematically discriminated against in your home country.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, Mr Škripek’s words made me decide to focus on the issue of LGBTI rights and the fight against homophobia in this common Europe.  Mr Škripek, I was quite surprised. You mentioned there is pressure on the sovereign state, and you meant Slovakia, because of the referendum you held. Nobody pressured the Slovak government or the Slovak parliament to decide on a referendum on homophobia. You said there was a huge campaign against this referendum and that was not fair. Well, the pictures I saw, most of them, there was even the Pope that you used in order to support you.  I also had the chance to speak with Vice-President of the Commission Timmermans  recently: we really need an action plan, a road map against homophobia in our common Europe because we have infringement procedures for laws but we do not have something that helps LGBTI people to get their rights when it comes to information, for example. Lithuania has prohibited a book of fairy tales that shows LGBT people. We really need an implementation of that with mechanisms and monitoring mechanisms to make sure that LGBTI people have the right to live in freedom all over Europe.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE). -
text: It is certainly to be welcomed that, among the institutions of the European Union, the Council and the Commission want to address the problems of the rule of law in the Member States. Here in Parliament, we speak openly on a number of issues, but unfortunately experience so far has shown that the Commission has not addressed these issues in any meaningful way, citing a lack of competence. And the Council, composed of representatives of the Member States, has always been reluctant to take intoes an examination of specific cases. We must fight more and more for the trust of citizens, and the only way to be worthy of this trust is to speak openly and honestly about the problems.  When we talk about democracy and the rule of law, we must honestly look at those Member States where there are serious doubts about the rule of law. If we start a dialogue on fundamental rights, it is not only the positions of the Member States that need to be heard by the Council and the Commission, but also, for example, the complaints of indigenous national minorities that need to be taken seriously by EU bodies. Simply because Europe can only truly belong to citizens if it does not sweep the needs of any social group under the carpet. I'm not going to go into details. We know that Greece, France, Slovakia and Romania are the driving forces in the area of the rights of national minorities, indigenous national minorities.  I believe that dialogue on the rule of law can be most effective if the Council and the Commission try to improve the overall picture by encouraging the exchange of best practices in the Member States. However, this incentive must also be openly voiced by EU bodies, even if some Member States will not be happy about it. One thing is certain: by failing to have a genuine dialogue, the Union will permanently admit that it cannot make any progress in the enforcement of fundamental rights in the Member States.  (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Dear Colleague Shogor, do you not consider that the internal order of each state should be determined by the population and by the laws of that State and that excessive interfering in the internal affairs of sovereign states would ultimately have the opposite effect?

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: , blue card answer – I don't think so.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann (S&D). -
text: Madam President! I welcome the Council's decision to establish a political dialogue to protect fundamental values and the rule of law, as well as the Commission's procedure to counter systemic violations of fundamental values and the rule of law. Both initiatives are a step in the right direction. The European Union is not just a common internal market, it is based on common values. And the European Union must make a firm commitment to respect ingesly to European fundamental values. This is a question of one's own credibility. Only those who keep their own house in order can also be credible to third parties. That is why there must be no discounts on this issue among us Europeans. Since we are committed to a European community of values, I do not think that the principle of non-interference in the internal affairs of a state applies either. Our countries are now so closely linked that national policy is inevitably also part of European domestic policy. However, even if the measures taken by the Council and the Commission are a step in the right direction, I have to say that they are only a first step. Unfortunately, we do not yet have a real intra-European mechanism of fundamental rights. A discussion in the Council – about once a year, and then probably behind closed doors – is simply not enough. The Council and the Commission should take a close look at Parliament's proposal. It is a question of establishing a Copenhagen mechanism, that is, a mechanism that regularly reviews compliance with fundamental rights and the rule of law in all Member States, through independent experts and on the basis of objective data and recognised indicators. We need a real basic value TÜV. The Fundamental Rights Agency could also make an important contribution to this.

name: Fernando Maura Barandiarán (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, this debate raises the need for self-criticism. Self-criticism because we continue to talk about the defence of freedom of expression as a genuinely European value and yet can we say that all Member States comply with Article 11 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights? And I quote: "The freedom of the media and its pluralism are respected". In Hungary, for example, the national television network is a means of propaganda by the Government of Orbán. There is a tax on advertising revenue aimed at controlling private opposition media, and journalists are under unheard of political pressure. I am not saying this, says a recent council of Europe report confirming that democratic standards and the human rights situation in Hungary are in clear decline. It is time to demand that the European Union play a role in ensuring that fundamental rights are respected in all Member States without exception.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. European debates on fundamental rights and the rule of law in recent times, I must say, can be considered a failure. The European Union has not been able to act effectively on the legal issues that have arisen in Hungary and in other Member States. There are several reasons for this, and here we have talked a lot about the necessary procedures and institutions necessary to properly sanction such infringements.  However, I would like to draw attention to another thing: until there are mechanisms that warn in time, which are ringing the alarm bells in the European institutions, that there is a problem in the individual Member States and that they are independent of political decision-making, there is no expectation of an effective response from the European institutions.  There has been a lot of criticism of the procedure with Hungary for political decision-making, but of course, as long as the signal of infringement is only possible politically and there is no institutional form of how to press the alarm bell, these debates will remain political. Thank you!

name: Artis Pabriks (PPE). -
text: Madam President, this discussion shows that we are not a perfect institution, we are not perfect societies, we are not perfect countries, but at the same time we must remember that sometimes the road to hell is paved with good intentions. In particular, we can all state, and we know, that fundamental rights are basics for our institutions in the European Union, but if we look at history we also know that they have been applied differently: differently in west and east, differently in north and south.  I am not speaking here about the League of Nations and those days when countries like Czechoslovakia had to implement rights for minorities which none of the other countries which suggested this implementation did themselves.  I can say the same about all those countries which joined the European Union later on, via the Copenhagen criteria, which have implemented things like national minorities’ rights which still do not exist, maybe, in many other countries.  By stating this, I would like to say that we have to stick not only to fundamental rights but also to other principles which rule the European Union such as the Montesquieu principle of division of roles, of division of powers, and also the principle that it is the courts which can decide and not some political institutions. In this discussion, I see that somebody is willing to create a political institution which will sometimes take the role of the courts, but I find creating a new institution at this moment counterproductive.  Moreover, let us remember that even in this Chamber in the European Union we have people who are influenced by certain types of NGOs which are getting money, or by parties which are getting money, from countries outside the European Union which do not care about fundamental rights or democracy or anything else, but which complain and create discord among us here.  So let us try to use all the mechanisms that we do have. Let us stick to fundamental divisions of powers, and we will be much more successful than here today.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European systems for the protection of rights, that of the ECHR and that developed within the Community, constitute a link against the risks of degeneration of democracies and are aimed at ensuring respect for the fundamental values of the Union. But there are still gaps and weaknesses in these systems. The Charter of Rights, for example, is applied to states, but only in the context of EU law. This is a questionable limitation which can lead to truly contradictory discrimination in the case of fundamental rights. The infringement procedure also concerns only breaches of specific provisions of the Treaties, leaving behind many conduct which also violates or threatens the principles of the rule of law. Even more difficult to use are the cumbersome procedures provided for in Article 7 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union for cases of obvious risk of serious or serious and persistent violation of these principles. The Commission's idea of opening the dialogue on fundamental rights in the European Union and activating a kind of early warning mechanism in all cases of systemic violation of fundamental rights and values, irrespective of specific violations of the Treaties or elements of connection with Union law, is therefore to be welcomed. The Commission's attempt to define the concept of the rule of law better by listing certain essential principles closely linked to the protection of fundamental rights is also to be welcomed. The new operational framework outlined by the Commission as a whole is to be welcomed, but it must be implemented as soon as possible, starting with those situations that are of greatest concern today, thus ensuring protection against discrimination and marginalisation, persecution and any violation of fundamental rights.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, transparency and good practice in democratic governance would be the best prophylaxis against corruption; they are also to defend fundamental rights. The smear of old politics has to do with opacity and bad practices, as if politicians and governments were above citizens, not at their service. The mechanism of Article 7 does not take place in the light of Article 2 of the Treaty. Some of the bad practices have to do with the politicization of powers, which must be independent, and this affects fundamental rights. In Spain, for example, the politicization of the governing bodies of the judiciary and the politicization of the supervisory bodies of savings banks has cost the Spaniards twice as much as all the cuts last year, in money, but also in unbecoming social control. Poor democratic governance makes us poorer and less free; That is why, Mr Timmermans, we ask you for a long, long and necessary debate.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE). -
text: First of all, what does the rule of law mean? Citizens and those who govern them must respect the law. The rule of law also applies to relations between private actors in society, not only to citizens and those in power. Move on. How should laws be made? How should criminal suspects be treated? How should taxes be set and collected? All this is part of the rule of law, because it must be governed by laws that must be applied precisely. The law, in a rule of law, must always be applied equally to each. There are no exceptions. Without the rule of law, society doesn't work, justice doesn't work, democracy doesn't work, it doesn't work. The rule of law is the difference between dictatorship and democracy. There are no small violations or large violations of the rule of law, there are violations and that's it. And every violation is a slip into dictatorship. The rule of law also means that we must behave as required by law. There is no rule of law when politicians change the law often because they don't like the law and it doesn't serve their own interests. That's why we have laws: for politicians and all citizens to adapt their behaviour to the law, not for politicians (because they can, right? are in Parliament or Government) to change the law often, whenever they don't like it. The rule of law also means that the law must be public, clear, predictable, so that everyone can adopt their behaviour towards this law. Parliaments have responsibility primarily for the quality, clarity of the laws they adopt.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank you for your support. The European Parliament can rightly be proud to stand up for human rights all over the world. And this is very important, because human rights, fundamental rights, are the essence and the foundations of the European Union. We have asked several people, and I am also asking: do we rightly expect countries wishing to enter the Union to respect our fundamental values? But what about EU countries that are already members of the Union and do not respect fundamental rights?  You, Mr. Vice President, said a few minutes ago that there is no illiberal democracy. You, too, know that the Hungarian Government is building and proclaiming an illiberal democracy. And I understand, of course, that both Parliament and the Commission are tired of Hungarian affairs. But I must ask what will become of the European Union if neither the Commission nor Parliament is willing to stand up for its fundamental values? What should we say to citizens who are the subject of infringements and lack of legal certainty? Moreover, there are democratic forces in this House that cover illiberal democracy, non-Democrats, from partisan or factional interests. What should we tell the electorate in these cases? I think we cannot turn our backs on their interests, we cannot back down in a cowardly way, but we must stand up for these values in all circumstances.  I believe that Europe, the European Union, has no future other than to stick to its values. I think that our task is to develop effective mechanisms to prevent these cases. We need to monitor fundamental rights everywhere in Europe. We need decisive and courageous action when the situation requires it. We cannot hide behind our own cowardice, because it is the end of this European Union.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, Europe is democracy and human rights, and we cannot respond to threats to our security by cutting liberties: we have had a hard time getting and enjoying them, they make us better. Ending them is the aim of terrorism and that is why we call for more powers and capacity for the European institutions to ensure that all Member States always meet the Copenhagen criteria.  I congratulate ALDE, and especially our freedom officer, for defending these ideas in the proposed pact for democratic governance and in our document on terrorism. It is not easy, because sometimes you have to put your finger on the sore, and in Spain, for example, they want to establish the reviewable permanent prison or criminalize political activities. I would like the European institutions to recall, as they have done today with regard to the non-compliance in Spain with Framework Decision 2008/909/JHA on criminal justice, that there are limits which cannot be crossed in the face of these reforms and in the face of the low independence shown there by the judiciary. Europe needs tools to correct any decision that violates the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Mr Timmermans, I invite you to keep a close eye on the reforms being carried out by the Spanish Government.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D). -
text: Madam President! The European Union is not just an economic community, it is above all a community of values. This was also defined in the Copenhagen criteria in 1993. Since then, however, there have been repeated discussions as to whether Member States will follow suit even after they have been admitted. This is logically often discussed politically controversially. There are also only fairly general sanctions mechanisms. Such a situation is unsatisfactory because, as in the case of Hungary, it allows individual Member States to often deliberately disregard the commitments once made. We therefore urgently need a mechanism that establishes clear liabilities. Putting this on the back burner would be grossly negligent and would damage the future viability of the Union.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D). -
text: Madam President, European DNA is based on fundamental, shared and immutable values. These include equality, freedom, democracy, respect for human dignity, human rights and the rule of law. To join the European Union, a state is required to meet the Copenhagen criteria in order to ensure respect, protection and promotion of fundamental rights. These criteria are not only valid at the time of EU membership, but must remain a reality on a daily basis. Yet democracy and the rule of law are not protected in the same way in all Member States. The rights and freedoms of many citizens are being violated and ignored within the Union. Vulnerable people, Roma, the LGBT community, journalists and migrants and asylum seekers are most affected by discrimination, marginalization and even abuse. To keep the spirit of Copenhagen alive, the European Parliament is calling for the adoption of an instrument to assess respect for European values in the Union. It is essential that this mechanism of regular monitoring is part of a logic of ongoing dialogue on fundamental rights and is accompanied by more effective infringement procedures and sanctions. It would complement the procedure under Article 7 of the Treaty, which allows a State's right to vote in the Council to be suspended in the event of a serious violation of European values - a sanction that is very difficult to implement today. Does the Commission intend to put in place this mechanism in the near future to monitor compliance with the Copenhagen criteria? (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I listen to these voices with amazement. If these last three votes were to be considered true, one could get the impression that Europe is an area of human rights violations. This applies primarily to criticism of Hungary. I do not share this point of view at all. I believe that we should trust more in the democratic traditions of the Member States. I have a question, what do you actually ask? What do you request? What actions do you request?

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, it is curious, but I have not mentioned any country. Unfortunately, as long as there are human rights violations in the European Union, we will fight for them to be respected and that is why we absolutely want a European rule of law.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, a few days ago I was in Turkey, within the Joint Parliamentary Committee, and there I was trying to explain to my Turkish colleagues that respect for the rule of law is a prerequisite for the accession of a state to the European Union and one of the main values on which the Union is founded together with democracy and human rights. But they pointed out something to me that I too knew: there are cases where the mechanisms put in place to safeguard the rule of law do not work effectively, and so there is a threat to the functioning of the whole Of the European Union as an area of freedom, security and justice. So how do we ask them for compliance? It is true that such cases exist. I therefore firmly believe that a new institutional framework is necessary; let us say the Copenhagen mechanism, as mentioned earlier, will be able to deal effectively and with resistance to pressure in such cases, since respect for the rule of law is inextricably linked to democracy.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE). -
text: "In order to enter the European Union, every country must have stable institutions that guarantee democracy, it must be the rule of law, it must respect human rights and protect minorities." But unfortunately, the picture in my country today is different.  In Slovenia, we will celebrate the 24th anniversary of independence, but we are still facing a failed transition, which is most reflected in the state of the Slovenian judiciary. It's very selective about who to prosecute. Some are convicted on the basis of indidides, others the mountain of evidence is too small. Many cases are also barred.  Moreover, the problem is quality, as shown by the data on a number of judgments annulled for human rights violations.  The justice system in Slovenia is a major, if not the main obstacle, to a free and democratic society. I therefore call on the European Union to monitor the situation in the Slovenian judiciary with great care.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the adoption of the European Union's strategic framework on human rights and democracy marks a turning point in the Union's policy. Progress has been made, but much remains to be done. I am thinking of the role that the European Union can play in the protection of economic, social and cultural rights, in the fight against impunity, against all forms of discrimination, for women's rights and gender equality. From this point of view, I welcome the speech by Vice-President Timmermans. Now that the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union has finally become legally binding, the Union's action can therefore no longer be limited to mere censorship and must guarantee concrete respect for rights. It is necessary to build a European area of rights to ensure respect for, protection and promotion of fundamental rights as defined in the Copenhagen criteria. This must be an area which must not only border Europe.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr Timmermans, the European Commission's bilingualism with regard to the protection of human rights in the European Union is obvious. A few days ago, on 26 January, at the meeting of the Committee on Petitions, I raised the issue that the Memorandum violates human rights in Greece and asked the Commission to take action, but it declared itself not competent, as the Memorandum does not supposedly fall under European Union law. This position is politically and legally unacceptable. Politically because there cannot be a special area where human rights do not apply, and legally because the Memorandum has been incorporated into European Union law by ECOFIN Decision 2010/320 and published in the Official Journal of the European Union on 6 June 2010, on page 9. So will you continue the claims that the Troika and the Memorandum may be violating human rights in Greece?

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, Article 2 and Article 7 of the basic treaty are very clear. I am definitely one of those who believes that any intolerance, disregard for human rights should be truly punished. Of course, even if they are also countries, it is necessary to use the mechanisms that the European Commission will now have at its disposal.  But colleagues, the European Union is actually the largest area where human rights are truly respected. And that's why I would like us to maybe turn things around sometimes and start talking about those good examples, because Europe has a really extremely great example where human rights are respected, tolerance is promoted and everything we talk about all the time in this Parliament.  In this context, I intend to come out with initiatives, so I expect the Commission of course to support such initiatives, because we have good examples and we need to show them and show them to the European public.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL). -
text: We do not recognize moral and political authority on the European Union to judge or evaluate democracy in any sovereign state. This European Union, which criticises countries such as Venezuela or Cuba and which finances so-called democratic NGOs in these countries, is the same one that, inside, throws thousands of human beings into poverty and fosters policies of concentration of wealth. It is the same European Union which does not even respect the referendums held in its area, which certainly all remember. Let us be clear: according to this European Union, a country is only democratic when it is faced with the markets and the large economic groups that run Europe. This is, in fact, the real criterion for scouting. We therefore advocate that people stifl their future, without hypocritical interference, determined for economic and geostrategic reasons, and often revealing a complete contempt for people.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, England has no need of an EU framework for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. We had a democracy that evolved over eight centuries. That democracy is now hollow, as most of our laws now come from the European Union and not our own democratically elected Parliament and government.  We had a rule of law that had evolved since the days of Alfred The Great, but English law is now superseded by EU law. Impartial English courts are now overridden by the political courts of the European Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights. Our ancient protections of individual liberties such as Habeas corpus have been swept away by such measures as the European Arrest Warrant.  We had fundamental rights in England, developed over centuries under common law and such enactments as Magna Carta and the Bill of Rights. There is nothing that the EU can teach the English about democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I would like to thank you for Sentencing is a matter for the courts, 100 on the basis of the rule of law principle and not on political forums. Any rule of law mechanism can only function properly and effectively if it analyses real problems and is not artificially created, based on facts and objective investigations, rather than press reports or frustrated political reports. Often the facts speak of something other than unsubstantiated and untrue claims, no matter how much they are repeated. It Hungary not a threat to European values today, it is not the Hungarian Government that must be protected today, and hungarian citizens understand this precisely at home. We need to focus on real problems, and I ask you, Commissioner, to monitor each Member State equally and to measure it objectively, on an equal basis, and to focus on a real problem. Protect those who may not be in the mainstream today, traditional national minorities who are citizens of Europe with the same equal rights.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D) -
text: I have repeatedly been shadow rapporteurs in this plenary, but also rapporteurs on the report on fundamental rights. It is from this position that I can assess what respect for fundamental rights in the European Union is, and I must say that it is indeed very weak in some areas. If the EU wants to be the one who refers to third countries, how human rights are violated, and we want to be the one who wants to launder other countries for not respecting fundamental rights, we must, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, find a system to ensure that rights are respected in the Member States of the European Union. There have been several mentioned referendums in Slovakia. I want to say that I am proud of the citizens of the Slovak Republic, that only 20% of them have come to speak out against a minority, and we must, Commissioner, in future look for tools to prevent those hate speech and the hate campaign that has been used in this referendum campaign in Slovakia so that it does not reach other countries as well.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, I will try and react to some of the remarks that were made. First of all, the principle. The principle is this: throughout our history we have learned that democracy alone is not a guarantee for human rights and the rule of law. That is why we have a tripod – democracy, rule of law, human rights. One cannot take away the value of the other. When I express my reservations or my rejection of something that was once described as ‘illiberal democracy’, I just want to say that you cannot use the argument of a democratic majority – even if it is a two-thirds majority – to weaken the rules based on the rule of law or human rights.
