You cannot use two-thirds or even more of a political majority through democratic votes to weaken human rights in a Member State.  This is one of the fundamental principles upon which this Union is built, and this applies to every single Member State. You cannot say that this is interference in our internal affairs. Nobody forced any Member State to sign and ratify the Lisbon Treaty. Nobody forced any Member State to sign and ratify the Charter. But if you do, and you ratify it, it is national law, so it is by your own national law that you will be held accountable, not any other rule. So the principle will have to remain that, if we look at the situation in our Member States, we will have to look at all three in balance: democracy, rule of law and human rights. You cannot separate the three. Secondly, I think that Ms in ’t Veld’s reasoning is seriously flawed on two levels. The first level of flawed reasoning is this: because the rule of law, human rights, etc. are at least as important as economic cooperation in Europe, let us use the way we look at economic cooperation as a model for how we look at human rights. That is flawed. You cannot create a mechanism which is applicable in economies, such as budget deficit or the level of state debt expressed in percentages, and apply it to issues of human rights and the rule of law. That does not work. It would be a tremendous loss of energy and loss of focus on the real issues if we were to embark on such a mechanism. The second reason why I think this is flawed reasoning is that this Commission has been in its term of office for three months. The mechanism introduced by the Council was in December. We are still in the beginnings of trying to make the system we have work. Give it a chance. I think it is unfair already to say ‘well, whatever you have, I do not believe in it; I want my own new toy, which is a new mechanism which compares to the growth and stability pact’. I think it is flawed on those two levels. I would like to say to those of you – especially to two Greek Members of the European Parliament (and I will be addressing you in English because I do not speak Greek) – as I said before, to be an ESM mechanism is the sovereign decision of the state concerned, and the responsibility then resides with that state to make sure it is applied in accordance with EU law. I would have welcomed it if those who raised the issue of human rights in this context had also distanced themselves from expressions such as ‘we all know that Jews do not pay taxes’ or homophobic expressions that we have also heard in that context. That is also the rule of law. Please be clear about that. (interjection from Mr Marias, a Greek Member: ‘This does not apply to me!’) This does not apply to you, Sir; it does not apply to your colleague in any sense. But we all have a responsibility if these things happen in our Member State – in the Union – to speak out against it. There is nothing that will prohibit you from speaking (interjection from Mr Marias) Thank you, Sir. As far as it concerns you, I am happy to hear that. But I did hear from the Independent Greeks utterances to that effect, Sir, and you will not be able to dispute that, I am afraid. In general terms, if we really want to improve the situation of the rule of law, we all need to speak out within the responsibilities we have, and if there is a call for an independent mechanism, in that sense the Commission is an independent mechanism and we will look at the situation in Member States, take Member States to task if it is on issues such as freedom of the press, the independence of the judiciary, the position of NGOs or any other issue related to the rule of law. You have me on your side. I am strongly committed to this, but please let us try first to make the mechanisms we have effective before we start talking about new mechanisms.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Madam President, I have listened carefully to the range of views expressed during the course of this debate. As I said at the outset, the EU is not only based on respect for fundamental rights, it is also founded on the rule of law.  All Member States must ensure that their domestic order respects this key principle. The political dialogue established in December 2014, by means of the General Affairs Council conclusions on ensuring respect for the rule of law, reaffirms the commitment of Member States to safeguarding this essential element of our democracies. I am therefore convinced that the new dialogue will help us to ensure that the rule of law will continue to be a commonly shared objective of this Union.  The First Vice-President has mentioned EU accession to the European Convention on Human Rights. On 18 December 2014 the ECJ opinion put the EU in the spotlight. We look forward to the proposal from the Commission on the way forward. The Council remains firm in its commitment and its opinion that accession is an obligation and not an option.  It is remarkable that we have heard the call to create a new European mechanism for human rights monitoring here in Strasbourg, the city hosting a dozen various monitoring mechanisms. I agree with the First Vice-President that we should carefully assess the potential provided by the mechanisms which already exist. The tools are there. We simply need to learn how to use them.  The Council believes that political dialogue has potential if used in compliance with the principles outlined in last December’s conclusions. This is where the added value lies as opposed to yet another monitoring mechanism. I am sure that the Colloquy announced by Mr Timmermans will produce new ideas and recommendations. We look forward to it and to our further cooperation with the Commission and Parliament.

name: La Présidente. -
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – I think it is very important that we also address democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in parliament's plenary session. In this debate, I would like to draw attention to two existing problems: the first problem is the lack of clarification of internal rules. I ask Vice-President Timmermans to think about this issue together. As long as there are no objective criteria or common solutions, there is a possibility of applying double standards, inside and outside the EU. Double standards are appreciable in EU approaches when looking at the protection of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The Commission is too lenient on some Member States and hasty judgments on certain issues. This is not right, it undermines the credibility of the European Union. The other important element is that there are some Member States which do not fulfil the conditions which they assumed at the time of entry. This may be because there is a lack of consistent subsequent monitoring of the fulfilment of the commitments entered into when entering the EU. We also need to look more vigorously at this process. The new Commission is still at the beginning of its mandate, so we are in good time to clarify and build up the aforementioned criteria and EU guarantees to protect fundamental rights.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. – In a Communication from the Commission to the European Parliament and the Council of 11.3.2014, the Commission acknowledged in its previous chamber that existing mechanisms and procedures proved inappropriate to ensure an effective and timely response to threats to the rule of law and fundamental human rights. It was argued that concerted protection of the rule of law is needed in all Member States to deal with situations where there is no specific breach of an existing provision, there is no 'clear risk of serious infringement' or 'serious and continuing infringement present', as required by Art. 7 of the EU Treaty, but in which threats to the rule of law are of a systemic nature and threaten the political, institutional or legal order, its constitutional structure, the separation of powers or the judiciary, or where national guarantees of the protection of the rule of law do not cope effectively enough. I believe that we should do everything possible to make this Commission recognise the application of the rule of law as a priority and continue to work to monitor compliance with EU values with regard to all Member States on an equal footing.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, on 28 January the European Commission adopted another progress report on Bulgaria under the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism. Once again, Bulgaria and Romania have been finger-pointing at problems with organised crime and corruption. But such problems exist in other Member States. An example of this is the EC report of February 2014 on the state of the fight against corruption in the European Union. I believe that the publication of such reports would show the overall picture in the Union, thus avoiding the focus on certain countries. Another example is the proposal for a pan-European rule of law mechanism to monitor respect for the rule of law and to make recommendations to Member States. In December 2014, this mechanism was replaced by a once-a-year dialogue based on the principle of objectivity, non-discrimination and equal treatment of all Member States. I believe that these two instruments could replace the cooperation and verification mechanism of Bulgaria, which has proven ineffective and is a double standard applied to countries such as Bulgaria in the fight against organised crime and corruption. In this context, it is high time that the cooperation and verification mechanism for Bulgaria was abolished.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. – In March 2014, the European Commission adopted a new framework to address systemic risks to the rule of law, which applies to all 28 EU Member States. Previously, the EU had very little competence when Member States violated human rights, the rule of law and democracy, unless there was a breach of European law. However, the new framework explicitly states that there are cases which do not fall within the scope of EU law and cannot therefore be regarded as a breach of the obligations under the EU Treaties, but which raise concerns as they pose a systemic threat to the rule of law. This ingly, the EU has the power to act in areas that are otherwise the full competence of the Member States - with a view to safeguarding the rule of law. I am sorry that the European Commission itself is not honouring its commitments. I have addressed several questions about the legal proceedings against the president of The Largest Slovenian Opposition Party, Janez Janši, who was imprisoned on the charge that he had accepted the promise of a prize in an unknown place at an unknown time. Human rights and freedoms were not only violated by Janez Janši, but this had major consequences for the whole Slovenian state. President Juncker has also recently said that the EU is not only a common market, it is also a community of values – and the rule of law is one of the fundamental values!

name: La Présidente. -
text: The agenda calls for debate on the statements of the Council and Commission on the future of Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office (2015/2527 (RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Madam President, first of all I would like to express my deepest sadness and condolences to the families of the migrants who died of hypothermia on board Italian coastguard vessels last Monday. Unfortunately, we learned this morning that there were two other boats which sailed from Libyan shores with around 300 migrants, and that only a few have survived. I also wish to express our solidarity with the Italian authorities, which saved 106 people in the middle of the night under extreme weather conditions. However, I do not think this tragic loss of life should hide the efforts made by Member States, Frontex and the Union. Probably we should do more and better. For this reason I thank Parliament for the opportunity today to discuss the way forward for two key Union players: the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and Frontex. In the resolution adopted by Parliament on 17 December 2014, it rightly calls for a review of our migration policy and sets out the elements that should be part of an EU holistic approach. As the Justice and Home Affairs Council noted last October, the challenge linked to increasing migratory flows and the shifting routes of access to the EU – also as a consequence of measures taken at national level – needs to be addressed with common actions. This is even more important as these migratory flows do not only affect countries on the front line but Europe as a whole, also due to the large secondary movements taking place. In this context, agencies like EASO and Frontex have a key role to play. On the initiative of the Presidency, increased migratory pressure was recently discussed at the informal JHA ministerial meeting in Riga. So let me share with you some ideas for making full use of the capabilities of Frontex and EASO. Starting with EASO, in June 2014 the European Council made it clear that in the coming years the focus should be on consolidating the Common European Asylum System. With that focus in mind, the Council shares the wish of this assembly that EASO needs to play a reinforced role in supporting practical cooperation, in particular by promoting the uniform application of the asylum acquis through practical and technical support. Action on migration and asylum within the EU must be complemented with an external dimension. In its resolution, Parliament rightly points out that external action should be part of an overall strategy in coordination with third countries. Given the volatile situation in the EU’s neighbourhood, the EU must set up cooperation with third countries. EASO can provide support to strengthen asylum and reception capacity, especially in Middle Eastern and North African countries. It also facilitates resettlement and support for the implementation of regional protection and development programmes. In doing so, EASO should work in close cooperation with UNHCR and the International Organisation for Migration. Furthermore, given the high migratory and asylum influx, there will be a continued need for practical support to Member States subject to particular pressure. This will require EASO to provide the necessary operational support, for instance by coordinating Asylum Support Teams. By providing such support, EASO puts intra-EU solidarity into practice. Finally, EASO should develop further as a centre of expertise in the field of asylum. By strengthening EASO’s information and analysis support, the EU and its Member States will be better placed to address future migratory inflow. In particular, EASO has to further develop the mechanism for early warning, preparedness and crisis management: a new task assigned to it by the Dublin III Regulation. With this expertise, EASO can also develop innovative solidarity tools for coping with situations of particular pressure. An example is the pilot project on supported processing of asylum applications. This pilot enhances mutual trust among Member State authorities, which is essential for considering future steps in the EU asylum policy. Now turning to Frontex, since its establishment in 2005 the agency has made a major contribution to the management of external borders. It has gradually increased its operational support to Member States and has taken a leading role in providing risk analysis. Its model of joint operations has also been successfully used by Member States, and its training activities have contributed to building a common border-guard culture across Europe. Those achievements have led the co-legislators to agree to widen and reinforce the mandate of the agency and its capacities by amending the Frontex Regulation in 2011 and by investing the agency with the role of central hub of the new European Border Surveillance System, Eurosur. I would also like to recall its potential role in the framework of the new Schengen evaluation mechanism. What more can be done by Frontex, in particular to support Member States in the Mediterranean? Member States remain responsible for the control and surveillance of their external borders, and Frontex only has a coordinating role in terms of EU operational cooperation. Thus we should in the first place ask the Member States concerned what their specific needs are and what is the real added value of the agency’s operational support that can be achieved. Frontex could then provide its support by organising more targeted joint operations, connecting national priorities and EU objectives, strengthening the spirit of operational solidarity, assisting with specialised capacities and contributing to building national capacities. In the current situation, it appears imperative that Frontex increase its reactivity towards the rapid evolution in migration flows, making full use of the Eurosur system, including the provisions of inter-agency cooperation. Because the roots of migration are far away from the EU’s borders, it is absolutely necessary to enhance cooperation with countries of origin and transit. In that regard, Frontex has the possibility of deploying its own Immigration Liaison Officers, who could become an information hub in key third countries. Frontex could also help third countries to manage their borders in a more secure way, in accordance with international law standards, by providing technical assistance and promoting regional cooperation on borders. In the context of the long-term development of Frontex, the European Council in its June 2014 conclusions indicated that ‘the possibility of setting up a European system of border guards to enhance the control and surveillance capabilities at our external borders should be studied’. The relevant working party within the Council has discussed the study carried out for the Commission on the feasibility of a European system of border guards. It now awaits the external evaluation commissioned by the Frontex Management Board as well as possible further action by the Commission. Both EASO and Frontex have managed to build up organisations capable of delivering results. EASO’s support improves the quality of national asylum systems. This brings us closer to the ideal of a Common European Asylum System in which applications for international protection are treated in the same manner irrespective of where in the EU they are lodged. By delivering operational support to Member States, Frontex strengthens the management of the EU’s external borders. In the light of these achievements, the Council commends EASO and Frontex for the results obtained over the past years and encourages them to continue supporting practical cooperation in the EU in the years to come.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, when I heard this morning that the representative of UNHCR in Lampedusa said that possibly more than three hundred people had died in the last couple of days trying to save their lives by crossing the Mediterranean I thought, do we still have words to express what we feel when these things happen? Are our senses becoming numb, are we becoming involuntarily indifferent to what is happening?  My reaction to that is we can never let that happen. We can never become indifferent to that level of human suffering and we will always be under an obligation to try to find a solution even though a solution will have to be comprehensive and will not only be controlling our borders in a more efficient way. It will always have to entail taking away the reasons why people feel they need to flee, knowing all too well that they risk dying on a boat somewhere between Africa or the Arab world and Europe. The price that people are prepared to pay is so high that I think we need to refocus on our obligation also to take away the reason why people feel the need to flee. At the same time I think it is necessary that we discuss the way forward for the European External Borders Agency FRONTEX and the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). We are confronted with a twofold challenge. Internally the common European asylum system must be implemented in a coherent and effective way by all participating Member States and associated countries. Externally we are confronted with the highest migratory pressures at the EU external borders since the 1990s and all EU Member States are affected. The time is gone that we could just leave that problem in the hands of a few Member States and ignore it. EASO and FRONTEX will have a prominent role in the implementation of the EU agenda on migration which is currently developed as announced in the Commission Work Programme for 2015. Since they were established both agencies have faced the increasing challenge of supporting Member States, especially those with high migratory pressures, while having limited resources at their disposal.  The Commission is very grateful for the support provided by the European Parliament and the Council in the development of both agencies and for ensuring they have the necessary funding. The management of migratory flows to the EU, including the protection of refugees, requires close collaboration both at policy level where the EU institutions operate, and in terms of practical cooperation, implementation and support from EASO and FRONTEX. The establishment of close and well-functioning practical cooperation and the continuous exchange of best practices is of utmost importance to build mutual trust between Member States and between the Member States and the EU. Here the agencies are playing a key role. Let me now say a few words about each agency in particular. Concerning EASO, the consolidation and implementation of the common European asylum system has the highest priority for the Commission in the coming years. EASO will continue to play an important role in this endeavour. It will help improve the quality of asylum decision-making and harmonise practices across the EU, by monitoring the quality of asylum decisions and ensuring that Member States are able to access up-to-date country of origin information to assist them in their assessments.  EASO further needs to contribute to enhancing the capacity of national asylum systems with training and exchanges of best practices between the Member States. With an unstable geopolitical environment and evolving threats, EASO is playing and will play an important role in crisis management; for example, it played a useful part in the Taskforce Mediterranean. Our objectives cannot be successfully met without further engaging third countries and better combining our external policy instruments. In that context, EASO’s external activities are part of a broad range of EU external relations instruments. On FRONTEX, firstly I should stress it has only a supporting function in coordinating operational cooperation between the Member States, especially in support of the requesting Member States facing the highest migratory pressure. FRONTEX devotes its resources to the hotspots and shifts those resources around as pressure shifts from one section of the external border to another. This fire brigade role is important for emergency support but it cannot be the only function of the agency. FRONTEX needs also to provide structural support to all Member States to help them better control all external borders of the EU. Examples are training of border guards and developing tools such as Eurosur which contribute to saving lives at sea.  Since the last revision of the FRONTEX mandate in 2011, great progress has been made regarding fully respecting fundamental rights during FRONTEX coordinated joint operations. A code of conduct has been established. All offices participating in joint operations are obliged to have the appropriate training concerning the rights of apprehended persons and their access to asylum. Furthermore, where there is proof of the violation of fundamental rights the executive director of the agency can suspend or terminate the ongoing joint operation. In line with the respective mandates of the agencies, the cooperation between Europol and FRONTEX is ongoing and will be further enhanced in the near future, especially regarding the common fight against the use of ghost ships to smuggle persons into the EU. Here, I think, a number of very, very cynical criminals prey on people in desperate situations and they need to be tackled. The agency launched an external evaluation in 2014 which covers all of these points. It is expected to be ready by the summer of this year. A study on the feasibility of a system of European border guards has also been carried out for the Commission by an external contractor. We have made the study public.  Based on the findings of these two studies the Commission intends to initiate a debate on how to further strengthen the agency which will have an important role to play in the coming years. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I warmly welcome the Presidency of the Council and I am very pleased that the Vice-President of the European Commission – you, Mr Timmermans – is with us because we did not really want the issue at the moment. We did not want to be in a situation where hundreds of people – whose numbers we can no longer even verify precisely, do not know exactly – have drowned in the Mediterranean and who are showing us the limits we have reached. I would therefore like to ask the following questions in particular: Frontex and EASO urgently need support in the development of their structures, both in terms of personnel and technology, as well as in the speed of the supply of expert staff from the Member States. I would like to ask the Commission very warmly to take this wish into account in the context of the next budget negotiations, because otherwise these agencies will really reach the limit of what they are able to do. I would also like to thank both agencies very much for their active and intensive work. Secondly, the question for me is whether we do not need something like community military action on the high seas again in order to save people on the one hand, but also to reduce the traffickers on the other, and also, urgently, other forms of cooperation with third countries. For if ISIS now dominates parts of Libyan ports and forces people onto boats with which they are definitely unable to arrive, but have to drown miserably, then this is an untenable state of affairs that Frontex and EASO can no longer change; we need other instruments, which ultimately lie in the dimension of foreign policy. We must also step up the fight against traffickers as a matter of urgency, thereby strengthening Europol's instruments in order to combat this.

name: Claude Moraes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. –  Madam President, last Monday I think the number that was cited by Frontex, the agency, was 106 lives saved. Of course, every day the European Asylum Support Office does its dedicated work. I was involved in the trialogues and negotiations for the Asylum Support Office and many colleagues here were involved in Frontex, a serious committee trying to work with these serious people and serious agencies. Over 14 years since these agencies were created, the estimate (and it is only an estimate) is that over 22 000 lives have been lost. In the last few months, it is not lost lives, it is a more brutal form of trafficking – these ghost ships, a much more calculated and cynical way of killing people when they cannot get their money. So let us be very clear: there are some people in this Chamber who will want to talk about a more existential threat to immigration, and they will want to talk about immigration in their own national spheres. But let us be very clear – of all the lives that have been lost, when we are talking about Frontex and the agencies, we in Parliament have been doing very meticulous work, and I have seen that work. There are good people in these agencies, and I have met them. So let us be very clear about the Council. I was in Riga recently, and I heard one Member State saying that (I have just written it down because I wrote it at the time) resourcing further Council cooperation in the Mediterranean will act as a push factor. Now the issue is that saving lives in the Mediterranean is a resource-rich issue which goes far beyond Frontex and the Asylum Support Office. The Asylum Support Office is an intelligence-led, information-rich office. Frontex is an agency which spots people who are dying and who are potentially going to die in a fairly small-scale operation. Our assets are small and limited: I have seen that. So for the Council, it has to do its job and it has to do it collectively, and we need the Council to do its job and the Commission to help us do it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: "blue card" question. Unfortunately, I would like to give the numbers of another massacre, the massacre two days ago. About 420 confirmed victims found empty boats. I would therefore like to ask the chairman of the LibE Committee whether he intends, as I hope, to have a permanent focus on this issue, which is certainly linked to immigration, which is certainly linked to the right of asylum. I would therefore ask him and the LIBE Committee to be careful on a daily basis on this issue.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I do apologise, I got a bit emotional and forgot I just had two minutes. The question of numbers is a really pertinent question, because the issue is that the numbers we get are secondary sources, and I think we just cannot tell who is dying. These are coming from the agencies, but many of them are coming from the Italian coastguard itself. I think the pertinent issue is that we are not getting the numbers of people who are actually dying, and there are thousands of people dying who we never hear of in the Mediterranean. His Holiness alluded to this in his speech to the Chamber. So people should focus on those who we never hear of who die unknown, and I think this is the real tragedy of the Mediterranean.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, this is not a new issue of course. We have talked about it here for many months. In the 1990s, I myself was the UK Minister for Immigration and Asylum and I recognise the sensitivities attached to the whole issue. Of course we do not want to repeat ourselves, but it really is, despite good intentions, enormously challenging now. The same concerns are in place. The situation faced by the European Union as a whole is a very serious one regarding immigration and asylum. Of course the European Asylum Support Office and the Frontex Agency have a large and important role to play in the challenges we face to manage migration into the EU and to secure our external border.  These are two agencies whose work I support, but my overall concerns remain the same as ever. More must be done to assist Member States who receive large numbers of migrants. Too many migrants slip through the net unprocessed. They remain in Europe, vulnerable to exploitation, and are undocumented. The terrible news of the further 300 fatalities underlines why more must be done to save the lives of those who tragically go to sea seeking a new life, and much more must be done to catch, detain and prosecute the actual perpetrators of the human trafficking itself. More must also be done to assist Member States in the integration and resettlement of asylum seekers, and more must be done by the Commission to ensure that those countries where migrants first arrive can properly deal with them, as soon as they arrive, in the right conditions. I am saddened that sometimes, particularly with children, they remain very vulnerable in the process that takes place.  The Commission needs to offer a clear strategy and a clear way forward so this Parliament and European citizens can again regain confidence that the European asylum system is working fairly and efficiently and that it benefits both those who genuinely seek asylum and all the citizens of the EU itself.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Kirkhope, would you agree with me that the trigger-happy UK government which intervened in Libya and wanted to intervene in Syria, that the policies of that government is a major contribution to the tragedy of the Mediterranean?

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – No, Lord Dartmouth, I would not. I think that the interventions and the international scene of the British government, certainly in recent times, have been to try and help humanity, to try and actually deal with despots and tyrants which the world needs to deal with and where we need a courageous government to take such actions. Furthermore, it does seem to me, Lord Dartmouth, that the progressive view of the British government to those who travel and migrants generally is something that we should be very proud of as British subjects, and I am very sorry that you have such a reluctance to admit that pride. (Applause)

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The grief lies heavy over the Mediterranean today just like the darkness over the water, for today we have been reached again by a similar news that we have been reached by too many times. More than 300 people may have drowned when the boats sank. People are dying before our eyes despite political promises – not least at Lampedusa a year and a second ago – that no one else should have to die in this way. But the tragedy repeats itself again and again, and it seems that it is someone else's responsibility.  Many of us have asked questions of our relatives who lived during World War II: "Why didn't you do more to help? Did you not see that the Jews were persecuted?" And we have been met with glances that have been knocked down: "Yes, we knew but what could we do?" Similarly, I fear that in future my grandchildren will ask me: 'Did you not see in the institutions of Europe that people fled burning wars? Did you not see that they were on the Mediterranean in unseaworthy boats and so many drowned?" Yes, we know.  But the challenges we face are common, we have to deal with them together. Frontex should be given a mandate, they should be given the means and materiel to deal with similar operations that Mare Nostrum managed – and for that we should thank Italy over and over again, for what they did.  At the same time, we should create legal, safe routes to europe so that people do not have to be in the hands of unscrupulous people smugglers and make the deadly journey across the Mediterranean. We should accept more quota refugees and offer humanitarian visas to come here and apply for asylum on the spot. In this process, we need EASO. Europe should have acted a long time ago. Our deeds, but also our indifference, will judge us all one day.  \*(The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: Blue card question. I wanted to put a question to the member who has just spoken. I am Italian, I have been to Lampedusa several times as an Italian Member of Parliament and, hearing your words like so many others here in this House, I ask you: but is it not total hypocrisy? Do you not think that continuing to make speeches saying that 300 people have died is just hypocrisy? Last year in Lampedusa they all came to say that we had to change and Europe did zero. Isn't that hypocrisy in your opinion? Isn't that crocodile tears?

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: answer ("blue card"). The Commission should now come together and come up with clear, straight answers on how to ensure that this terrible situation does not repeat itself. We know that almost 4 000 people have died in the Mediterranean in the last year.  The Pope was here. He told us that the Mediterranean is becoming an anonymous gigantic cemetery, and I repeat: our actions, your responsibility and my responsibility, the responsibility of the Commission and the Council is to act. For our deeds and our indifference will haunt us until people have a safe way here.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the news from the Mediterranean is tragic: between 300 and 400 deaths as in Lampedusa in 2013. The facts speak for themselves now. The end of Mare Nostrum is once again producing humanitarian disasters, and the Frontex mission, which had been described as a solution, I am referring to Triton, turns out to be what it is: a false replacement and a radical failure. That is why I do not believe, in the present circumstances, that Frontex should receive any additional resources. Despite regulations that are too vague and not enforced, its task is only to patrol the borders and not to search for and rescue fugitives from wars and chaos that also extend on our own responsibility. Frontex even warns the Italian Government that the aid it coordinates is prohibited beyond 30 miles from the coast. The shipwrecks of these days have all taken place on the high seas, near the Libyan coast, where Mare Nostrum was operating. The truth is that Mare Nostrum, despite the statements of the European and Italian authorities, has never been replaced. We should now ask for two things as a Parliament. Firstly, that Frontex should not stand in the way when it is called upon to rescue over 30 miles. Secondly, that Europe should decide to support financially the restoration of missions such as Mare Nostrum. Both the UN High Commissioner and the Council of Europe have stated that Triton is not up to the job. What are we waiting for to say the same thing? Today, the President of the Italian Senate, Pietro Grasso, said: 'action now is already too late'.

name: Ska Keller
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Vice-President, you said that Europe must not allow such tragedies. But how many times have we heard this here? It is not only since Lampedusa a year and a half ago that people have died in the Mediterranean. And many people are dying – 300 people these days alone. Who knows, maybe even more. But instead of finally seeking a solution, the interior ministers keep downplaying the same thing: more money for Frontex, more border surveillance, more fortress Europe. But that is the wrong answer to the crisis we are in. We do not need more foreclosure, we do not need more surveillance. What we need instead is a European response to the maritime rescue crisis that we have. We need a European Mare Nostrum. Triton does not help us; this is a defensive program. We need a European maritime rescue programme! Vice-President, where is that? Criminal smugglers must, of course, be put to work. We must fight them, but not the refugees. And if we are only fighting people smugglers on our own, we will bring refugees into a vicious circle. Because if we shut ourselves off, if we fight the smugglers, then refugees will have to take more, more dangerous routes. We can only change this by finally creating legal, safe access routes for refugees. We must open up the ferries to the refugees so that they no longer have to go on small inflatable boats. That is what we must do, Europe! We need answers from the Commission, but also from the Member States, which are currently doing far too little, either in resettlement or in the reception of refugees. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. - Colleague, thank you for your performance, I think you have a lot of truth, but I would like to ask. Is there even a simple recipe for fighting smuggling? Can you give me the answer to this question?

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – I think the appropriate response to smuggling is to take away their business base. This means that refugees have other options, that they have legal, safe access, that we do not force them to go on the boats and risk their lives after they have just fled war and persecution. We need more resettlement, we need legal entry for Syrian refugees, for example, but not only. We need humanitarian visas, we need escape corridors. These are all possibilities that are already possible with the EU Aquis. We should not pretend that we do not have answers to it. Certainly not the answer to everything, but to many things that we can already do now, including here as the European Parliament. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, I have a question for Mrs Keller. My question is: how should the European Union finally go about differentiating economic migrants from migrants seeking international protection?

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – We have a very clear role for refugees. We have the Geneva Convention and indeed, as I said, we should have a proper way for them to enter. We need to have a European asylum system but – I agree – we also need to have a way for people who flee for economic reasons, who are looking for a better future – because that is also something Europe is about, we want to create a better future for ourselves. Other people also want to have a part of this better future but we do not have any possibilities for migrants to come here. This needs to change, and here it is the Member States which need to open up to allow legal migration to the European Union. They should not block things like the Seasonal Workers Directive and we also need to reform the Blue Card to make it more open for people.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, here we are discussing yet another tragedy: 300-400 deaths in the Strait of Sicily. We can no longer even talk about a tragedy, because it is a permanent tragedy. So I ask myself: what are we discussing if, year after time, year after year, we are always in the same situation? Because we cannot take any measures, no decision that is concrete. I am pleased that there are here the Council and the Commission talking about joint measures, about European activity that can really combat this kind of tragedy and, above all, that can combat trafficking in human beings, because that is what it is all about. But these are words, because what actually happens is that we continue to see in a disjointed way, that is, with the intergovernmental method, the discourse of immigration and that there is a total lack of interest in dealing with the phenomenon of organized crime that makes the routes of billionaire men and that causes these tragedies to occur. We must try to work in ensuring humanitarian corridors for those fleeing safe wars and in combating the organised crime that is speculating really heavily on these routes.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI). -
text: Madam President, FRONTEX has no past, present and, much more, future. Its establishment as a European Agency for the Management of Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union expected benefits, but its operational effectiveness so far is considered insufficient. For example, in my country Greece, official data presented by the Agency's Executive Director, Ilkka Laitinen, showed an impressive increase in illegal crossings for the year 2013. In addition, compared to 2012, the number of illegal immigrants increased by 48%, a number that cannot be withstood and absorbed by the European Union. FRONTEX, like the Dublin II and Schengen Treaties, was created for a period of calm. As a result, at a time of tension, the European Union finds itself unprepared and confronts illegal immigration with nervousness, knee-jerk movements and not as an asymmetric threat. It is high time that they were revised in the interests of the people.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE). -
text: People smuggling and illegal immigration are one of the european Union's most significant problems, and a clear and unambiguous answer must be given and the task line that we must now carry out. Unfortunately, the recent terrorist incidents and this terrorist threat, which still exists today, have put this situation in a slightly new aspect.  I must think that we can also provide clearer and much more decisive responses to illegal immigration and to the economic aspects of the smuggling of people that preceded it. It is not just death ships, but every event that happens in the Mediterranean is an extremely serious tragedy.  It is also the case that there are countries that are becoming transit countries. Hungary one of these places. It is located at an intersection, a migration route where the number of illegal immigrants has multiplied. That number has multiplied since 2012 and has now reached half last year's level in the first two months. We have taken a number of measures, we have set up refugee camps, technical transfers, strengthening border guards, strengthening the police, training, information system. But that alone is not enough, it does not solve the problem.  The most serious thing is that 40% of the refugees are children, who are the most vulnerable and the most vulnerable. So far, the poorest have come from Syria, Afghanistan and Kosovo. But not now, now it's graduates, graduates. We need to give common answers, we need to take a strong position. That is what I expect from today's debate and from the Commission.  (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Madam President, dear Lady, I have listened carefully and noticed that you care about the same care that I have, which are transitional paths that are practically in the heart of Europe. Hungary and Croatia are such examples.  I ask you if you think as I think we should very much engage Frontex on our borders, in the case of Croatia towards Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia, help people of course in terms of asylum and corridors, but also in terms of the danger that threatens?

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Blue card answer. – Illegally refugees, migrants come from Serbia. They don't come from Croatia, they come from Serbia. That is why I believe that it is important precisely to strengthen and complete Frontex. And this is not only the responsibility of a Member State, it is also our common task and our shared responsibility. That is why I believe that, together with the Commission, we need to draw up a firm roadmap, a work plan, a task plan, so that we can be more effective, so that we do not talk about death ships, not about the number of illegally refugees multiplying, but about solving a problem.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D) -
text: The subject of European asylum policy is a very sensitive subject, including in the context of a previous subject, Mr Vice-President, because it is immigration policy and immigrants who are the bullets for politicians or those who would like to get into different parliaments and abuse the position of these people, as well as perhaps our imperfect immigration policy. We therefore need a new common asylum system. After all, it is not possible for asylum seekers to have such very different chances of obtaining it in different Member States if they meet the same conditions. Nor must we forget that we must protect our borders and actively combat illegal activity, which is closely linked to migration. FRONTEX has set itself very ambitious targets for solving problems in the Mediterranean and ensuring external border control. I believe that, if we want these objectives to be achieved, we must also increase the current budget for FRONTEX in order to strengthen its work. The people of the Member States must feel safe and be convinced that our common borders are carefully secured and that we will not allow criminals and traffickers to cross borders with impunity.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR). -
text: Mr President, better communication between existing EU agencies is important to establish information exchange and cooperation. In this context, europol's operational capacity should be better utilised. Frontex must also be given a greater role. Not only in the context of protecting Europe's external borders, but also in the safe interception of migrants from North Africa. This is crucial for our internal security, but also, of course, for the safety of the refugees and the management of the influx of refugees. In addition, EASO also supports Member States that are coming under intense pressure from the massive influx of refugees and helps to fulfil their European and international obligations. But Greece's asylum treatment leaves so much to be desired that a return under the Dublin rules encounters human rights concerns. As a result, some EU countries have not been sending anyone back to Greece for four years. So it is very clear that the system is not working. And my question is, how are we going to proceed now? Please see a concrete response from the Commission. How do we solve this problem?

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mrs Kalnia-Luka'evica, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for her work on this The current situation reminds us, on a daily basis and today, painfully, that we finally need a functioning management system for a migration and asylum policy at European level. Migration flows are constantly changing, and we simply cannot and must no longer respond only to recurrent disasters. Our priorities should and should be a common European asylum system and better border management. EASO and Frontex are two important instruments for getting from the current patchwork of measures to a sound common migration and asylum policy. These two institutions should work more closely together in the future and focus on operational measures. If we want to achieve the objective of an open and secure Europe, the current instruments are simply not enough. We therefore need to revise, rethink and strengthen the effectiveness of the powers of EASO and Frontex.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul I'll be clear. The EU's migration and refugee policy is a disaster. We have built a fortress, and at all the fortresses, people fall by its walls. What we should be discussing here and now is how Europe can take more responsibility when we have a refugee situation that has not been worse since the Second World War.  Instead of discussing life-saving in the Mediterranean and legal asylum routes, we are discussing increased resources for Frontex and Eurosur. It is a disgrace because these two are part of this fortress Europe. Using death in the Mediterranean as a lever for more funds, more money for Frontex, I think is a disgrace. I am opposed to more money for Frontex or a Triton 1, 2, 3, 4. Frontex is not and will never be a life-saving operation, it is a border police and a border control authority. We need greater European responsibility for search and rescue in the Mediterranean, we need legal asylum routes. We want to see a Mare Nostrum Plus, but it cannot, as the Liberals said here, be built on Frontex. We didn't want a Frontex Plus we want an Mare Nostrum Plus. So I ask the Commission and the Council: when will you come back with real measures that put an end to death in the Mediterranean and which are not based on the foundations of fortress Europe? \*(The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – In fact, I would like to ask our colleague who has already said that Frontex is not saving lives and that Frontex is a border police: what is your opinion, considering you know about the cooperation between Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office?

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card answer. – I think that the cooperation between the different agencies is one thing. What we should be discussing here is the kind of activities that we have to build up and which could be an answer to the deaths in the Mediterranean. Frontex – and, I am sorry to say, to a limited extent EASO – is not part of the answer. We want to see Mare Nostrum Plus, not Frontex Plus. So, regardless of how great the coordination between these actors is, they are part of Fortress Europe, a fortress that is not actually saving lives but taking lives.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, last Christmas, the Dutch Secretary of State, Mr Teeven, said that it was not Europe's job to rescue people from the Mediterranean. He also said that he did not want to take in extra people from Syrian refugee camps in the Netherlands, because that would only compete with the refugees who are already in the Netherlands and who also want to live comfortably. If I was a refugee and I could choose between a big boat, which we now call a ghost ship, or a small rubber dinghy, I'd know, and I'd get on that big boat. And what all this shows is that one thing really doesn't work, and that's border control. Because smugglers are always outsmarting us and refugees are always looking for a way to get home safely. So we can talk about Frontex here, but we really need to talk about generous re-enactments and access to safe places, including in Europe.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the umpteenth tragedy announced and avoidable: 300 dead, 29 of whom died as a result of the inadequacy of the means by which they were rescued. We are here to express our solidarity, to express our condolences, but we could do much more. We could and should, because it makes sense for us to be here in this Parliament, inso far as we take concrete action. We have a responsibility and a moral and legal duty to do something more. So, as a member of the LibE Committee, I believe that the resolution we voted on two months ago must be implemented immediately. Two months have passed since the resolution was voted on in this plenary and adopted and there is still total stagnation. I expect the Commission to propose proposals and concrete measures to improve the management of migratory flows, so that we do not find ourselves here again asking for help, in showing solidarity, without any fact. There is also a need, the urgency, the need for clear and uniform rules at European level, also to protect those particularly vulnerable people such as minors, who very often find themselves disappearing into nothingness, in the middle of the demand for international protection. We must give greater protection to children and women. If Europe is to be an open society project based on fundamental rights, it is essential that the common European asylum system, to which EASO also contributes, should focus on the protection of fundamental rights.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI). -
text: These days the barrage of tragedies with migrant victims in the Mediterranean reveals the common anti-immigration policy of the European Union and governments. This is FRONTEX. This is the Triton program. This is Dublin III and the so-called 'smart borders' of the European Union. They are mechanisms that persecute migrants and refugees, migrants who do not need monopolies and all those who have had to flee their countries in order to escape poverty, hunger and imperialist interventions by the same guilty parties: the European Union, NATO, the United States, for the control of the sources of wealth from monopolies. The JRC is now demanding immediate measures to accommodate, accommodate and relieve migrants and refugees. Legalize those workers who live and work in Greece. To close the concentration camps now and to repeal the Dublin II and III Regulations. Travel documents to those who wish to move to other countries.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ (PPE). -
text: Madam President, we have repeatedly said in this Chamber that we will not allow the Mediterranean to become a vast graveyard of souls. And we've made very important efforts. We shouldn't be hypocrites. Congratulations are due to those who work at FRONTEX because, in addition to doing a difficult job and their duties, they are also moving in a fine line that requires respect for the human rights of these people. And that's what happens. Let us not forget that FRONTEX, in addition to guarding the external borders, must also coordinate Operation Triton and coordinate other services that contribute – because it also contributes – to the rescue. What needs to be done to deal with the phenomenon? Is the resources that exist so far in FRONTEX sufficient? And besides, is it manned with the right manpower that has the necessary know-how? We must contribute to this in order to strengthen it. But there is another obligation of the European Union: we must speed up those avenues that guarantee asylum, because we know that desperate people who come to Europe because they believe it is the promised land, seek a way of asylum and resort to the traffickers, whom the European Union has an obligation, in the ways it has and with others it will invent , to check. So this route of legal immigration, which must be controlled already across borders and by other methods, is the only way to stop irregular immigration. This is also the principle that permeates the declaration of our Commissioner, Mr Avramopoulos, while François Crépeau, who is the UN special rapporteur on the rights of migrants, recently said that we must incentivise and invest in the mobility of migrants, so that this phenomenon is certainly addressed. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Speaking as the grandson of a refugee from Poland and, indeed, the grandson of a proud British lady who took in a family of asylum seekers following the Hungarian 1956 uprising – so someone who has strong support for the concept of asylum – do you not realise clearly from the comments you have just made that this whole concept of free movement within the European Union actually places such great constraints on the Member States that the ability to offer asylum as much as possible cannot be given?

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ (PPE)
text: 'blue card' reply. – If I understood the question correctly, the philosophy of the European Union is not to close the borders but to control them. To control those people who can deal with human conditions by guaranteeing their human rights, on the one hand, and on the other hand to fight the phenomenon of traffickers who get rich at the expense of human souls.

name: Илияна Йотова (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, we expected to see here tonight, together with you, Mr Avramopoulos, who in just a few months has to propose a new holistic policy to tackle europe's biggest problem and challenge, migration, as illegal crossings at the external borders have more than doubled in just one year.  The greatest pressure is in the Mediterranean, but no lighter is the situation on the land border between Bulgaria and Turkey. In December alone, 1,500 more migrants have tried to enter our country. Illegal emigration from Kosovo to Hungary is also on the rise. There is a danger of another severe humanitarian crisis after the events in Ukraine. Behind these statistics are severe consequences of an economic, societal and political nature. There is a sense of helplessness in both national and European institutions. You asked, Commissioner, what are our proposals. The review of the instruments to date shows that risk analyses of European agencies and Member States, coordination and cooperation are not sufficient.  Rather, the process should start by increasing Frontex's powers and ending with the creation of a European border response corps at the hotspots where the pressure is greatest.  Operations must be carried out under the command of Frontex and the corps must be composed of border police officers from individual Member States, and of course the whole process should be controlled by the European Parliament.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. The Minister representing the Latvian Presidency spoke of the need for coordination of asylum policy. There have been words about a uniform asylum policy, but this is not just a technical issue, it is a substantive issue. We should be ruthless and generous to the criminal world – certainly generous to refugees, to Christian refugees and, where possible, generous to those who want to come to Europe for economic reasons. First you need to set the substantive directions, and then the technical decisions. Commissioner Timmermans said that policy in this area must be global. I understand his words that it must be linked to the neighbourhood policy, to the south-east policy. I would like to know the concrete proposals. Finally, I cannot help but refer to the words of a British colleague who spoke in the blue card procedure. Should I understand that Britain's policy during communism, asylum policy was easier? Well, it was certainly easier, but mature countries should have a difficult policy.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, with regard to Frontex's activities, there are numerous tools for protecting Europe's borders: the SIS-II system, the VIS system, the EUROSUR programme is being developed, the Smart Borders pilot project is about to be launched. In order to protect Europe, we need, in particular, good cooperation.  It would be more effective to introduce an obligation under frontex's leadership to carry out the exchange of data collected between the law enforcement authorities of the Member States and between them, Frontex and Europol, with particular emphasis on the countries entrusted with the responsibility to protect the external European borders. And in so far as the obligations correspond with rights and responsibility goes hand in hand with solidarity, I would like to recall that Bulgaria and Romania carry out their obligations to protect Europe's borders and security, but despite the met reception requirements, they remain outside the Schengen area.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, with Frontex we are building the Europe of strength, where migration policy is simply a part of an alleged security policy: visa restriction, construction of murderous walls and fences, militarisation of border control, forced repatriations, outsourcing of migration control to non-democratic countries. We are systematically violating human rights, not only in hot returns, but installing blades on fences, mistreating in detention centres or attacking with our patrol boats. There have even been cases where the European authorities have authorised the trigger to be pulled. Let's talk about security. Do you know when citizens feel safe, ladies and gentlemen? When they have a dignified life in their country and don't have to emigrate. In my country there have been more than two million people who have had to go outside to find their lives. None of you would want your children, parents or siblings to be treated the way we treat people from other countries, dragging dramas often generated by our foreign and economic policy. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I have a question for the previous speaker: you, like so many others, are talking about a 'Fortress Europe', a 'Fortress Europe' with barbed wire and very massively equipped. Can you answer the question whether it is really a fortress that inputs about 278 000 people into the fortress every year? Or is it just a holey fence, a wooden fence? Or is it really a fortress as open as Europe was in 2014? Perhaps you could answer that kindly.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Obermayr, I would like you to answer to me what happens to all those who die along the way, what about those who come and are mistreated, what happens to those who come and see their rights systematically violated. If we do not see that we are building a fortress with barbed wire, it is that we are having a very short look at the Europe we are building.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are no longer any reports of harassment and abuse by the police against asylum seekers and migrants trying to survive, for example in Calais. There are no more dead, drowned, missing at sea, starving on makeshift rafts, off Lampedusa or Istanbul. Demagogues and populists across Europe are exploiting foreigners by playing on fears. So what are you waiting for? What is the Council waiting for? Instead of looking elsewhere, does the Council not see that it is encouraging the xenophobic wave that is swelling all over Europe? Does the Council not see that it is withdrawal and not immigration that is undermining our societies? You know, politics is like air. It is when you lack it that you need it most. So show courage and politics! Ladies and gentlemen, Heads of State, I say that Frontex will not guarantee that all measures will be taken to ensure that the Mediterranean is not a graveyard. It takes courage, but above all we need a real common migration policy, with a safe legal path, especially for asylum seekers.

name: Diane James (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, today there have been more innocent victims of the human traffickers, but victims – I would say to everybody here in the Chamber this evening, the few of us that are here – of failed EU policies, the EU’s failure to control its borders and therefore  directly the responsibility of FRONTEX. Let us go through some figures, everybody. Let us just expose what we are talking about. An EU budget of EUR 84 million, 82 500 kilometres of land and sea borders to patrol and it works out at EUR 2.8 a day per kilometre and a detection rate of one in ten.  Look at the US, and I heard the comment about fortress Europe and such, but just look at the US. Funded to the tune of USD 13 billion with less than half the kilometres of borders to actually patrol and manage but it has invested in infrastructure and resources. It has fences, it has electronic and satellite surveillance and it has 20 000 agents patrolling. That level of investment delivers a detection rate of 61 % and starts to deal with the problem. Therefore, anyone reading those figures, understanding those figures, would recognise that FRONTEX is a complete and utter irrelevance. You do not have to be an economic migrant to actually want to come here and create a problem. You can be somebody quite legitimately getting hold of genuine papers but from somebody who is producing and supplying them unlawfully or illegally.  Where does that leave us? It leaves us with two very clear problems. EU policy has subverted the ability and the very will of Member States to control their borders and secondly, this state of affairs is a product quite clearly of the failings of EU policy on freedom of movement and labour and persons. I am going to leave you with some messages. The traffickers – yes, they can continue to line their pockets with vast amounts of cash. We are going to see more tragedies like we saw today. FRONTEX is not fit for purpose and it never will be. My message to you all and to the EU is to go back to the drawing board on EU policy or go back to the piggy bank and actually resource this properly.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, immigration policies are the clearest example of Europe's failure or, rather, of the desire to destroy a continent socially, economically and culturally. Let's not make fun of it. Frontex, first of all, should control Europe's borders. Where do they place his headquarters? In Warsaw. Evidently in the farthest place that can be useful to check the starting points of immigration arriving in Italy. EUR 600 million spent over ten years. EUR 5 million spent each year on the rent of this mammoth headquarters and staff. Out of 80 million euros of total budget in 2013, 30 million are needed to maintain the structure. So, of course, we are paying with public money for a bandwagon that has zero practical results when it comes to immigration.  Last year, 3 000 people died in the Mediterranean Sea, dying on the conscience of those who are calling on these people to leave. The only recipe is not Frontex, Triton, Mare Nostrum, Goofy, Pluto or Donald Duck, but it is to prevent these people from leaving helping them try not to escape hunger and war. A war that, however, this Europe likes, given that there is someone who is playing the war against Putin. Instead of deploying NATO men and means to unhinge that madness, that beast, that crap called ISIS, we are playing the war against Putin. So it's yet another demonstration of how taxpayers' money is being thrown away. Just copy from what others do, just copy from Canada, Australia and the developed countries: you don't need Frontex and immigration is controlled quietly.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE). -
text: As several colleagues have mentioned, more than three hundred people have died trying to reach our shores. Twenty-nine more died yesterday. I have said this several times in this Chamber: saving lives must be a priority! It is clear that we must discuss long-term policies and clearly attack the roots of this phenomenon: cooperating with third countries, creating corridors of legal migration, making every effort to ensure that human beings do not have to put their lives at risk to flee their countries. It is crucial that the European Union act swiftly and attack the roots of the problem, but this reality does not change by decree, it takes time. And, however, the migratory pressure does not seem to show signs of diminishing, to be evaluated by the information released by Frontex. In October I asked the European Commission for more information on the means and the range of action of Operation Triton, warning that it could call into question thousands of lives. The answer was confidential. For today's tragedy has made public that the means are clearly not sufficient. Today it has become public that the solidarity that founds this Union is not always put into practice. That is why, Madam President, I call on the European Commission and, above all, the Council to exercise its powers, with the sense of urgency and firmness.  \*(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, Mr Coelho you have just said quite rightly that the problem of immigration must be tackled at its root, but you did not mention Turkey.  We know that many cargo ships loaded with stowaways actually leave From Turkish ports. Do you not think that there is an urgent need to negotiate with Turkey in order for this to stop? Because finally, Turkey is a very advanced country that is able to keep its coasts. What do you think?

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, I fully agree with you. Turkey is a candidate country for membership of the European Union. In the area of neighbourhood policy, we have tools, tools, to invite him to cooperate more effectively with us.

name: Elnök asszony. -
text: We will now continue to debate the Council and Commission statements on further steps for Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office (2015/2527(RSP))

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (S&D). -
text: Madam President, is it a tragic coincidence that today, together with our debate, we had the horrific incident off the coast of Libya? Unfortunately, it's not. Whatever day we had our conversation, people would be at sea trying to reach the shores of Europe and many of them would drown. Coming from a country, Greece, which is under a lot of pressure every day at its external borders from migration flows, I am able to appreciate the role of FRONTEX and I assure you that without FRONTEX we would mourn many more victims. The situation in Africa and the Middle East places two tasks on us: guarding and protecting the Union's land and sea borders and ensuring the lives of refugees at sea. On this basis, and waiting for a comprehensive migration policy to finally be completed in the European Union, FRONTEX should be strengthened with the necessary resources and legislative power to save lives and to support the Member States, always with respect for fundamental rights. And let's not forget: Summer is coming and the wave of refugees will be huge.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR). -
text: Madam President, according to available data in 2014, the year was a record for the number of attempts to illegally enter the European Union. Around 270,000 people wanted to look for happiness in Europe, which accounts for a growth of 138% compared to the year before. More than 3,000 died trying. These are difficult human destinies, and we mustn't forget that. But we should also take into account how much of a threat to the safety of our citizens the influx of illegal migrants poses. Although the vast majority flee misery and war, some among them come with the aim of dealing with crime and expanding their terrorist networks. That is why I believe that we need to give the greatest possible support to Frontex and the competent authorities of the Member States that help save people's lives, but also represent a front line in the fight against terrorism and organised crime.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, representatives of the Council, we do not take away our mourning at the Mediterranean borders. I do not know if anyone has doubts about the need for operational cooperation at these external borders, which are everyone's. I, as a Spaniard, have to give you a Spanish example: the Spanish border towns of Ceuta and Melilla. There the Civil Guard and the police are overwhelmed, because they have to face a border with three serious problems: human trafficking, behind which are the mafias of illegal immigration; drug and arms smuggling; the entry and exit of people related to jihadist terrorism. All this affects the union as a whole, our security and freedoms, and affects the lives of migrants and refugees. Frontex must therefore be given more budget to also increase its human capacities and, of course, we must always think that we must combine this with a policy that can really be welcomed and can regulate flows. Because we are facing a historic catastrophe. I can also say that I am a daughter, niece and granddaughter of refugees.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, I have no objection to genuine cooperation between sovereign nation states and it would make sense for all European countries affected by illegal immigration to contribute financially to external border controls. But this is not what we are discussing. Everything here leads to an increase in EU power and dominion. The Commissioner said that Frontex should lead to a common border control system. He said that the Council intends to focus on implementing a common immigration and asylum system and the harmonisation of asylum application rules. These harmonised rules can be guaranteed to be more lax than the existing national rules. The EU wants to decide how many migrants should be allowed in and to which countries they should be sent.  Britain’s representative on the Council is of course David Cameron. No doubt, while telling British voters that he wants tighter immigration controls, he will simultaneously work to implement laxer EU rules on migration.

name: Vicky Maeijer (NI). -
text: Mr President, hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants entered the European Union in 2014, smuggled in by people smugglers or dragged ashore by Frontex. Frontex guards no borders. Frontex is a shuttle service. The EU is helping to facilitate tragedies. What we already knew, of course, but what many here do not want to see, was confirmed by the terrorists of the Islamic State last week. The Muslim terror group has smuggled 4 000 terrorists into the European Union as asylum seekers. In response to my written questions, the Commission replied that we should not confuse asylum seekers with terrorists. It is yet another sign of shocking naivety. To top it all off, Frontex is also unable to identify terrorists. Like all illegal immigrants, they are now being brought to the European continent. As far as I am concerned, there is only one way to go for Frontex, literally: back with those boats full of illegal immigrants to their country of origin or a third country. Because so far, they haven't sent anyone back. It is absurd that we are knowingly not only bringing thousands of illegal immigrants into our territory, but also receiving terrorists with open arms. We already have our hands full with our home grown Islamic terrorists. Please, let's not import them again. When will it dawn on the Commission that we must stop importing more terror? When did it end with this madness? We must take responsibility for protecting our citizens. They deserve that safety. De-Islamize, close the borders and stop mass immigration! Enough is enough! (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. I wanted to ask my colleague to explain for a moment the difference between a refugee and an economic migrant.

name: Vicky Maeijer (NI)
text: "blue card" answer. – Thank you, my colleague, for this question. Do you know what the problem is of this European Union? That the policy doesn't work. We've been seeing that for years now, and yet we're going to keep doing this. We continue to move forward with more money towards Frontex, knowing that Frontex does not guard a border, but only introduces people. We can't take on that flow of refugees anymore. Look at my own country. This year we are already 40 000 asylum seekers. You just can't. There's no way. Enough is enough. It just has to stop.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE). -
text: Sinjura President, illum qed nitkellmu, kif qalu l-kollegi tiegħi, fid-dell ta' traġedja oħra fil-Mediterran: rapporti li mijiet ta' persuni reġgħu tilfu ħjithom fi triqthom lejn l-Ewropa matul dan il-lejl. Is-sitwazzjoni fil-Libja qed tkompli tiħżien u sejra aktar lura. F'dan il-kuntest, il-UNHCR wissa lill-pajjiżi fil-Mediterran li mistenni jkun hemm żieda qawwija tan-nies li se jipprovaw jaqsmu lejn l-Ewropa hedge kif it-temp jitjieb.
