Il-UNHCR appella biex jiżdiedu r-riżorsi ta' tiftix u salvataġġ qabel il-vittmi jitilfu ħajjithom waqt li jkunu qed jittamaw għal ġejjieni ajarħ.  L-operazzjonijiet konġunti tal-FRONTEX huma effettivi skont kemm jagħmluhom effettivi l-pajjiżi membri. Jeħtieġ illi jsiru aktar sforzi biex il-pajjiżi membri jagħtu sehemhom. X'inhu meħtieġ biex il-FRONTEX tkun tista' twettaq dak li hu mistenni minnha fid-dawl tal-wasliet li huma previsti?  Irridu neżaminaw ukoll jekk il-fondi u l-assi Ewropej humiex qed jintużaw bl-aktar mod effettiv. Għaldaqstant irridu naraw jekk għandniex bżonn assi li bħalissa qed jintużaw xi mkien ieħor, pereżempju għall-operazzjoni kontra l-piraterija, l-EUNAVFOR, fis-Somalja, meta dawn l-assi jistgħu jkunu ta' użu aħjar fil-Mediterran sabiex jgħinu flower-FRONTEX u nawsalv il-ħajjiet.  Ma jistax ikun li jkun hawn min joqgħod b'idejh fuq żaqqu u mbagħad jgħaddu ftit tax-xhur oħra u jitwasslu l-kondoljanzi u jintesa kollox. Għandna bżonn li naġixxu.  Dwar l-EASO: mit-twaqqif tiegħu 'l hawn, l-EASO għamel ħafna xogħol u rridu nirringrazzjawhom tal-ħidma tagħhom. Madankollu, parti essenzjali mill-kompetenza ta' din l-aġenzija hi l-promozzjoni tar-rilokazzjoni ta' min igawdi minn protezzjoni internazzjonali. Aħna għal darb'oħra qegħdin ngħidu hawnhekk li qed nistennew li l-EASO jieħu f'idejh it-tmexxija ta' din il-kwistjoni u, bl-aktar mod attiv, jippromwovi dan il-kun大ett fost il-pajjiżi membri.  Inti, ir-rappreżentanta tal-Kunsill, għidt ukoll li hemm bżonn ta' iżjed solidarjetà. Aħna qed nistennew ukoll mill-Kunsill li jippromwovi din is-solidarjetà fil-prattika qalb il-pajjiżi membri.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D). -
text: Madam President! Not a week goes by without a refugee tragedy in the Mediterranean. This Monday, 29 people froze to a ship, and today we have heard this tragic news. Every time we are affected again, and I do not know how many times we have debated this in this House in recent years. Each of these incidents and each of the ensuing debates reinforced the sense of helplessness. It is dangerous to get used to it, and it is irresponsible to carry on as before. The wave of refugees will not abate in the face of the worsening humanitarian situation in our neighbourhood. Our instruments, especially the Dublin system, are not designed for this. We need new approaches, we need new thinking. Above all, however, it is a question of relieving countries at the EU's external borders and of safe entry corridors. The Austrian Minister of the Interior, Mikl-Leitner, has made an interesting proposal with the 'Safe Lives' model, and she has also presented this model to this House in the LIBE Committee. The Commission and the Council should give serious consideration to these proposals.

name: Karol Karski (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Due to increasing migratory pressure not only on the southern but also on the Eastern External Border of the European Union, the role of Frontex, which is facing new challenges, is increasing. The recent tragic events concerning migrants smuggled on cargo ships from Turkey to Italy and abandoned at sea by smugglers clearly show that coordination between Member States is necessary, as well as the need to increase support measures.  The European Commission must also be aware of the seriousness of the situation at the European Union's eastern external border. Due to the war in Donbass, Polish population fleeing war and persecution from eastern Ukraine has already begun to flow into the country. The European Commission must realise that Poland may need resources and assistance at any time to receive a huge number of migrants from eastern Ukraine due to the unrecified conflict in Ukraine. I therefore also have a question for the Commissioner: what action has the Commission taken and allocated in the event of a large influx of refugees from Ukraine to Polish?

name: Gerolf Annemans (NI). -
text: The Frontex issue is a clear illustration of the fact that the whole concept of the European Union is a boulevard of broken dreams. The Member States have ceded their national borders, the so-called internal borders, to the European Union. In return, the European Union would guard the external borders with Frontex. The result is now known. The internal borders disappeared, but the external borders did not come. In this way, beautiful and idyllic-sounding intentions and principles of freedom of movement for people and goods and open borders for all and everyone have become an immigration magnet, a social tragedy in which the poor of our own people in the neighbourhoods foot the bill in terms of liveability and security. Above all, these fine intentions have become a failure and a break of the promises and commitments that have been made between the Member States and the European Union. Pacta sunt servanda. We will continue to fight within the European Union for a review of the whole system, including Schengen.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the tragedies that occur almost daily in the Mediterranean show us that it is time to act resolutely. I will allow myself to raise four lines of thought. Firstly, Frontex does not have its own technical equipment and depends on the goodwill of the Member States. A partial solution to this problem would be to systematically register all assets co-financed by the Internal Security Fund in Frontex's equipment fleet. Moreover, since the end of Operation Mare Nostrum, the issue of patrols in international waters remains unresolved, while this is where shipwrecks are most frequent. What is your plan to respond to this dilemma? Secondly, cooperation between the various European agencies - EASO and Frontex, but also Eurojust and Europol - should be strengthened, particularly with regard to data sharing. This is the only way to strengthen mutual trust between Member States and the various agencies and to gradually lead to the establishment of a genuine integrated border management system. In the case of EASO, its action is in particular concerned with assistance and training. However, it is dispensed at the request of the Member States and on a voluntary basis. How can we determine priorities and needs in light of the failures we are seeing in the various Member States, for example by involving the European Parliament more actively? Finally, we must ask ourselves what is the case with the actions carried out in the framework of the task force for the Mediterranean. What can we learn from the task force's action? What are the concrete and viable solutions, as well as good practices to remember? We must have the courage and the political will to also establish a genuine migration diplomacy, which also requires a strengthened role of agencies, which can become real interlocutors and credible partners for third countries.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D). -
text: Sinjura President, fil-qasam ta' kif popli minn barra l-Ewropa jitťallew jiżu jgťixu fiha, hemm tliet fatturi li jridu jiżu żviluppati flimkien jekk se naffaèjaw b'mod koerenti l-isfidi li qed iwasslu biex ikun hemm żaqliq qawwi ta' popolazzjonijiet lejna. U rridu nżommu koerenti wkoll mal-valuri li jikkostitwixxu l-Ewropa. Fl-ewwel post, irid ikun hemm viťilanza serja mal-fruntieri tal-Unjoni. Gťad baqa' ťafna xi jsir f'dal-qasam. Il-pajjiżi li jinsabu fil-fruntiera tal-Unjoni waťedhom mhux jirnexxielhom ilaťťqu mal-problemi. L-isforz komuni sadattant gťadu mhux biżżejjed. Fit-tieni post, gťandu jkollna politika ta' gťoti u tťaddim ta' ażil li tkun komprensiva, ażżornata u kkordinata sew. Saru passi siewja f'dan is-sens imma baqa' żafna xi jsir speèjalment fil-mod kif il-piżijiet jitqassmu bejn il-pajjiżi members, il-burden sharing. U fit-tielet post, gťandha tiddaťťal politika komuni dwar immigrazzjoni legale fl-Unjoni li tissodisfa t-talba gťal aktar żaddiema f'erti pajjiżi members u li tirrifletti bżonnijiet ekonomiżi different f'pajjiżi members oťra. Politika bťal din tkun tista' tikkanalizza t-talba gťal immigrazzjoni ekonomika minn barra l-Unjoni u tgťin fl-ikkalibrar tal-politika ta' viťilanza tal-fruntieri. Toffri qafas razzjonali u ťanin gťall-problemi umani kbar li tirrappreżenta kwalunkwe forma ta' migrazzjoni. B'xorti żażina, l-anqas li żiet żviluppata sa issa, kienet din il-politika komuni dwar l-immigrazzjoni legale, anke jekk dan hu qasam fejn l-gťajta ta' aktar Ewropa l-aktar li jagťmel sens. Sa issa, kien biss il-President ta' dal-Parlament Martin Schulz li l-aktar ta gťarfien lil din il-prijorità. Hu f'qafas ta' politika gťal migrazzjoni legale li l-isforzi biex titťaddem il-viżilanza fil-fruntieri u biex l-ażil ikun regolat jistgťu jsiru aktar effettivi.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR). -
text: Madam President! In view of the major crises in Africa and the Middle East, we are faced with a permanently high level of migration to Europe. The UN has just determined that around 52 million people worldwide are on the run. A large part of this is stated as a destination Germany. We need to look at both asylum seekers and economic migrants. This separation is difficult, because many economic refugees destroy their documents in order to protect themselves from deportation. The debate on this issue is poisoned because the mainstream in politics supports immigration and often enough protects even legally rejected migrants from deportation. We in the EU must finally come up with a concept that clearly signals to the outside world that economic migrants will not be tolerated and that people without documents will be deported as soon as possible. The resulting smuggling crime – which has been spreading unmolested for years and is constantly finding new ways – must not lead to the development of an industry here that benefits from illegal migration. At the same time, the EU must ensure greater justice in the distribution of asylum seekers. Germany cannot accept more asylum seekers than all the countries bordering the Mediterranean.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI). -
text: Madam President! It is the wrong way to address the issue of illegal immigration only at the level of border security. What is needed is measures that start much earlier, because that is the only way to combat illegal immigration effectively. First of all, agreements are needed with the main transit states in order to prevent the entry and transit of illegal immigrants already in those states. The control of smuggling requires rigorous controls. We must also make this clear to Turkey. Similarly, the large amounts of development aid should consequently create an incentive for the population not to leave their country of origin. This makes it all the more important for the Union to look at how development aid is used in recipient countries and whether the right people get the money. Frontex's work is not bad, but Frontex needs even more competence – competence to return the illegals to their ports of departure accordingly. For me, Frontex is a good example among the Union's many pointless agencies.

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. In view of the dramas taking place in the Mediterranean, one of the priorities of action should be to urgently develop a new frontex strategy, including the establishment of a new, more effective framework for cooperation between member states' border services and Frontex.  I would like to address the Latvian Presidency – today it has become clear that there is an urgent need for greater, solidarity-based involvement of all the Member States of the Union and, above all, of those which are not burdened with migratory pressure in the Mediterranean, in frontex's operational activities. At the moment, participation in terms of sharing equipment and people is insufficient. So instead of focusing on the debate on the Common Border Guard, maybe we should focus more on an integrated approach to joint rescue operations.  It should also be borne in mind that Member States are parties to the Convention on the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) and the Rescue Convention (SAR) and, in fulfilling their international obligations, cannot expect Frontex to do everything itself. Therefore, it seems that if the Latvian Presidency had taken action to increase the participation of Member States in Frontex's coordination and operational activities in the supply of equipment and people, it would have been a huge success. Solidarity on security issues, including security in the Mediterranean, is extremely necessary for the Union today.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Our discussion was largely marked by a lot of chaos. It is only the speeches of Mr Karski or Mrs Kudrycka that seem to sort things out a little, and let us have no doubt that, yes, Frontex is an agency that is all the way to go. The fact that it is located in Warsaw is an advantage rather than a defect, about which one of his colleagues said. Initially, we need to be very clear about the concepts, because we are talking about all sorts of immigration (as a rule, these are forced situations): it is political, economic immigration, because of religious persecution, for humanitarian reasons or because of the persecution of minorities of various kinds. And asylum policy – in asylum policy it is important that we start to do it in a de facto integrated way, that is, Frontex should have greater powers over the Member States, because Frontex is not an army of border guards. I think that in asylum policy we should pay attention to one more rather important humanitarian aspect. We have states, we have millions of people mingling in different places as a result of wars. I wanted to appeal: let us prepare a programme in asylum policy, particularly for young people, for a limited period of time. Let us give them the chance to finish school, perhaps to complete their studies, with a commitment to return to their own country and there to build and transfer European values. We all need such a new impetus from the Commission.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. It is no coincidence that I am speaking as the third Pole in a row – frontex agency or at least located in our country. It is not coincidentally located there, because Poland, alongside Finland, has the longest eastern external border of the Union. Of course, we need to talk today and about the southern border, but we also need to talk about the eastern border. In the context of what is happening there, in the context of war – not formal but actual – behind the eastern border of the European Union, there is a very likely high migration (which is already happening) from Ukraine. Is the European Union already prepared for this? Is the European Commission prepared for this? Not only conceptually, intellectually, but also in a financial sense, because even if, may it turn out tomorrow, that this war will be suspended for some time, then the issue of economic migration will be topical. We must be prepared for this as a Union.

name: Udo Voigt (NI). -
text: Madam President, dear colleagues! Since I have been a member of this House, we have been talking about what Mare Nostrum has done great. But at the same time, we are also talking about the fact that in November last year the funds for Mare Nostrum were running out. Since then, however, nothing has really happened. Matteo Renzi said in his inaugural address here in this House: we can only combat migration if we tackle the causes of migration. The causes of migration have not been and continue to be discussed in this House, but about how we can continue to bring refugees to Europe. So you have to make a decision. Frontex has done a great job in the past. Frontex was proud of the Hera, Poseidon and Hermes operations, which succeeded in reducing migration by 60-90%. Now we have Mare Nostrum – the result: 131% increase in migration. But now there is no money left for Mare Nostrum. What happens? Obviously, no one has told the refugees of poverty that there is no money left and that there is no more rescue. They continue to sit down in the ships. They are still being taken to sea by people smugglers in the hope that someone will come to save them. If you say A, you have to say B. Either you lead Frontex to the real task of securing the borders; but if you want to continue Mare Nostrum, you also have to provide the means for it.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have heard very distant positions in this House, and I would add, unfortunately. Europe as a fortress or even it has been said that neither Triton nor Frontex are needed. Instead, I would like to begin with what Mr Juncker said when he took office. The problem of immigration is a European problem. So Europe is there, Europe must be more involved, and I believe that the Commission and the Council have taken note, after everything that is happening and what has happened. We have three important points which are: security, legality and humanitarian data. It is not acceptable that women, children and people who want to come to Europe to find refuge can still die, because they are not just illegals. As far as security is concerned, we must also combat what is a new terror alert. As far as legality is concerned, there are criminal organisations, think of the scandal that happened in Italy where gangs ran the immigrant business. And then, I repeat the humanitarian fact. Commissioner, given that we have talked about budgets, funds, resources and resources, including human resources, and that the head of Frontex has said that the means are there, that the resources are there and that they do not need other means, then what is the truth? Can Frontex and Triton be strengthened, certainly involving the other Member States, do we need new resources or do we just need a new organisation? That is what I want to ask the Commissioner.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D). -
text: Madam President, the perception in the European Union that the migration phenomenon is a pressure imposes a challenge on Frontex, not only to increase its ambition and extend the radius of its action, but also, and above all, to adapt it to European standards and European law; also for Eurosur, the new sea rescue system on European borders. Frontex needs to expand its ambition and range of action, to begin with, in Operation Triton, because it does not live up to the ambition deployed by Mare Nostrum, and triton would need to be a 'Mare Nostrum plus' but, above all, of a European dimension, to demand from the Member States an intelligent conjugation with asylum policy and immigration policy , which has to open doors to regular immigration, especially through the solidarity clause, by establishing the financing clauses for this management of external borders. That's why it's impossible to rely only on Frontex as the only tool. It must be put in connection with the need to combat mafias, illicit human trafficking, and also with cooperation at source with those States whose desperation is the source of this European perception of immigration as a problem, as a challenge, even as a threat, and not as an opportunity, as must be understood in the European Union.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Frontex is an unfit attempt to alleviate the symptoms of a failed asylum and migration policy in Europe. I deliberately distinguish between asylum and migration policy. Europeans are partly responsible for the crisis in the Middle East and the collapse of the order in North Africa in asylum policy. For the asylum seekers, we have a duty to allow safe access to Europe, so that not only young men come to us, but especially the most vulnerable among the refugees, namely the elderly, women and children, for whom, unfortunately, the road is far too arduous today. We have clear rules in migration. In other words, we must draw up an immigration law so that everyone who wants to come to Europe is also aware of whether they have a right to come to us and whether they are also welcome here, so that hundreds of thousands of people are not ultimately deported after excessively long procedures and have risked their lives in vain. Europe has no concept, and thousands pay for it with their lives. On the other hand, your repeated crocodile tears, which have been repeatedly on display every few weeks, do not help either, ladies and gentlemen!

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE). -
text: Madam President, first of all, let me respond to the colleagues who have spoken here about Frontex. In my opinion, Frontex is one of the important agencies, if not the most important. Migratory pressures are increasing and this puts the Agency in a position where its effective functioning is threatened and thus the security of the European Union is also threatened. Faced with migratory flows from the south, Member States are putting constant pressure on the European Union, so more and more tasks are being shifted to Frontex. In my opinion, it's the right thing to do. But at the same time, these states must be prepared to cooperate and help as much as possible. Let us therefore consider how to improve, streamline and, first and foremost, make Frontex's cooperation with individual Member States more transparent.  Furthermore, there is the question of Frontex's capacities, both financial and personnel, which we need to adapt to current needs as soon as possible. Here I am clear that there are two things that must not be spared and will not be spared. The first is saving lives and the second is the protection of the EU's external borders and thus the security of European citizens. Finally, I would also like to mention one problem that my pre-speaking people have already touched on here. We must not forget that Frontex is supposed to protect the borders of the entire EU, i.e. it is also intended to protect the eastern borders. And here, let us pay particular attention to the threat of immigration, which is linked to the crisis in Ukraine.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D). -
text: Madam President, fortress Europe and the 'all security' can no longer remain the alpha and omega of our common migration policy. On the contrary, we must work as much as possible to respect the fundamental rights of migrants and asylum seekers.  More than border surveillance, the real priority is the coherent and effective implementation of the common European asylum system. In this sense, the European Asylum Support Office has a key coordinating role to play, particularly in the area of refugee resettlement programmes and the implementation of humanitarian visas. In order for EASO to meet this ambitious and essential objective, it is important to substantially increase the European funds allocated to it. announced that the European Union will provide financial support of EUR 1 billion as part of its regional strategy for Syria and Iraq for the years 2015 and 2016.  EASO has a place to take in this strategy. The work is immense: helping refugees on the ground, especially the most vulnerable, improving the capacity of asylum systems in neighbouring countries, but also and above all, stepping up our efforts to take in more asylum seekers in the European Union, in decent conditions and through safe and legal access routes.  The majority of people who wish to reach Europe today are fleeing war and have the right to international protection. It is not about flow or pressure, but about people: men, women and children in search of a better future.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE). -
text: Madam President, all Member States have to meet the challenge of the growing migratory flow. It is a common challenge that requires to be dealt with together. Our toolbox is limited but we need to use all the tools we have before talking about new routes. We need to increase humanitarian aid and help the neighbouring countries that are receiving millions of refugees, and support regional protection programmes.  Let us implement the new asylum package in full, and I would like here to call on the Commission, present here today, to do everything it can to bridge the gaps. As Vice-President Timmermans was saying, and rightly so, we need to harmonise practices, exchange practices, and do capacity-building, and there is a lot that Frontex and EASO can do in this respect. They have an important role to play.  But Frontex and EASO should be better resourced and strengthened, once again by all Member States. It is unacceptable that only a few Member States participate in these operations. Those here who are demonising the great job that Frontex is doing without offering any alternatives are just irresponsible, as people are dying. Member States should also fully implement Dublin, but that requires a Eurodac function and again, I would like to know what the Commission and the Member States are doing for the thousands of asylum seekers who come unregistered, unprocessed, to countries like Sweden. How can we implement Dublin – which has just been revised – in these circumstances? We need also to join forces on combating the trafficking of people, and undertake increased cooperation with countries like Turkey. Some people here talk about fortress Europe. Again, it is irresponsible. We are talking about combating criminals who are smuggling women and children fleeing for their lives. The key word here is more responsibility amongst all Member States, including responding to the desperate call of UNHCR for a resettlement programme. I conclude by saying that we have the tools. We should be able to live up to being a humanitarian superpower if all the Member States take responsibility as they should.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I would like to stress that, apart from the migration and refugee problems in southern Europe, we must look more and more at Eastern Europe. The Crimean crisis has led Ukraine to take 14th place today among the countries of origin of refugees in the European Union. Today, Mrs Morvai and Mr Jakovčić presented us with a real danger and a possible failure in the case of border control between Hungary, the Schengen Member State, and Serbia. This proves to us that it is necessary to pay more attention to the protection of our borders elsewhere, not just to the south. Romania is an important partner in securing the eastern borders and fully meets the criteria for joining Schengen. I think it is time for politicians to recognise this reality as well. That is why I call for more effort, more honesty and certainly more transparency in romania's integration into the Schengen area. I want to stress that FRONTEX must not mean tightening controls at a Schengen border that does not cover Romania and Bulgaria. I also ask the European Commission to confirm whether or not there is a system for monitoring how the amounts allocated to refugee defence programmes outside Europe have been used and to provide us with their reports.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the umpteenth lampedusa massacre requires Europe as a whole to reflect on what must be the most appropriate strategy to be applied to deal with migratory flows unprecedented in the history of our continent, if it is true that landings continue to increase and with them deaths at sea. Operation Triton, as it has been structured up to now, has proved to be totally inadequate in resources and resources. Suffice it to say that it costs EUR 3 million per month, while operation Mare Nostrum was having an impact on the Italian Government's coffers of EUR 9.3 million per month. That is why resources and means must necessarily be integrated through the participation, in my view absolutely obligatory and not optional, of the Member States, through the application of the principle of solidarity, which must be the discriminating element of Europe. But we also need to change the principle of the Dublin Regulation – as has been said on several sides – which obliges refugees to seek asylum only in the state of first port. Action must also be taken on border nations, so that they exercise every possible control in advance in order to contain the departures of migrants. Finally, we must also not underestimate the real risk of terrorist infiltration among immigrants, as some secret services have expressed in recent weeks, which is another absolute emergency that must be tackled with due firmness.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, since the beginning of Operation Triton, we have announced that it is totally inadequate and inadequate, not only because it does not have the means to respond in an emergency situation such as the one that occurred only two days ago in Lampedusa, but also because there is no real search and rescue mandate at sea, while people continue to embark and die. Moreover, it operates only 30 miles beyond Italian territorial waters, while Mare Nostrum operated up to 172 miles. In that difference in space people die again, they have started to die again. That's the only difference we have. Those who previously said that Mare Nostrum had to be eliminated because it encouraged departures have been tragically disproved by the facts, because since the beginning of this year, without Mare Nostrum, they have increased by 60%. Here we need a European Mare Nostrum, we finally need a response from those governments that have so far been too selfish and too jealous of their competences to give a truly European response that is increasingly necessary. I would ask the Latvian Presidency to say this to the governments in the Council, and I would like you to remind them of our responsibility as Europeans and that we finally find a common response.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I view this phenomenon in two ways. First, the causes of this phenomenon should be established and work should be done in the direction that the causes are eliminated, and on the other hand the mechanisms we have at our disposal should be used to the maximum.  It should be known that we live in very turbulent times, from the southeast of Europe, not only Europe but also the world, we are talking about the crisis in Ukraine, we are talking about the situation in Greece, we know what is happening in Africa, at the same time Syria, Iraq, the Mediterranean. So it's hard times and Europe has to find a way to respond to it. I am committed to addressing crisis areas and addressing this diplomatically and trying to reduce crisis hot spots. In this way, we will also reduce the flow of refugees. This is not easy, of course it is easy to talk, however at the same time we have mechanisms available these days. And this morning when we talked about terrorism and yesterday when we talked about traffic violations, we kept saying that we should use the intelligence mechanisms that states have and that states need to communicate better with each other. We go back to that all the time. So we don't need new mechanisms, we need old mechanisms to use, but when it comes to Frontex, then all Member States need to participate, all Member States have to provide funding. It is not only Italy and the southern states that are under the greatest pressure to provide the greatest funds.  Since I come from Croatia, I am very sensitive to the issue of refugees and displaced persons. Since only 25 years ago there were 550,000 refugees in Croatia itself, within a small country of 4.5 million. And there were also another 150,000 who had to go abroad. And I'm really sensitive to this phenomenon. However, the fact is that we need to find the means, that we need to help to get Frontex to its fullness of benefits. Likewise, Mare Nostrum was an excellent mechanism, Triton is solid, but it needs to be helped to come to full expression.   (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" question. Perhaps I have not understood correctly, I would like to ask my colleague what the situation in Greece has to do with the flight from Libya or the war in Ukraine.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. Maybe you didn't get what I wanted to say very well. I wanted to say that we live in very turbulent times, that the crisis is all around in Europe itself and that Europe must gather enough strength, enough energy, enough spirit to respond to all the problems, and that is why I have used Greece, among other problems that Europe is facing at the moment.

name: Michał Boni (PPE). -
text: Madam President, firstly Frontex and EASO need to cooperate closely with third countries and develop dialogues with the countries of origin and transition. EASO should strengthen its activities and support the Commission and Member States by providing necessary assistance. We need one focused and well-coordinated approach to this issue. We need to simplify procedures related to asylum.  Secondly, EASO should further play its role in the collection and exchange of information, as well as developing an early-warning and preparedness system, also using data processing properly. Frontex should further focus on enhancing the capacities of the border guard community and on developing capacity-building projects in third countries, but first of all those agencies should have their own sufficient capacities adequately financed by the EU and Member States. We need much more European solidarity in that area.  Thirdly, we are focused on Mediterranean countries but, looking to the east, we should be prepared for a possible immigration flow. The situation in Ukraine is deteriorating and the number of internally displaced people is nearly one million. That is why both agencies should also be strongly involved in the activities in this area.  Fourthly – but this is only part of the problem – we need a new framework for a comprehensive European immigration policy responding to real recent and future challenges and we need to define the role of those agencies, or one strong agency, in line with the new policy.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE). -
text: Madam President, frontex and the European Asylum Support Office face a major challenge in how to respond to rapidly growing trends of pressure on the Borders of the European Union and the growing number of asylum applications sought by as many as 530,000 people last year. Crisis hot spots in Africa are not calming down, and smugglers and traffickers are increasingly ingenious and cruel in their actions. A large number of immigrants disappear after crossing the border with the European Union, and this is of particular concern in the case of ISIS fighters returning to Europe. Terrorist attacks and threats sent to European Union citizens indicate that we will need to step up our external border protection measures as well as controls within the common asylum system. This is why it is necessary to increase the budget for the work of both agencies and increase their powers.  Cooperation should be established with Turkey that does not respond to ghost ships, and almost 90% of illegal immigrants are detected at the european union's sea border. Cooperation is needed with western Balkan countries from which radicals joining ISIS come. An important role will also be played by Croatia, the country from which I come, because we have the longest border in the European Union and of course we are preparing to enter Schengen.  Through the cooperation of both these agencies and the support of the other bodies, we must respond to new challenges without losing the spirit of humanism woven into the foundations of the European Union.

name: Milan Zver (PPE). -
text: Mobility is a reality, centuries old. But there has never been such a strong wave of migrants in Europe. Last year alone, a quarter of a million illegal crossings of the European Union's borders were illegal. It will be difficult to implement the common migration and asylum policy if we do not have adequate joint institutions. I therefore support a stronger and more effective Frontex, including the European Asylum Office and other bodies. It is important that we are aware of the causes of migratory pressures. The intolerable circumstances in some countries are forcing people to leave their fate to traffickers just to get to Europe. When migration occurs, it must be properly managed, managed in an integrated way. Political immigrants know how to deal with it, as determined by the Geneva Convention. The challenge for the European Union is to tackle the problem of illegal economic migrants. We therefore need a new immigration policy in the European Union, with clear criteria that also takes into account the needs of the labour market and the social prospects of European societies. We must not give potential immigrants false hope, we must not encourage them to ming for the supposed paradise. The absorption potential of the European Union is not great. Illegal immigration can also be enthed by encouraging the development of countries from which refugees come in different ways. I would add that we must also improve the implementation of the common asylum policy and counter the abuse of asylum procedures.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE). -
text: Madam President! Firstly, thank you to the Presidency and to First Vice-President Timmermanns for the statement we have received here today. After all, in recent months we have experienced one tragedy after another in the Mediterranean off Africa, so I very much agree with the Commission's comments that we need to look at how Frontex operates and will operate in the future. I also agree with the Presidency when it says that we need to be more reactive to the flows of integration. There is therefore a need to strengthen cooperation, not least in relation to third countries.  In addition, there are some organised people smugglers who shovel money into people's misfortune. That is why my concern today, as I would like to draw the Commissioner's attention to, is that we need bigger budgets both for Frontex, where we need to look at both the budgets and the powers, and also very much for Europol. I believe that this debate has forgotten this: we must try to unite in Europol in order to crack the rings of people smugglers. Is this something the Commissioner agrees with?

name: Barbara Matera (PPE). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after months of comparison, it is therefore clear to everyone that the problem of managing migratory flows is not only a problem for border states, such as Italy and Malta, but a problem for Europe as a whole. But it also seems clear to me that this awareness is difficult to translate into a common migration and action policy. The instruments put in place are deficient. Frontex struggles to ensure a balance between the need for security and humanitarian responsibility. Last night's 400 deaths demonstrate, with brutal realism, how bankrupt its management and management of Operation Triton is. These massacres are triggering outrage from so many representatives of international communities. I recall the words of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, António Guterres, who reminded us just yesterday, with disarming lucidity, how the failure of this mission will soon result in new, unmanageable tragedies. The Mediterranean was once a crossroads of grandiose civilizations, but today it has become a theatre of death. New unnamed corpses, but still landless faces. The increase in arrivals will result in a proliferation of asylum applications, and so, Commissioner Timmermans, Madam Representative of the Council, the image of a limp system becomes clear. Without structural intervention approaching this issue in a holistic form, we will not be able to deal with this announced emergency.

name: József Nagy (PPE). -
text: The tragic news of the 400 new victims in the Mediterranean is saddening. At the word level, we have repeatedly committed ourselves to strengthening Frontex and not to allow this to be the infiltration route for foreign jihadist fighters and not to make the Mediterranean a graveyard. Overburdened Frontex has neither the capacity nor the financial support to carry out the new tasks properly and therefore needs its support. Unfortunately, the stagnation so far is also the basis for misconceptions and harmful views, such as the renewal of the introduction of border controls within the Schengen zone so that terrorists can be screened at the borders. I therefore strongly support the need to seek to create a complex structure rather than plugting holes, as the Commissioner has indicated. In addition to what has been said, this includes the cooperation of the military, criminal, intelligence and immigration bodies of the Member States. And I have said many times that we should also start providing targeted information immediately in the source countries of refugees and immigrants.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, more than 300 lives have been lost, more than 300 victims have ended up at the bottom of the sea off the coast of Europe. Mr President, this is yet another tragedy that could have been avoided if only this House and our institutions had been more attentive, more decisive, less than I can tell. Europe needs, as several colleagues have said, an effective rescue system to be recovered. Triton is totally inadequate, as several authoritative personalities admit today. We must radically change our approach, we must finally give weight to human rights, following the Italian example of Mare Nostrum.  What we are asking for, the commitment we are also asking for this evening is a European Mare Nostrum: do not leave Italy alone and no longer abandon migrants to their fate. Mr President, Europe, our institutions, this Parliament are not yet looking the other way.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr Timmermans, an immediate change to Dublin is needed so that Greece can stop turning into a warehouse of souls. To establish a solidarity clause for the distribution of migration flows and refugees in all the Member States of the European Union, depending on their extent, GDP and population. So I ask, Mr Timmermans, what measures does the Commission intend to take to initiate the Dublin change? I hope this time you will answer me and not throw the ball on the podium, as you did in the previous debate. Finally, I would like to point out to you by microphone that what you said earlier does not concern me, because my struggles are known not only against racism and xenophobia but also for Germany's compensation of the families of Greek citizens and the Jews of Thessaloniki who were executed in the Nazi camps. So you knocked on the wrong door, Mr Timmermans. Make your comments elsewhere. That's not what they pass on to me. Just so we're explained.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, Mr Timmermans, Mrs Kalniưa, last Monday, 29 migrants died of hypothermia because, after being rescued by the Italian coast guard off Libya, they spent 18 hours in the cold due to a lack of patrol vessels capable of protecting them under the deck, as Mrs Kalniưa says. These people were not criminals, but human beings in need of protection and assistance.  The European Union must urgently and collectively ensure a strong capacity to carry out search, rescue and landing operations for immigrants, as well as support for countries with the most pressure-seeking asylum and reception systems.  It therefore calls for Member States to increase economic contributions to FRONTEX to strengthen their resources, to expand their competences and areas of activity. It is also important to strengthen cooperation between Member States in external border controls, in the referral of illegal immigrants to their countries of origin, neither by allowing those who are expelled to be subjected to abuse by border and coastal guards or collective expulsions to countries where their fundamental rights are not respected.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, Hasana Alia is a young Saharawi activist. He was to be tried by a Moroccan military court and applied for international protection. He is supported by UNHCR, but that did not prevent the Spanish government from denying him asylum.  Like others, hasana's case, now based in Euskal Herria, portrays how far away the European Union is and, of course, the Spanish state, from being a space of rights. Today perhaps it would have been more useful and real to hear here his testimony, that of a Saharawi persecuted by the Moroccan State and under threat of expulsion by the Spanish state. By the way, while it is justified here or is about giving Frontex legitimacy, Morocco has just razed the migrant camps on Mount Gurugú, near the infamous Melilla fence. Most are potential asylum seekers: they are people, not a problem, not a threat. I invite you to talk to them, so you know what's really going on.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: Thank you very much! Commissioner Timmermans, do not take the device off, because I would like to speak to you again. I'm going to do it again because you refused to answer my question in this morning's debate.  You spoke so nicely about the importance of the rule of law, that is, the importance of consistent compliance with the law in the previous debate. Let us now look at a practical example: according to the relevant legislation, a person who has the appropriate travel documents can enter the European Union, enter at a designated border crossing point, verify his identity, and, more, there are a few other relevant pieces of legislation. By comparison, around 1 500 illegal border offenders enter the Hungarian-Serbian border every day and do not meet these conditions.  Dear Commissioner, Please inform me how you think this is compatible with the rule of law, the rule of law and what you and the European Union might wish to do to put an end to this situation.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the massacre the day before yesterday is unfortunately only the first confirmed massacre this year and the toll is even greater than the tragedy in Lampedusa that led to the establishment of Mare Nostrum, which, thanks to Italian generosity and self-denial, saved over 150 000 lives. That sacrifice like that was useless, we went back in time. In fact, this time the migrants died on board patrol boats that traveled 100 miles by force 8 because there were no Triton ships in the area. Triton that lacks the humanitarian aspect that Mare Nostrum carried out. Triton that does not go beyond 30 miles, while Mare Nostrum sometimes went to rescue to the coast of Libya. Triton which has only 2,900,000 euros per month while Mare Nostrum had 9,500,000. Then let's get ready for more massacres. If European leaders do not really address this issue, if they do not acknowledge that migrants leave anyway – in fact the landings have increased – if a humanitarian corridor is not established, we will prepare for horror accounting.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: Mr President, honourable Members, Honourable Mr Timmermans, I must state that dublin regulations and agreements are extremely unreasonable and unfair because they place the burden on border states. Thus, all the burden of a huge refugee flow is currently burdening Italy, Greece and Bulgaria, on a huge migration wave.  In the last year alone, more than 14 000 illegal immigrants entered the territory of Bulgaria legally. No one knows how many entered illegally. The Bulgarian economy cannot afford to withstand this huge migratory pressure anymore. And here is your role and frontex's role in finding a fairer distribution of this burden and organising the burden of illegal immigration more fairly and more responsibly.  And here comes the next problem: the problem is with the role of Turkey, which organizes trafficking on the territory of Italy, on the territory of Greece and on the territory of Bulgaria. I think you should think about sanctions against Turkey, Commissioner.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE). -
text: Mr. President, this debate has shown that we need more Europe.  This debate has shown the concern of us MEPs and MEPs from many parts of Europe starting from Poland and the entire border to Spain. It shows that we need more Europe. And it is those who are most critical in this situation who are unaware of the fact that without more Europe, without a stronger Frontex, without greater investment in what security at our borders means, it will not be good for anyone in the European Union.  We need humanitarian corridors, we need a new asylum policy, we need absolute solidarity between member states, because Italy cannot bear the greatest burden of all this that is happening. We need more Europe, and that's why I call on all of us to have more Europe.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, this debate is about the way forward for Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office – at least that is what I thought it was, but it has become a debate about much more than that. It has become a debate about what is arguably one of the biggest challenges European societies have faced, and will face, for perhaps a generation. Migration is an issue with daunting complexity – all sides of the migration issue – and therefore I would warn against politicians who have very simple, one-dimensional solutions to such a daunting challenge. Frontex is not going to solve this; the Office is not going to solve this; just building ever-stronger borders is not going to solve this; putting an end to free movement is not going to solve this. If I were a father with children in Homs or in Damascus and I wanted my children to survive a terrible war and therefore I would try and flee to Europe, do you think that, for one second, I would ask myself, ‘Is there free movement in Europe or is there not?’ No! I would look for a way to save my children, and I think that is completely justified. We would kill the fundamental values we share as Europeans if we would deny people the right – if they have to flee – to flee to a safe haven. But that is not the only dimension of this issue. The other dimension is that this is also an economic activity exploited by very dangerous criminals. So you cannot have the naive answer of saying: just let everybody in. Just imagine what would happen to our inner cities if we were to have a completely open-door policy in terms of migration. Just look what would happen to the fabric of our societies if we were to do that. So there is no room for being naive. This is not a conspiracy of big corporations in a capitalist world to create migration flows. Come on, let us not try and sell people this sort of nonsense. This is a consequence of the world as it is today, with many facets. That is why the Commission will present a holistic approach to the migration issue, because at the same time Europe is struggling with illegal immigration, it is struggling with the need for solidarity between European nations in tackling the issue of illegal migration and asylum seekers. But at the same time, Europe will need migration for our economy, for our sciences, for the structure of our societies. Europe is in a demographic place where we will have fewer people in Europe without immigration over a longer period of time, and our economy will ask for people to come for a while and work here and then go back or not, etc. So we need to have a clever policy that addresses all these issues, and that is why the Commission will come up with a holistic migration policy. It is part of our working programme. It is one of our absolute priorities. As part of that, we will have to look at the way forward with Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office. These two organisations are part of the solution, but not the only part. Frontex needs to be strengthened. I do not think at this stage that the finances are the most acute problem but, if they are, on a year-to-year basis the Commission has always made sure that we had enough financing for Frontex. I do think that; but if you were to ask me what I am going to do to ensure more solidarity between Member States, this, to a large extent, is a matter for discussion between the Member States. This is not a competence of the Commission or even of the European Union. You know, if you have seen the reports of the informal Councils, that there is a long and deep debate about this issue. Member States by now understand that it is no longer possible to simply say that we should let the countries that are closest to the problem solve it by themselves, because Germany alone had more than 200 000 refugees last year. So we all share that problem, and there will only be a collective solution to that problem based on a discussion where the responsibility lies, and that is with the Member States.  My final remark is this. I think that this august Parliament has a huge responsibility in taking back the message to the Member States that there is no simple solution to this very complex problem but that there is one thing that is assured: there is no national solution to this problem. There is only a European solution to this problem. Those of you who reject European integration: that is fine, that is up to you; but sometimes you give me the impression of being a hammer, and hammers only see nails. This issue is not an issue where you can say that putting an end to free movement will help us to solve the challenge we face with people migrating to Europe. They will continue migrating even without freedom of movement, and it will not make our task easier to solve this problem for European citizens. (inaudible comment from a Member) I indeed forgot to answer a question, which was completely misdirected at me. If you want to know whether the border between Hungary and Serbia is patrolled correctly, you should address the Hungarian authorities about this. You cannot ask the Commission to do that. That is the responsibility of the Hungarian authorities.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, thank you for inviting the Presidency to take part in your deliberations, and also thank you for the fruitful discussions we had today. Once more it has become clear how important it is to talk to each other, and the more we cooperate the more successful we will be in face of the serious challenges that lie ahead. I share the view that the tragic loss of life in the Mediterranean is closely linked to the problem of human smuggling and organised crime. The communication on the work of the Task Force for the Mediterranean includes a list of measures to fight these phenomena. We should all continue this work. The Union has numerous tools that should be more intensively applied and, where necessary, adapted to new realities. For example, Frontex could make use of the common application tools offered by the European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur) to enable selected monitoring of designated pre-frontier areas at the external borders, which have been identified through risk analysis and information as being potential departure or transit areas for illegal immigration or cross-border crime. There is also potential for more intensive inter-agency cooperation – for example, ensuring that Europol is made aware swiftly of all information useful in the fight against smugglers that is gathered at the EU borders by Member States’ surveillance services. Cooperation is also working well under the recently concluded service-level agreement between Frontex and the European Maritime Safety Agency. I would also like to mention the actions included in the Operational Action Plan on illegal immigration of the EU policy cycle, which aim to combat criminal groups organising the smuggling of immigrants. The European Asylum Support Office (EASO) can cooperate with Frontex in relation to reinforced management of the EU’s external borders. EASO could coordinate the screening of immigrants in mixed flows by identifying those in need of international protection and those who have special needs, including vulnerable persons; and by providing information, EASO could contribute to catering for their needs upon disembarkation. Furthermore, enhanced inter-agency cooperation between EASO, Frontex and Europol could be important in the fight against smuggling and in the identification of facilitators. EASO could also, for instance, contribute by gathering information on facilitation during the asylum decision process. We might also ask what EASO can do in relation to unaccompanied minors. EASO already takes action to support Member States in the implementation of the common European asylum system in relation to children, including unaccompanied minors. These actions take into account the general work on child protection and the protection of the rights of children carried out inter alia by the Commission and the Fundamental Rights Agency. Concrete EASO deliverables so far include the publication of a report on age assessment and the organisation of a meeting of experts on family tracing. In the coming years, EASO should continue to provide support and develop practical cooperation tools on issues relating to children and unaccompanied minors. Further to remarks made in the discussion, I have a few points. First, on budget resources: EASO and Frontex operate within the new multiannual financial framework, including within the bounds of the new Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund. For the period 2014-2020 this financial framework provides the basis for EU financial support on asylum, migration and borders, including allocations to EU agencies. As a consequence, any choice to have EASO and Frontex intensify their existing tasks or taking up new tasks will require either the allocation of additional means to these agencies within the financial framework or prioritisation in the agencies’ work plans. Both in the Council and in the European Parliament, the executive directors of EASO and Frontex have highlighted the need to match expectations with funds. Secondly, at the moment external evaluations of both EASO and Frontex are being conducted. When ready, the evaluations should provide important input for discussion on the role and tasks of these agencies in the coming years. Honourable Members, several remarks have been made about the efficiency of the European asylum system. In this regard, I must note that the new legislative instruments of the common European asylum system will come into force this summer. This means that we will first have to assess the impact of these instruments. Only then, in the light of the results of that assessment, could the issue of mutual recognition be discussed. We will have to see if sufficient mutual trust exists among Member States to introduce a mutually recognised EU protection status. EASO could provide important input for that discussion. As co-legislators we will be called on to agree how EASO and Frontex should further contribute to successful EU migration and asylum policies. Today’s debate provides important input for mapping the way forward. In doing so, it is our common responsibility to match means and expectations and to continue giving both agencies our full support.

name: Przewodniczący. -
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Mario Borghezio (NI)
text: in writing. The European Commission is calling for adequate funding for Frontex, believing that 'a budget of only EUR 90 million per year is certainly not up to the task of protecting Europe's common borders'. Is the EU spokeswoman aware that only a few days ago it was announced, on the contrary, that Frontex will cost EUR 114 million for 2015, 14% more than in 2014, and that donations from the Schengen countries increase from EUR 5.6 million to EUR 7 million, while those in the United Kingdom and Ireland, which increase from EUR 900 000 to EUR 820 thousand? Do you know that 72% of this budget will be spent on monitoring the Union's borders? But I ask myself and I ask myself: given the poor results achieved so far in containing illegal immigration by Frontex, how will this additional funding be actively used? Will these additional funds really help to curb illegal immigration? Do the Commissioner and his spokeswoman talk to each other before making statements on the same subject?

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: in writing - Borders are the only way to ensure the separation and integrity of two different spaces. Most of the Member States of the Union are part of the Schengen area, which draws extremely porous common external borders and causes migration flows to become uncontrollable in the various territories. Frontex is equally conspicuous by its ineffectiveness in controlling migration flows in Europe; Worse, the European Agency accompanies illegal immigrants to the territories of the Union, leaving thousands of human beings left to fend for themselves through the various countries trying to apply their sovereign law. This management of migratory flows also encourages mafia networks to maintain clandestine channels, especially in the Mediterranean, where too many people have already died. The policy of the right of asylum belongs to the Member States and it is not acceptable for them to suffer the political errors of the European Union, which, living outside the realities, is not aware of the human disasters it de facto condones, nor the need for sovereign borders that protect the peoples of Europe. The only realistic future of asylum and border management policy is respect for the legal and territorial sovereignty of Member States.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. – Europe’s borders have to become more secure by increasing financial, human and technical resources and strengthening Frontex. Countries along Europe’s external borders in particular face specific challenges on migration issues. The statistics show that whereas the older EU Member States have been dealing with the issue for a long time, the newer ones like Hungary have just begun to confront it. In 2014 the number of persons requesting refugee status in Hungary was nearly 20 times higher than in 2012. Our aim should be to find solutions for the Member States particularly concerned and effective measures against asylum abuse to put an end to organised crime and human trafficking in order to prevent tragedies along Europe’s external borders. There is a difference between those who cross the border illegally because they are fleeing persecution, armed conflict or other hardships and those who enter the EU in search of better living standards. Political asylum-seekers merit protection, and we have to meet our humanitarian responsibility towards them. However, we have to distinguish refugees from illegal economic migrants. We need a frank debate on the issue, as illegal immigration poses a problem today.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I have decided, together with all the Members of the National Front, to call for the abolition of the European external border agency, Frontex. There are two main reasons for this. First of all, Frontex no longer guards our external borders, it no longer prevents anyone from entering the Union illegally. She is a substitute for the "smugglers": they fill garbage boats with stowaways and then let them sink off the coast of Italy or Greece, knowing full well that Frontex agents are under a moral obligation - and this is quite normal - to come to their rescue and bring them back to the mainland. Frontex therefore facilitates the entry of illegal immigrants into the territory of the Union. The second reason is the hypocrisy of the Union. Indeed, it has facilitated the movement of people, encouraged millions of unfortunate people to attempt the crossing, so often fatal. Without the Union, without Schengen, we would not be aware of the current migration problems. And, under no circumstances, we believe that those behind these disasters will be able to solve them. Uncontrolled immigration is a consequence of the Union, and only nation states have the capacity to respond to these problems.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Europe, as a region of relative prosperity, is a place where many people would like to find themselves. They are fleeing countries with armed or ethnic conflicts, from poverty-stricken countries, with no prospect of change for the better. The creation of institutions, such as Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office, aimed to coordinate measures to reduce the flow of migrants and create the conditions for dealing with those who have already arrived in Europe. However, it is undeniable that a high level of responsibility for the tightness of borders falls directly on the Member States. In particular, the countries constituting the southern and eastern EU borders have to deal to a large extent with the refugee problem. There is also concern about the double increase in the number of immigrants in the last two years. This is the result of an escalation of military and terrorist activities in Syria and Iraq. Therefore, by observing the situation in Ukraine, we should redouble our efforts to provide support and to target existing agencies so that they can better prepare for the deteriorating situation. Financial support should be provided so that these institutions can fulfil their tasks and support Member States in receiving refugees.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Today, too, has once again brought tragic reports of hundreds of refugees who have drowned in the Mediterranean. This is once again a sad signal that the EU's external border needs to be strengthened. The EU border agency Frontex has been underfunded and under-built. The growing pressure on the EU's borders does not allow this to continue. Frontex needs to be transformed into a full-fledged EU agency that can be adequately funded from the EU budget. Frontex must not depend solely on the contribution of the Member States. The coming time will also be difficult for the EU in terms of border protection and refugee pressures. It is therefore high time to finance and manning Frontex properly and steadily. This must be reflected in the EU budget for the following year at the latest and preferably in the past.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I support efforts to create a common policy on the European asylum system. The free movement of persons in the EU and the phasing out of internal borders makes concerted action inevitable. The European Asylum Support Office continuously works to harmonise the provision of operational support to Member States, especially in countries where the reception system is subject to strong migratory pressure.  The Office's actions have made serious progress in the creation and implementation of the Common European Asylum Policy. There is still room for improvement, in particular in view of the growing number of applications due to the escalating conflicts in Syria and Iraq and the continuing migratory pressure on southern Europe, notably in reducing disparities between Member States in granting asylum, subsidiary and temporary protection.  Frontex has also been an important element in implementing migration policy since 2005. The high migratory pressure on the EU requires coordinated operational action in risk analysis and external border monitoring and increasingly demanding technical and professional competence, in particular in the main marine area of illegal migration – the Mediterranean.  I welcome the increase in Frontex's budget, but the fact is that there are still insufficient resources for all their actions. Consistent implementation of best border management practices should continue, with strong measures to save the lives of migrants attempting to reach European shores through illegal routes and ensuring the rights of asylum seekers and asylum seekers are protected.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – With Frontex we are building a strong Europe where migration policy is simply a part of security policy: visa restriction, construction of murderous walls and fences, militarization of border control, forced repatriations, outsourcing of immigration control to non-democratic countries... We are systematically violating human rights, not only with hot returns, but also installing blades on fences, mistreating in detention centres for foreigners, ramming engable boats with migrant-filled boats, and there have even been cases where European authorities have pulled the trigger. Enough of inconsistencies and cynicism! It is our policies, the outside in general and the commercial in particular, that lead to despair for the people of the South forcing them to emigrate. Ladies and gentlemen, have you stopped to think about the effects that TTIP will have on migration? TTIP will further impoverish the South and force more people to emigrate. Let us be consistent, take root in the problem of migration and promote the development and well-being of the people of the countries of the South and stop impoverishing them.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – In the context of the Paris attacks, the governments of several Member States – and perhaps most extreme the Hungarian Government – found the source of the problems in regulating immigration at EU level. Prime Minister Viktor Orban and several key figures in his party have repeatedly described EU rules as loose, unreasonable and playable, so Orban stressed that eu decisions should not be waited for, but "what can be done for ourselves." "We don't want to be the destination country for subsistence immigrants," he said, noting that statistics show that Hungary not a target for immigration. The problem in Hungary is not immigration, but emigration. In order to prevent irresponsible actions by the Hungarian Government, it would be appropriate to consider how the issue of immigration could be tackled reassuringly at EU level. The German Social Democrats have initiated the introduction of a flexible points system, on the basis of which they would review annually the shortages in the Union. According to the needs of the Member States, immigrants with a profession and qualifications in which there is a shortage of labour would receive more points. Let us not forget that, due to the ageing of EU society, the number of workers will decrease by 6-7 million over the next decade, which can only be replaced by regulated immigration within the appropriate framework. In addition to regulating immigration legislation, it would be worth thinking about ways and means of helping immigrants already in the EU integrate into society.

name: Przewodniczący. -
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on access to medicines in the EU (2015/2528(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, the issue of access to medicines is a very emotional one. Each and every one of us has a story to tell about his or her own experience. As we all agree, access for patients to medicines that efficiently treat illness is an important issue that must be addressed both at national and EU level. It involves several aspects, namely: availability – meaning that new medicines are developed or existing products are adapted; also accessibility – bringing the products to patients who need them. It is also about affordability – ensuring that patients, healthcare providers and governments can afford the products; and lastly, ensuring quality so that the medicinal products work as intended and are efficient and safe. In terms of availability of medicines, a lot of emphasis has been put on research and development, especially of innovative medicines. EU pharmaceutical legislation aims at safeguarding public health whilst ensuring timely access of medicines to the market for the benefit of patients. Over the years, several mechanisms were built into the legislation to facilitate innovation and timely access of patients to innovative medicines. They include a centralised procedure for the authorisation of medicines, support to SMEs (through fee reduction or deferment and administrative assistance), and regulatory data protection incentives. Additional incentives were introduced by specific legislation in order to promote research and development of paediatrics and orphan medicinal products. These include 10-year market exclusivity for orphan medicines. The recently-adopted Regulation on Clinical Trials (agreed by the Council and the European Parliament in December 2013 and to be applicable as of May 2016) is expected to foster more clinical research in Europe. It will also promote the development of better medicines by facilitating the authorisation of clinical trials conducted at the same time in several Member States. A concrete example of a European mechanism to support research into innovative medicines is the Innovative Medicines Initiative, a joint undertaking between the EU and the pharmaceutical industry association EFPIA. It is Europe’s largest public-private initiative aiming to speed up the development of better and safer medicines for patients. This initiative will continue to be co-financed from the Horizon 2020 programme. Secondly, to tackle the accessibility of medicines – that is, making authorised products available to patients in need – European legislation already provides for mechanisms allowing marketing authorisation of medicinal products on the basis of less comprehensive data in a variety of special circumstances where there is sufficient justification. Such mechanisms include conditional marketing authorisation and authorisation under exceptional circumstances. It also includes accelerated scientific review, compassionate use programmes, or adaptive licensing. Despite the fact that the existing system provides innovative, safe and efficient medicines for patients, some challenges still remain, as patients are demanding faster availability of promising new therapies at affordable prices. In order to maximise the potential of existing EU regulatory tools, the Council invited the Member States, in cooperation with the Commission, to discuss how to make even better use of these tools. Thirdly, the problem of the affordability of medicines for European patients and Member States’ health system budgets has been addressed by the Council on several occasions in recent months. At the EPSCO Council meeting in June 2014, where the Council adopted conclusions on the economic crisis and health care, the Council recognised the need for cooperation among Member States through, inter alia, sharing information on strategies to effectively manage pharmaceutical and medical device expenditure while ensuring equitable access to effective medicines within sustainable national health care systems. Work should also continue on issues related to affordable pricing, the use of generic medicines, orphan medicines, medical devices and small markets. At the same Council meeting, a specific problem of the high price for the hepatitis C medicine Sovaldi from the US company Gilead was raised, at the initiative of the French Government. This resulted in exchanges of information between Member States with the objective of pushing down prices. The problem was further discussed by health ministers at their informal meeting in Milan in September 2014. Ministers agreed that, while the pricing of medicinal products is the exclusive competence of Member States, more systematic and structured exchange of information would be beneficial to ensure greater transparency. They also stressed the need for greater use of HTA (Health Technology Assessment) to ensure the efficiency of new medicines. Recently, at its December 2014 meeting, the Council adopted conclusions on innovation for the benefit of patients, in which it invited Member States and the Commission to deepen work in several areas, namely to explore opportunities for exchange of information between competent bodies in relation to the ‘life cycle approach’ for innovative medicinal products. The Council also invited them: to implement the Health Technology Assessment (HTA) Strategy adopted recently by the HTA Network; to increase effective sharing of information on prices and expenditures on medicinal products – such a measure should contribute to greater transparency, while respecting the competence of Member States for financing their health systems, including reimbursement of medicinal products; and to increase transparency from all relevant actors – including industry – that could contribute to increased availability and accessibility of innovative products. The Presidency will work on the implementation of the Council conclusions in the coming months. The Council also notes with satisfaction the recent creation of the Expert Group on Safe and Timely Access to Medicines for Patients under the auspices of the Pharmaceutical Committee of the Commission, which recently started work. It is clear that we will have to continue our discussions about how we can ensure the best possible quality of medical treatment to our citizens – old and young, rich and poor – all of our citizens.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I am here today on behalf of Vice-President Jyrki Katainen. In September of last year, here in Parliament, the Commission made a declaration on access to lifesaving medicines. On that occasion the Commission expressed its concern regarding the accessibility of medicines for patients and stressed its commitment to support Member States in addressing this key challenge. Since then we have, of course, had a change of Commission. I can assure you, however, that the new Commission maintains this position and continues to uphold the principle that medicines are a special case, that is to say they are not goods like any others. In December 2014, Health Ministers adopted a conclusion on innovation for the benefit of patients, calling for action to foster better access to medicines. The Commission comprehensively supports the Member States in this endeavour. Just two weeks ago, a new Commission Expert Group on Safe and Timely Access to Medicine for Patients (STAMP) met for the first time. This expert group will examine ways to use existing regulatory tools under EU pharmaceutical legislation more effectively with the aim of fostering innovation and further facilitating safe and timely access, in order to end the unavailability of innovative medicines for patients with unmet medical needs. The Commission services for health are coordinating this work together with other relevant Commission services and the European Medicines Agency. In addition, the use of the joint procurement mechanism, developed by the Commission at the Council’s request to counteract cross-border health threats, has been further explored. This mechanism enables Member States to purchase medicines together so as to help secure access to medicines at better conditions and prices. To start with, Member States will be purchasing together pandemic flu vaccines, and they can use the mechanism to purchase a range of other medicines. Furthermore, a strategy on EU cooperation on health technology assessment was adopted in October of last year.
