By reducing fragmentation in the evaluation of technologies and by avoiding duplication, health technology assessment promises to speed up access to innovative treatments. The Commission also extends support to Member States to mitigate some of the negative effects on patient access that are associated with the common practice of benchmarking national prices to those in other countries. The Commission’s public health programme supports research and information tools that aim to provide a better understanding of how pharmaceutical pricing may be applied so as to minimise negative effects on both patient access and health budgets. The first results are expected by the end of this year. In this context, the Commission services will continue to support the exchange of information among all interested Member States and other relevant EU and national public and private stakeholders, including patients, with the core objective of improving patient access to medicines. Next week Member State public health delegates will meet in Brussels at senior level for further discussion of innovation for the benefit of patients, in the light of the December Council conclusions. Finally, the Commission recognises and appreciates the activities undertaken by Parliament in this area, such as the recently established Interest Group on Access to Healthcare. Indeed, the Commission fully supports and welcomes Parliament’s commitment to this issue. I am confident that combined action by the Commission, Parliament, the Member States and health stakeholders will collectively make an important and significant contribution to improving access to healthcare for patients across the European Union.

name: Jens Gieseke
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, representatives of the Commission, representatives of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work he has said. Our European health systems face major challenges. The economic crisis has meant that smaller budgets have to deal with ever greater tasks. We have to think of our ageing population, but also, of course, of chronic diseases, such as hepatitis C. I come from Germany. In Germany alone, 500 000 people are infected. In Europe, almost nine million people suffer from this disease. Difficult economic conditions of a health system must not lead us to be unable to help these patients. However, I do not believe that planned economic demands – such as European price fixing or even patent expropriation – will solve our problems. In such a planned economic system, there would be no incentive for entrepreneurs to innovate. In such a system, life-saving medicine against hepatitis would never have been developed. In such a system, there would be no medicines to discuss today. Today's debate is not about the price of a single pill. It is completely indisputable that this price is very high in individual cases and almost priceless for the health insurance companies and, unfortunately, also for patients. But there is a fundamental question: how do we promote innovation in medicine and then at the same time ensure the widest possible care for patients? We need transparency in negotiations with companies at Member State level. The way to cheaper prices for patients and health insurance companies is not planned economy, but fair competition. At Member State level, this fair competition must be organised transparently and without discrimination in such a way that as many patients as possible have access to medicines. I believe that such fair competition can benefit both businesses and patients.

name: Matthias Groote
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the This is not about a planned economy or about politicians setting any prices. However, if up to EUR 200 000 has to be paid for a therapy – for pills – then this will knock the bottom of the barrel. I am very pleased that 'doctors of the world' have today lodged an appeal with the European Patent Office so that we can get generic medicines in the future. That's where the journey goes. This is because huge groups of people are excluded from access to reasonable care. It still has one component, namely in the field of development. Europe and some Member States in Europe are the price index for other countries in the world. If we want the spiral of costs to continue to be driven up there, then we must sit back and say: this is all regulated by the market. Yes, he regulates that. We see in which direction. That is why it will be important for us to consider: how can we manage to reduce prices? Of course, we cannot define it, but – it has already been mentioned – that this should be addressed through HDA and other procedures. The EMA, the European Medicines Agency, will play a very important role in this. My question to the Commission is this: what does the Commission, but also the Council, intend to do to ensure that we provide the EMA with more resources for this? Is there anything there? Is there also money planned for future measures? Because that's the only thing that's going to happen. However, we will save money at the end of the day, because we have 28 different health systems, if we cooperate more closely there, which has also been discussed with the Council – I will say it very diplomatically, because I actually liked what you said. We need a little more momentum here, and we would cut a great deal of red tape in the Member States and ensure that access is improved. Because everyone has only one health, and health is a human right and must not be further commercialised until no one can afford it any more. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you very much for your comments, sir. I would just like to raise with you the aspect of orphan drugs and the market for those, where the patient pools are often very small, and as a result drug costs have to be very high. Are you now advocating drug cost subsidisation and, if you are, on what scale and in which areas? Just so that patients know!

name: Matthias Groote (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I am happy to answer that. I believe that we have tools at our disposal – called HDA, health impact assessment, medical impact assessment. And if we need medicines for small groups of people, then we should talk about the authorisation procedures so that they do not last so long. There are models, the things are in the drawer. For this, however, we need money from the European Union. We could make a massive impact on national health systems at this point. Therefore, more money for the EMA, so that the EMA can move forward in this direction. We will relieve national budgets and health systems at this point. There's a shoe out there. We do not have to set prices, but that would be an instrument in which we have competence.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, here we have another example of fairy-tale economics. We do not simply conjure money into the Commission to enable Member States to work harder in their health systems to get access to medicine. That money has to come from the Member States: it does not go round and round and multiply magically. Access to medicines is an economic issue. The pricing and reimbursement of medicines within the EU is a Member State competence under Article 168 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. This Parliament is not the appropriate forum for this discussion. Each Member State has its own unique healthcare system with varying degrees of state funding for reimbursement. It is the responsibility of the individual Member States to use their bargaining power to keep these costs as low as possible. This is to enable their own health services to work better. Nobody is pretending that that is easy, but each Member State must prioritise funding on the basis of its own national plans, and sometimes tough decisions have to be made. There is no evidence anywhere to suggest that transferring this competence to the EU would produce any improvement at all. Probably exactly the opposite would happen. These budgets should remain in the hands of Member State governments – governments which are directly elected by their citizens rather than run by officials here in Brussels. We should be debating the economic health of Europe: ensuring thriving economies that can afford the best of health for their citizens.

name: José Inácio Faria
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Mr Stylianides, Mrs Kalniưa, Member States are going through difficult times with regard to the sustainability of their national health systems, and an increasingly important part of the health budgets relate to pharmaceutical spending.  States have tried to counter this trend with measures to control prescriptions and with measures relating to pricing and reimbursement. There is, however, less transparency in cost-making and reimbursement measures and there are huge delays in decision-making deadlines, not only for innovative medicines but also for generic medicines. At the same time, we are witnessing very serious cases such as hepatitis C, for which many patients are deprived of life-saving medicines. There seems to be an inornated greed of pharmaceutical companies, which set exorbitant prices for their innovative drugs, making a real bleed in health systems. These situations have nothing to do with achieving a fair return on investments and risks taken during research and development processes, often co-financed by public funds. Greater collaboration at European level is needed to gain greater negotiating power vis-à-vis industry and to ensure that patients have rapid access to medicines. It's human lives we're dealing with.  In this regard, how can we understand that a legislative proposal such as the amendment of the Transparency Directive, which regulates the rules for the pricing of pharmaceutical products for human use, of which I am rapporteur and which aims at shortening the decision-making deadlines on the cost of reimbursement of innovative and generic medicines, is blocked in the Council? How is it possible that the Commission, despite pressure from the European Parliament, is assessing its withdrawal from the work programme? Too bad Mr. Timmermans isn't here, because I had a question for you. Why does he not respond to the letters I send him on this matter, so I have asked for the Commission's cooperation in this matter? I end, Mr President, by saying that in cases like this, Europeans need more Europe, not less Europe.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Sovaldi is the name by which pharmaceutical company Gilead markets sofosbuvir. This medicine increases the likelihood of curing hepatitis C by up to 95%. But even though this medicine exists, there are hundreds of people in the world who die every day from this disease. And why? Because, for example, in the Spanish State a twelve-week treatment with this medicine costs 25 000 euros. The Government of the People's Party does not subsidize Sovaldi to all patients who need it. There is a spending ceiling for the drug. They have put a price on people's lives, although with the 47 million euros of Bárcenas, of the People's Party in Switzerland, 783 treatments could have been paid. Or, for example, with the $40 billion that is no longer paid for tax evasion each year, 666,000 treatments could be paid. And it is true that our governments are inhumane and decide who lives and who dies, and dies who has no money to pay for this treatment when it is not funded by Social Security. But it should be noted higher: if a Sovaldi treatment of this drug has this absolutely exorbitant price it is because patents protect the benefits of pharmaceuticals. Patents are a death sentence for millions of people around the world and those who are allowing it are accomplices to murder. Its laws allow Gilead to make a profit last year for $13.3 billion and that twelve people died today in the Spanish state, as every day.

name: Michèle Rivasi
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, in September we had the same debate in the plenary session at the initiative of the environmentalists. What for? Because of this hepatitis C drug, Sovaldi. You are talking about 24,000 euros in Spain; in France, it is worth 46,000 euros. When you consider that more than 25,000 people are affected, that is more than a billion a year. If we continue like this, we will completely break the social security system of all our European countries. When I asked this question, the Barroso Commission replied: "The Commission can't do anything". So I have some proposals for you. You said, "We are giving money to the pharmaceutical industry under the IMI program." We gave $1.6 billion to the pharmaceutical companies. All right, we need to encourage research and development, but we also need to ensure the availability of these drugs. That means giving public money, but there is no patent. Laboratories make money by selling their drugs, but that monopoly no longer exists. I make a second proposal to the Commission: you know about the compulsory licensing process that each Member State can use. I ask the Commission to accompany the Member States so that in case of emergency - and there is an urgent need, in view of all the figures given - we can help States to remove this patent and open it up at the generic level. The last proposal is that a resolution must be adopted. A resolution was called for at the level of all political groups. Access to medicines is a demand of European citizens. We must stop the race for the benefit of laboratories for the benefit, precisely, of patients. Commissioner, we have a real responsibility in this regard.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, access to medicines is part of the right to health, which is one of the most important of the charter of fundamental rights of European citizens.  However, in low- and middle-income countries, the price of drugs can reach up to 80 times the international reference price. In these countries there is very little availability of medicines in the public sector, while there is a great deal of availability in the private sector, where prices are much higher, thus making medicines inaccessible to huge slices of the population. We therefore have a problem with access to medicines, but above all we have a problem of over-medicine. I am referring to the excessive concentration of industrial drug production, which is all in the hands of very few pharmaceutical companies. More than 90% of the drugs produced worldwide are produced in rich countries. More than 70% of drugs are produced in only five countries worldwide. More than 45% of drugs are produced by only ten pharmaceutical companies, ten multinational drug companies. These multinationals therefore have enormous power in their hands: the power to decide the price of medicines; the power to lay down rules for intellectual property rights; the power to decide on investment allocates of scientific research; the power to encourage so-called incremental innovations, i.e. to encourage only small improvements in existing products. This perverse logic continues to introduce uneaso innovative medicines on to the market compared to those already on the market, and this requires considerable investment only from the point of view of marketing. The result is that drugs are becoming more and more expensive but less and less innovative and therefore have little impact on patients' health. I am talking about Cetuximab which, at a cost of EUR 80 000 per lung cancer patient, produces an average survival increase of only one and a half months. I am talking about Erlotinib which, at a cost of EUR 15 000 per patient with pancreatic cancer, produces an average increase in survival of only ten days. We propose that the market for generic medicines and biosimilar medicines, which are as effective as the originals but cost much less and are therefore much more sustainable by the health systems of all the Member States, should be finally released. In addition, we propose the establishment of a large public and European pharmaceutical company, which can deal with research in all those sectors that are snubbed by private pharmaceutical companies because they are considered unattrated commercially, as in the case of antimicrobial resistance or in the case of the development of vaccines against tragic pandemics such as the Ebola virus.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI). -
text: Mr President, the nannies ruling the European Union are treating Europeans like small children. I would like to inform Mrs Kalniņa-Lukaševica that we are already grown up, and every European should be allowed to buy in every pharmacy any medicine he wants – whether the government wants it or not – provided the pharmacy wants to sell it to him. If Mrs Kalniņa-Lukaševica maintains that she knows better than me what is good for me, that is not even fascist, it is much worse. It is socialist. Moreover, I think that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE). -
text: Mr President, nowadays the European Union is facing an unprecedented paradox in the healthcare sector. The existence of innovative new drugs, new technologies and developments in medical science that could ensure good outcomes and long-term survival on the one hand, and on the other hand many European citizens not being able to access them, mainly due to high costs. The issue of access to medicine is not only related to one innovative drug with an unusual high price but also to innovative medicines with reasonable prices, due to bureaucratic reimbursement procedures, lack of implementation of European laws such as the Cross-Border Healthcare Directive, or even due to the blocking of other important European laws such as the Transparency Directive. Also, to finance the cost of new high-priced medicines, generic and biosimilar medicines, uptake must be used to create headroom for the healthcare budget. A major problem is that making the best use of such developments in the area of healthcare is particularly expensive and difficult, especially for some of the Member States that are relatively small or low-income countries. European patients, and especially European cancer patients, rely on innovation to access new and better treatments. For many European patients, innovative treatments are the only hope to fight their disease. EU policy-makers should make sure that regulatory decisions on the value of innovative therapies are based on what matters the most to patients, namely long-term quality survival, and also to ensure access to innovative treatments following a cost-benefit analysis performed at centralised level by the EMA. We should prioritise at EU and national level more investment in research into innovative therapies and find sustainable solutions for including innovative therapies in national healthcare plans, treatment pathways and funding streams.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin in a positive way and say that it has been good words, good intentions, what I have heard from the Council and on the part of the Commission. But more must be asked, especially in the face of the recent announcement of the withdrawal of the Transparency Directive in the pricing of medicines. This debate affects us all: today is hepatitis C, tomorrow it will be the anti-tumors. It is suffered by patients and puts into check the different health systems of our Member States. My group has promoted this debate because it defends the right to health as a fundamental right that we have contained in the Treaties and we cannot allow it to be marketed. Having said that, I would also like to begin by saying that, to this day, Member States have an obligation to ensure access to this medicine and all the innovations given to different patients in their Member States, while having an obligation, together with the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council, to seek transparency mechanisms in pricing , to look at the results of all clinical trials and confirm the true added value provided by these new drugs and see what the percentage actually corresponds to the research within those prices. We need new powers for the European Medicines Agency and new measures to enable coordinated purchase, or measures such as auctions, which are already underway today on lands like mine, Andalusia. I would also like to acknowledge the role of NGOs who have taught us a lesson today and have taken the lead in many Governments of the Member States; and I want and ask and demand, finally, that necessary political will, because I think we have plenty of powers.

name: Bolesław G. Piecha (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking At first, I wanted to express a little surprise at the statements made by the Commissioner and the Council representative, because these were beautiful words, but unfortunately nothing came of them. Because there were no suggestions of patients' access to medicines. It is difficult to talk about this problem, I will say more: It seems to me that this is mission impossible if we are talking about 26 health systems in Europe. Each of these systems is regulated by national legislation – and what, the price of the drug is to be one and the same everywhere and still low for this? I think it's hard to talk about. Nevertheless, around 25-30% of patients in some European countries do not have access to any medicines because they do not buy them from a pharmacy for a simple reason – a financial barrier. The outlay in Europe varies, so there are countries like this – perhaps some colleagues don't know about it, which is why I'm talking about it.  What is the problem today? The problem is that if we are talking about access to medicines, especially in terms of innovation and generics, especially in terms of price, and we are not talking about harmonisation of health systems, then we are not talking about anything for good. My question is quite difficult, because we have already heard different opinions here: is the Council or the Commission at all capable of taking on the challenge of Obamacare? Could health systems be harmonised across Europe? If this is possible, then we can talk about the availability of medicines, because the cost of treatment with medical preparations is only 15-17% of the total cost of healthcare. So without resolving this issue, it will be difficult to solve a problem. The question is: is the Commission and are the Council able to address this challenge facing Europeans?

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Today we are talking about a very important asset, namely people's health and access to medicines, which we naturally want to have for all the people of Europe alike. This is a wishful thinking and an ideal. But we always strive in the direction of ideals. Matthias Groote is absolutely right: it is in a way a human right to have access to medicine. It is now the case that health policy is very different in the various Member States, as has already been said. The systems cannot simply be unify. It is also the case that competence lies with the Member States. I think that's okay for her to do that. However, we must consider, if we have free mobility for the people of Europe, if we now also have health tourism in Europe: how can we ensure that as many people as possible actually have access to similarly supplied medicines, including innovative medicines? I think there are a number of things that are quite good as an approach. The Council has said that there is an accelerated scientific review – Minister, you said that – in the case of innovative medicines. You have also said that you want to have a better exchange for the life cycle of innovative instruments. I find this good. The Commission has said that it has just set up a new group of experts and has proposed making a joint purchase of the Member States. It is up to the Member States to decide whether this is possible. I know that this – I come from Germany – can be difficult even between the federal states. We used to have bird flu. The federal states have been arguing about how much stock is needed. Everyone had a different stock, and in the end they spent a lot of money for nothing. That would certainly have been better with a vote. I think the road is complicated. But I could imagine that this might be a viable way forward. What I think is very important and what is not being debated here, but what I think is important for health care in the future in the face of demographic change, is to seek savings potential. I used to be a health politician in Germany. There are many ways to save money. Many things are still inhospital, for example, which can also go on an outpatient basis. There is a great deal to be improved. And I would also like to see a group of experts on exchanges between the Member States. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I have a question for Mr Messner. How do you explain that at European level we are unable to make, at least, group purchases? We have the opportunity to create a grouping at the level of the five largest countries - Germany, France, England, etc. - and it is these countries that refuse, because they want to keep sovereignty over the setting of drug prices. However, one of the ways to bring down the price is to make group purchases. We have done that for vaccines, could we not do it for drugs? I wanted to know where you stand.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. This proposal has indeed come, in this case from the Commission, and I have just said that I could imagine that it would run into difficulties, because there is also the sovereignty of the Member States. That is why I have also described how it was already difficult for the countries in Germany alone with avian influenza a few years ago. However, I believe that we need to move in this direction, not necessarily price agreements – that is not the solution. But it is precisely better cooperation, especially in the case of funds for epidemics, which are not needed every day, that we actually try together to make a stockeconomy in order to save money there. Saving is the most important thing for me. And that goes in a good direction.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, 2 billion people lack access to medicines, either because of their high cost or because there is no adequate medication. This is the consequence of drug development being geared towards market priorities, not public health requirements. In Europe, moreover, disparities in access to medicines are increasingly exacerbated between states and within the countries themselves. In Spain, between ten and twelve people die every day from hepatitis C, and access to the most effective medicine in the fight against hepatitis C is restricted by its abusive price. However, the company that markets this drug earned in one year more than it cost to purchase the patent. The current model of biomedical research corneres knowledge through intellectual property rights, hides risks and places the knowledge generated through eu funding, everyone's money, in private hands. The European Union needs to assure citizens of the benefits of investment through improved public health, with a change in the research model, with initiatives such as free and socially responsible licensing, open source research, free access to research, and also ensure that States can put health protection before patents and the benefits of a few. We can't let anyone who can afford it have the right to live.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, we should have this debate 'The case of the best cost-benefit ratio in the world'. Europe cannot leave this issue in the hands of a social confrontation between more or less heroic affected and state and private powers acting against the general interest. Member States are subordinated to the large pharmaceutical industry, which conditions markets and drowns social security systems. That's why we have to act now. We don't need experts or reports. We know everything. We can make decisions right away. And we must do so in the short term in the face of situations of social emergency, as in the case of hepatitis C, and more thoroughly to adopt the urgent legislative reform that empowers Europe, a reform based on four concepts: duly compensated public research, total transparency of processes and associated costs, delinking prices and development costs, extensive use of generics. This Parliament must already take the initiative to lead this double strategy, now frozen by the Council and the Commission. And we will do so, at the out point, by means of the specific resolution that develops these points and formulates the corresponding mandate.

name: Diane James (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, the cost of drugs is increasing, and that is a very simple economic fact. We need to recognise that drug innovation is pivotal to future cure and treatment options – and that comes with cost, of which there are two components: development time and research process. We cannot short circuit that, and we should not even attempt to do so. We have to be realistic. The EU would do well to accept that, historically, interventions have created and exacerbated access eligibility. They have not actually delivered any resolution. Clinical trial interference is a very good example of this. Additional distortion and disruption from the EU, as colleagues have already mentioned this evening, is not going to help. But let me give Members a list of things that maybe we should be debating this evening. What about parallel imports caused by the eurozone issues? What about stopping penalising UK and European manufacturers of both patent-protected and generic products via the HTA system? What about supporting drug development and innovation in academia and the commercial sectors on a free-market basis? What about preventing access from fraudulent medicines, and what about penalising countries that do not adhere to our patent systems? If we could deal with the inefficiencies of drug waste, drug dumping and patient compliance, we would do an awful lot to help with patient access. ‘Want’, ‘need’ and ‘should have’ for patients can be delivered, but you do not do it by more intervention. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, do you know how much research and development is in the cost of a drug? All of the studies I have consulted show only 10%. When you pay 10 euros for research, the community pays 100 euros. Do you think that is normal? There needs to be more transparency about the role of research and development in the drugs that are sold to us.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for your question. May I suggest you go back to your sources, because you are incorrect with the figures you gave this evening. Any drug company will tell you, whether it is a generic manufacture or coming from the academic sector, that it takes a lot longer, and that they do need the time to actually develop that. If we are going to start penalising companies when they are bringing forward therapeutic innovation, I think we have started off from the wrong position.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI). -
text: Mr President, fine words have been heard and will continue to be heard during this debate. Unfortunately, however, words often do not go hand in hand with actions or reflect reality, because some of those who are now being cut off for the good of European citizens are the same people who condemned my country and its people to an unprecedented humanitarian crisis for a Country of the European Union. They are the same ones who, with the financial measures they imposed, led to the dissolution of the National Health System: Patients with serious chronic conditions, such as cancer, stand in line to take the chemotherapy drug and, if they find it, go to the hospital for their treatment. Pensioners are forced to pay a very high participation rate for the necessary medicines. The prohibitive cost forced them to divest their property and others into stopping treatment, thus endangering their own lives. Even when the medicines are purchased, they are not authentic, but generics of much worse quality, usually of Central Asian origin, in which formal checks are not often carried out either. So you understand how the average Greek European citizen feels when he sees us discussing issues not just seriously but literally life and death, with the sole result of another text-wish list.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The market for medicines and their availability is one of the important elements of the health of citizens of the European Union. At a time of ageing population and the prevalence of many civilisational and chronic diseases, the pharmaceutical sector and its regulations are becoming of great importance for the health of European citizens, for whom access to innovative, safe, effective and cost-effective medicines is a priority. According to many estimates based on demographic data, both the amount of spending on medicines and the amount of medicines taken by patients in the coming years will increase. We should pay particular attention to the activities of pharmacological concerns and their conduct on the markets in the Countries of the European Union. Often the same drug with the same composition is offered at different prices depending on the pharmaceutical market in the Member State concerned – and this is normal, but unfortunately this situation results, for example, in the wholesale purchase of a medicine in one country and its sale in another, resulting in the withdrawal of treatment options for patients with this medicine on the local market and the real threat to the health and life of patients. This is the situation we have recently in Poland. Such practices should undoubtedly be eliminated. Attention must be paid to drug authorisation systems and to co-financing by Member States, as they are sometimes incomprehensible and questionable.  We should do everything we can to ensure that patients have equal access to innovative procedures and medicines that effectively save lives and health. Better access, including pricing, combined with an adequate level of education and prevention for the prevention and spread of diseases will reduce the number of cases and will certainly improve the health and life of society.  I also agree here with those who have said that the dreams that the Commissioner spoke about are rather difficult to come true. The common market for medicines, when we have different health systems and it is absolutely within the competence of the Member States, seems to be the dream that Europeans expect, but probably difficult to achieve.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Madam Representative of the Presidency, Commissioner, people have also died in my country, Portugal, because the National Health Service is not financially available and the government has not taken the exceptional measures to ensure that essential innovative medicines are administered, in particular in the case of hepatitis C. , and only then was it possible to establish an agreement for the most urgent treatments.  We are therefore facing a market failure, Commissioner. In fact, life is priceless, but the fact that life is priceless cannot allow suppliers an unjustified competitive advantage in the formation of a fair price for access to new medicines. The abolition of the death penalty was a great achievement of modernity, but in disguise, it is returning to the European Union through a financial guillotine.  It is therefore very important that we promote a dynamic process of cooperation that gives strength to the Union to safeguard the interests of citizens. We know that health is not communitised, but subsidiarity has to be looked at intelligently. There are cases where subsidiarity is exactly cooperation at Union level. In this case it is not national policy, it is the Union that makes the force, that defends people and guarantees balance.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, Mr Stylianides, Mrs Kalnya-Luka-evica, hepatitis C has put Europe in front of the mirror, and what the mirror shows us is that our model of access to medicines does not work.  Nine million European citizens, hundreds of thousands in Spain, cry out for a life-saving medicine. A chronic, incurable and deadly disease now has a cure. And governments are obliged to provide it. It is up to states to set prices and finance public health, but the European Union has a mandate to ensure the protection of human health. That is why I are asking the Commission and the Council today to urgently draw up a European Medicines Access Plan which includes a new structure of the relationship with the pharmaceutical industry, a partner essential to fulfil this mandate; a revision of the Pricing Transparency Directive; an in-depth review of the current patent model, dissofiing the costs of researching the final price of medicines; and an aggregate purchasing policy that strengthens the negotiating position of States in the procurement of key medicines. And it's not emotional at all, it's a right.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, this could be one of those debates that are usually held here on Thursday, on cases of human rights violations. Debates in which the majority of this Parliament likes to point the finger at other countries. For in this case we are facing a shocking violation of human rights. Article 25 of its Universal Declaration on access to health and medical care. In the European Union, in the 21st century, there are governments, such as the Portuguese government, which decide to give a price to human life, and who come to the conclusion that a life-saving medicine for patients, for example with hepatitis C, is too expensive and cannot be, that it will not be supplied to these patients. And so these patients die without access to these life-saving medicines.  Of course, this cannot hide the fact that, in fact, some medicines are now priced scandalously, set by multinationals in the pharmaceutical industry. The same to which the European Union directs millions of public resources, for example from the Research Framework Programme, instead of directing these resources to the development, research and development of drug production capacity in the public sector.  It is necessary to confront the interests of multinationals at once. We cannot say that those who exist to serve these interests will do so, in particular the European Commission. But any initiative that will serve to force multinationals to lower the price of these medicines naturally will count on our support.

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President! Here we are faced with a situation where the market has obviously collapsed, and it is outrageous to hear colleagues talk about the fact that the market is more important than human life. We are faced with an industry which has been so serious in the exploitation of a patent system that does not protect human life. This product, which is used to treat hepatitis C, costs €100 in production. Gilead, who produces it, earns $2 billion a month! We need to recognise that we now need to create a common system. There is a difference in the different countries, yes, but we need to have full transparency so that we can see what it costs. We must make it clear that up to 50% of research and development expenditure comes from the public sector. First we pay them, then we give it all away, and then they rob us afterwards. We have to do this in a different way and I am very pleased that a moral patent case has been brought against this product because it is simply immoral. It is reprehensible to have a patent that kills loose!

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to return to a subject to which we have already referred, that of orphan drugs, those medicines that are intended for the treatment of rare diseases. Pharmaceutical companies are usually reluctant to develop these drugs under normal market conditions, as there is clearly no economic return from the sale of such drugs. However, some data must be taken into account: it is estimated that there are between 5 000 and 8 000 rare diseases, affecting about 6 to 8% of the European population, an estimated 27 to 36 million people. So, it is true that we have 28 different health systems and 28 different approaches to health care, but one thing unites all our Member States, namely the conception of the patient as a customer, because he is the customer of the pharmaceutical multinationals. It is therefore essential to succeed in changing this paradigm and I would like to relaunch the proposal and the idea that led my colleague Mr Pedicini of a European public pharmaceutical company, which can really completely change the system with which we care and deal with health in Europe.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI). -
text: The barbarity of capitalist exploitation and the European Union is revealed in its full size by turning even the most vital human need for health and medicine into a commodity. The people are paying more and more. Poor, unemployed and uninsured are completely deprived of them, while a handful of pharmaceutical companies are sussing up state budgets, insurance funds, millions of patients, with bandit prices. Financial coverage from the state and insurance funds is decreasing, private spending is increasing, companies are treasured and the public's pharmaceutical protection is declining. Health and medicine are being put in the guillotine of the European Union's reforms and are loading the costs on the people, who have to fight for an exclusively state-owned drug organisation, in an exclusively public health system without entrepreneurs, abolishing VAT on medicines, abolishing the participation of workers in pharmaceutical expenditure, with responsibility exclusively from the State.

name: József Nagy (PPE). -
text: Thank you very much! The pharmaceutical industry plays an extremely important role in protecting the health of European citizens. In the last year alone, the amount issued for medicinal products amounted to an average of EUR 430 per European resident. Patients should therefore be provided with effective and, not least, reliable medicines on the market. Drug manufacturers should be encouraged to make their medicines available in increased quantities but at moderate prices. This will make it easier for citizens to access it and make significant savings to health budgets. Tougher action is also needed to reduce falsification of medicines.  Innovation in medicines has enabled patients to receive treatments that were considered unimaginable a few decades ago. However, many diseases are still not properly treated, so continuous effort is needed to develop new drugs. It is therefore essential to create a business environment that stimulates research and supports the competitiveness of the sector. We cannot allow research and development to leave the European Union. Thank you!

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, medical research now makes it possible to make progress in the effectiveness of treatment on such a revolutionary scale that it also reverberates on the economic factors of health treatment. It is good and ethically necessary for medicines to cost less. The objective of an ever greater universal health coverage involves, in fact, the adoption of the most modern techniques of experimentation and production of the drug to meet inescapable criteria of efficiency and cost-effectiveness. As you know, however, the lack of such economic sustainability is now reflected in the same possibility of treatment due to the prohibitive cost of certain medicines, such as Sofosbuvir for hepatitis, which costs as much as EUR 50 000. The policy must direct its choices towards processes that can positively affect the effectiveness of research and the cost-effectiveness of health treatment. I am thinking of the innovativeness of research processes, such as the remote patient monitoring system or even the development of molecular drugs called biological or intelligent. I also hope that we will encourage the development of centres of excellence in research with greater subsidies from the Member States, in order to promote greater cost-effectiveness of the drug and an ever-increasing sharing of information and knowledge, going beyond the logic of the research monopoly. Another way to combine innovation and cost-effectiveness is through joint and coordinated political action. It is true that the regulatory process belongs to each Member State, but the Commission must encourage cooperation between States in order to put a stop to price speculation. Finally, a production method could be developed that allows to produce drugs, deviate from the classic discontinuous system called "batch system" widely used today. In my opinion, the actions of the Member States and the Commission must be directed in this direction, in order to ensure the accessibility of medicines and therefore greater social equity.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL). -
text: Health is a public good and a fundamental right. It's not a commodity. However, in recent years we have seen health being targeted by murderous austerity policies and public health spending shrinking. We now have in Europe armies of uninsured or even insured people who are unable to pay for their medicines, both because their own economic capacity is being reduced and because pharmaceutical companies are demanding ever higher prices. There is a need for a European policy on the pricing of medicines that will strengthen the social dimension of the Union and public health. We need to ensure everyone has access to medicines. To disconnect research and innovation in the field of medicine from the price of the drug on the market. The current model of patents and monopolies no longer works. Access to medicines is not a luxury; it's an imperative for life.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, hepatitis C patients die in the Spanish state abandoned by their Government, unable to access life-saving treatments that are expensive. In addition to the irresponsibility of the Spanish Government, this case confronts us with a debate: patients or patents? Multinationals or people? Pressed by civil movements, the World Trade Organization adopted the Doha Declaration in 2001. It was clear that intellectual property of medicines should not be an obstacle to the world's access to medicines by the world. NGOs soon reported that this Declaration was not being complied with and that millions of people were dying every year because of it. This problem, which only affected impoverished countries, has now reached Europe. That, ladies and gentlemen, is also globalisation. The European Commission is to blame for this. In 2013, he lobbied India not to export generic drugs. And he also pressured the governments of the European Union not to import much cheaper Indian medicines, including those that cure hepatitis C. You have to choose. What is the position of the Commission and the grand coalition supporting it? Citizens or multinationals? And when you make the decision, remember that thousands of people die in Europe from hepatitis C, and millions around the world.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI). -
text: Mr President, for the 28 member countries, but also for the many countries with a social protection system, it is legitimate to say that EUR 30,000 to EUR 70,000 for curative treatment of hepatitis C represents, in absolute terms, a small sum compared to the expenditure induced by chronic hepatitis C and aggravated until the transplant. , as has been the case so far. This is a small sum when a nation is given back healed men and women, who can regain their place in their families and in their professional activities, and thus enrich the system of national solidarity. The only problem that will persist will be the possible diversion of treatments into large-scale trafficking, since the infection now affects 185 million people. On the other hand, the cost of each treatment is a problem in some developing countries. In this case, we believe that it is up to each Member State to establish rules for international cooperation in the area of the transfer of know-how. Europe could lead to constraints on innovation, the only guarantee of the access to healing of the greatest number.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE). -
text: Mr President, in view of the advanced hour and the debate, let me make a few comments on this very important subject. Firstly, I would like to say that we must realise, and it has also been said here, that health policy, drug policy, is in the hands of the national states of the Member States. This is right, in my view, and it is up to each country, its management, to decide in national elections how much money it will determine for public health systems and what money it will provide for expensive medicines. That's very important. Nevertheless, I think that the European Union can do something. Not by accumulating competence, but by promoting cooperation and cooperation between Member States, as the Commissioner and also the Council representative have indicated in his speech. That is, cooperation, support, that is what should come from the European level.  Greater support for research and innovation is a topic that has also been raised here. Here, the EU can play a rather significant role. Support for generics and, in general, the debate about the form of patent protection are also an important topic. It must be guaranteed that intellectual property is protected there, but I think generics are a good thing where the EU can play its part. And also in the plane of the approval procedures mentioned above. So the subject is important, we should talk about it, we should promote cooperation between Member States, not transfer powers.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D). -
text: Mr President, because of the long periods when new medicines are protected by patents, many treatments remain inaccessible to people who desperately need them. After the expiration of a drug's patent, its price may fall by 99%, an astonishing figure that suggests how much money companies earn when they have a monopoly on a drug. Year after year, these companies make huge profits and, moreover, call for expanding their monopoly on medicines that could improve the health of some people, many of them deprived of possibilities. This is deeply incorrect. We are not talking about a problem of developing countries, but a painful reality in the European Union, including in Romania, where the price of medicines is often too high for people or hospitals to afford. Obviously, the creation of a medicine is not an inexpensive process and, indeed, better research funding is needed, but it is the citizens who need to benefit from the results of medical research. More transparency is needed about the actual costs of research. Whatever actions proposed by the Commission, I will not support the extension of patents for medicines and, by implication, high-priced medicines, which people cannot afford.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI). -
text: Mr President, I would like to point out two major issues relating to access to medicines.  First, we are faced with a real medico-industrial complex with considerable economic and political weight. The fact is that health today represents a juicy business, just like clothing production or war. The patient often comes to the fore - mediator or Vioxx scandals are just symptoms of a profit system applied to health. The major consequences of this system are the exorbitant costs of health care costs.  The second problem is the excesses of egalitarianism, which tends to impose without nuance an enforceable right in all areas: the right to housing, education and medicines. It burdens the community with a considerable amount of drugs, not always adapted, for the greater benefit of a pharmaceutical industry that practices omerta excessively. "Who embraces too much, who is not well hugged": it is important to turn our backs on an absurd system by being profitable and unfair by being egalitarian.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE) -
text: As a doctor, I see very sensitive situations where the market for health services, medicines, devices and materials fails to find a balance. I understand that, in the case of medicines, it is important that investments in research, clinical trials, as well as other costs are returned. I also understand why it is important for pharmaceutical companies to make a profit. However, we are increasingly seeing cases of misuse of drug patents, in an effort to achieve maximum profit for as long as possible. This Parliament has always sought harmonisation in the field of health that strikes a balance between human health and the needs of the pharmaceutical industry. The Spanish case, but also the whole debate today, shows that there is no such balance yet. I therefore join the request for the Commission to examine the causes of these price excesses and to propose a correction. I consider it important that we open a debate on the models used to set the prices of medicines. The need to review these models is also closely linked to the unfavourable demographic situation and the associated pressure on the sustainability of health funding in Europe. It will be a difficult and long debate, but we cannot postpone it anymore.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D). -
text: Mr President, today, millions of European citizens cannot access the medicines that can cure them and save their lives. Those affected by hepatitis C in Spain are the most visible side of this drama, but there are also millions affected by rare diseases that suffer in silence from this problem. The exorbitant prices imposed by monopolies in the pharmaceutical industry prevent all patients in need from paying for treatment, denying them the right to health and breaking the principle of equity. This is basically the case for three reasons: because there is a pricing system lacking the information and transparency necessary to know the costs and profitability obtained by companies; because there is inadequate regulation and control of R&D and patents that benefits multinationals against the sick; and because the European Union, I am sorry to say, does not exert its capacity to influence the negotiations to lower industry prices. Ladies and gentlemen, it is necessary to change the rules of the game and, for this, one thing is needed: political will.  The European Union needs to manage intellectual property more efficiently, it needs to demand the transparency and information necessary to know the costs of innovation and reward it in a fair way, and it has to put in place a centralized purchasing mechanism. Look, we don't accept the death penalty, but we're able to accept deferred executions from millions of people who can't afford a drug they need to keep living. I hope that none of you will be in that situation and that we will be able to solve this true drama as soon as possible.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE). -
text: Sur President, l-aèèess għall-medièina huwa fundamentali biex inwettqu d-dritt għall-ogħla standard tas-saħħa. Il-Continuity of supply in l-garanzija li ssib il-medièina huma prijorità. Il-miżuri li ħadna from issa mhumiex biżżejjed.  The students of the Tal-European Association of Hospital Pharmacists are chasing malta hija l-aktar pajjiż affettwat b'nuqqas ta' medièini, liema nuqqas anki ġieli jdum ġimgħat. Malta ukoll kienet fost dawk il-pajjiżi li l-aktar taħli ħin biex ifittxu l-medièina li tkun nieqsa. Għandna nkunu minn ta' quddiem biex nagħmlu l-medièini aktar aèèessibbli, billi nwasslu għal riduzzjoni fil-prezz, in nnaqqs l-burocrasion biex medizine jiġu inklużi fil-formularium. Għandna nieqfu nagħżlu bejn il-pazing meta napprovaw medinas għal kundizzjoni waħda in mhux għall-oħra. Gverniet bħal tiegħi ma jistgħux jibqgħu jagħmlu l-kwotas fuq il-pazing whether jirèiev l-medièina b'xejn, għax il-pazjenti ma jimirdux bil-kwota. L-Unjoni Ewropea, bl-impenn tal-gverniet u ta' dawk fis-settur tas-saħħa, tista' ssib is-soluzzjonijiet sabiex kull marid jingħata r-rispett li jixraqlu. Ma ninsewx ukoll lit-tobba u infermiera, li għandhom bżonn jingħataw l-għodda sabiex id-dianjożi tagħhom tiġi indirizzata tramite l-medièini li jagħżlu huma għall-pazjent.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D). -
text: Mr. President, with the advancement of medical science, extremely expensive, new drugs are emerging. When an effective lifesaving drug appears on the market, I am sure that there is no doctor who wants to choose between the health of the patient and savings in the health budget.  If we talk about the cost of health care, on the one hand, for some diseases such as hepatitis we have too expensive and unavailable medicine, and on the other hand society costs extremely much all hospitalizations that without cure this man will experience, all diagnostics and therapy and all absences from work. Not to mention that human life has no price. The European Union is built on the equality of its citizens. But in terms of access to medicines, this equality does not exist. The shift could have been made the Transparency Directive, but it was stuck at an impasse.  The idea that the European Medicines Agency fixes the relative value of new medicines as a starting point for national governments' negotiations with pharmaceutical companies is something they can support. Especially if the variable part of the price is tied to GDP because the negotiating position of small and poorer countries is worse at first. The agency is already deciding whether the new medicine is safe and effective. I am absolutely in it to extend her competencies to prices as well.  It makes no sense for the European Union, which united to determine the safety of the drug, to break down into 28 member states when its price is set. In terms of facilitating access to life-saving medicines, the Union can save taxpayers money and save lives through action.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the subject at hand today is no less. We talk about people, we talk about health, we talk about knowledge, we talk about transparency. Today we are faced with unfair situations, where European citizens are restricted from accessing the medicines they need for their survival. A few weeks ago, this Member asked the Commission precisely on this subject, which is of great concern in Catalonia, in the whole of the Spanish State and in the rest of the Union. And precisely one of the questions was whether the Commission intends to promote or establish a common position between member states so that no union patient is discriminated against on the ground that they belong to one state or another, or that their access to public health is limited by their level of income. Because there is the key: either we empower, as Mr Maragall said, Europe, or we weaken our citizens to the extreme and harm our researchers along the way. And as we say this from full conviction, we must be aware that we must find a balance that in turn guarantees pharmaceutical laboratories the continuity of research and non-abusive protection of their patents and universal access to treatment prescribed in health care. Without affordable medicines, we don't cure. If we don't heal, we fail. But without an economic return to laboratories, there are no new medicines, and no new medicines, no affordable medicines. We have to break this vicious circle without breaking the fragile balance in the content. All this must make us wonder which society we want to be be happy about: ask ourselves, respond and work to make our proposals a reality.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we in Europe are witnessing an unprecedented paradox. For decades we have been asking research to provide us with the tools to fight cancer. Today we are able to defeat many cancers and we can chronicise different types of cancer, but too many patients throughout Europe do not have access to the new drugs that guarantee these results. The approach to drug pricing and reimbursement is too fragmented. Each Member State must negotiate a price with the pharmaceutical companies and decide whether and how to reimburse the new drug, which leads to differences that are unacceptable to European patients. We think that it often goes up to ten years, if not more, before an EMA-authorised drug is made available, and in addition the price of new medicines varies greatly between countries and not always in relation to the cost of living. That's not right. The situation must not be changed. The price of a new medicine must be based on a balanced assessment between the real costs of production and development of the drug and the impact on the health of the patient and society. The EMA must be able to include a cost-benefit analysis and for this reason the Commission must include the work of the Health Technology Assessment Agency. I believe, for all that I have said, that we must go much further than the proposal put forward by the Commission. Let's say it's a good start.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the right to health is a fundamental element of the right to life provided for in Article 3 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The European Union and the responsible institutions must be constantly concerned that this right does not remain a mere statement in a normative act, but, on the contrary, constitutes a reality of our day. The right to health also means access to medicines. The major discrepancies between the various states are absolutely unacceptable. Citizens of the European Union in different countries are sentenced to death by what means too high and inaccessible price of medicines, which is unacceptable and inhumane. The pharmaceutical industry must understand that it needs a partnership with the European citizen, without which, moreover, it could not exist. Member States should consider creating a framework within which all citizens who pay health insurance, but not only, have access to quality, fast and efficient healthcare. The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission must always be concerned that the laws of the Member States are in line with the European directives and provide for clear penalties in the event of their infringement as an additional guarantee of the right to life and health. Without firm measures involving a partnership with the pharmaceutical industry and all the major players in this field, we will have further European citizens who will die for days because of the immobilism of the institutions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr President, the issues of concern to the austere citizens of the European South in relation to access to medicines focus on high prices and the European Commission's decision to turn medicine from a public good into a commodity. In Greece, due to the memorandum, thousands of Greeks now find it difficult to obtain medicines. This applies to cancer patients and other deeply suffering patients. That is why dozens of social pharmacies have now been set up, offering free medicines to the unemployed. At the same time, the violent budgetary adjustment imposed by the Troika and the Memorandum drastically reduced the budgets of hospitals, where there are now huge shortages of basic medicines, with the result that patients are at risk. Therefore, under the responsibility of the Commission, which is a member of The Local, thousands of Greek citizens do not have access to medicines. Congratulations, gentlemen of the Commission!

name: Giulia Moi (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while it is true that one of the main cornerstones of the European Union is also to guarantee the protection of public health, perhaps so far this Europe has escaped something. I am referring to the excessive power of the pharmaceutical companies and the monopoly with which they manage, for example, the trade in life-saving medicines, with unsustainable costs for the sick and huge profits for multinationals and often for corrupt politicians. As it has been managed to date, this system seems to have guaranteed only the interests of a few and their bank account, to the detriment of poor citizens who cannot even access generic medicines. This system has mortified the efforts of thousands of researchers, often poorly paid, who have sacrificed their lives to a dream: that their drugs, those they discover, should be accessible to all. We need more social justice in this Europe.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Health protection is an obvious requirement of the common good. This is what every government, every public institution must care about, but in the context of today's crisis of European culture, it is sometimes used as a pretext for actions that have nothing to do with the protection of life or health. This is the case, for example, in the case of the promotion of preparations that have an abortion effect at the earliest embryonic period of life, when they prevent the embryo from nesting in the mother's uterus. A month ago, the European Commission issued a decision exempting EllaOne from the prescription requirement, which may, albeit secondaryly, have this effect. We are waiting for the Commission's response to the interpellation as to why there has been such an escalation of actions that disregard life in its most sensitive, most sensitive period, and above all we call on the Commission to respect the lives of the most vulnerable, for the most vulnerable because it is completely silent.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I very much appreciate the views expressed here tonight, which I can assure you will be conveyed to the relevant colleagues within the Commission. I can also assure you that the Commission will continue to work hard in support of Member States to improve patient access to medicines across the European Union. As I already explained in my earlier speech, a great deal of preparatory work has already been delivered since the Commission declaration was made here in Strasbourg in September last year. On Tuesday next week, the working party on public health at senior level will convene in Brussels. That is very important. The Latvian Presidency of the Council has already proposed a discussion document for the Member States, which will serve as the basis for future work, for which I would like to thank it very much. The Commission will, naturally, continue to actively support these and other discussions. This is the situation. Of course, all of us already recognise the difficulties, but let me close by thanking Parliament once again for its interest and its activities in support of our common objective in this important area of access to medicines for patients.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, I would like to thank the Members of the European Parliament for their views and suggestions for the future work to be conducted by the Council and the Member States, and I also thank you, Commissioner, for mentioning the Presidency document. A number of you have raised the issue of pricing and reimbursement of medicinal products. There is a widespread view that more transparency on pricing decisions by Member States for reimbursement proposals, as well as the pricing of medicinal products by the industry, would contribute to lowering prices. While pricing for proposals of reimbursement is an exclusive competence of the Member States, the only way forward is a voluntary exchange of information on Member States’ pricing and reimbursement models, and involvement of the industry. This was one of the objectives of the Council conclusions on innovation for the benefit of patients, adopted on 1 December 2014. Such information-sharing between the Member States’ competent authorities could take place in the network of competent authorities on pricing and reimbursement established in 2008. I can assure you that the Presidency will inform the Council about the views expressed during this debate in order to feed them into the ongoing debate in the Council and in other relevant fora on the issue of access to medicines. Thank you very much for today’s debate. It was a very important debate.

name: Przewodniczący. -
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. – Access to medicines is discussed in plenary at the initiative of our delegation in the face of social demand for the treatment of hepatitis C, although it has already been worked on, as it is a major problem both for the sustainability of health systems and for ensuring fairness; in short, we consider that it violates the fundamental right to health. We propose actions on several fronts, being one of the most important transparency in pricing. Drug prices should be made public in the Twenty-eight and all clinical trial results should be known to determine their true added value, as well as the percentage of research costs in the price of medicines. This requires a European agency to assess new technologies or at least to give new powers to the EME. Other measures would be coordinated purchases and auctions, with which there is already experience in Spain (Andalusia). However, this work cannot relieve Member States of the obligation to ensure access to new medicines, beyond promoting measures that ensure the sustainability of health systems.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – It is imperative that, as regards the market for medical products, in particular medicines, attention be paid to the fact that there are no clear and working guarantees for consumers/patients to access medical devices. We comment on the issue of access to innovative medicines, which is a problem in some Member States. I would like to stress that in Bulgaria there is a problem not only with access to innovative medicines, but in general with access to medicines and medical preparations. There are structures and informal relationships in Europe that distort the market at the expense of consumers, resulting in some pharmaceutical companies making colossal profits at the expense of citizens. In Bulgaria, a simple remedy for influenza and cold produced in Bulgaria cannot be sold 2 times more expensive than the same is sold in Serbia, Turkey or Greece. In Europe, there is a drug mafia that is bening at the expense of the people and at the expense of the high public spending on the purchase of medicines. It is our duty to react and put an end to this process because it is unfair. It is unacceptable in this way to do business on the backs of citizens. I'm sure there are drug cartels and monopolies, the question is, why are we still putting up with them?!

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. – Access to medicines is a major problem that undermines the sustainability of health systems and the fundamental right to health. The high cost of new drugs for the treatment of hepatitis C , which manage to cure the vast majority of patients treated without major side effects – makes the individual acquisition of the drugs unworkable by most people in need, highlighting the urgency of developing initiatives at European and national level to remedy it. The Spanish Socialists, drivers of this debate, propose actions on several fronts, in particular in relation to transparency in pricing. We therefore require that the prices of medicines in the Member States be reported, the cost and results of clinical trials to determine their true added value, as well as the percentage of the costs of price research. However, this work cannot relieve Member States of the obligation to ensure access to new medicines, beyond promoting measures that ensure the sustainability of health systems.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – With regard to the European Council and European Commission declaration on access to medicines, I consider it important to draw attention to the fact that everyone has the right of access to a safe medicine. In my opinion, this is already a very big problem in many EU Member States, which I would like to draw the attention of the Commission and the Council to. There are three factors that need to be looked at in relation to access to medicines: affordability, accessibility and, finally, innovation. In most cases, health care expenditure is covered by public funding, which is accompanied by private funding. Public spending on medicines in the EU increased by an average of 76% between 2000 and 2009, which has now fallen considerably due to austerity measures to tackle the economic crisis. The necessary level of expenditure should, of course, be considered. Accessibility varies from one Member State to another, but it can be seen that more and more medicines are being excluded from State aid, groups are excluded from insured persons or there is a shortage of medicines. In Hungary, these problems are also manifested by elderly people begging on the streets with their prescriptions in their hands in order to get the medicines they need. In conclusion, I would like to note that, in my opinion, the current pharmaceutical innovation model is unsustainable. Pharmaceutical companies spend 23% of their turnover on marketing in the EU and only 17% on R&D. I propose that these points be taken into account by the European Commission.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Europe is confronted with an increasing problem of shortages and unaffordability of medicines; it is not possible anymore to have the same reaction from the Commission indicating the areas of competence of the Member States. It is clear that both unaffordability and shortage impact directly on the outcome of patients’ treatment, endangering the status of public health in the Union.  The Commission needs to act and find the right balance between the protection of medical research and access to medicines. The prices required for some life-saving drugs are absolutely astronomical and the population cannot make use of the discovery if it is out of their reach. The Commission has to come out with immediate proposals to improve safe, affordable and timely access and availability of medicines for patients in the Union.
